tuple: ['Teacher: What kind of questions does the field of psychology explore?', 'The field of psychology explores questions like these.']
['Teacher: Can you provide some examples of the topics that fall under the study of psychology?', 'Psychology refers to the scientific study of the mind and behavior.']
['Teacher: How do psychologists use the scientific method to acquire knowledge in the study of psychology?', 'Psychologists use the scientific method to acquire knowledge.']

['Teacher: How does a psychologist go about testing their hypothesis using the scientific method?', 'To apply the scientific method, a researcher with a question about how or why something happens will propose a tentative explanation, called a hypothesis, to explain the phenomenon.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the role of evidence in supporting a scientific theory?', 'A hypothesis should fit into the context of a scientific theory, which is a broad explanation or group of explanations for some aspect of the natural world that is consistently supported by evidence over time.']
['Teacher: What is the significance of scientific theories in the field of psychology?', 'A theory is the best understanding we have of that part of the natural world.']

['What is the purpose of making observations or carrying out experiments in testing the validity of a hypothesis?', 'The researcher then makes observations or carries out an experiment to test the validity of the hypothesis.']

['What is the importance of replicating or building on the results of a study in the field of psychology?', 'Those results are then published or presented at research conferences so that others can replicate or build on the results.']
['Teacher: How do scientists determine what they can test in the field of psychology?', 'Scientists test that which is perceivable and measurable.']

['Teacher: Can you give me another example of a hypothesis in psychology that cannot be tested because it cannot be measured?', 'For example, the hypothesis that a bird sings because it is happy is not a hypothesis that can be tested since we have no way to measure the happiness of a bird.']

['Teacher: Why is the hypothesis that a bird sings because it is happy not testable in psychology?', 'We must ask a different question, perhaps about the brain state of the bird, since this can be measured.']

['Teacher: How can asking individuals about their feelings help in testing hypotheses in psychology?', 'However, we can ask individuals about whether they sing because they are happy since they are able to tell us.']
['Teacher: Can you explain why it is important for psychological science to be based on measurable data?', 'Thus, psychological science is empirical, based on measurable data.']

['Teacher: How does science typically limit its scope when it comes to the subjects it investigates?', 'In general, science deals only with matter and energy, that is, those things that can be measured, and it cannot arrive at knowledge about values and morality.']

['Teacher: Why is our scientific understanding of the mind limited, according to the student?', 'This is one reason why our scientific understanding of the mind is so limited, since thoughts, at least as we experience them, are neither matter nor energy.']
['Teacher: How does the scientific method contribute to our understanding of the mind?', 'The scientific method is also a form of empiricism.']

['Teacher: How does the scientific method help us gain knowledge about the mind?', 'An empirical method for acquiring knowledge is one based on observation, including experimentation, rather than a method based only on forms of logical argument or previous authorities.']
['Teacher: When did psychology become accepted as its own academic discipline?', 'It was not until the late 1800s that psychology became accepted as its own academic discipline.']

['Teacher: What field of study was responsible for exploring the workings of the mind before psychology emerged as its own academic discipline?', 'Before this time, the workings of the mind were considered under the auspices of philosophy.']

['Teacher: How does the understanding that behavior is rooted in biology contribute to the scientific nature of psychology?', 'Given that any behavior is, at its roots, biological, some areas of psychology take on aspects of a natural science like biology.']

['Teacher: How does the influence of our interactions with others relate to the study of psychology?', 'No biological organism exists in isolation, and our behavior is influenced by our interactions with others.']
['Can you provide an example of how the field of psychology incorporates elements of both natural science and social science?', 'Therefore, psychology is also a social science.']

['Teacher: What are some common reasons why students take their first psychology course?', 'Often, students take their first psychology course because they are interested in helping others and want to learn more about themselves and why they act the way they do.']

['Teacher: Can you give an example of a specific program of study that requires students to take a psychology course?', 'Sometimes, students take a psychology course because it either satisfies a general education requirement or is required for a program of study such as nursing or pre-med.']

["Teacher: What role does their initial interest in helping others and learning about themselves play in students' decision to declare psychology as their major?", 'Many of these students develop such an interest in the area that they go on to declare psychology as their major.']

['Teacher: Why do many students choose to declare psychology as their major?', 'As a result, psychology is one of the most popular majors on college campuses across the United States (Johnson & Lubin, 2011).']
['Teacher: What are some examples of well-known individuals who were psychology majors?', 'A number of well-known individuals were psychology majors.']

['Teacher: Can you provide some reasons why these well-known individuals chose to major in psychology?', 'Just a few famous names on this list are Facebook’s creator Mark Zuckerberg, television personality and political satirist Jon Stewart, actress Natalie Portman, and filmmaker Wes Craven (Halonen, 2011).']

["Teacher: What percentage of bachelor's degrees in the United States are in the discipline of psychology?", 'About 6 percent of all bachelor degrees granted in the United States are in the discipline of psychology (U.S. Department of Education, 2016).']
['Teacher: What are some of the reasons that make an education in psychology valuable?', 'An education in psychology is valuable for a number of reasons.']

['Teacher: How does studying psychology help students develop critical thinking skills and use the scientific method?', 'Psychology students hone critical thinking skills and are trained in the use of the scientific method.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how psychology students apply critical thinking skills in their studies and research?', 'Critical thinking is the active application of a set of skills to information for the understanding and evaluation of that information.']

['Teacher: Why is the evaluation of information an important skill for psychology students to develop?', 'The evaluation of information—assessing its reliability and usefulness— is an important skill in a world full of competing “facts,” many of which are designed to be misleading.']

['Teacher: How does maintaining an attitude of skepticism help psychology students in their studies and research?', 'For example, critical thinking involves maintaining an attitude of skepticism, recognizing internal biases, making use of logical thinking, asking appropriate questions, and making observations.']

['Why is the development of communication skills important for psychology students?', 'Psychology students also can develop better communication skills during the course of their undergraduate coursework (American Psychological Association, 2011).']

["What are some other ways that studying psychology can enhance students' scientific literacy and ability to evaluate information?", 'Together, these factors increase students’ scientific literacy and prepare students to critically evaluate the various sources of information they encounter.']

['Teacher: What are some broad-based skills that psychology students acquire?', 'In addition to these broad-based skills, psychology students come to understand the complex factors that shape one’s behavior.']

["Teacher: How does understanding the complex factors that shape one's behavior benefit psychology students?", 'They appreciate the interaction of our biology, our environment, and our experiences in determining who we are and how we will behave.']

['What are some basic principles that psychology students learn that guide how we think and behave?', 'They learn about basic principles that guide how we think and behave, and they come to recognize the tremendous diversity that exists across individuals and across cultural boundaries (American Psychological Association, 2011).']

['Teacher: When did psychology begin to develop experimentally, in comparison to the field of human physiology?', 'Psychology is a relatively young science with its experimental roots in the 19th century, compared, for example, to human physiology, which dates much earlier.']

['Teacher: Can you explain how the study of the mind was approached before the 19th century, particularly in relation to philosophy?', 'As mentioned, anyone interested in exploring issues related to the mind generally did so in a philosophical context prior to the 19th century.']

['Teacher: Who are the two scholars credited with being the founders of psychology as a distinct science and academic discipline in the 19th century?', 'Two 19th century scholars, Wilhelm Wundt and William James, are generally credited as being the founders of psychology as a science and academic discipline that was distinct from philosophy.']

['Teacher: What major changes have occurred in the field of psychology since the time of Wilhelm Wundt and William James?', 'This section will provide an overview of the shifts in paradigms that have influenced psychology from Wundt and James through today.']
['Teacher: How is Wilhelm Wundt commonly recognized in the field of psychology?', 'Wilhelm Wundt (1832–1920) was a German scientist who was the first person to be referred to as a psychologist.']
["Teacher: What was the title of Wilhelm Wundt's famous book that was published in 1873?", 'His famous book entitled Principles of Physiological Psychology was published in 1873.']

["Teacher: According to Wilhelm Wundt's views, what was the goal of psychology and how did he believe it could be achieved?", 'Wundt viewed psychology as a scientific study of conscious experience, and he believed that the goal of psychology was to identify components of consciousness and how those components combined to result in our conscious experience.']

['Teacher: How did Wilhelm Wundt view introspection and why did he consider it important in studying conscious experience?', 'Wundt used introspection (he called it “internal perception”), a process by which someone examines their own conscious experience as objectively as possible, making the human mind like any other aspect of nature that a scientist observed.']

['Teacher: Why did Wilhelm Wundt believe that it was essential for participants to understand the intentions of a psychological experiment?', 'He believed in the notion of voluntarism—that people have free will and should know the intentions of a psychological experiment if they were participating (Danziger, 1980).']

['Teacher: How did Wilhelm Wundt differentiate his version of introspection from other forms of introspection?', 'Wundt considered his version experimental introspection; he used instruments such as those that measured reaction time.']

["Teacher: What was the significance of Wilhelm Wundt's book Volkerpsychologie in expanding the scope of psychology?", 'He also wrote Volkerpsychologie in 1904 in which he suggested that psychology should include the study of culture, as it involves the study of people.']
["What did one of Wilhelm Wundt's students, Edward Titchener, go on to develop?", 'Edward Titchener, one of his students, went on to develop structuralism.']

["What was the main focus of the structuralism developed by Edward Titchener, one of Wilhelm Wundt's students?", 'Its focus was on the contents of mental processes rather than their function (Pickren & Rutherford, 2010).']

['Why was it significant for Wilhelm Wundt to establish his psychology laboratory at the University at Leipzig in 1879?', 'Wundt established his psychology laboratory at the University at Leipzig in 1879.']

['What kind of experiments did Wilhelm Wundt and his students conduct in his psychology laboratory at the University at Leipzig?', 'In this laboratory, Wundt and his students conducted experiments on, for example, reaction times.']

["Teacher: What was the purpose of administering a stimulus to the subject in Wilhelm Wundt's experiments on reaction times?", 'A subject, sometimes in a room isolated from the scientist, would receive a stimulus such as a light, image, or sound.']

["Teacher: What was the significance of recording the time to reaction in Wilhelm Wundt's experiments on reaction times?", 'The subject’s reaction to the stimulus would be to push a button, and an apparatus would record the time to reaction.']
['Teacher: How did Wilhelm Wundt measure reaction time in his experiments?', 'Wundt could measure reaction time to one-thousandth of a second (Nicolas & Ferrand, 1999).']

['Teacher: Who are some of the individuals who played a key role in establishing functional psychology?', 'William James, John Dewey, and Charles Sanders Peirce helped establish functional psychology.']

['What was the main factor that influenced the views of William James, John Dewey, and Charles Sanders Peirce in establishing functional psychology?', 'They accepted Darwin’s theory of evolution by natural selection and viewed this theory as an explanation of an organism’s characteristics.']

['What is the main concept that William James, John Dewey, and Charles Sanders Peirce focused on when establishing functional psychology?', 'Key to that theory is the idea that natural selection leads to organisms that are adapted to their environment, including their behavior.']

['What does adaptation refer to in the context of functional psychology?', 'Adaptation means that a trait of an organism has a function for the survival and reproduction of the individual, because it has been naturally selected.']

['What was one of the main goals of William James in his perspective of functionalism?', 'As James saw it, psychology’s purpose was to study the function of behavior in the world, and as such, his perspective was known as functionalism.']
['What was the focus of functionalism in relation to mental activities?', 'Functionalism focused on how mental activities helped an organism fit into its environment.']

['What was the main difference between functionalism and structuralism in terms of their focus in studying the mind?', 'Functionalism has a second, more subtle meaning in that functionalists were more interested in the operation of the whole mind rather than of its individual parts, which were the focus of structuralism.']

['What were some of the methods that William James used to study mental activities in functionalism?', 'Like Wundt, James believed that introspection could serve as one means by which someone might study mental activities, but James also relied on more objective measures, including the use of various recording devices, and examinations of concrete products of mental activities and of anatomy and physiology (Gordon, 1995).']
['Teacher: Can you tell me which theory of psychology we discussed last time?', 'Freud and Psychoanalytic']
['What is the name of the theory we discussed today?', 'Theory.']

["Teacher: Who was one of the most influential and well-known figures in psychology's history?", 'Perhaps one of the most influential and well-known figures in psychology’s history was Sigmund Freud.']

["Teacher: That's correct, but we're focusing on a different perspective in psychology. Can you tell me who is one of the key figures associated with functionalism?", 'Freud (1856–1939) was an Austrian neurologist who was fascinated by patients suffering from “hysteria” and neurosis.']

["Teacher: Yes, that's true. But can you tell me who is one of the key figures associated with functionalism?", 'Hysteria was an ancient diagnosis for disorders, primarily of women with a wide variety of symptoms, including physical symptoms and emotional disturbances, none of which had an apparent physical cause.']

["Teacher: That's an interesting point about Freud's theories. However, I'm asking about a different perspective called functionalism. Can you provide me with the name of one of the key figures associated with functionalism in psychology?", 'Freud theorized that many of his patients’ problems arose from the unconscious mind.']
['Who is one of the key figures associated with functionalism in psychology?', 'In Freud’s view, the unconscious mind was a repository of feelings and urges of which we have no awareness.']
['Who is associated with functionalism in psychology?', 'Gaining access to the unconscious, then, was crucial to the successful resolution of the patient’s problems.']

['What are some methods according to Freud that can be used to access the unconscious mind?', 'According to Freud, the unconscious mind could be accessed through dream analysis, by examinations of the first words that came to people’s minds, and through seemingly innocent slips of the tongue.']

["Can you explain how psychoanalytic theory, which focuses on the role of a person's unconscious and early childhood experiences, relates to the concept of functionalism in psychology?", 'Psychoanalytic theory focuses on the role of a person’s unconscious, as well as early childhood experiences, and this particular perspective dominated clinical psychology for several decades (Thorne & Henley, 2005).']

["Teacher: Can you explain how Freud's ideas influenced the study of lifespan development, personality, and therapy?", 'Freud’s ideas were influential, and you will learn more about them when you study lifespan development, personality, and therapy.']

["Teacher: Can you elaborate on how therapists' beliefs in the unconscious and the impact of early childhood experiences align with Freud's ideas?", 'For instance, many therapists believe strongly in the unconscious and the impact of early childhood experiences on the rest of a person’s life.']

['Teacher: Why is the method of psychoanalysis still used today in therapy, despite not being invented by Freud?', 'The method of psychoanalysis, which involves the patient talking about their experiences and selves, while not invented by Freud, was certainly popularized by him and is still used today.']
["What are some examples of Freud's ideas that are considered controversial by many?", 'Many of Freud’s other ideas, however, are controversial.']

["What reasons does Drew Westen give for arguing that criticisms of Freud's ideas are misplaced?", 'Drew Westen (1998) argues that many of the criticisms of Freud’s ideas are misplaced, in that they attack his older ideas without taking into account later writings.']

["What are some broad ideas introduced or developed by Freud that Drew Westen argues critics fail to consider when criticizing Freud's ideas?", 'Westen also argues that critics fail to consider the success of the broad ideas that Freud introduced or developed, such as the importance of childhood experiences in adult motivations, the role of unconscious versus conscious motivations in driving our behavior, the fact that motivations can cause conflicts that affect behavior, the effects of mental representations of ourselves and others in guiding our interactions, and the development of personality over time.']

['What evidence does Drew Westen provide to support his argument that there is subsequent research support for the broad ideas introduced or developed by Freud?', 'Westen identifies subsequent research support for all of these ideas.']

["Teacher: Can you provide some examples of modern empirical studies that have demonstrated the effectiveness of Freud's clinical approach?", 'More modern iterations of Freud’s clinical approach have been empirically demonstrated to be effective (Knekt et al., 2008; Shedler, 2010).']

["Teacher: Can you explain how the modern iterations of Freud's clinical approach involve examining unconscious aspects of the self and relationships?", 'Some current practices in psychotherapy involve examining unconscious aspects of the self and relationships, often through the relationship between the therapist and the client.']

["Teacher: Can you elaborate on the historical movements within psychology that Freud's contributions have been included in?", 'Freud’s historical significance and contributions to clinical practice merit his inclusion in a discussion of the historical movements within psychology.']

['Teacher: Who were the three German psychologists who immigrated to the United States in the early 20th century to escape Nazi Germany?', 'Max Wertheimer (1880–1943), Kurt Koffka (1886–1941), and Wolfgang Köhler (1887–1967) were three German psychologists who immigrated to the United States in the early 20th century to escape Nazi Germany.']

['What were some of the contributions of Max Wertheimer, Kurt Koffka, and Wolfgang Köhler to psychology in the United States?', 'These scholars are credited with introducing psychologists in the United States to various Gestalt principles.']

['What major emphasis does Gestalt psychology place on?', 'The word Gestalt roughly translates to “whole;” a major emphasis of Gestalt psychology deals with the fact that although a sensory experience can be broken down into individual parts, how those parts relate to each other as a whole is often what the individual responds to in perception.']

['What is the significance of the relationships between individual parts in Gestalt psychology?', 'For example, a song may be made up of individual notes played by different instruments, but the real nature of the song is perceived in the combinations of these notes as they form the melody, rhythm, and harmony.']

['What are some ways in which the perspective of Gestalt psychology contradicts the ideas of structuralism, particularly those proposed by Wundt?', 'In many ways, this particular perspective would have directly contradicted Wundt’s ideas of structuralism (Thorne & Henley, 2005).']

['Teacher: Why were Wertheimer, Koffka, Köhler, and the other scientists forced to abandon much of their work when they moved to the United States?', 'Unfortunately, in moving to the United States, these scientists were forced to abandon much of their work and were unable to continue to conduct research on a large scale.']

['What were some factors that prevented the principles of Gestalt psychology from being as influential in the United States as they had been in Germany?', 'These factors along with the rise of behaviorism (described next) in the United States prevented principles of Gestalt psychology from being as influential in the United States as they had been in their native Germany (Thorne & Henley, 2005).']
['What are some examples of Gestalt principles that are still influential today?', 'Despite these issues, several Gestalt principles are still very influential today.']

['What specific principle of Gestalt psychology became an important foundation in humanistic theory?', 'Considering the human individual as a whole rather than as a sum of individually measured parts became an important foundation in humanistic theory late in the century.']
['What area of psychology has been heavily influenced by the ideas of Gestalt psychology?', 'The ideas of Gestalt have continued to influence research on sensation and perception.']

["Teacher: That's correct! Now, let's focus on the Gestalt psychologists. Can you tell me who were the key figures associated with Gestalt Psychology?", 'Structuralism, Freud, and the Gestalt psychologists were all concerned in one way or another with describing and understanding inner experience.']

['Teacher: Very insightful! Can you specifically name the key figures associated with Gestalt Psychology?', 'But other researchers had concerns that inner experience could be a legitimate subject of scientific inquiry and chose instead to exclusively study behavior, the objectively observable outcome of mental processes.']

['Teacher: Who is the Russian physiologist known for his early work in the field of behavior?', 'Early work in the field of behavior was conducted by the Russian physiologist Ivan Pavlov (1849–1936).']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a conditioned reflex that Pavlov studied?', 'Pavlov studied a form of learning behavior called a conditioned reflex, in which an animal or human produced a reflex (unconscious) response to a stimulus and, over time, was conditioned to produce the response to a different stimulus that the experimenter associated with the original stimulus.']
['Teacher: What are some other types of responses that Pavlov studied besides salivation?', 'The reflex Pavlov worked with was salivation in response to the presence of food.']

['Teacher: Who is the American psychologist known for his role in the development of behaviorism and his experiments on classical conditioning with a young boy named Little Albert?', 'The salivation reflex could be elicited using a second stimulus, such as a specific sound, that was presented in association with the initial food stimulus several times.']

['Teacher: What is the name of the American psychologist known for his role in the development of behaviorism and his experiments on classical conditioning with a young boy named Little Albert?', 'Once the response to the second stimulus was “learned,” the food stimulus could be omitted.']

['Teacher: What is the general term used to describe the field of study that Pavlov, Watson, Skinner, and other psychologists focused on?', 'Pavlov’s “classical conditioning” is only one form of learning behavior studied by behaviorists.']

['Teacher: Who is the influential American psychologist that we are discussing in this passage?', 'John B. Watson (1878–1958) was an influential American psychologist whose most famous work occurred during the early 20th century at Johns Hopkins University.']

["Teacher: What was Watson's critique of the study of consciousness and why did he think it was flawed?", 'While Wundt and James were concerned with understanding conscious experience, Watson thought that the study of consciousness was flawed.']

['Teacher: Why did Watson prefer to focus on observable behavior rather than the study of consciousness?', 'Because he believed that objective analysis of the mind was impossible, Watson preferred to focus directly on observable behavior and try to bring that behavior under control.']

["Teacher: What is the name given to Watson's approach of observing and controlling behavior instead of studying the mind?", 'Watson was a major proponent of shifting the focus of psychology from the mind to behavior, and this approach of observing and controlling behavior came to be known as behaviorism.']

['Teacher: What are some major areas of study within behaviorism that interested Watson and other behaviorists?', 'A major object of study by behaviorists was learned behavior and its interaction with inborn qualities of the organism.']

['Teacher: How did behaviorists, like Watson, view the use of animals in their experiments and how did they believe it could be applied to human behavior?', 'Behaviorism commonly used animals in experiments under the assumption that what was learned using animal models could, to some degree, be applied to human behavior.']

['Teacher: What did Tolman believe could be investigated through the experimental and theoretical analysis of the determiners of rat behavior at a choice-point in a maze?', 'Indeed, Tolman (1938) stated, “I believe that everything important in psychology (except … such matters as involve society and words) can be investigated in essence through the continued experimental and theoretical analysis of the determiners of rat behavior at a choice-point in a maze.”']

["Teacher: Can you provide some insight into the dominant influence of behaviorism in experimental psychology for several decades and its lasting impact in today's context?", 'Behaviorism dominated experimental psychology for several decades, and its influence can still be felt today (Thorne & Henley, 2005).']

['What were some of the objective methods used by behaviorism to establish psychology as a scientific discipline?', 'Behaviorism is largely responsible for establishing psychology as a scientific discipline through its objective methods and especially experimentation.']
['What are some examples of how behaviorism is used in behavioral and cognitive-behavioral therapy?', 'In addition, it is used in behavioral and cognitive-behavioral therapy.']
['How does behaviorism influence behavior modification in classroom settings?', 'Behavior modification is commonly used in classroom settings.']
['How has behaviorism contributed to research on environmental influences on human behavior?', 'Behaviorism has also led to research on environmental influences on human behavior.']
["Teacher: That's correct! Can you briefly explain the key contributions B. F. Skinner made to the field of psychology?", 'B. F. Skinner (1904–1990) was an American psychologist.']
["Teacher: What was B. F. Skinner's focus within the field of psychology?", 'Like Watson, Skinner was a behaviorist, and he concentrated on how behavior was affected by its consequences.']
['Teacher: How did B. F. Skinner view reinforcement and punishment in relation to behavior?', 'Therefore, Skinner spoke of reinforcement and punishment as major factors in driving behavior.']

['What was the name of the chamber that B. F. Skinner developed for the study of modifying behavior through reinforcement and punishment?', 'As a part of his research, Skinner developed a chamber that allowed the careful study of the principles of modifying behavior through reinforcement and punishment.']

["What are some examples of behavior that can be modified using reinforcement and punishment in B. F. Skinner's operant conditioning chamber?", 'This device, known as an operant conditioning chamber (or more familiarly, a Skinner box), has remained a crucial resource for researchers studying behavior (Thorne & Henley, 2005).']

['Teacher: What is the purpose of the Skinner box and what kind of behavior indicator does it typically have?', 'The Skinner box is a chamber that isolates the subject from the external environment and has a behavior indicator such as a lever or a button.']

['What is the purpose of delivering a positive reinforcement or punishment in the Skinner box when the animal pushes the button or lever?', 'When the animal pushes the button or lever, the box is able to deliver a positive reinforcement of the behavior (such as food) or a punishment (such as a noise).']

["Teacher: How did Skinner's focus on positive and negative reinforcement of learned behaviors impact the field of psychology and why has its influence waned in recent years with the growth of research in cognitive psychology?", 'Skinner’s focus on positive and negative reinforcement of learned behaviors had a lasting influence in psychology that has waned somewhat since the growth of research in cognitive psychology.']

["What is conditioned learning and how is it still relevant in human behavioral modification despite the waning influence of Skinner's focus on positive and negative reinforcement?", 'Despite this, conditioned learning is still used in human behavioral modification (Greengrass, 2004).']

['Teacher: Why was American psychology dominated by behaviorism and psychoanalysis during the early 20th century?', 'During the early 20th century, American psychology was dominated by behaviorism and psychoanalysis.']

['Teacher: What specific aspects of behaviorism and psychoanalysis made some psychologists uncomfortable during the early 20th century?', 'However, some psychologists were uncomfortable with what they viewed as limited perspectives being so influential to the field.']

['Teacher: What alternative perspectives did psychologists seek during the early 20th century to challenge behaviorism and psychoanalysis?', 'They objected to the pessimism and determinism (all actions driven by the unconscious) of Freud.']

['Teacher: In response to the limitations of behaviorism and psychoanalysis, what new approach to psychology emerged during the early 20th century?', 'They also disliked the reductionism, or simplifying nature, of behaviorism.']

["Teacher: How did Maslow and Rogers's humanistic approach address the limitations of behaviorism and psychoanalysis?", 'Behaviorism is also deterministic at its core, because it sees human behavior as entirely determined by a combination of genetics and environment.']

["What were some key principles of Maslow and Rogers's humanistic approach that challenged the limitations of behaviorism and psychoanalysis?", 'Some psychologists began to form their own ideas that emphasized personal control, intentionality, and a true predisposition for “good” as important for our self-concept and our behavior.']
["What were some of the key features of Maslow and Rogers's humanistic approach to psychology?", 'Thus, humanism emerged.']
['What did Maslow and Rogers believe about the potential for good in all humans?', 'Humanism is a perspective within psychology that emphasizes the potential for good that is innate to all humans.']

['What were the main ideas and contributions of Abraham Maslow and Carl Rogers to the field of humanistic psychology?', 'Two of the most well-known proponents of humanistic psychology are Abraham Maslow and Carl Rogers (O’Hara, n.d.).']

['Teacher: Can you explain who Abraham Maslow was and what he is famous for in the field of psychology?', 'Abraham Maslow (1908–1970) was an American psychologist who is best known for proposing a hierarchy of human needs in motivating behavior.']

["Teacher: Please provide a brief overview of Abraham Maslow's hierarchy of human needs.", 'Although this concept will be discussed in more detail in a later chapter, a brief overview will be provided here.']

['What are some examples of higher-level needs that Maslow believed would motivate behavior once basic survival needs were met?', 'Maslow asserted that so long as basic needs necessary for survival were met (e.g., food, water, shelter), higher-level needs (e.g., social needs) would begin to motivate behavior.']

['What is the main idea behind self-actualization according to Maslow?', 'According to Maslow, the highest-level needs relate to self-actualization, a process by which we achieve our full potential.']

["What perspective is evident in Maslow's focus on the positive aspects of human nature?", 'Obviously, the focus on the positive aspects of human nature that are characteristic of the humanistic perspective is evident (Thorne & Henley, 2005).']

['What is one way in which humanistic psychologists differed from other psychologists in their research approach?', 'Humanistic psychologists rejected, on principle, the research approach based on reductionist experimentation in the tradition of the physical and biological sciences, because it missed the “whole” human being.']
['What is one key aspect of the humanistic research program advocated by Maslow and Rogers?', 'Beginning with Maslow and Rogers, there was an insistence on a humanistic research program.']

['What are some examples of quantitative research within the humanistic research program advocated by Maslow and Rogers?', 'This program has been largely qualitative (not measurement-based), but there exist a number of quantitative research strains within humanistic psychology, including research on happiness, self-concept, meditation, and the outcomes of humanistic psychotherapy (Friedman, 2008).']

['Teacher: What was one of the key beliefs shared by Carl Rogers and Maslow regarding human nature?', 'Carl Rogers (1902–1987) was also an American psychologist who, like Maslow, emphasized the potential for good that exists within all people.']

['Teacher: How did Carl Rogers approach therapy differently compared to traditional methods?', 'Rogers used a therapeutic technique known as client-centered therapy in helping his clients deal with problematic issues that resulted in their seeking psychotherapy.']

['What is one key aspect of client-centered therapy that distinguishes it from a psychoanalytic approach?', 'Unlike a psychoanalytic approach in which the therapist plays an important role in interpreting what conscious behavior reveals about the unconscious mind, client-centered therapy involves the patient taking a lead role in the therapy session.']

['What are the three features that Carl Rogers believed a therapist needed to display in client-centered therapy?', 'Rogers believed that a therapist needed to display three features to maximize the effectiveness of this particular approach: unconditional positive regard, genuineness, and empathy.']

['What does it mean for a therapist to display genuineness in client-centered therapy?', 'Unconditional positive regard refers to the fact that the therapist accepts their client for who they are, no matter what they might say.']

['What is the significance of empathy in client-centered therapy according to Carl Rogers?', 'Provided these factors, Rogers believed that people were more than capable of dealing with and working through their own issues (Thorne & Henley, 2005).']
['Teacher: How has humanism influenced the field of psychology?', 'Humanism has been influential to psychology as a whole.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how Maslow and Rogers have influenced scholars in the field of psychology?', 'Both Maslow and Rogers are well-known names among students of psychology (you will read more about both later in this text), and their ideas have influenced many scholars.']

["Teacher: How has Rogers' client-centered approach to therapy impacted the field of psychology?", 'Furthermore, Rogers’ client-centered approach to therapy is still commonly used in psychotherapeutic settings today (O’hara, n.d.)']

['Teacher: What led psychologists to shift their focus away from the mind for an extended period of time?', 'Behaviorism’s emphasis on objectivity and focus on external behavior had pulled psychologists’ attention away from the mind for a prolonged period of time.']

["What factors contributed to redirecting psychologists' attention back to the mind and the individual human?", 'The early work of the humanistic psychologists redirected attention to the individual human as a whole, and as a conscious and self-aware being.']

['Teacher: What were some emerging disciplinary perspectives in the 1950s that revived interest in the mind as a focus of scientific inquiry?', 'By the 1950s, new disciplinary perspectives in linguistics, neuroscience, and computer science were emerging, and these areas revived interest in the mind as a focus of scientific inquiry.']

['Teacher: How did the emerging disciplinary perspectives in linguistics, neuroscience, and computer science contribute to the revival of interest in the mind as a focus of scientific inquiry in the 1950s?', 'This particular perspective has come to be known as the cognitive revolution (Miller, 2003).']

["Teacher: What was the significance of Ulric Neisser's publication of the first textbook on Cognitive Psychology in 1967?", 'By 1967, Ulric Neisser published the first textbook entitled Cognitive Psychology, which served as a core text in cognitive psychology courses around the country (Thorne & Henley, 2005).']

['Teacher: Who was particularly influential in the early days of the cognitive revolution?', 'Although no one person is entirely responsible for starting the cognitive revolution, Noam Chomsky was very influential in the early days of this movement.']

['Teacher: Why was Noam Chomsky considered influential in the early days of the cognitive revolution?', 'Chomsky (1928–), an American linguist, was dissatisfied with the influence that behaviorism had had on psychology.']

["Teacher: What were Noam Chomsky's criticisms of behaviorism and its influence on psychology?", 'He believed that psychology’s focus on behavior was short-sighted and that the field had to re-incorporate mental functioning into its purview if it were to offer any meaningful contributions to understanding behavior (Miller, 2003).']

['Teacher: How did the cognitive revolution impact the relationship between European psychologists and their American counterparts?', 'European psychology had never really been as influenced by behaviorism as had American psychology; and thus, the cognitive revolution helped reestablish lines of communication between European psychologists and their American counterparts.']

['What were some other fields of science that psychologists began to cooperate with during the cognitive revolution?', 'Furthermore, psychologists began to cooperate with scientists in other fields, like anthropology, linguistics, computer science, and neuroscience, among others.']

['What is the term used to describe the interdisciplinary approach that psychologists and scientists from other fields adopted during the cognitive revolution?', 'This interdisciplinary approach often was referred to as the cognitive sciences, and the influence and prominence of this particular perspective resonates in modern-day psychology (Miller, 2003).']
['Teacher: How does culture influence individuals, groups, and society?', 'Culture impacts individuals, groups, and society.']

['What is one issue that researchers are trying to correct regarding the study of certain populations and their application of results to other populations?', 'An ongoing issue researchers are trying to correct is that certain populations have been over-studied and the results of these studies have been applied to other populations.']

['What are WEIRD societies and why have they been overstudied in the field of cultural psychology?', 'For example, Henrich, Heine, and Norenzayan discuss how WEIRD societies have been overstudied and the results have been wrongly applied to non-WEIRD societies (2010).']
['What are some characteristics of WEIRD societies?', 'WEIRD stands for western, educated, industrialized, rich, and democratic.']

['What are some examples of non-WEIRD societies mentioned by Henrich, Heine, and Norenzayan in their study?', 'Henrich, Heine, and Norenzayan found that there are many differences between people in the WEIRD group and people in less industrialized, less urban, and non-Western societies.']

["What are some specific differences between the WEIRD group and people in less industrialized, less urban, and non-Western societies, according to Henrich, Heine, and Norenzayan's study?", 'These differences occur in a variety of areas, including perception, cooperation, and moral reasoning.']
['What are some areas in which individuals from different cultures may vary according to their culture and environment?', 'That is, people vary depending on their culture and environment.']

['What is the purpose of conducting research with diverse populations in multicultural psychology?', 'Multicultural psychologists develop theories and conduct research with diverse populations, typically within one country.']

['What are some factors that cross-cultural psychologists consider when comparing populations across countries?', 'Cross-cultural psychologists compare populations across countries, such as participants from the United States compared to participants from China.']

['Teacher: Who was the first African American to receive a PhD in psychology in the United States?', 'In 1920, Francis Cecil Sumner was the first African American to receive a PhD in psychology in the United States.']

['Who was the first African American to establish a psychology degree program at Howard University?', 'Sumner established a psychology degree program at Howard University, leading to the education of a new generation of African American psychologists (Black, Spence, and Omari, 2004).']

['What was the focus of the work of early psychologists from diverse backgrounds?', 'Much of the work of early psychologists from diverse backgrounds was dedicated to challenging intelligence testing and promoting innovative educational methods for children.']
['What role did George I. Sanchez play in challenging intelligence testing?', 'George I. Sanchez contested such testing with Mexican American children.']

['What were some of the barriers that George I. Sanchez pointed out in intelligence testing for Mexican American children?', 'As a psychologist of Mexican heritage, he pointed out that the language and cultural barriers in testing were keeping children from equal opportunities (Guthrie, 1998).']

["What impact did George I. Sanchez's work have on segregated educational practices?", 'By 1940, he was teaching with his doctoral degree at University of Texas at Austin and challenging segregated educational practices (Romo, 1986).']

['Teacher: Can you tell me about two African American researchers and psychologists who have made significant contributions to the field of psychology?', 'Two famous African American researchers and psychologists are Mamie Phipps Clark and her husband, Kenneth Clark.']

['Teacher: What was the specific research conducted by Mamie Phipps Clark and Kenneth Clark on African American children and doll preference?', 'They are best known for their studies conducted on African American children and doll preference, research that was instrumental in the Brown v. Board of Education Supreme Court desegregation case.']

['What was the significance of the research conducted by Mamie Phipps Clark and Kenneth Clark on African American children and doll preference?', 'The Clarks applied their research to social services and opened the first child guidance center in Harlem (American Psychological Association, 2019).']

["Teacher: Can you please provide an overview of the impact of the Clarks' research on the Supreme Court decision?", 'The American Psychological Association has several ethnically based organizations for professional psychologists that facilitate interactions among members.']

['Teacher: How do the ethnically based organizations within the American Psychological Association contribute to the growth of research on the interplay between culture and psychology?', 'Since psychologists belonging to specific ethnic groups or cultures have the most interest in studying the psychology of their communities, these organizations provide an opportunity for the growth of research on the interplay between culture and psychology.']

['Teacher: In what ways have women been contributing to psychology since its inception as a field of study?', 'Although rarely given credit, women have been contributing to psychology since its inception as a field of study.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a significant contribution made by a woman to psychology during its early stages as a field of study?', 'In 1894, Margaret Floy Washburn was the first woman awarded the doctoral degree in psychology.']

["Teacher: How did Margaret Floy Washburn's book, The Animal Mind, impact the field of psychology during its early stages?", 'She wrote The Animal Mind: A Textbook of Comparative Psychology, and it was the standard in the field for over 20 years.']

["Teacher: How did Mary Whiton Calkins' experience with Harvard University highlight the challenges faced by women in pursuing a career in psychology during the early stages of the field?", 'In the mid 1890s, Mary Whiton Calkins completed all requirements toward the PhD in psychology, but Harvard University refused to award her that degree because she was a woman.']

["Teacher: How did Mary Whiton Calkins' experience with William James show the support she had from respected psychologists during that time?", 'She had been taught and mentored by William James, who tried and failed to convince Harvard to award her the doctoral degree.']

['What were some of the research topics that Mary Whiton Calkins focused on in her work in psychology?', 'Her memory research studied primacy and recency (Madigan & O’Hara, 1992), and she also wrote about how structuralism and functionalism both explained self-psychology (Calkins, 1906).']

["Teacher: Who conducted a study that she considered to be a sequel to John B. Watson's study of Little Albert?", 'Another influential woman, Mary Cover Jones, conducted a study she considered to be a sequel to John B. Watson’s study of Little Albert (you’ll learn about this study in the chapter on Learning).']

["Teacher: What study did Mary Cover Jones consider to be a sequel to John B. Watson's study of Little Albert?", 'Jones unconditioned fear in Little Peter, who had been afraid of rabbits (Jones, 1924).']

['Teacher: Can you please provide some examples of ethnic minority women who made significant contributions to the field of psychology?', 'Ethnic minority women contributing to the field of psychology include Martha Bernal and Inez Beverly Prosser; their studies were related to education.']

["Teacher: Can you explain what specific areas of education Martha Bernal's research focused on?", 'Bernal, the first Latina to earn her doctoral degree in psychology (1962) conducted much of her research with Mexican American children.']

["Teacher: Can you describe some of the key findings or outcomes of Martha Bernal's research with Mexican American children?", 'Prosser was the first African American woman awarded the PhD in 1933 at the University of Cincinnati (Benjamin, Henry, & McMahon, 2005).']

['Teacher: How does contemporary psychology relate to the historical perspectives discussed in the preceding section?', 'Contemporary psychology is a diverse field that is influenced by all of the historical perspectives described in the preceding section.']

['What is an example of the diversity within the American Psychological Association (APA) that reflects the diversity in contemporary psychology?', 'Reflective of the discipline’s diversity is the diversity seen within the American Psychological Association (APA).']

['What are some specific ways in which the American Psychological Association (APA) reflects the diversity within contemporary psychology?', 'The APA is a professional organization representing psychologists in the United States.']

['What are some ways in which the American Psychological Association (APA) fulfills its mission of advancing and disseminating psychological knowledge?', 'The APA is the largest organization of psychologists in the world, and its mission is to advance and disseminate psychological knowledge for the betterment of people.']

['What are some examples of the wide variety of specialties represented within the 54 divisions of the American Psychological Association (APA)?', 'There are 54 divisions within the APA, representing a wide variety of specialties that range from Societies for the Psychology of Religion and Spirituality to Exercise and Sport Psychology to Behavioral Neuroscience and Comparative Psychology.']

['What are some examples of the different backgrounds and professions of the members within the American Psychological Association (APA)?', 'Reflecting the diversity of the field of psychology itself, members, affiliate members, and associate members span the spectrum from students to doctoral-level psychologists, and come from a variety of places including educational settings, criminal justice, hospitals, the armed forces, and industry (American Psychological Association, 2014).']
['Who was the first president of the American Psychological Association (APA)?', 'G. Stanley Hall was the first president of the APA.']

["What were some of G. Stanley Hall's roles before becoming the first president of the American Psychological Association (APA)?", 'Before he earned his doctoral degree, he was an adjunct instructor at Wilberforce University, a historically Black college/university (HBCU), while serving as faculty at Antioch College.']
["What is significant about G. Stanley Hall's work under William James?", 'Hall went on to work under William James, earning his PhD.']

['Who was the first president of Clark University in Massachusetts?', 'Eventually, he became the first president of Clark University in Massachusetts when it was founded (Pickren & Rutherford, 2010).']

['Teacher: When was the Association for Psychological Science (APS) founded and what is its purpose?', 'The Association for Psychological Science (APS) was founded in 1988 and seeks to advance the scientific orientation of psychology.']

['What led to disagreements between the scientific and clinical branches of psychology within the APA?', 'Its founding resulted from disagreements between members of the scientific and clinical branches of psychology within the APA.']

['What are some of the activities that the Association for Psychological Science (APS) engages in, besides publishing research journals?', 'The APS publishes five research journals and engages in education and advocacy with funding agencies.']

['Teacher: How does the international presence of the Association for Psychological Science (APS) compare to its membership in the United States?', 'A significant proportion of its members are international, although the majority is located in the United States.']

['What is the purpose of the National Latina/o Psychological Association (NLPA), the Asian American Psychological Association (AAPA), the Association of Black Psychologists (ABPsi), and the Society of Indian Psychologists (SIP)?', 'Other organizations provide networking and collaboration opportunities for professionals of several ethnic or racial groups working in psychology, such as the National Latina/o Psychological Association (NLPA), the Asian American Psychological Association (AAPA), the Association of Black Psychologists (ABPsi), and the Society of Indian Psychologists (SIP).']

['What are some specific communities that the National Latina/o Psychological Association (NLPA), the Asian American Psychological Association (AAPA), the Association of Black Psychologists (ABPsi), and the Society of Indian Psychologists (SIP) focus on?', 'Most of these groups are also dedicated to studying psychological and social issues within their specific communities.']

['Teacher: What does this section aim to provide?', 'This section will provide an overview of the major subdivisions within psychology today in the order in which they are introduced throughout the remainder of this textbook.']

['Teacher: How does the section on contemporary psychology in this textbook provide insights into the major areas of research and practice?', 'This is not meant to be an exhaustive listing, but it will provide insight into the major areas of research and practice of modern-day psychologists.']
['Teacher: What does biopsychology explore in terms of our behavior?', 'As the name suggests, biopsychology explores how our biology influences our behavior.']

['What specific aspect of the nervous system do biological psychologists study in relation to behavior?', 'While biological psychology is a broad field, many biological psychologists want to understand how the structure and function of the nervous system is related to behavior.']

['What are some research strategies that biological psychologists often use to study the relationship between the nervous system and behavior?', 'As such, they often combine the research strategies of both psychologists and physiologists to accomplish this goal (as discussed in Carlson, 2013).']

['Teacher: What are some domains that fall under the research interests of biological psychologists?', 'The research interests of biological psychologists span a number of domains, including but not limited to, sensory and motor systems, sleep, drug use and abuse, ingestive behavior, reproductive behavior, neurodevelopment, plasticity of the nervous system, and biological correlates of psychological disorders.']

['What are some examples of professions or fields that are involved in the research of biological psychology?', 'Given the broad areas of interest falling under the purview of biological psychology, it will probably come as no surprise that individuals from all sorts of backgrounds are involved in this research, including biologists, medical professionals, physiologists, and chemists.']

['What is the relationship between biological psychology and neuroscience?', 'This interdisciplinary approach is often referred to as neuroscience, of which biological psychology is a component (Carlson, 2013).']

['Teacher: What is the difference between the focus of biopsychology and evolutionary psychology in studying behavior?', 'While biopsychology typically focuses on the immediate causes of behavior based in the physiology of a human or other animal, evolutionary psychology seeks to study the ultimate biological causes of behavior.']

['Teacher: How does evolutionary psychology differentiate itself from biopsychology with regard to understanding behavior in terms of biological causes?', 'To the extent that a behavior is impacted by genetics, a behavior, like any anatomical characteristic of a human or animal, will demonstrate adaption to its surroundings.']

['Teacher: How do biopsychology and evolutionary psychology differ in their consideration of the impact of surroundings on behavior?', 'These surroundings include the physical environment and, since interactions between organisms can be important to survival and reproduction, the social environment.']

['Teacher: Who is credited with the development of the theory of evolution by natural selection and thus, the originator of studying behavior in the context of evolution?', 'The study of behavior in the context of evolution has its origins with Charles Darwin, the co-discoverer of the theory of evolution by natural selection.']

['Teacher: Why is Charles Darwin considered the originator of studying behavior in the context of evolution?', 'Darwin was well aware that behaviors should be adaptive and wrote books titled, The Descent of Man (1871) and The Expression of the Emotions in Man and Animals (1872), to explore this field.']

["Teacher: What field of psychology has experienced a renewed interest in the study of humans' evolutionary psychology?", 'Evolutionary psychology, and specifically, the evolutionary psychology of humans, has enjoyed a resurgence in recent decades.']

['Teacher: What is a key requirement for a behavior to be subject to evolution by natural selection?', 'To be subject to evolution by natural selection, a behavior must have a significant genetic cause.']

['What is the significance of genetic differences among human groups in relation to the expression of behavior across different cultures?', 'In general, we expect all human cultures to express a behavior if it is caused genetically, since the genetic differences among human groups are small.']

['Teacher: How do evolutionary psychologists typically approach the study of behavior in relation to evolutionary theory?', 'The approach taken by most evolutionary psychologists is to predict the outcome of a behavior in a particular situation based on evolutionary theory and then to make observations, or conduct experiments, to determine whether the results match the theory.']

['What are some limitations or criticisms of studies that aim to determine whether a behavior is adaptive based on evolutionary theory and observations?', 'It is important to recognize that these types of studies are not strong evidence that a behavior is adaptive, since they lack information that the behavior is in some part genetic and not entirely cultural (Endler, 1986).']

['What are some challenges that make it difficult to demonstrate that a behavior is naturally selected, especially in humans?', 'Demonstrating that a trait, especially in humans, is naturally selected is extraordinarily difficult; perhaps for this reason, some evolutionary psychologists are content to assume the behaviors they study have genetic determinants (Confer et al., 2010).']

['Teacher: What is one drawback of evolutionary psychology in terms of our understanding of the traits we possess today?', 'One other drawback of evolutionary psychology is that the traits that we possess now evolved under environmental and social conditions far back in human history, and we have a poor understanding of what these conditions were.']

['What is one reason why the poor understanding of the environmental and social conditions in human history makes it difficult to predict what is adaptive for a behavior according to evolutionary psychology?', 'This makes predictions about what is adaptive for a behavior difficult.']

['What is one challenge in determining the adaptiveness of behavioral traits based on evolutionary psychology?', 'Behavioral traits need not be adaptive under current conditions, only under the conditions of the past when they evolved, about which we can only hypothesize.']
['Teacher: Can you provide some examples of areas of human behavior for which evolution can make predictions?', 'There are many areas of human behavior for which evolution can make predictions.']

["Teacher: That's correct! Can you explain how evolutionary psychology can explain the influence of evolution on memory, mate choice, relationships between kin, friendship and cooperation, parenting, social organization, and status?", 'Examples include memory, mate choice, relationships between kin, friendship and cooperation, parenting, social organization, and status (Confer et al., 2010).']

['Teacher: How have evolutionary psychologists been able to find experimental correspondence between observations and expectations in their research?', 'Evolutionary psychologists have had success in finding experimental correspondence between observations and expectations.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a study conducted by evolutionary psychologists that demonstrates the experimental correspondence between observations and expectations?', 'In one example, in a study of mate preference differences between men and women that spanned 37 cultures, Buss (1989) found that women valued earning potential factors greater than men, and men valued potential reproductive factors (youth and attractiveness) greater than women in their prospective mates.']

['Teacher: What were the main findings of the study conducted by Buss (1989) on mate preference differences between men and women in 37 cultures?', 'In general, the predictions were in line with the predictions of evolution, although there were deviations in some cultures.']

['Teacher: What is the common focus of scientists in the field of sensation and perception?', 'Scientists interested in both physiological aspects of sensory systems as well as in the psychological experience of sensory information work within the area of sensation and perception.']

['Teacher: How does the field of sensation and perception encompass both physiological and psychological aspects of sensory systems?', 'As such, sensation and perception research is also quite interdisciplinary.']

['Teacher: How does the interdisciplinary nature of sensation and perception research allow scientists to study the experience of sensory information in various contexts, such as walking between buildings?', 'Imagine walking between buildings as you move from one class to another.']

['Teacher: How does the sensory information that you receive while walking between buildings contribute to your overall perception of the environment?', 'You are inundated with sights, sounds, touch sensations, and smells.']

['Teacher: What role does the information received through your senses play in your overall perception of the environment while walking between buildings?', 'You also experience the temperature of the air around you and maintain your balance as you make your way.']

['What are some specific factors that someone studying sensation and perception might be interested in when observing a person walking between buildings?', 'These are all factors of interest to someone working in the domain of sensation and perception.']

['Teacher: Could you explain the main idea of the chapter on studies in sensation and perception?', 'As described in a later chapter that focuses on the results of studies in sensation and perception, our experience of our world is not as simple as the sum total of all of the sensory information (or sensations) together.']

['Teacher: What factors influence our experience of the world according to the chapter on studies in sensation and perception?', 'Rather, our experience (or perception) is complex and is influenced by where we focus our attention, our previous experiences, and even our cultural backgrounds.']

['Teacher: What event sparked the cognitive revolution in psychology, and what was the outcome of this shift in focus?', 'As mentioned in the previous section, the cognitive revolution created an impetus for psychologists to focus their attention on better understanding the mind and mental processes that underlie behavior.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how the cognitive revolution influenced the focus of psychologists in understanding behavior?', 'Thus, cognitive psychology is the area of psychology that focuses on studying cognitions, or thoughts, and their relationship to our experiences and our actions.']

['Teacher: How does cognitive psychology differ from biological psychology in terms of its focus and scope?', 'Like biological psychology, cognitive psychology is broad in its scope and often involves collaborations among people from a diverse range of disciplinary backgrounds.']

['Teacher: What does the term "cognitive science" refer to and why is it used to describe the field of cognitive psychology?', 'This has led some to coin the term cognitive science to describe the interdisciplinary nature of this area of research (Miller, 2003).']

['Teacher: What are some examples of the research interests that cognitive psychologists focus on?', 'Cognitive psychologists have research interests that span a spectrum of topics, ranging from attention to problem solving to language to memory.']
['Teacher: Can you provide some examples of the approaches that cognitive psychologists use when studying these topics?', 'The approaches used in studying these topics are equally diverse.']

['Teacher: How does cognitive psychology relate to the topics covered in this textbook?', 'Given such diversity, cognitive psychology is not captured in one chapter of this text per se; rather, various concepts related to cognitive psychology will be covered in relevant portions of the chapters in this text on sensation and perception, thinking and intelligence, memory, lifespan development, social psychology, and therapy.']
['Teacher: What does developmental psychology involve?', 'Developmental psychology is the scientific study of development across a lifespan.']
['What are some specific aspects of physical maturation that developmental psychologists study?', 'Developmental psychologists are interested in processes related to physical maturation.']

['Teacher: Can you provide some examples of the psychological attributes that developmental psychologists study besides physical changes associated with aging?', 'However, their focus is not limited to the physical changes associated with aging, as they also focus on changes in cognitive skills, moral reasoning, social behavior, and other psychological attributes.']

['Teacher: What was the main focus of early developmental psychologists?', 'Early developmental psychologists focused primarily on changes that occurred through reaching adulthood, providing enormous insight into the differences in physical, cognitive, and social capacities that exist between very young children and adults.']

["Teacher: What specific concept did Jean Piaget's research on object permanence illustrate in relation to young children's cognitive development?", 'For instance, research by Jean Piaget demonstrated that very young children do not demonstrate object permanence.']

['What is the significance of understanding object permanence in the cognitive development of young children?', 'Object permanence refers to the understanding that physical things continue to exist, even if they are hidden from us.']

['Why is it important for young children to develop an understanding of object permanence?', 'If you were to show an adult a toy, and then hide it behind a curtain, the adult knows that the toy still exists.']
['What does the concept of object permanence tell us about the cognitive development of very young infants?', 'However, very young infants act as if a hidden object no longer exists.']

['What does the controversy surrounding the age at which object permanence is achieved tell us about the research in developmental psychology?', 'The age at which object permanence is achieved is somewhat controversial (Munakata, McClelland, Johnson, and Siegler, 1997).']

['Teacher: What is the emerging interest in the field of developmental psychology when it comes to studying changes that occur later in life?', 'While Piaget was focused on cognitive changes during infancy and childhood as we move to adulthood, there is an increasing interest in extending research into the changes that occur much later in life.']

['What are some potential reasons for the increasing interest in studying changes that occur later in life within the field of developmental psychology?', 'This may be reflective of changing population demographics of developed nations as a whole.']

['Why might the changing demographics of developed nations contribute to the increasing interest in studying changes that occur later in life within the field of developmental psychology?', 'As more and more people live longer lives, the number of people of advanced age will continue to increase.']

['What impact does the increasing number of people of advanced age have on the study of changes that occur later in life within the field of developmental psychology?', 'Indeed, it is estimated that there were just over 40 million people aged 65 or older living in the United States in 2010.']

['What does this estimated increase in the number of people aged 65 or older in the United States suggest about future research opportunities in the field of developmental psychology?', 'However, by 2020, this number is expected to increase to about 55 million.']

['What does the estimated increase in the number of people aged 65 or older in the United States by the year 2050 suggest about future research opportunities in the field of developmental psychology?', 'By the year 2050, it is estimated that nearly 90 million people in this country will be 65 or older (Department of Health and Human Services, n.d.).']
['Teacher: What is the main focus of personality psychology?', 'Personality psychology focuses on patterns of thoughts and behaviors that make each individual unique.']

['Teacher: Who are some of the individuals that have contributed to early theories of personality in the field of personality psychology?', 'Several individuals (e.g., Freud and Maslow) that we have already discussed in our historical overview of psychology, and the American psychologist Gordon Allport, contributed to early theories of personality.']

["Teacher: What was the goal of the early theorists in personality psychology regarding the development of an individual's personality?", 'These early theorists attempted to explain how an individual’s personality develops from their given perspective.']

["Teacher: How did Freud's perspective explain the development of an individual's personality?", 'For example, Freud proposed that personality arose as conflicts between the conscious and unconscious parts of the mind were carried out over the lifespan.']

["Teacher: What were some of the key concepts in Freud's theory of psychosexual development?", 'Specifically, Freud theorized that an individual went through various psychosexual stages of development.']

['Teacher: How did Freud propose that adult personality would be influenced by the resolution of various conflicts in different stages of psychosexual development?', 'According to Freud, adult personality would result from the resolution of various conflicts that centered on the migration of erogenous (or sexual pleasure-producing) zones from the oral (mouth) to the anus to the phallus to the genitals.']

["Teacher: Why was Freud's idea about the migration of erogenous zones controversial and difficult to test experimentally?", 'Like many of Freud’s theories, this particular idea was controversial and did not lend itself to experimental tests (Person, 1980).']
['Teacher: How has the study of personality evolved over time?', 'More recently, the study of personality has taken on a more quantitative approach.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the shift from explaining how personality arises to focusing on identifying and measuring personality traits in the study of personality?', 'Rather than explaining how personality arises, research is focused on identifying personality traits, measuring these traits, and determining how these traits interact in a particular context to determine how a person will behave in any given situation.']

['Teacher: What are some of the main reasons why researchers focus on identifying and measuring personality traits in the study of personality?', 'Personality traits are relatively consistent patterns of thought and behavior, and many have proposed that five trait dimensions are sufficient to capture the variations in personality seen across individuals.']

['Teacher: Why are personality traits considered to be relatively consistent patterns of thought and behavior?', 'These five dimensions are known as the “Big Five” or the Five Factor model, and include dimensions of conscientiousness, agreeableness, neuroticism, openness, and extraversion.']

['Teacher: What evidence supports the idea that personality traits are relatively stable over the lifespan and influenced by genetics?', 'Each of these traits has been demonstrated to be relatively stable over the lifespan (e.g., Rantanen, Metsäpelto, Feldt, Pulkinnen, and Kokko, 2007; Soldz & Vaillant, 1999; McCrae & Costa, 2008) and is influenced by genetics (e.g., Jang, Livesly, and Vernon, 1996).']
['Teacher: What is the main focus of social psychology?', 'Social psychology focuses on how we interact with and relate to others.']

['Teacher: Can you provide examples of the specific topics that social psychologists research?', 'Social psychologists conduct research on a wide variety of topics that include differences in how we explain our own behavior versus how we explain the behaviors of others, prejudice, and attraction, and how we resolve interpersonal conflicts.']

['Teacher: How do social psychologists study the impact of being in social situations on our behavior and thinking?', 'Social psychologists have also sought to determine how being among other people changes our own behavior and patterns of thinking.']

['Teacher: Can you give me some examples of the interesting social psychological research that you mentioned will be covered in a later chapter of the textbook?', 'There are many interesting examples of social psychological research, and you will read about many of these in a later chapter of this textbook.']

['Teacher: What is the focus of the controversial psychological study that you will be introduced to before reading about the interesting social psychological research in the later chapter?', 'Until then, you will be introduced to one of the most controversial psychological studies ever conducted.']

["What are some key findings from Stanley Milgram's research on obedience that you will learn about in the upcoming chapter?", 'Stanley Milgram was an American social psychologist who is most famous for research that he conducted on obedience.']

["How did Stanley Milgram's research on obedience connect to the trial of Adolf Eichmann after the holocaust?", 'After the holocaust, in 1961, a Nazi war criminal, Adolf Eichmann, who was accused of committing mass atrocities, was put on trial.']

["What role did Stanley Milgram's research on obedience play in addressing the question of how German soldiers were capable of torturing prisoners in concentration camps?", 'Many people wondered how German soldiers were capable of torturing prisoners in concentration camps, and they were unsatisfied with the excuses given by soldiers that they were simply following orders.']

["What did Stanley Milgram's research on obedience reveal about the willingness of individuals to inflict pain and suffering on others?", 'At the time, most psychologists agreed that few people would be willing to inflict such extraordinary pain and suffering, simply because they were obeying orders.']
['What method did Stanley Milgram use to conduct his research on obedience?', 'Milgram decided to conduct research to determine whether or not this was true.']

["What were the ethical concerns surrounding Stanley Milgram's research on obedience?", 'As you will read later in the text, Milgram found that nearly two-thirds of his participants were willing to deliver what they believed to be lethal shocks to another person, simply because they were instructed to do so by an authority figure (in this case, a man dressed in a lab coat).']

["What were some of the criticisms or controversies regarding Stanley Milgram's research on obedience?", 'This was in spite of the fact that participants received payment for simply showing up for the research study and could have chosen not to inflict pain or more serious consequences on another person by withdrawing from the study.']

['Why was Stanley Milgram\'s experiment considered a "clever ruse"?', 'No one was actually hurt or harmed in any way, Milgram’s experiment was a clever ruse that took advantage of research confederates, those who pretend to be participants in a research study who are actually working for the researcher and have clear, specific directions on how to behave during the research study (Hock, 2009).']

["What impact did Stanley Milgram's research on obedience have on the development of ethical guidelines for conducting psychological research?", 'Milgram’s and others’ studies that involved deception and potential emotional harm to study participants catalyzed the development of ethical guidelines for conducting psychological research that discourage the use of deception of research subjects, unless it can be argued not to cause harm and, in general, requiring informed consent of participants.']

['Teacher: What is the main focus of Industrial-Organizational Psychology?', 'Industrial-Organizational psychology (I-O psychology) is a subfield of psychology that applies psychological theories, principles, and research findings in industrial and organizational settings.']
