['Teacher: Can you elaborate on the stress management techniques used in cognitive-behavioral therapy for insomnia?', 'Cognitive-behavioral therapy has been demonstrated to be quite effective in treating insomnia (Savard, Simard, Ivers, & Morin, 2005; Williams, Roth, Vatthauer, & McCrae, 2013).']
['Teacher: Can you define what a parasomnia is?', 'A parasomnia is one of a group of sleep disorders in which unwanted, disruptive motor activity and/or experiences during sleep play a role.']
['Teacher: Great job! Can you give me an example of a parasomnia that occurs during the NREM phase of sleep?', 'Parasomnias can occur in either REM or NREM phases of sleep.']

['Teacher: Excellent! Can you provide an example of a parasomnia that occurs during the REM phase of sleep?', 'Sleepwalking, restless leg syndrome, and night terrors are all examples of parasomnias (Mahowald & Schenck, 2000).']

['Teacher: What is the term used to describe the phenomenon where a sleeper engages in relatively complex behaviors such as wandering about or driving an automobile?', 'In sleepwalking, or somnambulism, the sleeper engages in relatively complex behaviors ranging from wandering about to driving an automobile.']

['What are some examples of the relatively complex behaviors that can occur during sleepwalking?', 'During periods of sleepwalking, sleepers often have their eyes open, but they are not responsive to attempts to communicate with them.']

['What sleep stage does sleepwalking most often occur in?', 'Sleepwalking most often occurs during slow-wave sleep, but it can occur at any time during a sleep period in some affected individuals (Mahowald & Schenck, 2000).']

['Teacher: What are some examples of pharmacotherapies used historically to treat somnambulism?', 'Historically, somnambulism has been treated with a variety of pharmacotherapies ranging from benzodiazepines to antidepressants.']
['Teacher: Can you explain why the success rate of pharmacotherapies used historically to treat somnambulism is questionable?', 'However, the success rate of such treatments is questionable.']

['Teacher: What did Guilleminault et al. (2005) find in regards to the use of benzodiazepines for treating sleepwalking?', 'Guilleminault et al. (2005) found that sleepwalking was not alleviated with the use of benzodiazepines.']

['Teacher: What did Guilleminault et al. (2005) observe regarding the relationship between sleep-related breathing problems and sleepwalking in their study?', 'However, all of their somnambulistic patients who also suffered from sleep-related breathing problems showed a marked decrease in sleepwalking when their breathing problems were effectively treated.']

['Teacher: What happens when the muscle paralysis associated with the REM sleep phase does not occur in REM sleep behavior disorder (RBD)?', 'REM sleep behavior disorder (RBD) occurs when the muscle paralysis associated with the REM sleep phase does not occur.']

['Why do individuals who suffer from RBD have high levels of physical activity during REM sleep?', 'Individuals who suffer from RBD have high levels of physical activity during REM sleep, especially during disturbing dreams.']

['What are some examples of the physical behaviors exhibited during REM sleep in individuals with RBD?', 'These behaviors vary widely, but they can include kicking, punching, scratching, yelling, and behaving like an animal that has been frightened or attacked.']

['What are some potential consequences of the physical behaviors exhibited during REM sleep in individuals with RBD?', 'People who suffer from this disorder can injure themselves or their sleeping partners when engaging in these behaviors.']

['Teacher: How does REM sleep behavior disorder (RBD) affect the quality of sleep for individuals who experience it?', 'Furthermore, these types of behaviors ultimately disrupt sleep, although affected individuals have no memories that these behaviors have occurred (Arnulf, 2012).']

['Teacher: What are some of the neurodegenerative diseases associated with REM Sleep Behavior Disorder (RBD)?', 'This disorder is associated with a number of neurodegenerative diseases such as Parkinson’s disease.']

['What are some potential benefits of identifying REM Sleep Behavior Disorder (RBD) in relation to neurodegenerative diseases?', 'In fact, this relationship is so robust that some view the presence of RBD as a potential aid in the diagnosis and treatment of a number of neurodegenerative diseases (Ferini-Strambi, 2011).']
['What is one commonly used medication for the treatment of REM Sleep Behavior Disorder (RBD)?', 'Clonazepam, an anti-anxiety medication with sedative properties, is most often used to treat RBD.']

['What is the role of melatonin in the treatment of REM Sleep Behavior Disorder (RBD)?', 'It is administered alone or in conjunction with doses of melatonin (the hormone secreted by the pineal gland).']

['What are some modifications that can be made to the sleeping environment to ensure safety for individuals with REM Sleep Behavior Disorder (RBD)?', 'As part of treatment, the sleeping environment is often modified to make it a safer place for those suffering from RBD (Zangini, Calandra-Buonaura, Grimaldi, & Cortelli, 2011).']

['Teacher: What kind of sensations does a person with restless leg syndrome experience in their legs during periods of inactivity or when trying to fall asleep?', 'A person with restless leg syndrome has uncomfortable sensations in the legs during periods of inactivity or when trying to fall asleep.']

['What is one common method that individuals with restless leg syndrome use to relieve discomfort in their legs?', 'This discomfort is relieved by deliberately moving the legs, which, not surprisingly, contributes to difficulty in falling or staying asleep.']

['What are some medical conditions that have been associated with restless leg syndrome?', 'Restless leg syndrome is quite common and has been associated with a number of other medical diagnoses, such as chronic kidney disease and diabetes (Mahowald & Schenck, 2000).']

['What are some common drugs used to treat restless leg syndrome?', 'There are a variety of drugs that treat restless leg syndrome: benzodiazepines, opiates, and anticonvulsants (Restless Legs Syndrome Foundation, n.d.).']

['Teacher: What are some common symptoms experienced during night terrors?', 'Night terrors result in a sense of panic in the sufferer and are often accompanied by screams and attempts to escape from the immediate environment (Mahowald & Schenck, 2000).']

['Teacher: What is one common characteristic of individuals experiencing night terrors in terms of their memory of the events that occurred?', 'Although individuals suffering from night terrors appear to be awake, they generally have no memories of the events that occurred, and attempts to console them are ineffective.']
['What is one ineffective method for consoling individuals experiencing night terrors?', 'Typically, individuals suffering from night terrors will fall back asleep again within a short time.']
['Teacher: What is the specific phase of sleep during which night terrors occur?', 'Night terrors apparently occur during the NREM phase of sleep (Provini, Tinuper, Bisulli, & Lagaresi, 2011).']

['What conditions would warrant treatment for night terrors?', 'Generally, treatment for night terrors is unnecessary unless there is some underlying medical or psychological condition that is contributing to the night terrors (Mayo Clinic, n.d.).']
['Teacher: Can you explain what sleep apnea is characterized by?', 'Sleep apnea is defined by episodes during which a sleeper’s breathing stops.']
['Teacher: How long can the episodes of breathing cessation during sleep apnea last?', 'These episodes can last 10–20 seconds or longer and often are associated with brief periods of arousal.']

['Teacher: How do individuals with sleep apnea often experience the disruptions in their sleep?', 'While individuals suffering from sleep apnea may not be aware of these repeated disruptions in sleep, they do experience increased levels of fatigue.']

['Teacher: What are some common symptoms that often lead individuals with sleep apnea to seek treatment?', 'Many individuals diagnosed with sleep apnea first seek treatment because their sleeping partners indicate that they snore loudly and/or stop breathing for extended periods of time while sleeping (Henry & Rosenthal, 2013).']
['Teacher: What is a common risk factor associated with sleep apnea?', 'Sleep apnea is much more common in overweight people and is often associated with loud snoring.']

['Teacher: What is one potential consequence of sleep apnea on cardiovascular health?', 'Surprisingly, sleep apnea may exacerbate cardiovascular disease (Sánchez-de-la-Torre, Campos-Rodriguez, & Barbé, 2012).']

['Teacher: What is one factor that can contribute to a higher likelihood of someone having sleep apnea?', 'While sleep apnea is less common in thin people, anyone, regardless of their weight, who snores loudly or gasps for air while sleeping, should be checked for sleep apnea.']

['Teacher: What are some of the adverse consequences that people with sleep apnea may experience?', 'While people are often unaware of their sleep apnea, they are keenly aware of some of the adverse consequences of insufficient sleep.']

['Teacher: Could you provide an example of one adverse consequence that someone with sleep apnea may experience?', 'Consider a patient who believed that as a result of his sleep apnea he “had three car accidents in six weeks.']
['What did the student imply about the car accidents?', 'They were ALL my fault.']
['What does the student imply about his awareness during the car accidents?', 'Two of them I didn’t even know I was involved in until afterwards” (Henry & Rosenthal, 2013, p. 52).']

['What concern do people with undiagnosed or untreated sleep apnea often have about their careers?', 'It is not uncommon for people suffering from undiagnosed or untreated sleep apnea to fear that their careers will be affected by the lack of sleep, illustrated by this statement from another patient, “I’m in a job where there’s a premium on being mentally alert.']
["What impact does sleep apnea have on a person's ability to concentrate at work?", 'I was really sleepy… and having trouble concentrating….']
['How did the student describe their ability to concentrate at work due to sleep apnea?', 'It was getting to the point where it was kind of scary” (Henry & Rosenthal, 2013, p. 52).']
['Teacher: What are the two types of sleep apnea?', 'There are two types of sleep apnea: obstructive sleep apnea and central sleep apnea.']
['Teacher: Can you describe central sleep apnea?', 'Obstructive sleep apnea occurs when an individual’s airway becomes blocked during sleep, and air is prevented from entering the lungs.']

['Teacher: How does central sleep apnea differ from obstructive sleep apnea in terms of its cause?', 'In central sleep apnea, disruption in signals sent from the brain that regulate breathing cause periods of interrupted breathing (White, 2005).']

['Teacher: What is one of the most common treatments for sleep apnea that involves the use of a special device during sleep?', 'One of the most common treatments for sleep apnea involves the use of a special device during sleep.']

['What is the purpose of the continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) device?', 'A continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) device includes a mask that fits over the sleeper’s nose and mouth, which is connected to a pump that pumps air into the person’s airways, forcing them to remain open, as shown in Figure 4.13.']
['What is the benefit of using smaller CPAP masks that only cover the nose?', 'Some newer CPAP masks are smaller and cover only the nose.']

['What are some of the advantages of using smaller CPAP masks that only cover the nose?', 'This treatment option has proven to be effective for people suffering from mild to severe cases of sleep apnea (McDaid et al., 2009).']

['What is one of the challenges associated with the use of CPAP devices for treating sleep apnea?', 'However, alternative treatment options are being explored because consistent compliance by users of CPAP devices is a problem.']

['What is one alternative treatment option for sleep apnea that has shown promise in double-blind trials?', 'Recently, a new EPAP (expiratory positive air pressure) device has shown promise in double-blind trials as one such alternative (Berry, Kryger, & Massie, 2011).']
['Teacher: What is Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS)?', 'In sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) an infant stops breathing during sleep and dies.']
['Teacher: Who is at the highest risk for SIDS?', 'Infants younger than 12 months appear to be at the highest risk for SIDS, and boys have a greater risk than girls.']

['Teacher: What are some of the risk factors that have been associated with SIDS?', 'A number of risk factors have been associated with SIDS including premature birth, smoking within the home, and hyperthermia.']

['Teacher: What are some potential biological factors that have been suggested to contribute to SIDS?', 'There may also be differences in both brain structure and function in infants that die from SIDS (Berkowitz, 2012; Mage & Donner, 2006; Thach, 2005).']

["Teacher: That's great to know! Can you share some of the recommendations that have been made to parents to protect their children from SIDS?", 'The substantial amount of research on SIDS has led to a number of recommendations to parents to protect their children.']

['What are some of the specific recommendations for placing infants down to sleep in order to protect them from SIDS?', 'For one, research suggests that infants should be placed on their backs when put down to sleep, and their cribs should not contain any items which pose suffocation threats, such as blankets, pillows or padded crib bumpers (cushions that cover the bars of a crib).']

['What other recommendations are there to protect infants from SIDS regarding their sleep environment and household habits?', 'Infants should not have caps placed on their heads when put down to sleep in order to prevent overheating, and people in the child’s household should abstain from smoking in the home.']

['What is the significance of avoiding overheating and abstaining from smoking in the home for the prevention of SIDS?', 'Recommendations like these have helped to decrease the number of infant deaths from SIDS in recent years (Mitchell, 2009; Task Force on Sudden Infant Death Syndrome, 2011).']

['Teacher: What makes narcolepsy different from the other sleep disorders discussed in this section?', 'Unlike the other sleep disorders described in this section, a person with narcolepsy cannot resist falling asleep at inopportune times.']

['Teacher: How are sleep episodes in narcolepsy different from the other sleep disorders described in this section?', 'These sleep episodes are often associated with cataplexy, which is a lack of muscle tone or muscle weakness, and in some cases involves complete paralysis of the voluntary muscles.']

['Teacher: Why are sleep episodes in narcolepsy compared to paralysis experienced during REM sleep?', 'This is similar to the kind of paralysis experienced by healthy individuals during REM sleep (Burgess & Scammell, 2012; Hishikawa & Shimizu, 1995; Luppi et al., 2011).']
['Teacher: What are some of the other features of REM sleep that narcoleptic episodes take on?', 'Narcoleptic episodes take on other features of REM sleep.']

['Teacher: How do narcoleptic episodes resemble the dreaming state of REM sleep?', 'For example, around one third of individuals diagnosed with narcolepsy experience vivid, dream-like hallucinations during narcoleptic attacks (Chokroverty, 2010).']
['Teacher: Can you explain how narcoleptic episodes are commonly triggered?', 'Surprisingly, narcoleptic episodes are often triggered by states of heightened arousal or stress.']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a state of heightened arousal or stress that could trigger a narcoleptic episode?', 'The typical episode can last from a minute or two to half an hour.']

['Teacher: What is the common feeling reported by individuals after they are awakened from a narcoleptic attack?', 'Once awakened from a narcoleptic attack, people report that they feel refreshed (Chokroverty, 2010).']

["Can you explain how narcolepsy can potentially impact an individual's daily activities and safety?", 'Obviously, regular narcoleptic episodes could interfere with the ability to perform one’s job or complete schoolwork, and in some situations, narcolepsy can result in significant harm and injury (e.g., driving a car or operating machinery or other potentially dangerous equipment).']
['Teacher: How is narcolepsy generally treated using drugs?', 'Generally, narcolepsy is treated using psychomotor stimulant drugs, such as amphetamines (Mignot, 2012).']
['What are some examples of psychomotor stimulant drugs used in the treatment of narcolepsy?', 'These drugs promote increased levels of neural activity.']

['What is the reason behind the traditional stimulant drugs not having direct effects on the hypocretin system in the brain?', 'Narcolepsy is associated with reduced levels of the signaling molecule hypocretin in some areas of the brain (De la Herrán-Arita & Drucker-Colín, 2012; Han, 2012), and the traditional stimulant drugs do not have direct effects on this system.']

['What is the potential implication of new medications that target the hypocretin system in the treatment of narcolepsy?', 'Therefore, it is quite likely that new medications that are developed to treat narcolepsy will be designed to target the hypocretin system.']

['Teacher: What can be said about the variability among individuals with narcolepsy in terms of symptoms and treatment effectiveness?', 'There is a tremendous amount of variability among sufferers, both in terms of how symptoms of narcolepsy manifest and the effectiveness of currently available treatment options.']

["Teacher: How does McCarty's case study illustrate the variability among individuals with narcolepsy in terms of symptom manifestation and treatment effectiveness?", 'This is illustrated by McCarty’s (2010) case study of a 50-year-old woman who sought help for the excessive sleepiness during normal waking hours that she had experienced for several years.']

["What can be inferred about the impact of narcolepsy symptoms on the daily life of individuals, based on McCarty's case study?", 'She indicated that she had fallen asleep at inappropriate or dangerous times, including while eating, while socializing with friends, and while driving her car.']

["What can be concluded about the physical symptoms experienced by individuals with narcolepsy, based on McCarty's case study?", 'During periods of emotional arousal, the woman complained that she felt some weakness in the right side of her body.']

['What were the treatment options available to McCarty for her excessive sleepiness symptoms?', 'Although she did not experience any dream-like hallucinations, she was diagnosed with narcolepsy as a result of sleep testing.']

['What specific symptom of narcolepsy did McCarty experience that was unusual compared to other individuals?', 'In her case, the fact that her cataplexy was confined to the right side of her body was quite unusual.']

['What were the treatment options pursued by McCarty for her narcolepsy symptoms after the unsuccessful use of a stimulant drug alone?', 'Early attempts to treat her condition with a stimulant drug alone were unsuccessful.']

["What can be said about the effectiveness of combining a stimulant drug with an antidepressant in the treatment of narcolepsy symptoms, based on McCarty's case study?", 'However, when a stimulant drug was used in conjunction with a popular antidepressant, her condition improved dramatically.']

['Teacher: What are some ways in which people can induce altered states of consciousness other than through sleep?', 'While we all experience altered states of consciousness in the form of sleep on a regular basis, some people use drugs and other substances that result in altered states of consciousness as well.']

['Teacher: Could you provide some examples of psychoactive drugs that can induce altered states of consciousness?', 'This section will present information relating to the use of various psychoactive drugs and problems associated with such use.']

['Teacher: What is the purpose of the brief descriptions of the effects of well-known drugs commonly used today?', 'This will be followed by brief descriptions of the effects of some of the more well-known drugs commonly used today.']

['Teacher: What is the purpose of using the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition (DSM-5) in diagnosing psychological disorders?', 'The fifth edition of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition (DSM-5) is used by clinicians to diagnose individuals suffering from various psychological disorders.']

['Teacher: How does the DSM-5 help clinicians diagnose individuals with drug use disorders specifically?', 'Drug use disorders are addictive disorders, and the criteria for specific substance (drug) use disorders are described in DSM-5.']

['Teacher: What are some of the criteria for substance use disorders as described in the DSM-5?', 'A person who has a substance use disorder often uses more of the substance than they originally intended to and continues to use that substance despite experiencing significant adverse consequences.']

['Teacher: What are some adverse consequences that individuals with substance use disorders may experience according to the DSM-5?', 'In individuals diagnosed with a substance use disorder, there is a compulsive pattern of drug use that is often associated with both physical and psychological dependence.']

['Teacher: What is one of the key symptoms of physical dependence on a drug?', 'Physical dependence involves changes in normal bodily functions—the user will experience withdrawal from the drug upon cessation of use.']

['What is the difference between physical dependence and psychological dependence on a drug?', 'In contrast, a person who has psychological dependence has an emotional, rather than physical, need for the drug and may use the drug to relieve psychological distress.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the concept of tolerance in substance use disorders?', 'Tolerance is linked to physiological dependence, and it occurs when a person requires more and more drug to achieve effects previously experienced at lower doses.']

['What are some potential consequences of developing a tolerance to a drug?', 'Tolerance can cause the user to increase the amount of drug used to a dangerous level—even to the point of overdose and death.']
['Teacher: Can you explain what drug withdrawal entails?', 'Drug withdrawal includes a variety of negative symptoms experienced when drug use is discontinued.']
['What is meant by saying that drug withdrawal symptoms are opposite of the effects of the drug?', 'These symptoms usually are opposite of the effects of the drug.']
['What are some examples of drug withdrawal symptoms that are opposite of the effects of the drug?', 'For example, withdrawal from sedative drugs often produces unpleasant arousal and agitation.']

['What is the relationship between drug tolerance and substance use disorders?', 'In addition to withdrawal, many individuals who are diagnosed with substance use disorders will also develop tolerance to these substances.']

['What is psychological dependence or drug craving and how does it relate to substance use disorders?', 'Psychological dependence, or drug craving, is a recent addition to the diagnostic criteria for substance use disorder in DSM-5.']

['What is the significance of developing tolerance and experiencing withdrawal from drugs that are not abused?', 'This is an important factor because we can develop tolerance and experience withdrawal from any number of drugs that we do not abuse.']

['What other factors should be considered besides physical dependence in determining whether someone has a substance use disorder?', 'In other words, physical dependence in and of itself is of limited utility in determining whether or not someone has a substance use disorder.']
['Teacher: How do the effects of psychoactive drugs occur?', 'The effects of all psychoactive drugs occur through their interactions with our endogenous neurotransmitter systems.']
['Teacher: What is shown in Table 4.2 regarding the drug relationships and categories?', 'Many of these drugs, and their relationships, are shown in Table 4.2.']

['Teacher: How do drugs act as agonists or antagonists of a given neurotransmitter system according to what you learned in Table 4.2?', 'As you have learned, drugs can act as agonists or antagonists of a given neurotransmitter system.']

['What are the roles of agonists and antagonists in relation to neurotransmitter activity?', 'An agonist facilitates the activity of a neurotransmitter system, and antagonists impede neurotransmitter activity.']
['Teacher: What is ethanol commonly referred to as?', 'Ethanol, which we commonly refer to as alcohol, is in a class of psychoactive drugs known as depressants.']
['What is the classification of ethanol within the group of psychoactive drugs?', 'A depressant is a drug that tends to suppress central nervous system activity.']
['What are some examples of other depressants besides alcohol?', 'Other depressants include barbiturates and benzodiazepines.']

['What is the common feature among barbiturates, benzodiazepines, and alcohol?', 'These drugs share in common their ability to serve as agonists of the gamma-Aminobutyric acid (GABA) neurotransmitter system.']

['What are some of the therapeutic uses of drugs that serve as agonists of the GABA neurotransmitter system?', 'Because GABA has a quieting effect on the brain, GABA agonists also have a quieting effect; these types of drugs are often prescribed to treat both anxiety and insomnia.']
['Teacher: What are some of the changes to consciousness that occur with acute alcohol administration?', 'Acute alcohol administration results in a variety of changes to consciousness.']
['What specific feelings are associated with acute alcohol administration at rather low doses?', 'At rather low doses, alcohol use is associated with feelings of euphoria.']
['Teacher: What are some of the effects of acute alcohol administration at higher doses?', 'As the dose increases, people report feeling sedated.']

['Teacher: How does acute alcohol administration affect reaction time and visual acuity?\nStudent: Generally, alcohol is associated with decreases in reaction time and visual acuity.', 'Generally, alcohol is associated with decreases in reaction time and visual acuity, lowered levels of alertness, and reduction in behavioral control.']

['What are some of the consequences of excessive alcohol use on consciousness?', 'With excessive alcohol use, a person might experience a complete loss of consciousness and/or difficulty remembering events that occurred during a period of intoxication (McKim & Hancock, 2013).']

["What are some potential long-term consequences of excessive alcohol use on a person's health?", 'In addition, if a pregnant person consumes alcohol, their infant may be born with a cluster of birth defects and symptoms collectively called fetal alcohol spectrum disorder (FASD) or fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS).']

['Teacher: What are some signs that a person may exhibit when they become physically dependent on a central nervous system depressant such as alcohol?', 'With repeated use of many central nervous system depressants, such as alcohol, a person becomes physically dependent upon the substance and will exhibit signs of both tolerance and withdrawal.']

['What are some signs of tolerance and withdrawal that a person may experience when they become physically dependent on central nervous system depressants like alcohol?', 'Psychological dependence on these drugs is also possible.']

['What are some examples of central nervous system depressants, besides alcohol, that can lead to physical dependence and exhibit signs of tolerance and withdrawal?', 'Therefore, the abuse potential of central nervous system depressants is relatively high.']

['Teacher: Why can drug withdrawal be a potentially life-threatening process for individuals with a long history of high doses of alcohol and/or barbiturates?', 'Drug withdrawal is usually an aversive experience, and it can be a life-threatening process in individuals who have a long history of very high doses of alcohol and/or barbiturates.']

['Teacher: Why is it important for individuals with a long history of high doses of alcohol and/or barbiturates to only overcome addiction under medical supervision?', 'This is of such concern that people who are trying to overcome addiction to these substances should only do so under medical supervision.']
['Teacher: What is the general effect of stimulants on neural activity?', 'Stimulants are drugs that tend to increase overall levels of neural activity.']
['What is the role of dopamine in the effects of stimulants on neural activity?', 'Many of these drugs act as agonists of the dopamine neurotransmitter system.']

['What is the relationship between dopamine activity and abuse liability of drugs that affect dopamine neurotransmission?', 'Dopamine activity is often associated with reward and craving; therefore, drugs that affect dopamine neurotransmission often have abuse liability.']

['What are some examples of stimulant drugs that fall into this category?', 'Drugs in this category include cocaine, amphetamines (including methamphetamine), cathinones (i.e., bath salts), MDMA (ecstasy), nicotine, and caffeine.']
['Teacher: What are some of the methods through which cocaine can be consumed?', 'Cocaine can be taken in multiple ways.']

['Teacher: Besides snorting, intravenous injection, and inhalation, can you mention any other methods of consuming cocaine?', 'While many users snort cocaine, intravenous injection and inhalation (smoking) are also common.']
['Teacher: What is the difference between cocaine and its freebase version known as crack?', 'The freebase version of cocaine, known as crack, is a potent, smokable version of the drug.']

['Teacher: How does cocaine affect the dopamine neurotransmitter system?', 'Like many other stimulants, cocaine agonizes the dopamine neurotransmitter system by blocking the reuptake of dopamine in the neuronal synapse.']

['Teacher: What do amphetamines block in addition to stimulating the release of dopamine, which is similar to cocaine?', 'Amphetamines have a mechanism of action quite similar to cocaine in that they block the reuptake of dopamine in addition to stimulating its release.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a medical condition for which amphetamines are commonly prescribed, besides being abused?', 'While amphetamines are often abused, they are also commonly prescribed to people diagnosed with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).']

['Teacher: Why might it seem counterintuitive to prescribe stimulant medications to individuals with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD)?', 'It may seem counterintuitive that stimulant medications are prescribed to treat a disorder that involves hyperactivity, but the therapeutic effect comes from increases in neurotransmitter activity within certain areas of the brain associated with impulse control.']

['Teacher: What are some potential therapeutic effects of stimulant medications in individuals with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD)?', 'These brain areas include the prefrontal cortex and basal ganglia.']
['Teacher: What has been happening with methamphetamine (meth) use in recent years?', 'In recent years, methamphetamine (meth) use has become increasingly widespread.']

['Teacher: Can you explain how methamphetamine is typically synthesized using easily obtainable ingredients?', 'Methamphetamine is a type of amphetamine that can be made from ingredients that are readily available (e.g., medications containing pseudoephedrine, a compound found in many over-the-counter cold and flu remedies).']

['Teacher: What are some recent changes in laws that have been implemented to make obtaining pseudoephedrine more difficult?', 'Despite recent changes in laws designed to make obtaining pseudoephedrine more difficult, methamphetamine continues to be an easily accessible and relatively inexpensive drug option (Shukla, Crump, & Chrisco, 2012).']

['Teacher: What are some of the effects that stimulant users often seek?', 'Stimulant users seek a euphoric high, feelings of intense elation and pleasure, especially in those users who take the drug via intravenous injection or smoking.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a mild stimulant commonly used by stimulant users?', 'MDMA (3.4-methelynedioxy-methamphetamine, commonly known as "ecstasy" or "Molly") is a mild stimulant with perception-altering effects.']
['Teacher: How do stimulant users typically consume MDMA?', 'It is typically consumed in pill form.']
['Teacher: What are some of the effects that stimulant users typically experience when consuming MDMA?', 'Users experience increased energy, feelings of pleasure, and emotional warmth.']
['What are some potential risks or negative effects associated with repeated use of stimulants like MDMA?', 'Repeated use of these stimulants can have significant adverse consequences.']

['Teacher: What are some psychological risks or negative effects associated with repeated use of stimulants like MDMA?', 'Users can experience physical symptoms that include nausea, elevated blood pressure, and increased heart rate.']

['What are some physical symptoms that stimulant users may experience as a result of repeated use of stimulants like MDMA?', 'In addition, these drugs can cause feelings of anxiety, hallucinations, and paranoia (Fiorentini et al., 2011).']
['What is one consequence of repeated use of stimulants like MDMA on normal brain functioning?', 'Normal brain functioning is altered after repeated use of these drugs.']

['Teacher: What role do monoamine neurotransmitters play in normal brain functioning, and how can repeated use of stimulants like MDMA lead to their depletion?', 'For example, repeated use can lead to overall depletion among the monoamine neurotransmitters (dopamine, norepinephrine, and serotonin).']

['What are some potential consequences or effects of depletion of monoamine neurotransmitters in the brain?', 'Depletion of certain neurotransmitters can lead to mood dysphoria, cognitive problems, and other factors.']

['How does the depletion of monoamine neurotransmitters contribute to the compulsive use of stimulants such as cocaine and amphetamines?', "This can lead to people compulsively using stimulants such as cocaine and amphetamines, in part to try to reestablish the person's physical and psychological pre-use baseline."]
['What is the significance of reestablishing the physical and psychological pre-use baseline for stimulant users?', '(Jayanthi & Ramamoorthy, 2005; Rothman, Blough, & Baumann, 2007).']
['Teacher: What category does caffeine fall into?', 'Caffeine is another stimulant drug.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why caffeine, despite being commonly used, is considered less potent compared to other stimulant drugs?', 'While it is probably the most commonly used drug in the world, the potency of this particular drug pales in comparison to the other stimulant drugs described in this section.']
['Teacher: How does caffeine differ from other stimulant drugs in terms of potency and common use?', 'Generally, people use caffeine to maintain increased levels of alertness and arousal.']

['Teacher: Can you give some examples of the different forms or products that contain caffeine?', 'Caffeine is found in many common medicines (such as weight loss drugs), beverages, foods, and even cosmetics (Herman & Herman, 2013).']

['Teacher: How does caffeine primarily work in the body to produce its effects?', 'While caffeine may have some indirect effects on dopamine neurotransmission, its primary mechanism of action involves antagonizing adenosine activity (Porkka-Heiskanen, 2011).']
['Teacher: How does antagonizing adenosine activity contribute to the stimulating effects of caffeine?', 'Adenosine is a neurotransmitter that promotes sleep.']

['Teacher: How does the inhibition of adenosine receptors by caffeine contribute to its stimulating effects on the body?', 'Caffeine is an adenosine antagonist, so caffeine inhibits the adenosine receptors, thus decreasing sleepiness and promoting wakefulness.']

['Teacher: What are some potential side effects of high blood levels of caffeine?', 'While caffeine is generally considered a relatively safe drug, high blood levels of caffeine can result in insomnia, agitation, muscle twitching, nausea, irregular heartbeat, and even death (Reissig, Strain, & Griffiths, 2009; Wolt, Ganetsky, & Babu, 2012).']

['What were some of the ill effects suffered by the 40-year-old woman in the case study mentioned by Kromann and Nielson?', 'In 2012, Kromann and Nielson reported on a case study of a 40-year-old woman who suffered significant ill effects from her use of caffeine.']

['What were some of the significant ill effects that the 40-year-old woman suffered from her excessive caffeine consumption?', 'The woman used caffeine in the past to boost her mood and to provide energy, but over the course of several years, she increased her caffeine consumption to the point that she was consuming three liters of soda each day.']

['What were some of the warning signs of cardiovascular disease and diabetes that the 40-year-old woman displayed as a result of her excessive caffeine consumption?', 'Although she had been taking a prescription antidepressant, her symptoms of depression continued to worsen and she began to suffer physically, displaying significant warning signs of cardiovascular disease and diabetes.']

['What diagnosis did the 40-year-old woman receive upon admission to the outpatient clinic for treatment of mood disorders?', 'Upon admission to an outpatient clinic for treatment of mood disorders, she met all of the diagnostic criteria for substance dependence and was advised to dramatically limit her caffeine intake.']

['What improvements did the 40-year-old woman experience in her mental and physical health after limiting her caffeine intake to less than 12 ounces of soda a day?', 'Once she was able to limit her use to less than 12 ounces of soda a day, both her mental and physical health gradually improved.']

["What was the significance of the case study mentioned by Kromann and Nielson regarding the 40-year-old woman's excessive caffeine consumption?", 'Despite the prevalence of caffeine use and the large number of people who confess to suffering from caffeine addiction, this was the first published description of soda dependence appearing in scientific literature.']

['Teacher: What are some of the health risks associated with the use of tobacco products?', 'Nicotine is highly addictive, and the use of tobacco products is associated with increased risks of heart disease, stroke, and a variety of cancers.']
['Teacher: How does nicotine affect the body by interacting with which receptors?', 'Nicotine exerts its effects through its interaction with acetylcholine receptors.']
["Teacher: How does the interaction of nicotine with acetylcholine receptors affect the body's motor system?", 'Acetylcholine functions as a neurotransmitter in motor neurons.']

['Teacher: When nicotine interacts with acetylcholine receptors in the body, what specific effects does it have on the motor system?', 'In the central nervous system, it plays a role in arousal and reward mechanisms.']

['Teacher: Why is there a tremendous interest in developing effective smoking cessation techniques?', 'Nicotine is most commonly used in the form of tobacco products like cigarettes or chewing tobacco; therefore, there is a tremendous interest in developing effective smoking cessation techniques.']

['What are some examples of nicotine replacement therapies and psychotherapeutic options that people have used to discontinue their use of tobacco products?', 'To date, people have used a variety of nicotine replacement therapies in addition to various psychotherapeutic options in an attempt to discontinue their use of tobacco products.']

['What is the effectiveness of smoking cessation programs in the long term?', 'In general, smoking cessation programs may be effective in the short term, but it is unclear whether these effects persist (Cropley, Theadom, Pravettoni, & Webb, 2008; Levitt, Shaw, Wong, & Kaczorowski, 2007; Smedslund, Fisher, Boles, & Lichtenstein, 2004).']

['What are some potential consequences or health risks associated with the increasing popularity of vaping, especially among teenagers and young adults?', 'Vaping as a means to deliver nicotine is becoming increasingly popular, especially among teens and young adults.']

['What are some potential health risks associated with the use of vaping devices, especially among teenagers and young adults?', 'Vaping uses battery-powered devices, sometimes called e-cigarettes, that deliver liquid nicotine and flavorings as a vapor.']

['What are some of the potential health risks associated with vaping, especially among teenagers and young adults?', 'Originally reported as a safe alternative to the known cancer-causing agents found in cigarettes, vaping is now known to be very dangerous and has led to serious lung disease and death in users (Shmerling, 2019).']
['Teacher: Can you provide some examples of drugs that belong to the category of opioids?', 'An opioid is one of a category of drugs that includes heroin, morphine, methadone, and codeine.']
['Teacher: That\'s correct! Now, can you explain what the term "analgesic properties" means in the context of opioids?', 'Opioids have analgesic properties; that is, they decrease pain.']

['What are some examples of endogenous opioid compounds that the human body produces?', 'Humans have an endogenous opioid neurotransmitter system—the body makes small quantities of opioid compounds that bind to opioid receptors reducing pain and producing euphoria.']

['What are some of the potential dangers or risks associated with the abuse of opioid drugs?', 'Thus, opioid drugs, which mimic this endogenous painkilling mechanism, have an extremely high potential for abuse.']
['What is the relationship between opioids and opiates?', 'Natural opioids, called opiates, are derivatives of opium, which is a naturally occurring compound found in the poppy plant.']

['What is the reason behind the potent painkilling effects of synthetic opioids compared to natural opiates?', 'There are now several synthetic versions of opiate drugs (correctly called opioids) that have very potent painkilling effects, and they are often abused.']

['What are some examples of prescription pain killers that are considered opioids and are known to be significant public health concerns?', 'For example, the National Institutes of Drug Abuse has sponsored research that suggests the misuse and abuse of the prescription pain killers hydrocodone and oxycodone are significant public health concerns (Maxwell, 2006).']

['What specific recommendations did the U.S. Food and Drug Administration make regarding the medical use of prescription pain killers hydrocodone and oxycodone?', 'In 2013, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration recommended tighter controls on their medical use.']
['Teacher: Can you tell me which specific opioid drug has a significant history of abuse?', 'Historically, heroin has been a major opioid drug of abuse.']
['What are the different methods of administration for heroin?', 'Heroin can be snorted, smoked, or injected intravenously.']

['Teacher: How do the methods of administration affect the intensity of the feelings of euphoria and pleasure produced by heroin?', 'Heroin produces intense feelings of euphoria and pleasure, which are amplified when the heroin is injected intravenously.']

['What are the effects experienced by users after the initial rush of heroin?', 'Following the initial "rush," users experience 4–6 hours of "going on the nod," alternating between conscious and semiconscious states.']
['How long do users typically experience the effects of heroin after injecting it intravenously?', 'Heroin users often shoot the drug directly into their veins.']

['What are some potential health risks associated with intravenous drug use, specifically with heroin?', 'Some people who have injected many times into their arms will show "track marks,"  while other users will inject into areas between their fingers or between their toes, so as not to show obvious track marks and, like all abusers of intravenous drugs, have an increased risk for contraction of both tuberculosis and HIV.']

['Teacher: What are some other medical uses of opioid-like compounds besides being analgesic drugs?', 'Aside from their utility as analgesic drugs, opioid-like compounds are often found in cough suppressants, anti-nausea, and anti-diarrhea medications.']

['What are some symptoms of opioid withdrawal that are similar to a severe case of the flu?', 'Given that withdrawal from a drug often involves an experience opposite to the effect of the drug, it should be no surprise that opioid withdrawal resembles a severe case of the flu.']

['What is the difference between the symptoms of opioid withdrawal and those of a severe case of the flu?', 'While opioid withdrawal can be extremely unpleasant, it is not life-threatening (Julien, 2005).']

['What is the purpose of administering methadone to individuals experiencing opioid withdrawal?', 'Still, people experiencing opioid withdrawal may be given methadone to make withdrawal from the drug less difficult.']

['What is the advantage of utilizing methadone for individuals going through opioid withdrawal compared to other opioids?', 'Methadone is a synthetic opioid that is less euphorigenic than heroin and similar drugs.']

['What is the role of methadone clinics in helping individuals with opioid addiction?', 'Methadone clinics help people who previously struggled with opioid addiction manage withdrawal symptoms through the use of methadone.']

['What is another drug that has been used to alleviate symptoms of opioid withdrawal, besides methadone?', 'Other drugs, including the opioid buprenorphine, have also been used to alleviate symptoms of opiate withdrawal.']
['Teacher: How would you describe the potency of codeine?', 'Codeine is an opioid with relatively low potency.']

['Why is codeine often prescribed for minor pain and available over-the-counter in some other countries?', 'It is often prescribed for minor pain, and it is available over-the-counter in some other countries.']

['Teacher: What is an important consideration when prescribing codeine, despite its use for minor pain and availability over-the-counter in some countries?', 'Like all opioids, codeine does have abuse potential.']

['What is the concern regarding the abuse of prescription opioid medications?', 'In fact, abuse of prescription opioid medications is becoming a major concern worldwide (Aquina, Marques-Baptista, Bridgeman, & Merlin, 2009; Casati, Sedefov, & Pfeiffer-Gerschel, 2012).']
['Teacher: How would you define a hallucinogen?', 'A hallucinogen is one of a class of drugs that results in profound alterations in sensory and perceptual experiences.']
['What are some of the effects that hallucinogens can have on users?', 'In some cases, users experience vivid visual hallucinations.']

['What are some other types of perceptual alterations that hallucinogens can cause?', 'It is also common for these types of drugs to cause hallucinations of body sensations (e.g., feeling as if you are a giant) and a skewed perception of the passage of time.']

['Teacher: What is one characteristic of hallucinogens in terms of the neurotransmitter systems they affect?', 'As a group, hallucinogens are incredibly varied in terms of the neurotransmitter systems they affect.']

['What specific neurotransmitter systems do hallucinogens like mescaline and LSD affect?', 'Mescaline and LSD are serotonin agonists, and PCP (angel dust) and ketamine (an animal anesthetic) act as antagonists of the NMDA glutamate receptor.']

['What sets hallucinogens apart from other classes of drugs in terms of their potential for abuse?', 'In general, these drugs are not thought to possess the same sort of abuse potential as other classes of drugs discussed in this section.']
['Teacher: How does our states of consciousness change as we move from wakefulness to sleep?', 'Our states of consciousness change as we move from wakefulness to sleep.']
['Teacher: How do we alter our consciousness through the use of various psychoactive drugs?', 'We also alter our consciousness through the use of various psychoactive drugs.']

['Teacher: How do hypnotic and meditative states serve as additional examples of altered states of consciousness?', 'This final section will consider hypnotic and meditative states as additional examples of altered states of consciousness experienced by some individuals.']
['Teacher: What is hypnosis?', 'Hypnosis is a state of extreme self-focus and attention in which minimal attention is given to external stimuli.']

['Teacher: How does a clinician use relaxation and suggestion during hypnosis in a therapeutic setting?', 'In the therapeutic setting, a clinician may use relaxation and suggestion in an attempt to alter the thoughts and perceptions of a patient.']

['Teacher: What is one additional application of hypnosis besides altering thoughts and perceptions in a therapeutic setting?', 'Hypnosis has also been used to draw out information believed to be buried deeply in someone’s memory.']

['Teacher: How do brain imaging studies support the effectiveness of hypnosis as a technique?', 'For individuals who are especially open to the power of suggestion, hypnosis can prove to be a very effective technique, and brain imaging studies have demonstrated that hypnotic states are associated with global changes in brain functioning (Del Casale et al., 2012; Guldenmund, Vanhaudenhuyse, Boly, Laureys, & Soddu, 2012).']
['Teacher: Why has hypnosis historically been viewed with some suspicion?', 'Historically, hypnosis has been viewed with some suspicion because of its portrayal in popular media and entertainment.']

['Teacher: What are some reasons why it is important to differentiate between hypnosis as a therapeutic approach and as a form of entertainment?', 'Therefore, it is important to make a distinction between hypnosis as an empirically based therapeutic approach versus as a form of entertainment.']

['Teacher: What is a common misconception about individuals undergoing hypnosis and their control over their own behaviors?', 'Contrary to popular belief, individuals undergoing hypnosis usually have clear memories of the hypnotic experience and are in control of their own behaviors.']

['What are some potential benefits of hypnosis in terms of memory and skill enhancement?', 'While hypnosis may be useful in enhancing memory or a skill, such enhancements are very modest in nature (Raz, 2011).']

['Teacher: What are the four consistent parts that bring people into the state of suggestibility associated with hypnosis?', 'While there are variations, there are four parts that appear consistent in bringing people into the state of suggestibility associated with hypnosis (National Research Council, 1994).']
['What are the four consistent parts discussed in the passage that bring people into the state of suggestibility associated with hypnosis?', 'These components include:']
['Teacher: What is it that the participant is guided to focus on during hypnosis?', 'The participant is guided to focus on one thing, such as the hypnotist’s words or a ticking watch.']
['Teacher: How does the hypnotist typically guide the participant to enter a state of relaxation and sleepiness?', 'The participant is made comfortable and is directed to be relaxed and sleepy.']

['Teacher: Why is it important for the participant to be open to the process of hypnosis, trust the hypnotist, and let go?', 'The participant is told to be open to the process of hypnosis, trust the hypnotist and let go.']
['Teacher: Why is it important for the participant to use their imagination during hypnosis?', 'The participant is encouraged to use their imagination.']

['Teacher: What does the available research suggest regarding the hypnotizability of most people?', 'People vary in terms of their ability to be hypnotized, but a review of available research suggests that most people are at least moderately hypnotizable (Kihlstrom, 2013).']

['What are some therapeutic purposes for which hypnosis, when combined with other techniques, has shown to be effective?', 'Hypnosis in conjunction with other techniques is used for a variety of therapeutic purposes and has shown to be at least somewhat effective for pain management, treatment of depression and anxiety, smoking cessation, and weight loss (Alladin, 2012; Elkins, Johnson, & Fisher, 2012; Golden, 2012; Montgomery, Schnur, & Kravits, 2012).']
['What are the two theories that attempt to answer this question?', 'Two theories attempt to answer this question:']

['Teacher: Can you explain how the theory that views hypnosis as dissociation defines the concept of hypnosis?', 'One theory views hypnosis as dissociation and the other theory views it as the performance of a social role.']

['What is the other theory that views hypnosis as the performance of a social role?', 'According to the dissociation view, hypnosis is effectively a dissociated state of consciousness, much like our earlier example where you may drive to work, but you are only minimally aware of the process of driving because your attention is focused elsewhere.']
['What research by Ernest Hilgard supports the theory that hypnosis is a dissociated state of consciousness?', 'This theory is supported by Ernest Hilgard’s research into hypnosis and pain.']
['What did Hilgard find in his experiments regarding hypnosis and pain?', 'In Hilgard’s experiments, he induced participants into a state of hypnosis, and placed their arms into ice water.']

['What does the fact that the participants pressed the button suggest about their state of consciousness during hypnosis?', 'Participants were told they would not feel pain, but they could press a button if they did; while they reported not feeling pain, they did, in fact, press the button, suggesting a dissociation of consciousness while in the hypnotic state (Hilgard & Hilgard, 1994).']

['Teacher: According to the social-cognitive theory, how are people in hypnotic states seen?', 'Taking a different approach to explain hypnosis, the social-cognitive theory of hypnosis sees people in hypnotic states as performing the social role of a hypnotized person.']

['Teacher: How does the social-cognitive theory explain the behavior of people in hypnotic states?', 'As you will learn when you study social roles, people’s behavior can be shaped by their expectations of how they should act in a given situation.']

['Teacher: How does the social-cognitive theory perceive the behavior of a person in a hypnotic state?', 'Some view a hypnotized person’s behavior not as an altered or dissociated state of consciousness, but as their fulfillment of the social expectations for that role (Coe, 2009; Coe & Sarbin, 1966).']

['Teacher: Can you explain what meditation involves and its purpose?', 'Meditation is the act of focusing on a single target (such as the breath or a repeated sound) to increase awareness of the moment.']

['What is the purpose of focusing on a single target during meditation?', 'While hypnosis is generally achieved through the interaction of a therapist and the person being treated, an individual can perform meditation alone.']

['Teacher: How can individuals achieve a meditative state during meditation?', 'Often, however, people wishing to learn to meditate receive some training in techniques to achieve a meditative state.']

['Teacher: What is the central feature of all meditation techniques?', 'Although there are a number of different techniques in use, the central feature of all meditation is clearing the mind in order to achieve a state of relaxed awareness and focus (Chen et al., 2013; Lang et al., 2012).']
['What is the purpose of clearing the mind in meditation?', 'Mindfulness meditation has recently become popular.']

['Teacher: Why has mindfulness meditation gained popularity in recent times?', 'In the variation of mindful meditation, the meditator’s attention is focused on some internal process or an external object (Zeidan, Grant, Brown, McHaffie, & Coghill, 2012).']

['Teacher: What is the origin of meditative techniques and how have they gained popularity?', 'Meditative techniques have their roots in religious practices, but their use has grown in popularity among practitioners of alternative medicine.']

['Teacher: What are some potential health benefits of meditation and how is it being incorporated into medical treatments?', 'Research indicates that meditation may help reduce blood pressure, and the American Heart Association suggests that meditation might be used in conjunction with more traditional treatments as a way to manage hypertension, although there is not sufficient data for a recommendation to be made (Brook et al., 2013).']

['Teacher: Can you provide some examples of how meditation can be beneficial for stress management, sleep quality, mood and anxiety disorders, and pain management?', 'Like hypnosis, meditation also shows promise in stress management, sleep quality (Caldwell, Harrison, Adams, Quin, & Greeson, 2010), treatment of mood and anxiety disorders (Chen et al., 2013; Freeman et al., 2010; Vøllestad, Nielsen, & Nielsen, 2012), and pain management (Reiner, Tibi, & Lipsitz, 2013).']
['Teacher: Can you explain what sensory receptors are and how they function in response to stimuli?', 'Sensory receptors are specialized neurons that respond to specific types of stimuli.']

['Teacher: Fantastic! Now, can you please explain what happens to the sensory information once sensation has occurred?', 'When sensory information is detected by a sensory receptor, sensation has occurred.']

['Teacher: Can you describe the specific process that occurs in the eye once light is detected by sensory receptors?', 'For example, light that enters the eye causes chemical changes in cells that line the back of the eye.']

['Teacher: What role do these action potentials play in the transmission of sensory information to the central nervous system?', 'These cells relay messages, in the form of action potentials (as you learned when studying biopsychology), to the central nervous system.']

["Teacher: That's correct! Can you explain how transduction allows sensory information to be transmitted to the central nervous system?", 'The conversion from sensory stimulus energy to action potential is known as transduction.']

['Teacher: Can you please list the five senses that humans have?', 'You have probably known since elementary school that we have five senses: vision, hearing (audition), smell (olfaction), taste (gustation), and touch (somatosensation).']
['Teacher: How is the notion of five senses oversimplified according to the passage?', 'It turns out that this notion of five senses is oversimplified.']

['Teacher: What are some additional sensory systems mentioned in the passage that go beyond the traditional notion of five senses?', 'We also have sensory systems that provide information about balance (the vestibular sense), body position and movement (proprioception and kinesthesia), pain (nociception), and temperature (thermoception).']

['Teacher: How can the sensitivity of a given sensory system to the relevant stimuli be expressed?', 'The sensitivity of a given sensory system to the relevant stimuli can be expressed as an absolute threshold.']

["Teacher: That's correct! And how is the absolute threshold typically measured?", 'Absolute threshold refers to the minimum amount of stimulus energy that must be present for the stimulus to be detected 50% of the time.']

['Teacher: What is the purpose of measuring the absolute threshold in sensation?', 'Another way to think about this is by asking how dim can a light be or how soft can a sound be and still be detected half of the time.']
['Teacher: Absolutely! Now, can you explain how the sensitivity of our sensory receptors is related to the absolute threshold?', 'The sensitivity of our sensory receptors can be quite amazing.']

['Teacher: How does the sensitivity of our sensory receptors contribute to our ability to detect stimuli such as a candle flame 30 miles away?', 'It has been estimated that on a clear night, the most sensitive sensory cells in the back of the eye can detect a candle flame 30 miles away (Okawa & Sampath, 2007).']

['Teacher: How does the sensitivity of our sensory receptors allow us to detect subtle stimuli such as the tick of a clock 20 feet away?', 'Under quiet conditions, the hair cells (the receptor cells of the inner ear) can detect the tick of a clock 20 feet away (Galanter, 1962).']

['Teacher: What are messages that are presented below the threshold for conscious awareness called?', 'It is also possible for us to get messages that are presented below the threshold for conscious awareness—these are called subliminal messages.']

['What is the term for messages that are presented below the threshold for conscious awareness?', 'A stimulus reaches a physiological threshold when it is strong enough to excite sensory receptors and send nerve impulses to the brain:']
['What is the term for a stimulus that is strong enough to excite sensory receptors and send nerve impulses to the brain?', 'This is an absolute threshold.']
['What is the term for a message that is presented below the absolute threshold and is said to be subliminal?', 'A message below that threshold is said to be subliminal:']
['How can you describe the awareness of a subliminal message?', 'We receive it, but we are not consciously aware of it.']

['What are some areas in which the use of subliminal messages has sparked speculation?', 'Over the years there has been a great deal of speculation about the use of subliminal messages in advertising, rock music, and self-help audio programs.']

["What does research evidence show about people's ability to process and respond to information outside of awareness?", 'Research evidence shows that in laboratory settings, people can process and respond to information outside of awareness.']

['What does research evidence show about the effect of hidden messages on behavior outside the laboratory?', 'But this does not mean that we obey these messages like zombies; in fact, hidden messages have little effect on behavior outside the laboratory (Kunst-Wilson & Zajonc, 1980; Rensink, 2004; Nelson, 2008; Radel, Sarrazin, Legrain, & Gobancé, 2009; Loersch, Durso, & Petty, 2013).']

['Teacher: How are absolute thresholds typically measured for sensation?', 'Absolute thresholds are generally measured under incredibly controlled conditions in situations that are optimal for sensitivity.']

['Teacher: What do we call the minimum amount of stimuli needed to detect a difference between them?', 'Sometimes, we are more interested in how much difference in stimuli is required to detect a difference between them.']
['Teacher: How is the just noticeable difference (jnd) or difference threshold typically determined?', 'This is known as the just noticeable difference (jnd) or difference threshold.']
['Teacher: How does the difference threshold change in relation to the stimulus intensity?', 'Unlike the absolute threshold, the difference threshold changes depending on the stimulus intensity.']

['Teacher: In this scenario, would the absolute threshold or the difference threshold be more important in detecting subtle changes in the movie?', 'As an example, imagine yourself in a very dark movie theater.']

['Teacher: What does this scenario illustrate about the relative importance of the absolute threshold and the difference threshold in detecting subtle changes in the movie?', 'If an audience member were to receive a text message that caused the cell phone screen to light up, chances are that many people would notice the change in illumination in the theater.']

['Teacher: How does the scenario with the dark movie theater and brightly lit arena illustrate the role of the absolute threshold and the difference threshold in detecting subtle changes in stimuli?', 'However, if the same thing happened in a brightly lit arena during a basketball game, very few people would notice.']

['What is the main difference between the dark movie theater and the brightly lit arena in relation to the detection of subtle changes in stimuli?', 'The cell phone brightness does not change, but its ability to be detected as a change in illumination varies dramatically between the two contexts.']

['What is the theory proposed by Ernst Weber in the 1830s that describes the change in difference threshold?', 'Ernst Weber proposed this theory of change in difference threshold in the 1830s, and it has become known as Weber’s law:']
["What is the basic principle behind Weber's Law?", 'The difference threshold is a constant fraction of the original stimulus, as the example illustrates.']

['Teacher: What determines how we interact with the world based on the information collected by our sensory receptors?', 'While our sensory receptors are constantly collecting information from the environment, it is ultimately how we interpret that information that affects how we interact with the world.']
['Teacher: How does perception affect our interaction with the world?', 'Perception refers to the way sensory information is organized, interpreted, and consciously experienced.']
['Teacher: What are the two types of processing involved in perception?', 'Perception involves both bottom-up and top-down processing.']

['Teacher: How does bottom-up processing differ from top-down processing in perception?', 'Bottom-up processing refers to sensory information from a stimulus in the environment driving a process, and top-down processing refers to knowledge and expectancy driving a process, as shown in Figure 5.2 (Egeth & Yantis, 1997; Fine & Minnery, 2009; Yantis & Egeth, 1999).']

['Teacher: Can you explain what happens when you and your friends are sitting in a crowded restaurant eating lunch and talking?', 'Imagine that you and some friends are sitting in a crowded restaurant eating lunch and talking.']

['Teacher: How does your perception of the environment change when you hear the sound of breaking glass and metal pans hitting the floor in a crowded restaurant?', 'It is very noisy, and you are concentrating on your friend’s face to hear what they are saying, then the sound of breaking glass and clang of metal pans hitting the floor rings out.']
['What impact does the sound of breaking glass and metal pans hitting the floor have on your perception of the crowded restaurant environment?', 'The server dropped a large tray of food.']

['How does the sound of breaking glass and metal pans hitting the floor affect your attention in a crowded restaurant?', 'Although you were attending to your meal and conversation, that crashing sound would likely get through your attentional filters and capture your attention.']

['Why would the sound of breaking glass and metal pans hitting the floor "get through your attentional filters and capture your attention" in a crowded restaurant?', 'You would have no choice but to notice it.']
['What type of attentional capture is described in this situation?', 'That attentional capture would be caused by the sound from the environment: it would be bottom-up.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the characteristics of top-down processes in perception?', "Alternatively, top-down processes are generally goal directed, slow, deliberate, effortful, and under your control (Fine & Minnery, 2009; Miller & Cohen, 2001; Miller & D'Esposito, 2005)."]

['What are some examples of how top-down processes in perception can be applied in everyday situations?', 'If you had a yellow key fob, you would probably look for yellowness of a certain size in specific locations, such as on the counter, coffee table, and other similar places.']
['What are some characteristics of bottom-up processes in perception?', 'You would not look for yellowness on your ceiling fan, because you know keys are not normally lying on top of a ceiling fan.']

['What are some examples of bottom-up processes in perception?', 'That act of searching for a certain size of yellowness in some locations and not others would be top-down—under your control and based on your experience.']
['Teacher: How can we differentiate sensation from perception?', 'One way to think of this concept is that sensation is a physical process, whereas perception is psychological.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how sensation and perception can be distinguished in a real-life situation?', 'For example, upon walking into a kitchen and smelling the scent of baking cinnamon rolls, the sensation is the scent receptors detecting the odor of cinnamon, but the perception may be “Mmm, this smells like the bread Grandma used to bake when the family gathered for holidays.”']
['Teacher: What is the relationship between perceptions and sensations?', 'Although our perceptions are built from sensations, not all sensations result in perception.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of stimuli that remain relatively constant over prolonged periods of time but may not result in perception?', 'In fact, we often don’t perceive stimuli that remain relatively constant over prolonged periods of time.']
['Teacher: How does sensory adaptation relate to our ability to perceive stimuli that remain constant over prolonged periods of time?', 'This is known as sensory adaptation.']
['Teacher: How does going to a new city relate to our ability to perceive stimuli?', 'Imagine going to a city that you have never visited.']

['Teacher: How does the presence of the road construction sign with a bright flashing light outside your window impact your ability to perceive stimuli in the new city?', 'You check in to the hotel, but when you get to your room, there is a road construction sign with a bright flashing light outside your window.']

['How might the bright flashing light from the road construction sign impact your ability to sleep in the new city?', 'Unfortunately, there are no other rooms available, so you are stuck with a flashing light.']
['How might watching television help you unwind in this situation?', 'You decide to watch television to unwind.']
['How might your perception of the flashing light change after watching television?', 'The flashing light was extremely annoying when you first entered your room.']

['How does the act of watching television affect your perception of the flashing light from the road construction sign?', 'It was as if someone was continually turning a bright yellow spotlight on and off in your room, but after watching television for a short while, you no longer notice the light flashing.']

['How can we explain the phenomenon that even though the flashing light is still present and your photoreceptors still sense it, you no longer perceive the rapid changes in lighting conditions after watching television for a short while?', 'The light is still flashing and filling your room with yellow light every few seconds, and the photoreceptors in your eyes still sense the light, but you no longer perceive the rapid changes in lighting conditions.']

['What is the significance of the phenomenon of sensory adaptation in relation to our understanding of sensation and perception?', 'That you no longer perceive the flashing light demonstrates sensory adaptation and shows that while closely associated, sensation and perception are different.']
['Teacher: What is another factor that affects sensation and perception?', 'There is another factor that affects sensation and perception: attention.']

['What is the significance of attention in the process of determining what is sensed versus what is perceived?', 'Attention plays a significant role in determining what is sensed versus what is perceived.']

['Teacher: How does attention help you differentiate between the various sounds and conversations at a party, and focus on the ones that are most important to you?', 'Imagine you are at a party full of music, chatter, and laughter.']

["How does attention allow you to focus on your friend's conversation at the party and ignore the other noises and conversations happening around you?", 'You get involved in an interesting conversation with a friend, and you tune out all the background noise.']

['How can the concept of attention explain the scenario where you are unable to answer what song had just finished playing?', 'If someone interrupted you to ask what song had just finished playing, you would probably be unable to answer that question.']

['Teacher: Can you tell me about the study conducted by Daniel Simons and Christopher Chabris (1999) that demonstrated the significance of attention in determining our perception of the environment?', 'One of the most interesting demonstrations of how important attention is in determining our perception of the environment occurred in a famous study conducted by Daniel Simons and Christopher Chabris (1999).']

['Teacher: What did participants in the study conducted by Daniel Simons and Christopher Chabris (1999) watch in the video?', 'In this study, participants watched a video of people dressed in black and white passing basketballs.']

['What did the participants in the study conducted by Daniel Simons and Christopher Chabris (1999) have to do while watching the video?', 'Participants were asked to count the number of times the team dressed in white passed the ball.']
['Teacher: What did the participants fail to notice while watching the video?', 'During the video, a person dressed in a black gorilla costume walks among the two teams.']

['What does this study conducted by Daniel Simons and Christopher Chabris (1999) reveal about our perception of the environment?', 'Nearly half of the people who watched the video didn’t notice the gorilla at all, despite the fact that he was clearly visible for nine seconds.']

['What was the main reason why participants in the study conducted by Daniel Simons and Christopher Chabris (1999) failed to notice the gorilla in the video?', 'Because participants were so focused on the number of times the team dressed in white was passing the ball, they completely tuned out other visual information.']

['What is inattentional blindness?', 'Inattentional blindness is the failure to notice something that is completely visible because the person was actively attending to something else and did not pay attention to other things (Mack & Rock, 1998; Simons & Chabris, 1999).']

['Teacher: What did the researchers do to test inattentional blindness in a similar experiment?', 'In a similar experiment, researchers tested inattentional blindness by asking participants to observe images moving across a computer screen.']

['Teacher: What was the purpose of instructing the participants to focus on either white or black objects during the experiment?', 'They were instructed to focus on either white or black objects, disregarding the other color.']

['Teacher: What can we conclude from the fact that about one third of subjects did not notice the red cross passing across the screen in the experiment?', 'When a red cross passed across the screen, about one third of subjects did not notice it (Most, Simons, Scholl, & Chabris, 2000).']
['Teacher: How can motivation affect perception?', 'Motivation can also affect perception.']

['What is an example of how motivation can affect our ability to discriminate between a true sensory stimulus and background noise?', 'If so, then you have experienced how motivation to detect a meaningful stimulus can shift our ability to discriminate between a true sensory stimulus and background noise.']

['What is the term used to describe the ability to identify a stimulus when it is embedded in a distracting background?', 'The ability to identify a stimulus when it is embedded in a distracting background is called signal detection theory.']

['What is an example of how signal detection theory can explain why a mother is awakened by a quiet murmur from her baby but not by other sounds that occur while she is asleep?', 'This might also explain why a mother is awakened by a quiet murmur from her baby but not by other sounds that occur while she is asleep.']
['What are some practical applications of signal detection theory?', 'Signal detection theory has practical applications, such as increasing air traffic controller accuracy.']

['How can signal detection theory be applied in the field of air traffic control?', 'Controllers need to be able to detect planes among many signals (blips) that appear on the radar screen and follow those planes as they move through the sky.']

['What is the main goal of using signal detection theory in the field of air traffic control?', 'In fact, the original work of the researcher who developed signal detection theory was focused on improving the sensitivity of air traffic controllers to plane blips (Swets, 1964).']

['Teacher: How can our beliefs, values, prejudices, expectations, and life experiences impact our perceptions?', 'Our perceptions can also be affected by our beliefs, values, prejudices, expectations, and life experiences.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example that illustrates how the absence of binocular vision during critical periods of development impacts perception?', 'As you will see later in this chapter, individuals who are deprived of the experience of binocular vision during critical periods of development have trouble perceiving depth (Fawcett, Wang, & Birch, 2005).']
['Teacher: How does the cultural context influence our perceptions?', 'The shared experiences of people within a given cultural context can have pronounced effects on perception.']

['Teacher: Can you provide another example that demonstrates how cultural context can influence perception?', 'For example, Marshall Segall, Donald Campbell, and Melville Herskovits (1963) published the results of a multinational study in which they demonstrated that individuals from Western cultures were more prone to experience certain types of visual illusions than individuals from non-Western cultures, and vice versa.']

['What is the Müller-Lyer illusion and how does it demonstrate the influence of cultural context on perception?', 'One such illusion that Westerners were more likely to experience was the Müller-Lyer illusion:']
['What does the Müller-Lyer illusion demonstrate about the influence of cultural context on perception?', 'The lines appear to be different lengths, but they are actually the same length.']

['Teacher: What were the perceptual differences consistent with?', 'These perceptual differences were consistent with differences in the types of environmental features experienced on a regular basis by people in a given cultural context.']
