['Why is the variable ratio reinforcement schedule considered to be one of the reasons that gambling is so addictive and resistant to extinction?', 'This is one of the reasons that gambling is so addictive—and so resistant to extinction.']

['Teacher: What is the relationship between the extinction of a reinforced behavior and the reinforcement schedule in operant conditioning?', 'In operant conditioning, extinction of a reinforced behavior occurs at some point after reinforcement stops, and the speed at which this happens depends on the reinforcement schedule.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why the point of extinction comes slowly in a variable ratio schedule, as described above?', 'In a variable ratio schedule, the point of extinction comes very slowly, as described above.']

['Teacher: Why is the point of extinction likely to come quickly in other reinforcement schedules, as opposed to a variable ratio schedule?', 'But in the other reinforcement schedules, extinction may come quickly.']

['What type of reinforcement schedule is being described in the given example?', 'For example, if June presses the button for the pain relief medication before the allotted time the doctor has approved, no medication is administered.']

['What happens in a fixed interval reinforcement schedule when reinforcement does not occur at the expected time?', 'They are on a fixed interval reinforcement schedule (dosed hourly), so extinction occurs quickly when reinforcement doesn’t come at the expected time.']
['What are the characteristics of a variable ratio reinforcement schedule?', 'Among the reinforcement schedules, variable ratio is the most productive and the most resistant to extinction.']

['What is the difference between a variable ratio reinforcement schedule and a fixed interval reinforcement schedule in terms of productivity and resistance to extinction?', 'Fixed interval is the least productive and the easiest to extinguish.']

['Teacher: What did strict behaviorists like Watson and Skinner primarily focus on studying?', 'Strict behaviorists like Watson and Skinner focused exclusively on studying behavior rather than cognition (such as thoughts and expectations).']

["Teacher: What did Skinner's belief that cognition didn't matter lead to in terms of his ideas being considered?", "In fact, Skinner was such a staunch believer that cognition didn't matter that his ideas were considered radical behaviorism."]

['Teacher: How did Skinner view the mind and why did he believe it should not be studied?', 'Skinner considered the mind a "black box"—something completely unknowable—and, therefore, something not to be studied.']
["Teacher: How did Edward C. Tolman's opinion differ from Skinner's regarding the study of the mind?", 'However, another behaviorist, Edward C. Tolman, had a different opinion.']

["Teacher: How did Edward C. Tolman's experiments challenge Skinner's belief about the necessity of immediate reinforcement for learning?", 'Tolman’s experiments with rats demonstrated that organisms can learn even if they do not receive immediate reinforcement (Tolman & Honzik, 1930; Tolman, Ritchie, & Kalish, 1946).']

["Teacher: How did Tolman's experiments challenge the prevailing idea at the time about the necessity of immediate reinforcement for learning?", 'This finding was in conflict with the prevailing idea at the time that reinforcement must be immediate in order for learning to occur, thus suggesting a cognitive aspect to learning.']
['Teacher: What did Tolman do with the hungry rats in the maze?', 'In the experiments, Tolman placed hungry rats in a maze with no reward for finding their way through it.']

['Teacher: Why did Tolman include a comparison group that was rewarded with food at the end of the maze in his experiments with hungry rats?', 'He also studied a comparison group that was rewarded with food at the end of the maze.']

['What did Tolman discover about the behavior of the unreinforced rats during their exploration of the maze?', 'As the unreinforced rats explored the maze, they developed a cognitive map: a mental picture of the layout of the maze.']

['Teacher: What did Tolman observe when he placed the food back in the goal box at the end of the maze for the unreinforced rats after 10 sessions?', 'After 10 sessions in the maze without reinforcement, food was placed in a goal box at the end of the maze.']

['Teacher: What did Tolman notice about the performance of the unreinforced rats in finding the food at the end of the maze, compared to the comparison group?', 'As soon as the rats became aware of the food, they were able to find their way through the maze quickly, just as quickly as the comparison group, which had been rewarded with food all along.']

['What is the term used to describe learning that occurs but is not observable in behavior until there is a reason to demonstrate it?', 'This is known as latent learning: learning that occurs but is not observable in behavior until there is a reason to demonstrate it.']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example of when latent learning has been observed in humans?', 'Latent learning also occurs in humans.']

["Teacher: Can you explain in what situations children may learn by watching their parents' actions?", 'Children may learn by watching the actions of their parents but only demonstrate it at a later date, when the learned material is needed.']
['Teacher: How might latent learning be demonstrated in the situation with Ravi and his dad driving him to school every day?', 'For example, suppose that Ravi’s dad drives him to school every day.']

["Teacher: How would Ravi's demonstration of latent learning change if he suddenly had to drive himself to school one day?", 'In this way, Ravi learns the route from his house to his school, but he’s never driven there himself, so he has not had a chance to demonstrate that he’s learned the way.']

["Teacher: How might Ravi's latent learning be demonstrated if he had to find an alternative route to school on his own one morning?", 'One morning Ravi’s dad has to leave early for a meeting, so he can’t drive Ravi to school.']

["Teacher: How does Ravi's behavior in finding an alternative route to school on his own demonstrate latent learning?", 'Instead, Ravi follows the same route on his bike that his dad would have taken in the car.']
["Why is Ravi's behavior of following the same route on his bike considered to be an example of latent learning?", 'This demonstrates latent learning.']
["What is the significance of Ravi's behavior in demonstrating latent learning?", 'Ravi had learned the route to school, but had no need to demonstrate this knowledge earlier.']

['Teacher: How does observational learning differ from classical and operant conditioning?', 'Previous sections of this chapter focused on classical and operant conditioning, which are forms of associative learning.']

['Teacher: Can you explain how observational learning differs from classical and operant conditioning in terms of how we acquire knowledge or behavior?', 'In observational learning, we learn by watching others and then imitating, or modeling, what they do or say.']

['Teacher: How does the act of observing others in observational learning contribute to our acquisition of knowledge or behavior?', 'The individuals performing the imitated behavior are called models.']

['Teacher: What role do mirror neurons play in the process of observational learning?', 'Research suggests that this imitative learning involves a specific type of neuron, called a mirror neuron (Hickock, 2010; Rizzolatti, Fadiga, Fogassi, & Gallese, 2002; Rizzolatti, Fogassi, & Gallese, 2006).']
['Teacher: What is observational learning?', 'Humans and other animals are capable of observational learning.']

['Teacher: How did the researchers study social learning in chimpanzees?', 'For example, in a study of social learning in chimpanzees, researchers gave juice boxes with straws to two groups of captive chimpanzees.']

['Teacher: What behavior did the second group of chimpanzees display when given the juice boxes with straws?', 'The first group dipped the straw into the juice box, and then sucked on the small amount of juice at the end of the straw.']

['Teacher: How did the behavior of the second group of chimpanzees differ from the behavior of the first group when given the juice boxes with straws?', 'The second group sucked through the straw directly, getting much more juice.']

['What behavior did all of the "dippers" in the first group of chimpanzees eventually switch to when given the juice boxes with straws?', 'All of the “dippers” in the first group switched to sucking through the straws directly.']

['What did the first group of chimpanzees learn from observing the behavior of the second group?', 'By simply observing the other chimps and modeling their behavior, they learned that this was a more efficient method of getting juice (Yamamoto, Humle, and Tanaka, 2013).']
['Teacher: According to the passage, why is imitation sometimes called the highest form of flattery?', 'Imitation is sometimes called the highest form of flattery.']

["Teacher: How does Claire's experience with observational learning relate to the concept of imitation being called the highest form of flattery?", 'But consider Claire’s experience with observational learning.']

["Teacher: How did Claire utilize observational learning to address her son's behavior issues at school and at home?", 'Claire’s nine-year-old son, Jay, was getting into trouble at school and was defiant at home.']

["Teacher: How did Claire use observational learning to address her son's behavior issues and prevent him from ending up like her brothers?", 'Claire feared that Jay would end up like her brothers, two of whom were in prison.']

["Teacher: What is the consequence of Claire's action of beating her son with a belt to get him to behave?", 'One day, after yet another bad day at school and another negative note from the teacher, Claire, at her wit’s end, beat her son with a belt to get him to behave.']

["What does Claire's observation of her daughter's behavior suggest about the consequence of Claire's action of beating her son with a belt?", 'Later that night, as she put her children to bed, Claire witnessed her four-year-old daughter, Anna, take a belt to her teddy bear and whip it.']

["What can we infer about the impact of Claire's action on her daughter based on her observation of Anna's behavior with the teddy bear?", 'Claire was horrified, realizing that Anna was imitating her mother.']

["What does Claire's realization that her daughter was imitating her suggest about her desire to discipline her children?", 'It was then that Claire knew she wanted to discipline her children in a different manner.']

["Teacher: How were Albert Bandura's ideas about learning different from those of strict behaviorists?", 'Like Tolman, whose experiments with rats suggested a cognitive component to learning, psychologist Albert Bandura’s ideas about learning were different from those of strict behaviorists.']

["Teacher: What is the main distinction between Bandura's social learning theory and the ideas of strict behaviorists regarding learning?", 'Bandura and other researchers proposed a brand of behaviorism called social learning theory, which took cognitive processes into account.']

['Teacher: Why did Bandura believe that pure behaviorism was insufficient in explaining learning in certain situations?', 'According to Bandura, pure behaviorism could not explain why learning can take place in the absence of external reinforcement.']

['Why did Bandura believe that internal mental states are important in observational learning?', 'He felt that internal mental states must also have a role in learning and that observational learning involves much more than imitation.']
['What is the difference between observational learning and imitation, according to Bandura?', 'In imitation, a person simply copies what the model does.']
['What does observational learning involve, according to Bandura?', 'Observational learning is much more complex.']
['What are some of the ways that observational learning can occur, according to Lefrançois (2012)?', 'According to Lefrançois (2012) there are several ways that observational learning can occur:']
['Teacher: How does the 6-4 observational learning model contribute to your ability to learn a new response?', 'You learn a new response.']

["Teacher: Excellent! Can you explain how this process of observing your coworker's experience and adjusting your behavior is an example of the 6-4 observational learning model?", 'After watching your coworker get chewed out by your boss for coming in late, you start leaving home 10 minutes earlier so that you won’t be late.']

["Why is it important to consider the consequences observed in the model's behavior before deciding whether or not to imitate it?", 'You choose whether or not to imitate the model depending on what you saw happen to the model.']

["How does Julian's behavior in learning to surf exemplify the process of observational learning according to the 6-4 observational learning model?", 'When learning to surf, Julian might watch how his father pops up successfully on his surfboard and then attempt to do the same thing.']

["What role does Julian's observation of his father's experience play in his decision to imitate or avoid touching a hot stove, according to the 6-4 observational learning model?", 'On the other hand, Julian might learn not to touch a hot stove after watching his father get burned on a stove.']

["What is the benefit of learning a general rule from observing someone else's experience, according to the 6-4 observational learning model?", 'You learn a general rule that you can apply to other situations.']

['Teacher: What are the three kinds of models that Bandura identified in his research on observational learning and modeling?', 'Bandura identified three kinds of models: live, verbal, and symbolic.']

['What is an example of a live model in the context of observational learning and modeling?', 'A live model demonstrates a behavior in person, as when Ben stood up on his surfboard so that Julian could see how he did it.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a verbal instructional model in the context of observational learning and modeling?', 'A verbal instructional model does not perform the behavior, but instead explains or describes the behavior, as when a soccer coach tells his young players to kick the ball with the side of the foot, not with the toe.']

['Teacher: How is a symbolic model different from a live or verbal model in the context of observational learning and modeling?', 'A symbolic model can be fictional characters or real people who demonstrate behaviors in books, movies, television shows, video games, or Internet sources.']
["Teacher: That's correct. Can you explain why we don't learn a behavior just by observing a model?", 'Of course, we don’t learn a behavior simply by observing a model.']

['Teacher: Excellent response! Can you explain what each of these steps in the modeling process entails?', 'Bandura described specific steps in the process of modeling that must be followed if learning is to be successful: attention, retention, reproduction, and motivation.']
['What is the second step in the modeling process according to Bandura?', 'First, you must be focused on what the model is doing—you have to pay attention.']
['What is the third step in the modeling process according to Bandura?', 'Next, you must be able to retain, or remember, what you observed; this is retention.']
['What is the final step in the modeling process according to Bandura?', 'Then, you must be able to perform the behavior that you observed and committed to memory; this is reproduction.']
['What is the first step in the modeling process according to Bandura?', 'Finally, you must have motivation.']

['What determines whether or not you are motivated to copy the behavior according to Bandura?', 'You need to want to copy the behavior, and whether or not you are motivated depends on what happened to the model.']

["What impact does reinforcement of the model's behavior have on your motivation to copy it, according to Bandura?", 'If you saw that the model was reinforced for their behavior, you will be more motivated to copy them.']

['What is the term used to describe the phenomenon where seeing someone else being reinforced for their behavior increases your motivation to copy that behavior?', 'This is known as vicarious reinforcement.']

["What impact does punishment of the model's behavior have on your motivation to copy it, according to Bandura?", 'On the other hand, if you observed the model being punished, you would be less motivated to copy them.']

['What is the term used to describe the phenomenon where seeing someone else being punished for their behavior decreases your motivation to copy that behavior?', 'This is called vicarious punishment.']

["What impact do you think Allison's observation of Kaitlyn's punishment would have on Allison's motivation to play with their mother's makeup?", 'For example, imagine that four-year-old Allison watched her older sister Kaitlyn playing in their mother’s makeup, and then saw Kaitlyn get a time out when their mother came in.']

["How do you think Allison's observation of Kaitlyn's punishment would impact Allison's motivation to play with their mother's makeup?", 'After their mother left the room, Allison was tempted to play in the make-up, but she did not want to get a time-out from her mother.']

["What role does reinforcement play in determining whether or not Allison will repeat the behavior of playing with her mother's makeup?", 'Once you actually demonstrate the new behavior, the reinforcement you receive plays a part in whether or not you will repeat the behavior.']

["Teacher: Who conducted research on modeling behavior, specifically focusing on children's modeling of adults' aggressive and violent behaviors?", 'Bandura researched modeling behavior, particularly children’s modeling of adults’ aggressive and violent behaviors (Bandura, Ross, & Ross, 1961).']
["Teacher: What was the purpose of Bandura's experiment with the Bobo doll?", 'He conducted an experiment with a five-foot inflatable doll that he called a Bobo doll.']

["Teacher: How did Bandura measure the children's aggressive behavior in the experiment with the Bobo doll?", 'In the experiment, children’s aggressive behavior was influenced by whether the teacher was punished for her behavior.']

["Teacher: What were the observations made by Bandura regarding the children's behavior after watching the teacher's aggressive actions towards the Bobo doll?", 'In one scenario, a teacher acted aggressively with the doll, hitting, throwing, and even punching the doll, while a child watched.']

["Teacher: What were the two types of responses exhibited by the children in reaction to the teacher's aggressive behavior towards the Bobo doll?", 'There were two types of responses by the children to the teacher’s behavior.']

["Teacher: What happened to the children's aggressive behavior when the teacher was rewarded for her aggressive actions towards the Bobo doll?", 'When the teacher was punished for her bad behavior, the children decreased their tendency to act as she had.']

["What was the impact on the children's behavior when the teacher was rewarded or praised for her aggressive actions towards the Bobo doll?", 'When the teacher was praised or ignored (and not punished for her behavior), the children imitated what she did, and even what she said.']
["What are the implications of Bandura's experiment with the Bobo doll on children's aggressive behavior?", 'They punched, kicked, and yelled at the doll.']

['Teacher: What did Bandura conclude about our learning process and its potential effects on our behavior?', 'Bandura concluded that we watch and learn, and that this learning can have both prosocial and antisocial effects.']
["What is one way prosocial (positive) models can be used according to Bandura's conclusion?", 'Prosocial (positive) models can be used to encourage socially acceptable behavior.']

["What group of people should pay attention to Bandura's finding regarding the use of prosocial models to encourage socially acceptable behavior?", 'Parents in particular should take note of this finding.']

["How can parents apply Bandura's finding about using prosocial models to encourage socially acceptable behavior in their parenting approach?", 'If you want your children to read, then read to them.']
['How can parents model prosocial behavior to their children?', 'Let them see you reading.']
['In addition to keeping books in your home, what else can parents do to model prosocial behavior to their children?', 'Keep books in your home.']
['What other ways can parents model prosocial behavior to their children besides keeping books in their home?', 'Talk about your favorite books.']

['What should parents do to model prosocial behavior related to health and fitness to their children?', 'If you want your children to be healthy, then let them see you eat right and exercise, and spend time engaging in physical fitness activities together.']

['What should parents do to model prosocial behavior related to qualities like kindness, courtesy, and honesty to their children?', 'The same holds true for qualities like kindness, courtesy, and honesty.']

['Why is it important for parents to be consistent in their behavior when modeling prosocial behavior to their children?', 'The main idea is that children observe and learn from their parents, even their parents’ morals, so be consistent and toss out the old adage “Do as I say, not as I do,” because children tend to copy what you do instead of what you say.']

['Who are some examples of public figures who are viewed as prosocial models?', 'Besides parents, many public figures, such as Martin Luther King, Jr. and Mahatma Gandhi, are viewed as prosocial models who are able to inspire global social change.']
['Teacher: What specific effects of observational learning should we consider regarding the topic we are discussing?', 'The antisocial effects of observational learning are also worth mentioning.']

['Teacher: Can you provide another example from the text that illustrates the antisocial effects of observational learning?', 'As you saw from the example of Claire at the beginning of this section, her daughter viewed Claire’s aggressive behavior and copied it.']

['Teacher: How does the research mentioned in the text link the antisocial effects of observational learning to the cycle of abuse?', 'Research suggests that this may help to explain why victims of abuse often grow up to be abusers themselves (Murrell, Christoff, & Henning, 2007).']

['Teacher: Based on the information provided in the text, why is it important to understand the link between the antisocial effects of observational learning and the cycle of abuse?', 'In fact, about 30% of child abuse victims become abusive parents (U.S. Department of Health & Human Services, 2013).']
['Teacher: How can understanding the link between the antisocial effects of observational learning and the cycle of abuse help us break this destructive pattern?', 'We tend to do what we know.']

["Teacher: Can you explain why it is important for us to intervene and provide alternative models for children who grow up witnessing their parents' aggressive behavior?", 'Children who grow up witnessing their parents deal with anger and frustration through violent and aggressive acts often learn to behave in that manner themselves.']

['Teacher: What does the passage suggest about the relationship between violent media and antisocial effects?', 'Some studies suggest that violent television shows, movies, and video games may also have antisocial effects although further research needs to be done to understand the correlational and causational aspects of media violence and behavior.']

['Teacher: What evidence does the passage provide for the relationship between violent media and antisocial effects?', 'Some studies have found a link between viewing violence and aggression seen in children (Anderson & Gentile, 2008; Kirsch, 2010; Miller, Grabell, Thomas, Bermann, & Graham-Bermann, 2012).']

['Teacher: How does the passage support the claim that exposure to violent media can lead to antisocial effects in children?', 'These findings may not be surprising, given that a child graduating from high school has been exposed to around 200,000 violent acts including murder, robbery, torture, bombings, beatings, and rape through various forms of media (Huston et al., 1992).']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example from the passage that illustrates how exposure to violent media can lead to desensitization?', 'Not only might viewing media violence affect aggressive behavior by teaching people to act that way in real life situations, but it has also been suggested that repeated exposure to violent acts also desensitizes people to it.']
['Teacher: Why are psychologists working to understand the dynamic of desensitization caused by exposure to violent media?', 'Psychologists are working to understand this dynamic.']
['Teacher: How would you describe the concept of cognition based on the passage?', 'Imagine all of your thoughts as if they were physical entities, swirling rapidly inside your mind.']

['Teacher: According to the passage, what are some of the activities that the brain is constantly engaged in?', 'The brain is endlessly perceiving, processing, planning, organizing, and remembering—it is always active.']

["Teacher: Why is it that we don't notice most of our brain's activity as we go about our daily routine, according to the passage?", 'Yet, you don’t notice most of your brain’s activity as you move throughout your daily routine.']
['Teacher: What are some other aspects or components of cognition that the passage may discuss?', 'This is only one facet of the complex processes involved in cognition.']

["Teacher: Can you provide examples of how cognition is involved in problem solving and judgment, based on what you've read in the passage?", 'Simply put, cognition is thinking, and it encompasses the processes associated with perception, knowledge, problem solving, judgment, language, and memory.']

['What are some examples of unconscious cognitive processes discussed in the passage?', 'Scientists who study cognition are searching for ways to understand how we integrate, organize, and utilize our conscious cognitive experiences without being aware of all of the unconscious work that our brains are doing (for example, Kahneman, 2011).']
['Teacher: What is the first thing you do when you wake up in the morning?', 'Upon waking each morning, you begin thinking—contemplating the tasks that you must complete that day.']
['Teacher: Can you explain how the thoughts you have upon waking in the morning are related to cognition?', 'These thoughts are one example of cognition at work.']

['Teacher: How would you describe the relationship between cognition and human consciousness?', 'Exceptionally complex, cognition is an essential feature of human consciousness, yet not all aspects of cognition are consciously experienced.']
['Teacher: What is the specific focus of cognitive psychology?', 'Cognitive psychology is the field of psychology dedicated to examining how people think.']

['Teacher: How does cognitive psychology contribute to our understanding of human thinking?', 'It attempts to explain how and why we think the way we do by studying the interactions among human thinking, emotion, creativity, language, and problem solving, in addition to other cognitive processes.']

['Teacher: What are some specific topics that cognitive psychologists strive to determine and measure in their research?', 'Cognitive psychologists strive to determine and measure different types of intelligence, why some people are better at problem solving than others, and how emotional intelligence affects success in the workplace, among countless other topics.']

['Teacher: How does cognitive psychology investigate the organization of thoughts and information gathered from the environment?', 'They also sometimes focus on how we organize thoughts and information gathered from our environments into meaningful categories of thought, which will be discussed later.']
['Teacher: How does the human nervous system demonstrate its ability to handle endless streams of information?', 'The human nervous system is capable of handling endless streams of information.']

["Teacher: How do the senses contribute to the human nervous system's ability to handle endless streams of information?", 'The senses serve as the interface between the mind and the external environment, receiving stimuli and translating it into nervous impulses that are transmitted to the brain.']

["Teacher: How does the concept of prototypes relate to the human brain's processing of information from the senses?", 'The brain then processes this information and uses the relevant pieces to create thoughts, which can then be expressed through language or stored in memory for future use.']

['Teacher: How does the concept of prototypes allow the brain to gather information from sources other than the external environment?', 'To make this process more complex, the brain does not gather information from external environments only.']

["Teacher: How do emotions and memories contribute to the brain's process of synthesizing information and forming thoughts?", 'When thoughts are formed, the mind synthesizes information from emotions and memories.']

['Teacher: How do emotions and memories influence the synthesis of information in the brain and formation of thoughts and behaviors?', 'Emotion and memory are powerful influences on both our thoughts and behaviors.']
['Teacher: How does the mind organize the large amount of information?', 'In order to organize this staggering amount of information, the mind has developed a "file cabinet" of sorts in the mind.']
['Teacher: What does the mind use to store the different types of information in its "file cabinet"?', 'The different files stored in the file cabinet are called concepts.']

['Teacher: How does the mind represent or symbolize linguistic information, images, ideas, or memories within concepts?', 'Concepts are categories or groupings of linguistic information, images, ideas, or memories, such as life experiences.']

['Teacher: How does the mind generate concepts based on observing details and categorizing and combining them?', 'Concepts are, in many ways, big ideas that are generated by observing details, and categorizing and combining these details into cognitive structures.']

['Teacher: How do concepts help in understanding the relationships between different elements of our experiences and in keeping information organized and accessible in our minds?', 'You use concepts to see the relationships among the different elements of your experiences and to keep the information in your mind organized and accessible.']

['Teacher: Where can we easily notice concepts?', 'Concepts are informed by our semantic memory (you will learn more about semantic memory in a later chapter) and are present in every aspect of our lives; however, one of the easiest places to notice concepts is inside a classroom, where they are discussed explicitly.']

['Teacher: Besides a classroom, where else can we easily notice concepts?', 'When you study United States history, for example, you learn about more than just individual events that have happened in America’s past.']

['Teacher: Besides studying United States history, where else can concepts be easily noticed?', 'You absorb a large quantity of information by listening to and participating in discussions, examining maps, and reading first-hand accounts of people’s lives.']

['Teacher: How does your brain analyze details and develop an overall understanding of American history?', 'Your brain analyzes these details and develops an overall understanding of American history.']

['Teacher: How do the details analyzed by your brain contribute to the understanding of concepts like democracy, power, and freedom in American history?', 'In the process, your brain gathers details that inform and refine your understanding of related concepts like democracy, power, and freedom.']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a concept that is complex and abstract?', 'Concepts can be complex and abstract, like justice, or more concrete, like types of birds.']
["Teacher: Can you explain how Piaget's stages of development can be considered abstract concepts in psychology?", 'In psychology, for example, Piaget’s stages of development are abstract concepts.']

['Teacher: How can the agreement upon a concept over time contribute to its complex and abstract nature?', 'Some concepts, like tolerance, are agreed upon by many people, because they have been used in various ways over many years.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a concept that is both complex and abstract, but also personal and individualized?', 'Other concepts, like the characteristics of your ideal friend or your family’s birthday traditions, are personal and individualized.']

['Why are concepts considered to be an integral part of various aspects of our lives?', 'In this way, concepts touch every aspect of our lives, from our many daily routines to the guiding principles behind the way governments function.']

['Teacher: Can you explain how the identification of prototypes helps the brain organize information in the context of concepts?', 'Another technique used by your brain to organize information is the identification of prototypes for the concepts you have developed.']

['Teacher: What role does the identification of prototypes play in helping the brain organize information within the context of concepts?', 'A prototype is the best example or representation of a concept.']

['Teacher: How do early experiences with dogs influence our imagination when it comes to identifying prototypes for the concept of dogs?', 'Most likely your early experiences with dogs will shape what you imagine.']
['What factors influence the formation of prototypes for concepts?', 'If your first pet was a Golden Retriever, there is a good chance that this would be your prototype for the category of dogs.']
['Teacher: How can concepts in psychology be categorized?', 'In psychology, concepts can be divided into two categories, natural and artificial.']

['Teacher: Can you explain what natural concepts are and how they are formed?', 'Natural concepts are created “naturally” through your experiences and can be developed from either direct or indirect experiences.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of an artificial concept and explain how it differs from a natural concept?', 'For example, if you live in Essex Junction, Vermont, you have probably had a lot of direct experience with snow.']

['Teacher: How does the experience with snow in Essex Junction, Vermont contribute to the formation of a natural concept?', 'You’ve watched it fall from the sky, you’ve seen lightly falling snow that barely covers the windshield of your car, and you’ve shoveled out 18 inches of fluffy white snow as you’ve thought, “This is perfect for skiing.”']

['Teacher: How do these direct experiences with snow in Essex Junction, Vermont contribute to the formation of a natural concept?', 'You’ve thrown snowballs at your best friend and gone sledding down the steepest hill in town.']
['Teacher: What kinds of experiences with snow in Essex Junction, Vermont help in forming a natural concept?', 'In short, you know snow.']

["Teacher: What are some qualities of a natural concept that you've learned through your experiences with snow in Essex Junction, Vermont?", 'You know what it looks like, smells like, tastes like, and feels like.']

['What impact does the absence of direct experiences with snow in the Caribbean have on the formation of a natural concept?', 'If, however, you’ve lived your whole life on the island of Saint Vincent in the Caribbean, you may never have actually seen snow, much less tasted, smelled, or touched it.']

['How does the absence of direct experiences with snow in the Caribbean impact the formation of a natural concept?', 'You know snow from the indirect experience of seeing pictures of falling snow—or from watching films that feature snow as part of the setting.']

['What are some ways in which someone living in the Caribbean can form a natural concept of snow, despite the absence of direct experiences?', 'Either way, snow is a natural concept because you can construct an understanding of it through direct observations, experiences with snow, or indirect knowledge (such as from films or books).']
['Teacher: Can you provide a definition of an artificial concept?', 'An artificial concept, on the other hand, is a concept that is defined by a specific set of characteristics.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of an artificial concept besides geometric shapes like squares and triangles?', 'Various properties of geometric shapes, like squares and triangles, serve as useful examples of artificial concepts.']
['Teacher: Can you tell me why the concept of a triangle is considered an artificial concept?', 'A triangle always has three angles and three sides.']
['Teacher: What is the definition of a natural concept?', 'A square always has four equal sides and four right angles.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a natural concept besides mathematical formulas like the equation for area?', 'Mathematical formulas, like the equation for area (length × width) are artificial concepts defined by specific sets of characteristics that are always the same.']
['Teacher: How can artificial concepts contribute to the comprehension of a subject?', 'Artificial concepts can enhance the understanding of a topic by building on one another.']

['Teacher: How can understanding natural concepts help in comprehending artificial concepts?', 'For example, before learning the concept of “area of a square” (and the formula to find it), you must understand what a square is.']

['Teacher: How can understanding natural concepts, such as the characteristics of geometric shapes, support the comprehension of artificial concepts?', 'Once the concept of “area of a square” is understood, an understanding of area for other geometric shapes can be built upon the original understanding of area.']

['What is the role of artificial concepts in communication and complex thought?', 'The use of artificial concepts to define an idea is crucial to communicating with others and engaging in complex thought.']

['Teacher: How do artificial concepts contribute to the process of forming complex thoughts and ideas, according to the research by Goldstone and Kersten (2003)?', 'According to Goldstone and Kersten (2003), concepts act as building blocks and can be connected in countless combinations to create complex thoughts.']

["Teacher: Can you explain what a schema is based on Bartlett's definition from the passage?", 'A schema is a mental construct consisting of a cluster or collection of related concepts (Bartlett, 1932).']

['What is the purpose of schemata according to the passage?', 'There are many different types of schemata, and they all have one thing in common: schemata are a method of organizing information that allows the brain to work more efficiently.']

["Teacher: How does the activation of a schema influence the brain's processing of information?", 'When a schema is activated, the brain makes immediate assumptions about the person or object being observed.']
['Teacher: Can you please elaborate on the different types of schemata mentioned in the passage?', 'There are several types of schemata.']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a role schema mentioned in the passage?', 'A role schema makes assumptions about how individuals in certain roles will behave (Callero, 1994).']

['What assumptions might you make about someone who introduces themselves as a firefighter, based on the role schema?', 'For example, imagine you meet someone who introduces himself as a firefighter.']

['What other assumptions might your brain make about this person based on the "firefighter schema"?', 'When this happens, your brain automatically activates the “firefighter schema” and begins making assumptions that this person is brave, selfless, and community-oriented.']

['What is the reason that our brains may automatically activate the "firefighter schema" when we meet someone who introduces themselves as a firefighter?', 'Despite not knowing this person, already you have unknowingly made judgments about them.']

['What role do schemata play in helping us understand and interpret information we receive from the world around us?', 'Schemata also help you fill in gaps in the information you receive from the world around you.']

['What are some potential problems with relying too heavily on schemata when interpreting information about others?', 'While schemata allow for more efficient information processing, there can be problems with schemata, regardless of whether they are accurate: Perhaps this particular firefighter is not brave, they just work as a firefighter to pay the bills while studying to become a children’s librarian.']

['Teacher: What is an event schema, or also known as a cognitive script, in relation to behaviors?', 'An event schema, also known as a cognitive script, is a set of behaviors that can feel like a routine.']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example of an event schema or cognitive script in your everyday life?', 'Think about what you do when you walk into an elevator.']

['Teacher: What might be the next step in the event schema or cognitive script when you walk into an elevator?', 'First, the doors open and you wait to let exiting passengers leave the elevator car.']

['What other behaviors or actions might you engage in as part of the event schema when you are inside the elevator?', 'Then, you step into the elevator and turn around to face the doors, looking for the correct button to push.']
['What does it mean when we say that event schemata can vary widely among different cultures and countries?', 'Interestingly, event schemata can vary widely among different cultures and countries.']

['How do different cultures and countries demonstrate variations in their event schemata or cognitive scripts related to greetings?', 'For example, while it is quite common for people to greet one another with a handshake in the United States, in Tibet, you greet someone by sticking your tongue out at them, and in Belize, you bump fists (Cairns Regional Council, n.d.)']
['Teacher: Why can event schemata be difficult to change?', 'Because event schemata are automatic, they can be difficult to change.']
['Teacher: Why is it difficult to change event schemata?', 'Imagine that you are driving home from work or school.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why the event schema for driving home involves getting in the car, shutting the door, and buckling your seatbelt before putting the key in the ignition?', 'This event schema involves getting in the car, shutting the door, and buckling your seatbelt before putting the key in the ignition.']
['Teacher: How does repetition contribute to the difficulty of changing event schemata for driving home?', 'You might perform this script two or three times each day.']
["Teacher: What is the potential consequence of hearing your phone's ring tone while driving home?", 'As you drive home, you hear your phone’s ring tone.']

['Teacher: What does the event schema that occurs when you hear your phone ringing involve?', 'Typically, the event schema that occurs when you hear your phone ringing involves locating the phone and answering it or responding to your latest text message.']

['Teacher: Why can reaching for your phone while driving home be dangerous?', 'So without thinking, you reach for your phone, which could be in your pocket, in your bag, or on the passenger seat of the car.']

['Teacher: How can the powerful event schema of reaching for your phone while driving home be influenced by your pattern of behavior and the pleasurable stimulation of a phone call or text message?', 'This powerful event schema is informed by your pattern of behavior and the pleasurable stimulation that a phone call or text message gives your brain.']

['Teacher: What makes it challenging for us to stop reaching for the phone, even though we know it endangers our lives and the lives of others?', 'Because it is a schema, it is extremely challenging for us to stop reaching for the phone, even though we know that we endanger our own lives and the lives of others while we do it (Neyfakh, 2013).']
['Teacher: What does it feel like when you walk into a room and face the door?', 'It feels almost impossible to walk in and not face the door.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how our powerful event schema affects our behavior with our phones?', 'Our powerful event schema dictates our behavior in the elevator, and it is no different with our phones.']

['Teacher: How does our powerful event schema affect our behavior with checking our phones while driving?', 'Current research suggests that it is the habit, or event schema, of checking our phones in many different situations that makes refraining from checking them while driving especially difficult (Bayer & Campbell, 2012).']

['What is the focus of psychologists\' research related to the "phone schema" and driving?', 'Because texting and driving has become a dangerous epidemic in recent years, psychologists are looking at ways to help people interrupt the “phone schema” while driving.']
['What is the impact of event schemata on breaking acquired habits?', 'Event schemata like these are the reason why many habits are difficult to break once they have been acquired.']

['Why is it important for us to be aware of the power of concepts and schemata in our understanding of the world?', 'As we continue to examine thinking, keep in mind how powerful the forces of concepts and schemata are to our understanding of the world.']

['Teacher: How would you define language?', 'Language is a communication system that involves using words and systematic rules to organize those words to transmit information from one individual to another.']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example of communication that is not considered language?', 'While language is a form of communication, not all communication is language.']

['Teacher: Can you give me an example of how animals communicate with each other without using language?', 'Many species communicate with one another through their postures, movements, odors, or vocalizations.']

['Teacher: Why is communication through postures, movements, odors, or vocalizations crucial for species that need to interact and develop social relationships with their conspecifics?', 'This communication is crucial for species that need to interact and develop social relationships with their conspecifics.']

['Teacher: What is the argument made by some researchers regarding the uniqueness of humans compared to other animal species?', 'However, many people have asserted that it is language that makes humans unique among all of the animal species (Corballis & Suddendorf, 2007; Tomasello & Rakoczy, 2003).']

['Teacher: What are the main aspects that will be explored in this section?', 'This section will focus on what distinguishes language as a special form of communication, how the use of language develops, and how language affects the way we think.']
['Teacher: What are the specific components of language?', 'Language, be it spoken, signed, or written, has specific components: a lexicon and grammar.']
['Teacher: Excellent! Can you explain what is meant by "grammar" when it comes to the components of language?', 'Lexicon refers to the words of a given language.']
['Teacher: That is correct. Now, could you explain what "lexicon" means in the context of language components?', 'Thus, lexicon is a language’s vocabulary.']

['Teacher: Great job explaining the concept of lexicon! Now, can you provide an example of how grammar is used to convey meaning through the lexicon?', 'Grammar refers to the set of rules that are used to convey meaning through the use of the lexicon (Fernández & Cairns, 2011).']

['Teacher: Excellent example! Can you think of another rule in English grammar that conveys meaning through the lexicon?', 'For instance, English grammar dictates that most verbs receive an “-ed” at the end to indicate past tense.']
['Teacher: How are words formed in a language?', 'Words are formed by combining the various phonemes that make up the language.']
['What are phonemes?', 'A phoneme (e.g., the sounds “ah” vs. “eh”) is a basic sound unit of a given language, and different languages have different sets of phonemes.']

['Teacher: How are morphemes formed in a language?', 'Phonemes are combined to form morphemes, which are the smallest units of language that convey some type of meaning (e.g., “I” is both a phoneme and a morpheme).']
['What are semantics and syntax?', 'We use semantics and syntax to construct language.']
['Teacher: How do semantics and syntax contribute to constructing language?', 'Semantics and syntax are part of a language’s grammar.']
['What does syntax refer to?', 'Semantics refers to the process by which we derive meaning from morphemes and words.']
['What does semantics refer to?', 'Syntax refers to the way words are organized into sentences (Chomsky, 1965; Fernández & Cairns, 2011).']

['Teacher: How do we utilize the rules of grammar in order to communicate information about both concrete and abstract concepts?', 'We apply the rules of grammar to organize the lexicon in novel and creative ways, which allow us to communicate information about both concrete and abstract concepts.']

['Teacher: Can you give me an example of how we can apply the rules of grammar to communicate information about concrete concepts?', 'We can talk about our immediate and observable surroundings as well as the surface of unseen planets.']

['What are some examples of abstract concepts that we can communicate using the rules of grammar?', 'We can share our innermost thoughts, our plans for the future, and debate the value of a college education.']

['How can we utilize the rules of grammar to communicate information about concrete processes or actions?', 'We can provide detailed instructions for cooking a meal, fixing a car, or building a fire.']

['What are some examples of abstract processes or actions that we can communicate using the rules of grammar?', 'Through our use of words and language, we are able to form, organize, and express ideas, schema, and artificial concepts.']

['Teacher: What might one expect, given the remarkable complexity of a language?', 'Given the remarkable complexity of a language, one might expect that mastering a language would be an especially arduous task; indeed, for those of us trying to learn a second language as adults, this might seem to be true.']
['Teacher: Why might it seem arduous for adults to master a second language, according to the passage?', 'However, young children master language very quickly with relative ease.']
['Teacher: According to B. F. Skinner, how is language learned?', 'B. F. Skinner (1957) proposed that language is learned through reinforcement.']

['Teacher: According to Noam Chomsky, what did he assert about the mechanisms underlying language acquisition?', 'Noam Chomsky (1965) criticized this behaviorist approach, asserting instead that the mechanisms underlying language acquisition are biologically determined.']

['Teacher: What does the passage suggest about the development of language in children from diverse cultures and backgrounds?', 'The use of language develops in the absence of formal instruction and appears to follow a very similar pattern in children from vastly different cultures and backgrounds.']

['What does the passage imply about the role of formal instruction in the development of language in children from different cultures and backgrounds?', 'It would seem, therefore, that we are born with a biological predisposition to acquire a language (Chomsky, 1965; Fernández & Cairns, 2011).']

['What does the passage suggest about the critical period for language acquisition?', 'Moreover, it appears that there is a critical period for language acquisition, such that this proficiency at acquiring language is maximal early in life; generally, as people age, the ease with which they acquire and master new languages diminishes (Johnson & Newport, 1989; Lenneberg, 1967; Singleton, 1995).']
['Teacher: When do children start to learn about language?', 'Children begin to learn about language from a very early age.']
['Teacher: How soon do children start to learn about language?', 'In fact, it appears that this is occurring even before we are born.']

['Teacher: What evidence supports the claim that newborns are already learning about language before birth?', 'Newborns show preference for their mother’s voice and appear to be able to discriminate between the language spoken by their mother and other languages.']

['What are some examples of how newborns demonstrate their awareness and preference for language?', 'Babies are also attuned to the languages being used around them and show preferences for videos of faces that are moving in synchrony with the audio of spoken language versus videos that do not synchronize with the audio (Blossom & Morgan, 2006; Pickens, 1994; Spelke & Cortelyou, 1981).']

['Teacher: What term is used to describe the smallest meaningful units in a language that are combined to form words?', 'You may recall that each language has its own set of phonemes that are used to generate morphemes, words, and so on.']

['What term is used to describe the ability of babies to differentiate between the sounds of all human languages, even those that do not occur in the languages used in their environments?', 'Babies can discriminate among the sounds that make up a language (for example, they can tell the difference between the “s” in vision and the “ss” in fission); early on, they can differentiate between the sounds of all human languages, even those that do not occur in the languages that are used in their environments.']

["What is the term used to describe the change in babies' ability to discriminate between sounds as they get older and become more familiar with their native language?", 'However, by the time that they are about 1 year old, they can only discriminate among those phonemes that are used in the language or languages in their environments (Jensen, 2011; Werker & Lalonde, 1988; Werker & Tees, 1984).']

['Teacher: What is the name given to the stage in which babies produce single syllables that are repeated over and over?', 'After the first few months of life, babies enter what is known as the babbling stage, during which time they tend to produce single syllables that are repeated over and over.']
['What is the name of the stage in which babies tend to produce single syllables that are repeated over and over?', 'As time passes, more variations appear in the syllables that they produce.']

['What is the likelihood of babies trying to communicate during the babbling stage?', 'During this time, it is unlikely that the babies are trying to communicate; they are just as likely to babble when they are alone as when they are with their caregivers (Fernández & Cairns, 2011).']

['How do babies who are raised in environments where sign language is used also demonstrate babbling during the babbling stage?', 'Interestingly, babies who are raised in environments in which sign language is used will also begin to show babbling in the gestures of their hands during this stage (Petitto, Holowka, Sergio, Levy, & Ostry, 2004).']

['Teacher: At what age is a child generally expected to start speaking their first word?', 'Generally, a child’s first word is uttered sometime between the ages of 1 year to 18 months, and for the next few months, the child will remain in the “one word” stage of language development.']
['What stage of language development is a child in when they are producing only one-word utterances?', 'During this time, children know a number of words, but they only produce one-word utterances.']
['What are some examples of familiar objects or events that a child might use in their one-word utterances?', 'The child’s early vocabulary is limited to familiar objects or events, often nouns.']

['What does it mean for one-word utterances to carry larger meaning?', 'Although children in this stage only make one-word utterances, these words often carry larger meaning (Fernández & Cairns, 2011).']
["What are some ways in which a child's one-word utterances can convey larger meaning?", 'So, for example, a child saying “cookie” could be identifying a cookie or asking for a cookie.']
["Teacher: What happens as a child's lexicon grows?", 'As a child’s lexicon grows, they begin to utter simple sentences and to acquire new vocabulary at a very rapid pace.']

["What happens to a child's understanding of language rules as their lexicon grows?", 'In addition, children begin to demonstrate a clear understanding of the specific rules that apply to their language(s).']

["Teacher: How do children's mistakes in language development provide evidence of their understanding of language rules?", 'Even the mistakes that children sometimes make provide evidence of just how much they understand about those rules.']
["What specific examples of overgeneralization can be observed in children's language development?", 'This is sometimes seen in the form of overgeneralization.']
["What does overgeneralization in children's language development refer to?", 'In this context, overgeneralization refers to an extension of a language rule to an exception to the rule.']

["What are some other examples of overgeneralization in children's language development?", 'For example, in English, it is usually the case that an “s” is added to the end of a word to indicate plurality.']
['What might be an example of overgeneralization in children\'s language development related to adding an "s" to indicate plurality?', 'For example, we speak of one dog versus two dogs.']

['What does the phenomenon of overgeneralization in children\'s language development refer to when it comes to adding an "s" to indicate plurality?', 'Young children will overgeneralize this rule to cases that are exceptions to the “add an s to the end of the word” rule and say things like “those two gooses” or “three mouses.”']

["What is the significance of children's overgeneralization in their language development?", 'Clearly, the rules of the language are understood, even if the exceptions to the rules are still being learned (Moskowitz, 1978).']

['Teacher: Can you explain why we agree that words in a language represent ideas, people, places, and events?', 'When we speak one language, we agree that words are representations of ideas, people, places, and events.']

['Teacher: How does the connection between the language children learn and their culture and surroundings support the idea that words represent ideas, people, places, and events?', 'The given language that children learn is connected to their culture and surroundings.']

['Teacher: What is the central question that psychologists have been investigating regarding language and thought?', 'Psychologists have long investigated the question of whether language shapes thoughts and actions, or whether our thoughts and beliefs shape our language.']

['Teacher: Who were the two researchers who initiated the investigation on the relationship between language and thought in the 1940s?', 'Two researchers, Edward Sapir and Benjamin Lee Whorf, began this investigation in the 1940s.']

['What was the main goal of the investigation initiated by Sapir and Whorf in the 1940s?', 'They wanted to understand how the language habits of a community encourage members of that community to interpret language in a particular manner (Sapir, 1941/1964).']
['What is the Sapir-Whorf hypothesis and how does it relate to the investigation on language and thought?', 'Sapir and Whorf proposed that language determines thought.']

['How does the diversity of words for "love" in different languages support the Sapir-Whorf hypothesis that language determines thought?', 'For example, in some languages there are many different words for love.']

['How does the fact that English uses the same word "love" for all types of love challenge the Sapir-Whorf hypothesis that language determines thought?', 'However, in English we use the word love for all types of love.']

['What are some criticisms that researchers have made about the Sapir-Whorf hypothesis?', 'Researchers have since identified this view as too absolute, pointing out a lack of empiricism behind what Sapir and Whorf proposed (Abler, 2013; Boroditsky, 2011; van Troyer, 1994).']

['What are some alternative theories or perspectives that psychologists have proposed regarding the relationship between language and thought?', 'Today, psychologists continue to study and debate the relationship between language and thought.']
['Teacher: What is the concept that suggests that language can influence our thinking?', 'Language may indeed influence the way that we think, an idea known as linguistic determinism.']

["Teacher: Can you provide an example of how linguistic determinism is shown in the differences between English and Mandarin Chinese speakers' perception of time?", 'One recent demonstration of this phenomenon involved differences in the way that English and Mandarin Chinese speakers talk and think about time.']

['Teacher: How do Mandarin Chinese speakers typically talk about time that reflects linguistic determinism?', 'English speakers tend to talk about time using terms that describe changes along a horizontal dimension, for example, saying something like “I’m running behind schedule” or “Don’t get ahead of yourself.”']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how Mandarin Chinese speakers describe time using terms associated with a vertical arrangement?', 'While Mandarin Chinese speakers also describe time in horizontal terms, it is not uncommon to also use terms associated with a vertical arrangement.']
['Teacher: How does the vertical arrangement of time in Mandarin Chinese reflect linguistic determinism?', 'For example, the past might be described as being “up” and the future as being “down.”']

['Teacher: What do the differences in language and thinking between English and Mandarin Chinese speakers ultimately result in?', 'It turns out that these differences in language translate into differences in performance on cognitive tests designed to measure how quickly an individual can recognize temporal relationships.']

['Teacher: How does the performance of Mandarin Chinese speakers on cognitive tests comparing temporal relationships differ from that of English speakers?', 'Specifically, when given a series of tasks with vertical priming, Mandarin Chinese speakers were faster at recognizing temporal relationships between months.']

["What is the significance of Boroditsky's (2001) statement regarding the relationship between language and thought?", 'Indeed, Boroditsky (2001) sees these results as suggesting that “habits in language encourage habits in thought” (p. 12).']

['Teacher: What did the group of researchers aim to investigate?', 'One group of researchers who wanted to investigate how language influences thought compared how English speakers and the Dani people of Papua New Guinea think and speak about color.']

['Teacher: How did the researchers compare the thinking and speaking about color between English speakers and the Dani people of Papua New Guinea?', 'The Dani have two words for color: one word for light and one word for dark.']
['Teacher: How does the number of color words in the Dani language compare to the number of color words in the English language?', 'In contrast, the English language has 11 color words.']

["Teacher: What hypothesis did the researchers have regarding the number of color terms and its effect on the Dani people's conceptualization of color?", 'Researchers hypothesized that the number of color terms could limit the ways that the Dani people conceptualized color.']

["Teacher: How did the researchers find evidence to support or refute their hypothesis about the Dani people's conceptualization of color despite having fewer color words?", 'However, the Dani were able to distinguish colors with the same ability as English speakers, despite having fewer words at their disposal (Berlin & Kay, 1969).']

['Teacher: What does a recent review of research suggest about the influence of language on perceptual phenomena, particularly in the left hemisphere of the brain?', 'A recent review of research aimed at determining how language might affect something like color perception suggests that language can influence perceptual phenomena, especially in the left hemisphere of the brain.']

['Teacher: According to the recent review of research, how does language influence perceptual phenomena, particularly in the left hemisphere of the brain?', 'You may recall from earlier chapters that the left hemisphere is associated with language for most people.']

['Teacher: How does the recent review of research suggest that language influences perceptual phenomena in the right hemisphere of the brain?', 'However, the right (less linguistic hemisphere) of the brain is less affected by linguistic influences on perception (Regier & Kay, 2009)']
['Teacher: How frequently do people face problems?', 'People face problems every day—usually, multiple problems throughout the day.']
['What type of problems are considered straightforward?', 'Sometimes these problems are straightforward:']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a problem that is considered straightforward?', 'To double a recipe for pizza dough, for example, all that is required is that each ingredient in the recipe be doubled.']
['Teacher: Can you give an example of a problem that is more complex than doubling a recipe for pizza dough?', 'Sometimes, however, the problems we encounter are more complex.']

['Teacher: What makes the problem of meeting a work deadline and mailing a report more complex compared to doubling a recipe for pizza dough?', 'For example, say you have a work deadline, and you must mail a printed copy of a report to your supervisor by the end of the business day.']

['Teacher: Why would sending a report overnight make the problem of meeting a work deadline more complex compared to doubling a recipe for pizza dough?', 'The report is time-sensitive and must be sent overnight.']
['What impact does the printer not working have on the problem of meeting a work deadline and mailing a report?', 'You finished the report last night, but your printer will not work today.']

['What steps can you take to address the issue of the printer not working when you need to meet a work deadline and mail a report?', 'First, you need to identify the problem and then apply a strategy for solving the problem.']
['Teacher: Can you explain why it is important to clearly identify the problem before finding a solution?', 'Before finding a solution to the problem, the problem must first be clearly identified.']

['Teacher: Why is it necessary to clearly identify the problem before applying problem-solving strategies?', 'After that, one of many problem solving strategies can be applied, hopefully resulting in a solution.']
['What is a problem-solving strategy and how is it used?', 'A problem-solving strategy is a plan of action used to find a solution.']
['What is the purpose of having different action plans associated with different problem-solving strategies?', 'Different strategies have different action plans associated with them.']
['Can you explain how the trial and error strategy is used in problem-solving?', 'For example, a well-known strategy is trial and error.']

['What does the old adage "If at first you don\'t succeed, try, try again" suggest about the trial and error strategy in problem-solving?', 'The old adage, “If at first you don’t succeed, try, try again” describes trial and error.']

['What are some examples of steps or actions you could take when using the trial and error strategy to solve a problem?', 'In terms of your broken printer, you could try checking the ink levels, and if that doesn’t work, you could check to make sure the paper tray isn’t jammed.']

['What does the student suggest about the trial and error strategy when mentioning that "the printer isn\'t actually connected to your laptop"?', 'Or maybe the printer isn’t actually connected to your laptop.']

["How does the student's suggestion relate to the use of the trial and error strategy in problem-solving?", 'When using trial and error, you would continue to try different solutions until you solved your problem.']
['What is one downside of using the trial and error strategy in problem-solving?', 'Although trial and error is not typically one of the most time-efficient strategies, it is a commonly used one.']
['Teacher: Can you give me an example of another type of strategy?', 'Another type of strategy is an algorithm.']

['Teacher: How would you define an algorithm and its purpose in problem-solving?', 'An algorithm is a problem-solving formula that provides you with step-by-step instructions used to achieve a desired outcome (Kahneman, 2011).']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a real-life situation where an algorithm can be used as a problem-solving strategy?', 'You can think of an algorithm as a recipe with highly detailed instructions that produce the same result every time they are performed.']
['Teacher: In what ways are algorithms used in computer science?', 'Algorithms are used frequently in our everyday lives, especially in computer science.']

['Teacher: How do search engines like Google use algorithms in computer science to determine the order of search results?', 'When you run a search on the Internet, search engines like Google use algorithms to decide which entries will appear first in your list of results.']

['Teacher: Can you think of any other examples of how algorithms are used in computer science besides search engines and social media platforms like Facebook?', 'Facebook also uses algorithms to decide which posts to display on your newsfeed.']
['Teacher: Can you explain to me what a heuristic is, and how it differs from other problem-solving strategies?', 'A heuristic is another type of problem solving strategy.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how a heuristic can be used in problem-solving?', 'While an algorithm must be followed exactly to produce a correct result, a heuristic is a general problem-solving framework (Tversky & Kahneman, 1974).']
['Teacher: How does a heuristic differ from an algorithm in terms of flexibility and precision?', 'You can think of these as mental shortcuts that are used to solve problems.']
['What is an example of a mental shortcut used in problem-solving that is referred to as a "rule of thumb"?', 'A “rule of thumb” is an example of a heuristic.']

['What are some advantages and disadvantages of using a "rule of thumb" heuristic in problem-solving?', 'Such a rule saves the person time and energy when making a decision, but despite its time-saving characteristics, it is not always the best method for making a rational decision.']

['What are the five conditions that may lead to the use of a heuristic in problem-solving?', 'Different types of heuristics are used in different types of situations, but the impulse to use a heuristic occurs when one of five conditions is met (Pratkanis, 1989):']
['Teacher: What is one common scenario that requires problem-solving strategies?', 'When the time to make a decision is limited']
['What is another scenario in which problem-solving strategies are necessary?', 'When there is access to very little information to use in making the decision']
['What is a third scenario in which problem-solving strategies are useful?', 'When an appropriate heuristic happens to come to mind in the same moment']

['Teacher: Can you explain the concept of working backwards as a problem-solving strategy?', 'Working backwards is a useful heuristic in which you begin solving the problem by focusing on the end result.']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how working backwards can be applied as a problem-solving strategy?', 'Consider this example:']

['Teacher: How could you use the working backwards strategy to ensure that you arrive at the wedding in Philadelphia on time?', 'You live in Washington, D.C. and have been invited to a wedding at 4 PM on Saturday in Philadelphia.']

['Teacher: What steps would you take to apply the working backwards strategy in this situation?', 'Knowing that Interstate 95 tends to back up any day of the week, you need to plan your route and time your departure accordingly.']

['How does using the working backwards strategy help you plan your day more effectively?', 'You use the working backwards heuristic to plan the events of your day on a regular basis, probably without even thinking about it.']

['Teacher: Can you explain another problem-solving strategy that involves breaking a large goal or task into smaller steps?', 'Another useful heuristic is the practice of accomplishing a large goal or task by breaking it into a series of smaller steps.']

['Teacher: How can students apply the strategy of breaking a large goal or task into smaller steps in completing a research project or long essay for school?', 'Students often use this common method to complete a large research project or long essay for school.']

['What are the different steps involved in completing a research project or a long essay using the strategy of breaking a large goal or task into smaller steps?', 'For example, students typically brainstorm, develop a thesis or main topic, research the chosen topic, organize their information into an outline, write a rough draft, revise and edit the rough draft, develop a final draft, organize the references list, and proofread their work before turning in the project.']
['What is the advantage of breaking a large task into a series of small steps?', 'The large task becomes less overwhelming when it is broken down into a series of small steps.']
['Teacher: What can you say about the success rate of problem solving?', 'Not all problems are successfully solved, however.']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a potential pitfall to problem solving in the situation you mentioned?', 'Imagine a person in a room that has four doorways.']
['Teacher: How does the locked doorway present a potential pitfall to problem solving in this situation?', 'One doorway that has always been open in the past is now locked.']

['Teacher: Why does the person continue to try to exit through the locked doorway even though there are three other open doorways available?', 'The person, accustomed to exiting the room by that particular doorway, keeps trying to get out through the same doorway even though the other three doorways are open.']

['Teacher: What advice would you give to the person in order to overcome the pitfall of trying to exit through the locked doorway?', 'The person is stuck—but they just need to go to another doorway, instead of trying to get out through the locked doorway.']

['Teacher: How does a mental set contribute to the pitfall of trying to exit through the locked doorway?', 'A mental set is where you persist in approaching a problem in a way that has worked in the past but is clearly not working now.']

['Teacher: Can you define functional fixedness and explain how it can hinder problem solving?', 'Functional fixedness is a type of mental set where you cannot perceive an object being used for something other than what it was designed for.']
['What are the potential consequences or drawbacks of functional fixedness in problem-solving?', 'Duncker (1945) conducted foundational research on functional fixedness.']

["What was the purpose of Duncker's experiment in which participants were given a candle, a book of matches, and a box of thumbtacks?", 'He created an experiment in which participants were given a candle, a book of matches, and a box of thumbtacks.']

["What were the results or findings of Duncker's experiment regarding functional fixedness?", 'They were instructed to use those items to attach the candle to the wall so that it did not drip wax onto the table below.']
["What did Duncker's experiment reveal about participants' ability to overcome functional fixedness?", 'Participants had to use functional fixedness to overcome the problem.']

['How does the example of the Apollo 13 mission demonstrate the importance of overcoming functional fixedness in problem-solving?', 'During the Apollo 13 mission to the moon, NASA engineers at Mission Control had to overcome functional fixedness to save the lives of the astronauts aboard the spacecraft.']

['What specific obstacles or challenges did the engineers at Mission Control face in overcoming functional fixedness during the Apollo 13 mission?', 'An explosion in a module of the spacecraft damaged multiple systems.']

['How did the engineers at Mission Control overcome the challenge of rising carbon dioxide levels on the Apollo 13 mission?', 'The astronauts were in danger of being poisoned by rising levels of carbon dioxide because of problems with the carbon dioxide filters.']

['What materials did the engineers at Mission Control use to create a makeshift air filter for the astronauts on the Apollo 13 mission?', 'The engineers found a way for the astronauts to use spare plastic bags, tape, and air hoses to create a makeshift air filter, which saved the lives of the astronauts.']
['Teacher: What have researchers been investigating in relation to functional fixedness?', 'Researchers have investigated whether functional fixedness is affected by culture.']

['Teacher: What were the findings of the experiment conducted with individuals from the Shuar group in Ecuador regarding their ability to overcome functional fixedness?', 'In one experiment, individuals from the Shuar group in Ecuador were asked to use an object for a purpose other than that for which the object was originally intended.']

['Teacher: How did the individuals from the Shuar group in Ecuador perform in using objects for purposes other than their original intention in the experiment?', 'For example, the participants were told a story about a bear and a rabbit that were separated by a river and asked to select among various objects, including a spoon, a cup, erasers, and so on, to help the animals.']

["Teacher: What impact did the presentation of the spoon have on the participants' ability to choose it for solving the problem?", 'The spoon was the only object long enough to span the imaginary river, but if the spoon was presented in a way that reflected its normal usage, it took participants longer to choose the spoon to solve the problem.']
['Why did it take participants longer to choose the spoon to solve the problem if it was presented in a way that reflected its normal usage?', '(German & Barrett, 2005).']

["What were the implications or significance of the researchers' interest in investigating the impact of exposure to highly specialized tools on functional fixedness?", 'The researchers wanted to know if exposure to highly specialized tools, as occurs with individuals in industrialized nations, affects their ability to transcend functional fixedness.']
