['What did the researchers find out about functional fixedness in both industrialized and nonindustrialized cultures?', 'It was determined that functional fixedness is experienced in both industrialized and nonindustrialized cultures (German & Barrett, 2005).']
['Teacher: What are the two factors we rely on when making good decisions?', 'In order to make good decisions, we use our knowledge and our reasoning.']
['Teacher: Why is it important for our knowledge and reasoning to be sound and solid when making decisions?', 'Often, this knowledge and reasoning is sound and solid.']
['Teacher: What are some factors that can influence our knowledge and reasoning when making decisions?', 'Sometimes, however, we are swayed by biases or by others manipulating a situation.']

['Teacher: What would be a potential pitfall or challenge that could arise when trying to find a house within your combined budget of $1,600?', 'For example, let’s say you and three friends wanted to rent a house and had a combined target budget of $1,600.']

['Teacher: What is a potential pitfall or challenge that could arise in this situation?', 'The realtor shows you only very run-down houses for $1,600 and then shows you a very nice house for $2,000.']
['Teacher: How does the realtor challenging your anchoring bias affect your decision-making process in finding a house within your budget?', 'The realtor may be challenging your anchoring bias.']
['What effect does anchoring bias have on the decision-making process?', 'An anchoring bias occurs when you focus on one piece of information when making a decision or solving a problem.']

['Teacher: How can an anchoring bias potentially hinder your ability to find a suitable house within your budget?', 'In this case, you’re so focused on the amount of money you are willing to spend that you may not recognize what kinds of houses are available at that price point.']
['Teacher: Can you explain what the confirmation bias refers to?', 'The confirmation bias is the tendency to focus on information that confirms your existing beliefs.']

['Teacher: How does the confirmation bias impact our perception of others and their behavior?', 'For example, if you think that your professor is not very nice, you notice all of the instances of rude behavior exhibited by the professor while ignoring the countless pleasant interactions he is involved in on a daily basis.']

['Teacher: What is hindsight bias and how does it influence our perception of past events?', 'Hindsight bias leads you to believe that the event you just experienced was predictable, even though it really wasn’t.']
['Teacher: How does the hindsight bias affect our ability to learn from past mistakes?', 'In other words, you knew all along that things would turn out the way they did.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how the representative bias can affect our perception of others and their behavior?', 'Representative bias describes a faulty way of thinking, in which you unintentionally stereotype someone or something; for example, you may assume that your professors spend their free time reading books and engaging in intellectual conversation, because the idea of them spending their time playing volleyball or visiting an amusement park does not fit in with your stereotypes of professors.']

['Teacher: Can you explain what the availability heuristic is and how it can impact decision-making?', 'Finally, the availability heuristic is a heuristic in which you make a decision based on an example, information, or recent experience that is that readily available to you, even though it may not be the best example to inform your decision.']

['What is the impact of biases on decision-making?', 'Biases tend to “preserve that which is already established—to maintain our preexisting knowledge, beliefs, attitudes, and hypotheses” (Aronson, 1995; Kahneman, 2011).']
['What are some examples of biases that can impact decision-making?', 'These biases are summarized in Table 7.3.']
['Teacher: How many items do you need in order to complete the task successfully?', 'You need nine.']
['Teacher: Can you please list the nine items needed to successfully complete the task?', 'Here are the answers.']

['Teacher: Can you explain to me the difference between intelligence and creativity?', 'A four-and-a-half-year-old boy sits at the kitchen table with his father, who is reading a new story aloud to him.']
['Teacher: What do you think the boy might have said to his father before he asked him to wait?', 'He turns the page to continue reading, but before he can begin, the boy says, “Wait, Daddy!”']

["Teacher: What does the boy's behavior in pointing to the words and reading aloud suggest about his intelligence or creativity?", 'He points to the words on the new page and reads aloud, “Go, Pig! Go!”']
["Teacher: How do you think the father's reaction might relate to the boy's intelligence or creativity?", 'The father stops and looks at his son.']
['Teacher: What might the father\'s question, "Can you read that?" indicate about his understanding of the boy\'s intelligence or creativity?', '“Can you read that?” he asks.']
['What does the boy\'s confident response "Yes, Daddy!" suggest about his intelligence or creativity?', '“Yes, Daddy!”']
["How does the boy's confident response to his father's question indicate his intelligence or creativity?", 'And he points to the words and reads again, “Go, Pig! Go!”']

["Teacher: How would you describe the child's attitude towards learning and curiosity?", 'This father was not actively teaching his son to read, even though the child constantly asked questions about letters, words, and symbols that they saw everywhere: in the car, in the store, on the television.']
['Teacher: Why do you think the father decided to try an experiment with his son?', 'The dad wondered about what else his son might understand and decided to try an experiment.']

['Teacher: What was the purpose of the experiment the father conducted with his son?', 'Grabbing a sheet of blank paper, he wrote several simple words in a list: mom, dad, dog, bird, bed, truck, car, tree.']
["Teacher: How did the child respond to the father's request to read the words on the list?", 'He put the list down in front of the boy and asked him to read the words.']
["Teacher: How would you characterize the child's ability to read the words on the list?", '“Dad, dog, bird, bed, truck, car, tree,” he read, slowing down to carefully pronounce bird and truck.']
["Teacher: How did the father respond to the child's reading of the words on the list?", 'Then, “Did I do it, Daddy?” “You sure did!']
['Teacher: How did the child feel after successfully reading the words on the list?', 'That is very good.”']

["Teacher: What was the father's thought process regarding his son's abilities after the successful reading of the words?", 'The father gave his little boy a warm hug and continued reading the story about the pig, all the while wondering if his son’s abilities were an indication of exceptional intelligence or simply a normal pattern of linguistic development.']

['What are some of the questions psychologists have asked about intelligence and how it can be measured?', 'Like the father in this example, psychologists have wondered what constitutes intelligence and how it can be measured.']

['Teacher: How has the definition of intelligence evolved over time, according to researchers in psychology?', 'The way that researchers have defined the concept of intelligence has been modified many times since the birth of psychology.']

['Teacher: Who is the psychologist that believed intelligence consists of one general factor, called "g"?', 'British psychologist Charles Spearman believed intelligence consisted of one general factor, called g, which could be measured and compared among individuals.']
['Teacher: What did Charles Spearman focus on in his theory of intelligence?', 'Spearman focused on the commonalities among various intellectual abilities and de-emphasized what made each unique.']

["Teacher: How did ancient philosophers, like Aristotle, align with Charles Spearman's view on intelligence?", 'Long before modern psychology developed, however, ancient philosophers, such as Aristotle, held a similar view (Cianciolo & Sternberg, 2004).']

['Teacher: What is the alternative viewpoint proposed by some psychologists regarding intelligence?', 'Others psychologists believe that instead of a single factor, intelligence is a collection of distinct abilities.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a theory that supports the idea of intelligence being composed of different abilities?', 'In the 1940s, Raymond Cattell proposed a theory of intelligence that divided general intelligence into two components: crystallized intelligence and fluid intelligence (Cattell, 1963).']

["Teacher: How would you define crystallized intelligence according to Raymond Cattell's theory of intelligence?", 'Crystallized intelligence is characterized as acquired knowledge and the ability to retrieve it.']

["Teacher: Can you explain the main difference between crystallized intelligence and fluid intelligence according to Raymond Cattell's theory?", 'When you learn, remember, and recall information, you are using crystallized intelligence.']

['Teacher: How does fluid intelligence differ from crystallized intelligence in terms of its application in problem-solving tasks?', 'You use crystallized intelligence all the time in your coursework by demonstrating that you have mastered the information covered in the course.']
['Teacher: How would you apply fluid intelligence in problem-solving tasks?', 'Fluid intelligence encompasses the ability to see complex relationships and solve problems.']

['Teacher: Can you provide another example of a real-life situation that would require the use of fluid intelligence?', 'Navigating your way home after being detoured onto an unfamiliar route because of road construction would draw upon your fluid intelligence.']

["What are the two components of general intelligence according to Raymond Cattell's theory?", 'Fluid intelligence helps you tackle complex, abstract challenges in your daily life, whereas crystallized intelligence helps you overcome concrete, straightforward problems (Cattell, 1963).']

['Teacher: What do other theorists and psychologists believe in terms of defining intelligence?', 'Other theorists and psychologists believe that intelligence should be defined in more practical terms.']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how these theorists and psychologists suggest defining intelligence in practical terms?', 'Think about this for a moment.']
['Teacher: How is practical intelligence, as proposed by Sternberg, often described or compared to?', 'Practical intelligence, as proposed by Sternberg, is sometimes compared to “street smarts.”']

['Teacher: Can you explain why practical intelligence is sometimes referred to as "street smarts"?', 'Being practical means you find solutions that work in your everyday life by applying knowledge based on your experiences.']

['Teacher: How does practical intelligence differ from traditional IQ?', 'This type of intelligence appears to be separate from traditional understanding of IQ; individuals who score high in practical intelligence may or may not have comparable scores in creative and analytical intelligence (Sternberg, 1988).']

["Teacher: What part of Robert Sternberg's triarchic theory of intelligence is specifically associated with academic problem solving and computations?", 'Analytical intelligence is closely aligned with academic problem solving and computations.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how someone with analytical intelligence might use their skills in academic problem solving?', 'Sternberg says that analytical intelligence is demonstrated by an ability to analyze, evaluate, judge, compare, and contrast.']

['Teacher: How does the ability to analyze, evaluate, judge, compare, and contrast help someone with analytical intelligence when reading a classic novel for literature class?', 'When reading a classic novel for literature class, for example, it is usually necessary to compare the motives of the main characters of the book or analyze the historical context of the story.']

['Teacher: How might someone with practical intelligence apply their skills in a science course such as anatomy?', 'In a science course such as anatomy, you must study the processes by which the body uses various minerals in different human systems.']

['Teacher: How might someone with creative intelligence contribute to a group project in a science course such as anatomy?', 'In developing an understanding of this topic, you are using analytical intelligence.']

['Teacher: How might someone with practical intelligence contribute to a group project in a science course such as anatomy?', 'When solving a challenging math problem, you would apply analytical intelligence to analyze different aspects of the problem and then solve it section by section.']
['Teacher: Can you explain what creative intelligence entails?', 'Creative intelligence is marked by inventing or imagining a solution to a problem or situation.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how creative intelligence can be demonstrated in everyday life?', 'Creativity in this realm can include finding a novel solution to an unexpected problem or producing a beautiful work of art or a well-developed short story.']

['Teacher: How could creative intelligence be used in this situation of forgetting the camp coffee pot?', 'Imagine for a moment that you are camping in the woods with some friends and realize that you’ve forgotten your camp coffee pot.']

['Teacher: How would you classify the person who comes up with a creative solution to brew coffee without a camp coffee pot?', 'The person in your group who figures out a way to successfully brew coffee for everyone would be credited as having higher creative intelligence.']
['Teacher: What theory did Robert Sternberg develop about intelligence?', 'Multiple Intelligences']

['Teacher: No, that is incorrect. Robert Sternberg developed another theory of intelligence. Can you try again?', 'Theory was developed by Howard Gardner, a Harvard psychologist and former student of Erik Erikson.']
["Teacher: That's not quite right. We're discussing Robert Sternberg's theory here. Can you try again?", 'In Gardner’s theory, each person possesses at least eight intelligences.']

["Teacher: That's correct. But we're actually discussing Robert Sternberg's theory of intelligence. So, can you tell me what the three parts of his theory are?", 'The eight intelligences are linguistic intelligence, logical-mathematical intelligence, musical intelligence, bodily kinesthetic intelligence, spatial intelligence, interpersonal intelligence, intrapersonal intelligence, and naturalistic intelligence.']

["Teacher: We're actually discussing Robert Sternberg's theory of intelligence, not Howard Gardner's theory. Can you try again to tell me what the three parts of Sternberg's theory are?", 'Among cognitive psychologists, Gardner’s theory has been heavily criticized for lacking empirical evidence.']

["Teacher: That's a valid point, but we're specifically discussing Robert Sternberg's theory of intelligence. Can you try again to tell me what the three parts of Sternberg's theory are?", 'However, educators continue to study and use Gardner’s theory, with some colleges even discussing how they integrate Gardner’s theory into their classrooms.']

["Teacher: Well, that's an interesting perspective on Gardner's theory. However, let's refocus on Robert Sternberg's theory of intelligence. Can you try again to tell me what the three parts of Sternberg's theory are?", 'Gottfredson describes one possible reason for the continued use of Gardner’s theory: “ . . . that there are multiple independent intelligences, suggesting that everyone can be smart in some way.']

["Teacher: Yes, that's an interesting perspective on Gardner's theory. However, let's refocus on Robert Sternberg's theory of intelligence. Can you try again to tell me what the three parts of Sternberg's theory are?", 'This is, understandably, a very attractive idea in democratic societies” (2004).']

["Teacher: Can you explain how Robert Sternberg's theory of intelligence differs from Gardner's theory?", 'Gardner’s inter- and intrapersonal intelligences are often combined into a single type: emotional intelligence.']

["Teacher: How does Sternberg's theory of intelligence differ from Gardner's theory in terms of emotional intelligence?", 'Emotional intelligence encompasses the ability to understand the emotions of yourself and others, show empathy, understand social relationships and cues, and regulate your own emotions and respond in culturally appropriate ways (Parker, Saklofske, & Stough, 2009).']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how someone with high emotional intelligence might demonstrate well-developed social skills?', 'People with high emotional intelligence typically have well-developed social skills.']

['Teacher: How does Daniel Goleman argue that emotional intelligence is a better predictor of success than traditional intelligence?', 'Some researchers, including Daniel Goleman, the author of Emotional Intelligence: Why It Can Matter More than IQ, argue that emotional intelligence is a better predictor of success than traditional intelligence (Goleman, 1995).']

['Teacher: What are some of the criticisms and challenges of emotional intelligence as a predictor of success, according to researchers?', 'However, emotional intelligence has been widely debated, with researchers pointing out inconsistencies in how it is defined and described, as well as questioning results of studies on a subject that is difficult to measure and study empirically (Locke, 2005; Mayer, Salovey, & Caruso, 2004)']

["Teacher: That's an interesting perspective! Can you explain to me how Robert Sternberg's theory of intelligence, the triarchic theory, differs from the Cattell-Horn-Carroll (CHC) theory of cognitive abilities?", 'The most comprehensive theory of intelligence to date is the Cattell-Horn-Carroll (CHC) theory of cognitive abilities (Schneider & McGrew, 2018).']

["Teacher: How does Robert Sternberg's triarchic theory of intelligence differ in its organization of cognitive abilities compared to the Cattell-Horn-Carroll (CHC) theory?", 'In this theory, abilities are related and arranged in a hierarchy with general abilities at the top, broad abilities in the middle, and narrow (specific) abilities at the bottom.']

["What are the three parts or components of intelligence according to Robert Sternberg's triarchic theory?", 'The narrow abilities are the only ones that can be directly measured; however, they are integrated within the other abilities.']
["According to Robert Sternberg's triarchic theory, what are the three parts or components of intelligence?", 'At the general level is general intelligence.']

["What are some examples of specific abilities that are considered as narrow abilities in Robert Sternberg's triarchic theory of intelligence?", 'Next, the broad level consists of general abilities such as fluid reasoning, short-term memory, and processing speed.']

["What are some examples of specific forms of cognitive abilities that are considered as narrow abilities in Robert Sternberg's triarchic theory of intelligence?", 'Finally, as the hierarchy continues, the narrow level includes specific forms of cognitive abilities.']

["Can you provide me with an example of a specific form of cognitive ability within the narrow level in Robert Sternberg's triarchic theory of intelligence?", 'For example, short-term memory would further break down into memory span and working memory capacity.']

["Teacher: Can you please explain how Robert Sternberg's triarchic theory of intelligence addresses the concept of intelligence in different cultures?", 'Intelligence can also have different meanings and values in different cultures.']

["Teacher: How does Robert Sternberg's triarchic theory of intelligence accommodate the idea that intelligence can have different meanings and values in different cultural contexts?", 'If you live on a small island, where most people get their food by fishing from boats, it would be important to know how to fish and how to repair a boat.']

["Teacher: In which part of Robert Sternberg's triarchic theory of intelligence does the ability to fish and repair a boat fall into?", 'If you were an exceptional angler, your peers would probably consider you intelligent.']

["Teacher: How does the perception of intelligence in the context of fishing and boat repair align with Robert Sternberg's theory of practical intelligence?", 'If you were also skilled at repairing boats, your intelligence might be known across the whole island.']
["Teacher: How does the recognition of intelligence in the context of boat repair align with Robert Sternberg's theory of practical intelligence?", 'Think about your own family’s culture.']

["Teacher: How might the cultural values of Irish families, such as hospitality and storytelling, be reflected in Robert Sternberg's triarchic theory of intelligence?", 'In Irish families, hospitality and telling an entertaining story are marks of the culture.']

["Teacher: How would the ability to tell an entertaining story align with Robert Sternberg's concept of intelligence?", 'If you are a skilled storyteller, other members of Irish culture are likely to consider you intelligent.']

["Teacher: How does Robert Sternberg's triarchic theory of intelligence account for different cultural values regarding working together as a collective?", 'Some cultures place a high value on working together as a collective.']

["Teacher: How does Sternberg's triarchic theory of intelligence acknowledge the cultural perspective on individual achievement versus group cohesion?", 'In these cultures, the importance of the group supersedes the importance of individual achievement.']

["Teacher: How does cultural intelligence, or cultural competence, fit within Robert Sternberg's triarchic theory of intelligence?", 'When you visit such a culture, how well you relate to the values of that culture exemplifies your cultural intelligence, sometimes referred to as cultural competence.']
['Teacher: How would you define creativity?', 'Creativity is the ability to generate, create, or discover new ideas, solutions, and possibilities.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the characteristics that very creative people tend to possess?', 'Very creative people often have intense knowledge about something, work on it for years, look at novel solutions, seek out the advice and help of other experts, and take risks.']

['What are some disciplines other than the arts that are driven by creativity?', 'Although creativity is often associated with the arts, it is actually a vital form of intelligence that drives people in many disciplines to discover something new.']

['What are some examples of everyday situations where creativity can be found?', 'Creativity can be found in every area of life, from the way you decorate your residence to a new way of understanding how a cell works.']
['Teacher: What mental process is creativity often connected to?', 'Creativity is often connected to a person’s ability to engage in divergent thinking.']

['Teacher: How can divergent thinking be described?', 'Divergent thinking can be described as thinking “outside the box;” it allows an individual to arrive at unique, multiple solutions to a given problem.']

['Teacher: How does convergent thinking differ from divergent thinking in terms of problem-solving abilities?', 'In contrast, convergent thinking describes the ability to provide a correct or well-established answer or solution to a problem (Cropley, 2006; Gilford, 1967)']
['Teacher: What does IQ stand for and what does it describe?', 'IQ stands for intelligence quotient and describes a score earned on a test designed to measure intelligence.']

['Teacher: Can you explain briefly why IQ is considered a measure of intelligence, despite the existence of multiple ways to describe intelligence?', 'You’ve already learned that there are many ways psychologists describe intelligence (or more aptly, intelligences).']

['Teacher: How do psychologists define intelligence and how do IQ tests fit into this definition?', 'Similarly, IQ tests—the tools designed to measure intelligence—have been the subject of debate throughout their development and use.']

['Teacher: What is important to note about the limitations and controversies surrounding intelligence testing?', 'While there are certainly many benefits to intelligence testing, it is important to also note the limitations and controversies surrounding these tests.']

['Teacher: Besides the eugenics movement, can you provide another example of how IQ tests have been used in controversial ways?', 'For example, IQ tests have sometimes been used as arguments in support of insidious purposes, such as the eugenics movement (Severson, 2011).']

['What was the outcome of the Supreme Court Case, Buck v. Bell, in relation to IQ testing?', 'The infamous Supreme Court Case, Buck v. Bell, legalized the forced sterilization of some people deemed “feeble-minded” through this type of testing, resulting in about 65,000 sterilizations (Buck v. Bell, 274 U.S. 200; Ko, 2016).']

['What is the reason that only professionals trained in psychology can administer IQ tests today?', 'Today, only professionals trained in psychology can administer IQ tests, and the purchase of most tests requires an advanced degree in psychology.']

['Why is it necessary for professionals trained in psychology to be the ones administering IQ tests?', 'Other professionals in the field, such as social workers and psychiatrists, cannot administer IQ tests.']
['What topics will we cover in this section about intelligence tests?', 'In this section, we will explore what intelligence tests measure, how they are scored, and how they were developed.']

['Teacher: What aspect of intelligence do you find limited when we focus on traditional or academic-type intelligence?', 'It seems that the human understanding of intelligence is somewhat limited when we focus on traditional or academic-type intelligence.']

['Teacher: What does the upcoming discussion on the development and history of intelligence tests suggest about our understanding of intelligence?', 'In the following paragraphs, we will explore how intelligence tests were developed and the history of their use.']
['Teacher: What has the IQ test been synonymous with for over a century?', 'The IQ test has been synonymous with intelligence for over a century.']

['Teacher: Who was the individual responsible for developing the first broad test of intelligence in the late 1800s?', 'In the late 1800s, Sir Francis Galton developed the first broad test of intelligence (Flanagan & Kaufman, 2004).']

["Teacher: How did Sir Francis Galton's contributions to the concepts of intelligence testing continue to have an impact today?", 'Although he was not a psychologist, his contributions to the concepts of intelligence testing are still felt today (Gordon, 1995).']

['Teacher: Who is credited with beginning reliable intelligence testing during the early 1900s?', 'Reliable intelligence testing (you may recall from earlier chapters that reliability refers to a test’s ability to produce consistent results) began in earnest during the early 1900s with a researcher named Alfred Binet.']

['Teacher: What was the purpose of the intelligence test developed by Alfred Binet at the request of the French government?', 'Binet was asked by the French government to develop an intelligence test to use on children to determine which ones might have difficulty in school; it included many verbally based tasks.']
['Teacher: How did American researchers contribute to the development of intelligence testing after recognizing its value?', 'American researchers soon realized the value of such testing.']

["Teacher: What changes did Louis Terman make to Binet's intelligence test?", 'Louis Terman, a Stanford professor, modified Binet’s work by standardizing the administration of the test and tested thousands of different-aged children to establish an average score for each age.']

['What is the significance of establishing an average score for each age in intelligence testing?', 'As a result, the test was normed and standardized, which means that the test was administered consistently to a large enough representative sample of the population that the range of scores resulted in a bell curve (bell curves will be discussed later).']
['What are the benefits of standardized intelligence testing?', 'Standardization means that the manner of administration, scoring, and interpretation of results is consistent.']

['What is the purpose of comparing groups, such as age groups, in intelligence testing?', 'Norming involves giving a test to a large population so data can be collected comparing groups, such as age groups.']
['Why is it important to have referential scores in intelligence testing?', 'The resulting data provide norms, or referential scores, by which to interpret future scores.']

['What does it mean for a test to be standardized in the context of intelligence testing?', 'Norms are not expectations of what a given group should know but a demonstration of what that group does know.']
['Why is it necessary to ensure that new scores in intelligence testing are reliable?', 'Norming and standardizing the test ensures that new scores are reliable.']
['What were some of the modifications made to the original intelligence test by Terman?', 'This new version of the test was called the Stanford-Binet Intelligence Scale (Terman, 1916).']
['What are some of the key features of the Stanford-Binet Intelligence Scale that make it still widely used today?', 'Remarkably, an updated version of this test is still widely used today.']

['Teacher: Who developed a new IQ test in the United States after working with World War I veterans in 1939?', 'In 1939, David Wechsler, a psychologist who spent part of his career working with World War I veterans, developed a new IQ test in the United States.']

["Teacher: What was the purpose of David Wechsler's new IQ test that he developed in the United States after working with World War I veterans in 1939?", 'Wechsler combined several subtests from other intelligence tests used between 1880 and World War I.']

["Teacher: How did David Wechsler's new IQ test measure intelligence according to his beliefs?", 'These subtests tapped into a variety of verbal and nonverbal skills, because Wechsler believed that intelligence encompassed “the global capacity of a person to act purposefully, to think rationally, and to deal effectively with his environment” (Wechsler, 1958, p. 7).']

['What was the name of the IQ test that David Wechsler developed in the United States after working with World War I veterans in 1939?', 'He named the test the Wechsler-Bellevue Intelligence Scale (Wechsler, 1981).']

['What made the Wechsler-Bellevue Intelligence Scale one of the most extensively used intelligence tests in the history of psychology?', 'This combination of subtests became one of the most extensively used intelligence tests in the history of psychology.']

['What are the aims of the Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale (WAIS) and how have they remained unchanged since its inception?', 'Although its name was later changed to the Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale (WAIS) and has been revised several times, the aims of the test remain virtually unchanged since its inception (Boake, 2002).']

['What are the names of the three intelligence tests credited to David Wechsler?', 'Today, there are three intelligence tests credited to Wechsler, the Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale-fourth edition (WAIS-IV), the Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children (WISC-V), and the Wechsler Preschool and Primary Scale of Intelligence—IV (WPPSI-IV) (Wechsler, 2012).']

['What are the purposes and uses of the Wechsler intelligence tests in schools and communities throughout the United States?', 'These tests are used widely in schools and communities throughout the United States, and they are periodically normed and standardized as a means of recalibration.']

['What is the purpose of periodically norming and standardizing the Wechsler intelligence tests in schools and communities throughout the United States?', 'As a part of the recalibration process, the WISC-V was given to thousands of children across the country, and children taking the test today are compared with their same-age peers.']

['Teacher: How many subtests does the WISC-V consist of, and what do these subtests form in terms of indices and IQ scores?', 'The WISC-V is composed of 14 subtests, which comprise five indices, which then render an IQ score.']
['What are the names of the five indices in the WISC-V?', 'The five indices are Verbal Comprehension, Visual Spatial, Fluid Reasoning, Working Memory, and Processing Speed.']

['What is the purpose of combining subtest scores into five indices and a Full Scale IQ score in the WISC-V?', 'When the test is complete, individuals receive a score for each of the five indices and a Full Scale IQ score.']

['What does the method of scoring in the WISC-V reflect about the nature of intelligence?', 'The method of scoring reflects the understanding that intelligence is comprised of multiple abilities in several cognitive realms and focuses on the mental processes that the child used to arrive at their answers to each test item.']
['Teacher: What has the periodic recalibrations of intelligence tests led to?', 'Interestingly, the periodic recalibrations have led to an interesting observation known as the Flynn effect.']

['What is the observation known as the Flynn effect?', 'Named after James Flynn, who was among the first to describe this trend, the Flynn effect refers to the observation that each generation has a significantly higher IQ than the last.']

["What is James Flynn's perspective on the correlation between increased IQ scores and intelligence in younger generations?", 'Flynn himself argues, however, that increased IQ scores do not necessarily mean that younger generations are more intelligent per se (Flynn, Shaughnessy, & Fulgham, 2012).']
['Teacher: What is the lingering question we are faced with in our exploration of intelligence tests?', 'Ultimately, we are still left with the question of how valid intelligence tests are.']

['What are some of the ongoing issues of debate surrounding the use and validity of intelligence tests?', 'Certainly, the most modern versions of these tests tap into more than verbal competencies, yet the specific skills that should be assessed in IQ testing, the degree to which any test can truly measure an individual’s intelligence, and the use of the results of IQ tests are still issues of debate (Gresham & Witt, 1997; Flynn, Shaughnessy, & Fulgham, 2012; Richardson, 2002; Schlinger, 2003).']
['Teacher: What is the shape of the graph that represents the results of intelligence tests?', 'The results of intelligence tests follow the bell curve, a graph in the general shape of a bell.']

['Teacher: How does the bell curve demonstrate a normal distribution of intelligence in the human population when used in psychological testing?', 'When the bell curve is used in psychological testing, the graph demonstrates a normal distribution of a trait, in this case, intelligence, in the human population.']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example of another human trait that could follow a bell curve?', 'Many human traits naturally follow the bell curve.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why height can be represented by a bell curve when considering a large population of people?', 'For example, if you lined up all your female schoolmates according to height, it is likely that a large cluster of them would be the average height for an American woman: 5’4”–5’6”.']

['What does the cluster in the center of the bell curve represent in terms of height for American women?', 'This cluster would fall in the center of the bell curve, representing the average height for American women.']
['What can we infer about the number of American women who are significantly taller than average based on the bell curve?', 'There would be fewer women who stand closer to 4’11”.']

['What can we infer about the number of American women who are significantly shorter than average based on the bell curve?', 'The same would be true for women of above-average height: those who stand closer to 5’11”.']
['How does using a large sample size help in finding a bell curve in nature?', 'The trick to finding a bell curve in nature is to use a large sample size.']

['How does a larger sample size increase the likelihood of the bell curve representing the wider population?', 'Without a large sample size, it is less likely that the bell curve will represent the wider population.']
['What is the importance of having a representative sample when studying bell curves?', 'A representative sample is a subset of the population that accurately represents the general population.']

['Why is it important to have a representative sample when studying bell curves?', 'If, for example, you measured the height of the women in your classroom only, you might not actually have a representative sample.']

["Why might having only the women's basketball team in your class as the sample for studying the bell curve of height not accurately represent the wider population?", 'Perhaps the women’s basketball team wanted to take this course together, and they are all in your class.']

['Why is it important to select a representative sample that accurately represents the wider population when studying bell curves?', 'Because basketball players tend to be taller than average, the women in your class may not be a good representative sample of the population of American women.']

['Why is it important to have a natural bell curve when studying human traits such as height?', 'But if your sample included all the women at your school, it is likely that their heights would form a natural bell curve.']
['Teacher: How do the principles we just discussed apply to intelligence test scores in the context of The Bell Curve?', 'The same principles apply to intelligence tests scores.']

["Teacher: That's right! Can you tell me more about how this intelligence quotient (IQ) is calculated and what it represents in terms of intelligence test scores?", 'Individuals earn a score called an intelligence quotient (IQ).']

['Teacher: How do different types of IQ tests contribute to the interpretation of intelligence quotient (IQ) scores?', 'Over the years, different types of IQ tests have evolved, but the way scores are interpreted remains the same.']
['How are IQ scores interpreted in relation to the average score of 100 on most IQ tests?', 'On most IQ tests, the average (or mean) IQ score is 100.']

['What does the concept of standard deviation provide in relation to IQ scores and their interpretation?', 'Standard deviations describe how data are dispersed in a population and give context to large data sets.']
['What does the bell curve represent in relation to the interpretation of IQ scores?', 'The bell curve uses the standard deviation to show how all scores are dispersed from the average score.']
['What does one standard deviation represent in terms of IQ scores?', 'In modern IQ testing, one standard deviation is 15 points.']
['What does a score of 115 represent in terms of IQ scores?', 'So a score of 85 would be described as “one standard deviation below the mean.”']

['What percentage of the population falls within one standard deviation above and below the mean on an IQ test?', 'Any IQ score that falls within one standard deviation above and below the mean (between 85 and 115) is considered average, and 68% of the population has IQ scores in this range.']
['What percentage of the population is considered to have a superior level of intelligence based on IQ scores?', 'An IQ score of 130 or above is considered a superior level.']

['Teacher: According to the American Psychiatric Association [APA] in 2013, what percentage of the population has an IQ score below 70?', 'Only 2.2% of the population has an IQ score below 70 (American Psychiatric Association [APA], 2013).']

['Teacher: Can you explain the criteria for diagnosing someone with an intellectual disability based on their IQ score?', 'If a person earns a score approximately two standard deviations below the mean on an intelligence test, (about 70 on a test with a mean of 100), has major deficits in adaptive functioning, and these cognitive and adaptive deficits were present before the age of 18, they could be diagnosed as having an intellectual disability (ID).']

['Teacher: What are the four subtypes of intellectual disability?', 'Formerly known as mental retardation, the accepted term now is intellectual disability, and it has four subtypes: mild, moderate, severe, and profound.']

['Teacher: What are the criteria used to diagnose someone with each subtype of intellectual disability according to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Psychological Disorders?', 'The Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Psychological Disorders lists criteria for each subgroup (APA, 2013).']

['Teacher: What group of individuals do we find on the other end of the intelligence spectrum, whose IQs fall into the highest ranges?', 'On the other end of the intelligence spectrum are those individuals whose IQs fall into the highest ranges.']

['Teacher: Based on the bell curve, what percentage of the population falls into the category of individuals whose IQs fall into the highest ranges?', 'Consistent with the bell curve, about 2% of the population falls into this category.']

['Teacher: How do we classify individuals who have an IQ score of 130 or higher, or superior intelligence in a particular area?', 'People are considered to have a higher aptitude for learning (and may be classified as "gifted" within educational systems) if they have an IQ score of 130 or higher, or superior intelligence in a particular area.']
['Teacher: What was the popular belief regarding individuals with high intelligence in the past?', 'Long ago, popular belief suggested that people of high intelligence were maladjusted.']
['What does the groundbreaking study disprove regarding individuals with high intelligence?', 'This idea was disproven through a groundbreaking study of these children.']

["What were the findings of Lewis Terman's longitudinal study on children with IQs over 135?", 'In 1921, Lewis Terman began a longitudinal study of over 1500 children with IQs over 135 (Terman, 1925).']

["What did Lewis Terman's longitudinal study reveal about the future success and adjustment of children with IQs over 135?", 'His findings showed that these children became well-educated, successful adults who were, in fact, well-adjusted (Terman & Oden, 1947).']

["What were some physical characteristics of the subjects in Terman's study who had IQs over 135?", 'Additionally, Terman’s study showed that the subjects were above average in physical build and attractiveness, dispelling an earlier popular notion that highly intelligent people were “weaklings.”']
['What is Mensa and what is its purpose?', 'Some people with very high IQs elect to join Mensa, an organization dedicated to identifying, researching, and fostering intelligence.']

['Teacher: What are the requirements for individuals to become members of Mensa?', 'Members must have an IQ score in the top 2% of the population, and they may be required to pass other exams in their application to join the group.']
['Teacher: In what settings is the value of IQ testing most evident?', 'The value of IQ testing is most evident in educational or clinical settings.']

['What can IQ testing help identify in children who are experiencing learning difficulties or severe behavioral problems?', 'Children who seem to be experiencing learning difficulties or severe behavioral problems can be tested to ascertain whether the child’s difficulties can be partly attributed to an IQ score that is significantly different from the mean for their age group.']

['Why is it important to identify children and adults needing extra support effectively?', 'Without IQ testing—or another measure of intelligence—children and adults needing extra support might not be identified effectively.']

['What is another context in which IQ testing is used to determine whether someone can participate in a trial?', 'In addition, IQ testing is used in courts to determine whether a defendant has special or extenuating circumstances that preclude them from participating in some way in a trial.']
['What is another situation where IQ testing results are used to seek certain benefits?', 'People also use IQ testing results to seek disability benefits from the Social Security Administration.']
['Teacher: What does the passage aim to demonstrate?', 'The following case study demonstrates the usefulness and benefits of IQ testing.']

['Teacher: Why was Candace referred for a court-ordered psychological evaluation?', 'Candace, a 14-year-old girl experiencing problems at school in Connecticut, was referred for a court-ordered psychological evaluation.']
["Teacher: What were the possible reasons for Candace's referral for a court-ordered psychological evaluation?", 'She was in regular education classes in ninth grade and was failing every subject.']

['Teacher: What did the passage suggest about the consequences of Candace being continuously promoted to the next grade despite her poor academic performance?', 'Candace had never been a stellar student but had always been passed to the next grade.']

["Teacher: How did Candace's behavior in class reflect the consequences of being continuously promoted despite her poor academic performance?", 'Frequently, she would curse at any of her teachers who called on her in class.']
["Teacher: What information does the passage provide about Candace's behavior outside of the classroom?", 'She also got into fights with other students and occasionally shoplifted.']

['Why did Candace express her strong dislike for everything about school during the evaluation?', 'When she arrived for the evaluation, Candace immediately said that she hated everything about school, including the teachers, the rest of the staff, the building, and the homework.']

["Why did Candace's parents believe that she was being picked on at school?", 'Her parents stated that they felt their daughter was picked on, because she was of a different ethnicity than the teachers and most of the other students.']

["Why did Candace believe that her teachers only called on her when she didn't know the answer?", 'When asked why she cursed at her teachers, Candace replied, “They only call on me when I don’t know the answer.']
['Why did Candace feel pressured to always have an answer in class?', 'I don’t want to say, ‘I don’t know’ all of the time and look like an idiot in front of my friends.']
["Why did Candace's parents express concerns about her academic performance and her behavior at school?", 'The teachers embarrass me.”']
['Why was Candace given a battery of tests, including an IQ test?', 'She was given a battery of tests, including an IQ test.']
["Teacher: What does Candace's low score on the IQ test suggest about her level of intelligence?", 'Her score on the IQ test was 68.']

['Teacher: How would you describe the methods and interpretations of intelligence tests, considering their evolving nature?', 'Despite evidence for the value of intelligence and related evaluations, the methods and interpretations of these tests are continually evolving.']

['Teacher: Can you provide some examples of how researchers like Jack A. Naglieri have contributed to the development and improvement of intelligence testing programs?', 'Researchers such as Jack A. Naglieri (2020) have developed or improved on testing programs in order to make them more accurate, equitable, and useful.']

['Teacher: How do researchers like Jack A. Naglieri contribute to the accuracy, equity, and usefulness of intelligence testing programs?', 'Beyond new testing instruments, some researchers demonstrate value in differentiating tests for different age groups, abilities, and contexts.']
['Teacher: Can you tell me about the background of the protagonist in the passage?', 'A young girl, born of teenage parents, lives with her grandmother in rural Mississippi.']
["What is the protagonist's living situation and location in the passage?", 'She learns to read when she is just 3 years old.']
["What is the protagonist's desire as she grows older?", 'As she grows older, she longs to live with her mother, who now resides in Wisconsin.']
['What motivates the protagonist to move to Wisconsin?', 'She moves there at the age of 6 years.']
['What happens to the protagonist at 9 years of age?', 'At 9 years of age, she is raped.']
["How does the protagonist's experience change after she is raped at 9 years of age?", 'During the next several years, several different male relatives repeatedly molest her.']
["How does the protagonist's life change as a result of the repeated molestations by different male relatives during her teenage years?", 'Her life unravels.']
['What does the protagonist resort to in order to cope with her deep, lonely void inside her?', 'She turns to drugs and sex to fill the deep, lonely void inside her.']

["How does the protagonist's life change after she is sent to live with her father in Nashville?", 'Her mother then sends her to Nashville to live with her father, who imposes strict behavioral expectations upon her, and over time, her wild life settles once again.']

["What positive change occurs in the protagonist's life after she moves to Nashville and lives with her father?", 'She begins to experience success in school, and at 19 years old, becomes the youngest and first African-American female news anchor (“Dates and Events,” n.d.).']
['What does Oprah Winfrey become known for as she grows up?', 'The woman—Oprah Winfrey—goes on to become a media giant known for both her intelligence and her empathy.']
['Teacher: Can you tell me more about the viewpoint of those researchers?', 'Some researchers believe that intelligence is a trait inherited from a person’s parents.']

['Teacher: How do researchers usually determine the heritability of intelligence in twin studies?', 'Scientists who research this topic typically use twin studies to determine the heritability of intelligence.']

['Teacher: What are some findings or conclusions from the Minnesota Study of Twins Reared Apart regarding the heritability of intelligence?', 'The Minnesota Study of Twins Reared Apart is one of the most well-known twin studies.']

['Teacher: What does the higher correlation between the IQ scores of identical twins raised together and identical twins raised apart suggest about the heritability of intelligence?', 'In this investigation, researchers found that identical twins raised together and identical twins raised apart exhibit a higher correlation between their IQ scores than siblings or fraternal twins raised together (Bouchard, Lykken, McGue, Segal, & Tellegen, 1990).']

['Teacher: Based on the findings from the Minnesota Study of Twins Reared Apart, what can we conclude about the role of genetics in intelligence?', 'The findings from this study reveal a genetic component to intelligence.']

['Teacher: What are some arguments or evidence that psychologists who believe in the importance of environmental factors present to support their viewpoint?', 'At the same time, other psychologists believe that intelligence is shaped by a child’s developmental environment.']

['What is one argument that psychologists who believe in the importance of environmental factors present to support their viewpoint?', 'If parents were to provide their children with intellectual stimuli from before they are born, it is likely that they would absorb the benefits of that stimulation, and it would be reflected in intelligence levels.']

['Teacher: Can you elaborate on your statement? Why do you believe that aspects of both ideas regarding high intelligence - nature and nurture - are likely correct?', 'The reality is that aspects of each idea are probably correct.']

['Teacher: Can you provide more evidence or examples from the study that supports the idea that genetics control the level of intelligence, while environmental influences trigger the manifestation of cognitive abilities?', 'In fact, one study suggests that although genetics seem to be in control of the level of intelligence, the environmental influences provide both stability and change to trigger manifestation of cognitive abilities (Bartels, Rietveld, Van Baal, & Boomsma, 2002).']

['What role do environmental influences play in the manifestation of cognitive abilities, according to the study you mentioned?', 'Certainly, there are behaviors that support the development of intelligence, but the genetic component of high intelligence should not be ignored.']

['Teacher: What evidence supports the idea that high intelligence is a heritable trait that can be passed on to the next generation?', 'As with all heritable traits, however, it is not always possible to isolate how and when high intelligence is passed on to the next generation.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the concept of Range of Reaction and its relevance to the nature versus nurture debate on high intelligence?', 'Range of Reaction is the theory that each person responds to the environment in a unique way based on their genetic makeup.']

['Can you provide an example that illustrates how the theory of Range of Reaction applies to the development of high intelligence?', 'According to this idea, your genetic potential is a fixed quantity, but whether you reach your full intellectual potential is dependent upon the environmental stimulation you experience, especially in childhood.']

['Teacher: How might the theory of Range of Reaction explain the potential for the adopted child to develop high intelligence despite having average genetic potential?', 'Think about this scenario: A couple adopts a child who has average genetic intellectual potential.']

['Teacher: What might be the possible outcome for the adopted child in terms of intelligence if she is raised in an extremely stimulating environment, according to the theory of Range of Reaction?', 'They raise her in an extremely stimulating environment.']

["What role does the stimulating environment play in fulfilling the potential of the adopted child's high intelligence, based on the theory of Range of Reaction?", 'It is likely that the stimulating environment will improve her intellectual outcomes over the course of her life.']

['Teacher: How might the theory of Range of Reaction explain the potential outcome for a child with strong genetic potential but a lack of stimulating environment in terms of their intelligence?', 'If a child with an extremely strong genetic background is placed in an environment that does not stimulate him:']

['What might be the potential outcome for a child with strong genetic potential but a lack of stimulating environment in terms of their intelligence, according to the theory of Range of Reaction?', 'Interestingly, according to a longitudinal study of highly gifted individuals, it was found that “the two extremes of optimal and pathological experience are both represented disproportionately in the backgrounds of creative individuals”; however, those who experienced supportive family environments were more likely to report being happy (Csikszentmihalyi & Csikszentmihalyi, 1993, p. 187).']

['Teacher: What can pose a challenge when trying to determine the origins of high intelligence due to our human social structures?', 'Another challenge to determining origins of high intelligence is the confounding nature of our human social structures.']

['What impact does the confounding nature of our human social structures have on determining the origins of high intelligence?', 'It is troubling to note that some ethnic groups perform better on IQ tests than others—and it is likely that the results do not have much to do with the quality of each ethnic group’s intellect.']

["How does the confounding nature of our human social structures affect the relationship between ethnic groups' performance on IQ tests and their intellectual capabilities?", 'The same is true for socioeconomic status.']

["What impact does the confounding nature of our human social structures have on the relationship between socioeconomic status and children's experience of stress?", 'Children who live in poverty experience more pervasive, daily stress than children who do not worry about the basic needs of safety, shelter, and food.']

['How does the experience of pervasive, daily stress in children living in poverty affect their brain function and development?', 'These worries can negatively affect how the brain functions and develops, causing a dip in IQ scores.']

['What did Mark Kishiyama and his colleagues determine about the prefrontal brain functioning of children living in poverty?', 'Mark Kishiyama and his colleagues determined that children living in poverty demonstrated reduced prefrontal brain functioning comparable to children with damage to the lateral prefrontal cortex (Kishiyama, Boyce, Jimenez, Perry, & Knight, 2009).']

['Teacher: What event sparked the intense discussion and examination of the origins and impact of intelligence in 1969?', 'The debate around the foundations and influences on intelligence exploded in 1969, when an educational psychologist named Arthur Jensen published the article “How Much Can We Boost I.Q. and Achievement” in the Harvard Educational Review.']

['Teacher: What was the title of the article published by Arthur Jensen in 1969 that sparked the intense discussion on the origins and impact of intelligence?', 'Jensen had administered IQ tests to diverse groups of students, and his results led him to the conclusion that IQ is determined by genetics.']

['Teacher: What were the two types of abilities that Arthur Jensen proposed intelligence was composed of?', 'He also posited that intelligence was made up of two types of abilities: Level I and Level II.']

["Teacher: What is the difference between Level I and Level II abilities according to Arthur Jensen's theory of intelligence?", 'In his theory, Level I is responsible for rote memorization, whereas Level II is responsible for conceptual and analytical abilities.']
["What did Arthur Jensen's findings reveal about the consistency of Level I abilities among the human race?", 'According to his findings, Level I remained consistent among the human race.']
['What were the differences that Arthur Jensen found among ethnic groups in terms of Level II abilities?', 'Level II, however, exhibited differences among ethnic groups (Modgil & Routledge, 1987).']

["What was Arthur Jensen's controversial conclusion regarding the prevalence of Level II intelligence among different ethnic groups?", 'Jensen’s most controversial conclusion was that Level II intelligence is prevalent among Asian people, then White people, then Black people.']

["Teacher: How did Robert Williams respond to Arthur Jensen's conclusions about the prevalence of Level II intelligence among different ethnic groups?", 'Robert Williams was among those who called out racial bias in Jensen’s results (Williams, 1970).']

["Teacher: How did Jensen's interpretation of his own data impact the nation's response to the issue of racism?", 'Obviously, Jensen’s interpretation of his own data caused an intense response in a nation that continued to grapple with the effects of racism (Fox, 2012).']

["Teacher: What were some of the implications of Jensen's interpretation of his own data on the nation's response to racism?", "While even some who took issue with Jensen's findings indicated that they did not detect overt racism in his work, Jensen himself made a number of racist statements during an interview with a White nationalist publication, American Renaissance."]

["Teacher: How did Jensen's personal beliefs about race and intelligence impact his interpretation of his own data regarding high intelligence?", 'He indicated his belief that many Black people were not "educable up to a level for which there’s any economic demand," while also having a higher birth rate than other groups, which would lead to a shift in population and a deterioration of the nation (Taylor, 1992).']

["Teacher: How did Jensen's ideas about racial differences in IQ and cognitive ability compare to the ideas of other psychologists?", 'However, Jensen’s ideas were not solitary or unique; rather, they represented one of many examples of psychologists asserting racial differences in IQ and cognitive ability.']
["What did Rushton and Jensen's review of research focus on?", 'In fact, Rushton and Jensen (2005) reviewed three decades worth of research on the relationship between race and cognitive ability.']

['What were some of the core beliefs held by Jensen that influenced his conclusions about intelligence and the use of IQ tests?', 'Jensen’s belief in the inherited nature of intelligence and the validity of the IQ test to be the truest measure of intelligence are at the core of his conclusions.']

['Teacher: How did the parents of African American students in California argue that the testing method for identifying students with learning disabilities was culturally unfair?', 'In a related story, parents of African American students filed a case against the State of California in 1979, because they believed that the testing method used to identify students with learning disabilities was culturally unfair as the tests were normed and standardized using White children (Larry P. v. Riles).']

['What case did African American parents in California file against the State of California in 1979 regarding the testing method for identifying students with learning disabilities?', 'The testing method used by the state disproportionately identified African American children as “mentally retarded," which resulted in many students being incorrectly classified.']

['What was the reason behind African American parents arguing that the testing method used to identify students with learning disabilities was culturally unfair?', 'According to a summary of the case, Larry P. v. Riles:']
['Teacher: How would you define learning disabilities?', 'Learning disabilities are cognitive disorders that affect different areas of cognition, particularly language or reading.']

["Teacher: That's correct. Can you explain the difference between learning disabilities and intellectual disabilities?", 'It should be pointed out that learning disabilities are not the same thing as intellectual disabilities.']

['Teacher: How would you describe learning disabilities in terms of their impact on cognitive abilities compared to intellectual disabilities?', 'Learning disabilities are considered specific neurological impairments rather than global intellectual or developmental disabilities.']

["Teacher: Can you provide an example of a specific learning disability and explain its impact on an individual's abilities?", 'A person with a language disability has difficulty understanding or using spoken language, whereas someone with a reading disability, such as dyslexia, has difficulty processing what they are reading.']
['Teacher: When are learning disabilities typically recognized?', 'Often, learning disabilities are not recognized until a child reaches school age.']

['Teacher: What is one confounding aspect of learning disabilities in terms of intelligence?', 'One confounding aspect of learning disabilities is that they most often affect children with average to above-average intelligence.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why learning disabilities are considered specific to a particular area and not a measure of overall intellectual ability?', 'In other words, the disability is specific to a particular area and not a measure of overall intellectual ability.']

['Teacher: What is a common disorder that often coexists with learning disabilities, such as ADHD?', 'At the same time, learning disabilities tend to exhibit comorbidity with other disorders, like attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).']

['Teacher: What is the potential impact of having both a learning disability and ADHD?', 'Anywhere between 30–70% of individuals with diagnosed cases of ADHD also have some sort of learning disability (Riccio, Gonzales, & Hynd, 1994).']

['What are the three examples of common learning disabilities mentioned in the passage?', 'Let’s take a look at three examples of common learning disabilities: dysgraphia, dyslexia, and dyscalculia.']
['Teacher: What is the main characteristic or symptom experienced by children with dysgraphia?', 'Children with dysgraphia have a learning disability that results in a struggle to write legibly.']

['What specific physical challenges does dysgraphia present for individuals when writing with a pen and paper?', 'The physical task of writing with a pen and paper is extremely challenging for the person.']

['What is one common difficulty that children with dysgraphia face when trying to express their thoughts in writing?', 'These children often have extreme difficulty putting their thoughts down on paper (Smits-Engelsman & Van Galen, 1997).']
["What impact can dysgraphia have on a student's academic performance?", 'This difficulty is inconsistent with a person’s IQ.']

['What is one potential intervention or strategy that can be used to support students with dysgraphia in the classroom?', 'That is, based on the child’s IQ and/or abilities in other areas, a child with dysgraphia should be able to write, but can’t.']
['What are some possible ways to support and address the spatial abilities of children with dysgraphia in the classroom?', 'Children with dysgraphia may also have problems with spatial abilities.']
['Teacher: What can be done to support students with dysgraphia so they can succeed in school?', 'Students with dysgraphia need academic accommodations to help them succeed in school.']

['How do academic accommodations provide support to students with dysgraphia in school?', 'These accommodations can provide students with alternative assessment opportunities to demonstrate what they know (Barton, 2003).']

['What is an example of an academic accommodation that can be provided to a student with dysgraphia to support their success in school?', 'For example, a student with dysgraphia might be permitted to take an oral exam rather than a traditional paper-and-pencil test.']

['What is the typical provider of treatment for dysgraphia, and what is a concern regarding its effectiveness?', 'Treatment is usually provided by an occupational therapist, although there is some question as to how effective such treatment is (Zwicker, 2005).']
['Teacher: What is the most common learning disability in children?', 'Dyslexia is the most common learning disability in children.']

["Teacher: That's correct! Can you explain some of the challenges individuals with dyslexia face when it comes to processing letters?", 'An individual with dyslexia exhibits an inability to correctly process letters.']

["Teacher: That's partially correct. Can you provide an example of how dyslexia affects an individual's ability to process letters?", 'The neurological mechanism for sound processing does not work properly in someone with dyslexia.']

['Teacher: How does the inability to understand sound-letter correspondence affect the reading ability of dyslexic children?', 'As a result, dyslexic children may not understand sound-letter correspondence.']

['What are some other reading difficulties that dyslexic children may experience besides letter reversals and skipping words?', 'A child with dyslexia may mix up letters within words and sentences—letter reversals, such as those shown in Figure 7.17, are a hallmark of this learning disability—or skip whole words while reading.']

['Teacher: What are some strategies or accommodations that can help dyslexic children with their spelling difficulties while writing?', 'A dyslexic child may have difficulty spelling words correctly while writing.']

['What are some specific strategies or accommodations that can be used to support dyslexic children with their spelling difficulties while writing?', 'Because of the disordered way that the brain processes letters and sound, learning to read is a frustrating experience.']

['What is one way that dyslexic individuals cope with their reading difficulties, but never actually learn to read?', 'Some dyslexic individuals cope by memorizing the shapes of most words, but they never actually learn to read (Berninger, 2008).']
['Teacher: Can you explain to me what Dyscalculia is?', 'Dyscalculia is difficulty in learning or comprehending arithmetic.']

['Teacher: What is one common symptom of dyscalculia that is often observed in children?', 'This learning disability is often first evident when children exhibit difficulty discerning how many objects are in a small group without counting them.']

['Teacher: Can you give me an example of a math fact that a student with dyscalculia might struggle to memorize?', 'Other symptoms may include struggling to memorize math facts, organize numbers, or fully differentiate between numerals, math symbols, and written numbers (such as “3” and “three”).']
['Teacher: What do we commonly compare the process of memory to?', 'Memory is an information processing system; therefore, we often compare it to a computer.']

["Teacher: That's correct! Can you provide me with an example of a specific process that is a part of the memory system?", 'Memory is the set of processes used to encode, store, and retrieve information over different periods of time.']

['Teacher: How do we describe the process of inputting information into our memory system?', 'We get information into our brains through a process called encoding, which is the input of information into the memory system.']

['Teacher: What is the term used to describe the process of labeling or coding sensory information in our brains?', 'Once we receive sensory information from the environment, our brains label or code it.']

['What term is used to describe the process of organizing information with other similar information and connecting new concepts to existing concepts?', 'We organize the information with other similar information and connect new concepts to existing concepts.']
['What are the two types of processing involved in the process of encoding information?', 'Encoding information occurs through automatic processing and effortful processing.']

['Teacher: Why is it that we can recall what we ate for lunch today quite easily when asked by someone?', 'If someone asks you what you ate for lunch today, more than likely you could recall this information quite easily.']

['Teacher: What is the term used to describe the encoding of details like time, space, frequency, and the meaning of words?', 'This is known as automatic processing, or the encoding of details like time, space, frequency, and the meaning of words.']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example of automatic processing in encoding?', 'Automatic processing is usually done without any conscious awareness.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why recalling the last time you studied for a test is considered an example of automatic processing in encoding?', 'Recalling the last time you studied for a test is another example of automatic processing.']
['Teacher: What factors contribute to the encoding of information during automatic processing?', 'It probably required a lot of work and attention on your part in order to encode that information.']

['Teacher: Why is it typically more difficult to recall information that was encoded through effortful processing compared to information encoded through automatic processing?', 'This is known as effortful processing.']
['Teacher: According to Anderson (1984), what makes it easier to recall a simple sentence?', 'Even a simple sentence is easier to recall when it is meaningful (Anderson, 1984).']

['Teacher: How can we enhance the recall of a simple sentence, as mentioned by Anderson (1984)?', 'Read the following sentences (Bransford & McCarrell, 1974), then look away and count backwards from 30 by threes to zero, and then try to write down the sentences (no peeking back at this page!).']
['Teacher: Can you explain the reason behind the sour taste of the notes?', 'The notes were sour because the seams split.']
['Teacher: Why did the notes have a sour taste?', "The voyage wasn't delayed because the bottle shattered."]
['Why was the haystack important?', 'The haystack was important because the cloth ripped.']

['Teacher: Why were the statements you wrote down confusing and difficult for you to recall?', 'By themselves, the statements that you wrote down were most likely confusing and difficult for you to recall.']

['Teacher: How can the prompts like "bagpipe, ship christening, and parachutist" help you in writing the statements again, compared to the initial confusion and difficulty?', 'Now, try writing them again, using the following prompts: bagpipe, ship christening, and parachutist.']

['Why did I ask you to count backwards from 40 by fours after using the prompts to write the statements again?', 'Next count backwards from 40 by fours, then check yourself to see how well you recalled the sentences this time.']
['Why is material far better encoded when you make it meaningful?', 'Material is far better encoded when you make it meaningful.']
['Teacher: What is the number of encoding types discussed in the passage?', 'There are three types of encoding.']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example of semantic encoding mentioned in the passage?', 'The encoding of words and their meaning is known as semantic encoding.']

['Teacher: How did William Bousfield demonstrate semantic encoding in his experiment?', 'It was first demonstrated by William Bousfield (1935) in an experiment in which he asked people to memorize words.']

["Teacher: How did William Bousfield manipulate the participants' exposure to different categories of word meaning in his experiment?", 'The 60 words were actually divided into 4 categories of meaning, although the participants did not know this because the words were randomly presented.']

["Teacher: What was the participants' tendency in recalling the words in William Bousfield's experiment?", 'When they were asked to remember the words, they tended to recall them in categories, showing that they paid attention to the meanings of the words as they learned them.']
['Teacher: What are the two types of encoding mentioned in the passage?', 'Visual encoding is the encoding of images, and acoustic encoding is the encoding of sounds, words in particular.']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a task that would involve acoustic encoding?', 'To see how visual encoding works, read over this list of words: car, level, dog, truth, book, value.']

['What type of encoding is being discussed in the passage when the student mentions recalling words based on a list?', 'You would probably have an easier time recalling the words car, dog, and book, and a more difficult time recalling the words level, truth, and value.']
['Why would you have an easier time recalling images (mental pictures) than words alone?', 'Because you can recall images (mental pictures) more easily than words alone.']
['What is the reason behind being able to recall images more easily than words alone?', 'When you read the words car, dog, and book you created images of these things in your mind.']
['What type of words are more easily encoded and recalled according to the passage?', 'These are concrete, high-imagery words.']
['Why are concrete, high-imagery words more easily encoded and recalled than abstract, low-imagery words?', 'On the other hand, abstract words like level, truth, and value are low-imagery words.']
['How are high-imagery words encoded according to the passage?', 'High-imagery words are encoded both visually and semantically (Paivio, 1986), thus building a stronger memory.']
['Teacher: What aspect of encoding will we be focusing on next?', 'Now let’s turn our attention to acoustic encoding.']

['Teacher: Can you give me an example of how acoustic encoding can be observed in everyday life?', 'You are driving in your car and a song comes on the radio that you haven’t heard in at least 10 years, but you sing along, recalling every word.']

['Teacher: How can we explain the example you provided using the concept of acoustic encoding?', 'In the United States, children often learn the alphabet through song, and they learn the number of days in each month through rhyme: “Thirty days hath September, / April, June, and November; / All the rest have thirty-one, / Save February, with twenty-eight days clear, / And twenty-nine each leap year.”']
['What other examples of acoustic encoding can you think of that help people remember information easily?', 'These lessons are easy to remember because of acoustic encoding.']
['How does acoustic encoding contribute to the easy remembrance of information?', 'We encode the sounds the words make.']

['What are some techniques that are commonly used to incorporate acoustic encoding into teaching young children?', 'This is one of the reasons why much of what we teach young children is done through song, rhyme, and rhythm.']

['Teacher: What did psychologists Fergus Craik and Endel Tulving conduct a series of experiments on some years ago?', 'Some years ago, psychologists Fergus Craik and Endel Tulving (1975) conducted a series of experiments to find out.']

['Teacher: What were participants given along with questions during the series of experiments conducted by psychologists Fergus Craik and Endel Tulving?', 'Participants were given words along with questions about them.']

['Teacher: How did the questions in the experiments conducted by psychologists Fergus Craik and Endel Tulving require participants to process the words?', 'The questions required the participants to process the words at one of the three levels.']

['Teacher: What other types of questions were included in the experiments conducted by psychologists Fergus Craik and Endel Tulving besides visual processing questions?', 'The visual processing questions included such things as asking the participants about the font of the letters.']

['What two types of questions were included in the experiments conducted by psychologists Fergus Craik and Endel Tulving, besides visual processing questions?', 'The acoustic processing questions asked the participants about the sound or rhyming of the words, and the semantic processing questions asked the participants about the meaning of the words.']

['What task were participants given after being presented with the words and questions in the experiments conducted by psychologists Fergus Craik and Endel Tulving?', 'After participants were presented with the words and questions, they were given an unexpected recall or recognition task.']

['Teacher: According to the passage, which type of encoding was found to result in better remembering of words: semantic, visual, or acoustic?', 'Words that had been encoded semantically were better remembered than those encoded visually or acoustically.']
