['According to the passage, why were words encoded semantically found to be better remembered compared to visually or acoustically encoded words?', 'Semantic encoding involves a deeper level of processing than the shallower visual or acoustic encoding.']

['What type of encoding was found to result in better remembering of words according to Craik and Tulving?', 'Craik and Tulving concluded that we process verbal information best through semantic encoding, especially if we apply what is called the self-reference effect.']

['What is the self-reference effect and how does it relate to semantic encoding?', 'The self-reference effect is the tendency for an individual to have better memory for information that relates to oneself in comparison to material that has less personal relevance (Rogers, Kuiper, & Kirker, 1977).']
['Teacher: What process occurs after the information has been encoded?', 'Once the information has been encoded, we have to somehow retain it.']
['Teacher: How does our brain handle the encoded information after it has been retained?', 'Our brains take the encoded information and place it in storage.']
['What is the purpose of storage in relation to the encoded information?', 'Storage is the creation of a permanent record of information.']

['Teacher: What are the three distinct stages that a memory has to pass through in order to go into storage?', 'In order for a memory to go into storage (i.e., long-term memory), it has to pass through three distinct stages: Sensory Memory, Short-Term Memory, and finally Long-Term Memory.']

['What are the names of the three stages that a memory has to pass through in order to go into storage, and who proposed these stages?', 'These stages were first proposed by Richard Atkinson and Richard Shiffrin (1968).']

['What is the name of the model proposed by Richard Atkinson and Richard Shiffrin that describes the three stages of memory?', "Their model of human memory, called Atkinson and Shiffrin's model, is based on the belief that we process memories in the same way that a computer processes information."]
["Teacher: What do you want to point out about Atkinson and Shiffrin's model of memory?", "Atkinson and Shiffrin's model is not the only model of memory."]

["Teacher: Can you explain how Baddeley and Hitch's working memory model differs from Atkinson and Shiffrin's model of memory?", 'Baddeley and Hitch (1974) proposed a working memory model in which short-term memory has different forms.']

["Teacher: How does Baddeley and Hitch's working memory model compare the process of storing memories to using a computer?", 'In their model, storing memories in short-term memory is like opening different files on a computer and adding information.']

["Teacher: What is a characteristic of Baddeley and Hitch's working memory files in terms of the amount of information they can hold?", 'The working memory files hold a limited amount of information.']

["Teacher: In Baddeley and Hitch's working memory model, what determines the type of short-term memory or computer file that is used?", 'The type of short-term memory (or computer file) depends on the type of information received.']

["Teacher: What are the three short-term systems in Baddeley and Hitch's working memory model?", 'There are memories in visual-spatial form, as well as memories of spoken or written material, and they are stored in three short-term systems: a visuospatial sketchpad, an episodic buffer (Baddeley, 2000), and a phonological loop.']

["What is the function of the central executive in Baddeley and Hitch's working memory model?", 'According to Baddeley and Hitch, a central executive part of memory supervises or controls the flow of information to and from the three short-term systems, and the central executive is responsible for moving information into long-term memory.']

['Teacher: What is the function of sensory memory in the Atkinson-Shiffrin model?', 'In the Atkinson-Shiffrin model, stimuli from the environment are processed first in sensory memory: storage of brief sensory events, such as sights, sounds, and tastes.']
['What type of information does sensory memory store in the Atkinson-Shiffrin model?', 'It is very brief storage—up to a couple of seconds.']
['What is the duration of sensory memory in the Atkinson-Shiffrin model?', 'We are constantly bombarded with sensory information.']
['What is the relevance of sensory memory to our perception in the Atkinson-Shiffrin model?', 'As long as the professor was dressed appropriately, it does not really matter what she was wearing.']

['What happens to sensory information that we do not view as valuable in the Atkinson-Shiffrin model?', 'Sensory information about sights, sounds, smells, and even textures, which we do not view as valuable information, we discard.']

['What determines whether sensory information will move into our short-term memory system in the Atkinson-Shiffrin model?', 'If we view something as valuable, the information will move into our short-term memory system.']
['Teacher: What is the function of Short-term memory (STM)?', 'Short-term memory (STM) is a temporary storage system that processes incoming sensory memory.']
['Teacher: How does short-term memory differ from working memory?', 'The terms short-term and working memory are sometimes used interchangeably, but they are not exactly the same.']
['Teacher: How would you describe the relationship between short-term memory and working memory?', 'Short-term memory is more accurately described as a component of working memory.']

['Teacher: Can you explain how short-term memory connects information from sensory memory to long-term memory?', 'Short-term memory takes information from sensory memory and sometimes connects that memory to something already in long-term memory.']
['Teacher: What is the duration of short-term memory storage?', 'Short-term memory storage lasts 15 to 30 seconds.']

['Teacher: Can you give an example of a situation where short-term memory would be utilized?', 'Think of it as the information you have displayed on your computer screen, such as a document, spreadsheet, or website.']

['Teacher: How can short-term memory be transferred to long-term memory?', 'Then, information in STM goes to long-term memory (you save it to your hard drive), or it is discarded (you delete a document or close a web browser).']
['Teacher: What is the process that moves information from short-term memory to long-term memory called?', 'Rehearsal moves information from short-term memory to long-term memory.']

['What is active rehearsal and how does it help to move information from short-term memory to long-term memory?', 'Active rehearsal is a way of attending to information to move it from short-term to long-term memory.']

['Teacher: How does the process of active rehearsal contribute to the movement of information from short-term memory to long-term memory?', 'During active rehearsal, you repeat (practice) the information to be remembered.']
['What is the purpose of repeating the information during active rehearsal?', 'If you repeat it enough, it may be moved into long-term memory.']

['What is an example of active rehearsal that many children use to learn their ABCs?', 'For example, this type of active rehearsal is the way many children learn their ABCs by singing the alphabet song.']

['What is elaborative rehearsal and how does it differ from active rehearsal in terms of the process of moving information from short-term memory to long-term memory?', 'Alternatively, elaborative rehearsal is the act of linking new information you are trying to learn to existing information that you already know.']

["What is an example of elaborative rehearsal that can help you remember someone's phone number?", 'For example, if you meet someone at a party and your phone is dead but you want to remember his phone number, which starts with area code 203, you might remember that your uncle Abdul lives in Connecticut and has a 203 area code.']

['How does elaborative rehearsal differ from active rehearsal in terms of the process of moving information from short-term memory to long-term memory?', 'This way, when you try to remember the phone number of your new prospective friend, you will easily remember the area code.']

['What is the levels of processing hypothesis and what does it propose about memory?', 'Craik and Lockhart (1972) proposed the levels of processing hypothesis that states the deeper you think about something, the better you remember it.']

['Teacher: Good question! Well, our memory capacity is divided into two types: short-term memory and long-term memory. Could you please explain what short-term memory refers to?', 'You may find yourself asking, “How much information can our memory handle at once?”']

['Student: What method can be used to explore the capacity and duration of our short-term memory?', 'To explore the capacity and duration of your short-term memory, have a partner read the strings of random numbers out loud to you, beginning each string by saying, “Ready?” and ending each by saying, “Recall,” at which point you should try to write down the string of numbers from memory.']
['Teacher: What instruction does the passage provide regarding determining the capacity of short-term memory?', 'Note the longest string at which you got the series correct.']
['Teacher: What is the approximate capacity of short-term memory for most individuals, according to the passage?', 'For most people, the capacity will probably be close to 7 plus or minus 2.']

["What is the significance of George Miller's research on the capacity of short-term memory?", 'In 1956, George Miller reviewed most of the research on the capacity of short-term memory and found that people can retain between 5 and 9 items, so he reported the capacity of short-term memory was the "magic number" 7 plus or minus 2.']

['What is the difference between George Miller\'s "magic number" and the contemporary research findings on the capacity of working memory?', 'However, more contemporary research has found working memory capacity is 4 plus or minus 1 (Cowan, 2010).']

['What are some factors that can affect recall in short-term memory according to the passage?', 'Generally, recall is somewhat better for random numbers than for random letters (Jacobs, 1887) and also often slightly better for information we hear (acoustic encoding) rather than information we see (visual encoding) (Anderson, 1969).']
['Teacher: What are the two factors that affect short-term memory retention?', 'Memory trace decay and interference are two factors that affect short-term memory retention.']

['What did Peterson and Peterson (1959) investigate in relation to short-term memory?', 'Peterson and Peterson (1959) investigated short-term memory using the three letter sequences called trigrams (e.g., CLS) that had to be recalled after various time intervals between 3 and 18 seconds.']

["What were the findings of Peterson and Peterson's study on short-term memory decay after different time intervals?", 'Participants remembered about 80% of the trigrams after a 3-second delay, but only 10% after a delay of 18 seconds, which caused them to conclude that short-term memory decayed in 18 seconds.']
['What is one way short-term memory decay can be explained during the forgetting process?', 'During decay, the memory trace becomes less activated over time, and the information is forgotten.']

['What did Keppel and Underwood (1962) find in regards to short-term memory retention and interference?', 'However, Keppel and Underwood (1962) examined only the first trials of the trigram task and found that proactive interference also affected short-term memory retention.']

["What is one way that short-term memory retention can be affected according to the findings of Keppel and Underwood's study?", 'During proactive interference, previously learned information interferes with the ability to learn new information.']

['What are two factors that have been found to affect short-term memory retention according to the research discussed?', 'Both memory trace decay and proactive interference affect short-term memory.']

['What is the process that occurs once information reaches long-term memory?', 'Once the information reaches long-term memory, it has to be consolidated at both the synaptic level, which takes a few hours, and into the memory system, which can take weeks or longer.']
['Teacher: How would you define long-term memory (LTM)?', 'Long-term memory (LTM) is the continuous storage of information.']

["Teacher: That's a great definition! Can you provide an example of how information is stored in long-term memory?", 'Unlike short-term memory, long-term memory storage capacity is believed to be unlimited.']
['Teacher: How does long-term memory differ from short-term memory in terms of storage capacity?', 'It encompasses all the things you can remember that happened more than just a few minutes ago.']

['Teacher: How does the organization of long-term memory contribute to our ability to remember things from the past?', 'One cannot really consider long-term memory without thinking about the way it is organized.']

['What is the relationship between the organization of long-term memory and the association of peanut butter and jelly in your mind?', 'If you did, you probably have associated peanut butter and jelly in your mind.']

['How does the concept of semantic networks relate to the association between peanut butter and jelly in your mind?', 'It is generally accepted that memories are organized in semantic (or associative) networks (Collins & Loftus, 1975).']

['What is the role of semantic networks in the organization of long-term memory?', 'A semantic network consists of concepts, and as you may recall from what you’ve learned about memory, concepts are categories or groupings of linguistic information, images, ideas, or memories, such as life experiences.']

['What is the relationship between hierarchical arrangement of concepts and the organization of long-term memory?', 'Although individual experiences and expertise can affect concept arrangement, concepts are believed to be arranged hierarchically in the mind (Anderson & Reder, 1999; Johnson & Mervis, 1997, 1998; Palmer, Jones, Hennessy, Unze, & Pick, 1989; Rosch, Mervis, Gray, Johnson, & Boyes-Braem, 1976; Tanaka & Taylor, 1991).']

['How does the strength of the link between related concepts in a hierarchical arrangement impact the organization of long-term memory?', 'Related concepts are linked, and the strength of the link depends on how often two concepts have been associated.']
['Teacher: How do semantic networks vary?', 'Semantic networks differ depending on personal experiences.']

['Teacher: What happens when any part of a semantic network is activated in terms of memory?', 'Importantly for memory, activating any part of a semantic network also activates the concepts linked to that part to a lesser degree.']
['Teacher: What is the significance of spreading activation in the context of long-term memory?', 'The process is known as spreading activation (Collins & Loftus, 1975).']

['Teacher: How does spreading activation affect the accessibility of associated concepts in long-term memory?', 'If one part of a network is activated, it is easier to access the associated concepts because they are already partially activated.']

['Teacher: How does spreading activation enhance the process of remembering or recalling information from long-term memory?', 'When you remember or recall something, you activate a concept, and the related concepts are more easily remembered because they are partially activated.']

['Teacher: What does the bidirectional spreading of activations in semantic networks imply for the process of remembering or recalling information from long-term memory?', 'However, the activations do not spread in just one direction.']

['Teacher: How does the bidirectional spreading of activations in semantic networks affect the process of remembering or recalling information from long-term memory?', 'When you remember something, you usually have several routes to get the information you are trying to access, and the more links you have to a concept, the better your chances of remembering.']
['Teacher: What are the two types of long-term memory?', 'There are two types of long-term memory: explicit and implicit.']

['What are some factors that can affect explicit and implicit memory differently?', 'Understanding the difference between explicit memory and implicit memory is important because aging, particular types of brain trauma, and certain disorders can impact explicit and implicit memory in different ways.']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example of an explicit memory?', 'Explicit memories are those we consciously try to remember, recall, and report.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of an implicit memory?\nStudent:', 'For example, if you are studying for your chemistry exam, the material you are learning will be part of your explicit memory.']

['Teacher: How would you describe implicit memory in comparison to explicit memory, using the computer analogy?', 'In keeping with the computer analogy, some information in your long-term memory would be like the information you have saved on the hard drive.']

['Teacher: How does the computer analogy help us understand the accessibility of implicit memory?', 'It is not there on your desktop (your short-term memory), but most of the time you can pull up this information when you want it.']

['What is the significance of using prompts in relation to recalling certain long-term memories?', 'Not all long-term memories are strong memories, and some memories can only be recalled using prompts.']

['Teacher: Why might we need prompts to recall certain long-term memories?', 'For example, you might easily recall a fact, such as the capital of the United States, but you might struggle to recall the name of the restaurant at which you had dinner when you visited a nearby city last summer.']

['Why might the use of prompts be beneficial in the process of recalling certain long-term memories?', 'A prompt, such as that the restaurant was named after its owner, might help you recall the name of the restaurant.']
['What is another term used to refer to explicit memory and why?', 'Explicit memory is sometimes referred to as declarative memory, because it can be put into words.']
['What is the difference between episodic memory and semantic memory within the category of explicit memory?', 'Explicit memory is divided into episodic memory and semantic memory.']
['Teacher: Can you explain what episodic memory refers to?', 'Episodic memory is information about events we have personally experienced (i.e., an episode).']
['Teacher: Can you provide another example of a personal event that would fall under episodic memory?', 'For instance, the memory of your last birthday is an episodic memory.']
['Teacher: How is episodic memory typically reported?', 'Usually, episodic memory is reported as a story.']
['Teacher: When was the concept of episodic memory first proposed?', 'The concept of episodic memory was first proposed about in the 1970s (Tulving, 1972).']

['Teacher: What is the current understanding of episodic memory according to Tulving and other scientists?', 'Since then, Tulving and others have reformulated the theory, and currently scientists believe that episodic memory is memory about happenings in particular places at particular times—the what, where, and when of an event (Tulving, 2002).']

['Teacher: How does the current understanding of episodic memory differ from the original proposal by Tulving in the 1970s?', 'It involves recollection of visual imagery as well as the feeling of familiarity (Hassabis & Maguire, 2007).']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example of knowledge that falls under semantic memory?', 'Semantic memory is knowledge about words, concepts, and language-based knowledge and facts.']
['Teacher: How does semantic memory differ from episodic memory in terms of the type of information it represents?', 'Semantic memory is typically reported as facts.']
['Teacher: Can you explain how semantic memory differs from episodic memory in terms of the way it is acquired?', 'Semantic means having to do with language and knowledge about language.']

['Teacher: How would you describe the content of semantic memory in comparison to episodic memory?', 'For example, answers to the following questions like “what is the definition of psychology” and “who was the first African American president of the United States” are stored in your semantic memory.']
['Teacher: What are implicit memories?', 'Implicit memories are long-term memories that are not part of our consciousness.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how implicit memory is demonstrated in the performance of a task?', 'Although implicit memories are learned outside of our awareness and cannot be consciously recalled, implicit memory is demonstrated in the performance of some task (Roediger, 1990; Schacter, 1987).']

['Teacher: What are some examples of cognitive demand tasks that have been used to study implicit memory?', 'Implicit memory has been studied with cognitive demand tasks, such as performance on artificial grammars (Reber, 1976), word memory (Jacoby, 1983; Jacoby & Witherspoon, 1982), and learning unspoken and unwritten contingencies and rules (Greenspoon, 1955; Giddan & Eriksen, 1959; Krieckhaus & Eriksen, 1960).']

['Teacher: How would you compare implicit memories to a program running in the background of a computer?', 'Returning to the computer metaphor, implicit memories are like a program running in the background, and you are not aware of their influence.']
['Teacher: How do implicit memories influence observable behaviors and cognitive tasks?', 'Implicit memories can influence observable behaviors as well as cognitive tasks.']

['Teacher: Why is it difficult to put implicit memories into words that adequately describe the task?', 'In either case, you usually cannot put the memory into words that adequately describe the task.']
['Teacher: Can you provide examples of each of the types of implicit memories?', 'There are several types of implicit memories, including procedural, priming, and emotional conditioning.']

['Teacher: How is implicit procedural memory commonly examined and understood?', 'Implicit procedural memory is often studied using observable behaviors (Adams, 1957; Lacey & Smith, 1954; Lazarus & McCleary, 1951).']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a skill that would fall under the category of implicit procedural memory?', 'Implicit procedural memory stores information about the way to do something, and it is the memory for skilled actions, such as brushing your teeth, riding a bicycle, or driving a car.']

['Teacher: How does implicit procedural memory relate to the learning and mastery of skills like riding a bicycle or driving a car?', 'You were probably not that good at riding a bicycle or driving a car the first time you tried, but you were much better after doing those things for a year.']
['Teacher: What type of memory is responsible for your improved bicycle riding after practicing for a year?', 'Your improved bicycle riding was due to learning balancing abilities.']

['Teacher: How would you classify the memory that allows you to ride a bicycle without consciously thinking about staying upright?', 'You likely thought about staying upright in the beginning, but now you just do it.']

['Teacher: What type of memory allows for the automatic and unconscious execution of skilled actions, such as staying balanced while riding a bicycle?', 'Moreover, you probably are good at staying balanced, but cannot tell someone the exact way you do it.']

['Teacher: What term describes the type of memory that allows for the automatic execution of skilled actions, such as driving a car without much conscious thought?', 'Similarly, when you first learned to drive, you probably thought about a lot of things that you just do now without much thought.']
['Teacher: What is another type of implicit memory?', 'Implicit priming is another type of implicit memory (Schacter, 1992).']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how implicit priming works in the context of long-term memory?', 'During priming exposure to a stimulus affects the response to a later stimulus.']

['Teacher: Can you explain how stimuli like words, pictures, and other stimuli can be used to elicit a response or increase recognition in the context of implicit priming?', 'Stimuli can vary and may include words, pictures, and other stimuli to elicit a response or increase recognition.']

['Teacher: How can stimuli like words, pictures, and other stimuli contribute to the elicitation of a response or the enhancement of recognition in the context of implicit priming?', 'For instance, some people really enjoy picnics.']

['Why is the example of people enjoying picnics relevant to the discussion of stimuli in implicit priming?', 'They love going into nature, spreading a blanket on the ground, and eating a delicious meal.']
['Teacher: What is the purpose of providing a word unscrambling task in the context of implicit priming and stimuli?', 'Now, unscramble the following letters to make a word.']
['Teacher: What is the most likely term that completes the acronym AETPL?', 'Chances are good that it was "plate."']
['Teacher: What is the main focus of the passage you just mentioned?', 'Had you read, “Some people really enjoy growing flowers.']

['What word could you have come up with instead of "plate" if you had read the passage about people enjoying growing flowers?', 'They love going outside to their garden, fertilizing their plants, and watering their flowers,” you probably would have come up with the word "petal" instead of plate.']

['Teacher: Why do people tend to associate the word "plate" with the concept of a picnic?', 'The reason people are more likely to come up with “plate” after reading about a picnic is that plate is associated (linked) with picnic.']
['Teacher: How does plate being primed by activating the semantic network relate to people associating it with picnics?', 'Plate was primed by activating the semantic network.']

['Teacher: Can you give an example of another word that is primed by activating the semantic network, similar to how "plate" is primed by the concept of a picnic?', 'Similarly, “petal” is linked to flower and is primed by flower.']
['Teacher: Why do people tend to associate the word "jelly" with the concept of peanut butter?', 'Priming is also the reason you probably said jelly in response to peanut butter.']

["Teacher: What type of memory is involved in classically conditioned emotion responses, according to Olson and Fazio's study?", 'Implicit emotional conditioning is the type of memory involved in classically conditioned emotion responses (Olson & Fazio, 2001).']

['What type of emotional relationships can be associated with different stimuli in classically conditioned emotion responses?', 'These emotional relationships cannot be reported or recalled but can be associated with different stimuli.']

['What is an example of a specific stimulus that can elicit a specific emotional response in classically conditioned emotion responses?', 'For example, specific smells can cause specific emotional responses for some people.']

["Teacher: How do Olson and Fazio's findings suggest that implicit emotional conditioning can affect our responses to certain stimuli?", "If there is a smell that makes you feel positive and nostalgic, and you don't know where that response comes from, it is an implicit emotional response."]

["What is Olson and Fazio's main finding regarding the relationship between implicit emotional conditioning and our responses to certain stimuli?", 'Similarly, most people have a song that causes a specific emotional response.']

["What are some examples of stimuli that can trigger implicit emotional memories according to Yang, Xu, Du, Shi, and Fang's study?", "That song's effect could be an implicit emotional memory (Yang, Xu, Du, Shi, & Fang, 2011)."]

['Teacher: What is the next step after encoding and storing important information for your upcoming final exam?', 'So you have worked hard to encode (via effortful processing) and store some important information for your upcoming final exam.']

["Teacher: That's correct! Now, can you describe the process of retrieval and how it helps you in your final exam preparation?", 'The act of getting information out of memory storage and back into conscious awareness is known as retrieval.']
['Why is retrieval an important process in your final exam preparation?', 'This would be similar to finding and opening a paper you had previously saved on your computer’s hard drive.']
['What are some strategies that can help improve retrieval of information from long-term memory?', 'Our ability to retrieve information from long-term memory is vital to our everyday functioning.']

['What are some strategies that can help improve retrieval of information from long-term memory? Can you provide some examples?', 'You must be able to retrieve information from memory in order to do everything from knowing how to brush your hair and teeth, to driving to work, to knowing how to perform your job once you get there.']

['Teacher: Can you please explain the three ways you can retrieve information out of your long-term memory storage system?', 'There are three ways you can retrieve information out of your long-term memory storage system: recall, recognition, and relearning.']

['Teacher: Can you give an example of recall and explain how it differs from recognition and relearning?', 'Recall is what we most often think about when we talk about memory retrieval: it means you can access information without cues.']
['Teacher: How does recall differ from recognition and relearning in terms of accessing information?', 'For example, you would use recall for an essay test.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of recognition and explain how it differs from recall and relearning?', 'Recognition happens when you identify information that you have previously learned after encountering it again.']
['Teacher: How does recognition differ from recall and relearning in terms of the process involved?', 'It involves a process of comparison.']

['Teacher: How does the process of recognition in a multiple-choice test differ from the process of recall used in an essay test?', 'When you take a multiple-choice test, you are relying on recognition to help you choose the correct answer.']
['What type of retrieval process is used when taking a multiple-choice test compared to an essay test?', 'Here is another example.']

['Teacher: How would you retrieve information about your high school classmates after 10 years, using the three ways discussed?', 'Let’s say you graduated from high school 10 years ago, and you have returned to your hometown for your 10-year reunion.']

['What type of retrieval process is the student using when recognizing their high school classmates based on their yearbook photos at the 10-year reunion?', 'You may not be able to recall all of your classmates, but you recognize many of them based on their yearbook photos.']
['Teacher: Can you please explain the concept of relearning in the context of retrieval?', 'The third form of retrieval is relearning, and it’s just what it sounds like.']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how relearning can be used in the context of retrieval?', 'It involves learning information that you previously learned.']

['Teacher: How can relearning be beneficial for Whitney in her quest for speaking Spanish again?', 'Whitney took Spanish in high school, but after high school she did not have the opportunity to speak Spanish.']
['Teacher: How can relearning help Whitney in preparing to speak Spanish again?', 'Whitney is now 31, and her company has offered her an opportunity to work in their Mexico City office.']

['Teacher: How does enrolling in a Spanish course at the local community center relate to the concept of relearning in the context of retrieval?', 'In order to prepare herself, she enrolls in a Spanish course at the local community center.']

["What does Whitney's experience of quickly picking up the language after 13 years of not speaking it illustrate in terms of relearning in the context of retrieval?", 'She’s surprised at how quickly she’s able to pick up the language after not speaking it for 13 years; this is an example of relearning.']

['Teacher: Who began exploring the problem of the parts of the brain involved with memory by making lesions in the brains of animals such as rats and monkeys about 100 years ago?', 'Karl Lashley began exploring this problem, about 100 years ago, by making lesions in the brains of animals such as rats and monkeys.']

['Who was Karl Lashley searching for evidence of when he began exploring the problem of the parts of the brain involved with memory?', 'He was searching for evidence of the engram: the group of neurons that serve as the “physical representation of memory” (Josselyn, 2010).']
['Who did Lashley train the rats to find their way through a maze?', 'First, Lashley (1950) trained rats to find their way through a maze.']

["What was the purpose of creating lesions in the rats' brains by Karl Lashley?", 'Then, he used the tools available at the time—in this case a soldering iron—to create lesions in the rats’ brains, specifically in the cerebral cortex.']

["What did Karl Lashley hope to achieve by creating lesions in the rats' brains?", 'He did this because he was trying to erase the engram, or the original memory trace that the rats had of the maze.']

['Teacher: What did Lashley not find evidence of in his research on the rats?', 'Lashley did not find evidence of the engram, and the rats were still able to find their way through the maze, regardless of the size or location of the lesion.']

['What is the equipotentiality hypothesis proposed by Lashley based on his research on rats?', 'Based on his creation of lesions and the animals’ reaction, he formulated the equipotentiality hypothesis: if part of one area of the brain involved in memory is damaged, another part of the same area can take over that memory function (Lashley, 1950).']

["Teacher: What does modern research suggest about the existence of the engram, in contrast to Lashley's early work?", 'Although Lashley’s early work did not confirm the existence of the engram, modern psychologists are making progress locating it.']

["What does Eric Kandel's research focus on in regards to memory?", 'For example, Eric Kandel has spent decades studying the synapse and its role in controlling the flow of information through neural circuits needed to store memories (Mayford, Siegelbaum, & Kandel, 2012).']
['Teacher: What is the belief of many scientists regarding the involvement of the brain in memory?', 'Many scientists believe that the entire brain is involved with memory.']

["Teacher: How has Lashley's research influenced the understanding of the brain's involvement in memory?", 'However, since Lashley’s research, other scientists have been able to look more closely at the brain and memory.']

['Teacher: Can you provide any examples of specific parts of the brain that have been identified as being involved in memory formation?', 'They have argued that memory is located in specific parts of the brain, and specific neurons can be recognized for their involvement in forming memories.']

['Teacher: How does the involvement of the amygdala, hippocampus, cerebellum, and prefrontal cortex in memory affect the functioning of the brain?', 'The main parts of the brain involved with memory are the amygdala, the hippocampus, the cerebellum, and the prefrontal cortex.']
['Teacher: What are we about to explore regarding the amygdala?', 'First, let’s look at the role of the amygdala in memory formation.']
['Teacher: What other function of the amygdala will we be discussing besides its role in memory formation?', 'The main job of the amygdala is to regulate emotions, such as fear and aggression.']
['What is the impact of stress hormones on memory storage?', 'The amygdala plays a part in how memories are stored because storage is influenced by stress hormones.']
['What did the researcher study in relation to the fear response and the amygdala?', 'For example, one researcher experimented with rats and the fear response (Josselyn, 2010).']

['What was the result of the experiment with rats and the fear response conducted by Josselyn in relation to the amygdala?', 'Using Pavlovian conditioning, a neutral tone was paired with a foot shock to the rats.']
['What specific changes in the amygdala were observed as a result of the fear memory produced in the rats?', 'This produced a fear memory in the rats.']

['What does the freezing response in rats indicate in relation to the fear memory and the amygdala?', 'After being conditioned, each time they heard the tone, they would freeze (a defense response in rats), indicating a memory for the impending shock.']

['How did the researchers manipulate the amygdala in the experiment on rats and fear memory conducted by Josselyn?', 'Then the researchers induced cell death in neurons in the lateral amygdala, which is the specific area of the brain responsible for fear memories.']
['What was the result of inducing cell death in neurons in the lateral amygdala in relation to the fear memory in rats?', 'They found the fear memory faded (became extinct).']

['What is the involvement of the amygdala in memory consolidation?', 'Because of its role in processing emotional information, the amygdala is also involved in memory consolidation: the process of transferring new learning into long-term memory.']

['What is the impact of emotional arousal on the encoding of memories with the involvement of the amygdala?', 'The amygdala seems to facilitate encoding memories at a deeper level when the event is emotionally arousing.']

['Teacher: What did another group of researchers do to understand the functioning of the hippocampus in memory processing?', 'Another group of researchers also experimented with rats to learn how the hippocampus functions in memory processing.']

['What were the findings of the experiments conducted by the group of researchers who created lesions in the hippocampi of rats?', 'They created lesions in the hippocampi of the rats, and found that the rats demonstrated memory impairment on various tasks, such as object recognition and maze running.']

['What specific tasks were the rats impaired in after the lesions were created in their hippocampi?', 'They concluded that the hippocampus is involved in memory, specifically normal recognition memory as well as spatial memory (when the memory tasks are like recall tests) (Clark, Zola, & Squire, 2000).']

['What is the role of the hippocampus in relation to memory processing?', 'Another job of the hippocampus is to project information to cortical regions that give memories meaning and connect them with other memories.']
['How does the hippocampus contribute to the process of memory consolidation?', 'It also plays a part in memory consolidation: the process of transferring new learning into long-term memory.']
['Teacher: What happens if there is an injury to the <mask> region?', 'Injury to this area leaves us unable to process new declarative memories.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a famous patient who had both his left and right temporal lobes (hippocampi) removed?', 'One famous patient, known for years only as H. M., had both his left and right temporal lobes (hippocampi) removed in an attempt to help control the seizures he had been suffering from for years (Corkin, Amaral, González, Johnson, & Hyman, 1997).']

["Teacher: How did the removal of both left and right temporal lobes (hippocampi) affect the famous patient H. M.'s declarative memory?", 'As a result, his declarative memory was significantly affected, and he could not form new semantic knowledge.']

["Teacher: How did the removal of both left and right temporal lobes (hippocampi) affect H. M.'s ability to form new memories?", 'He lost the ability to form new memories, yet he could still remember information and events that had occurred prior to the surgery.']

['Teacher: What part of the brain is responsible for creating implicit memories such as procedural memory, motor learning, and classical conditioning, even if the hippocampus is lost?', 'Although the hippocampus seems to be more of a processing area for explicit memories, you could still lose it and be able to create implicit memories (procedural memory, motor learning, and classical conditioning), thanks to your cerebellum.']

['What part of the brain is primarily responsible for creating implicit memories such as procedural memory, motor learning, and classical conditioning, even if the hippocampus is lost?', 'For example, one classical conditioning experiment is to accustom subjects to blink when they are given a puff of air to the eyes.']

['What did researchers discover when they damaged the cerebellums of rabbits?', 'When researchers damaged the cerebellums of rabbits, they discovered that the rabbits were not able to learn the conditioned eye-blink response (Steinmetz, 1999; Green & Woodruff-Pak, 2000).']

['Teacher: How have other researchers investigated the processing and retention of information in relation to the cerebellum and prefrontal cortex?', 'Other researchers have used brain scans, including positron emission tomography (PET) scans, to learn how people process and retain information.']

['What specific brain scanning technique have researchers used to investigate the processing and retention of information in relation to the cerebellum and prefrontal cortex?', 'From these studies, it seems the prefrontal cortex is involved.']

['What were the two different tasks that participants had to complete in the study investigating the involvement of the prefrontal cortex in processing and retention of information?', 'In one study, participants had to complete two different tasks: either looking for the letter a in words (considered a perceptual task) or categorizing a noun as either living or non-living (considered a semantic task) (Kapur et al., 1994).']
["What were the results of the study in terms of participants' ability to recall previously seen words?", 'Participants were then asked which words they had previously seen.']
['Why was recall much better for the semantic task than for the perceptual task in the study?', 'Recall was much better for the semantic task than for the perceptual task.']

['What did the PET scans reveal about the activation of the left inferior prefrontal cortex in the semantic task?', 'According to PET scans, there was much more activation in the left inferior prefrontal cortex in the semantic task.']

['What did the PET scans reveal about the activation of the left frontal cortex in the encoding and retrieval of information?', 'In another study, encoding was associated with left frontal activity, while retrieval of information was associated with the right frontal region (Craik et al., 1999).']

['Teacher: Can you name some of the specific neurotransmitters involved in the process of memory?', 'There also appear to be specific neurotransmitters involved with the process of memory, such as epinephrine, dopamine, serotonin, glutamate, and acetylcholine (Myhrer, 2003).']

['What are some of the neurotransmitters involved in the process of memory?', 'There continues to be discussion and debate among researchers as to which neurotransmitter plays which specific role (Blockland, 1996).']

['What is the current understanding among researchers regarding the specific roles of neurotransmitters in memory?', 'Although we don’t yet know which role each neurotransmitter plays in memory, we do know that communication among neurons via neurotransmitters is critical for developing new memories.']

['Why is communication among neurons via neurotransmitters critical for developing new memories?', 'Repeated activity by neurons leads to increased neurotransmitters in the synapses and more efficient and more synaptic connections.']
['How does repeated activity by neurons lead to memory consolidation?', 'This is how memory consolidation occurs.']

['Teacher: What is the term used to describe the phenomenon where strong emotions lead to the formation of strong memories, while weaker emotional experiences result in weaker memories?', 'It is also believed that strong emotions trigger the formation of strong memories, and weaker emotional experiences form weaker memories; this is called arousal theory (Christianson, 1992).']

['What are the factors that contribute to the formation of stronger memories during strong emotional experiences?', 'For example, strong emotional experiences can trigger the release of neurotransmitters, as well as hormones, which strengthen memory; therefore, our memory for an emotional event is usually better than our memory for a non-emotional event.']

['What neurotransmitter is released in greater amounts by the brain during times of stress to help enhance memory?', 'When humans and animals are stressed, the brain secretes more of the neurotransmitter glutamate, which helps them remember the stressful event (McGaugh, 2003).']

['What is the flashbulb memory phenomenon and how does it relate to the release of glutamate during times of stress?', 'This is clearly evidenced by what is known as the flashbulb memory phenomenon.']
['Teacher: Can you define what a flashbulb memory is?', 'A flashbulb memory is an exceptionally clear recollection of an important event.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a historic or momentous event that people often have flashbulb memories of?', 'Many people who have lived through historic and momentous events can recall exactly where they were and how they heard about them.']

['What is one specific example of a historic event that people often have flashbulb memories of?', 'For example, a Pew Research Center (2011) survey found that for those Americans who were age 8 or older at the time of 9/11 terrorist attacks, 97% can recall the moment they learned of this event, even a decade after it happened.']

['Why is it not necessary for a flashbulb memory to be a widely shared event?', 'Many widely discussed examples of flashbulb memories pertain to national or global events, but according to their initial definition by researchers Brown and Kulik (1977) as well as additional work by more recent researchers, such a widely shared event is not required (Hirst & Phelps, 2016).']

['Can you provide examples of personal events that can be considered flashbulb memories?', 'Family members might always remember how they heard about an important event in their lives, or people in a school may recall nearly everything about the way they experienced a major event in that setting.']

['What are some examples of positive events that can elicit flashbulb memories?', 'And although most studies (and many conversations) involve negative memories, positive events can also elicit flashbulb memories.']

['Teacher: What are some examples of memories that people may pride themselves on their ability to remember?', 'You may pride yourself on your amazing ability to remember the birthdates and ages of all of your friends and family members, or you may be able recall vivid details of your 5th birthday party at Chuck E. Cheese’s.']

["Teacher: Can you provide an example of a situation where someone's memory failure may have caused frustration or embarrassment?", 'However, all of us have at times felt frustrated, and even embarrassed, when our memories have failed us.']
['Teacher: Can you explain some of the reasons why memory failures occur?', 'There are several reasons why this happens.']
['Teacher: What is the definition of amnesia?', 'Amnesia is the loss of long-term memory that occurs as the result of disease, physical trauma, or psychological trauma.']
['Teacher: Who conducted a study on K. C. and his memory loss?', 'Endel Tulving (2002) and his colleagues at the University of Toronto studied K. C. for years.']
['Teacher: How did K. C. develop severe amnesia?', 'K. C. suffered a traumatic head injury in a motorcycle accident and then had severe amnesia.']
['"What were the main symptoms of K. C.\'s amnesia?"', 'Tulving writes,']
['Teacher: Can you please elaborate on the two types of amnesia mentioned in the passage?', 'There are two common types of amnesia: anterograde amnesia and retrograde amnesia.']
['Teacher: What typically causes anterograde amnesia?', 'Anterograde amnesia is commonly caused by brain trauma, such as a blow to the head.']

["Teacher: That's correct. Can you explain what the main characteristic of anterograde amnesia is?", 'With anterograde amnesia, you cannot remember new information, although you can remember information and events that happened prior to your injury.']
["Teacher: How does anterograde amnesia affect a person's ability to form new memories?", 'The hippocampus is usually affected (McLeod, 2011).']

["Teacher: Excellent explanation. Can you give an example to illustrate how anterograde amnesia affects a person's ability to form new memories?", 'This suggests that damage to the brain has resulted in the inability to transfer information from short-term to long-term memory; that is, the inability to consolidate memories.']

['Teacher: What is the specific cognitive function that people with Anterograde Amnesia struggle with, in terms of forming new memories?', 'Many people with this form of amnesia are unable to form new episodic or semantic memories, but are still able to form new procedural memories (Bayley & Squire, 2002).']
['Teacher: Who is H. M. that was discussed earlier in relation to Anterograde Amnesia?', 'This was true of H. M., which was discussed earlier.']
['Teacher: What specific type of brain damage did H. M. experience as a result of his surgery?', 'The brain damage caused by his surgery resulted in anterograde amnesia.']

['Teacher: What type of memories was H. M. still able to form despite his anterograde amnesia?', 'H. M. would read the same magazine over and over, having no memory of ever reading it—it was always new to him.']
["Teacher: What distinguishes procedural memory from episodic and semantic memory in terms of H. M.'s abilities?", 'He also could not remember people he had met after his surgery.']

["Teacher: How does H. M.'s inability to remember people he had met after his surgery relate to his anterograde amnesia?", 'If you were introduced to H. M. and then you left the room for a few minutes, he would not know you upon your return and would introduce himself to you again.']

['Teacher: What is an example of a task or activity that H. M. was able to improve on despite his inability to form new memories?', 'However, when presented the same puzzle several days in a row, although he did not remember having seen the puzzle before, his speed at solving it became faster each day (because of relearning) (Corkin, 1965, 1968).']
['Teacher: Can you please define retrograde amnesia in your own words?', 'Retrograde amnesia is loss of memory for events that occurred prior to the trauma.']
['Teacher: Can you give an example of a traumatic event that may result in retrograde amnesia?', 'People with retrograde amnesia cannot remember some or even all of their past.']
['Teacher: What is the specific type of memory that individuals with retrograde amnesia have difficulty recalling?', 'They have difficulty remembering episodic memories.']
['What is the cause of retrograde amnesia in the situation you described?', 'You were in a car accident, suffered a head injury, and now have retrograde amnesia.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why someone might not remember anything about their life prior to waking up in the hospital if they have retrograde amnesia?', 'You don’t remember anything about your life prior to waking up in the hospital.']

['How has Hollywood portrayed retrograde amnesia in movies throughout history?', 'This may sound like the stuff of Hollywood movies, and Hollywood has been fascinated with the amnesia plot for nearly a century, going all the way back to the film Garden of Lies from 1915 to more recent movies such as the Jason Bourne spy thrillers.']

['What is one real-life example of a person who has experienced retrograde amnesia?', 'However, for real-life sufferers of retrograde amnesia, like former NFL football player Scott Bolzan, the story is not a Hollywood movie.']
['Are there any common symptoms or side effects associated with retrograde amnesia?', 'Bolzan fell, hit his head, and deleted 46 years of his life in an instant.']
['What specific memories did Scott Bolzan lose as a result of his head injury?', 'He is now living with one of the most extreme cases of retrograde amnesia on record.']

['Teacher: What is the term used to describe the process of creating new memories?', 'The formulation of new memories is sometimes called construction, and the process of bringing up old memories is called reconstruction.']
['What term is used to describe the process of altering and modifying our memories as we retrieve them?', 'Yet as we retrieve our memories, we also tend to alter and modify them.']
['What term is used to describe the flexibility of a memory pulled from long-term storage into short-term memory?', 'A memory pulled from long-term storage into short-term memory is flexible.']

['What effect does the process of reconstructing memories have on the accuracy of our recollections?', 'New events can be added and we can change what we think we remember about past events, resulting in inaccuracies and distortions.']

['What are some factors that can contribute to the inaccuracies and distortions in our memories?', 'People may not intend to distort facts, but it can happen in the process of retrieving old memories and combining them with new memories (Roediger & DeSoto, 2015).']

["Teacher: Why is someone's memory of the details of a crime important in catching the suspect?", 'When someone witnesses a crime, that person’s memory of the details of the crime is very important in catching the suspect.']

["Teacher: How does suggestibility affect the accuracy of a witness's memory?", 'Because memory is so fragile, witnesses can be easily (and often accidentally) misled due to the problem of suggestibility.']

['Teacher: How can suggestibility lead to the creation of false memories?', 'Suggestibility describes the effects of misinformation from external sources that leads to the creation of false memories.']

["Teacher: Can you provide an example of how suggestibility can influence a witness's memory in the context of the fall 2002 sniper attacks in the DC area?", 'In the fall of 2002, a sniper in the DC area shot people at a gas station, leaving Home Depot, and walking down the street.']

["Teacher: How might suggestibility have affected the witness's memory of the events during the fall 2002 sniper attacks in the DC area?", 'These attacks went on in a variety of places for over three weeks and resulted in the deaths of ten people.']

["Teacher: How might the high level of fear and anxiety during the sniper attacks have impacted the suggestibility of witnesses' memories?", 'During this time, as you can imagine, people were terrified to leave their homes, go shopping, or even walk through their neighborhoods.']

['Teacher: How can the high level of fear and anxiety experienced by witnesses during the sniper attacks impact the accuracy of their memories?', 'Police officers and the FBI worked frantically to solve the crimes, and a tip hotline was set up.']

['Teacher: What is the potential impact of the large number of tips received by law enforcement during the sniper attacks on the accuracy of their investigation?', 'Law enforcement received over 140,000 tips, which resulted in approximately 35,000 possible suspects (Newseum, n.d.).']

['Teacher: What finally caught the attention of the investigators at the scene of the shootings?', 'Most of the tips were dead ends, until a white van was spotted at the site of one of the shootings.']
['Teacher: Why did the police chief go on national television with a picture of the white van?', 'The police chief went on national television with a picture of the white van.']

['Teacher: What was the result of the police chief going on national television with a picture of the white van?', 'After the news conference, several other eyewitnesses called to say that they too had seen a white van fleeing from the scene of the shooting.']
['Teacher: How did the news conference and the picture of the white van influence the number of eyewitness accounts?', 'At the time, there were more than 70,000 white vans in the area.']

['What was the reason behind the focus on white vans by both the police officers and the general public?', 'Police officers, as well as the general public, focused almost exclusively on white vans because they believed the eyewitnesses.']
['What was the consequence of the police officers and the general public exclusively focusing on white vans?', 'Other tips were ignored.']
['What lesson can we learn from the fact that the suspects were driving a blue sedan when they were finally caught?', 'When the suspects were finally caught, they were driving a blue sedan.']

['Teacher: How does the passage suggest that individuals can become susceptible to suggestion?', 'As illustrated by this example, we are vulnerable to the power of suggestion, simply based on something we see on the news.']
['Teacher: What example does the passage provide to demonstrate the vulnerability of individuals to suggestion?', 'It is the suggestion that is the cause of the false memory.']

['Teacher: Why do police officers, prosecutors, and the courts often rely on eyewitness identification and testimony in the prosecution of criminals, even though memory and the process of reconstruction can be fragile?', 'Even though memory and the process of reconstruction can be fragile, police officers, prosecutors, and the courts often rely on eyewitness identification and testimony in the prosecution of criminals.']

['Teacher: What is one potential consequence of relying heavily on faulty eyewitness identification and testimony in the prosecution of criminals?', 'However, faulty eyewitness identification and testimony can lead to wrongful convictions.']

['Teacher: Can you tell me about the traumatic incident that Jennifer Thompson experienced in 1984?', 'In 1984, Jennifer Thompson, then a 22-year-old college student in North Carolina, was brutally raped at knifepoint.']

['Teacher: How did Jennifer Thompson respond to the traumatic incident?', 'As she was being raped, she tried to memorize every detail of her rapist’s face and physical characteristics, vowing that if she survived, she would help get him convicted.']

["Teacher: How did Jennifer Thompson's identification process take place after the composite sketch was made and the police were involved?", 'After the police were contacted, a composite sketch was made of the suspect, and Jennifer was shown six photos.']

["Teacher: How did Jennifer Thompson's identification process contribute to the investigation after she chose the two photos, one of which was of Ronald Cotton?", 'She chose two, one of which was of Ronald Cotton.']
["What was Jennifer Thompson's initial reaction after looking at the photos for 4-5 minutes?", 'After looking at the photos for 4–5 minutes, she said, “Yeah.']
["What was Jennifer Thompson's reaction to seeing the photo of Ronald Cotton during the identification process?", 'This is the one,” and then she added, “I think this is the guy.”']
['Teacher: How confident was Jennifer Thompson in her identification of Ronald Cotton during the identification process?', 'Positive?”']

["Teacher: Why did the detective reinforce Jennifer Thompson's choice during the identification process?", 'Then she asked the detective if she did OK, and he reinforced her choice by telling her she did great.']

['What can unintentional cues and suggestions by police officers during the identification process lead witnesses to do?', 'These kinds of unintended cues and suggestions by police officers can lead witnesses to identify the wrong suspect.']

["How did Jennifer Thompson's viewing of the lineup of seven men affect the investigation?", 'The district attorney was concerned about her lack of certainty the first time, so she viewed a lineup of seven men.']

["What was the outcome of Jennifer Thompson's viewing of the lineup of seven men?", 'She said she was trying to decide between numbers 4 and 5, finally deciding that Cotton, number 5, “Looks most like him.”']
['What was the age of Jennifer Thompson when she experienced the traumatic incident in 1984?', 'He was 22 years old.']

['Teacher: How confident was Jennifer Thompson about her identification of Ronald Cotton as her rapist by the time the trial began?', 'By the time the trial began, Jennifer Thompson had absolutely no doubt that she was raped by Ronald Cotton.']

["Teacher: What was the effect of Jennifer Thompson's confident identification on the outcome of the trial?", 'She testified at the court hearing, and her testimony was compelling enough that it helped convict him.']

['What are some suggestive police identification procedures that can influence eyewitness identification?', 'Gary Wells and Deah Quinlivan (2009) assert it’s suggestive police identification procedures, such as stacking lineups to make the defendant stand out, telling the witness which person to identify, and confirming witnesses choices by telling them “Good choice,” or “You picked the guy.”']
['Teacher: What was the outcome for Cotton after he was convicted of the rape?', 'After Cotton was convicted of the rape, he was sent to prison for life plus 50 years.']
['Teacher: What led to Cotton being able to get a new trial after 4 years in prison?', 'After 4 years in prison, he was able to get a new trial.']
['Teacher: Who testified against Cotton during his new trial after 4 years in prison?', 'Jennifer Thompson once again testified against him.']
['What was the outcome for Ronald Cotton after his second trial?', 'This time Ronald Cotton was given two life sentences.']

["What was the ultimate result of the DNA evidence in Ronald Cotton's case?", 'After serving 11 years in prison, DNA evidence finally demonstrated that Ronald Cotton did not commit the rape, was innocent, and had served over a decade in prison for a crime he did not commit.']
["Teacher: Why is Ronald Cotton's story unfortunately not unique?", 'Ronald Cotton’s story, unfortunately, is not unique.']

['Teacher: Can you provide some examples of individuals who, like Ronald Cotton, were convicted and placed on death row but later exonerated?', 'There are also people who were convicted and placed on death row, who were later exonerated.']

['What is the purpose or goal of The Innocence Project?', 'The Innocence Project is a non-profit group that works to exonerate falsely convicted people, including those convicted by eyewitness testimony.']
['What are some common factors that contribute to eyewitness misidentification?', 'To learn more, you can visit http://www.innocenceproject.org.']

['Teacher: What specific topic within memory has cognitive psychologist Elizabeth Loftus researched extensively?', 'Cognitive psychologist Elizabeth Loftus has conducted extensive research on memory.']

["Teacher: That's correct! In her research on memory, what are the two types of memories that Elizabeth Loftus has focused on?", 'She has studied false memories as well as recovered memories of childhood sexual abuse.']

['What is the main concept developed by Elizabeth Loftus regarding memory and exposure to additional information?', 'Loftus also developed the misinformation effect paradigm, which holds that after exposure to additional and possibly inaccurate information, a person may misremember the original event.']
["Teacher: What did Loftus argue about an eyewitness's memory of an event?", 'According to Loftus, an eyewitness’s memory of an event is very flexible due to the misinformation effect.']

['Teacher: How did Loftus and John Palmer test the theory of the misinformation effect in their study?', 'To test this theory, Loftus and John Palmer (1974) asked 45 U.S. college students to estimate the speed of cars using different forms of questions.']

['Teacher: What were the results of the study conducted by Loftus and John Palmer regarding the misinformation effect?', 'The participants were shown films of car accidents and were asked to play the role of the eyewitness and describe what happened.']

["Teacher: What effect did the wording of the question have on the participants' estimation of the speed of the cars in the study conducted by Loftus and John Palmer?", 'They were asked, “About how fast were the cars going when they (smashed, collided, bumped, hit, contacted) each other?”']
['Teacher: How did the participants estimate the speed of the cars in the study conducted by Loftus and John Palmer?', 'The participants estimated the speed of the cars based on the verb used.']

["Teacher: How did participants' estimation of the cars' speed differ based on the word they heard?", 'Participants who heard the word “smashed” estimated that the cars were traveling at a much higher speed than participants who heard the word “contacted.”']

["Teacher: What was the effect of the word participants heard on their estimation of the cars' speed?", 'The implied information about speed, based on the verb they heard, had an effect on the participants’ memory of the accident.']

['Teacher: What was the outcome of asking participants about the presence of broken glass in the follow-up question?', 'In a follow-up one week later, participants were asked if they saw any broken glass (none was shown in the accident pictures).']

["What was the difference in the participants' responses regarding the presence of broken glass based on the word they heard?", 'Participants who had been in the “smashed” group were more than twice as likely to indicate that they did remember seeing glass.']

["What did Loftus and Palmer's study demonstrate about the influence of a leading question on participants' memory?", 'Loftus and Palmer demonstrated that a leading question encouraged them to not only remember the cars were going faster, but to also falsely remember that they saw broken glass.']

['Teacher: What have other researchers described about the recall of false memories in relation to whole events?', 'Other researchers have described how whole events, not just words, can be falsely recalled, even when they did not happen.']

['Teacher: Why is the idea of repressed memories of traumatic events controversial in the field of psychology?', 'The idea that memories of traumatic events could be repressed has been a theme in the field of psychology, beginning with Sigmund Freud, and the controversy surrounding the idea continues today.']
['Teacher: What is the term used to describe the recollection of false autobiographical memories?', 'Recall of false autobiographical memories is called false memory syndrome.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why false memory syndrome has received a lot of publicity, particularly in cases where there are no independent witnesses to the alleged abuse?', 'This syndrome has received a lot of publicity, particularly as it relates to memories of events that do not have independent witnesses—often the only witnesses to the abuse are the perpetrator and the victim (e.g., sexual abuse).']

['Teacher: What is the stance of those who have recovered memories of childhood abuse years after it occurred in the controversies over repressed and recovered memories?', 'On one side of the debate are those who have recovered memories of childhood abuse years after it occurred.']

['Teacher: Why do some researchers argue that individuals with recovered memories of childhood abuse may have locked those memories away?', 'These researchers argue that some children’s experiences have been so traumatizing and distressing that they must lock those memories away in order to lead some semblance of a normal life.']

['Teacher: What are some techniques that researchers believe can help in the recall of repressed memories of childhood abuse?', 'They believe that repressed memories can be locked away for decades and later recalled intact through hypnosis and guided imagery techniques (Devilly, 2007).']

['Teacher: What does the research suggest about the prevalence of adults having no memory of childhood sexual abuse?', 'Research suggests that having no memory of childhood sexual abuse is quite common in adults.']

['Teacher: Can you provide any specific evidence or examples from the study conducted by Briere and Conte (1993) that supports the notion that forgetting childhood sexual abuse experiences is common among adults?', 'For instance, one large-scale study conducted by John Briere and Jon Conte (1993) revealed that 59% of 450 men and women who were receiving treatment for sexual abuse that had occurred before age 18 had forgotten their experiences.']

['Teacher: What is one possible consequence suggested by Ross Cheit (2007) for adults who repress memories of childhood sexual abuse?', 'Ross Cheit (2007) suggested that repressing these memories created psychological distress in adulthood.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the purpose or goal of the Recovered Memory Project, as mentioned by Ross Cheit and Devilly (2007)?', 'The Recovered Memory Project was created so that victims of childhood sexual abuse can recall these memories and allow the healing process to begin (Cheit, 2007; Devilly, 2007).']

['Teacher: What are some therapeutic techniques that Loftus challenges in terms of memory recovery?', 'Loftus is not saying that childhood sexual abuse doesn’t happen, but she does question whether or not those memories are accurate, and she is skeptical of the questioning process used to access these memories, given that even the slightest suggestion from the therapist can lead to misinformation effects.']

['Teacher: Can you provide more examples or studies that demonstrate the potential for misinformation effects in memory retrieval?', 'For example, researchers Stephen Ceci and Maggie Brucks (1993, 1995) asked three-year-old children to use an anatomically correct doll to show where their pediatricians had touched them during an exam.']

['Teacher: How does the study by Stephen Ceci and Maggie Brucks demonstrate the potential for misinformation effects in memory retrieval?', 'Fifty-five percent of the children pointed to the genital/anal area on the dolls, even when they had not received any form of genital exam.']

['Teacher: What has Loftus challenged regarding the recovery of repressed memories of traumatic events?', 'Ever since Loftus published her first studies on the suggestibility of eyewitness testimony in the 1970s, social scientists, police officers, therapists, and legal practitioners have been aware of the flaws in interview practices.']

['Teacher: How does Loftus challenge the idea of individuals recovering repressed memories of traumatic events through therapeutic techniques such as hypnosis and age regression?', 'Consequently, steps have been taken to decrease suggestibility of witnesses.']
['Teacher: How does Loftus suggest modifying the way witnesses are questioned in order to decrease suggestibility?', 'One way is to modify how witnesses are questioned.']

['Teacher: How can modifying the language used by interviewers help children accurately recall what happened and who was involved in traumatic events?', 'When interviewers use neutral and less leading language, children more accurately recall what happened and who was involved (Goodman, 2006; Pipe, 1996; Pipe, Lamb, Orbach, & Esplin, 2004).']

['Teacher: How does Loftus recommend modifying the process of conducting police lineups to decrease suggestibility and enhance accurate recall?', 'Another change is in how police lineups are conducted.']

['Teacher: How can using a blind photo lineup instead of a traditional lineup enhance accurate recall and decrease suggestibility, according to Loftus?', 'It’s recommended that a blind photo lineup be used.']

['Teacher: How can using a blind photo lineup prevent potential leading cues from being given during the identification process, according to Loftus?', 'This way the person administering the lineup doesn’t know which photo belongs to the suspect, minimizing the possibility of giving leading cues.']

['Teacher: How does informing jurors about the possibility of misidentification contribute to the goal of decreasing suggestibility and enhancing accurate recall, as recommended by Loftus?', 'Additionally, judges in some states now inform jurors about the possibility of misidentification.']

['Teacher: How does suppressing unreliable eyewitness testimony contribute to the goal of decreasing suggestibility and enhancing accurate recall, as recommended by Loftus?', 'Judges can also suppress eyewitness testimony if they deem it unreliable.']
['Teacher: According to Robert Louis Stevenson, what kind of memory did he have?', '“I’ve a grand memory for forgetting,” quipped Robert Louis Stevenson.']
['What did Robert Louis Stevenson mean when he said, "I\'ve a grand memory for forgetting"?', 'Forgetting refers to loss of information from long-term memory.']
['Why did Robert Louis Stevenson say "I\'ve a grand memory for forgetting"?', 'We all forget things, like a loved one’s birthday, someone’s name, or where we put our car keys.']
['What are some examples of things that people commonly forget?', 'As you’ve come to see, memory is fragile, and forgetting can be frustrating and even embarrassing.']
['What perspectives on forgetting will we be looking at to answer this question?', 'To answer this question, we will look at several perspectives on forgetting.']
['Teacher: Can you explain what encoding failure means in relation to memory loss?', 'Sometimes memory loss happens before the actual memory process begins, which is encoding failure.']

['Teacher: How does the analogy of trying to find a book on your e-reader that you never purchased and downloaded relate to encoding failure?', 'This would be like trying to find a book on your e-reader that you never actually purchased and downloaded.']

['Teacher: How does effortful encoding relate to encoding failure?', 'Often, in order to remember something, we must pay attention to the details and actively work to process the information (effortful encoding).']
["Teacher: Why does encoding failure often occur in cases when we don't pay attention to the details and actively process the information?", 'Lots of times we don’t do this.']

['Teacher: How does the common occurrence of seeing a penny but not remembering its specific details exemplify encoding failure?', 'For instance, think of how many times in your life you’ve seen a penny.']

['Teacher: What does the research conducted by Raymond Nickerson and Marilyn Adams (1979) reveal about the knowledge of most Americans regarding the specific details of a penny?', 'When researchers Raymond Nickerson and Marilyn Adams (1979) asked this question, they found that most Americans don’t know which one it is.']

['Teacher: How does encoding failure contribute to the inability of most Americans to accurately recognize and remember the specific details of a penny according to the research conducted by Raymond Nickerson and Marilyn Adams (1979)?', 'The reason is most likely encoding failure.']
['Teacher: What can be done to prevent or reduce encoding failure in regards to remembering the specific details of a penny?', 'Most of us never encode the details of the penny.']
['What is the primary reason that most of us never encode the details of the penny?', 'We only encode enough information to be able to distinguish it from other coins.']
['What happens if the information is not encoded into our long-term memory?', 'If we don’t encode the information, then it’s not in our long-term memory, so we will not be able to remember it.']

['Teacher: What are the seven ways that Psychologist Daniel Schacter (2001) identifies as factors contributing to memory errors?', 'Psychologist Daniel Schacter (2001), a well-known memory researcher, offers seven ways our memories fail us.']

['What are the three groups that Psychologist Daniel Schacter categorizes the seven sins of memory into?', 'He calls them the seven sins of memory and categorizes them into three groups: forgetting, distortion, and intrusion.']

['Teacher: What does the term "transience" refer to in the context of memory errors?', 'Let’s look at the first sin of the forgetting errors: transience, which means that memories can fade over time.']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how transience, as a memory error, can cause memories to fade over time?', 'Here’s an example of how this happens.']

["Teacher: How can the fading of memories over time affect Nathan's ability to recall the events or characters from the novel To Kill a Mockingbird?", 'Nathan’s English teacher has assigned his students to read the novel To Kill a Mockingbird.']

["Teacher: What is the impact of transience on Nathan's ability to recall the events or characters from the novel To Kill a Mockingbird?", 'Nathan comes home from school and tells his mom he has to read this book for class.']

["Teacher: How might Nathan's mother's reaction to his assigned reading impact his ability to recall the events or characters from the novel To Kill a Mockingbird?", '“Oh, I loved that book!” she says.']

["What type of memory error can Nathan's mother's hesitation when trying to recall the events or characters from the novel To Kill a Mockingbird be an example of?", 'Nathan asks her what the book is about, and after some hesitation she says, “Well . . .']

["What term would describe Nathan's mother's hesitation and inability to recall the events or characters from the novel To Kill a Mockingbird?", 'I know I read the book in high school, and I remember that one of the main characters is named Scout, and her father is an attorney, but I honestly don’t remember anything else.”']

["What memory error is Nathan's mother experiencing when she is unable to recall the plot of the novel To Kill a Mockingbird?", 'Nathan wonders if his mother actually read the book, and his mother is surprised she can’t recall the plot.']
['Why does unused information tend to fade with the passage of time, causing storage decay?', 'What is going on here is storage decay: unused information tends to fade with the passage of time.']
['Teacher: Who was the psychologist that analyzed the process of memorization in 1885?', 'In 1885, German psychologist Hermann Ebbinghaus analyzed the process of memorization.']
['What method did Hermann Ebbinghaus use to analyze the process of memorization?', 'First, he memorized lists of nonsense syllables.']
['Teacher: How did Hermann Ebbinghaus measure his retention of the lists of nonsense syllables?', 'Then he measured how much he learned (retained) when he attempted to relearn each list.']

['Teacher: What did Hermann Ebbinghaus discover about the retention of lists of nonsense syllables when he tested himself over different periods of time?', 'He tested himself over different periods of time from 20 minutes later to 30 days later.']
['What does the forgetting curve represent?', 'The result is his famous forgetting curve.']
