['How does the forgetting curve illustrate the process of memory decay over time?', 'Due to storage decay, an average person will lose 50% of the memorized information after 20 minutes and 70% of the information after 24 hours (Ebbinghaus, 1885/1964).']
['What is the impact of time on the decay of memory according to the forgetting curve?', 'Your memory for new information decays quickly and then eventually levels out.']
['Teacher: Have you ever encountered any memory errors before?', 'You probably answered yes to at least one, if not all, of these examples—but don’t worry, you are not alone.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of absentmindedness that you have personally experienced?', 'We are all prone to committing the memory error known as absentmindedness, which describes lapses in memory caused by breaks in attention or our focus being somewhere else.']
['Teacher: Can you recall the name of the actor in the movie Oblivion?', '“I just streamed this movie called Oblivion, and it had that famous actor in it.']

['Teacher: Who is the actor that appeared in the movie Oblivion and has been in other popular movies like The Shawshank Redemption and The Dark Knight trilogy?', 'He’s been in all of those movies, like The Shawshank Redemption and The Dark Knight trilogy.']
['Teacher: What other movies has the actor from Oblivion been in besides The Shawshank Redemption and The Dark Knight trilogy?', 'I think he’s even won an Oscar.']
['What is the name of the actor from Oblivion who has won an Oscar?', 'Oh gosh, I can picture his face in my mind, and hear his distinctive voice, but I just can’t think of his name!']
["What strategies have you used in the past to help you remember something when you're having trouble recalling it?", 'This is going to bug me until I can remember it!”']

['What steps can you take to minimize absentmindedness and improve your memory recall in situations like this?', 'This particular error can be so frustrating because you have the information right on the tip of your tongue.']

['What are some ways you can overcome the error known as blocking and access stored information more easily?', 'If so, you’ve committed the error known as blocking: you can’t access stored information.']

['Teacher: What are the three errors of distortion discussed in the passage on absentmindedness?', 'Now let’s take a look at the three errors of distortion: misattribution, suggestibility, and bias.']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example of misattribution happening in everyday life?', 'Misattribution happens when you confuse the source of your information.']

["Teacher: Can you explain how misattribution could be a factor in Alejandra's experience of watching the Hobbit movie with Lucia?", 'Let’s say Alejandra was dating Lucia and they saw the first Hobbit movie together.']

["Teacher: How might misattribution play a role in Alejandra's experience of watching the second Hobbit movie with someone else after her breakup with Lucia?", 'Then they broke up and Alejandra saw the second Hobbit movie with someone else.']
['What could Alejandra potentially misattribute when she watches the second Hobbit movie with Lucia after they get back together?', 'Later that year, Alejandra and Lucia get back together.']

['What error of distortion is Alejandra potentially demonstrating in her statement to Lucia about watching the second Hobbit movie together?', 'One day, they are discussing how the Hobbit books and movies are different and Alejandra says to Lucia, “I loved watching the second movie with you and seeing you jump out of your seat during that super scary part.”']

["What is Alejandra's error in her statement about watching the second Hobbit movie together with Lucia?", 'When Lucia responded with a puzzled and then angry look, Alejandra realized she’d committed the error of misattribution.']
['Teacher: Can you share an instance when Donald Thomson experienced absentmindedness?', 'This is exactly what happened to Donald Thomson.']
['Teacher: Can you explain to me what suggestibility refers to in the context of absentmindedness?', 'The second distortion error is suggestibility.']

['Teacher: How is suggestibility similar to misattribution in terms of the involvement of false memories, and how is it different?', 'Suggestibility is similar to misattribution, since it also involves false memories, but it’s different.']

['What is an example of how suggestibility is different from misattribution in terms of the creation of false memories?', 'With misattribution you create the false memory entirely on your own, which is what the victim did in the Donald Thomson case above.']

['How does suggestibility differ from misattribution in terms of the source of the false memory?', 'With suggestibility, it comes from someone else, such as a therapist or police interviewer asking leading questions of a witness during an interview.']
['Teacher: How can memories be affected by bias?', 'Memories can also be affected by bias, which is the final distortion error.']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how bias can lead to distorted memories?', 'Schacter (2001) says that your feelings and view of the world can actually distort your memory of past events.']
['What are some examples of different types of bias that can affect our memories?', 'There are several types of bias:']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example of when you have experienced absentmindedness?', 'Stereotypical bias involves racial and gender biases.']

['Asian American and European American names such as Timothy and Matthew to be associated with the occupation doctor.', 'For example, when Asian American and European American research participants were presented with a list of names, they more frequently incorrectly remembered typical African American names such as Jamal and Tyrone to be associated with the occupation basketball player, and they more frequently incorrectly remembered typical']

['What were the names that Asian American and European American research participants more frequently incorrectly remembered to be associated with the occupation of politician?', 'White names such as Greg and Howard to be associated with the occupation of politician (Payne, Jacoby, & Lambert, 2004).']
['What is the bias associated with enhancing our memories of the past called?', 'Egocentric bias involves enhancing our memories of the past (Payne et al., 2004).']
['What does hindsight bias involve?', 'Hindsight bias happens when we think an outcome was inevitable after the fact.']
['What is another name for the "I knew it all along" phenomenon?', 'This is the “I knew it all along” phenomenon.']
['What is the factor that contributes to hindsight bias?', 'The reconstructive nature of memory contributes to hindsight bias (Carli, 1999).']

['What is the term used to describe the phenomenon of remembering events that never actually happened, but seem to confirm our belief that we knew the outcome all along?', 'We remember untrue events that seem to confirm that we knew the outcome all along.']

['Teacher: What is it called when you can\'t "get something out of your head" and it affects your ability to concentrate on other things?', 'When you keep remembering something, to the point where you can’t “get it out of your head” and it interferes with your ability to concentrate on other things, it is called persistence.']
['What is Schacter’s seventh and last memory error called?', 'It’s Schacter’s seventh and last memory error.']

['Teacher: What is the term used to describe the involuntary recall of unwanted memories, especially unpleasant ones, which is considered a failure of our memory system?', 'It’s actually a failure of our memory system because we involuntarily recall unwanted memories, particularly unpleasant ones.']

['What is the term used to describe the experience of being unable to concentrate on work due to continually remembering a horrific car accident scene?', 'For instance, you witness a horrific car accident on the way to work one morning, and you can’t concentrate on work because you keep remembering the scene.']
['Teacher: What phenomenon occurs when stored information in our memory becomes temporarily inaccessible?', 'Sometimes information is stored in our memory, but for some reason it is inaccessible.']

['Teacher: Can you explain proactive interference and retroactive interference in more detail?', 'This is known as interference, and there are two types: proactive interference and retroactive interference.']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example of retroactive interference?', 'These are examples of proactive interference: when old information hinders the recall of newly learned information.']

['Teacher: Can you clarify the relationship between interference and the accessibility of stored information in our memory?', 'Retroactive interference happens when information learned more recently hinders the recall of older information.']

['Teacher: How does the phenomenon of interference affect the accessibility of stored information in our memory, according to the passage?', 'For example, this week you are studying about memory and learn about the Ebbinghaus forgetting curve.']

["Teacher: How does the example of studying Ebbinghaus's work and then studying Erikson's theory relate to the concept of interference?", "Next week you study lifespan development and learn about Erikson's theory of psychosocial development, but thereafter have trouble remembering Ebbinghaus's work because you can only remember Erickson's theory."]

['Teacher: Why do most people want to improve their memories?', 'Most of us suffer from memory failures of one kind or another, and most of us would like to improve our memories so that we don’t forget where we put the car keys or, more importantly, the material we need to know for an exam.']

['Teacher: What are some reasons why improving our memories can be beneficial in daily life?', 'In this section, we’ll look at some ways to help you remember better, and at some strategies for more effective studying.']

['Teacher: How can you ensure that information goes from short-term memory to long-term memory?', 'To help make sure information goes from short-term memory to long-term memory, you can use memory-enhancing strategies.']

['Teacher: Can you explain what the memory-enhancing strategy of rehearsal entails?', 'One strategy is rehearsal, or the conscious repetition of information to be remembered (Craik & Watkins, 1973).']

['Teacher: How does the memory-enhancing strategy of rehearsal help improve the transfer of information from short-term memory to long-term memory?', 'Think about how you learned your multiplication tables as a child.']

['Teacher: How does rehearsing multiplication tables as a child help improve the transfer of information from short-term memory to long-term memory?', 'You may recall that 6 x 6 = 36, 6 x 7 = 42, and 6 x 8 = 48.']
['Teacher: How does memorizing multiplication facts using rehearsal make it easier to recall them later on?', 'Memorizing these facts is rehearsal.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the memory-enhancing strategy of chunking and how it helps in organizing information?', 'Another strategy is chunking: you organize information into manageable bits or chunks (Bodie, Powers, & Fitch-Hauser, 2006).']
['Why is chunking considered a memory-enhancing strategy?', 'Chunking is useful when trying to remember information like dates and phone numbers.']
['What is an example of how chunking can be used to enhance memory?', 'Instead of trying to remember 5205550467, you remember the number as 520-555-0467.']

['Teacher: How does using the chunking strategy relate to the rehearsal strategy in enhancing memory?', 'So, if you met an interesting person at a party and you wanted to remember his phone number, you would naturally chunk it, and you could repeat the number over and over, which is the rehearsal strategy.']

['Teacher: Can you explain elaborative rehearsal and how it can enhance memory?', 'You could also enhance memory by using elaborative rehearsal: a technique in which you think about the meaning of new information and its relation to knowledge already stored in your memory (Tigner, 1999).']
['Teacher: How does elaborative rehearsal enhance memory?', 'Elaborative rehearsal involves both linking the information to knowledge already stored and repeating the information.']

['Teacher: Can you provide another example of how you can use elaborative rehearsal to enhance memory?', 'For example, in this case, you could remember that 520 is an area code for Arizona and the person you met is from Arizona.']
["How can elaborative rehearsal be used to remember someone's phone number?", 'This would help you better remember the 520 prefix.']
['What happens if the information is retained?', 'If the information is retained, it goes into long-term memory.']
['Teacher: What are mnemonic devices?', 'Mnemonic devices are memory aids that help us organize information for encoding.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a mnemonic device that can be used to remember steps, stages, phases, or parts of a system?', 'They are especially useful when we want to recall larger bits of information such as steps, stages, phases, and parts of a system (Bellezza, 1981).']

['Teacher: How can Brian use a mnemonic device to remember the order of the planets in the solar system?', 'Brian needs to learn the order of the planets in the solar system, but he’s having a hard time remembering the correct order.']
["Teacher: What is Kelly's mnemonic device suggestion to help Brian remember the order of the planets in the solar system?", 'His friend Kelly suggests a mnemonic device that can help him remember.']

['Teacher: What does the mnemonic device "Mr. VEM J. SUN" stand for in order to remember the order of the planets in the solar system?', 'Kelly tells Brian to simply remember the name Mr. VEM J. SUN, and he can easily recall the correct order of the planets: Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune.']

['What are some other examples of situations where mnemonic devices can be helpful?', 'You might use a mnemonic device to help you remember someone’s name, a mathematical formula, or the order of mathematical operations.']
['Teacher: According to Phil Dunphy, what makes it easier to remember names?', 'It seems the more vivid or unusual the mnemonic, the easier it is to remember.']
['What does the student say is the key to using any mnemonic successfully?', 'The key to using any mnemonic successfully is to find a strategy that works for you.']
['Teacher: How does Phil Dunphy from Modern Family remember names?', 'Some other strategies that are used to improve memory include expressive writing and saying words aloud.']

['Teacher: Can you give an example of how expressive writing can help boost your memory?', 'Expressive writing helps boost your short-term memory, particularly if you write about a traumatic experience in your life.']

['Teacher: What was the frequency at which participants in the study conducted by Masao Yogo and Shuji Fujihara engaged in expressive writing?', 'Masao Yogo and Shuji Fujihara (2008) had participants write for 20-minute intervals several times per month.']

['Teacher: What were the different topics that the participants in the study were instructed to write about?', 'The participants were instructed to write about a traumatic experience, their best possible future selves, or a trivial topic.']

['Teacher: Why did the researchers find that the writing task increased short-term memory capacity only for the participants who wrote about traumatic experiences?', 'The researchers found that this simple writing task increased short-term memory capacity after five weeks, but only for the participants who wrote about traumatic experiences.']

['Teacher: What are some other potential explanations that psychologists have suggested for why expressive writing helps boost memory?', 'Psychologists can’t explain why this writing task works, but it does.']
['Teacher: How did Phil Dunphy explain his method of remembering names on Modern Family?', 'Simply say them out loud to yourself.']

['Teacher: According to a series of studies (MacLeod, Gopie, Hourihan, Neary, & Ozubko, 2010), why does saying a word out loud improve your memory for the word?', 'A series of studies (MacLeod, Gopie, Hourihan, Neary, & Ozubko, 2010) found that saying a word out loud improves your memory for the word because it increases the word’s distinctiveness.']
['What did the series of studies find about mouthing the words instead of saying them out loud?', 'This technique works equally well if you just mouth the words.']
["How much did using these techniques increase participants' memory for the words?", 'Using these techniques increased participants’ memory for the words by more than 10%.']
['What is one practical application of using these techniques for improving memory?', 'These techniques can also be used to help you study.']

['Teacher: What do the strategies and suggestions mentioned in this chapter aim to help you with?', 'Based on the information presented in this chapter, here are some strategies and suggestions to help you hone your study techniques.']
['What is the importance of finding the right study techniques for each individual?', 'The key with any of these strategies is to figure out what works best for you.']
['What is one effective study technique students can use?', 'Use elaborative rehearsal:']

['Teacher: Can you explain how elaborative rehearsal helps with information retention and long-term memory?', 'In a famous article, Fergus Craik and Robert Lockhart (1972) discussed their belief that information we process more deeply goes into long-term memory.']
['Teacher: What does the levels of processing theory propose about the relationship between deep processing and long-term memory?', 'Their theory is called levels of processing.']

['Why does deep processing and linking information to other information and memories aid in information retention and long-term memory?', 'If we want to remember a piece of information, we should think about it more deeply and link it to other information and memories to make it more meaningful.']

['What is one example you can provide of using deep processing and linking information to aid in information retention and long-term memory?', 'For example, if we are trying to remember that the hippocampus is involved with memory processing, we might envision a hippopotamus with excellent memory and then we could better remember the hippocampus.']
['How does applying the self-reference effect help with information retention and long-term memory?', 'Apply the self-reference effect:']

['Why is it more beneficial to make the material you are trying to memorize personally meaningful to you during the process of elaborative rehearsal?', 'As you go through the process of elaborative rehearsal, it would be even more beneficial to make the material you are trying to memorize personally meaningful to you.']

['What are some ways in which students can make the material they are trying to memorize personally meaningful to them during the process of elaborative rehearsal?', 'In other words, make use of the self-reference effect.']
['How can writing notes in your own words help you make the material personally meaningful to you during the process of elaborative rehearsal?', 'Write notes in your own words.']
['What are some strategies you can use to write notes in your own words during the process of elaborative rehearsal?', 'Write definitions from the text, and then rewrite them in your own words.']

['What are some other strategies you can use to make the material personally meaningful to you during the process of elaborative rehearsal?', 'Relate the material to something you have already learned for another class, or think how you can apply the concepts to your own life.']

['How does building a web of retrieval cues help with accessing and remembering the material during the process of elaborative rehearsal?', 'When you do this, you are building a web of retrieval cues that will help you access the material when you want to remember it.']

['Why is it more effective to study across time in short durations rather than cramming all the material at once?', 'Use distributed practice: Study across time in short durations rather than trying to cram it all in at once.']
['Why does studying across time in short durations allow for memory consolidation?', 'Memory consolidation takes time, and studying across time allows time for memories to consolidate.']

['What are some negative effects of cramming and why is it less effective for memory consolidation?', 'In addition, cramming can cause the links between concepts to become so active that you get stuck in a link, and it prevents you from accessing the rest of the information that you learned.']

['What are some strategies you can use to rehearse and review the material over time, in spaced and organized study sessions?', 'Rehearse, rehearse, rehearse: Review the material over time, in spaced and organized study sessions.']

['What are some additional strategies you can use to rehearse and review the material over time, in spaced and organized study sessions?', 'Organize and study your notes, and take practice quizzes/exams.']

['How does linking the new information to other information you already know well help with rehearsing and reviewing the material over time, in spaced and organized study sessions?', 'Link the new information to other information you already know well.']

['What is a more efficient strategy for studying than highlighting?', 'Study efficiently: Students are great highlighters, but highlighting is not very efficient because students spend too much time studying the things they already learned.']
['Why is using index cards a more efficient strategy for studying than highlighting?', 'Instead of highlighting, use index cards.']

['How can sorting the index cards into ones you got right and ones you got wrong help with studying efficiently?', 'When you study, separate your cards into those you got right and those you got wrong.']
['What should you do with the index cards you got wrong when studying efficiently?', 'Study the ones you got wrong and keep sorting.']
['What should you do with the index cards you got right when studying efficiently?', 'Eventually, all your cards will be in the pile you answered correctly.']
['What is one potential challenge that students may face when studying over a long period of time?', 'Be aware of interference:']

['What is one strategy you can use to reduce the likelihood of interference while studying over a long period of time?', 'To reduce the likelihood of interference, study during a quiet time without interruptions or distractions (like television or music).']
['How can staying physically active while studying help reduce the likelihood of interference?', 'Keep moving:']

['What does research suggest about the relationship between regular aerobic exercise and memory?', 'Research suggests that regular aerobic exercise (anything that gets your heart rate elevated) is beneficial for memory (van Praag, 2008).']

['How does regular aerobic exercise promote memory and learning?', 'Aerobic exercise promotes neurogenesis: the growth of new brain cells in the hippocampus, an area of the brain known to play a role in memory and learning.']
['Why is getting enough sleep important for effective studying and memory retention?', 'Get enough sleep:']
['Why is it important for your brain to still be at work while you are sleeping?', 'While you are sleeping, your brain is still at work.']

['What happens to the information in your brain during sleep that helps with memory consolidation?', 'During sleep the brain organizes and consolidates information to be stored in long-term memory (Abel & Bäuml, 2013).']

['Teacher: How can mnemonic devices help with memory consolidation and effective studying?\nStudent: Mnemonic devices can help with memory consolidation and effective studying by providing an organized and memorable way to encode and retrieve information.', 'Make use of mnemonic devices:']

['What are some examples of mnemonic devices that students can use to aid in memory consolidation and effective studying?', 'As you learned earlier in this chapter, mnemonic devices often help us to remember and recall information.']
['What does the acronym mnemonic device stand for?', 'There are different types of mnemonic devices, such as the acronym.']

['What is one example of an acronym mnemonic device that can aid in memory consolidation and effective studying?', 'An acronym is a word formed by the first letter of each of the words you want to remember.']

['What is an example of an acronym mnemonic device that can help you remember the names of all five Great Lakes?', 'For example, even if you live near one, you might have difficulty recalling the names of all five Great Lakes.']

['What does the acronym HOMES represent when using it as a mnemonic device to remember the names of the five Great Lakes?', 'HOMES is an acronym that represents Huron, Ontario, Michigan, Erie, and Superior: the five Great Lakes.']

['What is an example of an acrostic mnemonic device that can aid in memory consolidation and effective studying?', 'Another type of mnemonic device is an acrostic: you make a phrase of all the first letters of the words.']

['What is an example of an acrostic mnemonic device that can help you remember the order of mathematical operations?', 'For example, if you are taking a math test and you are having difficulty remembering the order of operations, recalling the following sentence will help you: “Please Excuse My Dear Aunt Sally,” because the order of mathematical operations is Parentheses, Exponents, Multiplication, Division, Addition, Subtraction.']

['What is an example of a jingle mnemonic device that can aid in memory consolidation and effective studying?', 'There also are jingles, which are rhyming tunes that contain key words related to the concept, such as i before e, except after c.']
['Teacher: What does William Wordsworth mean when he says, "the child is father of the man"?', 'In this poem, William Wordsworth writes, “the child is father of the man.”']

['Teacher: How does Wordsworth suggest that a person\'s experiences in childhood shape them as an adult in the poem "the child is father of the man"?', 'Wordsworth might be suggesting that the person he is as an adult depends largely on the experiences he had in childhood.']
["How might childhood experiences influence a person's development and identity as an adult?", 'Consider the following questions:']

['Teacher: What is the main focus of developmental psychologists?', 'These are the types of questions developmental psychologists try to answer, by studying how humans change and grow from conception through childhood, adolescence, adulthood, and death.']

['Teacher: How do developmental psychologists view the process of development?', 'They view development as a lifelong process that can be studied scientifically across three developmental domains—physical, cognitive, and psychosocial development.']

['Teacher: Can you give examples of specific areas that fall under physical development?', 'Physical development involves growth and changes in the body and brain, the senses, motor skills, and health and wellness.']

['Teacher: Can you provide examples of specific areas that fall under psychosocial development?', 'Cognitive development involves learning, attention, memory, language, thinking, reasoning, and creativity.']
['Teacher: Can you give examples of specific areas that fall under cognitive development?', 'Psychosocial development involves emotions, personality, and social relationships.']
['Teacher: Why is it important to study the three domains of lifespan development?', 'We refer to these domains throughout the chapter.']
['Teacher: What are the three domains discussed in the passage?', 'Across these three domains—physical, cognitive, and psychosocial—the normative approach to development is also discussed.']
['Teacher: Can you explain further what the normative approach to development entails in the three domains?', 'This approach asks, “What is normal development?”']

['Teacher: How did normative psychologists determine norms for developmental milestones in each of the three domains?', 'In the early decades of the 20th century, normative psychologists studied large numbers of children at various ages to determine norms (i.e., average ages) of when most children reach specific developmental milestones in each of the three domains (Gesell, 1933, 1939, 1940; Gesell & Ilg, 1946; Hall, 1904).']

['Can you provide some examples of developmental milestones in each of the three domains?', 'Although children develop at slightly different rates, we can use these age-related averages as general guidelines to compare children with same-age peers to determine the approximate ages they should reach specific normative events called developmental milestones (e.g., crawling, walking, writing, dressing, naming colors, speaking in sentences, and starting puberty).']

['Teacher: Can you explain the concept of normative events and how they may vary across different cultures?', 'Not all normative events are universal, meaning they are not experienced by all individuals across all cultures.']

['Teacher: How do normative events like puberty differ from social milestones in terms of their universality across cultures?', 'Biological milestones, such as puberty, tend to be universal, but social milestones, such as the age when children begin formal schooling, are not necessarily universal; instead, they affect most individuals in a particular culture (Gesell & Ilg, 1946).']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how social milestones, such as the age when children start school, can differ between developed and developing countries?', 'For example, in developed countries children begin school around 5 or 6 years old, but in developing countries, like Nigeria, children often enter school at an advanced age, if at all (Huebler, 2005; United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization [UNESCO], 2013).']

['Teacher: How can we gain a better understanding of the normative approach in lifespan development?', 'To better understand the normative approach, imagine two new mothers, Louisa and Kimberly, who are close friends and have children around the same age.']

["Teacher: How can the normative approach help us analyze the development of Louisa's and Kimberly's children at their respective ages?", 'Louisa’s daughter is 14 months old, and Kimberly’s son is 12 months old.']

["Teacher: How does the normative approach help us interpret and compare the walking milestone of Louisa's and Kimberly's children?", 'According to the normative approach, the average age a child starts to walk is 12 months.']
["Teacher: How might we interpret Louisa's daughter's delayed walking milestone in relation to the normative approach?", 'However, at 14 months Louisa’s daughter still isn’t walking.']

["Teacher: What advice would you give Louisa based on the normative approach to help her understand her daughter's delayed walking milestone?", 'She tells Kimberly she is worried that something might be wrong with her baby.']

["Teacher: How can we use the normative approach to help Louisa understand and address her concerns about her daughter's delayed walking milestone, compared to Kimberly's son?", 'Kimberly is surprised because her son started walking when he was only 10 months old.']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example of one theoretical approach in developmental psychology?', 'There are many different theoretical approaches regarding human development.']

['What is the main focus of developmental psychology?', 'As we evaluate them in this chapter, recall that developmental psychology focuses on how people change, and keep in mind that all the approaches that we present in this chapter address questions of change:']
['Teacher: How does continuous development view the process of development?', 'Continuous development views development as a cumulative process, gradually improving on existing skills.']
['Teacher: How does continuous development differ from discontinuous development in terms of the pace of change?', 'With this type of development, there is gradual change.']

['Teacher: Can you give me another example of continuous development where skills are gradually improved over time?', 'Consider, for example, a child’s physical growth: adding inches to height year by year.']
['What is the main belief of theorists who view development as discontinuous?', 'In contrast, theorists who view development as discontinuous believe that development takes place in unique stages:']
['Teacher: At what age or time do theorists who view development as discontinuous believe that development occurs?', 'It occurs at specific times or ages.']

['Teacher: How does the pace of change in discontinuous development differ from continuous development?', 'With this type of development, the change is more sudden, such as an infant’s ability to conceive object permanence.']
['Teacher: What do stage theories hold in regards to the sequence of development?', 'Stage theories hold that the sequence of development is universal.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example to support the claim made by stage theories regarding the sequence of development?', 'For example, in cross-cultural studies of language development, children from around the world reach language milestones in a similar sequence (Gleitman & Newport, 1995).']
['Teacher: What does the example of infants cooing before babbling across cultures suggest about the sequence of language development?', 'Infants in all cultures coo before they babble.']
['Teacher: At what age do infants typically utter their first word?', 'They begin babbling at about the same age and utter their first word around 12 months old.']

['Teacher: How does the concept of living in diverse contexts relate to the claim made by stage theories about the universal sequence of development?', 'Yet we live in diverse contexts that have a unique effect on each of us.']

['Teacher: What evidence suggests that motor development may not follow a universal sequence for all children?', 'For example, researchers once believed that motor development follows one course for all children regardless of culture.']

['Teacher: How do child care practices in different cultures affect the achievement of developmental milestones such as sitting, crawling, and walking?', 'However, child care practices vary by culture, and different practices have been found to accelerate or inhibit achievement of developmental milestones such as sitting, crawling, and walking (Karasik, Adolph, Tamis-LeMonda, & Bornstein, 2010).']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example to illustrate the concept of one course of development or many?', 'For instance, let’s look at the Aché society in Paraguay.']
['What does the Aché society in Paraguay spend a significant amount of time doing?', 'They spend a significant amount of time foraging in forests.']

['Teacher: Why do Aché mothers rarely put their young children down while foraging in the forest?', 'While foraging, Aché mothers carry their young children, rarely putting them down in order to protect them from getting hurt in the forest.']
['What is one potential consequence of Aché mothers rarely putting their young children down while foraging in the forest?', 'Consequently, their children walk much later:']

['What is the typical age at which infants in Western cultures begin to walk?', 'They walk around 23–25 months old, in comparison to infants in Western cultures who begin to walk around 12 months old.']

['What is one potential reason for the difference in motor skills between Aché children and U.S. children of the same age?', 'However, as Aché children become older, they are allowed more freedom to move about, and by about age 9, their motor skills surpass those of U.S. children of the same age: Aché children are able to climb trees up to 25 feet tall and use machetes to chop their way through the forest (Kaplan & Dove, 1987).']

['What does the example of Aché children climbing trees and using machetes suggest about the influence of culture on development?', 'As you can see, our development is influenced by multiple contexts, so the timing of basic motor functions may vary across cultures.']
['What is the impact of cultural influence on the timing of basic motor functions across different societies?', 'However, the functions themselves are present in all societies.']
['Teacher: What is the term used in psychology to refer to the debate between nature and nurture?', 'This longstanding question is known in psychology as the nature versus nurture debate.']

['Teacher: Can you provide some examples of the biological factors that contribute to our personalities and traits in the context of the nature versus nurture debate?', 'It seeks to understand how our personalities and traits are the product of our genetic makeup and biological factors, and how they are shaped by our environment, including our guardians, peers, and culture.']

['Teacher: What factors determine the genetic traits we inherit from our parents, such as eye color, height, and personality traits?', 'We are all born with specific genetic traits inherited from our parents, such as eye color, height, and certain personality traits.']
['What is the term used to describe the interaction between our genes and our environment?', 'Beyond our basic genotype, however, there is a deep interaction between our genes and our environment:']

['What term is used to describe how our unique experiences in the environment influence the expression of particular traits, while genes influence how we interact with the environment?', 'Our unique experiences in our environment influence whether and how particular traits are expressed, and at the same time, our genes influence how we interact with our environment (Diamond, 2009; Lobo, 2008).']

['What does the chapter explore regarding the interaction between nature and nurture in shaping our development?', 'This chapter will show that there is a reciprocal interaction between nature and nurture as they both shape who we become, but the debate continues as to the relative contributions of each.']

['Teacher: Can you describe some of the theories about the growth and development of babies and children into happy, healthy adults?', 'There are many theories regarding how babies and children grow and develop into happy, healthy adults.']

['What are some of the theories discussed in this section about the growth and development of babies and children into happy, healthy adults?', 'We explore several of these theories in this section.']
['Teacher: Who was the psychologist who proposed the Psychosexual Theory of Development?', 'Sigmund Freud (1856–1939) believed that personality develops during early childhood.']

['Teacher: How did Sigmund Freud believe that our childhood experiences influence our personalities and behavior in adulthood?', 'For Freud, childhood experiences shape our personalities and behavior as adults.']

['Teacher: Can you explain what Freud meant by "fixation" in the context of his Psychosexual Theory of Development?', 'Freud viewed development as discontinuous; he believed that each of us must pass through a series of stages during childhood, and that if we lack proper nurturance and parenting during a stage, we may become stuck, or fixated, in that stage.']
["Teacher: What are the different stages in Freud's Psychosexual Theory of Development called?", 'Freud’s stages are called the stages of psychosexual development.']

["Teacher: Can you provide an example of an erogenous zone associated with one of the stages in Freud's Psychosexual Theory of Development?", 'According to Freud, children’s pleasure-seeking urges are focused on a different area of the body, called an erogenous zone, at each of the five stages of development: oral, anal, phallic, latency, and genital.']

["Teacher: Can you explain why most of Freud's ideas have not found support in modern research?", 'While most of Freud’s ideas have not found support in modern research, we cannot discount the contributions that Freud has made to the field of psychology.']

["Teacher: What do psychologists today say about Freud's psychosexual stages as an explanation for how one's personality develops, and what aspect of Freud's theory still holds value?", "Psychologists today dispute Freud's psychosexual stages as a legitimate explanation for how one's personality develops, but what we can take away from Freud’s theory is that personality is shaped, in some part, by experiences we have in childhood."]

["What is the main criticism of Freud's psychosexual stages according to psychologists today, and where can we find more information about these stages?", 'These stages are discussed in detail in the chapter on personality.']
["Teacher: How did Erik Erikson modify Freud's theory of development?", 'Erik Erikson (1902–1994), another stage theorist, took Freud’s theory and modified it as psychosocial theory.']

["Teacher: In what way does Erik Erikson's psychosocial theory differ from Freud's theory of development?", 'Erikson’s psychosocial development theory emphasizes the social nature of our development rather than its sexual nature.']

["Teacher: How does Erik Erikson's view on personality development differ from Freud's belief?", 'While Freud believed that personality is shaped only in childhood, Erikson proposed that personality development takes place all through the lifespan.']

['Teacher: What term did Erik Erikson use to refer to our sense of self in relation to others?', 'Erikson suggested that how we interact with others is what affects our sense of self, or what he called the ego identity.']

['Teacher: What did Erikson propose as the driving force behind our actions and behaviors in his Psychosocial Theory of Development?', 'Erikson proposed that we are motivated by a need to achieve competence in certain areas of our lives.']

["Teacher: Could you provide an example of one of these areas in which we strive to achieve competence according to Erikson's Psychosocial Theory of Development?", 'According to psychosocial theory, we experience eight stages of development over our lifespan, from infancy through late adulthood.']

['Teacher: Exactly! Can you tell me what Erikson called these conflicts or tasks that we need to resolve at each stage of development in his Psychosocial Theory?', 'At each stage there is a conflict, or task, that we need to resolve.']

['Teacher: What is the term Erikson used to describe the outcome when we successfully resolve the conflicts or tasks at each stage of development in his Psychosocial Theory?', 'Successful completion of each developmental task results in a sense of competence and a healthy personality.']

["Teacher: What are the consequences of failing to successfully resolve the conflicts or tasks at each stage of development in Erikson's Psychosocial Theory of Development?", 'Failure to master these tasks leads to feelings of inadequacy.']

['Teacher: What does Erikson (1963) suggest is the foundation of our development in the first year of life?', 'According to Erikson (1963), trust is the basis of our development during infancy (birth to 12 months).']
['Teacher: Can you explain what Erikson means by trust versus mistrust in the context of infancy development?', 'Therefore, the primary task of this stage is trust versus mistrust.']

['Teacher: How does the development of trust during infancy relate to the behavior of caregivers towards their infants?', 'Infants are dependent upon their caregivers, so caregivers who are responsive and sensitive to their infant’s needs help their baby to develop a sense of trust; their baby will see the world as a safe, predictable place.']

["Teacher: Why is it important for caregivers to be responsive and sensitive to their infant's needs during the first year of life?", 'Unresponsive caregivers who do not meet their baby’s needs can engender feelings of anxiety, fear, and mistrust; their baby may see the world as unpredictable.']

['Teacher: What do toddlers learn as they begin to explore their world, realizing that they have the ability to control their actions and have an impact on the environment?', 'As toddlers (ages 1–3 years) begin to explore their world, they learn that they can control their actions and act on the environment to get results.']

['What types of elements in their environment do toddlers begin to show clear preferences for?', 'They begin to show clear preferences for certain elements of the environment, such as food, toys, and clothing.']

['What is the main task that toddlers need to resolve during this stage of development?', 'A toddler’s main task is to resolve the issue of autonomy versus shame and doubt, by working to establish independence.']
['What are some examples of behaviors that toddlers might exhibit during the "me do it" stage?', 'This is the “me do it” stage.']

['What are some other examples of behaviors that toddlers might exhibit during the "me do it" stage besides wanting to choose their clothes and dress themselves?', 'For example, we might observe a budding sense of autonomy in a 2-year-old child who wants to choose her clothes and dress herself.']

['What is the impact of allowing toddlers to make their own choices, even if their decisions might not be appropriate for the situation?', 'Although her outfits might not be appropriate for the situation, her input in such basic decisions has an effect on her sense of independence.']

['Why is it important for toddlers to have the opportunity to act on their environment and make their own choices?', 'If denied the opportunity to act on her environment, she may begin to doubt her abilities, which could lead to low self-esteem and feelings of shame.']

['Teacher: What abilities do children develop during the preschool stage that allow them to initiate activities and assert control over their world?', 'Once children reach the preschool stage (ages 3–6 years), they are capable of initiating activities and asserting control over their world through social interactions and play.']

['Teacher: What is the outcome of successfully resolving the task of initiative versus guilt in preschool children, according to Erikson?', 'According to Erikson, preschool children must resolve the task of initiative versus guilt.']

['Teacher: How does successfully resolving the task of initiative versus guilt in preschool children contribute to their development?', 'By learning to plan and achieve goals while interacting with others, preschool children can master this task.']

['What are some examples of activities or behaviors that demonstrate successful resolution of the task of initiative versus guilt in preschool children?', 'Those who do will develop self-confidence and feel a sense of purpose.']

['What are some possible negative outcomes for preschool children who are unsuccessful at resolving the task of initiative versus guilt?', 'Those who are unsuccessful at this stage—with their initiative misfiring or stifled—may develop feelings of guilt.']

['Teacher: What is the main task that children face during the elementary school stage, according to the Psychosocial Theory of Development?', 'During the elementary school stage (ages 7–11), children face the task of industry versus inferiority.']

['What is the outcome for children who successfully resolve the conflict of industry versus inferiority during the elementary school stage?', 'Children begin to compare themselves to their peers to see how they measure up.']

['What are the two possible outcomes for children who successfully resolve the conflict of industry versus inferiority during the elementary school stage?', 'They either develop a sense of pride and accomplishment in their schoolwork, sports, social activities, and family life, or they feel inferior and inadequate when they don’t measure up.']

['Teacher: What is the main task that children face during adolescence according to the Psychosocial Theory of Development?', 'In adolescence (ages 12–18), children face the task of identity versus role confusion.']

['Teacher: How does Erikson describe the main task of adolescents according to the Psychosocial Theory of Development?', 'According to Erikson, an adolescent’s main task is developing a sense of self.']

['Teacher: How does the Psychosocial Theory of Development explain the main task of adolescents during adolescence?', 'Adolescents struggle with questions such as “Who am I?” and “What do I want to do with my life?”']

['Teacher: How do adolescents explore their sense of identity according to the Psychosocial Theory of Development?', 'Along the way, most adolescents try on many different selves to see which ones fit.']

['Teacher: What are the outcomes for adolescents who successfully navigate the main task of identity versus role confusion according to the Psychosocial Theory of Development?', 'Adolescents who are successful at this stage have a strong sense of identity and are able to remain true to their beliefs and values in the face of problems and other people’s perspectives.']

['What are the outcomes for adolescents who do not successfully navigate the main task of identity versus role confusion according to the Psychosocial Theory of Development?', 'These teens will have a weak sense of self and experience role confusion.']

['What are some common struggles that adolescents may face when trying to navigate the main task of identity versus role confusion according to the Psychosocial Theory of Development?', 'They are unsure of their identity and confused about the future.']

['Teacher: What is the main focus or conflict that individuals in early adulthood, specifically those in their 20s through early 40s, experience according to the Psychosocial Theory of Development?', 'People in early adulthood (i.e., 20s through early 40s) are concerned with intimacy versus isolation.']

['Teacher: How does the need for intimacy impact individuals in early adulthood, according to the Psychosocial Theory of Development?', 'After we have developed a sense of self in adolescence, we are ready to share our life with others.']

["Teacher: Why is it important for individuals to have a strong sense of self before developing intimate relationships with others, according to Erikson's Psychosocial Theory of Development?", 'Erikson said that we must have a strong sense of self before developing intimate relationships with others.']

["Teacher: What are the potential consequences for adults who do not develop a positive self-concept in adolescence, according to Erikson's Psychosocial Theory of Development?", 'Adults who do not develop a positive self-concept in adolescence may experience feelings of loneliness and emotional isolation.']

["Teacher: What is the name given to the developmental period that typically begins in a person's 40s and extends to their mid-60s?", 'When people reach their 40s, they enter the time known as middle adulthood, which extends to the mid-60s.']
['Teacher: Can you explain the key social task that individuals in middle adulthood face?', 'The social task of middle adulthood is generativity versus stagnation.']

['Teacher: Can you provide some examples of how individuals in middle adulthood can demonstrate generativity and contribute to the development of others?', 'Generativity involves finding your life’s work and contributing to the development of others, through activities such as volunteering, mentoring, and raising children.']

['What are some potential consequences for individuals in middle adulthood who do not master the task of generativity?', 'Those who do not master this task may experience stagnation, having little connection with others and little interest in productivity and self-improvement.']

['Teacher: What is the specific period of development called that encompasses the time from the mid-60s until the end of life?', 'From the mid-60s to the end of life, we are in the period of development known as late adulthood.']
["Teacher: What is Erikson's task referred to in late adulthood?", 'Erikson’s task at this stage is called integrity versus despair.']

["What are the two possible outcomes for individuals in late adulthood according to Erikson's theory?", 'He said that people in late adulthood reflect on their lives and feel either a sense of satisfaction or a sense of failure.']

['What about individuals who feel a sense of failure in late adulthood?', 'People who feel proud of their accomplishments feel a sense of integrity, and they can look back on their lives with few regrets.']

['What are some possible feelings or emotions that individuals who feel a sense of failure in late adulthood may experience?', 'However, people who are not successful at this stage may feel as if their life has been wasted.']

['What term is used to describe the focus on what "would have," "should have," and "could have" been for individuals who feel a sense of failure in late adulthood?', 'They focus on what “would have,” “should have,” and “could have” been.']

['What are some possible negative emotions or psychological states that individuals who feel a sense of failure in late adulthood may experience?', 'They face the end of their lives with feelings of bitterness, depression, and despair.']
['What does Table 9.1 summarize?', 'Table 9.1 summarizes the stages of Erikson’s theory.']
['Teacher: Who is the stage theorist who extensively researched childhood development?', 'Jean Piaget (1896–1980) is another stage theorist who studied childhood development.']

['Teacher: How did Jean Piaget approach childhood development differently from other perspectives?', 'Instead of approaching development from a psychoanalytical or psychosocial perspective, Piaget focused on children’s cognitive growth.']

["Teacher: According to Jean Piaget, what is a central aspect of development and how did he view children's natural tendencies?", 'He believed that thinking is a central aspect of development and that children are naturally inquisitive.']
['Teacher: How did Jean Piaget describe the way children think and reason compared to adults?', 'However, he said that children do not think and reason like adults (Piaget, 1930, 1932).']

["What is the main idea behind Jean Piaget's theory of cognitive development?", 'His theory of cognitive development holds that our cognitive abilities develop through specific stages, which exemplifies the discontinuity approach to development.']

['What are some examples of the specific stages that Piaget identified in his theory of cognitive development?', 'As we progress to a new stage, there is a distinct shift in how we think and reason.']
["Teacher: That's correct! Now, can you explain how Piaget's cognitive theory of development defines a schema?", 'Piaget said that children develop schemata to help them understand the world.']

['Teacher: Excellent explanation! Can you provide an example of how children use schemata to understand the world around them?', 'Schemata are concepts (mental models) that are used to help us categorize and interpret information.']
['Teacher: How do schemata help children categorize and interpret information as they grow older?', 'By the time children have reached adulthood, they have created schemata for almost everything.']

['How do children adjust their schemata through assimilation and accommodation?', 'When children learn new information, they adjust their schemata through two processes: assimilation and accommodation.']

["Teacher: That's a great explanation of assimilation! Now, can you explain the second process, accommodation, in the context of adjusting schemata?", 'First, they assimilate new information or experiences in terms of their current schemata: assimilation is when they take in information that is comparable to what they already know.']

['How does accommodation relate to adjusting schemata when children encounter information that does not fit their existing mental models?', 'Accommodation describes when they change their schemata based on new information.']
['Can you provide an example of how children might use accommodation to adjust their schemata based on new information?', 'This process continues as children interact with their environment.']
['Teacher: How did Abdul develop his schema for dogs?', 'For example, 2-year-old Abdul learned the schema for dogs because his family has a Labrador retriever.']
['Teacher: What does Abdul do when he sees other dogs in his picture books?', 'When Abdul sees other dogs in his picture books, he says, “Look mommy, dog!”']
['Teacher: How does Abdul react when he sees dogs in his picture books?', 'Thus, he has assimilated them into his schema for dogs.']
['What does Abdul say when he sees a sheep for the first time?', 'One day, Abdul sees a sheep for the first time and says, “Look mommy, dog!”']

["Teacher: How does Abdul's reaction to seeing a sheep for the first time demonstrate his cognitive development?", 'Having a basic schema that a dog is an animal with four legs and fur, Abdul thinks all furry, four-legged creatures are dogs.']

['How does Abdul accommodate his schema for dogs after seeing a sheep for the first time?', 'When Abdul’s mom tells him that the animal he sees is a sheep, not a dog, Abdul must accommodate his schema for dogs to include more information based on his new experiences.']
['What does Abdul learn about his schema for dogs after seeing a sheep for the first time?', 'Abdul’s schema for dog was too broad, since not all furry, four-legged creatures are dogs.']
['What does Abdul do when he sees a sheep after modifying his schema for dogs?', 'He now modifies his schema for dogs and forms a new one for sheep.']

['Teacher: Who are some other psychologists that also believed in the idea of development occurring in stages?', 'Like Freud and Erikson, Piaget thought development unfolds in a series of stages approximately associated with age ranges.']

["Teacher: Can you provide more details about Piaget's theory of cognitive development, specifically, what are the four stages he proposed?", 'He proposed a theory of cognitive development that unfolds in four stages: sensorimotor, preoperational, concrete operational, and formal operational.']

['Teacher: What is the first stage of the Cognitive Theory of Development and how long does it typically last?', 'The first stage is the sensorimotor stage, which lasts from birth to about 2 years old.']
['What are some characteristics of the sensorimotor stage in the Cognitive Theory of Development?', 'During this stage, children learn about the world through their senses and motor behavior.']

['Why do young children put objects in their mouths and shake or bang them in the sensorimotor stage?', 'Young children put objects in their mouths to see if the items are edible, and once they can grasp objects, they may shake or bang them to see if they make sounds.']

['What is the concept that develops between 5 and 8 months old in the sensorimotor stage?', 'Between 5 and 8 months old, the child develops object permanence, which is the understanding that even if something is out of sight, it still exists (Bogartz, Shinskey, & Schilling, 2000).']

['Why do young infants not remember an object after it has been removed from sight in the sensorimotor stage?', 'According to Piaget, young infants do not remember an object after it has been removed from sight.']

["What did Piaget observe when studying infants' reactions to a hidden toy in the sensorimotor stage?", 'Piaget studied infants’ reactions when a toy was first shown to an infant and then hidden under a blanket.']

["What did Piaget conclude about infants' ability to reach for a hidden toy in the sensorimotor stage?", 'Infants who had already developed object permanence would reach for the hidden toy, indicating that they knew it still existed, whereas infants who had not developed object permanence would appear confused.']

["Teacher: What is the term used to describe a fear of unfamiliar people that children develop around the same time as object permanence in Piaget's cognitive theory of development?", 'In Piaget’s view, around the same time children develop object permanence, they also begin to exhibit stranger anxiety, which is a fear of unfamiliar people.']

['What are some behaviors that babies may exhibit when they experience stranger anxiety?', 'Babies may demonstrate this by crying and turning away from a stranger, by clinging to a caregiver, or by attempting to reach their arms toward familiar faces such as parents.']

["Teacher: Why do children experience stranger anxiety according to Piaget's cognitive theory of development?", 'Stranger anxiety results when a child is unable to assimilate the stranger into an existing schema; therefore, she can’t predict what her experience with that stranger will be like, which results in a fear response.']
['Teacher: Can you tell me Piaget’s second stage of cognitive development and its age range?', 'Piaget’s second stage is the preoperational stage, which is from approximately 2 to 7 years old.']

["What is the main milestone or cognitive ability that children acquire during Piaget's preoperational stage of development?", 'In this stage, children can use symbols to represent words, images, and ideas, which is why children in this stage engage in pretend play.']

['What is an example of how children in the preoperational stage engage in pretend play?', 'A child’s arms might become airplane wings as they zoom around the room, or a child with a stick might become a brave knight with a sword.']

['What is one limitation or characteristic of children in the preoperational stage in terms of their understanding of logic and information manipulation?', 'Children also begin to use language in the preoperational stage, but they cannot understand adult logic or mentally manipulate information (the term operational refers to logical manipulation of information, so children at this stage are considered to be pre-operational).']

["What is the term used to describe children's logic during the preoperational stage of cognitive development?", 'Children’s logic is based on their own personal knowledge of the world so far, rather than on conventional knowledge.']

["What is an example that demonstrates the limitation of a child's logic during the preoperational stage of cognitive development?", 'For example, dad gave a slice of pizza to 10-year-old Keiko and another slice to her 3-year-old brother, Kenny.']

['Why did Kenny think he got more pizza than his sister even though they were given the same number of slices?', 'Kenny’s pizza slice was cut into five pieces, so Kenny told his sister that he got more pizza than she did.']

['Can you explain the concept of conservation and why children in the preoperational stage have difficulty understanding it?', 'Children in this stage cannot perform mental operations because they have not developed an understanding of conservation, which is the idea that even if you change the appearance of something, it is still equal in size as long as nothing has been removed or added.']

['Teacher: What is the term used to describe the inability of children to take the perspective of others?', 'During this stage, we also expect children to display egocentrism, which means that the child is not able to take the perspective of others.']

['What term best describes the cognitive limitation in which a child at this stage believes that everyone sees, thinks, and feels just as they do?', 'A child at this stage thinks that everyone sees, thinks, and feels just as they do.']
['What is the term used to describe the cognitive limitation in which a child at this stage believes that everyone sees, thinks, and feels just as they do?', 'Let’s look at Kenny and Keiko again.']
['What example from the passage illustrates the cognitive limitation discussed?', 'Keiko’s birthday is coming up, so their mom takes Kenny to the toy store to choose a present for his sister.']

["What does Kenny's belief that his sister will like the Iron Man action figure because he likes it himself exemplify?", 'He selects an Iron Man action figure for her, thinking that if he likes the toy, his sister will too.']

["Why is Kenny's belief that his sister will like the Iron Man action figure because he likes it himself considered an example of egocentrism?", 'An egocentric child is not able to infer the perspective of other people and instead attributes his own perspective.']
["Teacher: What is the name of Piaget's third stage of cognitive development?", 'Piaget’s third stage is the concrete operational stage, which occurs from about 7 to 11 years old.']

["Teacher: Can you provide an example of a memory strategy that children in Piaget's concrete operational stage might use?", 'In this stage, children can think logically about real (concrete) events; they have a firm grasp on the use of numbers and start to employ memory strategies.']

["Teacher: How does the concrete operational stage in Piaget's cognitive theory enable children to think logically about numbers and mathematical operations?", 'They can perform mathematical operations and understand transformations, such as addition is the opposite of subtraction, and multiplication is the opposite of division.']

["What is one additional concept or ability that children in Piaget's concrete operational stage of cognitive development master?", 'In this stage, children also master the concept of conservation: Even if something changes shape, its mass, volume, and number stay the same.']

["What is the term used to describe the ability of children in Piaget's concrete operational stage to understand that even if the appearance of an object changes, its essential characteristics remain the same?", 'For example, if you pour water from a tall, thin glass to a short, fat glass, you still have the same amount of water.']

['Teacher: What is the principle that children in the concrete operational stage understand, which implies that objects can be changed and then returned back to their original form or condition?', 'Children in the concrete operational stage also understand the principle of reversibility, which means that objects can be changed and then returned back to their original form or condition.']
['Teacher: Can you explain how the principle of reversibility applies to the example of pouring water into a short, fat glass?', 'Take, for example, water that you poured into the short, fat glass:']

['Teacher: What does this example demonstrate about the principle of reversibility in the concrete operational stage?', 'You can pour water from the fat glass back to the thin glass and still have the same amount (minus a couple of drops).']

["Teacher: What is the name of the fourth stage in Piaget's theory of cognitive development?", 'The fourth, and last, stage in Piaget’s theory is the formal operational stage, which is from about age 11 to adulthood.']

['Teacher: What are some key cognitive abilities that children in the formal operational stage possess?', 'Whereas children in the concrete operational stage are able to think logically only about concrete events, children in the formal operational stage can also deal with abstract ideas and hypothetical situations.']

["Teacher: How does the ability to think abstractly and deal with hypothetical situations impact a child's problem-solving skills in the formal operational stage?", 'Children in this stage can use abstract thinking to problem solve, look at alternative solutions, and test these solutions.']
["What does the renewal of egocentrism in adolescence mean in the context of Piaget's cognitive theory of development?", 'In adolescence, a renewed egocentrism occurs.']

["What is an example of renewed egocentrism that occurs in adolescence according to Piaget's cognitive theory of development?", 'For example, a 15-year-old with a very small pimple on her face might think it is huge and incredibly visible, under the mistaken impression that others must share her perceptions.']
['Teacher: What is the mental process that occurs when we are engaged in thinking?', 'Thought.']

["Teacher: What can you tell me about Piaget's ideas and their reception among researchers?", 'As with other major contributors of theories of development, several of Piaget’s ideas have come under criticism based on the results of further research.']

["Teacher: Can you provide some examples of the criticisms that have been made of Piaget's ideas by other researchers?", 'For example, several contemporary studies support a model of development that is more continuous than Piaget’s discrete stages (Courage & Howe, 2002; Siegler, 2005, 2006).']

['Teacher: Can you give me specific examples of studies that suggest children reach cognitive milestones earlier than what Piaget describes?', 'Many others suggest that children reach cognitive milestones earlier than Piaget describes (Baillargeon, 2004; de Hevia & Spelke, 2010).']

['Teacher: Can you explain what Piaget means by "formal operational thought"?', 'According to Piaget, the highest level of cognitive development is formal operational thought, which develops between 11 and 20 years old.']

['Teacher: How does formal operational thought differ from the other stages of cognitive development proposed by Piaget?', 'However, many developmental psychologists disagree with Piaget, suggesting a fifth stage of cognitive development, known as the postformal stage (Basseches, 1984; Commons & Bresette, 2006; Sinnott, 1998).']

['Teacher: What are some key differences between formal operational thought and postformal thinking?', 'In postformal thinking, decisions are made based on situations and circumstances, and logic is integrated with emotion as adults develop principles that depend on contexts.']

['Teacher: How do adults in postformal thought differ from adolescents in formal operational thought when it comes to handling emotionally charged issues?', 'One way that we can see the difference between an adult in postformal thought and an adolescent in formal operations is in terms of how they handle emotionally charged issues.']

['Teacher: How does the Cognitive Theory of Development explain changes in problem solving abilities once individuals reach adulthood?', 'It seems that once we reach adulthood our problem solving abilities change:']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example or explain further how the Cognitive Theory of Development relates to changes in problem solving abilities in adulthood?', 'As we attempt to solve problems, we tend to think more deeply about many areas of our lives, such as relationships, work, and politics (Labouvie-Vief & Diehl, 1999).']

['Teacher: How does the ability to think more deeply about various aspects of life, such as relationships, work, and politics, relate to problem solving abilities according to the Cognitive Theory of Development?', 'Because of this, postformal thinkers are able to draw on past experiences to help them solve new problems.']

['Teacher: How do problem-solving strategies using postformal thought vary depending on the situation, according to the Cognitive Theory of Development?', 'Problem-solving strategies using postformal thought vary, depending on the situation.']

['Teacher: How does the Cognitive Theory of Development explain the variation in problem-solving strategies using postformal thought depending on the situation?', 'Adults can recognize, for example, that what seems to be an ideal solution to a problem at work involving a disagreement with a colleague may not be the best solution to a disagreement with a significant other.']
['Teacher: Who was the Russian psychologist that proposed a sociocultural theory of development?', 'Lev Vygotsky was a Russian psychologist who proposed a sociocultural theory of development.']
['What does Lev Vygotsky propose about human development in his sociocultural theory?', 'He suggested that human development is rooted in one’s culture.']

["What is one example of how a child's social world influences language and thought, according to Lev Vygotsky's sociocultural theory?", 'A child’s social world, for example, forms the basis for the formation of language and thought.']

["How does Lev Vygotsky's sociocultural theory suggest that the language and thinking patterns of an individual are influenced?", 'The language one speaks and the ways a person thinks about things is dependent on one’s cultural background.']
["How does Lev Vygotsky's sociocultural theory incorporate historical influences into one's development?", 'Vygotsky also considered historical influences as key to one’s development.']

['What are some key elements that Lev Vygotsky considered in his sociocultural theory of development?', 'He was interested in the process of development and the individual’s interactions with their environment (John-Steiner & Mahn, 1996).']

['Teacher: What is a significant responsibility that individuals have during childhood and adolescence in relation to moral development?', 'A major task beginning in childhood and continuing into adolescence is discerning right from wrong.']

['What is the contribution of Lawrence Kohlberg to the understanding of moral development?', 'Psychologist Lawrence Kohlberg (1927–1987) extended upon the foundation that Piaget built regarding cognitive development.']
['Teacher: How does moral development according to Kohlberg parallel cognitive development?', 'Kohlberg believed that moral development, like cognitive development, follows a series of stages.']

["What was Lawrence Kohlberg's method of developing his theory of moral development?", 'To develop this theory, Kohlberg posed moral dilemmas to people of all ages, and then he analyzed their answers to find evidence of their particular stage of moral development.']

["What is the purpose of posing moral dilemmas to individuals of all ages in Kohlberg's method of developing his theory of moral development?", "Before reading about the stages, take a minute to consider how you would answer one of Kohlberg's best-known moral dilemmas, commonly known as the Heinz dilemma:"]

['Teacher: What aspect of moral thinking interested Kohlberg in relation to the dilemmas presented?', 'Kohlberg was not interested in whether you answer yes or no to the dilemma: Instead, he was interested in the reasoning behind your answer.']

['Teacher: How did Kohlberg determine the different stages of moral reasoning?', 'After presenting people with this and various other moral dilemmas, Kohlberg reviewed people’s responses and placed them in different stages of moral reasoning.']

['Teacher: How did Kohlberg determine the different stages of moral reasoning according to the passage?', 'According to Kohlberg, an individual progresses from the capacity for pre-conventional morality (before age 9) to the capacity for conventional morality (early adolescence), and toward attaining post-conventional morality (once formal operational thought is attained), which only a few fully achieve.']

['Teacher: What did Kohlberg determine as the highest stage of moral reasoning in relation to the Heinz dilemma?', 'Kohlberg placed in the highest stage responses that reflected the reasoning that Heinz should steal the drug because his wife’s life is more important than the pharmacist making money.']

["Teacher: What does the student suggest about the importance of human life in relation to the pharmacist's greed, based on their response to the Heinz dilemma?", 'The value of a human life overrides the pharmacist’s greed.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the concept of post-conventional reasons for choices and how it relates to the idea that people may still make choices based on pre-conventional reasons?', 'It is important to realize that even those people who have the most sophisticated, post-conventional reasons for some choices may make other choices for the simplest of pre-conventional reasons.']

["Teacher: How do psychologists view Kohlberg's theory of moral development in relation to the distinction between moral reasoning and moral behavior?", "Many psychologists agree with Kohlberg's theory of moral development but point out that moral reasoning is very different from moral behavior."]

["Teacher: How can we describe the discrepancy between moral reasoning and moral behavior according to the psychologists who agree with Kohlberg's theory of moral development?", 'In other words, we might “talk the talk,” but not “walk the walk.”']

['Teacher: According to Kohlberg (1969), which gender tends to move past stage four more in their moral development?', 'Kohlberg (1969) felt that more men than women move past stage four in their moral development.']

['Teacher: Can you elaborate on why Kohlberg believed that women are deficient in their moral reasoning abilities?', 'He went on to note that women seem to be deficient in their moral reasoning abilities.']

["Teacher: How did Carol Gilligan respond to Kohlberg's belief that women are deficient in their moral reasoning abilities?", 'These ideas were not well received by Carol Gilligan, a research assistant of Kohlberg, who consequently developed her own ideas of moral development.']

['white men and did not take into account the experiences and perspectives of diverse individuals.', 'In her groundbreaking book, In a Different Voice: Psychological Theory and Women’s Development, Gilligan (1982) criticized her former mentor’s theory because it was based only on upper class']
["What were the main criticisms that Gilligan had against Kohlberg's theory of moral development?", 'White men and boys.']

['How did Gilligan propose that different genders reason differently in terms of moral development?', 'She argued that women are not deficient in their moral reasoning—she proposed that different genders reason differently.']

['What did Gilligan argue was the focus of girls and women in terms of moral reasoning and development?', 'Girls and women focus more on staying connected and the importance of interpersonal relationships.']

['How does Gilligan believe that the focus on interpersonal relationships influences the way girls and women respond to the Heinz dilemma?', 'Therefore, in the Heinz dilemma, many girls and women respond that Heinz should not steal the medicine.']

["Why do girls and women respond that Heinz should not steal the medicine in the Heinz dilemma, according to Gilligan's theory?", 'Their reasoning is that if he steals the medicine, is arrested, and is put in jail, then he and his wife will be separated, and she could die while he is still in prison.']

['Teacher: What are the three areas in which developmental psychologists often divide our development?', 'As discussed at the beginning of this chapter, developmental psychologists often divide our development into three areas: physical development, cognitive development, and psychosocial development.']

['Teacher: Can you explain how physical development, cognitive development, and psychosocial development are interconnected in the context of lifespan development?', 'Mirroring Erikson’s stages, lifespan development is divided into different stages that are based on age.']
['Teacher: What are the different stages of lifespan development that we will discuss in this context?', 'We will discuss prenatal, infant, child, adolescent, and adult development.']
