['Teacher: Can you describe the process of prenatal development, from its initial stage to birth?', 'From beginning as a one-cell structure to your birth, your prenatal development occurred in an orderly and delicate sequence.']
['Teacher: What are the three stages of prenatal development?', 'There are three stages of prenatal development: germinal, embryonic, and fetal.']
['Teacher: Can you provide a brief explanation of what occurs during the germinal stage of prenatal development?', 'Let’s take a look at what happens to the developing baby in each of these stages.']

["Teacher: That's correct! Now let's focus on the germinal stage. Can you explain what the germinal stage refers to?", 'In the discussion of biopsychology earlier in the book, you learned about genetics and DNA.']

['Teacher: Excellent! In relation to the germinal stage, how does the passing on of DNA at the moment of conception contribute to the development of the embryo?', 'DNA is passed on to the child at the moment of conception.']
['What is the significance of the zygote formation during conception in the development of the embryo?', 'Conception occurs when sperm fertilizes an egg and forms a zygote.']
['What happens to the zygote as it continues to develop in the germinal stage?', 'A zygote begins as a one-cell structure that is created when a sperm and egg merge.']
['What are some key characteristics of the germinal stage in the development of the embryo?', 'The genetic makeup and sex of the zygote are set at this point.']

['What are some key milestones in the development of the zygote during the germinal stage?', 'During the first week after conception, the zygote divides and multiplies, going from a one-cell structure to two cells, then four cells, then eight cells, and so on.']
['What is the purpose or function of mitosis during the development of the zygote in the germinal stage?', 'This process of cell division is called mitosis.']

['What is the rate of survival for zygotes beyond the first two weeks of the germinal stage?', 'Mitosis is a fragile process, and fewer than one-half of all zygotes survive beyond the first two weeks (Hall, 2004).']

['What is the significance of the rapid cell division (mitosis) during the germinal stage in terms of the growth of the zygote?', 'After 5 days of mitosis there are 100 cells, and after 9 months there are billions of cells.']

['How does the process of cell division (mitosis) during the germinal stage contribute to the specialization of cells and the formation of different organs and body parts?', 'As the cells divide, they become more specialized, forming different organs and body parts.']

["What is the significance of the mass of cells not attaching itself to the lining of the mother's uterus during the germinal stage?", 'In the germinal stage, the mass of cells has yet to attach itself to the lining of the mother’s uterus.']
["What is the name of the stage that follows the germinal stage once the mass of cells attaches itself to the lining of the mother's uterus?", 'Once it does, the next stage begins.']

['Teacher: What happens after the zygote divides for about 7–10 days and has 150 cells?', 'After the zygote divides for about 7–10 days and has 150 cells, it travels down the fallopian tubes and implants itself in the lining of the uterus.']
['What is the term used to describe the multi-cellular organism after it implants itself in the lining of the uterus?', 'Upon implantation, this multi-cellular organism is called an embryo.']
['What is the timeframe for the embryonic stage of development?', 'Now blood vessels grow, forming the placenta.']

['What is the significance of the placenta during the embryonic stage of development?', 'The placenta is a structure connected to the uterus that provides nourishment and oxygen from the mother to the developing embryo via the umbilical cord.']

['What are some of the basic structures that start to develop during the embryonic stage and eventually become the head, chest, and abdomen?', 'Basic structures of the embryo start to develop into areas that will become the head, chest, and abdomen.']
['What are some examples of organs that form and begin to function during the embryonic stage?', 'During the embryonic stage, the heart begins to beat and organs form and begin to function.']

['What is the development that occurs along the back of the embryo during the embryonic stage, which eventually forms the spinal cord and brain?', 'The neural tube forms along the back of the embryo, developing into the spinal cord and brain.']
['Teacher: At what point in the development of the organism is the embryo referred to as a fetus?', 'When the organism is about nine weeks old, the embryo is called a fetus.']

['Why is the term "fetus" used to describe the organism at around nine weeks of development?', 'At this stage, the fetus is about the size of a kidney bean and begins to take on the recognizable form of a human being as the “tail” begins to disappear.']
['Teacher: What happens to the sex organs during the fetal stage from 9-12 weeks?', 'From 9–12 weeks, the sex organs begin to differentiate.']
['What is the size of the fetus at approximately 16 weeks during the fetal stage?', 'At about 16 weeks, the fetus is approximately 4.5 inches long.']
['What are some physical developments that occur during the fetal stage at approximately 26 weeks?', 'Fingers and toes are fully developed, and fingerprints are visible.']
['What are some milestones in fetal development that occur around the 24-week mark?', 'By the time the fetus reaches the sixth month of development (24 weeks), it weighs up to 1.4 pounds.']
['What are some milestones in fetal development that occur around the 30-week mark?', 'Hearing has developed, so the fetus can respond to sounds.']

['What are some milestones in fetal development that occur around the 37-week mark?', 'The internal organs, such as the lungs, heart, stomach, and intestines, have formed enough that a fetus born prematurely at this point has a chance to survive outside of the mother’s womb.']

['What is one significant change that occurs in the fetal brain during the fetal stage?', 'Throughout the fetal stage the brain continues to grow and develop, nearly doubling in size from weeks 16 to 28.']
['What are some physical changes that occur in the fetus around the 36-week mark?', 'Around 36 weeks, the fetus is almost ready for birth.']

['What are the weight and length of the fetus at around the 36-week mark?', 'It weighs about 6 pounds and is about 18.5 inches long, and by week 37 all of the fetus’s organ systems are developed enough that it could survive outside the uterus without many of the risks associated with premature birth.']
['What is the expected length of the fetus at approximately 40 weeks?', 'The fetus continues to gain weight and grow in length until approximately 40 weeks.']

['What is one significant change that occurs in the fetal development during the last weeks of the fetal stage, around 40 weeks?', 'By then, the fetus has very little room to move around and birth becomes imminent.']
['What does Figure 9.8 in the textbook show?', 'The progression through the stages is shown in Figure 9.8.']
['Teacher: What are the two types of factors that can influence development during each prenatal stage?', 'During each prenatal stage, genetic and environmental factors can affect development.']

['Teacher: How does the fact that the developing fetus is completely dependent on the mother for life relate to the two types of factors that can influence prenatal development?', 'The developing fetus is completely dependent on the mother for life.']

['Why is it important for the mother to take good care of herself and receive prenatal care during pregnancy?', 'It is important that the mother takes good care of herself and receives prenatal care, which is medical care during pregnancy that monitors the health of both the mother and the fetus.']

['What are some potential complications that can arise during pregnancy if the mother does not receive prenatal care?', 'According to the National Institutes of Health ([NIH], 2013), routine prenatal care is important because it can reduce the risk of complications to the mother and fetus during pregnancy.']

['What are some reasons why discussing pregnancy planning with a doctor is important for women who are trying to become pregnant or who may become pregnant?', 'In fact, women who are trying to become pregnant or who may become pregnant should discuss pregnancy planning with their doctor.']

['What are some specific recommendations that a doctor may give to women who are trying to become pregnant or may become pregnant?', 'They may be advised, for example, to take a vitamin containing folic acid, which helps prevent certain birth defects, or to monitor aspects of their diet or exercise routines.']
["Teacher: What is formed when the zygote attaches to the wall of the mother's uterus?", 'Recall that when the zygote attaches to the wall of the mother’s uterus, the placenta is formed.']
['What is the function of the placenta in the prenatal development of a fetus?', 'The placenta provides nourishment and oxygen to the fetus.']

['What substances are transferred from the mother to the fetus through the placenta during prenatal development?', 'Most everything the mother ingests, including food, liquid, and even medication, travels through the placenta to the fetus, hence the common phrase “eating for two.”']

['What impact can environmental factors have on the fetus during prenatal development?', 'Anything the mother is exposed to in the environment affects the fetus; if the mother is exposed to something harmful, the child can show life-long effects.']
['Teacher: What is the definition of a teratogen?', 'A teratogen is any environmental agent—biological, chemical, or physical—that causes damage to the developing embryo or fetus.']
['What are the three categories of teratogens?', 'There are different types of teratogens.']
['What are some examples of teratogens that fall under the category of biological agents?', 'Alcohol and most drugs cross the placenta and affect the fetus.']
['Teacher: Why is alcohol not safe to drink during pregnancy?', 'Alcohol is not safe to drink in any amount during pregnancy.']

['What is the impact of alcohol use during pregnancy on children?', 'Alcohol use during pregnancy has been found to be the leading preventable cause of intellectual disabilities in children in the United States (Maier & West, 2001).']

['What are some of the life-long consequences that can occur in children as a result of fetal alcohol spectrum disorders?', 'Excessive maternal drinking while pregnant can cause fetal alcohol spectrum disorders with life-long consequences for the child ranging in severity from minor to major.']

['What are some of the specific birth defects that can occur as a result of fetal alcohol spectrum disorders (FASD)?', 'Fetal alcohol spectrum disorders (FASD) are a collection of birth defects associated with heavy consumption of alcohol during pregnancy.']

['What are some of the physical characteristics that can be seen in children with fetal alcohol spectrum disorders (FASD)?', 'Physically, children with FASD may have a small head size and abnormal facial features.']

['What are some of the cognitive characteristics that can be seen in children with fetal alcohol spectrum disorders (FASD)?', 'Cognitively, these children may have poor judgment, poor impulse control, higher rates of ADHD, learning issues, and lower IQ scores.']

['What are some of the long-term developmental effects of fetal alcohol spectrum disorders (FASD) on individuals as they grow into adulthood?', 'These developmental problems and delays persist into adulthood (Streissguth et al., 2004).']

["What are some potential effects of fetal alcohol spectrum disorders (FASD) on an individual's future alcohol consumption habits?", "Based on studies conducted on animals, it also has been suggested that a parent's alcohol consumption during pregnancy may predispose their child to like alcohol (Youngentob et al., 2007)."]
['Teacher: Why is smoking considered a teratogen in terms of prenatal influences?', 'Smoking is also considered a teratogen because nicotine travels through the placenta to the fetus.']
['Teacher: How does the reduction in blood oxygen levels affect the developing baby?', 'When the mother smokes, the developing baby experiences a reduction in blood oxygen levels.']

['Teacher: What are some potential negative outcomes for the developing baby when the mother smokes during pregnancy?', 'According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (2013), smoking while pregnant can result in premature birth, low-birth-weight infants, stillbirth, and sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS).']

['Teacher: What are some substances that are considered teratogens?', 'Heroin, cocaine, methamphetamine, almost all prescription medicines, and most over-the counter medications are also considered teratogens.']
['How does prenatal exposure to heroin affect babies after birth?', 'Babies born with a heroin addiction need heroin just like an adult addict.']

['What can happen to a baby if they are not gradually weaned from heroin after birth?', 'The child will need to be gradually weaned from the heroin under medical supervision; otherwise, the child could have seizures and die.']

['What are some examples of non-substance teratogens that can have prenatal influences on babies?', 'Other teratogens include radiation, viruses such as HIV and herpes, and rubella (German measles).']

['What are some measures that can be taken to prevent rubella during pregnancy?', 'Women in the United States are much less likely to be afflicted with rubella because most women received childhood immunizations or vaccinations that protect the body from disease.']

['Teacher: Can you explain what is meant by the critical or sensitive period in prenatal development?', 'Each organ of the fetus develops during a specific period in the pregnancy, called the critical or sensitive period.']

['Teacher: How does the exposure to alcohol during the critical period affect the appearance of facial characteristics associated with fetal alcohol syndrome?', 'For example, research with primate models of FASD has demonstrated that the time during which a developing fetus is exposed to alcohol can dramatically affect the appearance of facial characteristics associated with fetal alcohol syndrome.']

['What are some specific facial abnormalities that can be caused by alcohol exposure during the critical period of gestation?', 'Specifically, this research suggests that alcohol exposure that is limited to day 19 or 20 of gestation can lead to significant facial abnormalities in the offspring (Ashley, Magnuson, Omnell, & Clarren, 1999).']

['What does the research suggest about the effects of alcohol exposure on regions of the brain during prenatal development?', 'Given regions of the brain also show sensitive periods during which they are most susceptible to the teratogenic effects of alcohol (Tran & Kelly, 2003).']
['Teacher: Can you provide me with the average weight of a newborn?', 'The average newborn weighs approximately 7.5 pounds.']

['Teacher: How do the reflexes and sensory capacities of newborns contribute to their ability to interact with the environment?', 'Although small, newborns are not completely helpless because their reflexes and sensory capacities help them interact with the environment from the moment of birth.']

['What are some examples of newborn reflexes that contribute to their ability to interact with the environment?', 'All healthy babies are born with newborn reflexes: inborn automatic responses to particular forms of stimulation.']

['What are some examples of newborn reflexes that are important for their survival?', 'Reflexes help the newborn survive until it is capable of more complex behaviors—these reflexes are crucial to survival.']
['At what age do newborn reflexes typically disappear?', 'They are present in babies whose brains are developing normally and usually disappear around 4–5 months old.']
['What are some examples of newborn reflexes that are important for their development and growth?', 'Let’s take a look at some of these newborn reflexes.']
['What is the purpose of the rooting reflex in newborns?', 'The rooting reflex is the newborn’s response to anything that touches their cheek:']
['What is the purpose of the rooting reflex in newborns?', 'When you stroke a baby’s cheek, the baby naturally turns the head in that direction and begins to suck.']
['What is the purpose of the sucking reflex in newborns?', 'The sucking reflex is the automatic, unlearned, sucking motions that infants do with their mouths.']
['What are some other examples of newborn reflexes that contribute to their ability to interact with the environment?', 'Several other interesting newborn reflexes can be observed.']

['What is the purpose of the grasping reflex in newborns?', 'For instance, if you put your finger into a newborn’s hand, you will witness the grasping reflex, in which a baby automatically grasps anything that touches the palms.']
['What does the Moro reflex in newborns respond to?', 'The Moro reflex is the newborn’s response to the sensation of falling.']
['What is the purpose of the stepping reflex in newborns?', 'The baby spreads the arms, pulls them back in, and then (usually) cries.']

["Teacher: What can we say about newborn infants' sensory abilities in relation to their development?", 'Newborn infants’ sensory abilities are significant, but their senses are not yet fully developed.']

["Teacher: How do newborn infants' innate preferences facilitate their interaction with caregivers and other humans?", 'Many of a newborn’s innate preferences facilitate interaction with caregivers and other humans.']
["Teacher: What can we say about newborn infants' sense of vision in relation to their development?", 'Although vision is their least developed sense, newborns already show a preference for faces.']

['Teacher: What evidence suggests that newborn infants have a preference for human voices?', 'Babies who are just a few days old also prefer human voices, they will listen to voices longer than sounds that do not involve speech (Vouloumanos & Werker, 2004), and they seem to prefer their mother’s voice over a stranger’s voice (Mills & Melhuish, 1974).']

["What were the results of the experiment with 3-week-old babies and pacifiers playing recordings of their mother's voice and a stranger's voice?", 'In an interesting experiment, 3-week-old babies were given pacifiers that played a recording of the infant’s mother’s voice and of a stranger’s voice.']

["What was the behavior of the 3-week-old babies when they heard their mother's voice during the experiment with pacifiers?", 'When the infants heard their mother’s voice, they sucked more strongly at the pacifier (Mills & Melhuish, 1974).']
["What can we say about newborn infants' sense of smell in relation to their development?", 'Newborns also have a strong sense of smell.']
['Teacher: How do newborn infants demonstrate their ability to distinguish smells?', 'For instance, newborn babies can distinguish the smell of their own mother from that of others.']

['What was the purpose of the study conducted by MacFarlane in regards to 1-week-old babies and breastfeeding?', 'In a study by MacFarlane (1978), 1-week-old babies who were being breastfed were placed between two gauze pads.']

['What was the behavior of the 1-week-old babies during the study conducted by MacFarlane regarding breastfeeding and gauze pads?', 'One gauze pad was from the bra of a nursing mother who was a stranger, and the other gauze pad was from the bra of the infant’s own mother.']

["What was the result of the study conducted by MacFarlane in regards to 1-week-old babies and gauze pads scented with their mother's scent and a stranger's scent?", 'More than two-thirds of the week-old babies turned toward the gauze pad with their mother’s scent.']
['Teacher: What is the pace of physical development during infancy, toddlerhood, and early childhood?', 'In infancy, toddlerhood, and early childhood, the body’s physical development is rapid.']

['Teacher: How does the weight of a newborn typically change within the first year?', 'On average, newborns weigh between 5 and 10 pounds, and a newborn’s weight typically doubles in six months and triples in one year.']

['What is the general pattern of weight change in a newborn within the first two years of life?', 'By 2 years old the weight will have quadrupled, so we can expect that a 2 year old should weigh between 20 and 40 pounds.']

['Teacher: What is the general pattern of length change in a newborn within the first two years of life?', 'The average length of a newborn is 19.5 inches, increasing to 29.5 inches by 12 months and 34.4 inches by 2 years old (WHO Multicentre Growth Reference Study Group, 2006).']

['Teacher: Can you tell me what happens to growth during infancy and childhood according to the passage?', 'During infancy and childhood, growth does not occur at a steady rate (Carel, Lahlou, Roger, & Chaussain, 2004).']

['What are the changes in growth that occur between 4 and 6 years old, as mentioned in the passage?', 'Growth slows between 4 and 6 years old: During this time children gain 5–7 pounds and grow about 2–3 inches per year.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why females experience a higher growth rate compared to males once they reach 8-9 years old, according to the passage?', 'Once females reach 8–9 years old, their growth rate outpaces that of males due to a pubertal growth spurt.']

['Can you describe the relationship between growth rate and the start of the menstrual cycle, based on the information provided in the passage?', 'This growth spurt continues until around 12 years old, coinciding with the start of the menstrual cycle.']

['What is the average weight of females and males at around 10 years old, as mentioned in the passage?', 'By 10 years old, the average female weighs 88 pounds, and the average male weighs 85 pounds.']
['Teacher: Is it true that we are born with all of the brain cells we will ever have?', 'It was previously believed that we are born with all of the brain cells we will ever have.']

['Teacher: What does more recent research suggest about neurogenesis (the formation of neurons) in adulthood?', 'More recent research suggests that neurogenesis (the formation of neurons) can continue through adulthood.']

["Teacher: How does the timing of neural connection and pathway formation in a child's life compare to neurogenesis in adulthood?", 'However, the vast majority of neural connections and pathways occur during the first few years of a child’s life (National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke, 2019).']
["Teacher: What is the term used to describe the period of rapid neural growth in a child's life?", 'This period of rapid neural growth is called blooming.']
['What is the term used to describe the process of neural pathways continuing to develop through puberty?', 'Neural pathways continue to develop through puberty.']

["What is the term used to describe the period of neural growth reduction after the blooming period in a child's life?", 'The blooming period of neural growth is then followed by a period of pruning, where neural connections are reduced.']
['What is the purpose of pruning in neural development?', 'It is thought that pruning causes the brain to function more efficiently, allowing for mastery of more complex skills (Hutchinson, 2011).']

["What are the two main phases of neural development that occur in a child's life?", 'Blooming occurs during the first few years of life, and pruning continues through childhood and into adolescence in various areas of the brain.']
['Teacher: What is one of the key aspects of physical development that occurs during this stage?', 'The size of our brains increases rapidly.']

['Teacher: Can you provide any other examples of how the size of our brains increase during this stage of physical development?', 'For example, the brain of a 2-year-old is 55% of its adult size, and by 6 years old the brain is about 90% of its adult size (Tanner, 1978).']
['Teacher: What are some of the specific areas of the brain that experience rapid growth during early childhood?', 'During early childhood (ages 3–6), the frontal lobes grow rapidly.']

["Teacher: How does the rapid growth of the frontal lobes during early childhood impact a child's development?", 'Recalling our discussion of the 4 lobes of the brain earlier in this book, the frontal lobes are associated with planning, reasoning, memory, and impulse control.']

["Teacher: What are some examples or behaviors that demonstrate how a child's impulse control may develop as a result of the rapid growth of the frontal lobes during early childhood?", 'Therefore, by the time children reach school age, they are developmentally capable of controlling their attention and behavior.']

["Teacher: How does the growth of the frontal, temporal, occipital, and parietal lobes during the elementary school years contribute to a child's overall development?", 'Through the elementary school years, the frontal, temporal, occipital, and parietal lobes all grow in size.']

["Teacher: How do the growth spurts of the frontal, temporal, occipital, and parietal lobes during the elementary school years contribute to a child's overall cognitive development?", 'The brain growth spurts experienced in childhood tend to follow Piaget’s sequence of cognitive development, so that significant changes in neural functioning account for cognitive advances (Kolb & Whishaw, 2009; Overman, Bachevalier, Turner, & Peuster, 1992).']

['Teacher: How does motor development progress in infants?', 'Motor development occurs in an orderly sequence as infants move from reflexive reactions (e.g., sucking and rooting) to more advanced motor functioning.']

['Teacher: Can you describe the order in which infants develop their motor skills, starting from reflexive reactions and progressing to more advanced functionalities?', 'For instance, babies first learn to hold their heads up, then to sit with assistance, and then to sit unassisted, followed later by crawling and then walking.']
['Teacher: Can you explain what the term "motor skills" refers to?', 'Motor skills refer to our ability to move our bodies and manipulate objects.']

['Teacher: Great explanation! Can you provide an example of a fine motor skill that involves coordination of small actions?', 'Fine motor skills focus on the muscles in our fingers, toes, and eyes, and enable coordination of small actions (e.g., grasping a toy, writing with a pencil, and using a spoon).']

["Teacher: That's correct! Can you give me an example of a gross motor skill?", 'Gross motor skills focus on large muscle groups that control our arms and legs and involve larger movements (e.g., balancing, running, and jumping).']

['Teacher: Can you provide some examples of the developmental milestones that young children should achieve as their motor skills develop?', 'As motor skills develop, there are certain developmental milestones that young children should achieve.']
['Teacher: What do you mean by "developmental milestones"?', 'For each milestone there is an average age, as well as a range of ages in which the milestone should be reached.']
['Teacher: Can you explain how sitting is a developmental milestone in terms of motor skills for young children?', 'An example of a developmental milestone is sitting.']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a motor skill that typically develops before the milestone of sitting?', 'On average, most babies sit alone at 7 months old.']

['What are some factors that contribute to the development of coordination and muscle strength in young children?', 'Sitting involves both coordination and muscle strength, and 90% of babies achieve this milestone between 5 and 9 months old.']

['What are some other examples of developmental milestones related to motor skills that young children typically achieve?', 'In another example, babies on average are able to hold up their head at 6 weeks old, and 90% of babies achieve this between 3 weeks and 4 months old.']
['What does it mean when a young child shows a delay in achieving a developmental milestone?', 'If a baby is not holding up their head by 4 months old, they are showing a delay.']

["What steps can parents or caregivers take if they notice a delay in their child's achievement of developmental milestones?", 'If the child is displaying delays on several milestones, that is reason for concern, and the parent or caregiver should discuss this with the child’s pediatrician.']
['What are some possible interventions for addressing developmental delays in young children?', 'Some developmental delays can be identified and addressed through early intervention.']

['Teacher: What are some examples of cognitive abilities that young children exhibit alongside their rapid physical growth?', 'In addition to rapid physical growth, young children also exhibit significant development of their cognitive abilities.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a cognitive ability that young children demonstrate regarding objects, as discussed by Piaget?', 'Piaget thought that children’s ability to understand objects—such as learning that a rattle makes a noise when shaken—was a cognitive skill that develops slowly as a child matures and interacts with the environment.']

["Teacher: Why do developmental psychologists today believe that Piaget's view on children's understanding of objects was incorrect?", 'Today, developmental psychologists think Piaget was incorrect.']

['Teacher: What evidence do researchers use to support the idea that young children understand objects and how they work before having experience with them?', 'Researchers have found that even very young children understand objects and how they work long before they have experience with those objects (Baillargeon, 1987; Baillargeon, Li, Gertner, & Wu, 2011).']

["Teacher: How do researchers test young children's understanding of objects and how they work without them having prior experience with those objects?", 'For example, children as young as 3 months old demonstrated knowledge of the properties of objects that they had only viewed and did not have prior experience with them.']

["Teacher: What did the researchers observe about the infants' response to the truck rolling behind the screen in the study?\nStudent: The researchers observed that the infants looked longer when the truck rolled out from behind the screen and defied their expectations.", 'In one study, 3-month-old infants were shown a truck rolling down a track and behind a screen.']
['Teacher: What did the researchers find when they placed the box next to the track in the study?', 'The box, which appeared solid but was actually hollow, was placed next to the track.']
['Teacher: Why did the researchers expect the infants to have a longer gaze when the truck rolled out from behind the screen?', 'The truck rolled past the box as would be expected.']

['Why did the researchers expect the infants to have a longer gaze when the truck rolled out from behind the screen and encountered the box on the track?', 'Then the box was placed on the track to block the path of the truck.']
['What was the result of placing the box on the track to block the path of the truck in the study?', 'When the truck was rolled down the track this time, it continued unimpeded.']

["What does the infants' longer gaze when the truck rolled out from behind the screen and encountered the box on the track suggest about their understanding of objects?", 'The infants spent significantly more time looking at this impossible event.']
["What conclusion did Baillargeon (1987) come to regarding the infants' understanding of solid objects?", 'Baillargeon (1987) concluded that they knew solid objects cannot pass through each other.']

["Do Baillargeon's findings support or contradict Piaget's belief about young children's understanding of objects?", 'Baillargeon’s findings suggest that very young children have an understanding of objects and how they work, which Piaget (1954) would have said is beyond their cognitive abilities due to their limited experiences in the world.']

['Teacher: What kind of milestones can we expect children to reach besides physical milestones?', 'Just as there are physical milestones that we expect children to reach, there are also cognitive milestones.']

['Teacher: Can you give me an example of a cognitive milestone that children may reach?', 'It is helpful to be aware of these milestones as children gain new abilities to think, problem solve, and communicate.']

['Teacher: Can you provide another example of a cognitive milestone children may reach besides responding to verbal requests?', 'For example, infants shake their head “no” around 6–9 months, and they respond to verbal requests to do things like “wave bye-bye” or “blow a kiss” around 9–12 months.']

["Teacher: How does the ability to understand object permanence affect a child's cognitive development?", 'We can expect children to grasp the concept that objects continue to exist even when they are not in sight by around 8 months old.']

["Can you provide an example of how a child's understanding of object permanence may impact their behavior or play?", 'Because toddlers (i.e., 12–24 months old) have mastered object permanence, they enjoy games like hide and seek, and they realize that when someone leaves the room they will come back (Loop, 2013).']

["Teacher: How does a child's ability to point to pictures in books demonstrate their cognitive development?", 'Toddlers also point to pictures in books and look in appropriate places when you ask them to find objects.']
['Teacher: What is the age range of preschool-age children?', 'Preschool-age children (i.e., 3–5 years old) also make steady progress in cognitive development.']

['Teacher: Can you give me an example of a decision that preschool-age children can make on their own?', 'Not only can they count, name colors, and tell you their name and age, but they can also make some decisions on their own, such as choosing an outfit to wear.']

["Teacher: That's great! Can you give me an example of how preschool-age children demonstrate their understanding of basic time concepts and sequencing?", 'Preschool-age children understand basic time concepts and sequencing (e.g., before and after), and they can predict what will happen next in a story.']
["Teacher: That's impressive! Can you provide an example of how preschool-age children demonstrate their emerging sense of humor in stories?", 'They also begin to enjoy the use of humor in stories.']

['Teacher: How do preschool-age children demonstrate their ability to think symbolically and engage in pretend play?', 'Because they can think symbolically, they enjoy pretend play and inventing elaborate characters and scenarios.']
["What are some common examples of preschool-age children's blossoming curiosity?", 'One of the most common examples of their cognitive growth is their blossoming curiosity.']
['What is one common way that preschool-age children display their blossoming curiosity?', 'Preschool-age children love to ask “Why?”']
['Teacher: What is the specific cognitive change that occurs in children at this age?', 'An important cognitive change occurs in children this age.']

['Teacher: What is meant by the term "egocentric" as used by Piaget to describe 2-3 year olds?', 'Recall that Piaget described 2–3 year olds as egocentric, meaning that they do not have an awareness of others’ points of view.']

["Teacher: How does children's understanding of others' points of view change between the ages of 2 and 5?", 'Between 3 and 5 years old, children come to understand that people have thoughts, feelings, and beliefs that are different from their own.']
["What is theory-of-mind (TOM) and how does it relate to children's cognitive development?", 'This is known as theory-of-mind (TOM).']

['What are some examples of how children can use their theory-of-mind (TOM) skills in their everyday interactions?', 'Children can use this skill to tease others, persuade their parents to purchase a candy bar, or understand why a sibling might be angry.']

["How does the development of theory-of-mind (TOM) in children relate to their understanding of others' false beliefs?", 'When children develop TOM, they can recognize that others have false beliefs (Dennett, 1987; Callaghan et al., 2005).']
['Teacher: What is the age range when cognitive skills continue to expand in middle and late childhood?', 'Cognitive skills continue to expand in middle and late childhood (6–11 years old).']

['Teacher: What specific changes occur in thought processes during middle and late childhood when dealing with concrete information?', 'Thought processes become more logical and organized when dealing with concrete information.']

["Teacher: How does understanding concepts such as the past, present, and future in middle and late childhood contribute to children's ability to plan and work toward goals?", 'Children at this age understand concepts such as the past, present, and future, giving them the ability to plan and work toward goals.']

['Teacher: What are some examples of complex ideas that children in middle and late childhood can process?', 'Additionally, they can process complex ideas such as addition and subtraction and cause-and-effect relationships.']

["Teacher: How does the development of attention spans in middle and late childhood impact children's ability to engage in tasks and activities?", 'However, children’s attention spans tend to be very limited until they are around 11 years old.']
["How does the improvement of attention spans in middle and late childhood impact children's ability to engage in tasks and activities?", 'After that point, it begins to improve through adulthood.']
['Teacher: What is one aspect of cognitive development that has been well-researched?', 'One well-researched aspect of cognitive development is language acquisition.']

["Teacher: Can you provide an example of how language acquisition follows a consistent order in children's cognitive development?", 'As mentioned earlier, the order in which children learn language structures is consistent across children and cultures (Hatch, 1983).']

['Teacher: How has research supported the idea that children have a biological predisposition for language acquisition?', 'You’ve also learned that some psychological researchers have proposed that children possess a biological predisposition for language acquisition.']
['Teacher: When does the development of language and communication skills usually begin for babies?', 'Starting before birth, babies begin to develop language and communication skills.']

["Teacher: What evidence supports the idea that babies can recognize their mother's voice and discriminate between languages from birth?", 'At birth, babies apparently recognize their mother’s voice and can discriminate between the language(s) spoken by their mothers and foreign languages, and they show preferences for faces that are moving in synchrony with audible language (Blossom & Morgan, 2006; Pickens, 1994; Spelke & Cortelyou, 1981).']

["Teacher: What is the significance of gesturing in children's language development?", 'Children communicate information through gesturing long before they speak, and there is some evidence that gesture usage predicts subsequent language development (Iverson & Goldin-Meadow, 2005).']
['Teacher: How does the usage of gesture influence subsequent language development in children?', 'In terms of producing spoken language, babies begin to coo almost immediately.']
["Teacher: What is the purpose of cooing in babies' language development?", 'Cooing is a one-syllable combination of a consonant and a vowel sound (e.g., coo or ba).']
['Teacher: How do babies replicate sounds from their own languages in their language development?', 'Interestingly, babies replicate sounds from their own languages.']

['Teacher: How does cooing differ among babies based on the language spoken by their parents?', 'A baby whose parents speak French will coo in a different tone than a baby whose parents speak Spanish or Urdu.']
['Teacher: What is the next stage in language development after cooing?', 'After cooing, the baby starts to babble.']
['Teacher: Why is babbling considered the next stage in language development after cooing?', 'Babbling begins with repeating a syllable, such as ma-ma, da-da, or ba-ba.']

['Teacher: At what age do we expect babies to start saying their first word for meaning?', 'When babies are about 12 months old, we expect them to say their first word for meaning, and to start combining words for meaning at about 18 months.']

["Teacher: What milestone in cognitive development occurs between 2 and 3 years of age regarding a toddler's language abilities?", 'At about 2 years old, a toddler uses between 50 and 200 words; by 3 years old they have a vocabulary of up to 1,000 words and can speak in sentences.']

['What are some examples of developmental milestones in language abilities that occur between the ages of 2 and 3?', "During the early childhood years, children's vocabulary increases at a rapid pace."]

['Teacher: How would you describe the "vocabulary spurt" that occurs between the ages of 2 and 3?', 'This is sometimes referred to as the “vocabulary spurt” and has been claimed to involve an expansion in vocabulary at a rate of 10–20 new words per week.']

['What do recent studies suggest about the universality of the "vocabulary spurt" between the ages of 2 and 3?', 'Recent research may indicate that while some children experience these spurts, it is far from universal (as discussed in Ganger & Brent, 2004).']

['What are some typical language abilities of 5-year-olds according to estimates?', 'It has been estimated that, 5 year olds understand about 6,000 words, speak 2,000 words, and can define words and question their meanings.']
['What are some examples of cognitive language abilities that 5-year-olds possess, in addition to rhyming and naming the days of the week?', 'They can rhyme and name the days of the week.']

['What are some examples of cognitive language abilities that seven-year-olds possess, in addition to speaking fluently and using slang and clichés?', 'Seven year olds speak fluently and use slang and clichés (Stork & Widdowson, 1974).']

['Teacher: According to behaviorist B.F. Skinner, how do we learn language?', 'Behaviorist B. F. Skinner thought that we learn language in response to reinforcement or feedback, such as through parental approval or through being understood.']

["Teacher: Can you provide an example of how parental approval can contribute to language learning, based on Skinner's theory?", 'For example, when a two-year-old child asks for juice, he might say, “me juice,” to which his mother might respond by giving him a cup of apple juice.']

["Teacher: According to Noam Chomsky's criticism of Skinner's theory, what did Chomsky propose about our ability to learn language?", 'Noam Chomsky (1957) criticized Skinner’s theory and proposed that we are all born with an innate capacity to learn language.']

['Teacher: What did Noam Chomsky refer to as a "language acquisition device" in his criticism of Skinner\'s theory on language learning?', 'Chomsky called this mechanism a language acquisition device (LAD).']
['Teacher: How does Chomsky\'s concept of the "language acquisition device" differ from Skinner\'s theory on language learning?', 'Both Chomsky and Skinner are right.']

['Teacher: Can you explain further how Chomsky\'s concept of the "language acquisition device" combines both nature and nurture in language learning?', 'Remember that we are a product of both nature and nurture.']

['Teacher: What evidence supports the idea that language acquisition is both inborn and learned through our interactions with the linguistic environment?', 'Researchers now believe that language acquisition is partially inborn and partially learned through our interactions with our linguistic environment (Gleitman & Newport, 1995; Stork & Widdowson, 1974).']

['Teacher: How does psychosocial development occur for children as described in the passage?', 'Psychosocial development occurs as children form relationships, interact with others, and understand and manage their feelings.']

['Teacher: What is the major social milestone of infancy in terms of social and emotional development according to the passage?', 'In social and emotional development, forming healthy attachments is very important and is the major social milestone of infancy.']
["Teacher: How does attachment contribute to a child's psychosocial development?", 'Attachment is a long-standing connection or bond with others.']

['What factors can influence the quality of attachment between a child and their caregiver, as discussed in the passage?', 'Developmental psychologists are interested in how infants reach this milestone.']

['Teacher: Can you tell me who conducted studies to answer questions about Attachment?', 'Researchers Harry Harlow, John Bowlby, and Mary Ainsworth conducted studies designed to answer these questions.']
["Teacher: What were the main objectives of Harlow's experiments on monkeys in the 1950s?", 'In the 1950s, Harlow conducted a series of experiments on monkeys.']
['Teacher: Why did Harlow separate newborn monkeys from their mothers in his experiments?', 'He separated newborn monkeys from their mothers.']
['What were the two types of surrogate mothers that Harlow used in his experiments?', 'Each monkey was presented with two surrogate mothers.']
["What was the other surrogate mother made out of in Harlow's experiments?", 'One surrogate monkey was made out of wire mesh, and she could dispense milk.']
['What did Harlow find when he observed the behavior of the monkeys towards the two surrogate mothers in his experiments?', 'The other monkey was softer and made from cloth:']
["How did the monkeys behave towards the cloth surrogate mother compared to the wire mesh surrogate mother in Harlow's experiments?", 'This monkey did not dispense milk.']

["Did Harlow's experiments suggest that the monkeys prioritized nourishment over comfort?", 'Research shows that the monkeys preferred the soft, cuddly cloth monkey, even though she did not provide any nourishment.']

["Why did the baby monkeys prefer to cling to the cloth monkey instead of the wire monkey in Harlow's experiments?", 'The baby monkeys spent their time clinging to the cloth monkey and only went to the wire monkey when they needed to be fed.']

["What was the significance of Harlow's findings on the monkeys' attachment behavior in relation to previous beliefs?", 'Prior to this study, the medical and scientific communities generally thought that babies become attached to the people who provide their nourishment.']

["What did Harlow's findings on the monkeys' attachment behavior suggest about the mother-child bond?", 'However, Harlow (1958) concluded that there was more to the mother-child bond than nourishment.']

["What are the critical components to maternal-infant bonding according to Harlow's findings on the monkeys' attachment behavior?", 'Feelings of comfort and security are the critical components to maternal-infant bonding, which leads to healthy psychosocial development.']

['Teacher: Who developed the concept of attachment theory, building on the work of Harlow and others?', 'Building on the work of Harlow and others, John Bowlby developed the concept of attachment theory.']
["What is John Bowlby's definition of attachment?", 'He defined attachment as the affectional bond or tie that an infant forms with the mother (Bowlby, 1969).']

['Why is it important for an infant to form a bond with a primary caregiver for normal social and emotional development?', 'An infant must form this bond with a primary caregiver in order to have normal social and emotional development.']

["What are the key factors that contribute to the formation and maintenance of the attachment bond throughout an individual's life, according to Bowlby?", 'In addition, Bowlby proposed that this attachment bond is very powerful and continues throughout life.']

['Can you explain what Bowlby meant by the concept of a secure base in the context of attachment?', 'He used the concept of secure base to define a healthy attachment between parent and child (1988).']
["What role does a secure base play in a child's exploration of their surroundings?", 'A secure base is a parental presence that gives the child a sense of safety as he explores his surroundings.']
['What are the two things that Bowlby said are needed for a healthy attachment?', 'Bowlby said that two things are needed for a healthy attachment:']

['What are the two things that Bowlby said are needed for a healthy attachment?', 'The caregiver must be responsive to the child’s physical, social, and emotional needs; and the caregiver and child must engage in mutually enjoyable interactions (Bowlby, 1969).']

["Teacher: What did Mary Ainsworth's research show about the process of attachment, contrasting with Bowlby's belief?", 'While Bowlby thought attachment was an all-or-nothing process, Mary Ainsworth’s (1970) research showed otherwise.']
['Teacher: What specific questions did Mary Ainsworth aim to answer through her research on attachment?', 'Ainsworth wanted to know if children differ in the ways they bond, and if so, why.']

['Teacher: How did Mary Ainsworth operationalize her research on attachment using the Strange Situation procedure?', 'To find the answers, she used the Strange Situation procedure to study attachment between mothers and their infants (1970).']

['Teacher: What are the different stages or episodes that occur within the Strange Situation procedure?', 'In the Strange Situation, the mother (or primary caregiver) and the infant (age 12-18 months) are placed in a room together.']

['Teacher: What happens after the caregiver and child spend some time alone in the room during the Strange Situation procedure?', 'There are toys in the room, and the caregiver and child spend some time alone in the room.']

["Teacher: What is the child's initial reaction when a stranger enters the room during the Strange Situation procedure?", 'After the child has had time to explore her surroundings, a stranger enters the room.']
["What is the child's response when the mother leaves her baby with the stranger during the Strange Situation procedure?", 'The mother then leaves her baby with the stranger.']
["What is the child's reaction when the mother returns to comfort her child during the Strange Situation procedure?", 'After a few minutes, she returns to comfort her child.']

['Teacher: What were the three types of parent-child attachments identified by Ainsworth based on how the infants/toddlers responded to the separation and reunion?', 'Based on how the infants/toddlers responded to the separation and reunion, Ainsworth identified three types of parent-child attachments: secure, avoidant, and resistant (Ainsworth & Bell, 1970).']

['What are the three types of parent-child attachments identified by Ainsworth based on how the infants/toddlers responded to the separation and reunion?', 'A fourth style, known as disorganized attachment, was later described (Main & Solomon, 1990).']
['What is the most common type of attachment, which is considered the healthiest?', 'The most common type of attachment—also considered the healthiest—is called secure attachment.']
['What type of attachment is characterized by the toddler preferring his parent over a stranger?', 'In this type of attachment, the toddler prefers his parent over a stranger.']

['What type of attachment involves the toddler using the attachment figure as a secure base to explore the environment and seeking them out during stressful situations?', 'The attachment figure is used as a secure base to explore the environment and is sought out in times of stress.']

['What is the Strange Situation experiment and what was the response of securely attached children when their caregivers returned?', 'Securely attached children were distressed when their caregivers left the room in the Strange Situation experiment, but when their caregivers returned, the securely attached children were happy to see them.']
['What are some characteristics of caregivers of securely attached children?', 'Securely attached children have caregivers who are sensitive and responsive to their needs.']

['Teacher: What are some characteristics of a child with avoidant attachment?', 'With avoidant attachment, the child is unresponsive to the parent, does not use the parent as a secure base, and does not care if the parent leaves.']
['Teacher: How does a child with avoidant attachment typically react when the parent leaves?', 'The toddler reacts to the parent the same way she reacts to a stranger.']
['Teacher: Why is a child with avoidant attachment slow to show a positive reaction when the parent returns?', 'When the parent does return, the child is slow to show a positive reaction.']

['What did Ainsworth theorize about the caregiver of children with avoidant attachment?', 'Ainsworth theorized that these children were most likely to have a caregiver who was insensitive and inattentive to their needs (Ainsworth, Blehar, Waters, & Wall, 1978).']

['Teacher: How do children with resistant attachment typically behave towards their attachment figure?', 'In cases of resistant attachment, children tend to show clingy behavior, but then they reject the attachment figure’s attempts to interact with them (Ainsworth & Bell, 1970).']

["Teacher: Why do children with resistant attachment typically reject the attachment figure's attempts to interact with them?", 'These children do not explore the toys in the room, as they are too fearful.']

['Teacher: How do children with resistant attachment typically react during separation in the Strange Situation?', 'During separation in the Strange Situation, they became extremely disturbed and angry with the parent.']
['Teacher: Why are children with resistant attachment difficult to comfort when the parent returns in the Strange Situation?', 'When the parent returns, the children are difficult to comfort.']

["Teacher: What is one possible explanation for the caregivers' inconsistent level of response to their child leading to resistant attachment?", 'Resistant attachment is the result of the caregivers’ inconsistent level of response to their child.']
['Teacher: How did children with disorganized attachment behave in the Strange Situation?', 'Finally, children with disorganized attachment behaved oddly in the Strange Situation.']

['Teacher: Can you elaborate on the specific behaviors that children with disorganized attachment exhibited in the Strange Situation?', 'They freeze, run around the room in an erratic manner, or try to run away when the caregiver returns (Main & Solomon, 1990).']
['Teacher: What are some common behaviors exhibited by children with disorganized attachment in the Strange Situation?', 'This type of attachment is seen most often in kids who have been abused.']
["Teacher: How does abuse affect a child's ability to regulate their emotions?", 'Research has shown that abuse disrupts a child’s ability to regulate their emotions.']
["Teacher: What has Ainsworth's research on attachment found in subsequent studies?", 'While Ainsworth’s research has found support in subsequent studies, it has also met criticism.']

["What are some of the criticisms that have been raised about Ainsworth's research on attachment in subsequent studies?", 'Some researchers have pointed out that a child’s temperament may have a strong influence on attachment (Gervai, 2009; Harris, 2009), and others have noted that attachment varies from culture to culture, a factor not accounted for in Ainsworth’s research (Rothbaum, Weisz, Pott, Miyake, & Morelli, 2000; van Ijzendoorn & Sagi-Schwartz, 2008).']

['Teacher: What is the primary psychosocial milestone of childhood?', 'Just as attachment is the main psychosocial milestone of infancy, the primary psychosocial milestone of childhood is the development of a positive sense of self.']
["Teacher: That's correct! Can you explain why infants don't have a self-concept?", 'Infants don’t have a self-concept, which is an understanding of who they are.']

['How does the behavior of infants in front of a mirror demonstrate their lack of self-concept?', 'If you place a baby in front of a mirror, they will reach out to touch their image, thinking it is another baby.']

["Teacher: That's right! How does the recognition of oneself in the mirror indicate the development of a self-concept in toddlers?", 'However, by about 18 months a toddler will recognize that the person in the mirror is themself.']

['How did the children in the experiment react to seeing the red dot on their noses in the mirror?', 'In a well-known experiment, a researcher placed a red dot of paint on children’s noses before putting them in front of a mirror (Amsterdam, 1972).']

["What was the researchers' purpose of placing a red dot on the children's noses before putting them in front of a mirror?", 'Commonly known as the mirror test, this behavior is demonstrated by humans and a few other species and is considered evidence of self-recognition (Archer, 1992).']

['What does the behavior of toddlers touching their own noses after seeing the red dot on their faces indicate about their self-concept development?', 'At 18 months old they would touch their own noses when they saw the paint, surprised to see a spot on their faces.']
['What is a specific example of how toddlers demonstrate self-recognition?', 'By 24–36 months old children can name and/or point to themselves in pictures, clearly indicating self-recognition.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the impact of self-concept on the social behavior of children from 2-4 years old?', 'Children from 2–4 years old display a great increase in social behavior once they have established a self-concept.']

['Teacher: What is one specific social behavior that children from 2-4 years old display once they have established a self-concept?', 'They enjoy playing with other children, but they have difficulty sharing their possessions.']

["Teacher: Can you elaborate on how children's exploration through play helps them understand their gender roles and label themselves as a girl or boy?", 'Also, through play children explore and come to understand their gender roles and can label themselves as a girl or boy (Chick, Heilman-Houser, & Hunter, 2002).']

['What are some specific social behaviors that children from 2-4 years old display once they have established a self-concept?', 'By 4 years old, children can cooperate with other children, share when asked, and separate from parents with little anxiety.']

['What are some examples of how children at 2-4 years old exhibit autonomy and initiate tasks once they have established a self-concept?', 'Children at this age also exhibit autonomy, initiate tasks, and carry out plans.']
['What are some factors that contribute to a positive sense of self in children from 2-4 years old?', 'Success in these areas contributes to a positive sense of self.']

['What do school-age children do to discover their competence in different areas and compare themselves to their peers?', 'Once children reach 6 years old, they can identify themselves in terms of group memberships: “I’m a first grader!” School-age children compare themselves to their peers and discover that they are competent in some areas and less so in others (recall Erikson’s task of industry versus inferiority).']

['What are some ways that children from 2-4 years old develop a positive sense of self?', 'At this age, children recognize their own personality traits as well as some other traits they would like to have.']
['What is an example of a specific trait or characteristic that children from 2-4 years old may recognize in themselves?', 'For example, 10-year-old Layla says, “I’m kind of shy.']
['What is Layla identifying as a trait in herself?', 'I wish I could be more talkative like my friend Alexa.”']
['Teacher: Why is the development of a positive self-concept important to healthy development?', 'Development of a positive self-concept is important to healthy development.']

['Teacher: Can you provide any examples of how children with a positive self-concept benefit in their daily lives?', 'Children with a positive self-concept tend to be more confident, do better in school, act more independently, and are more willing to try new activities (Maccoby, 1980; Ferrer & Fugate, 2003).']

["Teacher: How does the formation of a positive self-concept in Erikson's toddlerhood stage contribute to children becoming confident in their abilities?", 'Formation of a positive self-concept begins in Erikson’s toddlerhood stage, when children establish autonomy and become confident in their abilities.']

['Teacher: How does the comparison of oneself to others in elementary school contribute to the development of self-concept?', 'Development of self-concept continues in elementary school, when children compare themselves to others.']

['Teacher: What are the potential negative effects of children comparing themselves to others in terms of self-concept development?', 'When the comparison is favorable, children feel a sense of competence and are motivated to work harder and accomplish more.']

["Teacher: How does the re-evaluation of self-concept in Erikson's adolescence stage contribute to the formation of identity in teenagers?", 'Self-concept is re-evaluated in Erikson’s adolescence stage, as teens form an identity.']

["Teacher: How can the internalization of messages regarding strengths and weaknesses contribute to the formation of self-concept in teenagers during Erikson's adolescence stage?", 'They internalize the messages they have received regarding their strengths and weaknesses, keeping some messages and rejecting others.']

['Teacher: What are some potential benefits or positive outcomes that can result from adolescents achieving identity formation?', 'Adolescents who have achieved identity formation are capable of contributing positively to society (Erikson, 1968).']
['Teacher: According to Diana Baumrind, what does she believe may be a factor in self-concept?', 'Diana Baumrind (1971, 1991) thinks parenting style may be a factor.']
["Teacher: Can you explain how parenting style relates to a child's self-concept development?", 'The way we parent is an important factor in a child’s socioemotional growth.']

["Teacher: What are the characteristics of each parenting style according to Diana Baumrind's theory?", 'Baumrind developed and refined a theory describing four parenting styles: authoritative, authoritarian, permissive, and uninvolved.']

["What are the characteristics of the authoritarian parenting style according to Diana Baumrind's theory?", 'With the authoritative style, the parent gives reasonable demands and consistent limits, expresses warmth and affection, and listens to the child’s point of view.']
["What are the characteristics of the permissive parenting style according to Diana Baumrind's theory?", 'Parents set rules and explain the reasons behind them.']

["What are the characteristics of the uninvolved parenting style according to Diana Baumrind's theory?", 'They are also flexible and willing to make exceptions to the rules in certain cases—for example, temporarily relaxing bedtime rules to allow for a nighttime swim during a family vacation.']

["What are the characteristics of the authoritative parenting style according to Diana Baumrind's theory?", 'Of the four parenting styles, the authoritative style is the one that is most encouraged in modern American society.']

["Based on the given dialog, the question to fulfill the <mask> place could be:\n\nTeacher: What are some positive outcomes associated with the authoritative parenting style according to Diana Baumrind's theory?", 'American children raised by authoritative parents tend to have high self-esteem and social skills.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a cultural context where the authoritative parenting style may not be preferred or appropriate?', 'However, effective parenting styles vary as a function of culture and, as Small (1999) points out, the authoritative style is not necessarily preferred or appropriate in all cultures.']
['Teacher: What are some characteristics of the parent in the authoritarian style of parenting?', 'In authoritarian style, the parent places high value on conformity and obedience.']

['Teacher: How does the parent in the authoritarian style of parenting tend to interact with their children?', 'The parents are often strict, tightly monitor their children, and express little warmth.']

['Teacher: In this passage, what is the main reason why authoritarian parents might not relax bedtime rules during a vacation?', 'In contrast to the authoritative style, authoritarian parents probably would not relax bedtime rules during a vacation because they consider the rules to be set, and they expect obedience.']

["Teacher: From the passage, what are some possible negative effects that the authoritarian parenting style can have on children's self-concept?", 'This style can create anxious, withdrawn, and unhappy kids.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why authoritarian parenting might be beneficial in certain ethnic groups?', 'However, it is important to point out that authoritarian parenting is as beneficial as the authoritative style in some ethnic groups (Russell, Crockett, & Chao, 2010).']

['Teacher: According to the passage, what is one ethnic group mentioned that may benefit from authoritarian parenting?', 'For instance, first-generation Chinese American children raised by authoritarian parents did just as well in school as their peers who were raised by authoritative parents (Russell et al., 2010).']
['Teacher: Could you please explain what is meant by "the permissive style of parenting"?', 'For parents who employ the permissive style of parenting, the kids run the show and anything goes.']
['What is the role of children in a permissive style of parenting?', 'Permissive parents make few demands and rarely use punishment.']

['What is a common characteristic of permissive parents in terms of their relationship with their children?', 'They tend to be very nurturing and loving, and may play the role of friend rather than parent.']

['What is an example of how permissive parents might handle bedtime rules?', 'In terms of our example of vacation bedtimes, permissive parents might not have bedtime rules at all—instead they allow the child to choose their bedtime whether on vacation or not.']

["In what ways does the permissive parenting style affect children's self-discipline and academic performance?", 'Not surprisingly, children raised by permissive parents tend to lack self-discipline, and the permissive parenting style is negatively associated with grades (Dornbusch, Ritter, Leiderman, Roberts, & Fraleigh, 1987).']

['What are some potential negative outcomes or behaviors associated with the permissive parenting style?', 'The permissive style may also contribute to other risky behaviors such as alcohol abuse (Bahr & Hoffman, 2010), risky sexual behavior especially among female children (Donenberg, Wilson, Emerson, & Bryant, 2002), and increased display of disruptive behaviors by male children (Parent et al., 2011).']
['What are some of the positive outcomes associated with children raised by permissive parents?', 'However, there are some positive outcomes associated with children raised by permissive parents.']

['What are some positive outcomes associated with children raised by permissive parents?', 'They tend to have higher self-esteem, better social skills, and report lower levels of depression (Darling, 1999).']

['Teacher: How would you describe the parenting style where parents are indifferent, uninvolved, and sometimes referred to as neglectful?', 'With the uninvolved style of parenting, the parents are indifferent, uninvolved, and sometimes referred to as neglectful.']
['What are some characteristics of the uninvolved parenting style?', 'They don’t respond to the child’s needs and make relatively few demands.']

['What are some possible reasons for parents exhibiting the uninvolved parenting style?', 'This could be because of severe depression or substance abuse, or other factors such as the parents’ extreme focus on work.']
['What are some potential consequences or outcomes for children who are raised by uninvolved parents?', 'These parents may provide for the child’s basic needs, but little else.']

['What are some common characteristics of children raised by uninvolved parents?', 'The children raised in this parenting style are usually emotionally withdrawn, fearful, anxious, perform poorly in school, and are at an increased risk of substance abuse (Darling, 1999).']

['Teacher: Can you explain what temperament refers to and how it influences our thoughts, behaviors, and reactions with the environment?', 'Temperament refers to innate traits that influence how one thinks, behaves, and reacts with the environment.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how a child with an easy temperament may regulate their emotions?', 'Children with easy temperaments demonstrate positive emotions, adapt well to change, and are capable of regulating their emotions.']

['Teacher: How might a child with a difficult temperament differ in their emotional regulation compared to a child with an easy temperament?', 'Conversely, children with difficult temperaments demonstrate negative emotions and have difficulty adapting to change and regulating their emotions.']

['Teacher: What are some potential challenges that parents, teachers, and other caregivers may face when dealing with children who have difficult temperaments?', 'Difficult children are much more likely to challenge parents, teachers, and other caregivers (Thomas, 1984).']

['Teacher: How might the different temperaments of children influence the type of parenting they receive from their parents and caregivers?', 'Therefore, it’s possible that easy children (i.e., social, adaptable, and easy to soothe) tend to elicit warm and responsive parenting, while demanding, irritable, withdrawn children evoke irritation in their parents or cause their parents to withdraw (Sanson & Rothbart, 1995).']
['Teacher: Can you explain what you mean when you say "Adolescence is a socially constructed concept"?', 'Adolescence is a socially constructed concept.']

['Teacher: How has the perception of adulthood changed in modern society compared to pre-industrial times, leading to the emergence of adolescence as a social construct?', 'In pre-industrial society, children were considered adults when they reached physical maturity, but today we have an extended time between childhood and adulthood called adolescence.']

['What are some of the key characteristics and milestones of adolescence that are discussed in the textbook?', 'Adolescence is the period of development that begins at puberty and ends at emerging adulthood, which is discussed later.']

['What are some of the factors that contribute to the social construction of adolescence in different cultures around the world?', 'In the United States, adolescence is seen as a time to develop independence from parents while remaining connected to them.']

['Can you explain why adolescence is seen as a distinct stage of development with predictable milestones in different cultures around the world?', 'The typical age range of adolescence is from 12 to 18 years, and this stage of development also has some predictable physical, cognitive, and psychosocial milestones.']
['Teacher: What is the specific event that marks the start of adolescence?', 'As noted above, adolescence begins with puberty.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why the onset and pace of puberty can vary among individuals, even though the sequence of physical changes is predictable?', 'While the sequence of physical changes in puberty is predictable, the onset and pace of puberty vary widely.']

['Teacher: What are some examples of specific physical changes that occur during puberty?', 'Several physical changes occur during puberty, such as adrenarche and gonadarche, the maturing of the adrenal glands and sex glands, respectively.']

['Teacher: Can you provide some examples of primary and secondary sexual characteristics that develop and mature during puberty?', 'Also during this time, primary and secondary sexual characteristics develop and mature.']

['What are some examples of secondary sexual characteristics that develop and mature during puberty?', 'Primary sexual characteristics are organs specifically needed for reproduction, like the uterus and ovaries in females and testes in males.']

['Teacher: Can you provide some examples of primary sexual characteristics that develop and mature during puberty?', 'Secondary sexual characteristics are physical signs of sexual maturation that do not directly involve sex organs, such as development of breasts and hips in females, and development of facial hair and a deepened voice in males.']

['What are some examples of specific events that mark the start of puberty for females and males?', 'Females experience menarche, the beginning of menstrual periods, usually around 12–13 years old, and males experience spermarche, the first ejaculation, around 13–14 years old.']

['Teacher: What is the term used to describe the sudden increase in height that individuals go through during puberty?', 'During puberty, people experience a rapid increase in height (i.e., growth spurt).']

['Teacher: Can you explain the approximate age range when females typically experience their growth spurt during puberty?', 'For females this begins between 8 and 13 years old, with adult height reached between 10 and 16 years old.']

['What is the approximate age range when males typically experience their growth spurt during puberty?', 'Males begin their growth spurt slightly later, usually between 10 and 16 years old, and reach their adult height between 13 and 17 years old.']
["Teacher: What are some factors that can affect an individual's height?", 'Both nature (i.e., genes) and nurture (e.g., nutrition, medications, and medical conditions) can influence height.']

['Teacher: Why can puberty be a source of pride or embarrassment among teenagers?', 'Because rates of physical development vary so widely among teenagers, puberty can be a source of pride or embarrassment.']

['Teacher: What are some advantages of early maturing boys compared to their later maturing peers?', 'Early maturing boys tend to be stronger, taller, and more athletic than their later maturing peers.']

['Teacher: What are some potential risks associated with early maturing boys?', 'They are usually more popular, confident, and independent, but they are also at a greater risk for substance abuse and early sexual activity (Flannery, Rowe, & Gulley, 1993; Kaltiala-Heino, Rimpela, Rissanen, & Rantanen, 2001).']

['Teacher: How might early maturing girls feel about their physical development?', 'Early maturing girls may be teased or overtly admired, which can cause them to feel self-conscious about their developing bodies.']

['Teacher: What are some potential risks associated with early maturing girls?', 'These girls are at a higher risk for depression, substance abuse, and eating disorders (Ge, Conger, & Elder, 2001; Graber, Lewinsohn, Seeley, & Brooks-Gunn, 1997; Striegel-Moore & Cachelin, 1999).']

['Teacher: How might late blooming boys and girls feel about their physical development?', 'Late blooming boys and girls (i.e., they develop more slowly than their peers) may feel self-conscious about their lack of physical development.']

['Teacher: What are some potential risks associated with late maturing boys?', 'Negative feelings are particularly a problem for late maturing boys, who are at a higher risk for depression and conflict with parents (Graber et al., 1997) and more likely to be bullied (Pollack & Shuster, 2000).']

['Teacher: What aspects of transgender and gender-nonconforming youth do psychologists and clinicians study in relation to physical development?', 'Psychologists and clinicians also study the impact of gender identity and the impacts of puberty on transgender and gender-nonconforming youth.']

['Teacher: Why is it important for psychologists and clinicians to study the impacts of gender identity and puberty on transgender and gender-nonconforming youth?', 'This is a relatively recent area of study, and the impacts should not be over-generalized.']

['Teacher: What does the research indicate about the impact of support for gender identity on the mental health of transgender and gender-nonconforming youth?', 'However, the research seems to indicate that transgender and gender-nonconforming youth who are supported in their identity do not have significantly higher incidences of depression or anxiety symptoms when compared to control groups, while those who are not supported exhibit more symptoms and risk factors (Olson, Durwood, & McLaughlin, 2016).']

['Teacher: How does the passage suggest that the expression and exploration of gender identity can vary?', 'Expression and exploration of gender identity can take many forms and manifest at different times depending on a wide array of factors.']
['Teacher: What is the status of the adolescent brain in terms of development?', 'The adolescent brain also remains under development.']
['Teacher: What happens to brain development during puberty in terms of cell growth in the frontal region?', 'Up until puberty, brain cells continue to bloom in the frontal region.']

['Teacher: Why do adolescents engage in increased risk-taking behaviors and emotional outbursts?', 'Adolescents engage in increased risk-taking behaviors and emotional outbursts possibly because the frontal lobes of their brains are still developing.']

["Teacher: How does the maturation of the frontal lobes of the brain potentially contribute to adolescents' increased risk-taking behaviors and emotional outbursts?", 'Recall that this area is responsible for judgment, impulse control, and planning, and it is still maturing into early adulthood (Casey, Tottenham, Liston, & Durston, 2005).']
['Teacher: What happens to thinking abilities during adolescence?', 'More complex thinking abilities emerge during adolescence.']

['What are some possible explanations for the emergence of more complex thinking abilities during adolescence?', 'Some researchers suggest this is due to increases in processing speed and efficiency rather than as the result of an increase in mental capacity—in other words, due to improvements in existing skills rather than development of new ones (Bjorkland, 1987; Case, 1985).']
['What are some characteristics of abstract thought that emerge during adolescence?', 'During adolescence, teenagers move beyond concrete thinking and become capable of abstract thought.']
['What are some examples of abstract thought that teenagers might exhibit during the formal operational thought stage?', 'Recall that Piaget refers to this stage as formal operational thought.']
