['What are some other characteristics of thinking during the formal operational thought stage?', 'Teen thinking is also characterized by the ability to consider multiple points of view, imagine hypothetical situations, debate ideas and opinions (e.g., politics, religion, and justice), and form new ideas.']

['How does thinking during the formal operational thought stage differ from concrete thinking?', 'In addition, it’s not uncommon for adolescents to question authority or challenge established societal norms.']

['Teacher: What is cognitive empathy also known as?', 'Cognitive empathy, also known as theory-of-mind (which we discussed earlier with regard to egocentrism), relates to the ability to take the perspective of others and feel concern for others (Shamay-Tsoory, Tomer, & Aharon-Peretz, 2005).']
['Teacher: When does cognitive empathy begin to increase?', 'Cognitive empathy begins to increase in adolescence and is an important component of social problem solving and conflict avoidance.']

['Teacher: What are some of the important roles of cognitive empathy, specifically in terms of social interactions and conflict resolution?', 'According to one longitudinal study, levels of cognitive empathy begin rising in girls around 13 years old, and around 15 years old in boys (Van der Graaff et al., 2013).']

['Teacher: How can having a supportive father positively influence cognitive empathy development in teenagers?', 'Teens who reported having supportive fathers with whom they could discuss their worries were found to be better able to take the perspective of others (Miklikowska, Duriez, & Soenens, 2011).']
['Teacher: How do adolescents continue to refine their sense of self as they relate to others?', 'Adolescents continue to refine their sense of self as they relate to others.']

['Teacher: What did Erikson describe as the main challenge for adolescents in terms of their sense of self?', 'Erikson referred to the task of the adolescent as one of identity versus role confusion.']

['Teacher: How does Erikson believe that adolescents navigate the challenge of identity versus role confusion?', 'Thus, in Erikson’s view, an adolescent’s main questions are “Who am I?” and “Who do I want to be?”']

["Teacher: How might adopting the values and roles that their parents expect for them impact an adolescent's sense of self?", 'Some adolescents adopt the values and roles that their parents expect for them.']

["Teacher: How might adopting the values and roles that their parents expect for them impact an adolescent's sense of self?", 'Other teens develop identities that are in opposition to their parents but align with a peer group.']
["Teacher: How do peer relationships influence an adolescent's sense of self?", 'This is common as peer relationships become a central focus in adolescents’ lives.']

['Teacher: Why do adolescents tend to pull away from their parents during the process of forming their identities?', 'As adolescents work to form their identities, they pull away from their parents, and the peer group becomes very important (Shanahan, McHale, Osgood, & Crouter, 2007).']

['Why do most teenagers report positive feelings toward their parents despite spending less time with them during the process of forming their identities?', 'Despite spending less time with their parents, most teens report positive feelings toward them (Moore, Guzman, Hair, Lippman, & Garrett, 2004).']

['What are some positive outcomes associated with warm and healthy parent-child relationships?', 'Warm and healthy parent-child relationships have been associated with positive child outcomes, such as better grades and fewer school behavior problems, in the United States as well as in other countries (Hair et al., 2005).']

['Teacher: What observation did G. Stanley Hall make about adolescent development that most teens today seem to contradict?', 'It appears that most teens don’t experience adolescent storm and stress to the degree once famously suggested by G. Stanley Hall, a pioneer in the study of adolescent development.']

["Teacher: According to the passage, what is the contradiction between G. Stanley Hall's observation and the experiences of most teens today regarding adolescent storm and stress?", 'Only small numbers of teens have major conflicts with their parents (Steinberg & Morris, 2001), and most disagreements are minor.']

["What are some examples of day-to-day issues that commonly lead to conflicts between teenagers and their parents, according to Barber's study?", 'For example, in a study of over 1,800 parents of adolescents from various cultural and ethnic groups, Barber (1994) found that conflicts occurred over day-to-day issues such as homework, money, curfews, clothing, chores, and friends.']

["What is the trend in the frequency of conflicts between teenagers and their parents as teenagers develop, according to Galambos and Almeida's research?", 'These types of arguments tend to decrease as teens develop (Galambos & Almeida, 1992).']
['What is the focus of the emerging research on the adolescent brain?', 'There is emerging research on the adolescent brain.']

['What is one specific aspect of adolescent behavior that Galvan, Hare, Voss, Glover, and Casey (2007) focused on in their study of the adolescent brain?', 'Galvan, Hare, Voss, Glover and Casey (2007) examined its role in risk-taking behavior.']

['What were some of the findings or conclusions that Galvan, Hare, Voss, Glover, and Casey (2007) drew from their study on the role of the adolescent brain in risk-taking behavior?', 'They used fMRI to assess the readings’ relationship to risk-taking, risk perception, and impulsivity.']

['What did Galvan, Hare, Voss, Glover, and Casey (2007) discover about the correlation between brain activity in the neural reward center and impulsivity/risk perception in their study on the role of the adolescent brain in risk-taking behavior?', 'The researchers found that there was no correlation between brain activity in the neural reward center and impulsivity and risk perception.']

["What were the researchers' findings regarding the correlation between brain activity in the neural reward center and risk-taking behavior in their study?", 'However, activity in that part of the brain was correlated to risk taking.']

['What did Galvan, Hare, Voss, Glover, and Casey (2007) find in their study regarding the correlation between brain activity in the neural reward center and risk-taking behavior?', 'In other words, risk-taking adolescents experienced brain activity in the reward center.']

['What does the research conducted by Galvan, Hare, Voss, Glover, and Casey challenge in terms of adolescent behavior compared to other age groups?', 'The idea that adolescents, however, are more impulsive than other demographics was challenged in their research, which included children and adults.']
['Teacher: What is the name of the next stage of development after the previous one?', 'The next stage of development is emerging adulthood.']

['What are the defining characteristics of emerging adulthood?', 'This is a relatively newly defined period of lifespan development spanning from 18 years old to the mid-20s, characterized as an in-between time where identity exploration is focused on work and love.']
['Teacher: Can you explain to me the different ways in which one could approach this question?', 'There are many ways to answer this question.']

["Teacher: That's correct! Now, can you elaborate on how the concept of emerging adulthood expands upon this legal definition of adulthood?", 'In the United States, you are legally considered an adult at 18 years old.']

['What are some factors that contribute to different definitions of adulthood according to sociology?', 'But other definitions of adulthood vary widely; in sociology, for example, a person may be considered an adult when they become self-supporting, choose a career, get married, or start a family.']

['What is the term used to describe the period of life between adolescence and full adulthood?', 'The ages at which we achieve these milestones vary from person to person as well as from culture to culture.']

['What are some examples of cultural differences in the timing of achieving adult milestones?', 'For example, in the African country of Malawi, 15-year-old Njemile was married at 14 years old and had her first child at 15 years old.']
['What is the term used to describe the period of life between adolescence and full adulthood in sociology?', 'In her culture she is considered an adult.']

['What are some other examples of adult responsibilities that children in Malawi take on at an early age?', 'Children in Malawi take on adult responsibilities such as marriage and work (e.g., carrying water, tending babies, and working fields) as early as 10 years old.']

['What are some factors that contribute to the delay of adulthood in Western cultures?', 'In stark contrast, independence in Western cultures is taking longer and longer, effectively delaying the onset of adult life.']

['Teacher: What factors contribute to the emergence of adulthood according to Arnett, 2000?', 'It seems that emerging adulthood is a product of both Western culture and our current times (Arnett, 2000).']

['What are some factors that allow individuals in higher income and industrialized countries to have the freedom to delay starting a career and family?', 'People in higher income and more industrialized countries are living longer, allowing the freedom to take an extra decade to start a career and family.']

['What role do changes in the workforce play in allowing individuals in higher income and industrialized countries to delay starting a career and family?', 'Changes in the workforce also play a role.']

['How do changes in the workforce affect the ability of young adults to immediately enter the workforce and climb the economic ladder compared to 50 years ago?', 'For example, 50 years ago, a young adult with a high school diploma could immediately enter the work force and climb the economic ladder.']
['How do changes in the workforce now impact the opportunities for young adults with a high school diploma to enter the workforce and climb the economic ladder?', 'That is no longer the case.']

["What has become increasingly necessary in today's workforce, even for entry-level jobs, compared to the past according to Arnett, 2000?", 'Bachelor’s and even graduate degrees are required more and more often—even for entry-level jobs (Arnett, 2000).']

["What are some reasons why students are taking longer to complete a college degree in today's workforce?", 'In addition, many students are taking longer (five or six years) to complete a college degree as a result of working and going to school at the same time.']

['What are some challenges that young adults face after graduation that may lead them to return to the family home?', 'After graduation, many young adults return to the family home because they have difficulty finding a job.']

['What term is used to describe recent college graduates who often return to their parental home due to lack of employment?', 'The term Boomerang Generation describes recent college graduates for whom lack of adequate employment upon college graduation often leads to a return to the parental home (Davidson, 2014).']

['Why are changing cultural expectations considered to be the most important reason for the delay in entering adult roles?', 'Changing cultural expectations may be the most important reason for the delay in entering adult roles.']

['What is one of the reasons why young people today are delaying marriage and work?', 'Young people are spending more time exploring their options, so they are delaying marriage and work as they change majors and jobs multiple times, putting them on a much later timetable than their parents (Arnett, 2000).']
['Teacher: Can you please tell me what age range is considered to be the beginning of adulthood?', 'Adulthood begins around 20 years old and has three distinct stages: early, middle, and late.']
['What are the three distinct stages of adulthood?', 'Each stage brings its own set of rewards and challenges.']

['Teacher: What happens to our physical maturation by the time we reach early adulthood?', 'By the time we reach early adulthood (20 to early 40s), our physical maturation is complete, although our height and weight may increase slightly.']

['Teacher: How does our physical abilities change during young adulthood?', 'In young adulthood, our physical abilities are at their peak, including muscle strength, reaction time, sensory abilities, and cardiac functioning.']
['Teacher: What is the significance of young adulthood in terms of physical abilities for professional athletes?', 'Most professional athletes are at the top of their game during this stage.']

['What are some physical changes that women may experience during young adulthood?', 'Many women have children in the young adulthood years, so they may see additional weight gain and breast changes.']
['Teacher: Can you please tell me the age range for middle adulthood?', 'Middle adulthood extends from the 40s to the 60s.']
['Teacher: What can you tell me about the process of physical decline during middle adulthood?', 'Physical decline is gradual.']

['Teacher: Besides changes in the skin, can you provide an example of another physical change that occurs during middle adulthood?', 'The skin loses some elasticity, and wrinkles are among the first signs of aging.']
['Teacher: Can you explain how visual acuity changes during middle adulthood?', 'Visual acuity decreases during this time.']

['What is the age range for menopause, the end of the menstrual cycle, in women during middle adulthood?', 'Women experience a gradual decline in fertility as they approach the onset of menopause, the end of the menstrual cycle, around 50 years old.']

['What are some physical changes that tend to occur in both men and women during middle adulthood?', 'Both men and women tend to gain weight: in the abdominal area for men and in the hips and thighs for women.']
['What are some physical changes that are commonly observed in hair during middle adulthood?', 'Hair begins to thin and turn gray.']
['Teacher: What is the age range for late adulthood?', 'Late adulthood is considered to extend from the 60s on.']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a physical change that may occur during late adulthood?', 'This is the last stage of physical change.']

["Teacher: That's correct. Can you explain how the loss of elasticity in the skin affects an individual's physical appearance during late adulthood?", 'The skin continues to lose elasticity, reaction time slows further, and muscle strength diminishes.']
['Teacher: How do the senses, such as smell, taste, hearing, and vision, change during late adulthood?', 'Smell, taste, hearing, and vision, so sharp in our twenties, decline significantly.']

['What are some potential cognitive changes that may occur during late adulthood?', 'The brain may also no longer function at optimal levels, leading to problems like memory loss, dementia, and Alzheimer’s disease in later years.']
['Teacher: Why are cognitive changes numerous during adulthood?', 'Because we spend so many years in adulthood (more than any other stage), cognitive changes are numerous.']

['What does research suggest about the complexity and activity of adult cognitive development compared to cognitive development in infancy and early childhood?', 'In fact, research suggests that adult cognitive development is a complex, ever changing process that may be even more active than cognitive development in infancy and early childhood (Fischer, Yan, & Stewart, 2003).']

['Teacher: What is unique about our cognitive abilities compared to our physical abilities as we age?', 'Unlike our physical abilities, which peak in our mid-20s and then begin a slow decline, our cognitive abilities remain steady throughout early and middle adulthood.']

['Teacher: What is the term used to describe the information, skills, and strategies that we gather through a lifetime of experience?', 'Our crystallized intelligence (information, skills, and strategies we have gathered through a lifetime of experience) tends to hold steady as we age—it may even improve.']

['What is the pattern of change in our cognitive abilities as we age, according to the passage?', 'For example, adults show relatively stable to increasing scores on intelligence tests until their mid-30s to mid-50s (Bayley & Oden, 1955).']

['What are some examples of cognitive abilities that show relatively stable to increasing scores until our mid-30s to mid-50s?', 'However, in late adulthood we begin to experience a decline in another area of our cognitive abilities—fluid intelligence (information processing abilities, reasoning, and memory).']
['What specific processes in our cognitive abilities become slower as we enter late adulthood?', 'These processes become slower.']
['What factors seem to influence the decline in cognitive abilities in late adulthood?', 'Mental and physical activity seems to play a part.']

['How does engaging in mentally and physically stimulating activities impact cognitive decline in late adulthood?', 'Research has found adults who engage in mentally and physically stimulating activities experience less cognitive decline and have a reduced incidence of mild cognitive impairment and dementia (Hertzog, Kramer, Wilson, & Lindenberger, 2009; Larson et al., 2006; Podewils et al., 2005).']

['Teacher: What has been the focus of researchers when examining the aging brain in relation to brain functioning in younger individuals?', 'Researchers have examined the aging brain by comparing it to brain functioning in younger people.']

["What were the findings of Forstmann and colleagues' study comparing elderly participants to younger participants in terms of their ability to report the direction of movement of a set of dots?", 'Forstmann and colleagues (2011) compared elderly participants to younger participants, who in the study were asked to report the direction of movement of a set of dots.']

["What were the results or outcomes of Forstmann and colleagues' study in terms of the elderly participants' ability to report the direction of movement of the dots?", 'They were given feedback regarding speed and accuracy.']

["What specific brain areas were found to be affected in older participants as a result of the degeneration of corticostriatal connections in Forstmann and colleagues' study?", 'The researchers found that older participants made more errors and were slower due to degeneration of corticostriatal connections.']

["What is one potential implication of the findings from Forstmann and colleagues' study on the cognitive abilities of older individuals?", 'In other words, the decreased ability typically assigned to elderly people may be due to circumstances in the brain beyond their control.']

['What similarities in spatial representation have other researchers found when comparing children aged 6-7 to individuals over the age of 80?', 'Interestingly, other researchers have found similarities in spatial representations when comparing children aged 6–7 to those over the age of 80.']

['What is the reason behind the similarities in spatial representations observed between children aged 6-7 and individuals over the age of 80 according to Ruggiero, D’Errico, and Iachini (2016)?', 'Ruggiero, D’Errico, and Iachini (2016) reported that this is due to neurodegeneration in older adults and immature neurology in young children.']

['Teacher: What are some of the changes in the brain that negatively affect cognition in elderly people, also known as <mask>?', 'Many elderly people experience dementia, changes in the brain that negatively affect cognition.']

['What is another term used to describe the changes in the brain that negatively affect cognition in elderly people beyond dementia?', 'Alzheimer’s disease is one type of dementia, initially studied by medical researcher Solomon Carter Fuller.']
["What is the genetic basis of Alzheimer's disease?", 'Alzheimer’s disease has a genetic basis.']

["Teacher: What is the specific genetic factor that contributes to the development of Alzheimer's disease?", 'Plaques in the brain are due to cell death, which then causes those affected with the disease severe forgetfulness.']

["What are some of the specific consequences of severe forgetfulness caused by plaques in the brain in individuals with Alzheimer's disease?", 'A person can forget how to walk, talk, and eventually eat.']

["How can the risk of developing Alzheimer's disease be mitigated through environmental and nutritional factors?", 'The disease can be mitigated by assessing environmental factors (exposure to lead, iron, and zinc increase risk) and nutritional factors (the Mediterranean diet lowers risk) (Arora, Mittal, & Kakkar, 2015).']
["Are there any other methods or interventions that can help manage the symptoms or slow down the progression of Alzheimer's disease?", 'Although there is no cure, there is hope.']
['What is cognitive rehabilitation and how can it be used to offset mild cognitive impairment?', 'Cognitive rehabilitation can offset mild cognitive impairment, as it can evolve into dementia.']

['What were the findings of the study conducted by Garcia-Betances, Jimenez-Mixco, Arredondo, and Cabrera-Umpierrez (2015) on the use of virtual reality as a cognitive rehabilitative method for mild cognitive impairment?', 'Garcia-Betances, Jimenez-Mixco, Arredondo, and Cabrera-Umpierrez (2015) examined the use of virtual reality as a possible cognitive rehabilitative method.']

['What were some of the considerations identified by Garcia-Betances, Jimenez-Mixco, Arredondo, and Cabrera-Umpierrez (2015) for virtual reality technology used in cognitive rehabilitation?', 'They suggested that virtual reality technology should involve daily living activities, memory, and language, among other considerations.']
['Teacher: Can you provide me with an example of one of those theories?', 'There are many theories about the social and emotional aspects of aging.']
['Teacher: Can you explain how activities contribute to healthy aging?', 'Some aspects of healthy aging include activities, social connectedness, and the role of a person’s culture.']

["Teacher: How does finding meaning contribute to healthy aging according to George Vaillant's research?", 'According to many theorists, including George Vaillant (2002), who studied and analyzed over 50 years of data, we need to have and continue to find meaning throughout our lives.']

['Teacher: Can you provide any examples of how individuals in early and middle adulthood may find meaning through work and family life?', 'For those in early and middle adulthood, meaning is found through work (Sterns & Huyck, 2001) and family life (Markus, Ryff, Curan, & Palmersheim, 2004).']
["Teacher: What are the tasks of generativity and intimacy according to Erikson's theory?", 'These areas relate to the tasks that Erikson referred to as generativity and intimacy.']
['Teacher: How do adults tend to define themselves according to the passage?', 'As mentioned previously, adults tend to define themselves by what they do—their careers.']

['Teacher: How does job satisfaction relate to factors other than earnings, according to the passage?', 'Earnings peak during this time, yet job satisfaction is more closely tied to work that involves contact with other people, is interesting, provides opportunities for advancement, and allows some independence (Mohr & Zoghi, 2006) than it is to salary (Iyengar, Wells, & Schwartz, 2006).']

['Teacher: How have positive relationships with significant others in our adult years been found to impact our overall well-being?', 'Positive relationships with significant others in our adult years have been found to contribute to a state of well-being (Ryff & Singer, 2009).']

['Teacher: How do most adults in the United States identify themselves in terms of relationships with family members?', 'Most adults in the United States identify themselves through their relationships with family—particularly with spouses, children, and parents (Markus et al., 2004).']

['Teacher: How does research suggest that adult children tend to impact the well-being of their parents?', 'While raising children can be stressful, especially when they are young, research suggests that parents reap the rewards down the road, as adult children tend to have a positive effect on parental well-being (Umberson, Pudrovska, & Reczek, 2010).']

['Teacher: How does having a stable marriage contribute to well-being throughout adulthood?', 'Having a stable marriage has also been found to contribute to well-being throughout adulthood (Vaillant, 2002).']

['Teacher: What is one aspect of positive aging that is believed to contribute to social connectedness and social support?', 'Another aspect of positive aging is believed to be social connectedness and social support.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the socioemotional selectivity theory and how it relates to social support and friendships as we age?', 'As we get older, socioemotional selectivity theory suggests that our social support and friendships dwindle in number, but remain as close, if not more close than in our earlier years (Carstensen, 1992).']
['Teacher: That\'s true. In the textbook passage about 9-4 "Death and Dying," can you tell me what kind of topics or themes might be discussed?', 'Every story has an ending.']

["Teacher: Very well said. In the context of the passage, could you provide an example of how death is depicted as the end of one's life story in literature or art?", 'Death marks the end of your life story.']

["Teacher: That's a great point, and you're absolutely right. Can you elaborate on how our cultural and individual backgrounds influence our perception of death in different ways?", 'Our culture and individual backgrounds influence how we view death.']

['How might the acceptance and embracing of death as a natural part of life in some cultures influence the way they approach grieving and mourning?', 'In some cultures, death is accepted as a natural part of life and is embraced.']

['What impact can not informing someone about their impending death have on the individual and their loved ones?', 'In contrast, until about 50 years ago in the United States, a doctor might not inform someone that they were dying, and the majority of deaths occurred in hospitals.']

["Why do you think the creation of modern hospices, like Cicely Saunders's, was a significant step in how we approach death and dying?", 'In 1967 that reality began to change with Cicely Saunders, who created the first modern hospice in England.']

['How does the establishment of modern hospices affect the way people experience death and dying?', 'The aim of hospice is to help provide a death with dignity and pain management in a humane and comfortable environment, which is usually outside of a hospital setting.']
['What are some of the goals and principles of modern hospices in providing end-of-life care?', 'In 1974, Florence Wald founded the first hospice in the United States.']
['What are some of the goals and principles of modern hospices in providing end-of-life care?', 'Today, hospice provides care for 1.65 million Americans and their families.']

['How does receiving end-of-life care at home through hospice positively impact terminally ill individuals and their families?', 'Because of hospice care, many terminally ill people are able to spend their last days at home.']

['Teacher: Can you provide some evidence from research about the benefits of hospice care for both the patient and their family?', 'Research has indicated that hospice care is beneficial for the patient (Brumley, Enquidanos, & Cherin, 2003; Brumley et al., 2007; Godkin, Krant, & Doster, 1984) and for the patient’s family (Rhodes, Mitchell, Miller, Connor, & Teno, 2008; Godkin et al., 1984).']

['What is one reason that hospice patients report high levels of satisfaction with hospice care?', 'Hospice patients report high levels of satisfaction with hospice care because they are able to remain at home and are not completely dependent on strangers for care (Brumley et al., 2007).']

["Can you provide some evidence from research about the impact of hospice care on the length of a patient's life?", 'In addition, hospice patients tend to live longer than non-hospice patients (Connor, Pyenson, Fitch, Spence, & Iwasaki, 2007; Temel et al., 2010).']
["What are some ways in which hospice care benefits the patient's family?", 'Family members receive emotional support and are regularly informed of their loved one’s treatment and condition.']
["How does hospice care reduce the burden of care for the patient's family?", 'The family member’s burden of care is also reduced (McMillan et al., 2006).']

["In what ways does hospice care improve the patient's and the patient's family's quality of life?", 'Both the patient and the patient’s family members report increased family support, increased social support, and improved coping while receiving hospice services (Godkin et al., 1984).']

['Teacher: Who described the process of an individual accepting his own death?', 'Elizabeth Kübler-Ross (1969), who worked with the founders of hospice care, described the process of an individual accepting his own death.']

['Teacher: What are the five stages of grief proposed by Elizabeth Kübler-Ross in the process of an individual accepting their own death?', 'She proposed five stages of grief: denial, anger, bargaining, depression, and acceptance.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why the stages of grief proposed by Elizabeth Kübler-Ross may occur in different orders for different individuals?', 'Most individuals experience these stages, but the stages may occur in different orders, depending on the individual.']
['Can you explain why not all people experience all of the stages of grief proposed by Elizabeth Kübler-Ross?', 'In addition, not all people experience all of the stages.']

["Why is it important for psychologists to understand the connection between a dying person's acceptance of death and their progression through the stages of grief proposed by Elizabeth Kübler-Ross?", 'It is also important to note that some psychologists believe that the more a dying person fights death, the more likely they are to remain stuck in the denial phase.']

['Why is it important for psychologists to help dying individuals progress through the stages of grief proposed by Elizabeth Kübler-Ross?', 'This could make it difficult for the dying person to face death with dignity.']

['What are some potential benefits of allowing individuals to progress through the stages of grief proposed by Elizabeth Kübler-Ross at their own pace?', 'However, other psychologists believe that not facing death until the very end is an adaptive coping mechanism for some people.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why not everyone facing death or loss may experience the negative emotions described in the Kübler-Ross model?', 'Whether due to illness or old age, not everyone facing death or the loss of a loved one experiences the negative emotions outlined in the Kübler-Ross model (Nolen-Hoeksema & Larson, 1999).']

['What are some reasons why not everyone facing death or loss may experience the negative emotions outlined in the Kübler-Ross model?', 'For example, research suggests that people with religious or spiritual beliefs are better able to cope with death because of their hope in an afterlife and because of social support from religious or spiritual associations (Hood, Spilka, Hunsberger, & Corsuch, 1996; McIntosh, Silver, & Wortman, 1993; Paloutzian, 1996; Samarel, 1991; Wortman & Park, 2008).']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of someone who found meaning through death?', 'A prominent example of a person creating meaning through death is Randy Pausch, who was a well-loved and respected professor at Carnegie Mellon University.']

['Teacher: How did Randy Pausch find meaning through his terminal illness?', 'Diagnosed with terminal pancreatic cancer in his mid-40s and given only 3–6 months to live, Pausch focused on living in a fulfilling way in the time he had left.']

['Teacher: What message did Randy Pausch want to share in his last lecture?', 'Instead of becoming angry and depressed, he presented his now famous last lecture called “Really Achieving Your Childhood Dreams.”']

['Teacher: What were some of the key themes or topics discussed by Randy Pausch in his last lecture?', 'In his moving, yet humorous talk, he shares his insights on seeing the good in others, overcoming obstacles, and experiencing zero gravity, among many other things.']

["Teacher: How did Randy Pausch's perspective on death impact his outlook on the future?", 'Despite his terminal diagnosis, Pausch lived the final year of his life with joy and hope, showing us that our plans for the future still matter, even if we know that we are dying.']

['Teacher: Why do some individuals want to ensure that their wishes and desires are known in advance regarding medical procedures and practices?', 'As individuals become more knowledgeable about medical procedures and practices, some people want to ensure that their wishes and desires are known in advance.']

['Teacher: What is the main reason why individuals want their wishes and desires known in advance regarding medical procedures and practices?', 'This ensures that if the person ever becomes incapacitated or can no longer express themselves, their loved ones will know what they want.']

['Teacher: What are some examples of specific interventions that a person might include in a living will or advance directive?', 'For this reason, a person might write a living will or advance directive, which is a written legal document that details specific interventions a person wants.']

['Teacher: Why might a person in the last stages of a terminal illness choose not to receive life-extending treatments?', 'For example, a person in the last stages of a terminal illness may not want to receive life-extending treatments.']

['Teacher: What is another specific intervention that a person might include in a living will or advance directive besides the Do Not Resuscitate (DNR) Order?\nStudent: Another specific intervention that a person might include is a medical power of attorney, where they appoint someone to make medical decisions on their behalf if they are unable to do so.', 'A person may also include a Do Not Resuscitate (DNR) Order, which they would share this with family and close friends.']

['Teacher: What is the purpose of a Do Not Resuscitate (DNR) Order in a living will or advance directive?', 'A DNR Order states that if a person stops breathing or their heart stops beating, medical personnel such as doctors and nurses are not to take steps to revive or resuscitate the patient.']

['Teacher: What is the role of a health care proxy in a living will or advance directive?', 'A living will can also include a health care proxy, which appoints a specific person to make medical decisions for you if you are unable to speak for yourself.']

["Teacher: How can people's religion, culture, and upbringing influence their desire for living wills and DNRs?", 'People’s desire for living wills and DNRs are often influenced by their religion, culture, and upbringing.']
['Teacher: What is motivation?', 'Motivation describes the wants or needs that direct behavior toward a goal.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the difference between intrinsic and extrinsic motivations?', 'In addition to biological motives, motivations can be intrinsic (arising from internal factors) or extrinsic (arising from external factors) (Figure 10.2).']

['Teacher: How would you define intrinsic motivation?', 'Intrinsically motivated behaviors are performed because of the sense of personal satisfaction that they bring, while extrinsically motivated behaviors are performed in order to receive something from others.']
['Teacher: What are some reasons that motivate you to pursue an education?', 'Think about why you are pursuing an education.']
['Teacher: Can you explain what it means to be intrinsically motivated in pursuing an education?', 'If so, then you are intrinsically motivated.']

['Teacher: What are some examples of extrinsic motivations for pursuing an education?', 'However, if you are here because you want to get a college degree to make yourself more marketable for a high-paying career or to satisfy the demands of your parents, then your motivation is more extrinsic in nature.']

['Teacher: Can you explain how our motivations are often a combination of intrinsic and extrinsic factors?', 'In reality, our motivations are often a mix of both intrinsic and extrinsic factors, but the nature of the mix of these factors might change over time (often in ways that seem counter-intuitive).']

['Teacher: Can you give an example of how intrinsic motivation can outweigh extrinsic motivation in terms of job satisfaction?', 'There is an old adage: “Choose a job that you love, and you will never have to work a day in your life,” meaning that if you enjoy your occupation, work doesn’t seem like . . . well, work.']

['Teacher: Can you briefly explain the findings of the research conducted by Daniel & Esser (1980), Deci (1972), and Deci, Koestner, & Ryan (1999) that challenge the notion that intrinsic motivation always outweighs extrinsic motivation in terms of job satisfaction?', 'Some research suggests that this isn’t necessarily the case (Daniel & Esser, 1980; Deci, 1972; Deci, Koestner, & Ryan, 1999).']

['How do the findings of the research conducted by Daniel & Esser (1980), Deci (1972), and Deci, Koestner, & Ryan (1999) challenge the notion that intrinsic motivation always outweighs extrinsic motivation in terms of job satisfaction?', 'According to this research, receiving some sort of extrinsic reinforcement (i.e., getting paid) for engaging in behaviors that we enjoy leads to those behaviors being thought of as work no longer providing that same enjoyment.']

['How does the research conducted by Daniel & Esser (1980), Deci (1972), and Deci, Koestner, & Ryan (1999) suggest that the presence of extrinsic reinforcement can impact our motivation to engage in enjoyable behaviors?', 'As a result, we might spend less time engaging in these reclassified behaviors in the absence of any extrinsic reinforcement.']
["How might the absence of extrinsic reinforcement impact Odessa's motivation to engage in baking as a leisure activity?", 'For example, Odessa loves baking, so in her free time, she bakes for fun.']

["How might the absence of extrinsic reinforcement impact Odessa's motivation to engage in baking as a leisure activity after she stops working at the grocery store?", 'Oftentimes, after stocking shelves at her grocery store job, she often whips up pastries in the evenings because she enjoys baking.']

['What might be the impact of Odessa now getting paid for baking as part of her job in the bakery department on her motivation to engage in baking as a leisure activity?', 'When a coworker in the store’s bakery department leaves his job, Odessa applies for his position and gets transferred to the bakery department.']

["How does Odessa's new job in the bakery department impact her motivation to engage in baking as a leisure activity?", 'Although she enjoys what she does in her new job, after a few months, she no longer has much desire to concoct tasty treats in her free time.']

["How does the change in Odessa's motivation to engage in baking as a leisure activity relate to the concept of intrinsic and extrinsic motivation?", 'Baking has become work in a way that changes her motivation to do it (Figure 10.3).']

["How does the concept of the overjustification effect relate to Odessa's decrease in motivation to engage in baking as a leisure activity?", 'What Odessa has experienced is called the overjustification effect—intrinsic motivation is diminished when extrinsic motivation is given.']

["How can the overjustification effect impact a person's intrinsic motivation and reliance on extrinsic rewards?", 'This can lead to extinguishing the intrinsic motivation and creating a dependence on extrinsic rewards for continued performance (Deci et al., 1999).']

['Teacher: What do some other studies suggest about the vulnerability of intrinsic motivation to extrinsic reinforcements and the possible impact of verbal praise on intrinsic motivation?', 'Other studies suggest that intrinsic motivation may not be so vulnerable to the effects of extrinsic reinforcements, and in fact, reinforcements such as verbal praise might actually increase intrinsic motivation (Arnold, 1976; Cameron & Pierce, 1994).']

["What are some possible ways in which Odessa's motivation to bake in her free time could remain high, according to the passage?", 'In that case, Odessa’s motivation to bake in her free time might remain high if, for example, customers regularly compliment her baking or cake decorating skills.']
["Teacher: How can we make sense of the researchers' seemingly contradictory findings?", 'These apparent discrepancies in the researchers’ findings may be understood by considering several factors.']

["What are some factors that may help explain the apparent discrepancies in the researchers' findings?", 'For one, physical reinforcement (such as money) and verbal reinforcement (such as praise) may affect an individual in very different ways.']

["What are the different effects that physical reinforcement (such as money) and verbal reinforcement (such as praise) may have on an individual's motivation?", 'In fact, tangible rewards (i.e., money) tend to have more negative effects on intrinsic motivation than do intangible rewards (i.e., praise).']
["How does the expectation of an extrinsic motivator affect an individual's motivation?", 'Furthermore, the expectation of the extrinsic motivator by an individual is crucial:']

["What happens to an individual's intrinsic motivation for a task if they expect to receive an extrinsic reward?", 'If the person expects to receive an extrinsic reward, then intrinsic motivation for the task tends to be reduced.']

["What effect does the surprise presentation of an extrinsic motivation have on an individual's intrinsic motivation for a task according to Deci et al. (1999)?", 'If, however, there is no such expectation, and the extrinsic motivation is presented as a surprise, then intrinsic motivation for the task tends to persist (Deci et al., 1999).']
['Teacher: How does culture influence motivation?', 'In addition, culture may influence motivation.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how culture influences motivation, specifically in collectivistic cultures?', 'For example, in collectivistic cultures, it is common to do things for your family members because the emphasis is on the group and what is best for the entire group, rather than what is best for any one individual (Nisbett, Peng, Choi, & Norenzayan, 2001).']

['Teacher: How does the emphasis on the group rather than the individual in collectivistic cultures impact the motivation to do things for family members?', 'This focus on others provides a broader perspective that takes into account both situational and cultural influences on behavior; thus, a more nuanced explanation of the causes of others’ behavior becomes more likely.']

["Teacher: How does understanding the causes of others' behavior in collectivistic cultures contribute to a more nuanced explanation?", '(You will learn more about collectivistic and individualistic cultures when you learn about social psychology.)']

["Teacher: What factors in the classroom environment can foster students' intrinsic motivation to learn?", 'In educational settings, students are more likely to experience intrinsic motivation to learn when they feel a sense of belonging and respect in the classroom.']

['Teacher: How can the internalization of intrinsic motivation be enhanced in the classroom?', 'This internalization can be enhanced if the evaluative aspects of the classroom are de-emphasized and if students feel that they exercise some control over the learning environment.']

['Teacher: What are some ways that teachers can enhance intrinsic motivation in the classroom through the design of learning activities?', 'Furthermore, providing students with activities that are challenging, yet doable, along with a rationale for engaging in various learning activities can enhance intrinsic motivation for those tasks (Niemiec & Ryan, 2009).']

["Teacher: How might Hakim's sense of belonging and respect in the classroom contribute to his intrinsic motivation to learn?", 'Consider Hakim, a first-year law student with two courses this semester: Family Law and Criminal Law.']
["What are some aspects of Hakim's Family Law classroom that may diminish his sense of belonging and respect?", 'The Family Law professor has a rather intimidating classroom:']

["What impact might the intimidating and belittling behavior of Hakim's Family Law professor have on his intrinsic motivation to learn?", 'He likes to put students on the spot with tough questions, which often leaves students feeling belittled or embarrassed.']

["How might the emphasis on grades and public display of test results impact Hakim's intrinsic motivation to learn in his Family Law class?", 'Grades are based exclusively on quizzes and exams, and the instructor posts results of each test on the classroom door.']

["How might the facilitation of classroom discussions and respectful debates in small groups by Hakim's Criminal Law professor enhance his intrinsic motivation to learn compared to his Family Law class?", 'In contrast, the Criminal Law professor facilitates classroom discussions and respectful debates in small groups.']

["What impact might the facilitation of classroom discussions and respectful debates by Hakim's Criminal Law professor have on his intrinsic motivation to learn compared to his Family Law class?", 'The majority of the course grade is not exam-based, but centers on a student-designed research project on a crime issue of the student’s choice.']

["How might the student-designed research project in Hakim's Criminal Law class enhance his intrinsic motivation to learn compared to his Family Law class?", 'Research suggests that Hakim will be less intrinsically motivated in his Family Law course, where students are intimidated in the classroom setting, and there is an emphasis on teacher-driven evaluations.']

["What are some features of the classroom setting in Hakim's Criminal Law course that may contribute to his higher level of intrinsic motivation compared to his Family Law course?", 'Hakim is likely to experience a higher level of intrinsic motivation in his Criminal Law course, where the class setting encourages inclusive collaboration and a respect for ideas, and where students have more influence over their learning activities.']

['Teacher: Who is often referred to as the father of psychology in the United States?', 'William James (1842–1910) was an important contributor to early research into motivation, and he is often referred to as the father of psychology in the United States.']
['Teacher: What did William James theorize about behavior and its driving force?', 'James theorized that behavior was driven by a number of instincts, which aid survival (Figure 10.4).']
['What is the definition of an instinct from a biological perspective?', 'From a biological perspective, an instinct is a species-specific pattern of behavior that is not learned.']

['What were some of the points of controversy among James and his contemporaries regarding the definition of instinct?', 'There was, however, considerable controversy among James and his contemporaries over the exact definition of instinct.']

['What were some of the reasons for controversy among James and his contemporaries over the definition of instinct?', 'James proposed several dozen special human instincts, but many of his contemporaries had their own lists that differed.']

['What were some examples of human behaviors that William James proposed as true instincts during his era?', 'A mother’s protection of her baby, the urge to lick sugar, and hunting prey were among the human behaviors proposed as true instincts during James’s era.']

["What was a common critique of William James's view that human behavior is driven by instincts?", 'This view—that human behavior is driven by instincts—received a fair amount of criticism because of the undeniable role of learning in shaping all sorts of human behavior.']

['What is an example of an experiment that demonstrated that some instinctive behaviors result from associative learning?', 'In fact, as early as the 1900s, some instinctive behaviors were experimentally demonstrated to result from associative learning (recall when you learned about Watson’s conditioning of fear response in “Little Albert”) (Faris, 1921).']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of an early theory of motivation that emphasized the importance of maintaining homeostasis in influencing behavior?', 'Another early theory of motivation proposed that the maintenance of homeostasis is particularly important in directing behavior.']

['Teacher: Can you explain how the theory of homeostasis relates to maintaining a balance within a biological system?', 'You may recall from your earlier reading that homeostasis is the tendency to maintain a balance, or optimal level, within a biological system.']

['Teacher: How does the control center in a biological system regulate homeostasis based on the input it receives from receptors?', 'In a body system, a control center (which is often part of the brain) receives input from receptors (which are often complexes of neurons).']

['Teacher: What actions are taken by the control center to address any imbalance detected within a biological system?', 'The control center directs effectors (which may be other neurons) to correct any imbalance detected by the control center.']
['Teacher: What does the drive theory of motivation state about deviations from homeostasis?', 'According to the drive theory of motivation, deviations from homeostasis create physiological needs.']

['What are the consequences of deviations from homeostasis according to the drive theory of motivation?', 'These needs result in psychological drive states that direct behavior to meet the need and, ultimately, bring the system back to homeostasis.']

['What happens when your blood sugar levels drop below normal according to the drive theory of motivation?', 'For example, if it’s been a while since you ate, your blood sugar levels will drop below normal.']

['What is the purpose of the physiological need and corresponding drive state of hunger when your blood sugar levels drop below normal according to the drive theory of motivation?', 'This low blood sugar will induce a physiological need and a corresponding drive state (i.e., hunger) that will direct you to seek out and consume food (Figure 10.5).']
['What does eating do to your blood sugar levels according to the drive theory of motivation?', 'Eating will eliminate the hunger, and, ultimately, your blood sugar levels will return to normal.']

['What role do habits play in the type of behavioral response according to drive theory?', 'Interestingly, drive theory also emphasizes the role that habits play in the type of behavioral response in which we engage.']
['What is the emphasis of drive theory on the role of habits in behavioral response?', 'A habit is a pattern of behavior in which we regularly engage.']

['What is the likelihood of engaging in a behavior in the future after successfully reducing a drive according to drive theory?', 'Once we have engaged in a behavior that successfully reduces a drive, we are more likely to engage in that behavior whenever faced with that drive in the future (Graham & Weiner, 1996).']
['Teacher: What aspect do extensions of drive theory consider as potential motivators?', 'Extensions of drive theory take into account levels of arousal as potential motivators.']

['What is the main idea behind the extensions of drive theory in relation to levels of arousal as potential motivators?', 'As you recall from your study of learning, these theories assert that there is an optimal level of arousal that we all try to maintain (Figure 10.6).']
['What happens if we are overaroused according to these theories?', 'If we are underaroused, we become bored and will seek out some sort of stimulation.']
['What are examples of behaviors that we might engage in to reduce our arousal?', 'On the other hand, if we are overaroused, we will engage in behaviors to reduce our arousal (Berlyne, 1960).']

['What is the role of motivation in maintaining optimal levels of arousal according to the extensions of drive theory?', 'Most students have experienced this need to maintain optimal levels of arousal over the course of their academic career.']

['What can you infer about the relationship between stress and arousal levels based on the example of students experiencing the end of spring semester?', 'Think about how much stress students experience toward the end of spring semester.']

['How might the high levels of stress experienced by students at the end of the spring semester affect their levels of arousal?', 'They feel overwhelmed with seemingly endless exams, papers, and major assignments that must be completed on time.']

["What is the likely influence of the extended summer break on the students' levels of arousal after experiencing high levels of stress at the end of the spring semester?", 'They probably yearn for the rest and relaxation that awaits them over the extended summer break.']

['What might be some potential behaviors that students engage in to combat feelings of boredom during the extended summer break?', 'However, once they finish the semester, it doesn’t take too long before they begin to feel bored.']

["What can you conclude about the students' motivation to return to school in the fall based on their feelings of boredom during the extended summer break?", 'Generally, by the time the next semester is beginning in the fall, many students are quite happy to return to school.']

["What is the role of arousal theory in explaining the students' motivation to return to school in the fall after experiencing boredom during the extended summer break?", 'This is an example of how arousal theory works.']

['Teacher: According to research, what tends to happen to performance when arousal is very high or very low?', 'Research shows that moderate arousal is generally best; when arousal is very high or very low, performance tends to suffer (Yerkes & Dodson, 1908).']
['Teacher: Can you explain why moderate arousal is generally considered the optimal state for performance?', 'Think of your arousal level regarding taking an exam for this class.']

['Teacher: What is the expected outcome of having a very low arousal level, such as boredom and apathy, when taking an exam for this class?', 'If your level is very low, such as boredom and apathy, your performance will likely suffer.']
['Why is extreme anxiety considered detrimental to performance?', 'Similarly, a very high level, such as extreme anxiety, can be paralyzing and hinder performance.']
['What is the potential impact of having a moderate level of arousal on the performance of a softball team facing a tournament?', 'Consider the example of a softball team facing a tournament.']

['What can happen to the performance of a softball team if they have a lower level of arousal when facing a tournament?', 'They are favored to win their first game by a large margin, so they go into the game with a lower level of arousal and get beat by a less skilled team.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why optimal arousal level in the context of motivation is not simply about maintaining a middle level?', 'But optimal arousal level is more complex than a simple answer that the middle level is always best.']

['Teacher: What did Yerkes and Dodson discover about the optimal arousal level and its relationship to the complexity and difficulty of a task?', 'Researchers Robert Yerkes (pronounced “Yerk-EES”) and John Dodson discovered that the optimal arousal level depends on the complexity and difficulty of the task to be performed (Figure 10.7).']

['What is the relationship between arousal levels and task performance according to the Yerkes-Dodson law?', 'This relationship is known as Yerkes-Dodson law, which holds that a simple task is performed best when arousal levels are relatively high and complex tasks are best performed when arousal levels are lower.']

['Teacher: Can you explain what self-efficacy refers to?', 'Self-efficacy is an individual’s belief in their own capability to complete a task, which may include a previous successful completion of the exact task or a similar task.']

["Teacher: Who proposed the theory that an individual's sense of self-efficacy is crucial in motivating behavior?", 'Albert Bandura (1994) theorized that an individual’s sense of self-efficacy plays a pivotal role in motivating behavior.']

["Teacher: How does Bandura's theory suggest that self-efficacy influences motivation and goal-setting?", 'Bandura argues that motivation derives from expectations that we have about the consequences of our behaviors, and ultimately, it is the appreciation of our capacity to engage in a given behavior that will determine what we do and the future goals that we set for ourselves.']

["Teacher: Can you provide an example of how self-efficacy can impact an individual's behavior and persistence in achieving goals?", 'For example, if you have a sincere belief in your ability to achieve at the highest level, you are more likely to take on challenging tasks and to not let setbacks dissuade you from seeing the task through to the end.']

['Teacher: Who are some of the theorists that have conducted research on understanding social motives?', 'A number of theorists have focused their research on understanding social motives (McAdams & Constantian, 1983; McClelland & Liberman, 1949; Murray et al., 1938).']

['Teacher: Can you discuss some of the specific motives that McAdams & Constantian, McClelland & Liberman, and Murray et al. described in their research on understanding social motives?', 'Among the motives they describe are needs for achievement, affiliation, and intimacy.']
['Teacher: Why is the need for achievement considered important in driving accomplishment and performance?', 'It is the need for achievement that drives accomplishment and performance.']

['Teacher: How do the needs for affiliation and intimacy affect our relationships with others?', 'The need for affiliation encourages positive interactions with others, and the need for intimacy causes us to seek deep, meaningful relationships.']
['Teacher: Can you provide examples of the different domains in which Henry Murray et al. categorized these needs?', 'Henry Murray et al. (1938) categorized these needs into domains.']

['Teacher: Can you provide another example of a domain in which Henry Murray et al. categorized these needs, apart from ambition?', 'For example, the need for achievement and recognition falls under the domain of ambition.']

['Teacher: What were some of the needs that Henry Murray et al. categorized under the domain of human power?', 'Dominance and aggression were recognized as needs under the domain of human power, and play was a recognized need in the domain of interpersonal affection.']

['Teacher: What did Abraham Maslow propose in his hierarchy of needs?', 'While the theories of motivation described earlier relate to basic biological drives, individual characteristics, or social contexts, Abraham Maslow (1943) proposed a hierarchy of needs that spans the spectrum of motives ranging from the biological to the individual to the social.']
['Teacher: How did Abraham Maslow depict the hierarchy of needs in his theory?', 'These needs are often depicted as a pyramid (Figure 10.8).']
["Teacher: What types of needs are located at the base of Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs pyramid?", 'At the base of the pyramid are all of the physiological needs that are necessary for survival.']

['What are some examples of physiological needs that are located at the base of the pyramid?', 'These are followed by basic needs for security and safety, the need to be loved and to have a sense of belonging, and the need to have self-worth and confidence.']

["What is the top tier of Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs pyramid called, and when can it be realized?", 'The top tier of the pyramid is self-actualization, which is a need that essentially equates to achieving one’s full potential, and it can only be realized when needs lower on the pyramid have been met.']

['What is the importance of self-actualization according to Maslow and humanistic theorists?', 'To Maslow and humanistic theorists, self-actualization reflects the humanistic emphasis on positive aspects of human nature.']

['According to Maslow, what percentage of people actually achieve a self-actualized state?', 'Maslow suggested that this is an ongoing, life-long process and that only a small percentage of people actually achieve a self-actualized state (Francis & Kritsonis, 2006; Maslow, 1943).']

['Teacher: What is the concept that Maslow proposed regarding needs in his Hierarchy of Needs pyramid?', 'According to Maslow (1943), one must satisfy lower-level needs before addressing those needs that occur higher in the pyramid.']

["Teacher: Why is it important to satisfy lower-level needs before addressing higher-level needs, according to Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs pyramid?", 'So, for example, if someone is struggling to find enough food to meet their nutritional requirements, it is quite unlikely that they would spend an inordinate amount of time thinking about whether others viewed them as a good person or not.']

["Teacher: What is an example of a lower-level need that would take precedence over higher-level needs, according to Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs pyramid?", 'Instead, all of their energies would be geared toward finding something to eat.']

["What is one criticism of Maslow's theory of needs, as mentioned in the passage?", 'However, it should be pointed out that Maslow’s theory has been criticized for its subjective nature and its inability to account for phenomena that occur in the real world (Leonard, 1982).']

["What is one aspect of Maslow's theory that has been expanded upon in more recent research, as mentioned in the passage?", 'Other research has more recently addressed that late in life, Maslow proposed a self-transcendence level above self-actualization—to represent striving for meaning and purpose beyond the concerns of oneself (Koltko-Rivera, 2006).']

["What is an example of self-transcendence in relation to Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs pyramid as mentioned in the passage?", 'For example, people sometimes make self-sacrifices in order to make a political statement or in an attempt to improve the conditions of others.']

["What purpose did Mohandas K. Gandhi's hunger strikes serve in relation to Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs pyramid, as mentioned in the passage?", 'Mohandas K. Gandhi, a world-renowned advocate for independence through nonviolent protest, on several occasions went on hunger strikes to protest a particular situation.']

["What does this example of Mohandas K. Gandhi's hunger strikes illustrate in relation to Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs pyramid?", 'People may starve themselves or otherwise put themselves in danger displaying higher-level motives beyond their own needs.']

['Teacher: Why does a drive like <mask> exist in relation to eating?', 'Eating is essential for survival, and it is no surprise that a drive like hunger exists to ensure that we seek out sustenance.']

['What are some examples of the social, cultural, and economic influences that can impact hunger and eating?', 'While this chapter will focus primarily on the physiological mechanisms that regulate hunger and eating, powerful social, cultural, and economic influences also play important roles.']

['What are some of the adverse consequences of disordered eating that will be discussed in this section?', 'This section will explain the regulation of hunger, eating, and body weight, and we will discuss the adverse consequences of disordered eating.']
['Teacher: What role do these physiological mechanisms play in relation to hunger?', 'There are a number of physiological mechanisms that serve as the basis for hunger.']
['Teacher: Can you explain how the contraction of an empty stomach is a physiological mechanism related to hunger?', 'When our stomachs are empty, they contract.']
['Teacher: How does the contraction of an empty stomach lead to hunger pangs?', 'Typically, a person then experiences hunger pangs.']

['Teacher: How do the chemical messages that travel to the brain contribute to the initiation of feeding behavior?', 'Chemical messages travel to the brain, and serve as a signal to initiate feeding behavior.']

['Teacher: How do the chemical signals generated by the pancreas and liver when blood glucose levels drop contribute to the initiation of feeding behavior?', 'When our blood glucose levels drop, the pancreas and liver generate a number of chemical signals that induce hunger (Konturek et al., 2003; Novin, Robinson, Culbreth, & Tordoff, 1985) and thus initiate feeding behavior.']

['Teacher: What is the term used to describe the feeling of fullness and satisfaction after eating?', 'For most people, once they have eaten, they feel satiation, or fullness and satisfaction, and their eating behavior stops.']
['What are some examples of physiological mechanisms that regulate satiation?', 'Like the initiation of eating, satiation is also regulated by several physiological mechanisms.']

['What role do the pancreas and liver play in regulating satiation?', 'As blood glucose levels increase, the pancreas and liver send signals to shut off hunger and eating (Drazen & Woods, 2003; Druce, Small, & Bloom, 2004; Greary, 1990).']

['What are some other physiological mechanisms besides the pancreas, liver, and gastrointestinal tract that regulate satiation?', 'The food’s passage through the gastrointestinal tract also provides important satiety signals to the brain (Woods, 2004), and fat cells release leptin, a satiety hormone.']

['Teacher: Can you explain how the brain integrates the various hunger and satiety signals involved in the regulation of eating?', 'The various hunger and satiety signals that are involved in the regulation of eating are integrated in the brain.']

['What are some areas of the brain that are especially important for integrating hunger and satiety signals involved in the regulation of eating?', 'Research suggests that several areas of the hypothalamus and hindbrain are especially important sites where this integration occurs (Ahima & Antwi, 2008; Woods & D’Alessio, 2008).']
['What role does activity in the brain play in determining our feeding behavior?', 'Ultimately, activity in the brain determines whether or not we engage in feeding behavior (Figure 10.9).']

['Teacher: What are some factors that can influence our body weight, including gene-environment interactions and the balance between calories consumed and calories burned in daily activity?', 'Our body weight is affected by a number of factors, including gene-environment interactions, and the number of calories we consume versus the number of calories we burn in daily activity.']
['Teacher: How does our body respond when our caloric intake exceeds our caloric use?', 'If our caloric intake exceeds our caloric use, our bodies store excess energy in the form of fat.']
["Teacher: That's correct! Now, what happens when our caloric intake is less than our caloric use?", 'If we consume fewer calories than we burn off, then stored fat will be converted to energy.']

["Teacher: How does our body's metabolic rate affect our energy expenditure and body weight?", 'Our energy expenditure is obviously affected by our levels of activity, but our body’s metabolic rate also comes into play.']

['Teacher: How does individual variability in metabolic rates affect body weight?', 'A person’s metabolic rate is the amount of energy that is expended in a given period of time, and there is tremendous individual variability in our metabolic rates.']

['Teacher: How does the individual variability in metabolic rates relate to body weight and the ability to burn off calories?', 'People with high rates of metabolism are able to burn off calories more easily than those with lower rates of metabolism.']

["Teacher: What is the range within which most people's weights fluctuate, in the absence of extreme changes in diet and/or physical activity?", 'We all experience fluctuations in our weight from time to time, but generally, most people’s weights fluctuate within a narrow margin, in the absence of extreme changes in diet and/or physical activity.']

["What is the set-point theory of body weight regulation proposed in light of the observation that most people's weights fluctuate within a narrow margin?", 'This observation led some to propose a set-point theory of body weight regulation.']
['Why is the set-point theory of body weight regulation proposed?', 'The set-point theory asserts that each individual has an ideal body weight, or set point, which is resistant to change.']

['What are the compensatory changes in energy intake and/or expenditure that occur when we try to move our weight significantly from the set-point?', 'This set-point is genetically predetermined and efforts to move our weight significantly from the set-point are resisted by compensatory changes in energy intake and/or expenditure (Speakman et al., 2011).']

['Teacher: What can you tell me about the empirical support for the predictions generated from this particular theory?', 'Some of the predictions generated from this particular theory have not received empirical support.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example from the passage that challenges the predictions made by this theory regarding metabolic rate after significant weight loss?', 'For example, there are no changes in metabolic rate between individuals who had recently lost significant amounts of weight and a control group (Weinsier et al., 2000).']

['Teacher: What is one limitation of the set-point theory in explaining the influence of social and environmental factors on body weight?', 'In addition, the set-point theory fails to account for the influence of social and environmental factors in the regulation of body weight (Martin-Gronert & Ozanne, 2013; Speakman et al., 2011).']

['What are some other theories or explanations that researchers have proposed to account for the influence of social and environmental factors on body weight?', 'Despite these limitations, set-point theory is still often used as a simple, intuitive explanation of how body weight is regulated.']

['What are some other theories or explanations that researchers have proposed to account for the influence of social and environmental factors on body weight?', 'See Psychological Disorders for further discussion about eating disorders.']

['Teacher: What is the term used to describe someone who weighs more than what is generally accepted as healthy for a given height?', 'When someone weighs more than what is generally accepted as healthy for a given height, they are considered overweight or obese.']

['Teacher: How does the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) define being overweight based on body mass index (BMI)?', 'According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), an adult with a body mass index (BMI) between 25 and 29.9 is considered overweight (Figure 10.10).']

['What is the range of body mass index (BMI) that defines someone as overweight according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)?', 'An adult with a BMI of 30 or higher is considered obese (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention [CDC], 2012).']
['What term is used to classify individuals who are so overweight that they are at risk for death?', 'People who are so overweight that they are at risk for death are classified as morbidly obese.']
['What is the body mass index (BMI) threshold that defines someone as morbidly obese?', 'Morbid obesity is defined as having a BMI over 40.']

['What are some criticisms or concerns regarding the use of body mass index (BMI) as an assessment tool for determining healthy weight?', 'Note that although BMI has been used as a healthy weight indicator by the World Health Organization (WHO), the CDC, and other groups, its value as an assessment tool has been questioned.']

['What is one of the criticisms or concerns regarding the use of body mass index (BMI) as an assessment tool for determining healthy weight?', 'The BMI is most useful for studying populations, which is the work of these organizations.']

["Why is BMI less useful in assessing an individual's healthy weight?", 'It is less useful in assessing an individual since height and weight measurements fail to account for important factors like fitness level.']

["What is an example of a situation where BMI may not accurately assess an individual's healthy weight?", 'An athlete, for example, may have a high BMI because the tool doesn’t distinguish between the body’s percentage of fat and muscle in a person’s weight.']

['Teacher: What are some negative health consequences associated with being extremely overweight or obese?', 'Being extremely overweight or obese is a risk factor for several negative health consequences.']

['What are some of the specific health conditions or diseases that individuals who are extremely overweight or obese may be at a higher risk for?', 'These include, but are not limited to, an increased risk for cardiovascular disease, stroke, Type 2 diabetes, liver disease, sleep apnea, colon cancer, breast cancer, infertility, and arthritis.']

['What are some of the strategies or approaches being taken to address the issue of obesity in the United States?', 'Given that it is estimated that in the United States around forty percent of the adult population is obese and that nearly three-quarters of adults and one in six children qualify as overweight (CDC, 2018), there is substantial interest in trying to understand how to combat this important public health concern.']

['Teacher: According to the passage, what happens when more calories are consumed than expended?', 'You have already read that both genes and environment are important factors for determining body weight, and if more calories are consumed than expended, excess energy is stored as fat.']

["Teacher: That's correct. Can you provide an example of how socioeconomic status might contribute to the development of obesity?", 'However, socioeconomic status and the physical environment must also be considered as contributing factors (CDC, 2012).']

['Teacher: How might the lack of food options and high crime rates in a neighborhood contribute to the development of obesity?', 'For example, an individual who lives in a neighborhood with high crime rates and few food options may never feel comfortable walking or biking to work or to the local market.']

['Teacher: In addition to limited physical activity, what other factors might contribute to the development of obesity for individuals in neighborhoods with few food options and high crime rates?', 'This might limit the amount of physical activity in which they engage.']

['Teacher: How might relying primarily on fast food as the primary source of nutrition contribute to the development of obesity?', 'Similarly, some people may not be able to afford healthy food options from their market, or these options may be unavailable (especially in urban areas or poorer neighborhoods); therefore, some people must rely primarily on available, inexpensive, high fat, and high calorie fast food as their primary source of nutrition.']

['Teacher: How are people encouraged to maintain and improve health in relation to obesity?', 'Generally, people are encouraged to try to maintain and improve health through a combination of both diet and exercise.']
['What are some challenges that people face when trying to maintain and improve their health in relation to obesity?', 'While some people are very successful with these approaches, many are not.']

['What is bariatric surgery and when is it recommended in relation to obesity?', 'In cases in which a person has had no success with repeated attempts to reduce weight or is at risk for death because of obesity, bariatric surgery may be recommended.']

['What is the purpose or goal of bariatric surgery in relation to obesity?', 'Bariatric surgery is a type of surgery specifically aimed at weight reduction, and it involves modifying the gastrointestinal system to reduce the amount of food that can be eaten and/or limiting how much of the digested food can be absorbed (Figure 10.11) (Mayo Clinic, 2013).']

['What does the recent meta-analysis suggest regarding the effectiveness of bariatric surgery for obesity?', 'A recent meta-analysis suggests that bariatric surgery is more effective than non-surgical treatment for obesity in the two-years immediately following the procedure, but to date, no long-term studies yet exist (Gloy et al., 2013).']

['Teacher: What is the unique aspect of the portion of the population with eating disorders mentioned in the passage?', 'While nearly two out of three US adults struggle with issues related to being overweight, a smaller, but significant, portion of the population has eating disorders that typically result in being normal weight or underweight.']
['What is the physical characteristic of individuals with eating disorders mentioned in the passage?', 'Often, these individuals are fearful of gaining weight.']

['What are some health consequences that individuals with bulimia nervosa and anorexia nervosa face?', 'Individuals who have bulimia nervosa and anorexia nervosa face many adverse health consequences (Mayo Clinic, 2012a, 2012b).']

['Teacher: What is the typical behavior displayed by individuals with bulimia nervosa after binge eating?', 'People suffering from bulimia nervosa engage in binge eating behavior that is followed by an attempt to compensate for the large amount of food consumed.']

['What are two common compensatory behaviors displayed by individuals with bulimia nervosa after binge eating?', 'Purging the food by inducing vomiting or through the use of laxatives are two common compensatory behaviors.']

['What is another compensatory behavior that individuals with bulimia nervosa may engage in after binge eating?', 'Some affected individuals engage in excessive amounts of exercise to compensate for their binges.']

['What are some adverse health consequences that can be associated with bulimia nervosa?', 'Bulimia is associated with many adverse health consequences that can include kidney failure, heart failure, and tooth decay.']

['What are some psychological effects that individuals with bulimia nervosa may experience in addition to the adverse health consequences?', 'In addition, these individuals often suffer from anxiety and depression, and they are at an increased risk for substance abuse (Mayo Clinic, 2012b).']

['What is the estimated lifetime prevalence rate of bulimia nervosa for women and men?', 'The lifetime prevalence rate for bulimia nervosa is estimated at around 1% for women and less than 0.5% for men (Smink, van Hoeken, & Hoek, 2012).']
