['Teacher: Can you tell me which edition of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual recognized Binge Eating Disorder as a disorder?', 'As of the 2013 release of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual, fifth edition, Binge eating disorder is a disorder recognized by the American Psychiatric Association (APA).']

['Teacher: How does the recognition of Binge Eating Disorder in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual differ from bulimia in terms of behaviors following eating binges?', 'Unlike with bulimia, eating binges are not followed by inappropriate behavior, such as purging, but they are followed by distress, including feelings of guilt and embarrassment.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the key difference between binge eating disorder and overeating?', 'The resulting psychological distress distinguishes binge eating disorder from overeating (American Psychiatric Association [APA], 2013).']

['Teacher: Can you explain what anorexia nervosa is and how it is characterized?', 'Anorexia nervosa is an eating disorder characterized by the maintenance of a body weight well below average through starvation and/or excessive exercise.']

['Teacher: What are some of the methods used by individuals with anorexia nervosa to maintain a body weight well below average?', 'Individuals with anorexia nervosa often have a distorted body image, referenced in literature as a type of body dysmorphia, meaning that they view themselves as overweight even though they are not.']

['Teacher: Why is it important to recognize and address the distorted body image in individuals with anorexia nervosa?', 'Like bulimia nervosa, anorexia nervosa is associated with a number of significant negative health outcomes: bone loss, heart failure, kidney failure, amenorrhea (cessation of the menstrual period), reduced function of the gonads, and in extreme cases, death.']

['What are some of the significant negative health outcomes associated with anorexia nervosa?', 'Furthermore, there is an increased risk for a number of psychological problems, which include anxiety disorders, mood disorders, and substance abuse (Mayo Clinic, 2012a).']

['What are some of the psychological problems that individuals with anorexia nervosa may be at an increased risk for?', 'Estimates of the prevalence of anorexia nervosa vary from study to study but generally range from just under one percent to just over four percent in women.']
['What are some of the prevalence rates of anorexia nervosa in women according to different studies?', 'Generally, prevalence rates are considerably lower for men (Smink et al., 2012).']

['Teacher: Can you tell me which population tends to be the most at-risk group for both anorexia and bulimia nervosa, despite these eating disorders occurring in people from various cultures?', 'While both anorexia and bulimia nervosa occur in people from many different cultures, White females from Western societies tend to be the most at-risk population.']

['What age group of females is most at risk for anorexia and bulimia nervosa, according to recent research?', 'Recent research indicates that females between the ages of 15 and 19 are most at risk, and it has long been suspected that these eating disorders are culturally-bound phenomena that are related to messages of a thin ideal often portrayed in popular media and the fashion world (Figure 10.13) (Smink et al., 2012).']

['What are some factors, besides social influences, that may contribute to the development of eating disorders?', 'While social factors play an important role in the development of eating disorders, there is also evidence that genetic factors may predispose people to these disorders (Collier & Treasure, 2004).']
['Teacher: Why is it important to consider sex as an essential aspect of human life, similar to food?', "Like food, sex is an important part of many people's lives."]

["Teacher: That's correct! Can you explain how the perpetuation of the species is linked to the importance of considering sex as an essential aspect of human life?", 'From an evolutionary perspective, the reason is obvious—perpetuation of the species.']
['What are some other aspects of sexual behavior in humans besides reproduction?', 'Sexual behavior in humans, however, involves much more than reproduction.']

['Teacher: What does this research on human sexual behavior and motivation seek to understand?', 'This section provides an overview of research that has been conducted on human sexual behavior and motivation.']

['What are some concepts discussed in the section about human sexual behavior and motivation?', 'This section will close with a discussion of issues related to gender identity and expression and sexual orientation.']

['Teacher: Where does much of our knowledge about the physiological mechanisms underlying sexual behavior and motivation come from?', 'Much of what we know about the physiological mechanisms that underlie sexual behavior and motivation comes from animal research.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the specific role of the hypothalamus in the context of sexual behavior and motivation?', 'As you’ve learned, the hypothalamus plays an important role in motivated behaviors, and sex is no exception.']

["Teacher: How do lesions to the medial preoptic area of the hypothalamus affect a male rat's ability to engage in sexual behavior?", 'In fact, lesions to an area of the hypothalamus called the medial preoptic area completely disrupt a male rat’s ability to engage in sexual behavior.']

["Teacher: What is the finding regarding a male rat's willingness to work for sexual access after lesions to the medial preoptic area?", 'Surprisingly, medial preoptic lesions do not change how hard a male rat is willing to work to gain access to a sexually receptive female (Figure 10.14).']

['What does the finding suggest about the relationship between the ability to engage in sexual behavior and the motivation to do so?', 'This suggests that the ability to engage in sexual behavior and the motivation to do so may be mediated by neural systems distinct from one another.']

['Teacher: According to animal research, which limbic system structures have been found to be particularly significant for sexual motivation?', 'Animal research suggests that limbic system structures such as the amygdala and nucleus accumbens are especially important for sexual motivation.']

['What happens to sexual motivation when there is damage to limbic system structures such as the amygdala and nucleus accumbens?', 'Damage to these areas results in a decreased motivation to engage in sexual behavior, while leaving the ability to do so intact (Figure 10.15) (Everett, 1990).']

['What are some other research findings regarding the dissociation of sexual motivation and sexual ability in animals?', 'Similar dissociations of sexual motivation and sexual ability have also been observed in the female rat (Becker, Rudick, & Jenkins, 2001; Jenkins & Becker, 2001).']

['Teacher: What parallels can be drawn between human sexual behavior and the sexual behavior observed in rats, based on the research mentioned in the passage?', 'Although human sexual behavior is much more complex than that seen in rats, some parallels between animals and humans can be drawn from this research.']

['What evidence or examples from the passage support the idea that sexual motivation and the ability to engage in sexual behavior can be dissociated in humans?', 'The worldwide popularity of drugs used to treat erectile dysfunction (Conrad, 2005) speaks to the fact that sexual motivation and the ability to engage in sexual behavior can also be dissociated in humans.']

['Teacher: How does the passage suggest that hypothalamic function can impact sexual behavior in humans?', 'Moreover, disorders that involve abnormal hypothalamic function are often associated with hypogonadism (reduced function of the gonads) and reduced sexual function (e.g., Prader-Willi syndrome).']

['Teacher: Why is it not surprising that hormones secreted by the endocrine system play important roles in sexual motivation and behavior, based on the information provided in the passage?', 'Given the hypothalamus’s role in endocrine function, it is not surprising that hormones secreted by the endocrine system also play important roles in sexual motivation and behavior.']

['What is the significance of the appropriate combination of sex hormones from the gonads for sexual motivation in animals, according to the passage?', 'For example, many animals show no sign of sexual motivation in the absence of the appropriate combination of sex hormones from their gonads.']

['What evidence or examples from the passage support the claim that sexual motivation for all genders varies as a function of circulating testosterone levels?', 'While this is not the case for humans, there is considerable evidence that sexual motivation for all genders varies as a function of circulating testosterone levels (Bhasin, Enzlin, Coviello, & Basson, 2007; Carter, 1992; Sherwin, 1988).']

['Teacher: Why was access to reliable, empirically-based information on sex limited before the late 1940s?', 'Before the late 1940s, access to reliable, empirically-based information on sex was limited.']

['Teacher: What were physicians considered authorities on, despite their lack of training in these issues, before reliable information about sex became more accessible?', 'Physicians were considered authorities on all issues related to sex, despite the fact that they had little to no training in these issues, and it is likely that most of what people knew about sex had been learned either through their own experiences or by talking with their peers.']

['Why did Dr. Alfred Kinsey initiate large-scale survey research on issues related to human sexuality?', 'Convinced that people would benefit from a more open dialogue on issues related to human sexuality, Dr. Alfred Kinsey of Indiana University initiated large-scale survey research on the topic (Figure 10.16).']

['What were the titles of the two books that Dr. Alfred Kinsey published as a result of his large-scale survey research on human sexuality?', 'The results of some of these efforts were published in two books—Sexual Behavior in the Human Male and Sexual Behavior in the Human Female—which were published in 1948 and 1953, respectively (Bullough, 1998).']
['Teacher: How were the Kinsey reports perceived by the public during that time?', 'At the time, the Kinsey reports were quite sensational.']

["What was the impact of the Kinsey reports on the American public's perception of their private sexual behavior?", 'Never before had the American public seen its private sexual behavior become the focus of scientific scrutiny on such a large scale.']

['What was the result of the Kinsey reports being widely available to the general public?', 'The books, which were filled with statistics and scientific lingo, sold remarkably well to the general public, and people began to engage in open conversations about human sexuality.']

['What were some of the criticisms or objections raised by individuals regarding the wide dissemination of the Kinsey reports?', 'As you might imagine, not everyone was happy that this information was being published.']
['What were some of the reasons or justifications given by those who wanted to ban the Kinsey reports in certain countries?', 'In fact, these books were banned in some countries.']

['What was the outcome for Kinsey in terms of funding for his research due to the controversy surrounding the reports?', 'Ultimately, the controversy resulted in Kinsey losing funding that he had secured from the Rockefeller Foundation to continue his research efforts (Bancroft, 2004).']

["Teacher: How would you describe the impact of Kinsey's research on future studies of human sexual behavior and motivation?", 'Although Kinsey’s research has been widely criticized as being riddled with sampling and statistical errors (Jenkins, 2010), there is little doubt that this research was very influential in shaping future research on human sexual behavior and motivation.']

["What specific aspects of human sexual behavior and motivation did Kinsey's research shed light on?", 'Kinsey described a remarkably diverse range of sexual behaviors and experiences reported by the volunteers participating in his research.']

["What are some examples of the sexual behaviors that Kinsey's research revealed to be more common than previously believed?", 'Behaviors that had once been considered exceedingly rare or problematic were demonstrated to be much more common and innocuous than previously imagined (Bancroft, 2004; Bullough, 1998).']

["Teacher: What were some of the key findings of Kinsey's research regarding women's interest and experience in sex compared to men?", 'Among the results of Kinsey’s research were the findings that women are as interested and experienced in sex as men, that both males and females masturbate without adverse health consequences, and that relationships and sexual acts between people of the same sex and/or the same gender are fairly common (Bancroft, 2004).']

["What is one of the enduring contributions of Kinsey's research in the area of sexual orientation?", 'Kinsey also developed a continuum known as the Kinsey scale that is still commonly used today to categorize an individual’s sexual orientation, which is an individual’s emotional, romantic, and erotic attractions to other people or no people (Jenkins, 2010).']

['Teacher: What was the main purpose of the study conducted by Masters and Johnson, as described in the passage?', 'In 1966, William Masters and Virginia Johnson published a book detailing the results of their observations of nearly 700 people who agreed to participate in their study of physiological responses during sexual behavior.']

['What different research method did Masters and Johnson use compared to Kinsey in their study on physiological responses during sexual behavior?', 'Unlike Kinsey, who used personal interviews and surveys to collect data, Masters and Johnson observed people having intercourse in a variety of positions, and they observed people masturbating, manually or with the aid of a device.']

['What were some of the physiological variables and measurements of sexual arousal that Masters and Johnson recorded during their study on physiological responses during sexual behavior?', 'While this was occurring, researchers recorded measurements of physiological variables, such as blood pressure and respiration rate, as well as measurements of sexual arousal, such as vaginal lubrication and penile tumescence (swelling associated with an erection).']

['What were some of the key findings that Masters and Johnson discovered from their observations of nearly 10,000 sexual acts during their research on physiological responses during sexual behavior?', 'In total, Masters and Johnson observed nearly 10,000 sexual acts as a part of their research (Hock, 2008).']

['Teacher: Can you explain to me how Masters and Johnson divided the sexual response cycle into four phases?', 'Based on these observations, Masters and Johnson divided the sexual response cycle into four phases that are fairly similar in men and women: excitement, plateau, orgasm, and resolution (Figure 10.17).']

["What are the characteristics of the excitement phase in the sexual response cycle according to Masters and Johnson's research?", 'The excitement phase is the arousal phase of the sexual response cycle, and it is marked by erection of the penis or clitoris and lubrication and expansion of the vaginal canal.']

["What are the key features of the plateau phase in the sexual response cycle, as described by Masters and Johnson's research?", 'During plateau, the vagina swells further and blood flow to the labia minora increases, and the penis becomes fully erect and may exhibit pre-ejaculatory fluid.']
["What are the main characteristics of the orgasm phase in the sexual response cycle according to Masters and Johnson's research?", 'People experience increases in muscle tone during this time.']

["What are the typical features of the resolution phase in the sexual response cycle, as identified by Masters and Johnson's research?", 'Orgasm is marked in females by rhythmic contractions of the pelvis and uterus along with increased muscle tension.']

["What are the characteristic differences between the resolution phase in females and males, as described by Masters and Johnson's research?", 'In males, pelvic contractions are accompanied by a buildup of seminal fluid near the urethra that is ultimately forced out by contractions of genital muscles, (i.e., ejaculation).']

["What are the physiological changes that occur during the resolution phase, as explained by Masters and Johnson's research?", 'Resolution is the relatively rapid return to an unaroused state accompanied by a decrease in blood pressure and muscular relaxation.']

["What is the refractory period according to Masters and Johnson's research?", 'The refractory period is a period of time that follows an orgasm during which an individual is incapable of experiencing another orgasm.']

["What is the duration of the refractory period, as described by Masters and Johnson's research?", 'The duration of the refractory period can vary dramatically from individual to individual with some refractory periods as short as several minutes and others as long as a day.']

["What is the relationship between age and the duration of the refractory period, according to Masters and Johnson's research?", 'As people age, their refractory periods tend to span longer periods of time.']

["Teacher: What are some of the insights that Masters and Johnson's research provided about the sexual response cycle and the multi-orgasmic potential of females, in addition to collecting information about reproductive anatomy?", 'In addition to the insights that their research provided with regards to the sexual response cycle and the multi-orgasmic potential of females, Masters and Johnson also collected important information about reproductive anatomy.']

["What specific information did Masters and Johnson's research provide about the average size of a flaccid and an erect penis, and what beliefs did it dispel about the size of an erect penis in relation to sexual pleasure?", 'Their research demonstrated the oft-cited statistic of the average size of a flaccid and an erect penis (3 and 6 inches, respectively) as well as dispelling long-held beliefs about relationships between the size of an erect penis and its ability to provide sexual pleasure to a partner.']

["What other aspects of reproductive anatomy did Masters and Johnson's research explore, besides the size of the penis?", 'Furthermore, they determined that the vagina is a very elastic structure that can conform to penises of various sizes (Hock, 2008).']

["What are some criticisms, advancements, or findings that have challenged or built upon Masters and Johnson's research in the field of human sexuality?", 'In a similar manner to Kinsey’s work and other studies, Masters and Johnson’s research has been criticized, built on, and in some cases proven wrong.']

["What are some of the reasons why Masters and Johnson's research is not viewed as entirely accurate today?", 'The research represents an important element of the history of sexual research, and is not viewed as entirely accurate today.']

["Teacher: Can you provide some examples of the different aspects of a person's sexual orientation?", 'As mentioned earlier, a person’s sexual orientation is their emotional, romantic, and erotic attraction toward other people or no people.']

['Teacher: What are some specific sexual orientations that fall under the category of non-hetero sexualities?', 'While the majority of people identify as heterosexual, there is a sizable population of people within the United States who identify as lesbian, gay, bisexual, pansexual, asexual, or other non-hetero sexualities.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the difference between bisexual, pansexual, and asexual orientations?', 'Bisexual people are attracted to people of their own gender and another gender; pansexual people experience attraction without regard to sex, gender identity or gender expression; asexual people do not experience sexual attraction or have little or no interest in sexual activity.']

['Teacher: How does the term "queer" encompass different aspects of a person\'s sexual orientation, gender identity, or gender expression?', 'Queer is an umbrella term used to describe sexual orientation, gender identity, or gender expression.']

['Teacher: Can you provide some examples of descriptive terms that refer to a romantic attraction rather than a sexual one within the LGBTQ+ community?', 'Other descriptive terms may not refer to a sexual attraction, but rather a romantic one.']

['Teacher: Can you give me an example of a descriptive term within the LGBTQ+ community that specifically refers to a romantic attraction?', 'For example, an aromantic person does not experience romantic attraction; this is different from asexuality, which refers to a lack of sexual attraction.']
["What are some examples of sexual orientations that do not specifically refer to a person's gender?", 'And some sexual orientations do not refer to gender in their description (PFLAG, 2021).']

["Can you explain why it is important to acknowledge that sexual orientations exist on a spectrum and that there may not always be specific terms to describe someone's feelings?", 'It is important to acknowledge and understand that many of these orientations exist on on a spectrum, and there may be no specific term to describe how an individual feels.']

['Teacher: What is the significance of the term LGBTQ in relation to sexual orientation?', 'Some of these terms have been associated in abbreviations such as LGBTQ (lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and queer or questioning).']

['What other terms and identities are sometimes included in the LGBTQ+ acronym?', 'In some cases, people and organizations may add "I" to represent intersex people (described below), and "A" for asexual or aromantic people (or sometimes for "allies"), as well as one "P" to describe pansexual people and sometimes another "P" to describe polysexual people.']
['What does the plus sign (+) represent in the LGBTQ+ acronym?', 'Finally, some people and organizations add a plus sign (+) to represent other possible identities or orientations.']

['What is the importance of recognizing that each individual defines their own sexuality and gender identity within the LGBTQ+ community?', 'Sexuality and gender terminology are constantly changing, and may mean different things to different people; they are not universal, and each individual defines them for themselves (UC Davis LGBTQIA Resource Center 2020).']

["Teacher: What is the topic that scientists have been fascinated with in relation to individuals' characteristics?", 'Issues of sexual orientation have long fascinated scientists interested in determining what causes one individual to be straight while another is gay.']

['What did people believe for many years regarding the differences in sexual orientation?', 'For many years, people believed that these differences arose because of different socialization and familial experiences.']

['Teacher: What does research consistently demonstrate about the family backgrounds and experiences of straight people and LGBTQ people?', 'However, research has consistently demonstrated that the family backgrounds and experiences are very similar among straight people and LGBTQ people (Bell, Weinberg, & Hammersmith, 1981; Ross & Arrindell, 1988).']

['Teacher: What are some of the mechanisms, both genetic and biological, that have been proposed to explain sexual orientation?', 'Genetic and biological mechanisms have also been proposed, and the balance of research evidence suggests that sexual orientation has an underlying biological component.']

['What role do genetic factors play in contributing to sexual orientation according to the research findings mentioned in the passage?', 'For instance, over the past 25 years, research has demonstrated gene-level contributions to sexual orientation (Bailey & Pillard, 1991; Hamer, Hu, Magnuson, Hu, & Pattatucci, 1993; Rodriguez-Larralde & Paradisi, 2009), with some researchers estimating that genes account for at least half of the variability seen in human sexual orientation (Pillard & Bailey, 1998).']

['What are some examples of biological factors that have been mentioned in the passage to explain sexual orientation?', 'Other studies report differences in brain structure and function among those with different sexual orientations (Allen & Gorski, 1992; Byne et al., 2001; Hu et al., 2008; LeVay, 1991; Ponseti et al., 2006; Rahman & Wilson, 2003a; Swaab & Hofman, 1990), and even differences in basic body structure and function have been observed (Hall & Kimura, 1994; Lippa, 2003; Loehlin & McFadden, 2003; McFadden & Champlin, 2000; McFadden & Pasanen, 1998; Rahman & Wilson, 2003b).']

['What do the research findings mentioned in the passage suggest about the origin of sexual orientation?', 'In aggregate, the data suggest that to a significant extent, sexual orientations are something with which we are born.']

['Teacher: According to the passage, what has research made clear about sexual orientation?', 'Regardless of how sexual orientation is determined, research has made clear that sexual orientation is not a choice, but rather it is a relatively stable characteristic of a person that cannot be changed.']

['Teacher: Why does the research community criticize claims of effective conversion therapy?', 'Claims of effective conversion therapy have received wide criticism from the research community due to significant concerns with research design, recruitment of experimental participants, and interpretation of data.']

['Teacher: What are some reasons why the research community criticizes claims of effective conversion therapy?', 'As such, there is no credible scientific evidence to suggest that individuals can change their sexual orientation (Jenkins, 2010).']

['Teacher: Who is the author of one of the most widely-cited examples of conversion therapy, and what did he do to address his mistakes?', 'Dr. Robert Spitzer, the author of one of the most widely-cited examples of conversion therapy, apologized to both the scientific community and the LGBTQ community for his mistakes, and he publically recanted his own paper in a public letter addressed to the editor of Archives of Sexual Behavior in the spring of 2012 (Carey, 2012).']
['"What were Dr. Robert Spitzer\'s reasons for apologizing and recanting his own paper on conversion therapy?"', 'In this letter, Spitzer wrote,']

['Teacher: What are some reasons why people tend to confuse sexual orientation with gender identity?', 'Many people conflate sexual orientation with gender identity because of misconceptions and attitudes that exist about sexuality.']
['Why do people confuse sexual orientation with gender identity?', 'In reality, these are two related, but different, aspects of who we are.']

['What are some misconceptions and attitudes that exist about sexuality that contribute to the confusion between sexual orientation and gender identity?', 'Gender identity refers to one’s sense of being male, female, neither of these, both of these, or another gender.']
["What factors determine one's gender identity?", 'Generally, our gender identities correspond to our chromosomal and phenotypic sex, but this is not always the case.']
['What is the difference between chromosomal and phenotypic sex?', 'Transgender people’s gender identity differs from the sex they were assigned at birth.']

['What are some terms that transgender people might use to describe their gender identity?', 'Transgender people may use a range of terms to describe themselves, including abbreviations (e.g. trans) or terms such as non-binary.']

['Teacher: What is the term used to describe the condition when individuals do not feel comfortable identifying with the gender associated with their biological sex?', 'When individuals do not feel comfortable identifying with the gender associated with their biological sex, then they may experience gender dysphoria.']

['What is the specific diagnostic category in the DSM-5 that describes individuals who do not identify as the gender that most people would assume they are?', 'Gender dysphoria is a diagnostic category in the fifth edition of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5) that describes individuals who do not identify as the gender that most people would assume they are.']

['What are the two criteria that must be met for an individual to be diagnosed with gender dysphoria according to the DSM-5?', 'This dysphoria must persist for at least six months and result in significant distress or dysfunction to meet DSM-5 diagnostic criteria.']

['What are the specific criteria that must be met for children to be assigned the diagnostic category of gender dysphoria?', 'In order for children to be assigned this diagnostic category, they must verbalize their desire to become the other gender.']

['Are all transgender people diagnosed with gender dysphoria according to the DSM-5?', 'It is important to note that not all transgender people experience gender dysphoria, and that its diagnostic categorization is not universally accepted.']

['What is the significance of the World Health Organization\'s reclassification of "gender identity disorder" to "gender incongruence" in 2019?', 'For example, in 2019, the World Health Organization reclassified “gender identity disorder” as “gender incongruence,” and categorized it under sexual health rather than a mental disorder.']

['What does the presence of the diagnostic category of gender dysphoria assist in, according to health and mental health professionals?', 'However, health and mental health professionals indicate that the presence of the diagnostic category does assist in supporting those who need treatment or help.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the concept of transition in relation to gender identity?', 'Some transgender individuals may undertake a process of transition, in which they move from living in a way that is more aligned with the sex assigned at birth to living in a way that is aligned with their gender identity.']

["What are the different aspects of someone's life that transitioning can involve?", "Transitioning may take the form of social, legal, or medical aspects of someone's life, but not everyone undertakes any or all types of transition."]
['What are some examples of changes that can occur during a social transition?', "Social transition may involve the person's presentation, name, pronouns, and relationships."]

['What are some examples of changes that can occur during a legal transition?', 'Legal transition can include changing their gender on government or other official documents, changing their legal name, and so on.']

['What are some examples of changes that can occur during a physical or medical transition?', 'Some people may undergo a physical or medical transition, in which they change their outward, physical, or sexual characteristics in order for their physical being to better align with their gender identity (UCSF Transgender Care 2019).']

["What are some factors that may influence an individual's decision to undergo a physical or medical transition?", 'Not all transgender individuals choose to alter their bodies: many will maintain their original anatomy but may present themselves to society as another gender.']

['What are some ways that individuals who undergo a physical or medical transition can change their outward appearance to align with their gender identity?', 'This is typically done by adopting the dress, hairstyle, mannerisms, or other characteristics typically assigned to another gender.']

['What is an important distinction to make regarding individuals who cross-dress?', 'It is important to note that people who cross-dress, or wear clothing that is traditionally assigned to a gender different from their biological sex, are not necessarily transgender.']

['What does it mean for someone to cross-dress?', "Cross-dressing is typically a form of self-expression or personal style, and it does not indicate a person's gender identity or that they are transgender (TSER 2021)."]

['Teacher: Can you explain to me what the term "intersex" means and how it relates to differences in sex traits, reproductive anatomy, hormones, or chromosomes?', 'Intersex is a general term used to describe people whose sex traits, reproductive anatomy, hormones, or chromosomes are different from the usual two ways human bodies develop.']

['Can you provide some examples of intersex traits that may be recognizable at birth and others that may not be recognizable until puberty or later in life?', 'Some intersex traits are recognized at birth, while others are not recognizable until puberty or later in life (interACT 2021).']

['What is the key difference between the terms "intersex" and "transgender", according to the passage?', 'Intersex and transgender are not interchangeable terms; many transgender people have no intersex traits, and many intersex people do not consider themselves transgender.']

['Teacher: Can you please explain what the term "cisgender" signifies when we say someone identifies with the sex they were assigned at birth?', 'Those who identify with the sex they were assigned at birth are often referred to as cisgender, utilizing the Latin prefix "cis," which means "on the same side."']
['What is the meaning of the Latin prefix "cis" in the term "cisgender"?', '(The prefix "trans" means "across.")']
['What does the Latin prefix "trans" mean in the context of gender identity?', 'Many cisgender people do not self-identify as such.']

['What does it mean when it is said that the term "cisgender" doesn\'t indicate a person\'s sexual orientation, gender, or gender expression?', "As with transgender people, the term or usage of cisgender does not indicate a person's sexual orientation, gender, or gender expression (TSER 2021)."]

['Teacher: How has our scientific knowledge and general understanding about gender identity evolved over time, and what impact has it had on young people today?', 'Our scientific knowledge and general understanding about gender identity continue to evolve, and young people today have more opportunity to explore and openly express different ideas about what gender means than previous generations.']

["What do recent studies indicate about the majority of millennials' perception of gender?", 'Recent studies indicate that the majority of millennials (those ages 18–34) regard gender as a spectrum instead of a strict male/female binary, and that 12% identify as transgender or gender non-conforming.']

['Teacher: How does the increased knowledge and acceptance of gender diversity in millennials impact the use of gender-neutral pronouns like they/them?', 'Additionally, more people know others who use gender-neutral pronouns (such as they/them) (Kennedy, 2017).']

['What does the change in language usage among millennials and Generation Z people indicate about their understanding of gender?', 'This change in language may indicate that millennials and Generation Z people understand the experience of gender itself differently.']

['What are some examples of changes in public policies and organizations that have emerged due to the evolving understanding of gender among young people?', 'As young people lead this change, other changes are emerging in a range of spheres, from public bathroom policies to retail organizations.']

['What is the significance of retailers removing traditional gender-based marketing of products, such as "pink and blue" clothing and toy aisles?', 'For example, some retailers are starting to change traditional gender-based marketing of products, such as removing “pink and blue” clothing and toy aisles.']

['What challenges do individuals who exist outside of traditional gender norms continue to face despite the changes in gender understanding and policies?', 'Even with these changes, those who exist outside of traditional gender norms face difficult challenges.']

['What are some specific examples of the challenges that individuals who exist outside of traditional gender norms continue to face?', 'Even people who vary slightly from traditional norms are often the target of discrimination and violence.']

['Teacher: How would you describe the impact of sociocultural factors on issues related to sexual orientation and gender identity?', 'Issues related to sexual orientation and gender identity are very much influenced by sociocultural factors.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how sociocultural factors can influence the definition of sexual orientation and gender?', 'Even the ways in which we define sexual orientation and gender vary from one culture to the next.']

['Teacher: How does the concept of heteronormativity shape the societal understanding of sexual orientation in the United States?', 'While in the United States heterosexuality has historically been viewed as the norm (making it a heteronormative society), there are societies that have different attitudes regarding LGBTQ people.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a society where same-sex sexual behavior is socially prescribed as a part of normal development and maturation?', 'In fact, in some instances, periods of exclusively same-sex sexual behavior are socially prescribed as a part of normal development and maturation.']

['Teacher: How can the cultural practice in New Guinea of expecting young boys to engage in sexual behavior with other boys be seen as a sociocultural factor influencing sexual orientation and gender identity?', 'For example, in parts of New Guinea, young boys are expected to engage in sexual behavior with other boys for a given period of time because it is believed that doing so is necessary for these boys to become men (Baldwin & Baldwin, 1989).']

['Teacher: Can you explain how the presence of a two-gendered culture has shaped the understanding of sexual orientation and gender identity in the United States?', 'There has historically been a two-gendered culture in the United States.']

['Teacher: How does the classification of individuals as either male or female impact the understanding of sexual orientation and gender identity in the United States?', 'We have tended to classify an individual as either male or female according to the sex they were assigned at birth, leading the United States to be considered a cisnormative society.']

["Teacher: How does the presence of additional gender variants in some cultures challenge the understanding of sexual orientation and gender identity in comparison to the United States' two-gendered culture?", 'However, in some cultures there are additional gender variants resulting in more than two gender categories.']

['Teacher: How does the recognition of more than two gender categories, such as male, female, or kathoey in Thailand, challenge the understanding of sexual orientation and gender identity compared to the two-gendered culture in the United States?', 'For example, in Thailand, you can be male, female, or kathoey.']

['Teacher: How might the recognition of gender categories beyond male and female, like kathoey in Thailand, contribute to a more inclusive understanding of sexual orientation and gender identity?', 'A kathoey is an individual who would be described as intersex or transgender in the United States (Tangmunkongvorakul, Banwell, Carmichael, Utomo, & Sleigh, 2010).']
['Teacher: What is one common experience that we have as we go about our day?', 'As we move through our daily lives, we experience a variety of emotions.']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example of an emotion that you might experience during your daily life?', 'An emotion is a subjective state of being that we often describe as our feelings.']

['Teacher: What are the factors that contribute to the experience of emotions?', 'Emotions result from the combination of subjective experience, expression, cognitive appraisal, and physiological responses (Levenson, Carstensen, Friesen, & Ekman, 1991).']

['Teacher: How do subjective experience, expression, cognitive appraisal, and physiological responses contribute to the experience of emotions, according to the passage?', 'However, as discussed later in the chapter, the exact order in which the components occur is not clear, and some parts may happen at the same time.']
['Teacher: According to the passage, what is the initial component of an emotion?', 'An emotion often begins with a subjective (individual) experience, which is a stimulus.']
['According to the passage, what are some examples of stimuli that can trigger an emotion?', 'Often the stimulus is external, but it does not have to be from the outside world.']

['What is an example of an internal stimulus that can trigger an emotion, according to the passage?', 'For example, it might be that one thinks about war and becomes sad, even though they never experienced war.']

['What are some examples of nonverbal behaviors that can be considered as emotional expressions, according to the passage?', 'Emotional expression refers to the way one displays an emotion and includes nonverbal and verbal behaviors (Gross, 1999).']

['What is the purpose of cognitive appraisal in the experience of emotions, according to the passage?', 'One also performs a cognitive appraisal in which a person tries to determine the way they will be impacted by a situation (Roseman & Smith, 2001).']

['How do physiological responses contribute to the experience of emotions, according to the passage?', 'In addition, emotions include physiological responses, such as possible changes in heart rate, sweating, etc. (Soussignan, 2002).']

['Teacher: How do psychologists differentiate between the terms emotion and mood?', 'The words emotion and mood are sometimes used interchangeably, but psychologists use these words to refer to two different things.']

['Teacher: Can you explain in more detail what psychologists mean by the term "mood"?', 'Typically, the word emotion indicates a subjective, affective state that is relatively intense and that occurs in response to something we experience (Figure 10.20).']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example to illustrate how emotions can be consciously experienced and intentional?', 'Emotions are often thought to be consciously experienced and intentional.']

['Teacher: How would you describe the difference between an emotion and a mood in terms of their duration and intensity?', 'Mood, on the other hand, refers to a prolonged, less intense, affective state that does not occur in response to something we experience.']

['Teacher: How might psychologists characterize the conscious recognition and intentionality associated with emotions compared to mood states?', 'Mood states may not be consciously recognized and do not carry the intentionality that is associated with emotion (Beedie, Terry, Lane, & Devonport, 2011).']

['Teacher: What is the main focus of the chapter that covers psychological disorders?', 'Here we will focus on emotion, and you will learn more about mood in the chapter that covers psychological disorders.']
['Teacher: What does the passage say about the range of emotions we can experience?', 'We can be at the heights of joy or in the depths of despair.']

['Teacher: Can you give examples of specific emotions mentioned in the passage?', 'We might feel angry when we are betrayed, fear when we are threatened, and surprised when something unexpected happens.']

['Teacher: What does this section of the textbook aim to accomplish?', 'This section will outline some of the most well-known theories explaining our emotional experience and provide insight into the biological bases of emotion.']

['Teacher: How does this section of the textbook address the topic of facial expressions of emotion?', 'This section closes with a discussion of the ubiquitous nature of facial expressions of emotion and our abilities to recognize those expressions in others.']

['Teacher: What are the three factors that contribute to our emotional states according to the passage?', 'Our emotional states are combinations of physiological arousal, psychological appraisal, and subjective experiences.']

['Teacher: How do our experiences, backgrounds, and cultures influence our emotional states, according to the passage?', 'Together, these are the components of emotion, and our experiences, backgrounds, and cultures inform our emotions.']

['Teacher: Why is it that different people may have different emotional experiences even in similar circumstances, as mentioned in the passage?', 'Therefore, different people may have different emotional experiences even when faced with similar circumstances.']

['How do the different theories of emotion explain the interaction of the various components of emotion?', 'Over time, several different theories of emotion, shown in Figure 10.21, have been proposed to explain how the various components of emotion interact with one another.']
['Teacher: What does the James-Lange theory of emotion propose regarding the origin of emotions?', 'The James-Lange theory of emotion asserts that emotions arise from physiological arousal.']

['Teacher: Can you explain how the James-Lange theory suggests that physiological arousal contributes to the experience of emotions?', 'Recall what you have learned about the sympathetic nervous system and our fight or flight response when threatened.']

['Teacher: How does the physiological arousal generated by the sympathetic nervous system in response to a threat relate to the experience of emotions according to the James-Lange theory?', 'If you were to encounter some threat in your environment, like a venomous snake in your backyard, your sympathetic nervous system would initiate significant physiological arousal, which would make your heart race and increase your respiration rate.']

['Teacher: According to the James-Lange theory, how does the experience of fear or any other emotion occur in relation to the physiological arousal mentioned earlier?', 'According to the James-Lange theory of emotion, you would only experience a feeling of fear after this physiological arousal had taken place.']

['Teacher: How does the James-Lange theory propose that different arousal patterns are associated with different feelings?', 'Furthermore, different arousal patterns would be associated with different feelings.']

['Teacher: What do some theorists question regarding the relationship between physiological arousal and the wide range of emotions we experience?', 'Other theorists, however, doubted that the physiological arousal that occurs with different types of emotions is distinct enough to result in the wide variety of emotions that we experience.']

['What theory was developed as a result of doubt surrounding the distinctiveness of physiological arousal in creating a wide variety of emotions?', 'Thus, the Cannon-Bard theory of emotion was developed.']
['What is the main idea of the Cannon-Bard theory of emotion?', 'According to this view, physiological arousal and emotional experience occur simultaneously, yet independently (Lang, 1994).']

['Teacher: According to the Cannon-Bard theory, when does physiological arousal and emotional experience occur?', 'So, when you see the venomous snake, you feel fear at exactly the same time that your body mounts its fight or flight response.']

['When you see a heartwarming video and your eyes well up with tears, according to the Cannon-Bard theory, how would physiological arousal and emotional experience be related?', 'This emotional reaction would be separate and independent of the physiological arousal, even though they co-occur.']

['Teacher: What does the facial feedback hypothesis propose regarding the relationship between facial expressions and emotional experience?', 'The facial feedback hypothesis proposes that your facial expression can actually affect your emotional experience (Adelman & Zajonc, 1989; Boiger & Mesquita, 2012; Buck, 1980; Capella, 1993; Soussignan, 2001).']

['What is one research finding that supports the facial feedback hypothesis?', 'Research investigating the facial feedback hypothesis suggested that suppression of facial expression of emotion lowered the intensity of some emotions experienced by participants (Davis, Senghas, & Ochsner, 2009).']

['What method did Havas et al. (2010) use to limit facial expressions in their study on the facial feedback hypothesis?', 'Havas, Glenberg, Gutowski, Lucarelli, and Davidson (2010) used Botox injections to paralyze facial muscles and limit facial expressions, including frowning, and they found that depressed people reported less depression after their frowning muscles were paralyzed.']

['What did the research findings mentioned by Soussignan (2002) suggest regarding the relationship between the intensities of facial expressions and emotional reactions?', 'Other research found that the intensities of facial expressions affected the emotional reactions (Soussignan, 2002).']

['What does the research mentioned by the student suggest about the relationship between the intensity of a facial expression and the corresponding emotional reaction?', 'In other words, if something insignificant occurs and you smile as if you just won lottery, you will actually be happier about the little thing than you would be if you only had a tiny smile.']

['How does the intensity of a facial expression impact the corresponding emotional reaction?', 'Conversely, if you walk around frowning all the time, it might cause you to have less positive emotions than you would if you had smiled.']

['What did Soussignan (2002) find in terms of physiological arousal differences associated with the intensities of one type of smile?', 'Interestingly, Soussignan (2002) also reported physiological arousal differences associated with the intensities of one type of smile.']

['Teacher: Who was G. Marañon Posadillo and what did he study related to emotion?', 'G. Marañon Posadillo was a Spanish physician who studied the psychological effects of adrenaline to create a model for the experience of emotion.']

["Teacher: How did G. Marañon Posadillo's model of emotion differ from Schachter's two-factor theory?", "Marañon's model preceded Schachter's two-factor or arousal-cognition theory of emotion (Cornelius, 1991)."]

['Teacher: What are the two main factors considered in the Schachter-Singer two-factor theory of emotion?', 'The Schachter-Singer two-factor theory of emotion is another variation on theories of emotions that takes into account both physiological arousal and the emotional experience.']

['Teacher: What role does physiological arousal play in the Schachter-Singer two-factor theory of emotion?', 'According to this theory, emotions are composed of two factors: physiological and cognitive.']

['How does the interpretation of physiological arousal contribute to the emotional experience according to the Schachter-Singer two-factor theory of emotion?', 'In other words, physiological arousal is interpreted in context to produce the emotional experience.']

['What does the Schachter-Singer two-factor theory suggest about the role of context in the interpretation of physiological arousal in the emotional experience?', 'In revisiting our example involving the venomous snake in your backyard, the two-factor theory maintains that the snake elicits sympathetic nervous system activation that is labeled as fear given the context, and our experience is that of fear.']

['According to the Schachter-Singer two-factor theory, what would have been your emotional experience if you had labeled your sympathetic nervous system activation as joy?', 'If you had labeled your sympathetic nervous system activation as joy, you would have experienced joy.']

['According to the Schachter-Singer two-factor theory, what is the role of cognitive appraisal in the emotional experience?', 'The Schachter-Singer two-factor theory depends on labeling the physiological experience, which is a type of cognitive appraisal.']

['Teacher: Who was the first theorist to offer an exploration of the meaning of appraisal and present an outline of the appraisal process in relation to emotion?', 'Magda Arnold was the first theorist to offer an exploration of the meaning of appraisal, and to present an outline of what the appraisal process might be and how it relates to emotion (Roseman & Smith, 2001).']

['Who are some other important theorists in the field of appraisal theory and what are their contributions?', 'The key idea of appraisal theory is that you have thoughts (a cognitive appraisal) before you experience an emotion, and the emotion you experience depends on the thoughts you had (Frijda, 1988; Lazarus, 1991).']
['What is the key idea of appraisal theory?', 'If you think something is positive, you will have more positive emotions about it than if your appraisal was negative, and the opposite is true.']

['How does appraisal theory explain the possibility of two people having different emotions about the same event?', 'Appraisal theory explains the way two people can have two completely different emotions regarding the same event.']

['How might someone else in the class perceive being selected to lecture on emotion by the psychology instructor?', 'For example, suppose your psychology instructor selected you to lecture on emotion; you might see that as positive, because it represents an opportunity to be the center of attention, and you would experience happiness.']

['What factors of the situation may lead to a positive appraisal and experience of happiness for being selected to lecture on emotion?', 'However, if you dislike speaking in public, you could have a negative appraisal and experience discomfort.']

['Teacher: What was the belief held by Schachter and Singer regarding physiological arousal and the different types of emotions?', 'Schachter and Singer believed that physiological arousal is very similar across the different types of emotions that we experience, and therefore, the cognitive appraisal of the situation is critical to the actual emotion experienced.']

['Teacher: How does the belief of Schachter and Singer suggest that physiological arousal is not solely responsible for the different types of emotions experienced?', 'In fact, it might be possible to misattribute arousal to an emotional experience if the circumstances were right (Schachter & Singer, 1962).']
['What was the purpose of the experiment conducted by Schachter and Singer to test their belief about physiological arousal and emotions?', 'They performed a clever experiment to test their idea.']

['What were the different groups that the men participating in the experiment conducted by Schachter and Singer were randomly assigned to?', 'A group of men participating in the experiment were randomly assigned to one of several groups.']

['What was the purpose of assigning some of the men in the experiment to expect the bodily changes caused by epinephrine injections?', 'Some of the participants received injections of epinephrine that caused bodily changes that mimicked the fight-or-flight response of the sympathetic nervous system; however, only some of these men were told to expect these reactions as side effects of the injection.']

['What were the participants in the experiment conducted by Schachter and Singer told regarding the side effects of the epinephrine injections?', 'The other men that received injections of epinephrine were told either that the injection would have no side effects or that it would result in a side effect unrelated to a sympathetic response, such as itching feet or headache.']

['What were the participants in the experiment asked to do while waiting in the room with another person?', 'After receiving these injections, participants waited in a room with someone else they thought was another subject in the research project.']

['What did the participants in the experiment think about the other person they were waiting with in the room?', 'In reality, the other person was a confederate (someone working on behalf of) of the researcher.']

['What were the researchers trying to assess by having the confederate engage in scripted displays of euphoric or angry behavior?', 'The confederate engaged in scripted displays of euphoric or angry behavior (Schachter & Singer, 1962).']

['Teacher: What was the response of participants who were told to expect physiological arousal when asked about emotional changes related to euphoria or anger?', 'When those participants who were told that they should expect to feel symptoms of physiological arousal were asked about any emotional changes that they had experienced related to either euphoria or anger (depending on the way the confederate behaved), they reported none.']

['What was the difference in the reported emotional changes between participants who were expecting physiological arousal and those who were not?', 'However, the men who weren’t expecting physiological arousal as a function of the injection were more likely to report that they experienced euphoria or anger as a function of their assigned confederate’s behavior.']

["What role did the participants' expectations play in their interpretation of the physiological arousal they experienced?", 'While everyone who received an injection of epinephrine experienced the same physiological arousal, only those who were not expecting the arousal used context to interpret the arousal as a change in emotional state (Schachter & Singer, 1962).']

['Teacher: Why did some theorists suggest using signs of physiological arousal, such as increased heart rate, respiration rate, and sweating, to determine whether someone is telling the truth or not?', 'Strong emotional responses are associated with strong physiological arousal, which caused some theorists to suggest that the signs of physiological arousal, including increased heart rate, respiration rate, and sweating, might be used to determine whether someone is telling the truth or not.']

['What is one common method that is used to measure the physiological arousal of an individual responding to a series of questions?', 'A polygraph, or lie detector test, measures the physiological arousal of an individual responding to a series of questions.']

['Why might increased levels of physiological arousal in response to certain questions be seen as potential signs of dishonesty?', 'Someone trained in reading these tests would look for answers to questions that are associated with increased levels of arousal as potential signs that the respondent may have been dishonest on those answers.']

['What is a limitation of using polygraphs as a reliable measure of detecting lies?', 'While polygraphs are still commonly used, their validity and accuracy are highly questionable because there is no evidence that lying is associated with any particular pattern of physiological arousal (Saxe & Ben-Shakhar, 1999).']

['Teacher: What is the current topic of research and debate regarding the experiencing of emotions and cognitive processing?', 'The relationship between our experiencing of emotions and our cognitive processing of them, and the order in which these occur, remains a topic of research and debate.']

["Teacher: Can you provide an example of how Lazarus' cognitive-mediational theory explains the relationship between our cognitive processing and experiencing of emotions?", 'Lazarus (1991) developed the cognitive-mediational theory that asserts our emotions are determined by our appraisal of the stimulus.']

["What does Lazarus' cognitive-mediational theory propose in terms of the role of appraisal in the relationship between a stimulus and our emotional response?", 'This appraisal mediates between the stimulus and the emotional response, and it is immediate and often unconscious.']

["What is the main difference between Lazarus' cognitive-mediational theory and the Schachter-Singer model in terms of the sequence of events in the experiencing of emotions?", 'In contrast to the Schachter-Singer model, the appraisal precedes a cognitive label.']
["What other areas of psychology can the concept of Lazarus's appraisal be applied to?", 'You will learn more about Lazarus’s appraisal concept when you study stress, health, and lifestyle.']

['What are some alternative theories or perspectives in psychology that also emphasize the role of cognitive processes in the experiencing of emotions?', 'However, there are other views of emotions that also emphasize the cognitive processes.']
['Teacher: Can you recall a specific example that relates to the topic of Theories of Emotion?', 'Return to the example of being asked to lecture by your professor.']

['Teacher: Why is the example of being asked to lecture by your professor relevant in understanding the Theories of Emotion?', 'Even if you do not enjoy speaking in public, you probably could manage to do it.']

['Teacher: How does the example of purposefully controlling your emotions while speaking relate to the concept of emotion regulation?', 'You would purposefully control your emotions, which would allow you to speak, but we constantly regulate our emotions, and much of our emotion regulation occurs without us actively thinking about it.']

['Teacher: What is automatic emotion regulation (AER) and how does it differ from deliberate emotion regulation?', 'Mauss and her colleagues studied automatic emotion regulation (AER), which refers to the non-deliberate control of emotions.']

['Teacher: How did Mauss and her colleagues define automatic emotion regulation (AER) and what is its impact on emotional processes?', 'It is simply not reacting with your emotions, and AER can affect all aspects of emotional processes.']

['Teacher: How did Mauss and her colleagues demonstrate the impact of automatic emotion regulation (AER) on emotional processes?', 'AER can influence the things you attend to, your appraisal, your choice to engage in an emotional experience, and your behaviors after an emotion is experienced (Mauss, Bunge, & Gross, 2007; Mauss, Levenson, McCarter, Wilhelm, & Gross, 2005).']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of another automatic cognitive process that is similar to automatic emotion regulation (AER)?', 'AER is similar to other automatic cognitive processes in which sensations activate knowledge structures that affect functioning.']

['Teacher: How do concepts, schemas, or scripts influence automatic cognitive processes such as automatic emotion regulation (AER)?', 'These knowledge structures can include concepts, schemas, or scripts.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the concept of AER and how it relates to emotion regulation?', 'The idea of AER is that people develop an automatic process that works like a script or schema, and the process does not require deliberate thought to regulate emotions.']
["Teacher: That's a great analogy! Can you elaborate on how AER is similar to riding a bicycle in terms of regulating emotions?", 'AER works like riding a bicycle.']
['Why does the student compare AER to riding a bicycle in terms of regulating emotions?', 'Once you develop the process, you just do it without thinking about it.']
["How can the adaptiveness or maladaptiveness of AER impact an individual's overall health?", 'AER can be adaptive or maladaptive and has important health implications (Hopp, Troy, & Mauss, 2011).']

["What are the potential consequences of having a maladaptive AER compared to an adaptive AER in terms of an individual's health?", 'Adaptive AER leads to better health outcomes than maladaptive AER, primarily due to experiencing or mitigating stressors better than people with maladaptive AERs (Hopp, Troy, & Mauss, 2011).']

['What is one potential benefit of having a maladaptive AER, according to the mentioned study?', 'Alternatively, maladaptive AERs may be critical for maintaining some psychological disorders (Hopp, Troy, & Mauss, 2011).']

['What did Mauss and her colleagues discover in their studies regarding the impact of strategies on psychological health?', 'Mauss and her colleagues found that strategies could reduce negative emotions, which in turn should increase psychological health (Mauss, Cook, Cheng, & Gross, 2007; Mauss, Cook, & Gross, 2007; Shallcross, Troy, Boland, & Mauss, 2010; Troy, Shallcross, & Mauss, 2013; Troy, Wilhelm, Shallcross, & Mauss, 2010).']

['What does Mauss suggest regarding the measurement of emotions?', 'Mauss has also suggested there are problems with the way emotions are measured, but she believes most of the aspects of emotions that are typically measured are useful (Mauss, et al., 2005; Mauss & Robinson, 2009).']
['What does Mauss suggest about considering emotions in a different way?', 'However, another way of considering emotions challenges our entire understanding of emotions.']

['Teacher: According to Barrett, what is our current understanding of emotions after decades of interdisciplinary research?', 'After about three decades of interdisciplinary research, Barrett argued that we do not understand emotions.']

['What does Barrett propose about the origins of emotions based on her research findings?', 'She proposed that emotions were not built into your brain at birth, but rather they were constructed based on your experiences.']

['What is the main idea or concept behind the constructivist theory of emotions proposed by Barrett?', 'Emotions in the constructivist theory are predictions that construct your experience of the world.']

['What is the role of concepts in the constructivist theory of emotions proposed by Barrett?', 'In chapter 7 you learned that concepts are categories or groupings of linguistic information, images, ideas, or memories, such as life experiences.']

['What does Barrett argue about the relationship between concepts and emotions in the constructivist theory of emotions?', 'Barrett extended that to include emotions as concepts that are predictions (Barrett, 2017).']

['What does Barrett argue about the relationship between physiological states and emotional states in the constructivist theory of emotions?', 'Two identical physiological states can result in different emotional states depending on your predictions.']

['How does Barrett explain the relationship between physiological states and emotional states in the constructivist theory of emotions?', 'For example, your brain predicting a churning stomach in a bakery could lead to you constructing hunger.']

["What is the key factor that determines the emotional state according to Barrett's constructivist theory of emotions?", 'However, your brain predicting a churning stomach while you were waiting for medical test results could lead your brain to construct worry.']
["What is the significance of predictions in Barrett's constructivist theory of emotions?", 'Thus, you can construct two different emotions from the same physiological sensations.']

["How does Barrett's constructivist theory of emotions challenge the idea that emotions are something over which you have no control?", 'Rather than emotions being something over which you have no control, you can control and influence your emotions.']

['Teacher: What are the two other prominent views that arise from the work of Robert Zajonc and Joseph LeDoux in the field of theories of emotion?', 'Two other prominent views arise from the work of Robert Zajonc and Joseph LeDoux.']

['Teacher: Can you explain one of the two views that Robert Zajonc and Joseph LeDoux propose in the field of theories of emotion?', 'Zajonc asserted that some emotions occur separately from or prior to our cognitive interpretation of them, such as feeling fear in response to an unexpected loud sound (Zajonc, 1998).']

["Teacher: Can you provide an example that supports Zajonc's belief that some emotions occur separately from our cognitive interpretation of them?", 'He also believed in what we might casually refer to as a gut feeling—that we can experience an instantaneous and unexplainable like or dislike for someone or something (Zajonc, 1980).']

["Teacher: Can you give an example that supports LeDoux's belief that some emotions bypass contextual interpretation?", 'LeDoux also views some emotions as requiring no cognition: some emotions completely bypass contextual interpretation.']

["Teacher: How has LeDoux's research on the neuroscience of emotion supported his belief that some emotions bypass contextual interpretation?", 'His research into the neuroscience of emotion has demonstrated the amygdala’s primary role in fear (Cunha, Monfils, & LeDoux, 2010; LeDoux 1996, 2002).']

["Teacher: What role does the amygdala play in the processing of fear stimuli, according to LeDoux's research on the neuroscience of emotion?", 'A fear stimulus is processed by the brain through one of two paths: from the thalamus (where it is perceived) directly to the amygdala or from the thalamus through the cortex and then to the amygdala.']

["What is the advantage of the first path (from the thalamus directly to the amygdala) in processing fear stimuli, according to LeDoux's research on the neuroscience of emotion?", 'The first path is quick, while the second enables more processing about details of the stimulus.']
['What will the next section focus on in relation to the neuroscience of emotional response?', 'In the following section, we will look more closely at the neuroscience of emotional response.']

['Teacher: What is the specific function of the limbic system in relation to emotions and memory?', 'Earlier, you learned about the limbic system, which is the area of the brain involved in emotion and memory (Figure 10.22).']

['Teacher: Can you explain the role of the hypothalamus, thalamus, amygdala, and hippocampus within the limbic system in relation to emotions and memory?', 'The limbic system includes the hypothalamus, thalamus, amygdala, and the hippocampus.']

['Teacher: What are the functions of the thalamus, amygdala, and hippocampus within the limbic system in relation to emotions and memory?', 'The hypothalamus plays a role in the activation of the sympathetic nervous system that is a part of any given emotional reaction.']

['What roles does the amygdala play in the limbic system in relation to emotions and memory?', 'The thalamus serves as a sensory relay center whose neurons project to both the amygdala and the higher cortical regions for further processing.']

['What is the function of the hippocampus within the limbic system in relation to emotions and memory?', 'The amygdala plays a role in processing emotional information and sending that information on (Fossati, 2012).']

['What is the significance of integrating emotional experience with cognition in relation to the limbic system and emotions?', 'The hippocampus integrates emotional experience with cognition (Femenía, Gómez-Galán, Lindskog, & Magara, 2012).']

['Teacher: Why has the amygdala received a great deal of attention from researchers interested in understanding the biological basis for emotions, especially fear and anxiety?', 'The amygdala has received a great deal of attention from researchers interested in understanding the biological basis for emotions, especially fear and anxiety (Blackford & Pine, 2012; Goosens & Maren, 2002; Maren, Phan, & Liberzon, 2013).']

['Why is the amygdala considered important for understanding the biological basis of emotions, specifically fear and anxiety?', 'The amygdala is composed of various subnuclei, including the basolateral complex and the central nucleus (Figure 10.23).']

['What are some of the subnuclei of amygdala and what are their connections with sensory areas of the brain?', 'The basolateral complex has dense connections with a variety of sensory areas of the brain.']

['What role does the basolateral complex of the amygdala play in classical conditioning and emotional value?', 'It is critical for classical conditioning and for attaching emotional value to learning processes and memory.']

['What are some of the connections that the central nucleus of the amygdala has with other areas of the brain?', 'The central nucleus plays a role in attention, and it has connections with the hypothalamus and various brainstem areas to regulate the autonomic nervous and endocrine systems’ activity (Pessoa, 2010).']

['Teacher: What evidence from animal research supports the idea that the amygdala is activated in rat pups when odor cues are paired with electrical shock and their mother is absent?', 'Animal research has demonstrated that there is increased activation of the amygdala in rat pups that have odor cues paired with electrical shock when their mother is absent.']

['Teacher: What is the behavioral outcome in rat pups when the amygdala is activated in response to odor cues paired with electrical shock, and their mother is absent?', 'This leads to an aversion to the odor cue that suggests the rats learned to fear the odor cue.']

['Teacher: Why do the rat pups show a preference for the odor cue when their mother is present, despite its association with an electrical shock?', 'Interestingly, when the mother was present, the rats actually showed a preference for the odor cue despite its association with an electrical shock.']

['Teacher: What can we infer from the absence of increased amygdala activation when the mother is present and the rats show a preference for the odor cue despite its association with an electrical shock?', 'This preference was associated with no increases in amygdala activation.']

['What does the absence of increased amygdala activation suggest about the influence of the context (the presence or absence of the mother) on whether the rat pups learn to fear or be attracted to the odor cue?', 'This suggests a differential effect on the amygdala by the context (the presence or absence of the mother) determined whether the pups learned to fear the odor or to be attracted to it (Moriceau & Sullivan, 2006).']

['Teacher: How did Raineki, Cortés, Belnoue, and Sullivan (2012) show that negative early life experiences can impact the function of the amygdala in rats?', 'Raineki, Cortés, Belnoue, and Sullivan (2012) demonstrated that, in rats, negative early life experiences could alter the function of the amygdala and result in adolescent patterns of behavior that mimic human mood disorders.']
['What were the two different types of treatment that the rat pups received in the study?', 'In this study, rat pups received either abusive or normal treatment during postnatal days 8–12.']
['What were the behavioral outcomes observed in the rat pups receiving abusive treatment compared to those receiving normal treatment?', 'There were two forms of abusive treatment.']
['What was the second form of abusive treatment that the rat pups received?', 'The first form of abusive treatment had an insufficient bedding condition.']

["What effect did the insufficient bedding condition have on the mother rat's behavior towards her pups?", 'The mother rat had insufficient bedding material in her cage to build a proper nest that resulted in her spending more time away from her pups trying to construct a nest and less times nursing her pups.']

['What was the purpose of the associative learning task in the study conducted by Raineki, Cortés, Belnoue, and Sullivan (2012)?', 'The second form of abusive treatment had an associative learning task that involved pairing odors and an electrical stimulus in the absence of the mother, as described above.']

['What was the experimental condition for the control group of rat pups in the study conducted by Raineki, Cortés, Belnoue, and Sullivan (2012)?', 'The control group was in a cage with sufficient bedding and was left undisturbed with their mothers during the same time period.']

['What were the depressive-like symptoms exhibited by the rat pups who experienced abuse compared to the control group?', 'The rat pups that experienced abuse were much more likely to exhibit depressive-like symptoms during adolescence when compared to controls.']

['What was the correlation between the depressive-like behaviors in rat pups and the activation of the amygdala?', 'These depressive-like behaviors were associated with increased activation of the amygdala.']

['Teacher: What does human research indicate about the relationship between the amygdala and psychological disorders of mood or anxiety?', 'Human research also suggests a relationship between the amygdala and psychological disorders of mood or anxiety.']

['What evidence supports the relationship between the amygdala and psychological disorders of mood or anxiety in adolescents?', 'Changes in amygdala structure and function have been demonstrated in adolescents who are either at-risk or have been diagnosed with various mood and/or anxiety disorders (Miguel-Hidalgo, 2013; Qin et al., 2013).']

['Teacher: How can functional differences in the amygdala potentially be used as a biomarker to differentiate individuals with bipolar disorder from those with major depressive disorder?', 'It has also been suggested that functional differences in the amygdala could serve as a biomarker to differentiate individuals suffering from bipolar disorder from those suffering from major depressive disorder (Fournier, Keener, Almeida, Kronhaus, & Phillips, 2013).']
['Teacher: What is another function of the hippocampus besides its involvement in emotional processing?', 'As mentioned earlier, the hippocampus is also involved in emotional processing.']

['What evidence or research supports the connection between hippocampal structure and function and mood and anxiety disorders?', 'Like the amygdala, research has demonstrated that hippocampal structure and function are linked to a variety of mood and anxiety disorders.']

['What is the impact of posttraumatic stress disorder on the volume of the hippocampus?', 'Individuals suffering from posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) show marked reductions in the volume of several parts of the hippocampus, which may result from decreased levels of neurogenesis and dendritic branching (the generation of new neurons and the generation of new dendrites in existing neurons, respectively) (Wang et al., 2010).']

['What are some potential ways to potentially improve hippocampal volume and behavioral symptoms in individuals suffering from posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD)?', 'While it is impossible to make a causal claim with correlational research like this, studies have demonstrated behavioral improvements and hippocampal volume increases following either pharmacological or cognitive-behavioral therapy in individuals suffering from PTSD (Bremner & Vermetten, 2004; Levy-Gigi, Szabó, Kelemen, & Kéri, 2013).']
['Teacher: How does culture affect the way people express their emotions?', 'Culture can impact the way in which people display emotion.']

['Teacher: Can you give an example of a cultural display rule that governs the way people express their emotions?', 'A cultural display rule is one of a collection of culturally specific standards that govern the types and frequencies of displays of emotions that are acceptable (Malatesta & Haviland, 1982).']
['What is a cultural display rule?', 'Therefore, people from varying cultural backgrounds can have very different cultural display rules of emotion.']
