["Why do observers tend to default to a dispositionist perspective when explaining someone else's behavior in the context of the Actor-Observer Bias?", 'However as observers, we have less information available; therefore, we tend to default to a dispositionist perspective.']

['Teacher: What did the study on the actor-observer bias investigate?', 'One study on the actor-observer bias investigated reasons male participants gave for why they liked their girlfriend (Nisbett et al., 1973).']

['What specific type of qualities did the male participants focus on when explaining why they liked their girlfriends?', 'When asked why participants liked their own girlfriend, participants focused on internal, dispositional qualities of their girlfriends (for example, her pleasant personality).']

['What are some examples of internal, dispositional qualities that the male participants focused on when explaining why they liked their girlfriends?', 'The participants’ explanations rarely included causes internal to themselves, such as dispositional traits (for example, “I need companionship.”).']

['What types of explanations were the participants equally likely to give when speculating why a male friend likes his girlfriend?', 'In contrast, when speculating why a male friend likes his girlfriend, participants were equally likely to give dispositional and external explanations.']

['What does this study suggest about the explanations that actors tend to give for their own behavior?', 'This supports the idea that actors tend to provide few internal explanations but many situational explanations for their own behavior.']
["What type of explanations do observers tend to provide for a friend's behavior?", 'In contrast, observers tend to provide more dispositional explanations for a friend’s behavior (Figure 12.5).']

['Teacher: Can you explain what attribution means in the context of self-serving bias, and how it contributes to our understanding of this phenomenon?', 'We can understand self-serving bias by digging more deeply into attribution, a belief about the cause of a result.']

["Teacher: That's a good point! Can you provide an example that illustrates the concept of locus of control in the context of self-serving bias?", 'One model of attribution proposes three main dimensions: locus of control (internal versus external), stability (stable versus unstable), and controllability (controllable versus uncontrollable).']

['Teacher: Excellent explanation! Now, can you think of an example that demonstrates the concept of controllability in the context of self-serving bias?', 'In this context, stability refers to the extent in which the circumstances that result in a given outcome are changeable.']

['Teacher: Great job! Now, can you provide an example that demonstrates the concept of stability in the context of self-serving bias?', 'The circumstances are considered stable if they are unlikely to change.']

['Teacher: How does controllability of the circumstances affect our understanding of self-serving bias?', 'Controllability refers to the extent to which the circumstances that are associated with a given outcome can be controlled.']

["Teacher: That's a great explanation of controllability! Now, how does controllability contribute to our understanding of the self-serving bias phenomenon?", 'Obviously, those things that we have the power to control would be labeled controllable (Weiner, 1979).']

['Teacher: How would you define self-serving biases and what purpose do they serve?', 'Following an outcome, self-serving biases are those attributions that enable us to see ourselves in a favorable light (for example, making internal attributions for success and external attributions for failures).']

['Teacher: Why is it advantageous to make a dispositional attribution for your success rather than a situational one?', 'When you do well at a task, for example acing an exam, it is in your best interest to make a dispositional attribution for your behavior (“I’m smart,”) instead of a situational one (“The exam was easy,”).']

['Teacher: How does the self-serving bias affect our perception of our successes and failures?', 'Self-serving bias is the tendency to explain our successes as due to dispositional (internal) characteristics, but to explain our failures as due to situational (external) factors.']
['Teacher: Can you explain how the self-serving bias can vary across different cultures?', 'Again, this is culture dependent.']
['Teacher: How does the self-serving bias serve to protect our self-esteem?', 'This bias serves to protect self-esteem.']

['Teacher: Why would people be unable to take credit and feel good about their accomplishments if they always made situational attributions for their behavior?', 'You can imagine that if people always made situational attributions for their behavior, they would never be able to take credit and feel good about their accomplishments.']
['Teacher: Can you please elaborate on the example and how it relates to the concept of self-serving bias?', 'Consider the example of how we explain our favorite sports team’s wins.']

["Teacher: How do we typically explain our favorite sports team's wins according to the concept of self-serving bias?", 'Research shows that we make internal, stable, and controllable attributions for our team’s victory (Figure 12.6) (Grove, Hanrahan, & McInman, 1991).']

["Teacher: What are some internal, stable, and controllable attributions that individuals might make to explain their favorite sports team's wins according to the concept of self-serving bias?", 'For example, we might tell ourselves that our team is talented (internal), consistently works hard (stable), and uses effective strategies (controllable).']

["Teacher: Can you provide an example of external, unstable, and uncontrollable attributions that individuals might make to explain their favorite sports team's losses according to the concept of self-serving bias?", 'In contrast, we are more likely to make external, unstable, and uncontrollable attributions when our favorite team loses.']

["Teacher: How do individuals typically explain their favorite sports team's losses according to the concept of self-serving bias?", 'For example, we might tell ourselves that the other team has more experienced players or that the referees were unfair (external), the other team played at home (unstable), and the cold weather affected our team’s performance (uncontrollable).']

["Teacher: What is a consequence of westerners' tendency to provide dispositional explanations for behavior?", 'One consequence of westerners’ tendency to provide dispositional explanations for behavior is victim blame (Jost & Major, 2001).']

['What is one example of victim blame that can occur when individuals provide dispositional explanations for behavior?', 'When people experience bad fortune, others tend to assume that they somehow are responsible for their own fate.']

['Teacher: What does the just-world hypothesis propose or suggest about the way people view the world and the consequences of their actions?', 'A common ideology, or worldview, in the United States is the just-world hypothesis.']

["Teacher: How does the just-world hypothesis explain the relationship between people's actions and the outcomes they receive?", 'The just-world hypothesis is the belief that people get the outcomes they deserve (Lerner & Miller, 1978).']

["Teacher: How does the belief in the just-world hypothesis influence people's perception of good and bad outcomes?", 'In order to maintain the belief that the world is a fair place, people tend to think that good people experience positive outcomes, and bad people experience negative outcomes (Jost, Banaji, & Nosek, 2004; Jost & Major, 2001).']

["Teacher: How does the belief in the just-world hypothesis contribute to individuals' feelings of predictability and control over their life outcomes?", 'The ability to think of the world as a fair place, where people get what they deserve, allows us to feel that the world is predictable and that we have some control over our life outcomes (Jost et al., 2004; Jost & Major, 2001).']

['Teacher: How does the belief in the just-world hypothesis encourage individuals to take action to achieve positive outcomes in their lives?', 'For example, if you want to experience positive outcomes, you just need to work hard to get ahead in life.']

["Teacher: What is one negative consequence of the Just-World Hypothesis in terms of people's perception towards poor individuals?", 'One negative consequence is people’s tendency to blame poor individuals for their plight.']

['Teacher: How does the tendency to blame poor individuals for their plight relate to the fundamental attribution error in the context of the Just-World Hypothesis?', 'These dispositional explanations are clear examples of the fundamental attribution error.']

['Teacher: How does ignoring situational factors when blaming poor individuals for their poverty align with the principles of the Just-World Hypothesis?', 'Blaming poor people for their poverty ignores situational factors that impact them, such as high unemployment rates, recession, poor educational opportunities, and the familial cycle of poverty (Figure 12.7).']

['Teacher: What are some other examples of groups that people with just-world beliefs may hold negative attitudes towards?', 'Other research shows that people who hold just-world beliefs have negative attitudes toward people who are unemployed and people living with AIDS (Sutton & Douglas, 2005).']

['What is a common negative attitude that people with just-world beliefs may hold towards victims of sexual assault?', 'In the United States and other countries, victims of sexual assault may find themselves blamed for their abuse.']

['What role do victim advocacy groups, such as DOVE, play in addressing the negative attitudes towards victims of sexual assault in the context of the Just-World Hypothesis?', 'Victim advocacy groups, such as Domestic Violence Ended (DOVE), attend court in support of victims to ensure that blame is directed at the perpetrators of sexual violence, not the victims.']

['Teacher: Can you explain in your own words what social psychology focuses on?', 'As you’ve learned, social psychology is the study of how people affect one another’s thoughts, feelings, and behaviors.']

["Teacher: Excellent explanation! Now, can you provide an example of how situational perspectives can influence a person's behavior according to social psychology?", 'We have discussed situational perspectives and social psychology’s emphasis on the ways in which a person’s environment, including culture and other social influences, affect behavior.']

["Teacher: That's a great point! Now, can you give me an example of how social roles can impact someone's behavior in a specific situation?", 'In this section, we examine situational forces that have a strong influence on human behavior including social roles, social norms, and scripts.']

["Teacher: Excellent job! Now, could you provide an example of a social norm and how it can impact an individual's behavior?", 'We discuss how humans use the social environment as a source of information, or cues, on how to behave.']

['Teacher: Great insight! Now, can you explain how social norms provide cues for our behavior in specific situations?', 'Situational influences on our behavior have important consequences, such as whether we will help a stranger in an emergency or how we would behave in an unfamiliar environment.']
['Teacher: What can you tell me about one major social determinant of human behavior?', 'One major social determinant of human behavior is our social roles.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a social role and explain how it shapes human behavior in a given setting or group?', 'A social role is a pattern of behavior that is expected of a person in a given setting or group (Hare, 2003).']

['Teacher: Can you give me an example of multiple social roles that a person may have and explain how these roles can influence their behavior in different settings?', 'Each one of us has several social roles.']

["Teacher: How might having multiple social roles, such as being a student, a parent, and an aspiring teacher, influence a person's behavior in different settings?", 'You may be, at the same time, a student, a parent, an aspiring teacher, a son or daughter, a spouse, and a lifeguard.']
['What are some ways that culturally shared knowledge can shape and influence social roles?', 'Social roles are defined by culturally shared knowledge.']

['What are some examples of culturally shared knowledge that can shape and influence social roles?', 'That is, nearly everyone in a given culture knows what behavior is expected of a person in a given role.']

['What is an example of culturally shared knowledge that shapes the social role of a student in a college classroom?', 'If you look around a college classroom you will likely see students engaging in studious behavior, taking notes, listening to the professor, reading the textbook, and sitting quietly at their desks (Figure 12.8).']

['How does culturally shared knowledge shape the social role of a student in a college classroom, according to the passage?', 'Of course you may see students deviating from the expected studious behavior such as texting on their phones or using Facebook on their laptops, but in all cases, the students that you observe are attending class—a part of the social role of students.']
['Teacher: How do social roles impact our behavior in various settings?', 'Social roles, and our related behavior, can vary across different settings.']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how social roles influence behavior in a work setting?', 'Now imagine how you behave when you are engaged in the role of employee at your workplace.']
['Teacher: Why is it likely for behavior to be different when someone is in the role of an employee at their workplace?', 'It is very likely that your behavior will be different.']

['Teacher: Why is it important for individuals to adapt their behavior based on their social roles in different settings?', 'Perhaps you are more relaxed and outgoing with your family, making jokes and doing silly things.']

['What are some reasons why individuals may need to adapt their behavior based on their social roles in different settings?', 'But at your workplace you might speak more professionally, and although you may be friendly, you are also serious and focused on getting the work completed.']

['How can social roles impact our sense of identity and personality in different social groups?', 'These are examples of how our social roles influence and often dictate our behavior to the extent that identity and personality can vary with context (that is, in different social groups) (Malloy, Albright, Kenny, Agatstein & Winquist, 1997).']

["Teacher: Can you explain the concept of social roles and how they are determined within a culture's expectations?", 'As discussed previously, social roles are defined by a culture’s shared knowledge of what is expected behavior of an individual in a specific role.']
['Teacher: How do social norms contribute to the determination of social roles in a culture?', 'This shared knowledge comes from social norms.']

['What are some examples of social norms that influence the expectations of individuals in different social roles within a culture?', 'A social norm is a group’s expectation of what is appropriate and acceptable behavior for its members—how they are supposed to behave and think (Deutsch & Gerard, 1955; Berkowitz, 2004).']

["What are some specific social norms that colleges may have for students' behavior in the role of student?", 'In our discussion of social roles we noted that colleges have social norms for students’ behavior in the role of student and workplaces have social norms for employees’ behaviors in the role of employee.']

['What are some examples of social norms that can be observed within families, gangs, and on social media outlets?', 'Social norms are everywhere including in families, gangs, and on social media outlets.']

['Teacher: What is the reason people tend to know what behavior is expected of them in specific, familiar settings?', 'Because of social roles, people tend to know what behavior is expected of them in specific, familiar settings.']
['What is a script?', 'A script is a person’s knowledge about the sequence of events expected in a specific setting (Schank & Abelson, 1977).']

["Teacher: How do people indicate their need for server's attention at a restaurant in the United States?", 'For example, at a restaurant in the United States, if we want the server’s attention, we try to make eye contact.']
["What is an example of how people indicate their need for a server's attention at a restaurant in Brazil?", 'In Brazil, you would make the sound “psst” to get the server’s attention.']
['What are some examples of cultural differences in scripts that you can observe?', 'You can see the cultural differences in scripts.']

["What are some examples of cultural differences in scripts that you can observe in terms of how people indicate their need for a server's attention?", 'To an American, saying “psst” to a server might seem rude, yet to a Brazilian, trying to make eye contact might not seem an effective strategy.']
['What is the significance of scripts in guiding behavior in different situations?', 'Scripts are important sources of information to guide behavior in given situations.']
['What can happen when someone is unfamiliar with the script of a specific setting?', 'This could be uncomfortable and confusing.']

['Teacher: What were some of the key elements that the Stanford Prison Experiment by Philip Zimbardo aimed to demonstrate?', 'The famous Stanford prison experiment, conducted by social psychologist Philip Zimbardo and his colleagues at Stanford University, demonstrated the power of social roles, social norms, and scripts.']

['What was the purpose of the advertisement placed in a California newspaper for the Stanford Prison Experiment?', 'In the summer of 1971, an advertisement was placed in a California newspaper asking for male volunteers to participate in a study about the psychological effects of prison life.']

['What were some of the criteria that the volunteers for the Stanford Prison Experiment had to meet?', 'More than 70 men volunteered, and these volunteers then underwent psychological testing to eliminate candidates who had underlying psychiatric issues, medical issues, or a history of crime or drug abuse.']

['What were some of the factors that contributed to the final selection of participants for the Stanford Prison Experiment?', 'The pool of volunteers was whittled down to 24 healthy male college students.']

['What were the roles that the participants were randomly assigned to in the Stanford Prison Experiment?', 'Each student was paid $15 per day (equivalent to about $80 today) and was randomly assigned to play the role of either a prisoner or a guard in the study.']
["Teacher: Where was the mock prison constructed for Zimbardo's Stanford Prison Experiment?", 'A mock prison was constructed in the basement of the psychology building at Stanford.']

["Teacher: How did participants assigned to play the role of prisoners enter the mock prison in Zimbardo's Stanford Prison Experiment?", 'Participants assigned to play the role of prisoners were “arrested” at their homes by Palo Alto police officers, booked at a police station, and subsequently taken to the mock prison.']
['Teacher: How long was the Stanford Prison Experiment scheduled to run for?', 'The experiment was scheduled to run for several weeks.']

['What was the unexpected reaction of both the "prisoners" and "guards" in Zimbardo\'s Stanford Prison Experiment?', 'To the surprise of the researchers, both the “prisoners” and “guards” assumed their roles with zeal.']

["What actions did the guards take on the second day of the experiment in Zimbardo's Stanford Prison Experiment?", 'On the second day of the experiment, the guards forced the prisoners to strip, took their beds, and isolated the ringleaders using solitary confinement.']

["What were some of the ways in which the guards harassed the prisoners in Zimbardo's Stanford Prison Experiment?", 'In a relatively short time, the guards came to harass the prisoners in an increasingly sadistic manner, through a complete lack of privacy, lack of basic comforts such as mattresses to sleep on, and through degrading chores and late-night counts.']

["Teacher: What were some of the effects observed in the prisoners as a result of the guards' abuse during Zimbardo's Stanford Prison Experiment?", 'The prisoners, in turn, began to show signs of severe anxiety and hopelessness—they began tolerating the guards’ abuse.']

['What was the impact of the experiment on Philip Zimbardo, the head researcher, during the Stanford Prison Experiment?', 'Even the Stanford professor who designed the study and was the head researcher, Philip Zimbardo, found himself acting as if the prison was real and his role, as prison supervisor, was real as well.']
['What led to the decision to prematurely end the Stanford Prison Experiment?', 'After only six days, the experiment had to be ended due to the participants’ deteriorating behavior.']
['Can you provide some examples of the deteriorating behavior that led to the premature end of the Stanford Prison Experiment?', 'Zimbardo explained,']

["Teacher: What are some examples of social roles, norms, and scripts that were demonstrated in Zimbardo's Stanford Prison Experiment?", 'The Stanford Prison Experiment has been used as a memorable demonstration of the incredible power that social roles, norms, and scripts have in affecting human behavior.']

['What are some examples of the criticism that the Stanford Prison Experiment has faced since its inception?', 'However, multiple aspects of the study have been subject to criticism since its inception.']

['What are some examples of the ethical concerns and issues of generalizability that have been raised regarding the Stanford Prison Experiment?', 'The nature of these criticisms range from ethical concerns to issues of generalizability (Bartels, Milovich, & Moussier, 2016; Griggs, 2014; Le Texier, 2019).']

['What impact may the recruitment process have had on the outcome of the Stanford Prison Experiment?', 'One criticism is that the way students were recruited for the experiment may have impacted the outcome (Carnahan & McFarland, 2007).']
["What aspect of the Stanford Prison Experiment's conclusions is being questioned by critics?", 'Another criticism questions the conclusions that can be drawn from the study.']

["What is one specific example of the guidelines provided to the guards in Zimbardo's Stanford Prison Experiment?", 'Zimbardo appears to have provided specific guidelines of the types of behaviors that were expected of the guards (Zimbardo, 2007).']

["What does subsequent research suggest about the impact of the guidelines provided to the guards in Zimbardo's Stanford Prison Experiment?", 'Subsequent research suggests that such guidelines likely created an expectation of the types of behavior that Zimbardo reported observing in the Stanford Prison Experiment (Bartels, 2019), and that given these expectations, the guards simply acted as they thought they were expected to act.']

['What is a challenge or limitation of attempting to replicate aspects of the Stanford Prison Experiment?', 'It has also been problematic that attempts to replicate aspects of the study have not been successful.']

['What were the documented outcomes when no guidelines were presented to the guards in attempts to replicate aspects of the Stanford Prison Experiment?', 'For example, when no guidelines were presented to the guards, researchers documented different outcomes than those observed by Zimbardo.']
['What is one criticism that has been raised regarding the role-playing aspect of the Stanford Prison Experiment?', '(Reicher & Haslam, 2006).']

["Teacher: What real-life event has been compared to Zimbardo's Stanford Prison Experiment, specifically regarding the mistreatment of prisoners?", 'The Stanford Prison Experiment has some parallels with the abuse of prisoners of war by U.S. Army troops and CIA personnel at the Abu Ghraib prison in 2003 and 2004 during the Iraq War.']
['Teacher: How were the offenses at Abu Ghraib prison documented?', 'The offenses at Abu Ghraib were documented by photographs of the abuse, some taken by the abusers themselves (Figure 12.10).']

['Teacher: What have social psychologists done with regards to the influence of the situation on our behaviors?', 'Social psychologists have documented how the power of the situation can influence our behaviors.']

["Teacher: That's a great point! So, in addition to influencing our behaviors, what are social psychologists interested in understanding regarding the power of the situation?", 'Now we turn to how the power of the situation can influence our attitudes and beliefs.']
['Teacher: Excellent! Now, can you explain how social psychologists define persuasion and its relationship with attitudes?', 'Attitude is our evaluation of a person, an idea, or an object.']

["Teacher: That's correct! Now, based on social psychologists' definition, how does persuasion relate to attitudes?", 'We have attitudes for many things ranging from products that we might pick up in the supermarket to people around the world to political policies.']

["Teacher: That's a good explanation. Can you now explain how persuasion is used to change or reinforce attitudes?", 'Typically, attitudes are favorable or unfavorable: positive or negative (Eagly & Chaiken, 1993).']

["Teacher: That's correct! Now, can you provide some examples of how persuasion is used to change attitudes in real life situations?", 'And, they have three components: an affective component (feelings), a behavioral component (the effect of the attitude on behavior), and a cognitive component (belief and knowledge) (Rosenberg & Hovland, 1960).']
['Teacher: Can you provide me with an example of an attitude from the passage?', 'For example, you may hold a positive attitude toward recycling.']

['What kind of attitude might someone have toward recycling based on the passage?', 'This attitude should result in positive feelings toward recycling (such as “It makes me feel good to recycle” or “I enjoy knowing that I make a small difference in reducing the amount of waste that ends up in landfills”).']
['How might someone with a positive attitude toward recycling behave?', 'Certainly, this attitude should be reflected in our behavior:']
['How might someone with a positive attitude toward recycling behave in terms of their recycling habits?', 'You actually recycle as often as you can.']

['How might someone with a positive attitude toward recycling think about the importance of recycling?', 'Finally, this attitude will be reflected in favorable thoughts (for example, “Recycling is good for the environment” or “Recycling is the responsible thing to do”).']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of an external force that can influence our attitudes and beliefs?', 'Our attitudes and beliefs are not only influenced by external forces, but also by internal influences that we control.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of an internal influence that can consciously change our attitudes and thoughts?', 'Like our behavior, our attitudes and thoughts are not always changed by situational pressures, but they can be consciously changed by our own free will.']

['What are the conditions discussed in the section that might prompt us to change our attitudes and beliefs voluntarily?', 'In this section we discuss the conditions under which we would want to change our own attitudes and beliefs.']

['Teacher: How does feeling good about ourselves and maintaining positive self-esteem impact human behavior, according to social psychologists?', 'Social psychologists have documented that feeling good about ourselves and maintaining positive self-esteem is a powerful motivator of human behavior (Tavris & Aronson, 2008).']

['Teacher: How does the view of oneself as a good and above-average person contribute to cognitive dissonance, as discussed by social psychologists?', 'In the United States, members of the predominant culture typically think very highly of themselves and view themselves as good people who are above average on many desirable traits (Ehrlinger, Gilovich, & Ross, 2005).']

['Teacher: How does experiencing a threat to our self-esteem or positive self-image impact our behavior, attitudes, and beliefs, in the context of cognitive dissonance?', 'Often, our behavior, attitudes, and beliefs are affected when we experience a threat to our self-esteem or positive self-image.']

['Teacher: How does cognitive dissonance arise according to psychologist Leon Festinger (1957) and what does it refer to?', 'Psychologist Leon Festinger (1957) defined cognitive dissonance as psychological discomfort arising from holding two or more inconsistent attitudes, behaviors, or cognitions (thoughts, beliefs, or opinions).']

["Teacher: How does Festinger's theory of cognitive dissonance suggest that individuals can resolve the discomfort caused by inconsistent attitudes, behaviors, or beliefs?", 'Festinger’s theory of cognitive dissonance states that when we experience a conflict in our behaviors, attitudes, or beliefs that runs counter to our positive self-perceptions, we experience psychological discomfort (dissonance).']

["Teacher: How can individuals resolve the conflict between their belief and behavior, as described in the example of smoking, according to Festinger's theory of cognitive dissonance?", 'For example, if you believe smoking is bad for your health but you continue to smoke, you experience conflict between your belief and behavior (Figure 12.11).']

['Teacher: According to later research, what type of conflicting cognitions cause dissonance?', 'Later research documented that only conflicting cognitions that threaten individuals’ positive self-image cause dissonance (Greenwald & Ronis, 1978).']

['What are the potential consequences of experiencing cognitive dissonance?', 'Additional research found that dissonance is not only psychologically uncomfortable but also can cause physiological arousal (Croyle & Cooper, 1983) and activate regions of the brain important in emotions and cognitive functioning (van Veen, Krug, Schooler, & Carter, 2009).']

['How does experiencing cognitive dissonance motivate us?', 'When we experience cognitive dissonance, we are motivated to decrease it because it is psychologically, physically, and mentally uncomfortable.']

['How can we bring our cognitions, attitudes, and behaviors in line to reduce cognitive dissonance?', 'We can reduce cognitive dissonance by bringing our cognitions, attitudes, and behaviors in line—that is, making them harmonious.']
['What are some strategies or techniques that can be used to bring our cognitions, attitudes, and behaviors in line to reduce cognitive dissonance?', 'This can be done in different ways, such as:']

["Teacher: How does Joaquin's decision to enlist in the military demonstrate cognitive dissonance?", 'A classic example of cognitive dissonance is Joaquin, a 20-year-old who enlists in the military.']

["Teacher: How does Joaquin's experience during boot camp create cognitive dissonance for him?", 'During boot camp he is awakened at 5:00 a.m., is chronically sleep deprived, yelled at, covered in sand flea bites, physically bruised and battered, and mentally exhausted (Figure 12.12).']
['Teacher: How does Joaquin attempt to justify his decision to enlist in the military despite the challenging experiences he goes through during boot camp?', 'It gets worse.']

["Teacher: How does Joaquin's attempt to justify his decision to enlist in the military align with the concept of changing our cognitions through rationalization or denial?", 'Recruits that make it to week 11 of boot camp have to do 54 hours of continuous training.']
['Teacher: Why might Joaquin be miserable?', 'Not surprisingly, Joaquin is miserable.']
['Teacher: Why do you think Joaquin is miserable?', 'No one likes to be miserable.']

['Teacher: How can changing our beliefs, attitudes, or behaviors help someone like Joaquin who is feeling miserable?', 'In this type of situation, people can change their beliefs, their attitudes, or their behaviors.']
['Teacher: Why is changing behaviors not an option for Joaquin?', 'The last option, a change of behaviors, is not available to Joaquin.']
['Teacher: How might Joaquin change his cognitions to cope with his misery in this situation?', 'He has signed on to the military for four years, and he cannot legally leave.']

['Teacher: How can Joaquin potentially change his thinking in order to have a more positive experience during the four years?', 'If Joaquin keeps thinking about how miserable he is, it is going to be a very long four years.']
['Teacher: What strategies can Joaquin use to change his negative thinking and reduce cognitive dissonance during the four years?', 'He will be in a constant state of cognitive dissonance.']

['Teacher: How can Joaquin change his beliefs or attitudes to reduce cognitive dissonance and have a more positive experience during the four years?', 'As an alternative to this misery, Joaquin can change his beliefs or attitudes.']

['Teacher: How does Joaquin changing his beliefs or attitudes contribute to having a more positive experience during the four years?', 'He can tell himself, “I am becoming stronger, healthier, and sharper.']

["Teacher: How does Joaquin's rationalization about the benefits of smoking contribute to his positive experience during the four years?", 'I am learning discipline and how to defend myself and my country.']
['What new cognition can Joaquin add to contribute to his positive experience during the four years?', 'What I am doing is really important.”']

['How can Joaquin change his thinking about the challenges he will face in order to have a more positive experience during the four years?', 'If this is his belief, he will realize that he is becoming stronger through his challenges.']

["How does Joaquin's belief about becoming stronger through challenges help him avoid cognitive dissonance and have a more positive experience during the four years?", 'He then will feel better and not experience cognitive dissonance, which is an uncomfortable state.']

['Teacher: What does the military example illustrate regarding the effect of initiation on our perception of a group?', 'The military example demonstrates the observation that a difficult initiation into a group influences us to like the group more.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the concept of justification of effort and how it relates to our perception of a group after a difficult initiation?', 'Another social psychology concept, justification of effort, suggests that we value goals and achievements that we put a lot of effort into.']

['Teacher: How does the concept of justification of effort help explain why a difficult initiation into a group can influence our perception of the group?', 'According to this theory, if something is difficult for us to achieve, we believe it is more worthwhile.']

['Teacher: How does the example of assembling a dresser from Ikea relate to the concept of justification of effort and our perception of a group after a difficult initiation?', 'For example, if you move to an apartment and spend hours assembling a dresser you bought from Ikea, you will value that more than a fancier dresser someone else bought you.']

['What does the "concept of justification of effort" suggest about our motivation to stay in a group after a difficult initiation?', 'We do not want to have wasted time and effort to join a group that we eventually leave.']

['What is the purpose of the classic experiment by Aronson and Mills (1959) in relation to the concept of justification of effort?', 'A classic experiment by Aronson and Mills (1959) demonstrated this justification of effort effect.']

['What were the results of the classic experiment by Aronson and Mills (1959) in relation to the concept of justification of effort?', 'College students volunteered to join a campus group that would meet regularly to discuss the psychology of sex.']

["What were the findings of the classic experiment by Aronson and Mills (1959) regarding the effect of initiation on participants' perception of the group?", 'Participants were randomly assigned to one of three conditions: no initiation, an easy initiation, and a difficult initiation into the group.']

["What were the participants' ratings of the group after the first discussion in the classic experiment by Aronson and Mills (1959)?", 'After participating in the first discussion, which was deliberately made very boring, participants rated how much they liked the group.']

['What does the rating of the group by participants in the classic experiment by Aronson and Mills (1959) tell us about the effect of initiation on their perception of the group?', 'Participants who underwent a difficult initiation process to join the group rated the group more favorably than did participants with an easy initiation or no initiation (Figure 12.13).']

['Teacher: Can you tell me about the findings of the more recent study on how student effort influences course evaluations?', 'Similar effects can be seen in a more recent study of how student effort affects course evaluations.']

['Teacher: What was the purpose of the study conducted by Heckert, Latier, Ringwald-Burton, and Drazen (2006) on the amount of effort required in courses at a midwestern university?', 'Heckert, Latier, Ringwald-Burton, and Drazen (2006) surveyed 463 undergraduates enrolled in courses at a midwestern university about the amount of effort that their courses required of them.']

["Teacher: Can you please share the main findings of Heckert et al.'s (2006) study regarding student effort and course evaluations at the midwestern university?", 'In addition, the students were also asked to evaluate various aspects of the course.']

["What was the relationship between the level of effort required in a course and its perceived value according to Heckert et al.'s (2006) study at the midwestern university?", 'Given what you’ve just read, it will come as no surprise that those courses that were associated with the highest level of effort were evaluated as being more valuable than those that did not.']

["What other factors, besides perceived value, were influenced by the level of effort required in a course, according to Heckert et al.'s (2006) study at the midwestern university?", 'Furthermore, students indicated that they learned more in courses that required more effort, regardless of the grades that they received in those courses (Heckert et al., 2006).']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a location that has a very high cost of living?', 'Here is one: Maria and Marco live in Fairfield County, Connecticut, which is one of the wealthiest areas in the United States and has a very high cost of living.']
['Teacher: How does Maria manage to work from home despite living in an area with a high cost of living?', 'Maria telecommutes from home and Marco does not work outside of the home.']
["Teacher: How does the high cost of living affect Maria and Marco's housing situation?", 'They rent a very small house for more than $3000 a month.']
['Teacher: How does Marco adjust his lifestyle to cope with the high cost of living?', 'Marco shops at consignment stores for clothes and economizes when possible.']

['Why do Maria and Marco choose to stay in Fairfield County despite the high cost of living?', 'When asked why they do not move to a less expensive location, since Maria telecommutes, they respond that Fairfield County is beautiful, they love the beaches, and they feel comfortable there.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the concept of cognitive dissonance and how it relates to our attitudes, behaviors, and cognitions?', 'In the previous section we discussed that the motivation to reduce cognitive dissonance leads us to change our attitudes, behaviors, and/or cognitions to make them consonant.']

["Teacher: That's correct. Now, can you give me an example of how persuasion can be used to reduce cognitive dissonance?", 'Persuasion is the process of changing our attitude toward something based on some kind of communication.']
['What are some examples of ways in which outside forces can persuade us to change our attitudes or beliefs?', 'Much of the persuasion we experience comes from outside forces.']

['Teacher: Why has the topic of persuasion been extensively researched in social psychology?', 'The topic of persuasion has been one of the most extensively researched areas in social psychology (Fiske et al., 2010).']

['Teacher: Who is one of the researchers that extensively studied persuasion during the Second World War for the U.S. Army?', 'During the Second World War, Carl Hovland extensively researched persuasion for the U.S. Army.']
['Teacher: What is the name of the approach that Carl Hovland developed during his studies at Yale University?', 'After the war, Hovland continued his exploration of persuasion at Yale University.']

['Teacher: What does the Yale attitude change approach describe?', 'Out of this work came a model called the Yale attitude change approach, which describes the conditions under which people tend to change their attitudes.']

['Teacher: What are some of the factors that the Yale attitude change approach examines in relation to the persuasiveness of a message?', 'Hovland demonstrated that certain features of the source of a persuasive message, the content of the message, and the characteristics of the audience will influence the persuasiveness of a message (Hovland, Janis, & Kelley, 1953).']

['Teacher: What are some key factors that contribute to the source of a persuasive message?', 'Features of the source of the persuasive message include the credibility of the speaker (Hovland & Weiss, 1951) and the physical attractiveness of the speaker (Eagly & Chaiken, 1975; Petty, Wegener, & Fabrigar, 1997).']

['Teacher: Can you explain why speakers who are deemed as credible and trustworthy are more persuasive than less credible speakers?', 'Thus, speakers who are credible, or have expertise on the topic, and who are deemed as trustworthy are more persuasive than less credible speakers.']

['Teacher: What evidence supports the claim that attractive speakers are more persuasive than less attractive speakers?', 'Similarly, more attractive speakers are more persuasive than less attractive speakers.']

['Teacher: How does the use of famous actors and athletes in advertising relate to the Yale Attitude Change Approach?', 'The use of famous actors and athletes to advertise products on television and in print relies on this principle.']

['Teacher: How does the credibility of the messenger affect the impact of persuasion according to the Yale Attitude Change Approach?', 'The immediate and long term impact of the persuasion also depends, however, on the credibility of the messenger (Kumkale & Albarracín, 2004).']

['Teacher: What are some of the features of the message itself that can influence persuasion?', 'Features of the message itself that affect persuasion include subtlety (the quality of being important, but not obvious) (Petty & Cacioppo, 1986; Walster & Festinger, 1962); sidedness (that is, having more than one side) (Crowley & Hoyer, 1994; Igou & Bless, 2003; Lumsdaine & Janis, 1953); timing (Haugtvedt & Wegener, 1994; Miller & Campbell, 1959), and whether both sides are presented.']
['What are some other features of the message itself that can influence persuasion?', 'Messages that are more subtle are more persuasive than direct messages.']

['What is the influence of timing on persuasion when it comes to the order of presenting arguments in a debate?', 'Arguments that occur first, such as in a debate, are more influential if messages are given back-to-back.']

['How does the presence of both sides in a message affect persuasion?', 'However, if there is a delay after the first message, and before the audience needs to make a decision, the last message presented will tend to be more persuasive (Miller & Campbell, 1959).']

['Teacher: What are some features of the audience that have been found to affect persuasion according to the Yale Attitude Change Approach?', 'Features of the audience that affect persuasion are attention (Albarracín & Wyer, 2001; Festinger & Maccoby, 1964), intelligence, self-esteem (Rhodes & Wood, 1992), and age (Krosnick & Alwin, 1989).']

['Why is attention considered one of the features of the audience that can affect persuasion according to the Yale Attitude Change Approach?', 'In order to be persuaded, audience members must be paying attention.']

['Why is self-esteem considered one of the features of the audience that can affect persuasion according to the Yale Attitude Change Approach?', 'People with lower intelligence are more easily persuaded than people with higher intelligence; whereas people with moderate self-esteem are more easily persuaded than people with higher or lower self-esteem (Rhodes & Wood, 1992).']
['What is the impact of age on persuasion according to the Yale Attitude Change Approach?', 'Finally, younger adults aged 18–25 are more persuadable than older adults.']

['Teacher: Can you explain to me what the elaboration likelihood model of persuasion is?', 'An especially popular model that describes the dynamics of persuasion is the elaboration likelihood model of persuasion (Petty & Cacioppo, 1986).']

['Teacher: How does the elaboration likelihood model of persuasion determine when attitude change will occur?', 'The elaboration likelihood model considers the variables of the attitude change approach—that is, features of the source of the persuasive message, contents of the message, and characteristics of the audience are used to determine when attitude change will occur.']

['What are the main routes described by the elaboration likelihood model of persuasion?', 'According to the elaboration likelihood model of persuasion, there are two main routes that play a role in delivering a persuasive message: central and peripheral (Figure 12.15).']
['Teacher: What is the nature of the central route in the Elaboration Likelihood Model?', 'The central route is logic driven and uses data and facts to convince people of an argument’s worthiness.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how the central route can be used to persuade someone to purchase a car?', 'For example, a car company seeking to persuade you to purchase their model will emphasize the car’s safety features and fuel economy.']

['Teacher: How does the central route in the Elaboration Likelihood Model differ from other routes to persuasion?', 'This is a direct route to persuasion that focuses on the quality of the information.']

['Teacher: Why is it important for the argument in the central route to be strong in order to achieve lasting attitude change?', 'In order for the central route of persuasion to be effective in changing attitudes, thoughts, and behaviors, the argument must be strong and, if successful, will result in lasting attitude change.']

['Teacher: What is the ideal characteristic of the target audience that makes the central route to persuasion most effective?', 'The central route to persuasion works best when the target of persuasion, or the audience, is analytical and willing to engage in processing of the information.']
['Teacher: Can you explain why buying a computer is an example of the central route to persuasion?', 'One example is buying a computer.']

["Teacher: Why might small business owners be especially influenced by the focus on the computer's quality and features such as processing speed and memory capacity?", 'It is likely, for example, that small business owners might be especially influenced by the focus on the computer’s quality and features such as processing speed and memory capacity.']

['Teacher: Can you please explain the concept of the peripheral route in the Elaboration Likelihood Model?', 'The peripheral route is an indirect route that uses peripheral cues to associate positivity with the message (Petty & Cacioppo, 1986).']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how the peripheral route in the Elaboration Likelihood Model relies on association with positive characteristics?', 'Instead of focusing on the facts and a product’s quality, the peripheral route relies on association with positive characteristics such as positive emotions and celebrity endorsement.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why using a popular athlete to advertise athletic shoes is an example of the peripheral route in the Elaboration Likelihood Model?', 'For example, having a popular athlete advertise athletic shoes is a common method used to encourage young adults to purchase the shoes.']

['Teacher: Why does the peripheral route in the Elaboration Likelihood Model not require much effort or information processing?', 'This route to attitude change does not require much effort or information processing.']

['Why does the peripheral route in the Elaboration Likelihood Model typically result in less permanent attitude or behavior change?', 'This method of persuasion may promote positivity toward the message or product, but it typically results in less permanent attitude or behavior change.']

['What are some potential consequences of relying on the peripheral route in the Elaboration Likelihood Model for attitude or behavior change?', 'The audience does not need to be analytical or motivated to process the message.']

['What are some potential challenges or pitfalls of using the peripheral route in the Elaboration Likelihood Model for attitude or behavior change?', 'In fact, a peripheral route to persuasion may not even be noticed by the audience, for example in the strategy of product placement.']

['What is the purpose of using product placement as a strategy in the peripheral route of the Elaboration Likelihood Model?', 'Product placement refers to putting a product with a clear brand name or brand identity in a TV show or movie to promote the product (Gupta & Lord, 1998).']

['What is an example of product placement as a strategy in the peripheral route of the Elaboration Likelihood Model?', 'For example, one season of the reality series American Idol prominently showed the panel of judges drinking out of cups that displayed the Coca-Cola logo.']

['What role do peripheral cues play in the peripheral route of the Elaboration Likelihood Model?', 'Another example is clothing: A retailer may focus on celebrities that are wearing the same style of clothing.']

["Teacher: Can you provide an example of one such persuasion strategy that researchers have tested and found effective in selling products and changing people's attitude, ideas, and behaviors?", 'Researchers have tested many persuasion strategies that are effective in selling products and changing people’s attitude, ideas, and behaviors.']

["Teacher: What is an example of a persuasion strategy that researchers have found effective in selling products and changing people's attitude, ideas, and behaviors?", 'One effective strategy is the foot-in-the-door technique (Cialdini, 2001; Pliner, Hart, Kohl, & Saari, 1974).']

['How does the foot-in-the-door technique work in persuasion?', 'Using the foot-in-the-door technique, the persuader gets a person to agree to bestow a small favor or to buy a small item, only to later request a larger favor or purchase of a bigger item.']

['What does the study by Freedman and Fraser (1966) demonstrate about the effectiveness of the foot-in-the-door technique?', 'The foot-in-the-door technique was demonstrated in a study by Freedman and Fraser (1966) in which participants who agreed to a post small sign in their yard or sign a petition were more likely to agree to put a large sign in their yard than people who declined the first request (Figure 12.16).']

['What principle does the foot-in-the-door technique illustrate according to research?', 'Research on this technique also illustrates the principle of consistency (Cialdini, 2001): Our past behavior often directs our future behavior, and we have a desire to maintain consistency once we have committed to a behavior.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how the foot-in-the-door technique can be applied in the context of adolescents and their parents?', 'A common application of foot-in-the-door is when teens ask their parents for a small permission (for example, extending curfew by a half hour) and then asking them for something larger.']

['Teacher: Why does granting the smaller request increase the likelihood of parents acquiescing with the larger request in the context of adolescents and their parents using the foot-in-the-door technique?', 'Having granted the smaller request increases the likelihood that parents will acquiesce with the later, larger request.']

['Teacher: Can you explain how the foot-in-the-door technique may be applied in the scenario you mentioned regarding buying a smartphone and the suggestion to purchase a data plan?', 'For example, say that you are buying the latest model smartphone, and the salesperson suggests you purchase the best data plan.']
['Teacher: Can you describe what happens after you agree to purchasing the data plan in the context of the foot-in-the-door technique?', 'You agree to this.']

["Teacher: How does the salesperson's suggestion of purchasing the three-year extended warranty relate to the foot-in-the-door technique in this scenario?", 'The salesperson then suggests a bigger purchase—the three-year extended warranty.']

['Teacher: What psychological principle does the foot-in-the-door technique rely on in this scenario?', 'After agreeing to the smaller request, you are more likely to also agree to the larger request.']
['Teacher: Can you explain how the foot-in-the-door technique might apply in the context of buying a car?', 'You may have encountered this if you have bought a car.']

["Teacher: How does the salesperson's suggestion to add on multiple options to the car relate to the foot-in-the-door technique in this scenario?", 'When salespeople realize that a buyer intends to purchase a certain model, they might try to get the customer to pay for many or most available options on the car.']

['What is the likely outcome of the salesperson suggesting multiple options for the car in the context of the foot-in-the-door technique?', 'Another example of the foot-in-the-door technique would be applied to an individual in the market for a used car who decides to buy a fully loaded new car.']

['What is the main reason the buyer decides to purchase a fully loaded new car in this scenario?', 'Because the salesperson convinced the buyer that they need a car that has all of the safety features that were not available in the used car.']
['Teacher: What are the additional ways in which people influence others that are discussed in this section?', 'In this section, we discuss additional ways in which people influence others.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an overview of the specific topics covered in this section related to how people influence others?', 'The topics of conformity, social influence, obedience, and group processes demonstrate the power of the social situation to change our thoughts, feelings, and behaviors.']

['Teacher: What is the famous social psychology experiment discussed in this section that demonstrated the susceptibility of humans to outside social pressures?', 'We begin this section with a discussion of a famous social psychology experiment that demonstrated how susceptible humans are to outside social pressures.']

["Teacher: What was the purpose of Solomon Asch's experiments in the 1950s regarding the influence of thoughts and behaviors of others on individuals?", 'Solomon Asch conducted several experiments in the 1950s to determine how people are affected by the thoughts and behaviors of other people.']

["Teacher: Can you explain how Solomon Asch's experiments used printed line segments of different lengths to study the influence of thoughts and behaviors of others on individuals?", 'In one study, a group of participants was shown a series of printed line segments of different lengths: a, b, and c (Figure 12.17).']

["Teacher: What task were the participants of Solomon Asch's experiment asked to do after being shown the line segments of different lengths?", 'Participants were then shown a fourth line segment: x.']

["Teacher: Can you explain how the participants in Solomon Asch's experiment were expected to respond when identifying the line segment that most closely resembled the fourth line segment in length?", 'They were asked to identify which line segment from the first group (a, b, or c) most closely resembled the fourth line segment in length.']
['Teacher: What was the composition of each group of participants in the study?', 'Each group of participants had only one true, naïve subject.']
['Teacher: How were the other participants in each group characterized in the study on conformity?', 'The remaining members of the group were confederates of the researcher.']
['Teacher: What is the role of a confederate in the study on conformity?', 'A confederate is a person who is aware of the experiment and works for the researcher.']

['What is the purpose of using confederates in the study on conformity?', 'Confederates are used to manipulate social situations as part of the research design, and the true, naïve participants believe that confederates are, like them, uninformed participants in the experiment.']

["What was the specific task that the confederates were assigned to perform in Asch's study on conformity?", 'In Asch’s study, the confederates identified a line segment that was obviously shorter than the target line—a wrong answer.']

["What was the purpose of having the confederates provide a wrong answer in Asch's study on conformity?", 'The naïve participant then had to identify aloud the line segment that best matched the target line segment.']

["Teacher: According to Asch's study on conformity, what percentage of participants demonstrated conformity by choosing the incorrect line?", 'Asch (1955) found that 76% of participants conformed to group pressure at least once by indicating the incorrect line.']
['What is the definition of conformity according to the passage?', 'Conformity is the change in a person’s behavior to go along with the group, even if he does not agree with the group.']

['Teacher: According to the passage, what are some of the key influences on conformity in the Asch effect?', 'Research shows that the size of the majority, the presence of another dissenter, and the public or relatively private nature of responses are key influences on conformity.']
['What is the focus or subject of the Asch effect?', 'The size of the majority:']

["Teacher: Can you explain how the size of the majority influences individuals' conformity in the Asch effect?", 'The greater the number of people in the majority, the more likely an individual will conform.']

['What is the point called when adding more members to the majority does not increase conformity in the Asch effect?', 'There is, however, an upper limit: a point where adding more members does not increase conformity.']

["Teacher: Can you provide an example of the number of individuals in the majority where conformity in the Asch effect no longer increases according to Asch's study?", 'In Asch’s study, conformity increased with the number of people in the majority—up to seven individuals.']

["Teacher: What did Asch's study reveal about conformity when the number of individuals in the majority exceeded seven?", 'At numbers beyond seven, conformity leveled off and decreased slightly (Asch, 1955).']
['Teacher: How does the presence of another dissenter affect conformity in the Asch effect?', 'The presence of another dissenter:']
['Teacher: What impact does the presence of another dissenter have on conformity rates in the Asch effect?', 'If there is at least one dissenter, conformity rates drop to near zero (Asch, 1955).']
['Teacher: How does the public or private nature of the responses affect conformity in the Asch effect?', 'The public or private nature of the responses:']

['Teacher: How does the public or private nature of the responses influence conformity rates in the Asch effect?', 'When responses are made publicly (in front of others), conformity is more likely; however, when responses are made privately (e.g., writing down the response), conformity is less likely (Deutsch & Gerard, 1955).']

['Teacher: Can you explain why government elections require voting in secret, according to the passage?', 'The finding that conformity is more likely to occur when responses are public than when they are private is the reason government elections require voting in secret, so we are not coerced by others (Figure 12.18).']

['Teacher: How does the Asch effect connect to the reason government elections require voting in secret?', 'The Asch effect can be easily seen in children when they have to publicly vote for something.']

['Teacher: What does the example of children voting for extra recess, no homework, or candy demonstrate about the Asch effect in relation to government elections requiring voting in secret?', 'For example, if the teacher asks whether the children would rather have extra recess, no homework, or candy, once a few children vote, the rest will comply and go with the majority.']

['Teacher: How does the concept of voting in secret help prevent the influence of the group majority on individual judgment, as demonstrated by the example of children voting for extra recess, no homework, or candy?', 'In a different classroom, the majority might vote differently, and most of the children would comply with that majority.']

['Teacher: How does compliance relate to the concept of voting in secret and the influence of the group majority on individual judgment?', 'When someone’s vote changes if it is made in public versus private, this is known as compliance.']

['Teacher: How does compliance, as a form of conformity, contribute to the influence of the group majority on individual judgment, and how does voting in secret help mitigate this influence?', 'Compliance can be a form of conformity.']

['Teacher: How does the concept of voting in secret in government elections help mitigate the influence of compliance, as a form of conformity, on individual judgment?', 'Compliance is going along with a request or demand, even if you do not agree with the request.']

["Teacher: How does the example of Asch's study on compliance, where participants gave wrong answers publicly but privately did not believe they were correct, demonstrate the importance of voting in secret in government elections?", 'In Asch’s studies, the participants complied by giving the wrong answers, but privately did not accept that the obvious wrong answers were correct.']
['Teacher: Why is it important to note that the correct answer was obvious and it was an easy task?', 'The correct answer to the line segment question was obvious, and it was an easy task.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the two types of motivation to conform that researchers have identified?', 'Researchers have categorized the motivation to conform into two types: normative social influence and informational social influence (Deutsch & Gerard, 1955).']

['Teacher: Can you explain what people are trying to achieve when they conform to the group norm in normative social influence?', 'In normative social influence, people conform to the group norm to fit in, to feel good, and to be accepted by the group.']

['Teacher: How does normative social influence differ from informational social influence in terms of the reasons people conform to the group norm?', 'However, with informational social influence, people conform because they believe the group is competent and has the correct information, particularly when the task or situation is ambiguous.']

['Teacher: Why did participants in the line judgment task not rely on the group for information?', 'Since the line judgment task was unambiguous, participants did not need to rely on the group for information.']

['Teacher: How does the Asch effect relate to normative social influence in the line judgment task?', 'Instead, participants complied to fit in and avoid ridicule, an instance of normative social influence.']

["Teacher: Can you provide me with an example of how the group majority influences an individual's judgment in an emergency situation?", 'An example of informational social influence may be what to do in an emergency situation.']

["Teacher: That's a great example! In this situation, how might the group majority influence your judgment on what actions to take?", 'Imagine that you are in a movie theater watching a film and what seems to be smoke comes in the theater from under the emergency exit door.']

['Teacher: How might the presence of other people in the movie theater affect your judgment on whether or not to take action in response to the potential emergency?', 'You are not certain that it is smoke—it might be a special effect for the movie, such as a fog machine.']

['Teacher: What is the term used to describe this behavior of looking at the behavior of others in the theater when you are uncertain about whether or not to take action in response to the potential emergency?', 'When you are uncertain you will tend to look at the behavior of others in the theater.']

['Teacher: What is the psychological term that describes the tendency to look at the behavior of others in the theater in order to determine how to respond in a potential emergency situation?', 'If other people show concern and get up to leave, you are likely to do the same.']

["Teacher: What is the name of this phenomenon where an individual's judgment is influenced by the behavior and actions of others in a group situation?", 'However, if others seem unconcerned, you are likely to stay put and continue watching the movie (Figure 12.19).']

['Teacher: What argument might these students present to support their belief that the study on The Asch effect is outdated?', 'Many students say they would not conform, that the study is outdated, and that people nowadays are more independent.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why some students might argue that people nowadays are more independent and less likely to conform compared to when the study on The Asch effect was conducted?', 'To some extent this may be true.']

["Teacher: What evidence from research could support the idea that overall rates of conformity have reduced since the time of Asch's research?", 'Research suggests that overall rates of conformity may have reduced since the time of Asch’s research.']
["Asch's study have shown that the rate of conformity has decreased over time.", 'Furthermore, efforts to replicate']

["Teacher: What are some of the factors that Asch's study and its replications have revealed that determine an individual's likelihood to demonstrate conformity to the group?", 'Asch’s study have made it clear that many factors determine how likely it is that someone will demonstrate conformity to the group.']

["Teacher: Can you provide some examples from the research that support the claim that factors such as age, gender, and socio-cultural background influence an individual's likelihood to demonstrate conformity to the group?", 'These factors include the participant’s age, gender, and socio-cultural background (Bond & Smith, 1996; Larsen, 1990; Walker & Andrade, 1996).']

['Teacher: According to the passage, what is one effect of the influence of others on our thoughts, feelings, and behaviors?', 'Conformity is one effect of the influence of others on our thoughts, feelings, and behaviors.']

["Teacher: Can you provide an example from the passage that demonstrates the concept of obedience to authority in Stanley Milgram's Experiment?", 'Another form of social influence is obedience to authority.']

["Teacher: According to the passage, what are some factors that influence a person's level of obedience in Stanley Milgram's Experiment?", 'Obedience is the change of an individual’s behavior to comply with a demand by an authority figure.']

["Teacher: What is one factor mentioned in the passage that can explain why people in Stanley Milgram's Experiment often complied with the requests given by the authority figure?", 'People often comply with the request because they are concerned about a consequence if they do not comply.']

['What is the purpose of reviewing another classic social psychology experiment in relation to the phenomenon mentioned in the passage?', 'To demonstrate this phenomenon, we review another classic social psychology experiment.']

["Teacher: That's correct! Now, can you please explain how the trial of Adolf Eichmann influenced Stanley Milgram's experimentation in social psychology?", 'Stanley Milgram was a social psychology professor at Yale who was influenced by the trial of Adolf Eichmann, a Nazi war criminal.']

["What was Eichmann's defense for the atrocities he committed?", 'Eichmann’s defense for the atrocities he committed was that he was “just following orders.” Milgram (1963) wanted to test the validity of this defense, so he designed an experiment and initially recruited 40 men for his experiment.']

["What did the volunteer participants of Milgram's experiment believe they were participating in?", 'The volunteer participants were led to believe that they were participating in a study to improve learning and memory.']
["What was the role of the learners in Milgram's experiment?", 'The participants were told that they were to teach other students (learners) correct answers to a series of test items.']

['What was the purpose of the electric shocks that participants believed they were delivering to the learners?', 'The participants were shown how to use a device that they were told delivered electric shocks of different intensities to the learners.']

['What was the reaction of the participants when they administered the electric shocks to the learners?', 'The participants were told to shock the learners if they gave a wrong answer to a test item—that the shock would help them to learn.']

["What percentage of participants in Milgram's experiment administered the maximum 450-volt shock to the learners?", 'The participants believed they gave the learners shocks, which increased in 15-volt increments, all the way up to 450 volts.']

['What were the consequences for the participants who administered the maximum 450-volt shock to the learners?', 'The participants did not know that the learners were confederates and that the confederates did not actually receive shocks.']

["Teacher: What was the participants' behavior towards the learners after receiving a string of incorrect answers?", 'In response to a string of incorrect answers from the learners, the participants obediently and repeatedly shocked them.']

["Teacher: How did the confederate learners react to the participants' behavior of obediently and repeatedly shocking them?", 'The confederate learners cried out for help, begged the participant teachers to stop, and even complained of heart trouble.']

['What percentage of participants continued to administer shocks to the maximum voltage, even when the confederate learners cried out for help and complained of heart trouble?', 'Yet, when the researcher told the participant-teachers to continue the shock, 65% of the participants continued the shock to the maximum voltage and to the point that the learner became unresponsive (Figure 12.20).']

['Teacher: What was the purpose of conducting several variations of the original Milgram experiment?', 'Several variations of the original Milgram experiment were conducted to test the boundaries of obedience.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of one of the variations conducted in the Milgram experiment where a feature of the situation was changed?', 'When certain features of the situation were changed, participants were less likely to continue to deliver shocks (Milgram, 1965).']

["Teacher: How did the change in setting affect the participants' behavior in the Milgram experiment?", 'For example, when the setting of the experiment was moved to an off-campus office building, the percentage of participants who delivered the highest shock dropped to 48%.']

["What impact did changing the proximity between the learner and the teacher have on the participants' behavior in the Milgram experiment?", 'When the learner was in the same room as the teacher, the highest shock rate dropped to 40%.']

["What effect did altering the physical contact between the teacher and the learner have on the participants' behavior in the Milgram experiment?", 'When the teachers’ and learners’ hands were touching, the highest shock rate dropped to 30%.']

['What was the result of changing the method of communication between the researcher and the teacher in the Milgram experiment?', 'When the researcher gave the orders by phone, the rate dropped to 23%.']

['What conclusions can be drawn from the variations conducted in the Milgram experiment regarding the impact of increasing the humanity of the person being shocked?', 'These variations show that when the humanity of the person being shocked was increased, obedience decreased.']

['What conclusions can be drawn from the variations conducted in the Milgram experiment regarding the impact of decreasing the authority of the experimenter?', 'Similarly, when the authority of the experimenter decreased, so did obedience.']
["Teacher: In what ways do you think Stanley Milgram's Experiment is still applicable today?", 'This case is still very applicable today.']

["Teacher: Can you provide an example of a recent study or research that demonstrates the continued relevance of Stanley Milgram's Experiment?", 'In a study by Martin and Bull (2008), midwives privately filled out a questionnaire regarding best practices and expectations in delivering a baby.']

['Teacher: What were the participants in the study by Martin and Bull (2008) asked to do by their senior midwife and supervisor, despite their initial opposition?', 'Then, a more senior midwife and supervisor asked the junior midwives to do something they had previously stated they were opposed to.']

["Teacher: What parallel can you draw between the behavior of the junior midwives in the study by Martin and Bull (2008) and the participants in Stanley Milgram's Experiment?", 'Most of the junior midwives were obedient to authority, going against their own beliefs.']
['Teacher: Can you explain what Burger (2009) found in his partial replication of the study by Martin and Bull (2008)?', 'Burger (2009) partially replicated this study.']

['Teacher: What did Burger (2009) find in terms of obedience levels among a multicultural sample of women and men?', "He found among a multicultural sample of women and men that their levels of obedience matched Milgram's research."]

["Teacher: What were the findings of Doliński et al. (2017) in their replication of Burger's work in Poland, particularly with regards to obedience levels and gender?\nStudent: Doliński et al. (2017) found that even when gender was controlled for among both participants and learners, their results still aligned with Milgram's original work.", "Doliński et al. (2017) performed a replication of Burger's work in Poland and controlled for the gender of both participants and learners, and once again, results that were consistent with Milgram's original work were observed."]

["Teacher: What term is used to describe the phenomenon where individuals in a group tend to conform to the group's decision or opinions, even if it goes against their own beliefs?", 'When in group settings, we are often influenced by the thoughts, feelings, and behaviors of people around us.']

["Teacher: That's a great point, student. So, can you tell me what are the two types of social influence that can lead individuals to conform to a group's decision or opinions?", 'Whether it is due to normative or informational social influence, groups have power to influence individuals.']
['What is groupthink and how does it contribute to the conformity of individuals within a group?', 'Another phenomenon of group conformity is groupthink.']

['What are some of the factors that contribute to groupthink and how do they impact the decision-making process within a group?', 'Groupthink is the modification of the opinions of members of a group to align with what they believe is the group consensus (Janis, 1972).']

['What are some of the negative consequences that can arise from groupthink?', 'In group situations, the group often takes action that individuals would not perform outside the group setting because groups make more extreme decisions than individuals do.']
['What are some strategies that can be used to prevent or mitigate the occurrence of groupthink in a group setting?', 'Moreover, groupthink can hinder opposing trains of thought.']

['What can individuals do to promote the expression of diverse opinions within a group and prevent the occurrence of groupthink?', 'This elimination of diverse opinions contributes to faulty decision by the group.']
['Teacher: Can you please elaborate on the causes of groupthink that make it preventable?', 'There are several causes of groupthink, which makes it preventable.']

['Teacher: How does a strong sense of connection within a group contribute to the prevalence of groupthink?', 'When the group is highly cohesive, or has a strong sense of connection, maintaining group harmony may become more important to the group than making sound decisions.']

['Teacher: How can the presence of a directive leader discourage group members from expressing their disagreements?', 'If the group leader is directive and makes his opinions known, this may discourage group members from disagreeing with the leader.']

['What role does the limited exposure to different perspectives play in the occurrence of groupthink?', 'If the group is isolated from hearing alternative or new viewpoints, groupthink may be more likely.']

['Teacher: What are some strategies that can improve group decision making according to Janis (1972) and Mitchell & Eckstein (2009)?', 'There are several strategies that can improve group decision making including seeking outside opinions, voting in private, having the leader withhold position statements until all group members have voiced their views, conducting research on all viewpoints, weighing the costs and benefits of all options, and developing a contingency plan (Janis, 1972; Mitchell & Eckstein, 2009).']
['Teacher: What is another phenomenon that occurs within group settings?', 'Another phenomenon that occurs within group settings is group polarization.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the concept of group polarization and how it influences group attitudes?', 'Group polarization (Teger & Pruitt, 1967) is the strengthening of an original group attitude after the discussion of views within a group.']

['Teacher: How does the concept of group polarization relate to the strengthening of group attitudes after discussing views within a group?', 'That is, if a group initially favors a viewpoint, after discussion the group consensus is likely a stronger endorsement of the viewpoint.']
