["Teacher: What are some examples of benefits and costs that individuals consider in social exchanges or relationships, according to Sternberg's Triangular Theory of Love?", 'Let’s discuss an example.']

["Teacher: What are some advantages and disadvantages of committing to a romantic relationship, according to Sternberg's Triangular Theory of Love?", 'If you have ever decided to commit to a romantic relationship, you probably considered the advantages and disadvantages of your decision.']

["Teacher: What are some potential costs or disadvantages of committing to a romantic relationship, according to Sternberg's Triangular Theory of Love?", 'You may have considered having companionship, intimacy, and passion, but also being comfortable with a person you know well.']

["Teacher: According to Sternberg's Triangular Theory of Love, what are some potential benefits or advantages of committing to a romantic relationship?", 'You may think that over time boredom from being with only one person may set in; moreover, it may be expensive to share activities such as attending movies and going to dinner.']

["Teacher: Can you explain why individuals would continue a romantic relationship even when there are potential costs involved, according to Sternberg's Triangular Theory of Love?", 'However, the benefits of dating your romantic partner presumably outweigh the costs, or you wouldn’t continue the relationship.']

['Teacher: What are the average number of hours per week that people in the United States worked in 2019?', 'In 2019, people who worked in the United States spent an average of about 42–54 hours per week working (Bureau of Labor Statistics—U.S. Department of Labor, 2019).']

['Teacher: According to the passage, what activity did people in the United States spend more time on than working in 2019?', 'Sleeping was the only other activity they spent more time on with an average of about 43–62 hours per week.']
["Teacher: How does the passage describe the importance of the workday in relation to workers' time and energy?", 'The workday is a significant portion of workers’ time and energy.']

['What are some examples of the positive and negative impacts that the workday can have on workers and their families?', 'It impacts their lives and their family’s lives in positive and negative physical and psychological ways.']

['What does industrial and organizational (I-O) psychology focus on studying?', 'Industrial and organizational (I-O) psychology is a branch of psychology that studies how human behavior and psychology affect work and how they are affected by work.']

['Teacher: What are the four main contexts in which industrial and organizational psychologists work?', 'Industrial and organizational psychologists work in four main contexts: academia, government, consulting firms, and business.']
['Teacher: What level of education do most industrial and organizational psychologists have?', 'Most I-O psychologists have a master’s or doctorate degree.']

['Teacher: How is the field of I-O psychology divided into broad areas?', 'The field of I-O psychology can be divided into three broad areas (Figure 13.2 and Figure 13.3): industrial, organizational, and human factors.']

['Teacher: How does industrial psychology contribute to the field of I-O psychology?', 'Industrial psychology is concerned with describing job requirements and assessing individuals for their ability to meet those requirements.']

['Teacher: How does organizational psychology contribute to the field of I-O psychology?', 'In addition, once employees are hired, industrial psychology studies and develops ways to train, evaluate, and respond to those evaluations.']

['Teacher: How does industrial psychology address the issue of legality in hiring practices?', 'As a consequence of its concern for candidate characteristics, industrial psychology must also consider issues of legality regarding discrimination in hiring.']

['Teacher: How does organizational psychology contribute to the field of I-O psychology?', 'Organizational psychology is a discipline interested in how the relationships among employees affect those employees and the performance of a business.']
['Teacher: How does the field of industrial and organizational psychology contribute to the improvement of businesses?', 'This includes studying worker satisfaction, motivation, and commitment.']

['Teacher: How do industrial and organizational psychologists contribute to the improvement of businesses?', 'This field also studies management, leadership, and organizational culture, as well as how an organization’s structures, management and leadership styles, social norms, and role expectations affect individual behavior.']

['Teacher: How does industrial and organizational psychology address the issue of worker wellbeing and relationships within an organization?', 'As a result of its interest in worker wellbeing and relationships, organizational psychology also considers the subjects of harassment, including sexual harassment, and workplace violence.']

['Teacher: What is the focus of human factors psychology in the field of industrial and organizational psychology?', 'Human factors psychology is the study of how workers interact with the tools of work and how to design those tools to optimize workers’ productivity, safety, and health.']

["What are some examples of the tools that human factors psychology in the field of industrial and organizational psychology studies and designs to optimize workers' productivity, safety, and health?", 'These studies can involve interactions as straightforward as the fit of a desk, chair, and computer to a human having to sit on the chair at the desk using the computer for several hours each day.']

["What are some other examples of tools that human factors psychology studies and designs to optimize workers' productivity, safety, and health, apart from desk, chair, and computer arrangements?", 'They can also include the examination of how humans interact with complex displays and their ability to interpret them accurately and quickly.']
['What term is used to refer to the field of human factors psychology in Europe?', 'In Europe, this field is referred to as ergonomics.']

['Teacher: Can you please provide a brief explanation of the field of occupational health psychology (OHP)?', 'Occupational health psychology (OHP) deals with the stress, diseases, and disorders that can affect employees as a result of the workplace.']

['Teacher: How does the field of occupational health psychology incorporate knowledge from various disciplines?', 'As such, the field is informed by research from the medical, biological, psychological, organizational, human factors, human resources, and industrial fields.']

['Teacher: What are some of the key aspects that occupational health psychology researchers analyze when studying the influence of organizations on employee work life and responses?', 'Individuals in this field seek to examine the ways in which the organization affects the quality of work life for an employee and the responses that employees have towards their organization or as a result of their organization’s influence on them.']

["Teacher: How does the lack of work-life balance impact employees' responses to their organization?", 'The responses for employees are not limited to the workplace as there may be some spillover into their personal lives outside of work, especially if there is not good work-life balance.']

['How does the field of occupational health psychology contribute to improving the overall health and well-being of individuals?', 'The ultimate goal of an occupational health psychologist is to improve the overall health and well-being of an individual, and, as a result, increase the overall health of the organization (Society for Occupational Health Psychology, 2020).']

['Teacher: How did the field of humanitarian work psychology (HWP) originate in 2009?', 'In 2009, the field of humanitarian work psychology (HWP) was developed as the brainchild of a small group of I-O psychologists who met at a conference.']

['What led the small group of I-O psychologists to develop the field of humanitarian work psychology (HWP) in 2009?', 'Realizing they had a shared set of goals involving helping those who are underserved and underprivileged, the I-O psychologists formally formed the group in 2012 and have approximately 300 members worldwide.']
['What was the motivation behind the formation of the group of I-O psychologists in 2012?', 'Although this is a small number, the group continues to expand.']
['What specific population does the group of I-O psychologists aim to assist in finding work?', 'The group seeks to help marginalized members of society, such as people with low-income, find work.']

['What are some other areas of focus for the group of I-O psychologists besides assisting marginalized members of society in finding work?', 'In addition, they help to determine ways to deliver humanitarian aid during major catastrophes.']

['What is one way that the Humanitarian Work Psychology group reaches out to individuals in the local community who are in need of assistance?', 'The Humanitarian Work Psychology group can also reach out to those in the local community who do not have the knowledge, skills, and abilities (KSAs) to be able to find gainful employment that would enable them to not need to receive aid.']

['What is the main goal of the Humanitarian Work Psychology group when reaching out to individuals in the local community who are in need of assistance?', 'In both cases, humanitarian work psychologists try to help the underserved individuals develop KSAs that they can use to improve their lives and their current situations.']

['What is the focus of the training or education provided by humanitarian work psychologists to underserved individuals in the local community?', 'When ensuring these underserved individuals receive training or education, the focus is on skills that, once learned, will never be forgotten and can serve individuals throughout their lifetimes as they seek employment (APA, 2016).']
['What information can be found in Table 13.1 about the main fields in I-O psychology?', 'Table 13.1 summarizes the main fields in I-O psychology, their focuses, and jobs within each field.']
['Teacher: When did industrial and organizational psychology originate?', 'Industrial and organizational psychology had its origins in the early 20th century.']

['Teacher: Who were some of the influential early psychologists who studied issues that would be categorized as industrial psychology?', 'Several influential early psychologists studied issues that today would be categorized as industrial psychology: James Cattell (1860–1944), Hugo Münsterberg (1863–1916), Walter Dill Scott (1869–1955), Robert Yerkes (1876–1956), Walter Bingham (1880–1952), and Lillian Gilbreth (1878–1972).']

['Teacher: How did Cattell, Münsterberg, and Scott contribute to the field of industrial psychology?', 'Cattell, Münsterberg, and Scott had been students of Wilhelm Wundt, the father of experimental psychology.']

["Teacher: What is the significance of the researchers' involvement in industrial psychology before World War I?", 'Some of these researchers had been involved in work in the area of industrial psychology before World War I.']

['Teacher: How did the involvement of researchers in industrial psychology before World War I lay the foundation for its development?', 'Cattell’s contribution to industrial psychology is largely reflected in his founding of a psychological consulting company, which is still operating today called the Psychological Corporation, and in the accomplishments of students at Columbia in the area of industrial psychology.']

['Teacher: What were some topics covered in Münsterberg\'s book "Psychology and Industrial Efficiency"?', 'In 1913, Münsterberg published Psychology and Industrial Efficiency, which covered topics such as employee selection, employee training, and effective advertising.']

['Teacher: Who was one of the first psychologists to apply psychology to advertising, management, and personnel selection?', 'Scott was one of the first psychologists to apply psychology to advertising, management, and personnel selection.']
['Teacher: What were the titles of the two books that Scott published in 1903?', 'In 1903, Scott published two books: The Theory of Advertising and Psychology of Advertising.']
["Teacher: How did Scott's books contribute to the development of industrial and organizational psychology?", 'They are the first books to describe the use of psychology in the business world.']

["Teacher: Can you explain how Scott's books on influencing men in business and increasing human efficiency contributed to the development of industrial and organizational psychology?", 'By 1911 he published two more books, Influencing Men in Business and Increasing Human Efficiency in Business.']

['Teacher: What role did the Carnegie Institute of Technology play in the development of industrial and organizational psychology?', 'In 1916 a newly formed division in the Carnegie Institute of Technology hired Scott to conduct applied research on employee selection (Katzell & Austin, 1992).']

['Teacher: How did the field of organizational psychology develop in the century following the research in industrial psychology?', 'The focus of all this research was in what we now know as industrial psychology; it was only later in the century that the field of organizational psychology developed as an experimental science (Katzell & Austin, 1992).']

['What other roles did the researchers in industrial psychology have besides their academic positions?', 'In addition to their academic positions, these researchers also worked directly for businesses as consultants.']

['Teacher: How did the involvement of the United States in World War I impact the work of psychologists in the field of industrial and organizational psychology?', 'When the United States entered World War I in April 1917, the work of psychologists working in this discipline expanded to include their contributions to military efforts.']

['Teacher: How did the contributions of psychologists in the field of industrial and organizational psychology change when the United States entered World War I?', 'At that time Yerkes was the president of the 25-year-old American Psychological Association (APA).']

['What role did Yerkes play as the president of the American Psychological Association during World War I?', 'The APA is a professional association in the United States for clinical and research psychologists.']

['What are some functions of the American Psychological Association (APA) today?', 'Today the APA performs a number of functions including holding conferences, accrediting university degree programs, and publishing scientific journals.']

["What specific work did Yerkes and his group under the Surgeon General's Office (SGO) focus on during World War I?", 'Yerkes organized a group under the Surgeon General’s Office (SGO) that developed methods for screening and selecting enlisted men.']

["What was one specific method developed by Yerkes and his group under the Surgeon General's Office during World War I to measure mental abilities of enlisted men?", 'They developed the Army Alpha test to measure mental abilities.']

['What was the purpose of administering the Army Beta test to illiterate and non-English-speaking draftees during World War I?', 'The Army Beta test was a non-verbal form of the test that was administered to illiterate and non-English-speaking draftees.']

["What was the goal of Scott and Bingham's group under the Adjutant General's Office (AGO) during World War I?", 'Scott and Bingham organized a group under the Adjutant General’s Office (AGO) with the goal to develop selection methods for officers.']

["What specific methods did Scott and Bingham's group under the Adjutant General's Office (AGO) develop during World War I to select officers?", 'They created a catalogue of occupational needs for the Army, essentially a job-description system and a system of performance ratings and occupational skill tests for officers (Katzell & Austin, 1992).']
['What happened to the work on personnel selection after the conclusion of World War I?', 'After the war, work on personnel selection continued.']

['What are some examples of research on personnel selection that took place after the conclusion of World War I?', 'For example, Millicent Pond researched the selection of factory workers, comparing the results of pre-employment tests with various indicators of job performance (Vinchur & Koppes, 2014).']

["Teacher: Who conducted a series of studies at Western Electric's Hawthorne Works from 1929 to 1932?", 'From 1929 to 1932 Elton Mayo (1880–1949) and his colleagues began a series of studies at a plant near Chicago, Western Electric’s Hawthorne Works (Figure 13.4).']

["Teacher: What were the main focuses of the series of studies conducted by Elton Mayo and his colleagues at Western Electric's Hawthorne Works from 1929 to 1932?", 'This long-term project took industrial psychology beyond just employee selection and placement to a study of more complex problems of interpersonal relations, motivation, and organizational dynamics.']

["Teacher: What specific subjects did Elton Mayo and his colleagues study in their series of studies at Western Electric's Hawthorne Works from 1929 to 1932?", 'These studies mark the origin of organizational psychology.']

["Teacher: What did Elton Mayo and his colleagues initially focus on in their studies at Western Electric's Hawthorne Works from 1929 to 1932?", 'They began as research into the effects of the physical work environment (e.g., level of lighting in a factory), but the researchers found that the psychological and social factors in the factory were of more interest than the physical factors.']

["Teacher: How did Elton Mayo and his colleagues expand the scope of industrial psychology in their studies at Western Electric's Hawthorne Works from 1929 to 1932?", 'These studies also examined how human interaction factors, such as supervisorial style, increased or decreased productivity.']

['Teacher: What term is used to describe the increase in performance of individuals who are aware they are being observed by researchers or supervisors?', 'Analysis of the findings by later researchers led to the term the Hawthorne effect, which describes the increase in performance of individuals who are aware they are being observed by researchers or supervisors (Figure 13.5).']

['Teacher: Can you explain the findings that led to the development of the term "the Hawthorne effect" in more detail?', 'What the original researchers found was that any change in a variable, such as lighting levels, led to an improvement in productivity; this was true even when the change was negative, such as a return to poor lighting.']

['Teacher: How did the researchers determine that the increase in performance was specifically due to the awareness of being observed?', 'The effect faded when the attention faded (Roethlisberg & Dickson, 1939).']

['What is the significance of the Hawthorne effect in the field of industrial and organizational psychology today?', 'The Hawthorne-effect concept endures today as an important experimental consideration in many fields and a factor that has to be controlled for in an experiment.']

['Teacher: How does the Hawthorne effect impact the validity and reliability of research findings in industrial and organizational psychology?', 'In other words, an experimental treatment of some kind may produce an effect simply because it involves greater attention of the researchers on the participants (McCarney et al., 2007).']
["Teacher: What did researchers begin to study about employees' jobs in the 1930s?", 'In the 1930s, researchers began to study employees’ feelings about their jobs.']

['Teacher: Can you give an example of a researcher who conducted studies on the effects of leadership styles, team structure, and team dynamics in the 1930s?', 'Kurt Lewin also conducted research on the effects of various leadership styles, team structure, and team dynamics (Katzell & Austin, 1992).']

["Teacher: How did Kurt Lewin's research in the 1930s contribute to the development of organizational psychology?", 'Lewin is considered the founder of social psychology and much of his work and that of his students produced results that had important influences in organizational psychology.']

['Teacher: What were some key topics that Kurt Lewin and his students studied in their research on organizational psychology in the 1930s?', 'Lewin and his students’ research included an important early study that used children to study the effect of leadership style on aggression, group dynamics, and satisfaction (Lewin, Lippitt, & White, 1939).']

['Teacher: How did Lewin contribute to the study of group dynamics in relation to organizational psychology?', 'Lewin was also responsible for coining the term group dynamics, and he was involved in studies of group interactions, cooperation, competition, and communication that bear on organizational psychology.']

['Teacher: What other field was developing parallel to the studies in industrial and organizational psychology?', 'Parallel to these studies in industrial and organizational psychology, the field of human factors psychology was also developing.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how industrial and organizational psychologists and human factors psychologists worked together to improve workplace productivity?', 'Frederick Taylor was an engineer who saw that if one could redesign the workplace there would be an increase in both output for the company and wages for the workers.']

['Teacher: What were the main principles of Frederick Taylor\'s theory of scientific management, as discussed in his book "The Principles of Scientific Management"?', 'In 1911 he put forward his theory in a book titled, The Principles of Scientific Management (Figure 13.6).']

['Teacher: What specific methods did Frederick Taylor propose for improving workplace efficiency and productivity in his book "The Principles of Scientific Management"?', 'His book examines management theories, personnel selection and training, as well as the work itself, using time and motion studies.']

['Teacher: How did Frederick Taylor propose to achieve maximum efficiency and productivity in the workplace according to his book "The Principles of Scientific Management"?', 'Taylor argued that the principle goal of management should be to make the most money for the employer, along with the best outcome for the employee.']

['Teacher: According to Frederick Taylor, what was the key to achieving the best outcome for both the employee and management in the workplace?', 'He believed that the best outcome for the employee and management would be achieved through training and development so that each employee could provide the best work.']

['Teacher: How did Frederick Taylor propose to address the best interests of both the organization and the employee in the workplace?', 'He believed that by conducting time and motion studies for both the organization and the employee, the best interests of both were addressed.']

["Teacher: What was the purpose of conducting time and motion studies in Frederick Taylor's approach to improving workplace efficiency?", 'Time-motion studies were methods aimed to improve work by dividing different types of operations into sections that could be measured.']

["What were the benefits of standardizing work and checking the efficiency of people and equipment through time-motion studies in Frederick Taylor's approach to improving workplace efficiency?", 'These analyses were used to standardize work and to check the efficiency of people and equipment.']

['Teacher: What is the purpose of personnel selection in the context of industrial and organizational psychology?', 'Personnel selection is a process used by recruiting personnel within the company to recruit and select the best candidates for the job.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the relationship between personnel selection and training in the context of industrial and organizational psychology?', 'Training may need to be conducted depending on what skills the hired candidate has.']

['Teacher: How does the concept of "person-organization fit" relate to the hiring decisions made in personnel selection?', 'Often companies will hire someone with the personality that fits in with others but who may be lacking in skills.']

['Teacher: How does the historical development of industrial and organizational psychology contribute to our understanding of personnel selection and training practices?', 'Skills can be taught, but personality cannot be easily changed.']
["Teacher: Can you provide an example of how Taylor's theory was applied in the industrial setting?", 'One of the examples of Taylor’s theory in action involved workers handling heavy iron ingots.']
["Teacher: How did Taylor's theory suggest that workers could be more productive in the industrial setting?", 'Taylor showed that the workers could be more productive by taking work rests.']

["Teacher: How did the implementation of rest breaks according to Taylor's theory impact worker productivity and well-being in the industrial setting?", 'This method of rest increased worker productivity from 12.5 to 47.0 tons moved per day with less reported fatigue as well as increased wages for the workers who were paid by the ton.']

["Teacher: How did the implementation of rest breaks according to Taylor's theory impact both worker productivity and the company's costs in the industrial setting?", 'At the same time, the company’s cost was reduced from 9.2 cents to 3.9 cents per ton.']

["Teacher: Why did Taylor's theory receive criticism at the time despite the increases in worker productivity and cost reduction?", 'Despite these increases in productivity, Taylor’s theory received a great deal of criticism at the time because it was believed that it would exploit workers and reduce the number of workers needed.']

["Teacher: Why did Taylor's theory face criticism for its belief that only managers could determine the most efficient method of working?", 'Also controversial was the underlying concept that only a manager could determine the most efficient method of working, and that while at work, a worker was incapable of this.']

["What was one of the criticisms of Taylor's theory regarding worker well-being?", 'Taylor’s theory was underpinned by the notion that a worker was fundamentally lazy and the goal of Taylor’s scientific management approach was to maximize productivity without much concern for worker well-being.']

["What were some of the criticisms of Taylor's theory regarding worker rights and the impact on worker-management relations?", 'His approach was criticized by unions and those sympathetic to workers (Van De Water, 1997).']
['Teacher: Who was another influential I-O psychologist?', 'Gilbreth was another influential I-O psychologist who strove to find ways to increase productivity (Figure 13.7).']

['Teacher: What method did Gilbreth and her husband employ to make workers more efficient and increase productivity?', 'Using time and motion studies, Gilbreth and her husband, Frank, worked to make workers more efficient by reducing the number of motions required to perform a task.']
['Teacher: How did Gilbreth apply her methods to areas beyond industry?', 'She not only applied these methods to industry but also to the home, office, shops, and other areas.']

['Teacher: What were some of the areas where Gilbreth applied her methods besides industry?', 'She investigated employee fatigue and time management stress and found many employees were motivated by money and job satisfaction.']

['Teacher: What significant contribution did Gilbreth make to the field of psychology?', 'In 1914, Gilbreth wrote the book title, The Psychology of Management: The Function of the Mind in Determining, Teaching, and Installing Methods of Least Waste, and she is known as the mother of modern management.']

['What are some examples of practical inventions and ideas that Gilbreth contributed to?', 'Some of Gilbreth’s contributions are still in use today: you can thank her for the idea to put shelves inside on refrigerator doors, and she also came up with the concept of using a foot pedal to operate the lid of trash can (Gilbreth, 1914, 1998; Koppes, 1997; Lancaster, 2004).']

['What are some notable achievements and recognitions that Gilbreth received throughout her career?', 'Gilbreth was the first woman to join the American Society of Mechanical Engineers in 1926, and in 1966 she was awarded the Hoover Medal of the American Society of Civil Engineers.']

["Teacher: How did Taylor and Gilbreth's work not only improve productivity but also enhance the relationship between technology and the individuals operating it?", 'Taylor and Gilbreth’s work improved productivity, but these innovations also improved the fit between technology and the human using it.']
["What is the term used to describe the study of machine-human fit, as mentioned in the student's response?", 'The study of machine–human fit is known as ergonomics or human factors psychology.']
['Teacher: How did World War II impact the field of industrial psychology?', 'World War II also drove the expansion of industrial psychology.']

['Teacher: How did Bingham contribute to the field of industrial psychology during World War II?', 'Bingham was hired as the chief psychologist for the War Department (now the Department of Defense) and developed new systems for job selection, classification, training, ad performance review, plus methods for team development, morale change, and attitude change  (Katzell & Austin, 1992).']

['Teacher: What were some of the significant contributions made by Bingham in the field of industrial psychology during World War II?', 'Other countries, such as Canada and the United Kingdom, likewise saw growth in I-O psychology during World War II (McMillan, Stevens, & Kelloway, 2009).']

['Teacher: How did the field of industrial psychology evolve after World War II in terms of research focus?', 'In the years after the war, both industrial psychology and organizational psychology became areas of significant research effort.']

['What were some of the concerns that arose in the field of industrial psychology after World War II?', 'Concerns about the fairness of employment tests arose, and the ethnic and gender biases in various tests were evaluated with mixed results.']

['What were some of the areas of research that received significant attention in the field of industrial psychology after World War II?', 'In addition, a great deal of research went into studying job satisfaction and employee motivation (Katzell & Austin, 1992).']

['Teacher: In what decade did the research and work of I-O psychologists in the areas of employee selection, placement, and performance appraisal become increasingly important?', 'The research and work of I-O psychologists in the areas of employee selection, placement, and performance appraisal became increasingly important in the 1960s.']

['Teacher: What event in the 1960s led to the increased importance of research and work of I-O psychologists in employee selection, placement, and performance appraisal?', 'When Congress passed the 1964 Civil Rights Act, Title VII covered what is known as equal employment opportunity.']

['What impact did the 1964 Civil Rights Act have on the research and work of I-O psychologists in employee selection, placement, and performance appraisal?', 'This law protects employees against discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex, or national origin, as well as discrimination against an employee for associating with an individual in one of these categories.']

['Teacher: Why is it important for organizations to be interested in industrial and organizational psychology (I/O)?', 'There are many reasons for organizations to be interested in I/O so that they can better understand the psychology of their workers, which in turn helps them understand how their organizations can become more productive and competitive.']

['Teacher: Can you provide more examples of how understanding the psychology of workers can help organizations become more productive and competitive in a global market?', 'For example, most large organizations are now competing on a global level, and they need to understand how to motivate workers in order to achieve high productivity and efficiency.']

["Teacher: How can understanding the psychological complexity of a diverse workforce help organizations thrive in today's global market?", 'Most companies also have a diverse workforce and need to understand the psychological complexity of the people in these diverse backgrounds.']

['Teacher: How did organizations have to adjust to the social, political, and legal climate of the Civil Rights movement?', 'Today, I-O psychology is a diverse and deep field of research and practice, as you will learn about in the rest of this chapter.']

['What are some examples of the growth and significance of the field of I/O psychology?', 'The Society for Industrial and Organizational Psychology (SIOP), a division of the APA, lists 8,000 members (SIOP, 2014) and the Bureau of Labor Statistics—U.S. Department of Labor (2013) has projected this profession will have the greatest growth of all job classifications in the 20 years following 2012.']

['What is the projected growth of the I/O psychology profession according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics?', 'On average, a person with a master’s degree in industrial-organizational psychology will earn over $80,000 a year, while someone with a doctorate will earn over $110,000 a year (Khanna, Medsker, & Ginter, 2012).']

['Teacher: What specific aspect does industrial psychology focus on within an organization?', 'The branch of I-O psychology known as industrial psychology focuses on identifying and matching persons to tasks within an organization.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why accurately describing the task or job is important in the process of identifying and matching persons to tasks within an organization?', 'This involves job analysis, which means accurately describing the task or job.']

['Teacher: Why is it important for organizations to identify the characteristics of applicants in relation to the job analysis?', 'Then, organizations must identify the characteristics of applicants for a match to the job analysis.']

['Teacher: How does industrial psychology contribute to the process of training and appraising employees within an organization?', 'It also involves training employees from their first day on the job throughout their tenure within the organization, and appraising their performance along the way.']
['Teacher: How is the process of selecting employees typically carried out?', 'Often, this is done with the help of I-O psychologists.']

['Teacher: Can you elaborate on the two related but different approaches to job analysis that are commonly used in selecting employees?', 'There are two related but different approaches to job analysis—you may be familiar with the results of each as they often appear on the same job advertisement.']

["Teacher: That's correct! Now, can you explain the second approach to job analysis commonly used in selecting employees?", 'The first approach is task-oriented and lists in detail the tasks that will be performed for the job.']

['Teacher: Very well explained! Now, could you tell me about the main focus of the second approach to job analysis commonly used in selecting employees?', 'Each task is typically rated on scales for how frequently it is performed, how difficult it is, and how important it is to the job.']
['Teacher: Excellent! Now, can you discuss the key aspect that the worker-oriented approach focuses on in job analysis for selecting employees?', 'The second approach is worker-oriented.']
['What does the worker-oriented approach focus on in job analysis for selecting employees?', 'This approach describes the characteristics required of the worker to successfully perform the job.']
['What does the worker-oriented approach in job analysis for selecting employees specifically describe?', 'This second approach has been called job specification (Dierdorff & Wilson, 2003).']

['What are the elements that are identified in job specification for the worker-oriented approach in job analysis for selecting employees?', 'For job specification, the knowledge, skills, and abilities (KSAs) that the job requires are identified.']

['Teacher: How are observations, surveys, and interviews utilized in obtaining the information needed for job analysis?', 'Observation, surveys, and interviews are used to obtain the information required for both types of job analysis.']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how observations are used in job analysis?', 'It is possible to observe someone who is proficient in a position and analyze what skills are apparent.']

['Teacher: How are surveys utilized in obtaining the information needed for job analysis?', 'Another approach used is to interview people presently holding that position, their peers, and their supervisors to get a consensus of what they believe are the requirements of the job.']

['Teacher: What does research suggest regarding the factors that impact the selection of employees?', 'Research suggests that it can depend on the nature of the descriptions and the source for the job analysis.']

['Teacher: Why did Dierdorff & Wilson (2003) find that job analyses developed from descriptions provided by people holding the job themselves were the least reliable?', 'For example, Dierdorff & Wilson (2003) found that job analyses developed from descriptions provided by people holding the job themselves were the least reliable; however, they did not study or speculate why this was the case.']

['Teacher: What resource does the United States Department of Labor maintain to assist employers in selecting employees?', 'The United States Department of Labor maintains a database of previously compiled job analyses for different jobs and occupations.']

["What is the purpose of the United States Department of Labor's database of previously compiled job analyses?", 'This allows the I-O psychologist to access previous analyses for nearly any type of occupation.']

["Teacher: How can I-O psychologists access the United States Department of Labor's database of previously compiled job analyses for different occupations?", 'This system is called O*Net (accessible at www.onetonline.org).']

['How can individuals access the website O*Net to view the KSAs listed for their own position or a position they are curious about?', 'The site is open and you can see the KSAs that are listed for your own position or one you might be curious about  (Figure 13.8).']

['What information can individuals find on the O*Net website about different occupations?', 'Each occupation lists the tasks, knowledge, skills, abilities, work context, work activities, education requirements, interests, personality requirements, and work styles that are deemed necessary for success in that position.']

['What other types of information can individuals find on the O*Net website besides the KSAs and requirements for different occupations?', 'You can also see data on average earnings and projected job growth in that industry.']

["Teacher: Why is it important for a company to evaluate and compare candidates' knowledge, skills, and other abilities with the job description?", 'Once a company identifies potential candidates for a position, the candidates’ knowledge, skills, and other abilities must be evaluated and compared with the job description.']

["Teacher: What are some methods that can be used to evaluate and compare candidates' knowledge, skills, and other abilities with the job description?", 'These evaluations can involve testing, an interview, and work samples or exercises.']

['Teacher: How can personality tests be used in candidate analysis and testing?', 'You learned about personality tests in the chapter on personality; in the I-O context, they are used to identify the personality characteristics of the candidate in an effort to match those to personality characteristics that would ensure good performance on the job.']

['Teacher: How can knowledge, skills, and abilities assessments be utilized in candidate analysis and testing?', 'For example, a high rating of agreeableness might be desirable in a customer support position.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how knowledge, skills, and abilities assessments can be utilized in candidate analysis and testing?', 'However, it is not always clear how best to correlate personality characteristics with predictions of job performance.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why it might be challenging to correlate personality characteristics with job performance when using knowledge, skills, and abilities assessments in candidate analysis and testing?', 'It might be that too high of a score on agreeableness is actually a hindrance in the customer support position.']

["Why might agreeing with a customer's misperception be a hindrance in a customer support position?", 'For example, if a customer has a misperception about a product or service, agreeing with their misperception will not ultimately lead to resolution of their complaint.']

['What is the importance of having a verified assessment of what scores on a personality test correlate with good performance in candidate analysis and testing?', 'Any use of personality tests should be accompanied by a verified assessment of what scores on the test correlate with good performance (Arthur, Woehr, & Graziano, 2001).']

['What are some other types of tests that may be given to candidates in candidate analysis and testing?', 'Other types of tests that may be given to candidates include IQ tests, integrity tests, and physical tests, such as drug tests or physical fitness tests.']

['Teacher: Sure! Could you please explain what you understand by the term "Candidate Analysis and Testing" in the context of the hiring process?', 'To better understand the hiring process, let’s consider an example case.']
['Teacher: What was the purpose of the company advertising the open position?', 'A company determined it had an open position and advertised it.']

['Teacher: Who is responsible for directing the recruitment process after the company determines it has an open position and advertises it?', 'The human resources (HR) manager directed the hiring team to start the recruitment process.']

['Teacher: What happens to the résumés submitted by candidates, like Imani, after they are collected?', 'Imani saw the advertisement and submitted her résumé, which went into the collection of candidate résumés.']

['Teacher: What is the next step in the hiring process after the HR team provides a list of potential candidates to the department manager?', 'The HR team reviewed the candidates’ credentials and provided a list of the best potential candidates to the department manager, who reached out to them (including Imani) to set up individual interviews.']

['Teacher: What is a common requirement for most jobs in mid-size to large-size businesses in the United States?', 'Most jobs for mid-size to large-size businesses in the United States require a personal interview as a step in the selection process.']

['Why have interviews been the subject of considerable research by industrial psychologists?', 'Because interviews are commonly used, they have been the subject of considerable research by industrial psychologists.']
['What is the typical basis for the types of questions asked during job interviews?', 'Information derived from job analysis usually forms the basis for the types of questions asked.']

['What advantage do interviews have over standard testing measures in terms of gathering information about a candidate?', 'Interviews can provide a more dynamic source of information about the candidate than standard testing measures.']
['What are some factors that can influence the outcome of an interview?', 'Importantly, social factors and body language can influence the outcome of the interview.']

['What are some examples of nonverbal behaviors that can influence the outcome of an interview?', 'These include influences, such as the degree of similarity of the applicant to the interviewer and nonverbal behaviors, such as hand gestures, head nodding, and smiling (Bye, Horverak, Sandal, Sam, & Vivjer, 2014; Rakić, Steffens, & Mummendey, 2011).']
['Teacher: What are the two types of interviews mentioned in the passage?', 'There are two types of interviews: unstructured and structured.']
['What is the main characteristic of an unstructured interview mentioned in the passage?', 'In an unstructured interview, the interviewer may ask different questions of each different candidate.']

['What is the main characteristic of a structured interview mentioned in the passage?', 'One candidate might be asked about her career goals, and another might be asked about his previous work experience.']

['What is the difference between structured and unstructured interviews in terms of question preparation?', 'In an unstructured interview, the questions are often, though not always, unspecified beforehand.']

['Which type of interview does not score the responses to questions using a standard system?', 'And in an unstructured interview the responses to questions asked are generally not scored using a standard system.']

['What is the main characteristic of a structured interview in terms of question consistency and scoring?', 'In a structured interview, the interviewer asks the same questions of every candidate, the questions are prepared in advance, and the interviewer uses a standardized rating system for each response.']
['What is one advantage of using a structured interview approach?', 'With this approach, the interviewer can accurately compare two candidates’ interviews.']

['What did McDaniel, Whetzel, Schmidt & Maurer (1994) find regarding the effectiveness of structured interviews in predicting subsequent job performance of the job candidate?', 'In a meta-analysis of studies examining the effectiveness of various types of job interviews, McDaniel, Whetzel, Schmidt & Maurer (1994) found that structured interviews were more effective at predicting subsequent job performance of the job candidate.']
['Teacher: What made you suggest revisiting the example case?', 'Let’s return to our example case.']
["Teacher: How did Imani's first interview differ from the subsequent ones?", 'For her first interview, Imani was interviewed by a team of employees at the company.']
['Teacher: How did Imani feel about being one of the five candidates interviewed for the position?', 'She was one of five candidates interviewed that day for the position.']

['What was the purpose of asking each interviewee the same list of questions?', 'Each interviewee was asked the same list of questions, by the same people, so the interview experience was as consistent as possible across applicants.']
['What did the HR team do after the interviews?', 'At the end of the interviews, the HR team met and reviewed the answers given by Imani and the other candidates.']

["What was the HR team's next step after conducting the new round of initial interviews?", 'The HR team then identified a few new qualified candidates and conducted a new round of initial interviews, while the first group of potential hires waited to hear back from the company.']
['Teacher: Why is training considered an important element in achieving success and performance in various jobs?', 'Training is an important element of success and performance in many jobs.']

['Teacher: Can you explain how an orientation period during training helps new employees in understanding company history and policies?', 'Most jobs begin with an orientation period during which the new employee is provided information regarding the company history, policies, and administrative protocols such as time tracking, benefits, and reporting requirements.']

['Teacher: How does orientation training contribute to educating new employees about the organizational culture, values, hierarchies, and norms of a company?', 'An important goal of orientation training is to educate the new employee about the organizational culture, the values, visions, hierarchies, norms and ways the company’s employees interact—essentially how the organization is run, how it operates, and how it makes decisions.']

['Teacher: What are some examples of job-specific training that employees may receive during their period of employment?', 'There will also be training that is specific to the job the individual was hired to do, or training during the individual’s period of employment that teaches aspects of new duties, or how to use new physical or software tools.']

["Teacher: How are new employees typically introduced to the company's history, policies, and administrative protocols during the orientation period?", 'Much of these kinds of training will be formalized for the employee; for example, orientation training is often accomplished using software presentations, group presentations by members of the human resources department or with people in the new hire’s department (Figure 13.9).']
['Teacher: What is mentoring and how does it relate to training?', 'Mentoring is a form of informal training in which an experienced employee guides the work of a new employee.']

['What are the two ways in which a mentoring relationship can be established between an experienced employee and a new employee in a training program?', 'In some situations, mentors will be formally assigned to a new employee, while in others a mentoring relationship may develop informally.']
['Teacher: What aspect of mentoring have researchers focused on in recent years?', 'Mentoring effects on the mentor and the employee being mentored, the protégé, have been studied in recent years.']

['What specific effects of mentoring did Eby, Allen, Evans, Ng, & DuBois (2008) find in their review of mentoring studies?', 'In a review of mentoring studies, Eby, Allen, Evans, Ng, & DuBois (2008) found significant but small effects of mentoring on performance (i.e., behavioral outcomes), motivation and satisfaction, and actual career outcomes.']

['What were some of the specific career outcomes that were positively affected by mentoring, according to the review conducted by Allen, Eby, Poteet, Lentz, & Lima (2004)?', 'In a more detailed review, Allen, Eby, Poteet, Lentz, & Lima (2004) found that mentoring positively affected a protégé’s compensation and number of promotions compared with non-mentored employees.']

['What were some of the specific outcomes related to job satisfaction that were positively affected by mentoring, according to the review conducted by Allen, Eby, Poteet, Lentz, & Lima (2004)?', 'In addition, protégés were more satisfied with their careers and had greater job satisfaction.']

['What were some of the specific outcomes related to performance and motivation that were positively affected by mentoring, according to the review conducted by Eby, Allen, Evans, Ng, & DuBois (2008)?', 'All of the effects were small but significant.']

["What were some of the specific outcomes related to the mentor's job satisfaction and organizational commitment that were found in the study conducted by Eby, Durley, Evans, & Ragins (2006)?", 'Eby, Durley, Evans, & Ragins (2006) examined mentoring effects on the mentor and found that mentoring was associated with greater job satisfaction and organizational commitment.']

['What specific outcome related to performance ratings by supervisors was found in the study conducted by Gentry, Weber, & Sadri (2008)?', 'Gentry, Weber, & Sadri (2008) found that mentoring was positively related with performance ratings by supervisors.']

['What were some of the specific outcomes related to salaries and promotions that were found in the study conducted by Allen, Lentz, and Day (2006)?', 'Allen, Lentz, & Day (2006) found in a comparison of mentors and non-mentors that mentoring led to greater reported salaries and promotions.']

['Teacher: Can you tell me what researchers have focused on in understanding the impacts of gender, race, and ethnicity on mentoring relationships?', 'Researchers have worked to understand the impacts of gender, race, and ethnicity on mentoring relationships,  especially whether outcomes differ based on the gender or racial/ethnic makeup of the mentor-mentee pair.']

['Teacher: What are some factors that contribute to women and members of underrepresented racial/ethnic populations lacking access to mentors of the same gender, race, and ethnicity?', 'Overall, women and members of underrepresented racial/ethnic populations do not lack access to mentors, but they do lack access to mentors of the same gender, race, and ethnicity, because the senior roles in many organizations are made up of White men (MLDC, 2010).']

['Teacher: What are some potential benefits of mentor-mentee pairings with individuals of the same gender or race/ethnicity, according to the research?', 'Results from these studies are mixed, but generally suggest that pairings made up of two people of the same gender or race/ethnicity have better psychosocial outcomes, such as a feeling of more support (Koberg, Boss, & Goodman, 1998; Allen et al, 2006).']

['Teacher: Can you provide examples of some potential career advancement outcomes for women and individuals from underrepresented racial/ethnic backgrounds when they are mentored by someone of a different gender or race/ethnicity?', 'On the other hand, women and people of color typically experience greater career advancement or higher pay when mentored by people of a different gender or race/ethnicity (Parks-Yancy, 2012).']

['Teacher: According to the passage, what are some benefits of mentoring for the career success of women?', 'A 2003 study by Arthur, Bennett, Edens, and Bell examined multiple other studies to determine how effective organizational training is.']

['Teacher: What did the 2003 study by Arthur, Bennett, Edens, and Bell reveal about the effectiveness of organizational training?', 'Their results showed that training was effective, based on four types of measurement: (1) the immediate response of the employee to the training effort, (2) testing at the end of training to demonstrate that learning outcomes were met, (3) behavioral measurements of job activities by supervisors, and (4) results such as productivity and profits.']

['Teacher: How did the 2003 study by Arthur, Bennett, Edens, and Bell analyze the effectiveness of various forms of organizational training?', 'The examined studies represented diverse forms of training including self-instruction, lecture and discussion, and computer assisted training.']

['Teacher: What role do industrial and organizational psychologists play in organizations?', 'Industrial and organizational psychologists are typically involved in designing performance-appraisal systems for organizations.']
['Teacher: How do performance-appraisal systems help organizations in evaluating employee performance?', 'These systems are designed to evaluate whether each employee is performing satisfactorily.']

['What are some ways that industrial and organizational psychologists work to make work evaluations fair and positive?', 'Industrial and organizational psychologists study, research, and implement ways to make work evaluations as fair and positive as possible; they also work to decrease the subjectivity involved with performance ratings.']

['Teacher: Why is it important for organizations to decrease subjectivity in performance ratings?', 'Fairly evaluated work helps employees do their jobs better, improves the likelihood of people being in the right jobs for their talents, maintains fairness, and identifies company and individual training needs.']
['What is the purpose of the 90-day probation period for Imani in the example case?', 'In our example case, Imani was offered the position and was hired with a 90-day probation period.']

['What are some possible outcomes of the performance discussions between Imani and her supervisor during the 90-day probation period?', 'During that time, she met with her supervisor to discuss her performance and the expectations of the position and her growth.']

["What can be inferred about Imani's performance based on the outcome of the 90-day probation period?", 'At the end of the 90 days, it was determined that Imani was meeting the expectations of her employer and had passed her probationary period.']
['What is the significance of Imani passing her probationary period and obtaining a permanent job?', 'Imani was excited to now have a permanent job.']

['Teacher: Why are performance appraisals documented several times a year?', 'Performance appraisals are typically documented several times a year, often with a formal process and an annual face-to-face brief meeting between an employee and their supervisor.']

['Teacher: What factors should be considered in the performance appraisal process to ensure its effectiveness and accuracy?', 'It is important that the original job analysis play a role in performance appraisal as well as any goals that have been set by the employee or by the employee and supervisor.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the purpose of the annual face-to-face meeting between an employee and their supervisor during the performance appraisal process?', 'The meeting is often used for the supervisor to communicate specific concerns about the employee’s performance and to positively reinforce elements of good performance.']

['Teacher: What are some specific concerns that a supervisor may discuss with an employee during the annual face-to-face meeting in the performance appraisal process?', 'It may also be used to discuss specific performance rewards, such as a pay increase, or consequences of poor performance, such as a probationary period.']

['Teacher: Why is it important for organizations to document poor performance during performance appraisals?', 'Part of the function of performance appraisals for the organization is to document poor performance to bolster decisions to terminate an employee.']

['Teacher: What are the two purposes of performance appraisals within organizations?', 'Performance appraisals are becoming more complex processes within organizations and are often used to motivate employees to improve performance and expand their areas of competence, in addition to assessing their job performance.']

['What are the two purposes of performance appraisals within organizations, one being to motivate employees and improve their performance, but what is the other purpose?', 'In this capacity, performance appraisals can be used to identify opportunities for training or whether a particular training program has been successful.']
['What is one specific approach to performance appraisals that is mentioned in the passage?', 'One approach to performance appraisal is called 360-degree feedback appraisal (Figure 13.10).']

['What is one advantage of using the 360-degree feedback appraisal system mentioned in the passage?', 'In this system, the employee’s appraisal derives from a combination of ratings by supervisors, peers, employees supervised by the employee, and from the employee herself.']
['What is one advantage of incorporating ratings from multiple sources in the 360-degree feedback appraisal system?', 'Occasionally, outside observers may be used as well, such as customers.']

['What is one other group of people whose ratings may be incorporated in the 360-degree feedback appraisal system, as mentioned in the passage?', 'The purpose of 360-degree system is to give the employee (who may be a manager) and supervisor different perspectives of the employee’s job performance; the system should help employees make improvements through their own efforts or through training.']

['What is one additional benefit of using the 360-degree feedback appraisal system in a traditional performance-appraisal context?', 'The system is also used in a traditional performance-appraisal context, providing the supervisor with more information with which to make decisions about the employee’s position and compensation (Tornow, 1993a).']

["Teacher: According to Atkins and Wood (2002), what did they discover about the reliability of self and peer ratings in assessing an employee's performance?", 'Few studies have assessed the effectiveness of 360-degree methods, but Atkins and Wood (2002) found that the self and peer ratings were unreliable as an assessment of an employee’s performance and that even supervisors tended to underrate employees that gave themselves modest feedback ratings.']

['What is another perspective on the variability in ratings discussed by Tornow (1993b)?', 'However, a different perspective sees this variability in ratings as a positive in that it provides for greater learning on the part of the employees as they and their supervisor discuss the reasons for the discrepancies (Tornow, 1993b).']

['Teacher: Why do most employees seek feedback regarding their jobs if it is not offered?', 'In theory, performance appraisals should be an asset for an organization wishing to achieve its goals, and most employees will actually solicit feedback regarding their jobs if it is not offered (DeNisi & Kluger, 2000).']

['Why are performance appraisals often disliked by organizations and employees, and why is there a lack of research on their effectiveness in improving performance and motivating employees?', 'However, in practice, many performance evaluations are disliked by organizations, employees, or both (Fletcher, 2001), and few of them have been adequately tested to see if they do in fact improve performance or motivate employees (DeNisi & Kluger, 2000).']

['Teacher: What are some factors that contribute to performance evaluations failing to accomplish their purpose in an organization?', 'One of the reasons evaluations fail to accomplish their purpose in an organization is that performance appraisal systems are often used incorrectly or are of an inappropriate type for an organization’s particular culture (Schraeder, Becton, & Portis, 2007).']

["What are some potential consequences of using an inappropriate type of performance appraisal system for an organization's culture?", 'An organization’s culture is how the organization is run, how it operates, and how it makes decisions.']

["What are some potential consequences of using an inappropriate type of performance appraisal system for an organization's culture?", 'It is based on the collective values, hierarchies, and how individuals within the organization interact.']

['What are some potential consequences of using an inappropriate type of performance appraisal system on the effectiveness of training for its implementation?', 'Examining the effectiveness of performance appraisal systems in particular organizations and the effectiveness of training for the implementation of the performance appraisal system is an active area of research in industrial psychology (Fletcher, 2001).']

['knowledge, skills, and abilities before making a hiring decision. However, biases can often creep into the hiring process, leading to unfair and discriminatory outcomes. To address this issue, there are several protections in place to promote fairness and prevent bias in hiring. These protections include implementing standardized and objective selection criteria, conducting blind evaluations, promoting diversity and inclusion, providing training on unconscious bias, and enforcing laws and regulations against discrimination.', 'In an ideal hiring process, an organization would generate a job analysis that accurately reflects the requirements of the position, and it would accurately assess candidates’']
['Teacher: What are some protections that are in place to promote fairness and prevent bias in hiring?', 'KSAs to determine who the best individual is to carry out the job’s requirements.']

['Teacher: What are some examples of factors that can influence hiring decisions, other than matching a job analysis to KSAs?', 'For many reasons, hiring decisions in the real world are often made based on factors other than matching a job analysis to KSAs.']

['Teacher: Can you provide some specific examples of how interview rankings can be influenced by factors other than matching a job analysis to KSAs?', 'As mentioned earlier, interview rankings can be influenced by other factors: similarity to the interviewer (Bye, Horverak, Sandal, Sam, & Vijver, 2014) and the regional accent of the interviewee (Rakić, Steffens, & Mummendey 2011).']

['Teacher: What did the study by Agerström & Rooth (2011) focus on in relation to hiring decisions?', 'A study by Agerström & Rooth (2011) examined hiring managers’ decisions to invite equally qualified non-obese and obese job applicants to an interview.']

['Teacher: What were the results or findings of the study conducted by Agerström & Rooth (2011) regarding the hiring decisions of non-obese and obese job applicants?', 'The decisions of the hiring managers were based on photographs of the two applicants.']

['Teacher: What was the determining factor that influenced the hiring decisions of managers in the study conducted by Agerström & Rooth (2011) regarding non-obese and obese job applicants?', 'The study found that hiring managers that scored high on a test of negative associations with overweight people displayed a bias in favor of inviting the equally qualified non-obese applicant but not inviting the obese applicant.']

['Teacher: How did the study conducted by Agerström & Rooth (2011) measure the bias displayed by hiring managers towards non-obese and obese job applicants?', 'The association test measures automatic or subconscious associations between an individual’s negative or positive values and, in this case, the body-size attribute.']

['Teacher: What did the meta-analysis of experimental studies conducted by Hosoda, Stone-Romero, & Coats (2003) focus on in relation to job-related outcomes?', 'A meta-analysis of experimental studies found that physical attractiveness benefited individuals in various job-related outcomes such as hiring, promotion, and performance review (Hosoda, Stone-Romero, & Coats, 2003).']

['Teacher: Can you provide some specific job-related outcomes in which physical attractiveness has been found to benefit individuals, according to the meta-analysis conducted by Hosoda, Stone-Romero, & Coats (2003)?', 'They also found that the strength of the benefit appeared to be decreasing with time between the late 1970s and the late 1990s.']

['Teacher: What do you mean by "hiring criteria may be related to a particular group an applicant belongs to"?', 'Some hiring criteria may be related to a particular group an applicant belongs to and not individual abilities.']

['Teacher: What does the figure 13.11 suggest about decisions based on group membership in hiring?', 'Unless membership in that group directly affects potential job performance, a decision based on group membership is discriminatory (Figure 13.11).']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a city, state, or federal law in the United States that helps prevent hiring discrimination based on group-membership criteria?', 'To combat hiring discrimination, in the United States there are numerous city, state, and federal laws that prevent hiring based on various group-membership criteria.']

['Teacher: What specific types of attributes should employers avoid asking about during the hiring process to prevent discrimination based on group-membership criteria?', 'They cannot even ask questions that might shed some light on these attributes, such as where you were born or who you live with.']

['Teacher: What are some examples of group-membership criteria that employers should avoid asking about during the hiring process?', 'These are only a few of the restrictions that are in place to prevent discrimination in hiring.']

['What is the role of the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) in preventing discrimination in hiring based on group-membership criteria?', 'In the United States, federal anti-discrimination laws are administered by the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC).']

['Teacher: What federal laws does the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) enforce to protect job applicants and employees from discrimination based on various factors?', "The U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) is responsible for enforcing federal laws that make it illegal to discriminate against a job applicant or an employee because of the person's race, color, religion, sex (including pregnancy), sexual orientation, national origin, age (40 or older), disability, or genetic information."]

['What are some of the factors that the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) protects job applicants and employees from discrimination based on?', 'Figure 13.12 provides some of the legal language from laws that have been passed to prevent discrimination.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of an organization responsible for enforcing these laws to ensure equal employment opportunities are upheld?', 'The United States has several specific laws regarding fairness and avoidance of discrimination.']

["Teacher: That's correct! Can you give me another example of a law enforced by the organization we are discussing?", 'The Equal Pay Act requires that equal pay for men and women in the same workplace who are performing equal work.']
['Teacher: Why is it important for the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission to enforce the Equal Pay Act?', 'Despite the law, persistent inequities in earnings between men and women exist.']

["Teacher: Great! Can you summarize the findings of Corbett & Hill's study regarding earnings in the first year after college for men and women in the United States?", 'Corbett & Hill (2012) studied one facet of the gender gap by looking at earnings in the first year after college in the United States.']

["Teacher: According to Corbett & Hill's study, what is the wage gap between men and women in the first year after college in the United States?", 'Just comparing the earnings of women to men, women earn about 82 cents for every dollar a man earns in their first year out of college.']

["Teacher: What are some factors that can explain the wage gap between men and women in their first year after college, according to Corbett & Hill's study?", 'However, some of this difference can be explained by education, career, and life choices, such as choosing majors with lower earning potential or specific jobs within a field that have less responsibility.']

["What is the findings of Corbett & Hill's study regarding the wage gap between men and women in the first year after college in the United States, when factors such as education, career, and life choices are taken into account?", 'When these factors were corrected the study found an unexplained seven-cents-on-the-dollar gap in the first year after college that can be attributed to gender discrimination in pay.']

['Why has the human capital model, which accounts for education, career, and life choices, been criticized in relation to the gender pay gap?', 'This approach to analysis of the gender pay gap, called the human capital model, has been criticized.']

['Why has the human capital model been criticized in relation to the gender pay gap, according to Lips (2013)?', 'Lips (2013) argues that the education, career, and life choices can, in fact, be constrained by necessities imposed by gender discrimination.']

['What is the implication of Lips (2013) argument regarding the human capital model and the gender pay gap?', 'This suggests that removing these factors entirely from the gender gap equation leads to an estimate of the size of the pay gap that is too small.']

['Teacher: What is the name of the act that makes it illegal to treat individuals unfavorably because of their race or color of their skin?', 'Act of 1964 makes it illegal to treat individuals unfavorably because of their race or color of their skin:']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of an immutable characteristic that an employer cannot discriminate based on, according to the Act of 1964?', 'An employer cannot discriminate based on skin color, hair texture, or other immutable characteristics, which are traits of an individual that are fundamental to their identity, in hiring, benefits, promotions, or termination of employees.']
['Teacher: Can you explain how the Pregnancy Discrimination Act protects pregnant employees from being discriminated against in the workplace?', 'The Pregnancy Discrimination']

['Teacher: How does the Pregnancy Discrimination Act protect pregnant employees from being discriminated against in the workplace?', 'Act of 1978 amends the Civil Rights Act; it prohibits job (e.g., employment, pay, and termination) discrimination of a woman because she is pregnant as long as she can perform the work required.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the significance of the Supreme Court ruling in Griggs v. Duke Power Co. for the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC)?', 'The Supreme Court ruling in Griggs v. Duke Power Co. made it illegal under Title VII of the Civil Rights']

['What impact did the Supreme Court ruling in Griggs v. Duke Power Co. have on the inclusion of educational requirements in job descriptions under the Title VII of the Civil Rights Act?', 'Act to include educational requirements in a job description (e.g., high school diploma) that negatively impacts one race over another if the requirement cannot be shown to be directly related to job performance.']

['How did the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) respond to the Supreme Court ruling in Griggs v. Duke Power Co. regarding employment discrimination charges in 2013?', 'The EEOC (2014) received more than 94,000 charges of various kinds of employment discrimination in 2013.']

['What were some of the types of employment discrimination charges that the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) received in 2013?', 'Many of the filings are for multiple forms of discrimination and include charges of retaliation for making a claim, which itself is illegal.']

['What is the relationship between the number of employment discrimination charges received by the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) in 2013 and the number of suits filed in a federal court?', 'Only a small fraction of these claims become suits filed in a federal court, although the suits may represent the claims of more than one person.']

['What percentage of the employment discrimination charges received by the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) in 2013 resulted in suits being filed in a federal court?', 'In 2013, there were 148 suits filed in federal courts.']

['Teacher: What recent development has expanded the scope of federal protection against discrimination in the private sector based on sexual orientation and gender identity?', 'Based on a 2020 Supreme Court ruling regarding the application of the Civil Rights Act, federal legislation now protects employees in the private sector from discrimination related to sexual orientation and gender identity.']
['Teacher: Which legislation was the 2020 Supreme Court ruling based on?', 'These groups include lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender individuals.']

['Teacher: What are some sources of evidence that indicate discrimination against lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender individuals in the workplace?', 'There is evidence of discrimination derived from surveys of workers, studies of complaint filings, wage comparison studies, and controlled job-interview studies (Badgett, Sears, Lau, & Ho, 2009).']

['What were the groups that were previously protected from discrimination under federal legislation before the 2020 Supreme Court ruling?', 'Prior to the ruling, federal legislation protected federal employees from such discrimination; the District of Columbia and 20 states have laws protecting public and private employees from discrimination for sexual orientation (American Civil Liberties Union, n.d).']

['What is the role of the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) in addressing discrimination in the workplace?', 'Most of the states with these laws also protect against discrimination based on gender identity.']

['What is the purpose of the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) in relation to discrimination based on gender identity?', 'Gender identity refers to one’s sense of being male, female, neither of these, both of these, or another gender.']

['Act of 1964 prohibited employment discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex, or national origin, the enforcement of these laws was initially the responsibility of the individual who believed they were discriminated against. This often proved to be challenging and ineffective, leading to the establishment of the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) in 1965. \n\nTeacher: Why was the establishment of the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission necessary?', "While the Supreme Court's Civil Rights"]

['Teacher: How did the establishment of the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission address the challenges and ineffectiveness of individual enforcement of anti-discrimination laws?', 'Act interpretation is regarded as a landmark outcome for LGBTQ people, it will be continually tested by organizations that for various reasons see a need to exclude LGBTQ people from employment or service.']

['Teacher: How does the First Amendment protect religious organizations in regards to anti-discrimination laws?', 'The First Amendment protects religious organizations from some aspects of anti-discrimination laws, and some recent court decisions have expanded these exceptions so that certain ministries, schools, or other organizations could avoid employing or serving LGBTQ people.']

['Teacher: What is the main purpose of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) of 1990?', 'The Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) of 1990 states people may not be discriminated against due to the nature of their disability.']

['Teacher: Can you give me an example of a major life activity that could be limited by a disability?', 'A disability is defined as a physical or mental impairment that limits one or more major life activities such as hearing, walking, and breathing.']

['Teacher: What is one example of a reasonable accommodation that an employer might make for an employee with a disability?', 'An employer must make reasonable accommodations for the performance of the job of an employee with disabilities.']

['Teacher: How does the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) define a reasonable accommodation for employees with disabilities?', 'This might include making the work facility accessible with ramps, providing readers for blind personnel, or allowing for more frequent breaks.']

['Teacher: How has the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) expanded its coverage in recent years?', 'The ADA has now been expanded to include individuals with alcoholism, former drug use, obesity, or psychiatric disabilities.']
