['What is the underlying premise of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA)?', "The premise of the law is that individuals with disabilities can contribute to an organization and they cannot be discriminated against because of their disabilities (O'Keefe & Bruyere, 1994)."]
['Teacher: Can you name two other important laws that were enacted alongside the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA)?', 'The Civil Rights Act and the Age Discrimination in Employment']

["Teacher: That's correct! The Civil Rights Act and the Age Discrimination in Employment Act both have a significant impact on employment laws. Can you explain what bona fide occupational qualifications (BFOQs) are and how they relate to these laws?", 'Act make provisions for bona fide occupational qualifications (BFOQs), which are requirements of certain occupations for which denying an individual employment would otherwise violate the law.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how bona fide occupational qualifications (BFOQs) can be applied in an employment setting?', 'For example, there may be cases in which religion, national origin, age, and sex are bona fide occupational qualifications.']

['Teacher: How does the First Amendment come into play when discussing BFOQ exceptions for race in employment?', 'There are no BFOQ exceptions that apply to race, although the first amendment protects artistic expressions, such as films, in making race a requirement of a role.']

['Teacher: Can you think of any other examples of bona fide occupational qualifications (BFOQs) that apply to roles in religiously affiliated institutions?', 'Clearcut examples of BFOQs would be hiring someone of a specific religion for a leadership position in a worship facility, or for an executive position in religiously affiliated institutions, such as the president of a university with religious ties.']

["Teacher: That's correct! Age can be considered a bona fide occupational qualification in certain roles. Can you explain why mandatory retirement ages for airline pilots can be justified under the BFOQ exception?", 'Age has been determined to be a BFOQ for airline pilots; hence, there are mandatory retirement ages for safety reasons.']

['Teacher: How are mandatory retirement ages justified for airline pilots under the BFOQ exception?\nStudent: Age has been determined to be a BFOQ for airline pilots; hence, there are mandatory retirement ages for safety reasons.', 'Sex has been determined as a BFOQ for guards in male prisons.']

['Teacher: What is the most common reason for invoking a BFOQ as a defense against accusing an employer of discrimination in relation to sex or gender?', 'Sex or gender is the most common reason for invoking a BFOQ as a defense against accusing an employer of discrimination (Manley, 2009).']

['What is the three-part test that courts have established for determining whether a sex-related BFOQ exists?', 'Courts have established a three-part test for sex-related BFOQs that are often used in other types of legal cases for determining whether a BFOQ exists.']
['What is the second part of the three-part test for determining whether a sex-related BFOQ exists?', 'The first of these is whether all or substantially all women would be unable to perform a job.']

['What is the third part of the three-part test for determining whether a sex-related BFOQ exists?', 'This is the reason most physical limitations, such as “able to lift 30 pounds,” fail as reasons to discriminate because most women are able to lift this weight.']

['What is the "essence of the business" test and how does it relate to determining whether a sex-related BFOQ exists?', 'The second test is the “essence of the business” test, in which having to choose the other gender would undermine the essence of the business operation.']

['How did the "essence of the business" test apply in the case of Pan American World Airways (Pan Am) and their hiring of flight attendants?', 'This test was the reason the now defunct Pan American World Airways (i.e., Pan Am) was told it could not hire only women flight attendants.']

['What is the significance of Pan American World Airways (Pan Am) being told they could not hire only women flight attendants in relation to the "essence of the business" test?', 'Hiring men would not have undermined the essense of this business.']

["Why is it important that hiring cannot be made purely based on customers' or others' preferences?", 'On a deeper level, this means that hiring cannot be made purely on customers’ or others’ preferences.']

['What is the determining factor for the third and final test in determining whether a sex-related BFOQ exists?', 'The third and final test is whether the employer cannot make reasonable alternative accommodations, such as reassigning staff so that a woman does not have to work in a men-only part of a jail or other gender-specific facility.']

['How do privacy concerns relate to discrimination based on gender in certain employment situations?', 'Privacy concerns are a major reason why discrimination based on gender is upheld by the courts, for example in situations such as hires for nursing or custodial staff (Manley, 2009).']
['How are most cases of BFOQs decided?', 'Most cases of BFOQs are decided on a case-by-case basis and these court decisions inform policy and future case decisions.']

['Teacher: What is the relationship between organizational psychology and industrial and organizational psychology?', 'Organizational psychology is the second major branch of study and practice within the discipline of industrial and organizational psychology.']

['Teacher: What is the main focus of organizational psychology within the discipline of industrial and organizational psychology?', 'In organizational psychology, the focus is on social interactions and their effect on the individual and on the functioning of the organization.']

['What are some topics that organizational psychologists study within the context of work?', 'In this section, you will learn about the work organizational psychologists have done to understand job satisfaction, different styles of management, different styles of leadership, organizational culture, and teamwork.']

['Teacher: What are the different attitudes or feelings that people may have towards their jobs?', 'Some people love their jobs, some people tolerate their jobs, and some people cannot stand their jobs.']
['Teacher: What does job satisfaction refer to?', 'Job satisfaction describes the degree to which individuals enjoy their job.']

["Teacher: Who defined job satisfaction as the state of feeling resulting from appraising one's job experiences?", 'It was described by Edwin Locke (1976) as the state of feeling resulting from appraising one’s job experiences.']

['Teacher: How does job satisfaction result from both cognition and affect according to Saari and Judge?', 'While job satisfaction results from both how we think about our work (our cognition) and how we feel about our work (our affect) (Saari & Judge, 2004), it is described in terms of affect.']

['Teacher: What are the factors that can impact job satisfaction, according to Saari and Judge?', 'Job satisfaction is impacted by the work itself, our personality, and the culture we come from and live in (Saari & Judge, 2004).']

['Teacher: How is job satisfaction typically measured after a change in an organization?', 'Job satisfaction is typically measured after a change in an organization, such as a shift in the management model, to assess how the change affects employees.']

["Teacher: Why would job satisfaction be measured after a change in an organization's management model?", 'It may also be routinely measured by an organization to assess one of many factors expected to affect the organization’s performance.']

['Teacher: How does measuring job satisfaction on a national scale help gather information about the state of the economy and the workforce?', 'In addition, polling companies like Gallup regularly measure job satisfaction on a national scale to gather broad information on the state of the economy and the workforce (Saad, 2012).']
['Teacher: How is job satisfaction typically measured?', 'Job satisfaction is measured using questionnaires that employees complete.']

['Teacher: Can you give an example of a commonly used rating scale used in job satisfaction questionnaires?', 'Sometimes a single question might be asked in a very straightforward way to which employees respond using a rating scale, such as a Likert scale, which was discussed in the chapter on personality.']

['What are the five possible answers on a Likert scale?', 'A Likert scale (typically) provides five possible answers to a statement or question that allows respondents to indicate their positive-to-negative strength of agreement or strength of feeling regarding the question or statement.']

['What are the possible responses on a Likert scale for the question "How satisfied are you with your job today?"?', 'Thus the possible responses to a question such as “How satisfied are you with your job today?” might be “Very satisfied,” “Somewhat satisfied,” “Neither satisfied, nor dissatisfied,” “Somewhat dissatisfied,” and “Very dissatisfied.”']

['What is the purpose of asking multiple questions about job satisfaction in a survey?', 'More commonly the survey will ask a number of questions about the employee’s satisfaction to determine more precisely why they are satisfied or dissatisfied.']

['Why is it important to determine more precisely why employees are satisfied or dissatisfied with their jobs?', 'Sometimes these surveys are created for specific jobs; at other times, they are designed to apply to any job.']

['What are the two levels at which job satisfaction can be measured?', 'Job satisfaction can be measured at a global level, meaning how satisfied in general the employee is with work, or at the level of specific factors intended to measure which aspects of the job lead to satisfaction (Table 13.2).']

["Teacher: According to Saari and Judge's research in 2004, what factor is considered to be the most strongly predictive factor of overall job satisfaction?", 'Research has suggested that the work-content factor, which includes variety, difficulty level, and role clarity of the job, is the most strongly predictive factor of overall job satisfaction (Saari & Judge, 2004).']

["What is the most strongly predictive factor of overall job satisfaction according to Saari and Judge's research in 2004?", 'In contrast, there is only a weak correlation between pay level and job satisfaction (Judge, Piccolo, Podsakoff, Shaw, & Rich, 2010).']
['What does Judge et al. (2010) suggest about individuals adjusting or adapting to higher pay levels?', 'Judge et al. (2010) suggest that individuals adjust or adapt to higher pay levels:']

['Teacher: According to Judge et al. (2010), what happens to the satisfaction individuals feel when their salary increases?', 'Higher pay no longer provides the satisfaction the individual may have initially felt when their salary increased.']

['Teacher: How are measures of job satisfaction related to organizational citizenship or discretionary behaviors of an employee?', 'Measures of job satisfaction are somewhat correlated with job performance; in particular, they appear to relate to organizational citizenship or discretionary behaviors on the part of an employee that further the goals of the organization (Judge & Kammeyer-Mueller, 2012).']

['What are some factors that job satisfaction is correlated with, according to the passage?', 'Job satisfaction is related to general life satisfaction, although there has been limited research on how the two influence each other or whether personality and cultural factors affect both job and general life satisfaction.']

['What does the research suggest about the relationship between job satisfaction and life satisfaction?', 'One carefully controlled study suggested that the relationship is reciprocal: Job satisfaction affects life satisfaction positively, and vice versa (Judge & Watanabe, 1993).']
['What are some factors that organizations have limited control over when it comes to job satisfaction?', 'Of course, organizations cannot control life satisfaction’s influence on job satisfaction.']

['What are some examples of withdrawal behaviors that are related to low job satisfaction?', 'Job satisfaction, specifically low job satisfaction, is also related to withdrawal behaviors, such as leaving a job or absenteeism (Judge & Kammeyer-Mueller, 2012).']
['What does the passage suggest about the relationship between job satisfaction and employee turnover?', 'The relationship with turnover itself, however, is weak (Judge & Kammeyer-Mueller, 2012).']

['What does the research suggest about the impact of job satisfaction on organizational performance?', 'Finally, it appears that job satisfaction is related to organizational performance, which suggests that implementing organizational changes to improve employee job satisfaction will improve organizational performance (Judge & Kammeyer-Mueller, 2012).']

['Teacher: Can you please elaborate on your statement regarding the opportunity for more research in the area of job satisfaction?', 'There is opportunity for more research in the area of job satisfaction.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why separating emotional and cognitive concepts in the measurement of job satisfaction would lead to more reliable results and better relationships with outcomes like performance, according to Weiss (2002)?', 'For example, Weiss (2002) suggests that the concept of job satisfaction measurements have combined both emotional and cognitive concepts, and measurements would be more reliable and show better relationships with outcomes like performance if the measurement of job satisfaction separated these two possible elements of job satisfaction.']
['Teacher: How does job stress impact job satisfaction?', 'Job stress affects job satisfaction.']
['Teacher: Can you explain some examples of specific stressors in an occupation that can lead to job stress?', 'Job stress, or job strain, is caused by specific stressors in an occupation.']
['Teacher: How would you define the term "stressor" in the context of job stress and job satisfaction?', 'Stress can be an ambiguous term as it is used in common language.']

["Teacher: Can you provide some examples of how stressors in the workplace can impact an individual's well-being?", 'Stress is the perception and response of an individual to events judged as overwhelming or threatening to the individual’s well-being (Gyllensten & Palmer, 2005).']

['Teacher: Why is it important to identify and understand the specific stressors in the workplace?\nOr\nTeacher: How can identifying and understanding the specific stressors in the workplace help individuals improve their job satisfaction?', 'The events themselves are the stressors.']

['Teacher: How can understanding specific stressors in the workplace help organizations create a more positive work environment and increase overall job satisfaction?', 'Stress is a result of an employee’s perception that the demands placed on them exceed their ability to meet them (Gyllensten & Palmer, 2005), such as having to fill multiple roles in a job or life in general, workplace role ambiguity, lack of career progress, lack of job security, lack of control over work outcomes, isolation, work overload, discrimination, harassment, and bullying (Colligan & Higgins, 2005).']

['Teacher: How can understanding the gender differences in stressors in the workplace contribute to improving job satisfaction for both men and women?', 'The stressors are different for women than men and these differences are a significant area of research (Gyllensten & Palmer, 2005).']

['Teacher: How can organizations address and reduce job stress in order to improve employee health, job performance, and family life?', 'Job stress leads to poor employee health, job performance, and family life (Colligan & Higgins, 2005).']
['Teacher: What is one factor that contributes significantly to job stress as mentioned earlier?', 'As already mentioned, job insecurity contributes significantly to job stress.']

['Teacher: Can you elaborate on the two threats to job security mentioned, downsizing events and corporate mergers?', 'Two increasing threats to job security are downsizing events and corporate mergers.']

['Teacher: How can involving I-O psychologists in planning for, implementing, and managing downsizing events and corporate mergers help address the threats to job security?', 'Businesses typically involve I-O psychologists in planning for, implementing, and managing these types of organizational change.']

['Teacher: What is downsizing and when does it usually occur in a business?', 'Downsizing is an increasingly common response to a business’s pronounced failure to achieve profit goals, and it involves laying off a significant percentage of the company’s employees.']

['Teacher: How can industrial-organizational psychologists contribute to the process of downsizing in a business?', 'Industrial-organizational psychologists may be involved in all aspects of downsizing: how the news is delivered to employees (both those being let go and those staying), how laid-off employees are supported (e.g., separation packages), and how retained employees are supported.']

['Teacher: In what ways do downsizing events impact the intentions of retained employees to quit, their organizational commitment, and their job insecurity?', 'The latter is important for the organization because downsizing events affect the retained employee’s intent to quit, organizational commitment, and job insecurity (Ugboro, 2006).']

['Teacher: What are some strategies that corporations adopt to respond to external pressures on their business, such as downsizing?', 'In addition to downsizing as a way of responding to outside strains on a business, corporations often grow larger by combining with other businesses.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a merger and an acquisition between two corporations in response to external pressures on their business?', 'This can be accomplished through a merger (i.e., the joining of two organizations of equal power and status) or an acquisition (i.e., one organization purchases the other).']

['Teacher: How does the power or dominance of the organizations involved usually differ between a merger and an acquisition in response to external pressures on their business?', 'In an acquisition, the purchasing organization is usually the more powerful or dominant partner.']

['Teacher: What is a potential consequence of the duplication of services in a merger or an acquisition in response to external pressures on their business?', 'In both cases, there is usually a duplication of services between the two companies, such as two accounting departments and two sales forces.']

['What is one common outcome when two departments are merged in response to the duplication of services in a merger or an acquisition?', 'Both departments must be merged, which commonly involves a reduction of staff (Figure 13.14).']

['What are some similarities between the reduction of staff in a merger or acquisition and downsizing events?', 'This leads to organizational processes and stresses similar to those that occur in downsizing events.']

['What is one important factor to consider when it comes to the impact of organizational culture in a merger or acquisition?', 'Mergers require determining how the organizational culture will change, to which employees also must adjust (van Knippenberg, van Knippenberg, Monden, & de Lima, 2002).']

['What is one potential consequence of the stress on workers as they lose their connection to the old organization and try to make connections with the new combined group in a merger or acquisition?', 'There can be additional stress on workers as they lose their connection to the old organization and try to make connections with the new combined group (Amiot, Terry, Jimmieson, & Callan, 2006).']

['What is the focus of research in relation to understanding employee reactions and managing organizational changes in the context of mergers and acquisitions?', 'Research in this area focuses on understanding employee reactions and making practical recommendations for managing these organizational changes.']

['Teacher: What is the term used to describe the situation where individuals manage the responsibilities of their work life and their personal life at home?', 'Many people juggle the demands of work life with the demands of their home life, whether it be caring for children or taking care of an elderly parent; this is known as work-family balance.']

["What is work-family balance and how does it impact individuals' lives?", 'We might commonly think about work interfering with family, but it is also the case that family responsibilities may conflict with work obligations (Carlson, Kacmar, & Williams, 2000).']
['What are the three sources of work-family conflicts identified by Greenhaus and Beutell (1985)?', 'Greenhaus and Beutell (1985) first identified three sources of work–family conflicts:']

['Teacher: How does the increasing assumption of domestic responsibilities by men in the United States impact the fulfillment of family requirements in terms of time devoted to work?', 'Women often have greater responsibility for family demands, including home care, child care, and caring for aging parents, yet men in the United States are increasingly assuming a greater share of domestic responsibilities.']

['Teacher: How does the assumption of domestic responsibilities by men in the United States impact the fulfillment of family requirements in terms of stress levels reported by women?', 'However, research has documented that women report greater levels of stress from work–family conflict (Gyllensten & Palmer, 2005).']

['Teacher: How can individuals decrease work-family conflict and enhance their job satisfaction according to Posig and Kickul in 2004?', 'There are many ways to decrease work–family conflict and improve people’s job satisfaction (Posig & Kickul, 2004).']

['Teacher: How does emotional support in the home contribute to decreasing work-family conflict and enhancing job satisfaction according to Posig and Kickul in 2004?', 'These include support in the home, which can take various forms: emotional (listening), practical (help with chores).']

['Teacher: According to Posig and Kickul in 2004, what are some examples of workplace support that can help individuals decrease work-family conflict and enhance job satisfaction?', 'Workplace support can include understanding supervisors, flextime, leave with pay, and telecommuting.']

['Teacher: How does flextime help individuals fulfill the requirements of both work and family according to Posig and Kickul in 2004?', 'Flextime usually involves a requirement of core hours spent in the workplace around which the employee may schedule their arrival and departure from work to meet family demands.']

['How can telecommuting help individuals fulfill the requirements of both work and family according to Posig and Kickul in 2004?', 'Telecommuting involves employees working at home and setting their own hours, which allows them to work during different parts of the day, and to spend part of the day with their family; this may also be known as ecommuting, working remotely, flexible workspace, or simply working from home.']

['According to Posig and Kickul in 2004, what is an example of workplace support that can help individuals decrease work-family conflict and enhance job satisfaction?', 'Recall that Yahoo! had a policy of allowing employees to telecommute and then rescinded the policy.']

['What are some examples of workplace amenities that can help individuals decrease work-family conflict and enhance job satisfaction according to Posig and Kickul in 2004?', 'There are also organizations that have onsite daycare centers, and some companies even have onsite fitness centers and health clinics.']

['How did Lapierre and Allen in 2006 find the effectiveness of different coping methods in decreasing work-family conflict and enhancing job satisfaction?', 'In a study of the effectiveness of different coping methods, Lapierre & Allen (2006) found practical support from home more important than emotional support.']

['According to Lapierre and Allen in 2006, how does immediate-supervisor support help individuals decrease work-family conflict and enhance job satisfaction?', 'They also found that immediate-supervisor support for a worker significantly reduced work–family conflict through such mechanisms as allowing an employee the flexibility needed to fulfill family obligations.']

['How did Lapierre and Allen in 2006 find the effectiveness of flextime and telecommuting in decreasing work-family conflict and enhancing job satisfaction?', 'In contrast, flextime did not help with coping and telecommuting actually made things worse, perhaps reflecting the fact that being at home intensifies the conflict between work and family because with the employee in the home, the demands of family are more evident.']

['Teacher: According to Posig & Kickul (2004), what do exemplar corporations aim to reduce through their policies?', 'Posig & Kickul (2004) identify exemplar corporations with policies designed to reduce work–family conflict.']

['What are some examples of policies implemented by exemplar corporations to reduce work-family conflict?', 'Examples include IBM’s policy of three years of job-guaranteed leave after the birth of a child, Lucent Technologies offer of one year’s childbirth leave at half pay, and SC Johnson’s program of concierge services for daytime errands.']
['Teacher: What are some key areas of focus in I-O research?', 'A significant portion of I-O research focuses on management and human relations.']

['Teacher: Can you explain how Douglas McGregor integrated scientific management and human relations into the concept of leadership behavior?', 'Douglas McGregor (1960) combined scientific management (a theory of management that analyzes and synthesizes workflows with the main objective of improving economic efficiency, especially labor productivity) and human relations into the notion of leadership behavior.']
['Teacher: What are the main characteristics and assumptions of Theory X and Theory Y as proposed by Douglas McGregor?', 'His theory lays out two different styles called Theory X and Theory Y.']

['Teacher: What are some characteristics and assumptions of Theory X as proposed by Douglas McGregor?', 'In the Theory X approach to management, managers assume that most people dislike work and are not innately self-directed.']

['Teacher: What are some characteristics and assumptions of Theory Y as proposed by Douglas McGregor?', 'Theory X managers perceive employees as people who prefer to be led and told which tasks to perform and when.']

['Teacher: How do Theory X managers view their employees in terms of their work ethic and motivation?', 'Their employees have to be watched carefully to be sure that they work hard enough to fulfill the organization’s goals.']

["Teacher: How do Theory X managers typically monitor their employees' work hours?", 'Theory X workplaces will often have employees punch a clock when arriving and leaving the workplace: Tardiness is punished.']

['What is the prevailing mindset of Theory X managers regarding employee autonomy and decision-making?', 'Supervisors, not employees, determine whether an employee needs to stay late, and even this decision would require someone higher up in the command chain to approve the extra hours.']

['What are some characteristics of Theory X managers when it comes to employee suggestions and speaking out of order?', 'Theory X supervisors will ignore employees’ suggestions for improved efficiency and reprimand employees for speaking out of order.']

['What is the general attitude of Theory X managers towards employees when it comes to efficiency failures?', 'These supervisors blame efficiency failures on individual employees rather than the systems or policies in place.']

['Teacher: How do Theory X managers motivate their employees to achieve managerial goals?', 'Managerial goals are achieved through a system of punishments and threats rather than enticements and rewards.']

['What is the general approach of Theory X managers towards employee motivations and behaviors at work?', 'Managers are suspicious of employees’ motivations and always suspect selfish motivations for their behavior at work (e.g., being paid is their sole motivation for working).']

['Teacher: What is assumed by managers in the Theory Y approach?', 'In the Theory Y approach, on the other hand, managers assume that most people seek inner satisfaction and fulfillment from their work.']

["Teacher: According to the student's response, what type of leadership allows employees to participate in setting their personal and work goals?", 'Employees function better under leadership that allows them to participate in, and provide input about, setting their personal and work goals.']

['Teacher: How does Theory Y leadership approach prioritize employee involvement in goal-setting and decision-making processes?', 'In Theory Y workplaces, employees participate in decisions about prioritizing tasks; they may belong to teams that, once given a goal, decide themselves how it will be accomplished.']

['Teacher: How does the Theory Y leadership approach impact employee input on matters of efficiency and safety in the workplace?', 'In such a workplace, employees are able to provide input on matters of efficiency and safety.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example that illustrates how the Theory Y leadership approach promotes employee input and involvement in ensuring workplace efficiency and safety?', 'One example of Theory Y in action is the policy of Toyota production lines that allows any employee to stop the entire line if a defect or other issue appears, so that the defect can be fixed and its cause remedied (Toyota Motor Manufacturing, 2013).']

['Teacher: Can you explain how a Theory Y workplace involves employees in decision-making regarding changes to the work process or management system?', 'A Theory Y workplace will also meaningfully consult employees on any changes to the work process or management system.']
['Teacher: How does a Theory Y workplace encourage employees to contribute their own ideas?', 'In addition, the organization will encourage employees to contribute their own ideas.']

['Teacher: How does McGregor characterize Theory X, the traditional method of management used in the United States?', 'McGregor (1960) characterized Theory X as the traditional method of management used in the United States.']

['Teacher: According to McGregor, what are the consequences of using the Theory X management approach in the United States?', 'He argued that a Theory Y approach was needed to improve organizational output and the wellbeing of individuals.']
['What does Table 13.3 do in relation to the two management approaches discussed (Theory X and Theory Y)?', 'Table 13.3 summarizes how these two management approaches differ.']

['Teacher: What was the name of the management style that Donald Clifton focused his research on?', 'Another management style was described by Donald Clifton, who focused his research on how an organization can best use an individual’s strengths, an approach he called strengths-based management.']

['Teacher: According to Donald Clifton, what is the approach he called for in managing an organization?', 'He and his colleagues interviewed 8,000 managers and concluded that it is important to focus on a person’s strengths, not their weaknesses.']

['Teacher: How did Donald Clifton define a strength?', 'A strength is a particular enduring talent possessed by an individual that allows them to provide consistent, near-perfect performance in tasks involving that talent.']

['Teacher: Why does Donald Clifton argue that focusing on strengths provides the greatest opportunity for growth?', 'Clifton argued that our strengths provide the greatest opportunity for growth (Buckingham & Clifton, 2001).']
["Teacher: Can you give an example of a strength according to Donald Clifton's definition?", 'An example of a strength is public speaking or the ability to plan a successful event.']

['What did the student say about the popularity of the strengths-based approach and its effect on organization performance?', 'The strengths-based approach is very popular although its effect on organization performance is not well-studied.']

['Teacher: What did Kaiser & Overfield find about managers and their approach to improving their weaknesses and using their strengths?', 'However, Kaiser & Overfield (2011) found that managers often neglected improving their weaknesses and overused their strengths, both of which interfered with performance.']
['Teacher: Can you explain why leadership is considered an important element of management?', 'Leadership is an important element of management.']

['Teacher: Can you provide some examples of the theories of leadership that researchers have proposed within the field of I-O research?', 'Leadership styles have been of major interest within I-O research, and researchers have proposed numerous theories of leadership.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the difference between transactional leadership and transformational leadership as proposed by Bass (1985) within the field of I-O research?', 'Bass (1985) popularized and developed the concepts of transactional leadership versus transformational leadership styles.']

['Teacher: What are some key characteristics of transactional leadership according to Bass (1985)?', 'In transactional leadership, the focus is on supervision and organizational goals, which are achieved through a system of rewards and punishments (i.e., transactions).']
['What are some key characteristics of transformational leadership according to Bass (1985)?', 'Transactional leaders maintain the status quo:']
['What are some key characteristics of transformational leadership according to Bass (1985)?', 'They are managers.']
['What are some key characteristics of transformational leadership according to Bass (1985)?', 'This is in contrast to the transformational leader.']

['What are the four attributes that people with transformational leadership possess, according to Bass (1985)?', 'People who have transformational leadership possess four attributes to varying degrees:']

['What are the four attributes that people with transformational leadership possess, according to Bass (1985)?', 'They are charismatic (highly liked role models), inspirational (optimistic about goal attainment), intellectually stimulating (encourage critical thinking and problem solving), and considerate (Bass, Avolio, & Atwater, 1996).']

['Teacher: What has the increasing involvement of women in leadership roles in corporations raised questions about?', 'As women increasingly take on leadership roles in corporations, questions have arisen as to whether there are differences in leadership styles between men and women (Eagly, Johannesen-Schmidt, & van Engen, 2003).']
["Teacher: What was the purpose of Eagly & Johnson's meta-analysis on gender and leadership style?", 'Eagly & Johnson (1990) conducted a meta-analysis to examine gender and leadership style.']

["What did Eagly & Johnson's meta-analysis on gender and leadership style reveal?", 'They found, to a slight but significant degree, that women tend to practice an interpersonal style of leadership (i.e., she focuses on the morale and welfare of the employees) and men practice a task-oriented style (i.e., he focuses on accomplishing tasks).']

["What are the implications of Eagly & Johnson's meta-analysis regarding the differences in leadership styles between men and women in actual organizational settings?", 'However, the differences were less pronounced when one looked only at organizational studies and excluded laboratory experiments or surveys that did not involve actual organizational leaders.']

['What were the differences in leadership styles between men and women when leadership style was categorized as democratic or autocratic?', 'Larger gender-related differences were observed when leadership style was categorized as democratic or autocratic, and these differences were consistent across all types of studies.']

["What does Eagly & Johnson's meta-analysis suggest about the reasons behind the similarities and differences in leadership styles between men and women?", 'The authors suggest that similarities between genders in leadership styles are attributable to different genders needing to conform to the organization’s culture; additionally, they propose that gender-related differences reflect inherent differences in the strengths each gender brings to bear on leadership practice.']

["What were the characteristics of leadership styles exhibited by women and men according to Eagly, Johannesen-Schmidt, & van Engen's meta-analysis?", 'In another meta-analysis of leadership style, Eagly, Johannesen-Schmidt, & van Engen (2003) found that women tended to exhibit the characteristics of transformational leaders, while men were more likely to be transactional leaders.']

["What were some specific differences observed between the leadership styles of men and women according to Eagly, Johannesen-Schmidt, & van Engen's meta-analysis?", 'However, the differences are not absolute; for example, women were found to use methods of reward for performance more often than men, which is a component of transactional leadership.']

["What is the magnitude of the differences in leadership styles between men and women according to Eagly, Johannesen-Schmidt, & van Engen's meta-analysis?", 'The differences they found were relatively small.']

['What does research suggest about the effectiveness of transformational leadership approaches compared to transactional approaches?', 'As Eagly, Johannesen-Schmidt, & van Engen (2003) point out, research shows that transformational leadership approaches are more effective than transactional approaches, although individual leaders typically exhibit elements of both approaches.']

['Teacher: What is the specific area of research discussed in the passage?', 'A new and emerging area of research within psychology focuses on leadership and the relationship with leaders from the perspective of a follower.']

['Teacher: How does the "followership" research contribute to our understanding of the leader-follower relationship dynamics in psychology?', 'This “followership” research suggests that studies need to examine the leader-follower relationship in both directions—instead of focusing only on leadership—to better understand the dynamics of the relationship.']

['Teacher: How does the concept of "followership" challenge the traditional focus on leadership in studying the dynamics of leader-follower relationship in psychology?', 'Put differently, people are individuals, and because they are different, there probably is no single best leadership-follower dynamic between leaders and followers.']

['Teacher: How can the concept of "followership" help us recognize the importance of individual differences in the leader-follower relationship?', 'For instance, think about the differences between yourself and someone you know well.']

['Teacher: How can the concept of "followership" help us understand the role of individual differences in the preferred amount of structure in the leader-follower relationship?', 'Maybe one of you likes a lot of structure and other seems to work best with less structure.']

['Teacher: How can the concept of "followership" help us understand the influence of individual differences on decision-making in the leader-follower relationship?', 'Perhaps, one of you is ready to try a new restaurant at any time and the other prefers to go to the tried-and-true place that you’ve visited so many times the servers know your order before you place it.']

['Teacher: What did early research discover about the characteristics of individual followers and their relationship with a leader based on the leadership style?', 'Some early research has discovered that the characteristics of individual followers will result in different types of relationships with a leader depending on the leadership style.']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a leadership style that may not work well with certain follower types?', 'It appears that not all leadership styles work well with all follower types.']

['Teacher: How might the degree of extroversion of followers impact their compatibility with certain leadership styles?', 'One characteristic of followers, for example, is their degree of extroversion.']

['Teacher: What factors other than extroversion might contribute to the compatibility between followers and certain leadership styles?', 'Previous research suggests that individuals with a high degree of extroversion would need a larger amount of interaction with their leaders in order to function well; however, other research suggests this may not necessarily be the case and instead other factors may be at work (Phillips & Bedeian; Bauer et al, 2006).']
['Teacher: Can you discuss another characteristic of followers as mentioned in the passage?', 'Another characteristic of followers is their individual need for growth.']

['Teacher: How might a leader who provides developmental opportunities be better received by followers with a strong desire for learning and growth within their organization?', 'For followers who have a strong desire to learn and grow within their organization, a leader who provides developmental opportunities might be better received than one who does not.']

['What is the potential impact on followers when leaders push them to grow and develop, particularly for those who are low on growth and need strength?', 'In addition, for those followers who are low on growth and need strength, leaders who push them to grow may make them less satisfied followers as they feel forced into further development and training, possibly signaling a lower level of achievement from their supervisor.']

['How can training for leaders help in better understanding and supporting both followers who have a strong drive for growth and those who do not?', 'Training for leaders in both helping employees who have a strong drive for growth and those who do not appears to be helpful in improving the relationship between both types of followers and their leaders (Schyns, Kroon, & Moors, 2008).']

["Teacher: Can you explain why an employee's need for leadership is considered an important component of the leader-follower relationship?", 'Finally, an employee’s need for leadership is an important component of the leader-follower relationship.']

['Teacher: What can happen to the quality of the leader-follower relationship if leaders provide a lot of structure and rigidity of processes to employees who are significantly more autonomous?', 'Some individuals are significantly more autonomous than others and as a result do not respond as well to leaders who provide a lot of structure and rigidity of processes, in turn reducing the quality of their relationship with their leader.']

['Teacher: How does providing a well-structured environment with clear responsibilities and little ambiguity in their work impact the relationship between leaders and employees high in need for leadership?', 'Other employees who are high in need for leadership have a better relationship with their leader if they are provided with a well-structured environment with clear responsibilities and little ambiguity in their work.']

['Teacher: What type of environment do followers who prefer a well-structured work setting thrive in?', 'These followers work best in situations where they feel they can comfortably perform the work with little requirement to think outside of the guidelines that have been provided.']

['What kind of leadership style is most effective for followers who prefer a well-structured work setting?', 'For these individuals, having a leader who is able to set a clear path forward for the employee with little need for deviation promotes a strong positive leader-follower relationship (Felfe & Schyns, 2006).']

["Teacher: What are some factors that contribute to the rapid change in today's workplace?", 'The workplace today is rapidly changing due to a variety of factors, such as shifts in technology, economics, foreign competition, globalization, and workplace demographics.']

['What are some examples of how organizations can respond quickly to changes in factors that contribute to the rapid change in the workplace?', 'Organizations need to respond quickly to changes in these factors.']

["Teacher: How can work teams contribute to an organization's ability to respond quickly to changes in the workplace?", 'Many companies are responding to these changes by structuring their organizations so that work can be delegated to work teams, which bring together diverse skills, experience, and expertise.']

['What are some benefits of structuring organizations around work teams instead of individuals?', 'This is in contrast to organizational structures that have individuals at their base (Naquin & Tynan, 2003).']

['What are some advantages of using a team-based approach to accomplish specific tasks or goals in the workplace?', 'In the team-based approach, teams are brought together and given a specific task or goal to accomplish.']

['What are some potential challenges or limitations of using a team-based approach to accomplish specific tasks or goals in the workplace?', 'Despite their burgeoning popularity, team structures do not always deliver greater productivity—the work of teams is an active area of research (Naquin & Tynan, 2003).']
['Teacher: Can you explain what are some of the contributing factors to achieving goals, teamwork, and the success of work teams?', 'There are many contributing factors.']
['Teacher: How can teamwork help in identifying team members who are not contributing to the work?', 'For example, teams can mask team members that are not working (i.e., social loafing).']

['What are some potential obstacles that can hinder the success of work teams?', 'Teams can be inefficient due to poor communication; they can have poor decision-making skills due to conformity effects; and, they can have conflict within the group.']
['What is the team halo effect and how does it contribute to the popularity of teams?', 'The popularity of teams may in part result from the team halo effect:']
["How does the team halo effect influence the perception of a team's success?", 'Teams are given credit for their successes.']

['What is the impact of the team halo effect on individual members of a team when it comes to assigning blame for team failures?', 'but individuals within a team are blamed for team failures (Naquin & Tynan, 2003).']
['How does the gender mix of a team contribute to its effectiveness and success?', 'One aspect of team diversity is their gender mix.']
['What have researchers found in their exploration of whether gender mix has an effect on team performance?', 'Researchers have explored whether gender mix has an effect on team performance.']

['What are the potential advantages and disadvantages of having a diverse gender mix in a team?', 'On the one hand, diversity can introduce communication and interpersonal-relationship problems that hinder performance, but on the other hand diversity can also increase the team’s skill set, which may include skills that can actually improve team member interactions.']

['How did Hoogendoorn, Oosterbeek, & van Praag (2013) manipulate the gender mix in their study of project teams in a university business school?', 'Hoogendoorn, Oosterbeek, & van Praag (2013) studied project teams in a university business school in which the gender mix of the teams was manipulated.']

['What were the findings of Hoogendoorn, Oosterbeek, & van Praag (2013) regarding the performance of gender-balanced teams compared to teams made up mostly of men?', 'They found that gender-balanced teams performed better, as measured by sales and profits, than teams made up mostly by men.']

['What was the impact of team composition on the performance of teams with more women than men, according to the study conducted by Hoogendoorn, Oosterbeek, & van Praag (2013)?', 'The study did not have enough data to determine the relative performance of teams with more women than men.']

['What were the limitations of the study conducted by Hoogendoorn, Oosterbeek, & van Praag (2013) in determining the factors that contributed to the performance improvement of gender-balanced teams compared to teams made up mostly of men?', 'The study was unsuccessful in identifying which mechanism (interpersonal relationships, learning, or skills mixes) accounted for performance improvement.']
['Teacher: Can you please explain the three basic types of teams mentioned in the passage?', 'There are three basic types of teams: problem resolution teams, creative teams, and tactical teams.']

["Teacher: That's correct. Can you give me an example of a team that falls under the category of creative teams?", 'Problem resolution teams are created for the purpose of solving a particular problem or issue; for example, the diagnostic teams at the Centers for Disease Control.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a team that falls under the category of tactical teams?', 'Creative teams are used to develop innovative possibilities or solutions; for example, design teams for car manufacturers create new vehicle models.']

['Teacher: Can you explain how tactical teams differ from problem resolution and creative teams in terms of their objectives and tasks?', 'Tactical teams are used to execute a well-defined plan or objective, such as a police or FBI SWAT team handling a hostage situation (Larson & LaFasto, 1989).']

['Teacher: What is the focus of research on virtual teams mentioned in the passage?', 'One area of active research involves a fourth kind of team—the virtual team; these studies examine how groups of geographically disparate people brought together using digital communications technology function (Powell, Piccoli, & Ives, 2004).']

['What are the factors contributing to the increasing prevalence of virtual teams in organizations?', 'Even before the COVID-19 pandemic, virtual teams were more common due to the growing globalization of organizations and the use of consulting and partnerships facilitated by digital communication.']
['Teacher: Can you explain what organizational culture means?', 'Each company and organization has an organizational culture.']

["Teacher: That's a good start. Can you give me an example of how organizational culture can influence the behavior of employees within a company?", 'Organizational culture encompasses the values, visions, hierarchies, norms, and interactions among its employees.']

['What are some examples of values, visions, hierarchies, norms, and interactions that contribute to an organizational culture?', 'It is how an organization is run, how it operates, and how it makes decisions—the industry in which the organization participates may have an influence.']

['How can the industry in which an organization operates impact its organizational culture?', 'Different departments within one company can develop their own subculture within the organization’s culture.']

['What are some examples of observable artifacts, espoused values, and basic assumptions within an organizational culture?', 'Ostroff, Kinicki, and Tamkins (2003) identify three layers in organizational culture: observable artifacts, espoused values, and basic assumptions.']

['What are some examples of symbols, language, narratives, and practices that represent observable artifacts within an organizational culture?', 'Observable artifacts are the symbols, language (jargon, slang, and humor), narratives (stories and legends), and practices (rituals) that represent the underlying cultural assumptions.']

['What are some examples of beliefs or concepts that an organization may endorse as their espoused values?', 'Espoused values are concepts or beliefs that the management or the entire organization endorses.']

['What are some examples of rules and guidelines that can represent the basic assumptions within an organizational culture?', 'They are the rules that allow employees to know which actions they should take in different situations and which information they should adhere to.']
['What are some examples of unobservable and unquestioned basic assumptions within an organizational culture?', 'These basic assumptions generally are unobservable and unquestioned.']
['What are some examples of survey instruments that researchers have developed to measure organizational culture?', 'Researchers have developed survey instruments to measure organizational culture.']

["Teacher: How does having suppliers in different countries and employees from different parts of the world contribute to the global nature of your company's workforce?", 'With the workforce being a global marketplace, your company may have a supplier in Korea and another in Honduras and have employees in the United States, China, and South Africa.']

['What is the potential impact of having coworkers with diverse religious, ethnic, or racial backgrounds on the organizational culture of your company?', 'You may have coworkers of different religious, ethnic, or racial backgrounds than yourself.']
['How might having coworkers from different places around the globe influence the organizational culture of your company?', 'Your coworkers may be from different places around the globe.']

['How does diversity training contribute to bridging and understanding cultural differences in the workplace?', 'Many workplaces offer diversity training to help everyone involved bridge and understand cultural differences.']
['What is the objective of diversity training in the workplace?', 'Diversity training educates participants about cultural differences with the goal of improving teamwork.']

['How can the conditions of work be set in order to reduce or eliminate prejudice between members of two groups?', 'There is always the potential for prejudice between members of two groups, but the evidence suggests that simply working together, particularly if the conditions of work are set carefully that such prejudice can be reduced or eliminated.']

["What were the findings of Pettigrew and Tropp's meta-analysis regarding the impact of intergroup contact on reducing prejudice?", 'Pettigrew and Tropp (2006) conducted a meta-analysis to examine the question of whether contact between groups reduced prejudice between those groups.']
["What specific factors did Pettigrew and Tropp's meta-analysis find had a significant effect on reducing prejudice between groups?", 'They found that there was a moderate but significant effect.']

['What were some of the specific conditions under which the meta-analysis found contact between two groups to be most effective in reducing prejudice?', 'They also found that, as previously theorized, the effect was enhanced when the two groups met under conditions in which they have equal standing, common goals, cooperation between the groups, and especially support on the part of the institution or authorities for the contact.']

['Teacher: What is one well-recognized negative aspect of organizational culture that includes harassment, including sexual harassment?', 'One well-recognized negative aspect of organizational culture is a culture of harassment, including sexual harassment.']

['Teacher: How do organizations typically address and prevent sexual harassment within their organizational culture?', 'Most organizations of any size have developed sexual harassment policies that define sexual harassment (or harassment in general) and the procedures the organization has set in place to prevent and address it when it does occur.']

['Teacher: What are some common components or elements that are typically included in a sexual harassment policy developed by organizations?', 'Thus, in most jobs you have held, you were probably made aware of the company’s sexual harassment policy and procedures, and may have received training related to the policy.']

['What does the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission define as sexual harassment?', 'The U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (n.d.) provides the following description of sexual harassment:']
['Teacher: Can you explain what is meant by the term "quid pro quo" in relation to sexual harassment?', 'One form of sexual harassment is called quid pro quo.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how the concept of quid pro quo applies to sexual harassment in an organizational setting?', 'Quid pro quo means you give something to get something, and it refers to a situation in which organizational rewards are offered in exchange for sexual favors.']

['Teacher: How does the concept of quid pro quo harassment typically involve an exchange of power within an organization?', 'Quid pro quo harassment is often between an employee and a person with greater power in the organization.']

['Teacher: How can the power dynamics in an organization contribute to the occurrence of quid pro quo harassment?', 'For example, a supervisor might request an action, such as a kiss or a touch, in exchange for a promotion, a positive performance review, or a pay raise.']

['How does the threat of withholding a reward contribute to the occurrence of quid pro quo harassment in an organizational setting?', 'Another form of sexual harassment is the threat of withholding a reward if a sexual request is refused.']
['How does hostile environment sexual harassment differ from quid pro quo harassment in an organizational setting?', 'Hostile environment sexual harassment is another type of workplace harassment.']

['What are some examples of behaviors that could create a hostile or intimidating environment in the workplace?', 'In this situation, an employee experiences conditions in the workplace that are considered hostile or intimidating.']

['Why is it important for organizations to address and prevent both quid pro quo harassment and hostile environment harassment?', 'For example, a work environment that allows offensive language or jokes or displays sexually explicit images.']

['What steps can organizations take to create a workplace culture that prevents both quid pro quo harassment and hostile environment harassment?', 'Isolated occurrences of these events do not constitute harassment, but a pattern of repeated occurrences does.']

['What are the potential legal consequences for an organization if it fails to address and prevent quid pro quo harassment and hostile environment harassment?', 'In addition to violating organizational policies against sexual harassment, these forms of harassment are illegal.']

['Teacher: How would you define workplace violence?', 'Workplace violence is any act or threat of physical violence, harassment, intimidation, or other threatening, disruptive behavior that occurs at the workplace.']

['Teacher: Can you provide some examples of what constitutes workplace violence?', 'It ranges from threats and verbal abuse to physical assaults and even homicide (Occupational Safety & Health Administration, 2014).']
['Teacher: What are the different targets of workplace violence?', 'There are different targets of workplace violence: a person could commit violence against coworkers, supervisors, or property.']

['Teacher: Why is it important to be aware of warning signs preceding acts of workplace violence?', 'Warning signs often precede such actions: intimidating behavior, threats, sabotaging equipment, or radical changes in a coworker’s behavior.']
['Teacher: How can identifying warning signs help in preventing workplace violence?', 'Often there is intimidation and then escalation that leads to even further escalation.']

['Teacher: How can involving an immediate supervisor help in preventing workplace violence?', 'It is important for employees to involve their immediate supervisor if they ever feel intimidated or unsafe.']
['Teacher: According to the passage, what is the second leading cause of death in the workplace?', 'Murder is the second leading cause of death in the workplace.']
['What is the primary cause of death for women in the workplace, according to the passage?', 'It is also the primary cause of death for women in the workplace.']

['What is the annual number of workers who experience physical assault or threat of assault in the workplace, according to the passage?', 'Every year there are nearly two million workers who are physically assaulted or threatened with assault.']

['What is one reason why some victims of workplace violence are murdered?', 'Many are murdered in domestic violence situations by boyfriends or husbands who chose the woman’s workplace to commit their crimes.']
['Teacher: What are some of the triggers for workplace violence?', 'There are many triggers for workplace violence.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how feeling treated unfairly or disrespectfully can trigger workplace violence?', 'A significant trigger is the feeling of being treated unfairly, unjustly, or disrespectfully.']

["What were the reactions of the students in Greenberg's research experiment who were given pay for a task?", 'In a research experiment, Greenberg (1993) examined the reactions of students who were given pay for a task.']

["Teacher: What was the result of Greenberg's research experiment on the students who were given extensive explanations for the pay rate?", 'In one group, the students were given extensive explanations for the pay rate.']

["Teacher: What was the result of Greenberg's research experiment on the students who were given a curt uninformative explanation for the pay rate?", 'In the second group, the students were given a curt uninformative explanation.']

["What impact did the belief that the supervisor wouldn't know how much money the student withdrew have on the students' reactions in Greenberg's research experiment?", 'The students were made to believe the supervisor would not know how much money the student withdrew for payment.']

["What were the findings regarding the rate of stealing in Greenberg's research experiment between the group that received extensive explanations and the group that received a curt uninformative explanation for the pay rate?", 'The rate of stealing (taking more pay than they were told they deserved) was higher in the group who had been given the limited explanation.']

["What does Greenberg's research experiment on workplace violence demonstrate about the importance of procedural justice in organizations?", 'This is a demonstration of the importance of procedural justice in organizations.']

['Why is procedural justice important in preventing workplace violence?', 'Procedural justice refers to the fairness of the processes by which outcomes are determined in conflicts with or among employees.']

["Teacher: According to Greenberg & Barling's study, which factors were identified as accurate predictors of workplace violence against a coworker?", 'In another study by Greenberg & Barling (1999), they found a history of aggression and amount of alcohol consumed to be accurate predictors of workplace violence against a coworker.']

['What were the identified factors that predicted workplace violence against a supervisor, as mentioned in the study by Greenberg & Barling?', 'Aggression against a supervisor was predicted if a worker felt unfairly treated or untrusted.']

['What factors did the study by Greenberg & Barling identify as predictors of workplace violence against a subordinate?', 'Job security and alcohol consumption predicted aggression against a subordinate.']

['What does the study by Greenberg & Barling emphasize when it comes to understanding and predicting workplace violence?', 'To understand and predict workplace violence, Greenberg & Barling (1999) emphasize the importance of considering the employee target of aggression or violence and characteristics of both the workplace characteristics and the aggressive or violent person.']

['Teacher: What is the term favored in Europe for human factors psychology?', 'Human factors psychology (or ergonomics, a term that is favored in Europe) is the third subject area within industrial and organizational psychology.']

['Teacher: What is the specific focus of human factors psychology or ergonomics within the workplace?', 'This field is concerned with the integration of the human-machine interface in the workplace, through design, and specifically with researching and designing machines that fit human requirements.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of physical integration in the context of human factors psychology and workplace design?', 'The integration may be physical or cognitive, or a combination of both.']

['Teacher: Why might someone find it difficult to operate an unfamiliar television remote control or use new software for the first time?', 'Anyone who needs to be convinced that the field is necessary need only try to operate an unfamiliar television remote control or use a new piece of software for the first time.']

['What are the specific areas that human factors psychology focuses on within the workplace?', 'Whereas the two other areas of I-O psychology focus on the interface between the worker and team, group, or organization, human factors psychology focuses on the individual worker’s interaction with a machine, work station, information displays, and the local environment, such as lighting.']

['What are the origins of human factors psychology in the United States and who were some of the early contributors?', 'In the United States, human factors psychology has origins in both psychology and engineering; this is reflected in the early contributions of Lillian Gilbreth (psychologist and engineer) and her husband Frank Gilbreth (engineer).']

['Teacher: Can you explain the role of human factor professionals in the design process and when they are typically involved in a project?', 'Human factor professionals are involved in design from the beginning of a project, as is more common in software design projects, or toward the end in testing and evaluation, as is more common in traditional industries (Howell, 2003).']

['Teacher: What are some examples of traditional industries where human factor professionals are typically involved towards the end of a project in testing and evaluation?', 'Another important role of human factor professionals is in the development of regulations and principles of best design.']

['Teacher: Can you provide some examples of regulations and principles related to work safety that human factor professionals contribute to in the design process?', 'These regulations and principles are often related to work safety.']

['Teacher: Can you explain how the Three Mile Island nuclear accident influenced the regulations and principles related to work safety in the design of nuclear facilities?', 'For example, the Three Mile Island nuclear accident lead to Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) requirements for additional instrumentation in nuclear facilities to provide operators with more critical information and increased operator training (United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission, 2013).']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of an ergonomic design standard developed by the American National Standards Institute (ANSI) for the design of control-center workstations?', 'The American National Standards Institute (ANSI, 2000), an independent developer of industrial standards, develops many standards related to ergonomic design, such as the design of control-center workstations that are used for transportation control or industrial process control.']

['Teacher: What are some examples of workplace safety concerns that are addressed in the field of human factors psychology?', 'Many of the concerns of human factors psychology are related to workplace safety.']

['Why is it important to study workplace safety concerns in the field of human factors psychology?', 'These concerns can be studied to help prevent work-related injuries of individual workers or those around them.']

['What are some examples of activities outside of traditional workplace environments that may have workplace safety concerns related to human factors psychology?', 'Safety protocols may also be related to activities, such as commercial driving or flying, medical procedures, and law enforcement, that have the potential to impact the public.']
['Teacher: What is one of the methods used to reduce accidents in the workplace?', 'One of the methods used to reduce accidents in the workplace is a checklist.']
['Why is the airline industry known for using checklists to reduce accidents in the workplace?', 'The airline industry is one industry that uses checklists.']

['What is the purpose of pilots going through a checklist before takeoff in the airline industry?', 'Pilots are required to go through a detailed checklist of the different parts of the aircraft before takeoff to ensure that all essential equipment is working correctly.']
['Why do astronauts go through checklists before takeoff?', 'Astronauts also go through checklists before takeoff.']

['What is the purpose of using a surgical safety checklist in medical facilities?', 'The surgical safety checklist shown in Figure 13.15 was developed by the World Health Organization (WHO) and serves as the basis for many checklists at medical facilities.']

['Teacher: What are some examples of occupations where safety concerns dictate limits on how long individuals are allowed to operate equipment?', 'Safety concerns also lead to limits to how long an operator, such as a pilot or truck driver, is allowed to operate the equipment.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of an organization or agency that sets limits on the duration of pilot shifts to ensure safety?', 'Recently the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) introduced limits for how long a pilot is allowed to fly without an overnight break.']

['Teacher: What are the important areas of research and practice outlined by Howell (2003) in the field of human factors?', 'Howell (2003) outlines some important areas of research and practice in the field of human factors.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an overview of the areas of research and practice outlined by Howell (2003) in Table 13.4 regarding human factors in the workplace design?', 'These are summarized in Table 13.4.']

['Teacher: What specific aspect of human factors psychology did Bruno & Abrahão (2012) focus on in their research?', 'As an example of research in human factors psychology Bruno & Abrahão (2012) examined the impact of the volume of operator decisions on the accuracy of decisions made within an information security center at a banking institution in Brazil.']

['What was the main variable that Bruno & Abrahão (2012) investigated in their study on human factors psychology?', 'The study examined a total of about 45,000 decisions made by 35 operators and 4 managers over a period of 60 days.']

["What were the findings of Bruno & Abrahão's (2012) study regarding the relationship between the number of decisions made by operators and the accuracy of their decisions?", 'Their study found that as the number of decisions made per day by the operators climbed, that is, as their cognitive effort increased, the operators made more mistakes in falsely identifying incidents as real security breaches (when, in reality, they were not).']

["What was the relationship between the number of decisions made by operators and the occurrence of falsely identifying incidents as real security breaches, according to Bruno & Abrahão's (2012) study?", 'Interestingly, the opposite mistake of identifying real intrusions as false alarms did not increase with increased cognitive demand.']

["What was the impact of increased cognitive demand on the occurrence of falsely identifying real security breaches as false alarms, according to Bruno & Abrahão's (2012) study?", 'This appears to be good news for the bank, since false alarms are not as costly as incorrectly rejecting a genuine threat.']

["What are some of the key areas of research that are encompassed within human factors psychology, according to the student's statement?", 'These kinds of studies combine research on attention, perception, teamwork, and human–computer interactions in a field of considerable societal and business significance.']

['What is one example of a real-world event that demonstrates the societal and business significance of human factors psychology?', 'This is exactly the context of the events that led to the massive data breach for Target in the fall of 2013.']

["What specific aspect of human factors psychology could have potentially helped Target in preventing the data breach in 2013, based on the student's statement?", 'Indications are that security personnel received signals of a security breach but did not interpret them correctly, thus allowing the breach to continue for two weeks until an outside agency, the FBI, informed the company (Riley, Elgin, Lawrence, & Matlack, 2014).']

['Teacher: When did the term stress start to become commonly used in everyday language?', 'The term stress as it relates to the human condition first emerged in scientific literature in the 1930s, but it did not enter the popular vernacular until the 1970s (Lyon, 2012).']

['What is the significance of the 1970s in relation to the term stress becoming commonly used in everyday language?', 'Today, we often use the term loosely in describing a variety of unpleasant feeling states; for example, we often say we are stressed out when we feel frustrated, angry, conflicted, overwhelmed, or fatigued.']

['What are some examples of feeling states that we often describe as being stressed out?', 'Despite the widespread use of the term, stress is a fairly vague concept that is difficult to define with precision.']
['Teacher: Why have researchers had a difficult time agreeing on an acceptable definition of stress?', 'Researchers have had a difficult time agreeing on an acceptable definition of stress.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why some researchers have conceptualized stress as a demanding or threatening event or situation?', 'Some have conceptualized stress as a demanding or threatening event or situation (e.g., a high-stress job, overcrowding, and long commutes to work).']

['Teacher: How do stimulus-based definitions characterize stress?', 'Such conceptualizations are known as stimulus-based definitions because they characterize stress as a stimulus that causes certain reactions.']

['Teacher: Why do stimulus-based definitions of stress fail to recognize individual differences in how people view and react to challenging life events and situations?', 'Stimulus-based definitions of stress are problematic, however, because they fail to recognize that people differ in how they view and react to challenging life events and situations.']

["Teacher: Can you provide an example that illustrates how individual differences in perception and preparation can affect a person's experience of stress?", 'For example, a conscientious student who has studied diligently all semester would likely experience less stress during final exams week than would a less responsible, unprepared student.']

['Teacher: How have others conceptualized stress in relation to physiological responses?', 'Others have conceptualized stress in ways that emphasize the physiological responses that occur when faced with demanding or threatening situations (e.g., increased arousal).']

['Teacher: What is the main focus of response-based definitions of stress?', 'These conceptualizations are referred to as response-based definitions because they describe stress as a response to environmental conditions.']

['What is one example of a response-based definition of stress provided by Hans Selye?', 'For example, the endocrinologist Hans Selye, a famous stress researcher, once defined stress as the “response of the body to any demand, whether it is caused by, or results in, pleasant or unpleasant conditions” (Selye, 1976, p. 74).']

['Teacher: How does Hans Selye define stress according to his response-based definition?', 'Selye’s definition of stress is response-based in that it conceptualizes stress chiefly in terms of the body’s physiological reaction to any demand that is placed on it.']
['What are the limitations of stimulus-based and response-based definitions of stress?', 'Neither stimulus-based nor response-based definitions provide a complete definition of stress.']

['What is an example of a physiological reaction that can occur in response to something that most people would not consider to be genuinely stressful?', 'Many of the physiological reactions that occur when faced with demanding situations (e.g., accelerated heart rate) can also occur in response to things that most people would not consider to be genuinely stressful, such as receiving unanticipated good news: an unexpected promotion or raise.']

['Teacher: How can stress be described as a process according to Lazarus and Folkman in the textbook passage?', 'A useful way to conceptualize stress is to view it as a process whereby an individual perceives and responds to events that they appraise as overwhelming or threatening to their well-being (Lazarus & Folkman, 1984).']

["What does Lazarus and Folkman's definition of stress emphasize in terms of individual perception and response to events?", 'A critical element of this definition is that it emphasizes the importance of how we appraise—that is, judge—demanding or threatening events (often referred to as stressors); these appraisals, in turn, influence our reactions to such events.']

["What are the two kinds of appraisals of a stressor mentioned in relation to Lazarus and Folkman's definition of stress?", 'Two kinds of appraisals of a stressor are especially important in this regard: primary and secondary appraisals.']

["What is involved in a primary appraisal according to Lazarus and Folkman's definition of stress?", 'A primary appraisal involves judgment about the degree of potential harm or threat to well-being that a stressor might entail.']

["What is involved in a secondary appraisal according to Lazarus and Folkman's definition of stress?", 'A stressor would likely be appraised as a threat if one anticipates that it could lead to some kind of harm, loss, or other negative consequence; conversely, a stressor would likely be appraised as a challenge if one believes that it carries the potential for gain or personal growth.']

["How can an individual's perception of a stressor influence their appraisal of the situation?", 'For example, an employee who is promoted to a leadership position would likely perceive the promotion as a much greater threat if they believed the promotion would lead to excessive work demands than if they viewed it as an opportunity to gain new skills and grow professionally.']

["How might the perception of a stressor as a threat or a challenge impact an individual's response to the situation?", 'Similarly, a college student on the cusp of graduation may face the change as a threat or a challenge (Figure 14.2).']
