['Teacher: What is the purpose of the secondary appraisal in relation to stress?', 'The perception of a threat triggers a secondary appraisal: judgment of the options available to cope with a stressor, as well as perceptions of how effective such options will be (Lyon, 2012) (Figure 14.3).']

['Teacher: Can you explain the concept of self-efficacy and its relevance to the secondary appraisal of stress?', 'As you may recall from what you learned about self-efficacy, an individual’s belief in their ability to complete a task is important (Bandura, 1994).']

['Teacher: How does the concept of self-efficacy influence perception of a threat in the context of stress?', 'A threat tends to be viewed as less catastrophic if one believes something can be done about it (Lazarus & Folkman, 1984).']

['Teacher: How might the concept of self-efficacy influence the secondary appraisal process for Robin and Madhuri in this situation?', 'Imagine that two middle-aged people, Robin and Madhuri, perform breast self-examinations one morning and each notices a lump on the lower region of their left breast.']

['Teacher: How might the concept of self-efficacy influence the secondary appraisal process for Robin and Madhuri in this situation? Specifically, how might their beliefs about their ability to cope with the potential threat affect their secondary appraisals?', 'Although both view the breast lump as a potential threat (primary appraisal), their secondary appraisals differ considerably.']

["Teacher: How might Robin's beliefs about her ability to cope with the potential threat of breast cancer affect her secondary appraisal process?", 'In considering the breast lump, some of the thoughts racing through Robin’s mind are, “Oh my God, I could have breast cancer!']

["Teacher: How might Robin's beliefs about her ability to cope with the potential threat of breast cancer affect her secondary appraisal process? Specifically, how might her beliefs about the severity of the experience affect her secondary appraisal?", 'I’ve heard that experience is awful!']

['Teacher: How might the concept of self-efficacy influence the secondary appraisal process for Robin and Madhuri in the context of their financial concerns?', 'My partner and I won’t have enough money to pay the mortgage.']

["How might Robin's beliefs about her ability to cope with their financial concerns affect her secondary appraisal process? Specifically, how might her beliefs about the severity of the financial situation affect her secondary appraisal?", 'Oh, this is just horrible…I can’t deal with it!”']

["Teacher: How might Madhuri's beliefs about her ability to cope with their financial concerns affect her secondary appraisal process? Specifically, how might her beliefs about the severity of the financial situation affect her secondary appraisal?", 'On the other hand, Madhuri thinks, “Hmm, this may not be good.']

["Teacher: How might Madhuri's beliefs about her ability to cope with the potential threat of breast cancer affect her secondary appraisal process? Specifically, how might her beliefs about the severity of the experience affect her secondary appraisal?", 'Although most times these things turn out to be benign, I need to have it checked out.']

["Teacher: How might Madhuri's beliefs about her ability to cope with the potential threat of breast cancer affect her secondary appraisal process? Specifically, how might her beliefs about her ability to access medical treatment and technology influence her secondary appraisal?", 'If it turns out to be breast cancer, there are doctors who can take care of it because the medical technology today is quite advanced.']

["How might Madhuri's beliefs about her ability to access medical treatment and technology influence her secondary appraisal process? Specifically, how might her beliefs about the availability of different treatment options affect her secondary appraisal?", 'I’ll have a lot of different options, and I’ll be just fine.”']

['Teacher: How might the concept of self-efficacy influence the secondary appraisal process for Robin and Madhuri in the context of their potential breast cancer diagnosis? Specifically, how might their beliefs about the effectiveness of different treatment options affect their secondary appraisals?', 'Clearly, Robin and Madhuri have different outlooks on what might turn out to be a very serious situation: Robin seems to think that little could be done about it, whereas Madhuri believes that, worst case scenario, a number of options that are likely to be effective would be available.']

['How might their differing beliefs about the potential effectiveness of treatment options affect their levels of stress in response to the potential breast cancer diagnosis?', 'As such, Robin would clearly experience greater stress than would Madhuri.']

['Teacher: Can you explain how some stressors can be inherently more stressful compared to others?', 'To be sure, some stressors are inherently more stressful than others in that they are more threatening and leave less potential for variation in cognitive appraisals (e.g., objective threats to one’s health or safety).']

['Teacher: How does cognitive appraisal affect our reactions to inherently stressful events?', 'Nevertheless, appraisal will still play a role in augmenting or diminishing our reactions to such events (Everly & Lating, 2002).']

['Teacher: Can you explain the factors that contribute to a person subjectively experiencing a state of stress?', 'If a person appraises an event as harmful and believes that the demands imposed by the event exceed the available resources to manage or adapt to it, the person will subjectively experience a state of stress.']

["Teacher: How does a person's appraisal of an event contribute to their subjective experience of stress?", 'In contrast, if one does not appraise the same event as harmful or threatening, she is unlikely to experience stress.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how an individual might interpret an event as harmful or threatening, leading to a state of stress?', 'According to this definition, environmental events trigger stress reactions by the way they are interpreted and the meanings they are assigned.']

["Teacher: How does the interpretation and assignment of meaning to environmental events contribute to a person's experience of stress?", 'In short, stress is largely in the eye of the beholder: it’s not so much what happens to you as it is how you respond (Selye, 1976).']
['Teacher: Can you explain why stress may sometimes be beneficial, despite its negative connotation?', 'Although stress carries a negative connotation, at times it may be of some benefit.']

['Teacher: Can you give me an example of how stress can motivate someone to perform their best at work?', 'Stress can motivate us to do things in our best interests, such as study for exams, visit the doctor regularly, exercise, and perform to the best of our ability at work.']
["Teacher: What is the significance of Selye's observation about stress not always being harmful?", 'Indeed, Selye (1974) pointed out that not all stress is harmful.']

["Teacher: How does Selye's observation challenge the common belief that all stress is harmful?", 'He argued that stress can sometimes be a positive, motivating force that can improve the quality of our lives.']

['Teacher: How does eustress differ from distress in terms of its impact on our lives?', 'This kind of stress, which Selye called eustress (from the Greek eu = “good”), is a good kind of stress associated with positive feelings, optimal health, and performance.']
['What are some benefits of experiencing a moderate amount of stress in challenging situations?', 'A moderate amount of stress can be beneficial in challenging situations.']

['Why might athletes be motivated and energized by pregame stress?', 'For example, athletes may be motivated and energized by pregame stress, and students may experience similar beneficial stress before a major exam.']
['What evidence supports the claim that moderate stress can improve memory?', 'Indeed, research shows that moderate stress can enhance both immediate and delayed recall of educational material.']

['What is one example of how stress can improve memory, according to the study discussed?', 'Participants in one study who memorized a scientific text passage showed improved memory of the passage immediately after exposure to a mild stressor as well as one day following exposure to the stressor (Hupbach & Fieman, 2012).']
["Teacher: Can you explain how increasing one's level of stress affects performance in a predictable way?", 'Increasing one’s level of stress will cause performance to change in a predictable way.']

['Teacher: How does increasing stress levels relate to performance and general well-being, according to Figure 14.4?', 'As shown in Figure 14.4, as stress increases, so do performance and general well-being (eustress); when stress levels reach an optimal level (the highest point of the curve), performance reaches its peak.']

['Teacher: According to Figure 14.4, what happens to performance when stress levels exceed the optimal level?', 'A person at this stress level is colloquially at the top of their game, meaning they feel fully energized, focused, and can work with minimal effort and maximum efficiency.']

['Teacher: How does Selye define distress in relation to stress levels that exceed the optimal level?', 'But when stress exceeds this optimal level, it is no longer a positive force—it becomes excessive and debilitating, or what Selye termed distress (from the Latin dis = “bad”).']

["Teacher: How does Selye's concept of distress align with the idea of performance decline and negative effects on well-being?", 'People who reach this level of stress feel burned out; they are fatigued, exhausted, and their performance begins to decline.']
['What are some potential consequences of prolonged exposure to high levels of stress?', 'If the stress remains excessive, health may begin to erode as well (Everly & Lating, 2002).']
["What are some negative effects that severe test anxiety can have on a student's performance and well-being?", 'A good example of distress is severe test anxiety.']

["How can severe test anxiety impact a student's test scores?", 'When students are feeling very stressed about a test, negative emotions combined with physical symptoms may make concentration difficult, thereby negatively affecting test scores.']

['Teacher: According to Figure 14.5, what trend has been observed in the prevalence of stress over the last several years?', 'Stress is everywhere and, as shown in Figure 14.5, it has been on the rise over the last several years.']
['Teacher: Can you explain how the prevalence of stress has changed over the last several years based on Figure 14.5?', 'Each of us is acquainted with stress—some are more familiar than others.']

["What can you infer about the prevalence of stress based on the student's description of stress in different situations?", 'In many ways, stress feels like a load you just can’t carry—a feeling you experience when, for example, you have to drive somewhere in a blizzard, when you wake up late the morning of an important job interview, when you run out of money before the next pay period, and before taking an important exam for which you realize you are not fully prepared.']

['Teacher: What are some examples of physiological responses to stress?', 'Stress is an experience that evokes a variety of responses, including those that are physiological (e.g., accelerated heart rate, headaches, or gastrointestinal problems), cognitive (e.g., difficulty concentrating or making decisions), and behavioral (e.g., drinking alcohol, smoking, or taking actions directed at eliminating the cause of the stress).']

['What are some examples of cognitive responses to stress?', 'Although stress can be positive at times, it can have deleterious health implications, contributing to the onset and progression of a variety of physical illnesses and diseases (Cohen & Herbert, 1996).']

['Teacher: Can you please explain the significance of health psychology and its focus on understanding the impact of psychological factors on health?', 'The scientific study of how stress and other psychological factors impact health falls within the realm of health psychology, a subfield of psychology devoted to understanding the importance of psychological influences on health, illness, and how people respond when they become ill (Taylor, 1999).']

['What is the primary focus of health psychology and why is it important in understanding the connection between psychological factors and health?', 'Health psychology emerged as a discipline in the 1970s, a time during which there was increasing awareness of the role behavioral and lifestyle factors play in the development of illnesses and diseases (Straub, 2007).']

['What are some of the specific issues that health psychologists investigate besides the connection between stress and illness?', 'In addition to studying the connection between stress and illness, health psychologists investigate issues such as why people make certain lifestyle choices (e.g., smoking or eating unhealthy food despite knowing the potential adverse health implications of such behaviors).']

['What is one important aspect of health psychology that health psychologists research and evaluate?', 'Health psychologists also design and investigate the effectiveness of interventions aimed at changing unhealthy behaviors.']

['What is one of the fundamental tasks of health psychologists in relation to identifying at-risk groups for negative health outcomes?', 'Perhaps one of the more fundamental tasks of health psychologists is to identify which groups of people are especially at risk for negative health outcomes, based on psychological or behavioral factors.']

['What is an example of how health psychologists identify at-risk groups for negative health outcomes based on psychological or behavioral factors?', 'For example, measuring differences in stress levels among demographic groups and how these levels change over time can help identify populations who may have an increased risk for illness or disease.']

['Teacher: What information does Figure 14.6 present regarding the <mask>?', 'Figure 14.6 depicts the results of three national surveys in which several thousand individuals from different demographic groups completed a brief stress questionnaire; the surveys were administered in 1983, 2006, and 2009 (Cohen & Janicki-Deverts, 2012).']
['Teacher: What does Figure 14.6 reveal about the prevalence of stress between men and women in the three national surveys?', 'All three surveys demonstrated higher stress in women than in men.']

['Teacher: Can you provide some demographic groups that reported higher levels of stress in the three national surveys discussed in Figure 14.6?', 'Unemployed individuals reported high levels of stress in all three surveys, as did those with less education and income; retired persons reported the lowest stress levels.']

['Teacher: Based on Figure 14.6, which demographic groups experienced the greatest increase in stress levels from 2006 to 2009?', 'However, from 2006 to 2009 the greatest increase in stress levels occurred among men, Hispanic people aged 45–64, college graduates, and those with full-time employment.']

['Teacher: How did concerns surrounding the 2008-2009 economic downturn potentially affect the stress levels of college-educated employed men with limited time remaining in their working careers, based on the interpretation of the findings from Figure 14.6?', 'One interpretation of these findings is that concerns surrounding the 2008–2009 economic downturn (e.g., threat of or actual job loss and substantial loss of retirement savings) may have been especially stressful to college-educated employed men with limited time remaining in their working careers.']
['Teacher: How far back does the scientific interest in stress go, as stated previously?', 'As previously stated, scientific interest in stress goes back nearly a century.']

["Teacher: Can you tell me a bit about Walter Cannon's contribution to the study of stress?", 'One of the early pioneers in the study of stress was Walter Cannon, an eminent American physiologist at Harvard Medical School (Figure 14.7).']
["What were Walter Cannon's contributions to the study of stress?", 'In the early part of the 20th century, Cannon was the first to identify the body’s physiological reactions to stress.']

['Teacher: Can you explain what happens to your body when you encounter a potentially dangerous situation while hiking in the mountains of Colorado on a warm and sunny spring day?', 'Imagine that you are hiking in the beautiful mountains of Colorado on a warm and sunny spring day.']

['Teacher: What physiological response do you think your body might experience when you come face to face with the black bear in the mountains of Colorado?', 'At one point during your hike, a large, frightening-looking black bear appears from behind a stand of trees and sits about 50 yards from you.']
["Teacher: How would your body's fight-or-flight response be triggered in this situation?", 'The bear notices you, sits up, and begins to lumber in your direction.']

['Teacher: What are some examples of the physiological reactions that might take place inside you when the bear starts to approach you?', 'In addition to thinking, “This is definitely not good,” a constellation of physiological reactions begins to take place inside you.']

['Teacher: What is the purpose of your pupils dilating in this situation?', 'Prompted by a deluge of epinephrine (adrenaline) and norepinephrine (noradrenaline) from your adrenal glands, your pupils begin to dilate.']

['What effect does the release of epinephrine and norepinephrine have on your heart rate and breathing in this situation?', 'Your heart starts to pound and speeds up, you begin to breathe heavily and perspire, you get butterflies in your stomach, and your muscles become tense, preparing you to take some kind of direct action.']

['What did Cannon propose about the fight-or-flight response?', 'Cannon proposed that this reaction, which he called the fight-or-flight response, occurs when a person experiences very strong emotions—especially those associated with a perceived threat (Cannon, 1932).']

['What are the two systems that are activated during the fight-or-flight response?', 'During the fight-or-flight response, the body is rapidly aroused by activation of both the sympathetic nervous system and the endocrine system (Figure 14.8).']
['Why is the fight-or-flight response important in a potentially dangerous situation?', 'This arousal helps prepare the person to either fight or flee from a perceived threat.']

['Teacher: According to Cannon, what is the function of the fight-or-flight response in maintaining homeostasis?', 'According to Cannon, the fight-or-flight response is a built-in mechanism that assists in maintaining homeostasis—an internal environment in which physiological variables such as blood pressure, respiration, digestion, and temperature are stabilized at levels optimal for survival.']

['Teacher: How did Cannon view the fight-or-flight response in terms of its adaptiveness and its role in responding to threats?', 'Thus, Cannon viewed the fight-or-flight response as adaptive because it enables people to adjust internally and externally to threats in their environment, allowing them to continue to be alive and overcome the threat.']
['Teacher: Can you briefly tell me who Hans Selye was and his significance in the stress field?', 'Another important early contributor to the stress field was Hans Selye, mentioned earlier.']

["Teacher: Can you explain how Hans Selye's expertise in the study of stress contributed to his significance in the stress field?", 'He would eventually become one of the world’s foremost experts in the study of stress (Figure 14.9).']

['What was the area of research that Hans Selye was initially engaged in during his time at McGill University?', 'As a young assistant in the biochemistry department at McGill University in the 1930s, Selye was engaged in research involving sex hormones in rats.']

['What were some of the physiological changes that Selye observed in rats when exposed to prolonged negative stimulation?', 'Although he was unable to find an answer for what he was initially researching, he incidentally discovered that when exposed to prolonged negative stimulation (stressors)—such as extreme cold, surgical injury, excessive muscular exercise, and shock—the rats showed signs of adrenal enlargement, thymus and lymph node shrinkage, and stomach ulceration.']

['What did Selye coin to describe the pattern of physiological reactions that occur during continued exposure to a stressor?', 'Selye realized that these responses were triggered by a coordinated series of physiological reactions that unfold over time during continued exposure to a stressor.']

['How did Selye refer to this pattern of physiological reactions that occur during continued exposure to a stressor?', 'These physiological reactions were nonspecific, which means that regardless of the type of stressor, the same pattern of reactions would occur.']

['What is the significance of the general adaptation syndrome that Selye discovered?', 'What Selye discovered was the general adaptation syndrome, the body’s nonspecific physiological response to stress.']

['Teacher: How many stages are there in the general adaptation syndrome?', 'The general adaptation syndrome, shown in Figure 14.10, consists of three stages: (1) alarm reaction, (2) stage of resistance, and (3) stage of exhaustion (Selye, 1936; 1976).']

['Teacher: Can you explain the concept of the alarm reaction stage in the general adaptation syndrome?', 'Alarm reaction describes the body’s immediate reaction upon facing a threatening situation or emergency, and it is roughly analogous to the fight-or-flight response described by Cannon.']

['Teacher: What does the stage of resistance in the general adaptation syndrome refer to?', 'During an alarm reaction, you are alerted to a stressor, and your body alarms you with a cascade of physiological reactions that provide you with the energy to manage the situation.']

['Teacher: Can you give an example of a situation that could trigger the alarm reaction stage in the general adaptation syndrome?', 'A person who wakes up in the middle of the night to discover her house is on fire, for example, is experiencing an alarm reaction.']

["Teacher: What is the stage that an organism enters when exposure to a stressor is prolonged according to Selye's General Adaptation Syndrome?", 'If exposure to a stressor is prolonged, the organism will enter the stage of resistance.']

["What are the characteristics of the stage of resistance in Selye's General Adaptation Syndrome?", 'During this stage, the initial shock of alarm reaction has worn off and the body has adapted to the stressor.']

["What is the purpose or function of the stage of resistance in Selye's General Adaptation Syndrome?", 'Nevertheless, the body also remains on alert and is prepared to respond as it did during the alarm reaction, although with less intensity.']

["What is the importance of the stage of resistance in Selye's General Adaptation Syndrome when dealing with a long-term stressor?", 'For example, suppose a child who went missing is still missing 72 hours later.']

["What stage of Selye's General Adaptation Syndrome is the child's body likely in after 72 hours of the child being missing?", 'Although the parents would obviously remain extremely disturbed, the magnitude of physiological reactions would likely have diminished over the 72 intervening hours due to some adaptation to this event.']

['Teacher: What happens when exposure to a stressor continues over a longer period of time according to Selye and the General Adaptation Syndrome?', 'If exposure to a stressor continues over a longer period of time, the stage of exhaustion ensues.']

['What are some consequences of the stage of exhaustion in the General Adaptation Syndrome according to Selye?', 'At this stage, the person is no longer able to adapt to the stressor: the body’s ability to resist becomes depleted as physical wear takes its toll on the body’s tissues and organs.']

['What are some potential outcomes when the stage of exhaustion is reached in the General Adaptation Syndrome according to Selye?', 'As a result, illness, disease, and other permanent damage to the body—even death—may occur.']

["Can you provide an example of how the stage of exhaustion in the General Adaptation Syndrome can affect a person's health in a specific situation?", 'If a missing child still remained missing after three months, the long-term stress associated with this situation may cause a parent to literally faint with exhaustion at some point or even to develop a serious and irreversible illness.']

["Teacher: What are the three phases of Selye's general adaptation syndrome?", 'In short, Selye’s general adaptation syndrome suggests that stressors tax the body via a three-phase process—an initial jolt, subsequent readjustment, and a later depletion of all physical resources—that ultimately lays the groundwork for serious health problems and even death.']

["What are the three phases of Selye's general adaptation syndrome and how does this model conceptualize stress?", 'It should be pointed out, however, that this model is a response-based conceptualization of stress, focusing exclusively on the body’s physical responses while largely ignoring psychological factors such as appraisal and interpretation of threats.']

["What are the main criticisms of Selye's general adaptation syndrome in relation to its conceptualization of stress?", 'Nevertheless, Selye’s model has had an enormous impact on the field of stress because it offers a general explanation for how stress can lead to physical damage and, thus, disease.']

['What are some examples of disorders that have been implicated in the development of prolonged or repeated stress, according to our textbook?', 'As we shall discuss later, prolonged or repeated stress has been implicated in development of a number of disorders such as hypertension and coronary artery disease.']

['Teacher: What are the two systems that are generally involved in the physiological mechanisms of stress?', 'The physiological mechanisms of stress are extremely complex, but they generally involve the work of two systems—the sympathetic nervous system and the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis.']

['What happens when the sympathetic nervous system is triggered in response to stress?', 'When a person first perceives something as stressful (Selye’s alarm reaction), the sympathetic nervous system triggers arousal via the release of adrenaline from the adrenal glands.']

['What is the role of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis in the physiological response to stress?', 'Release of these hormones activates the fight-or-flight responses to stress, such as accelerated heart rate and respiration.']

['What are some of the responses in the body that are activated by the HPA axis during the physiological response to stress?', 'At the same time, the HPA axis, which is primarily endocrine in nature, becomes especially active, although it works much more slowly than the sympathetic nervous system.']

['What does the release of corticotropin-releasing factor by the hypothalamus during stress lead to?', 'In response to stress, the hypothalamus (one of the limbic structures in the brain) releases corticotropin-releasing factor, a hormone that causes the pituitary gland to release adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) (Figure 14.11).']

['What is one of the important hormones that is secreted by the adrenal glands in response to the activation of the HPA axis during the physiological response to stress?', 'The ACTH then activates the adrenal glands to secrete a number of hormones into the bloodstream; an important one is cortisol, which can affect virtually every organ within the body.']

['What is the function of cortisol in the physiological response to stress?', 'Cortisol is commonly known as a stress hormone and helps provide that boost of energy when we first encounter a stressor, preparing us to run away or fight.']
['What are the potential consequences of sustained elevated levels of cortisol on the body?', 'However, sustained elevated levels of cortisol weaken the immune system.']

['Teacher: What are some favorable effects that can occur during short bursts of the stress response?', 'In short bursts, this process can have some favorable effects, such as providing extra energy, improving immune system functioning temporarily, and decreasing pain sensitivity.']

['Teacher: Why might prolonged or chronic stress have negative effects on the body?', 'However, extended release of cortisol—as would happen with prolonged or chronic stress—often comes at a high price.']
['Teacher: What are some harmful effects that high levels of cortisol can produce in the body?', 'High levels of cortisol have been shown to produce a number of harmful effects.']

['Teacher: How does chronic stress affect the immune system and mental health?', 'For example, increases in cortisol can significantly weaken our immune system (Glaser & Kiecolt-Glaser, 2005), and high levels are frequently observed among depressed individuals (Geoffroy, Hertzman, Li, & Power, 2013).']

['Teacher: How do the adrenal glands contribute to the stress response in the body?', 'In summary, a stressful event causes a variety of physiological reactions that activate the adrenal glands, which in turn release epinephrine, norepinephrine, and cortisol.']

['What are the hormones released by the adrenal glands during the stress response and how do they affect the body?', 'These hormones affect a number of bodily processes in ways that prepare the stressed person to take direct action, but also in ways that may heighten the potential for illness.']
['Teacher: What happens when stress is extreme or chronic?', 'When stress is extreme or chronic, it can have profoundly negative consequences.']

['How does stress contribute to the development of psychological disorders?', 'For example, stress often contributes to the development of certain psychological disorders, including post-traumatic stress disorder, major depressive disorder, and other serious psychiatric conditions.']

['Teacher: Can you provide some specific examples of physical illnesses and diseases that are linked to stress?', 'Additionally, we noted earlier that stress is linked to the development and progression of a variety of physical illnesses and diseases.']

['What are some specific physical illnesses and diseases that have been found to be linked to stress?', 'For example, researchers in one study found that people injured during the September 11, 2001, World Trade Center disaster or who developed post-traumatic stress symptoms afterward later suffered significantly elevated rates of heart disease (Jordan, Miller-Archie, Cone, Morabia, & Stellman, 2011).']

['What were the findings of the investigation regarding self-reported stress symptoms among aging and retired Finnish food industry workers?', 'Another investigation yielded that self-reported stress symptoms among aging and retired Finnish food industry workers were associated with morbidity 11 years later.']

['What disorders were predicted by the study regarding self-reported stress symptoms among aging and retired Finnish food industry workers?', 'This study also predicted the onset of musculoskeletal, nervous system, and endocrine and metabolic disorders (Salonen, Arola, Nygård, & Huhtala, 2008).']

['What was the relationship between work-related stress levels and the likelihood of catching the common cold according to the study on South Korean manufacturing employees?', 'Another study reported that male South Korean manufacturing employees who reported high levels of work-related stress were more likely to catch the common cold over the next several months than were those employees who reported lower work-related stress levels (Park et al., 2011).']

['What will you explore later regarding the mechanisms through which stress can produce physical illness and disease?', 'Later, you will explore the mechanisms through which stress can produce physical illness and disease.']
['Teacher: What is the initial requirement for an individual to experience stress?', 'For an individual to experience stress, they must first encounter a potential stressor.']
['Teacher: Can you provide examples of chronic stressors and acute stressors?', 'In general, stressors can be placed into one of two broad categories: chronic and acute.']

['Teacher: Good job! Can you give me examples of acute stressors as well?', 'Chronic stressors include events that persist over an extended period of time, such as caring for a parent with dementia, long-term unemployment, or imprisonment.']

['Teacher: What are some examples of acute stressors?', 'Acute stressors involve brief focal events that sometimes continue to be experienced as overwhelming well after the event has ended, such as falling on an icy sidewalk and breaking your leg (Cohen, Janicki-Deverts, & Miller, 2007).']

['Teacher: What are some potential factors that determine how individuals respond to stressors, whether they are chronic or acute?', 'Whether chronic or acute, potential stressors come in many shapes and sizes.']

['Teacher: What are some examples of major traumatic events that can be potential stressors for individuals, whether they are chronic or acute?', 'They can include major traumatic events, significant life changes, daily hassles, as well as other situations in which a person is regularly exposed to threat, challenge, or danger.']

['Teacher: Can you provide me an example of a traumatic event or situation that could be considered a stressor?', 'Some stressors involve traumatic events or situations in which a person is exposed to actual or threatened death or serious injury.']

['Teacher: What are some examples of traumatic events or situations that fall under the category of stressors?', 'Stressors in this category include exposure to military combat, threatened or actual physical assaults (e.g., physical attacks, sexual assault, robbery, childhood abuse), terrorist attacks, natural disasters (e.g., earthquakes, floods, hurricanes), and automobile accidents.']

['Teacher: Who tends to report experiencing a greater number of traumatic events: men or women, White people or non-White people, and individuals in lower SES groups or higher SES groups?', 'Men, non-White people, and individuals in lower socioeconomic status (SES) groups report experiencing a greater number of traumatic events than do women, White people, and individuals in higher SES groups (Hatch & Dohrenwend, 2007).']

['Teacher: What are some symptoms or behaviors associated with post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) in individuals who have experienced stressors of extreme magnitude?', 'Some individuals who are exposed to stressors of extreme magnitude develop post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD): a chronic stress reaction characterized by experiences and behaviors that may include intrusive and painful memories of the stressor event, jumpiness, persistent negative emotional states, detachment from others, angry outbursts, and avoidance of reminders of the event (American Psychiatric Association [APA], 2013).']

['Teacher: What is the typical intensity level of the stressors we face in comparison to the ones described above?', 'Most stressors that we encounter are not nearly as intense as the ones described above.']

['Teacher: Can you provide examples of the potential stressors that require us to make changes in our ongoing lives and require time as we adjust to those changes?', 'Many potential stressors we face involve events or situations that require us to make changes in our ongoing lives and require time as we adjust to those changes.']

['Teacher: Can you explain how the death of a close family member can be a stressor that requires significant changes in our lives and time to adjust?', 'Examples include death of a close family member, marriage, divorce, and moving (Figure 14.12).']

['Teacher: What did psychiatrists Thomas Holmes and Richard Rahe want to examine in the 1960s?', 'In the 1960s, psychiatrists Thomas Holmes and Richard Rahe wanted to examine the link between life stressors and physical illness, based on the hypothesis that life events requiring significant changes in a person’s normal life routines are stressful, whether these events are desirable or undesirable.']

['What was the purpose of developing the Social Readjustment Rating Scale (SRRS)?', 'They developed the Social Readjustment Rating Scale (SRRS), consisting of 43 life events that require varying degrees of personal readjustment (Holmes & Rahe, 1967).']

['What was the hypothesis behind developing the Social Readjustment Rating Scale (SRRS)?', 'Many life events that most people would consider pleasant (e.g., holidays, retirement, marriage) are among those listed on the SRRS; these are examples of eustress.']

["What is the relationship between experiencing a cluster of stressful events and the risk of developing physical illnesses, according to Holmes and Rahe's research?", 'Holmes and Rahe also proposed that life events can add up over time, and that experiencing a cluster of stressful events increases one’s risk of developing physical illnesses.']

['Teacher: What method did Holmes and Rahe use to determine the numerical estimates for each event in their scale?', 'In developing their scale, Holmes and Rahe asked 394 participants to provide a numerical estimate for each of the 43 items; each estimate corresponded to how much readjustment participants felt each event would require.']

['What do the mean value scores for each event in the Holmes and Rahe scale represent?', 'These estimates resulted in mean value scores for each event—often called life change units (LCUs) (Rahe, McKeen, & Arthur, 1967).']
['What is the range of numerical scores in the Holmes and Rahe scale?', 'The numerical scores ranged from 11 to 100, representing the perceived magnitude of life change each event entails.']

['What event ranked second highest on the Holmes and Rahe scale in terms of life change units (LCUs)?', 'Death of a spouse ranked highest on the scale with 100 LCUs, and divorce ranked second highest with 73 LCUs.']

['What events ranked next on the Holmes and Rahe scale in terms of life change units (LCUs)?', 'In addition, personal injury or illness, marriage, and job termination also ranked highly on the scale with 53, 50, and 47 LCUs, respectively.']

['What were the LCUs for change in residence, change in eating habits, and vacation on the Holmes and Rahe scale?', 'Conversely, change in residence (20 LCUs), change in eating habits (15 LCUs), and vacation (13 LCUs) ranked low on the scale (Table 14.1).']
['What event ranked the lowest on the Holmes and Rahe scale in terms of life change units (LCUs)?', 'Minor violations of the law ranked the lowest with 11 LCUs.']
['What did participants do to complete the scale?', 'To complete the scale, participants checked yes for events experienced within the last 12 months.']
['What is the purpose of totaling the LCUs for each checked item on the Holmes and Rahe scale?', 'LCUs for each checked item are totaled for a score quantifying the amount of life change.']

['What is the consistency of agreement on the amount of adjustment required by the various life events on the SRRS scale?', 'Agreement on the amount of adjustment required by the various life events on the SRRS is highly consistent, even cross-culturally (Holmes & Masuda, 1974).']

['Teacher: What has extensive research demonstrated in relation to accumulating a high number of life change units within a brief period of time?', 'Extensive research has demonstrated that accumulating a high number of life change units within a brief period of time (one or two years) is related to a wide range of physical illnesses (even accidents and athletic injuries) and mental health problems (Monat & Lazarus, 1991; Scully, Tosi, & Banning, 2000).']

['What were the findings of the early demonstration conducted on U.S. and Norwegian Navy personnel before their six-month voyage?', 'In an early demonstration, researchers obtained LCU scores for U.S. and Norwegian Navy personnel who were about to embark on a six-month voyage.']

['What did the later examination of medical records reveal in relation to the LCU scores and subsequent illness symptoms during the six-month voyage?', 'A later examination of medical records revealed positive (but small) correlations between LCU scores prior to the voyage and subsequent illness symptoms during the ensuing six-month journey (Rahe, 1974).']

['What are some examples of physical symptoms that people tend to experience on days when their self-reported LCU values are considerably higher than normal?', 'In addition, people tend to experience more physical symptoms, such as backache, upset stomach, diarrhea, and acne, on specific days in which self-reported LCU values are considerably higher than normal, such as the day of a family member’s wedding (Holmes & Holmes, 1970).']

['Teacher: What is the purpose of the Social Readjustment Rating Scale (SRRS)?', 'The Social Readjustment Rating Scale (SRRS) provides researchers a simple, easy-to-administer way of assessing the amount of stress in people’s lives, and it has been used in hundreds of studies (Thoits, 2010).']
['Teacher: What has the Social Readjustment Rating Scale (SRRS) been used for in hundreds of studies?', 'Despite its widespread use, the scale has been subject to criticism.']

['Teacher: What is one criticism of the Social Readjustment Rating Scale (SRRS) regarding the items included in the scale?', 'First, many of the items on the SRRS are vague; for example, death of a close friend could involve the death of a long-absent childhood friend that requires little social readjustment (Dohrenwend, 2006).']

['Teacher: What is another criticism of the Social Readjustment Rating Scale (SRRS) regarding the assumption it makes about the stressfulness of life events?', 'In addition, some have challenged its assumption that undesirable life events are no more stressful than desirable ones (Derogatis & Coons, 1993).']

['Teacher: What does the available evidence suggest about the association between undesirable life events and mental health outcomes compared to desirable events?', 'However, most of the available evidence suggests that, at least as far as mental health is concerned, undesirable or negative events are more strongly associated with poor outcomes (such as depression) than are desirable, positive events (Hatch & Dohrenwend, 2007).']

["Teacher: Why is the lack of consideration of respondents' appraisals of life events a serious criticism of the Social Readjustment Rating Scale (SRRS)?", 'Perhaps the most serious criticism is that the scale does not take into consideration respondents’ appraisals of the life events it contains.']

['What role does the appraisal of a stressor play in the conceptualization and overall experience of stress?', 'As you recall, appraisal of a stressor is a key element in the conceptualization and overall experience of stress.']

["Teacher: How does individuals' appraisal of being fired from work differ based on their perspective?", 'Being fired from work may be devastating to some but a welcome opportunity to obtain a better job for others.']

['Why is the Social Readjustment Rating Scale (SRRS) considered a useful tool in identifying potential stress-related health outcomes?', 'The SRRS remains one of the most well-known instruments in the study of stress, and it is a useful tool for identifying potential stress-related health outcomes (Scully et al., 2000).']
['Teacher: What is one key characteristic of potential stressors?', 'Potential stressors do not always involve major life events.']

['What are some examples of daily hassles mentioned in the passage?', 'Daily hassles—the minor irritations and annoyances that are part of our everyday lives (e.g., rush hour traffic, lost keys, obnoxious coworkers, inclement weather, arguments with friends or family)—can build on one another and leave us just as stressed as life change events (Figure 14.13) (Kanner, Coyne, Schaefer, & Lazarus, 1981).']

['Teacher: What have researchers demonstrated about the frequency of daily hassles in relation to physical and psychological health, compared to life change units?', 'Researchers have demonstrated that the frequency of daily hassles is actually a better predictor of both physical and psychological health than are life change units.']

['What were the findings of the well-known study regarding the association between the frequency of daily hassles and physical health problems compared to life change events?', 'In a well-known study of San Francisco residents, the frequency of daily hassles was found to be more strongly associated with physical health problems than were life change events (DeLongis, Coyne, Dakof, Folkman, & Lazarus, 1982).']

['What are some examples of daily minor hassles that can often lead to negative and distressed mood states?', 'In addition, daily minor hassles, especially interpersonal conflicts, often lead to negative and distressed mood states (Bolger, DeLongis, Kessler, & Schilling, 1989).']
['What are some examples of modern and evolving sources of stress that may result in cyber hassles?', 'Cyber hassles that occur on social media may represent a modern and evolving source of stress.']

['What were the potential consequences of social media stress on adolescents, as found in a particular investigation?', 'In one investigation, social media stress was tied to loss of sleep in adolescents, presumably because ruminating about social media caused a physiological stress response that increased arousal (van der Schuur, Baumgartner, & Sumter, 2018).']
['What are some potential implications of daily hassles on our overall well-being?', 'Clearly, daily hassles can add up and take a toll on us both emotionally and physically.']
['What kind of hassles are specifically mentioned in the passage?', 'OCCUPATION-RELATED']
['What are some stressors that can be considered as occupation-related hassles?', 'Stressors.']

['Teacher: What are some examples of stressors that can contribute to hassles?', 'Stressors can include situations in which one is frequently exposed to challenging and unpleasant events, such as difficult, demanding, or unsafe working conditions.']

['Teacher: According to the passage, how can certain jobs and occupations be described in terms of stress levels?', 'Although most jobs and occupations can at times be demanding, some are clearly more stressful than others (Figure 14.14).']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a job that is considered more stressful than being a florist according to the passage?', 'For example, most people would likely agree that a firefighter’s work is inherently more stressful than that of a florist.']

['According to the passage, what are some examples of jobs with various unpleasant elements that are considered more demanding and stressful?', 'Equally likely, most would agree that jobs containing various unpleasant elements, such as those requiring exposure to loud noise (heavy equipment operator), constant harassment and threats of physical violence (prison guard), perpetual frustration (bus driver in a major city), or those mandating that an employee work alternating day and night shifts (hotel desk clerk), are much more demanding—and thus, more stressful—than those that do not contain such elements.']

['According to Table 14.2, what are some specific stressors associated with the occupation of a heavy equipment operator?', 'Table 14.2 lists several occupations and some of the specific stressors associated with those occupations (Sulsky & Smith, 2005).']

['Teacher: What are some common factors that seem to be shared by occupations that experience specific stressors?', 'Although the specific stressors for these occupations are diverse, they seem to share some common denominators such as heavy workload and uncertainty about and lack of control over certain aspects of a job.']

['Teacher: How does chronic occupational stress contribute to job strain?', 'Chronic occupational stress contributes to job strain, a work situation that combines excessive job demands and workload with little discretion in decision making or job control (Karasek & Theorell, 1990).']

["Teacher: How does chronic occupational stress impact an individual's ability to make decisions in their job?", 'Clearly, many occupations other than the ones listed in Table 14.2 involve at least a moderate amount of job strain in that they often involve heavy workloads and little job control (e.g., inability to decide when to take breaks).']

['Teacher: What are some examples of occupations that may experience chronic occupational stress and job strain?', 'Such jobs are often low-status and include those of factory workers, postal clerks, supermarket cashiers, taxi drivers, and short-order cooks.']

["Teacher: How does job strain affect an individual's physical and mental health?", 'Job strain can have adverse consequences on both physical and mental health; it has been shown to be associated with increased risk of hypertension (Schnall & Landsbergis, 1994), heart attacks (Theorell et al., 1998), recurrence of heart disease after a first heart attack (Aboa-Éboulé et al., 2007), significant weight loss or gain (Kivimäki et al., 2006), and major depressive disorder (Stansfeld, Shipley, Head, & Fuhrer, 2012).']

["Teacher: How does chronic occupational stress and job strain impact an individual's risk of developing heart disease?", 'A longitudinal study of over 10,000 British civil servants reported that workers under 50 years old who earlier had reported high job strain were 68% more likely to later develop heart disease than were those workers under 50 years old who reported little job strain (Chandola et al., 2008).']

['Teacher: What is job burnout?', 'Some people who are exposed to chronically stressful work conditions can experience job burnout, which is a general sense of emotional exhaustion and cynicism in relation to one’s job (Maslach & Jackson, 1981).']

['Teacher: Can you give some examples of human service jobs that are prone to experiencing job burnout?', 'Job burnout occurs frequently among those in human service jobs (e.g., social workers, teachers, therapists, and police officers).']
['What are the three dimensions of job burnout?', 'Job burnout consists of three dimensions.']

['Teacher: What is the second dimension of job burnout?', 'The first dimension is exhaustion—a sense that one’s emotional resources are drained or that one is at the end of their rope and has nothing more to give at a psychological level.']

['What is the third dimension of job burnout?', 'Second, job burnout is characterized by depersonalization: a sense of emotional detachment between the worker and the recipients of their services, often resulting in callous, cynical, or indifferent attitudes toward these individuals.']

['What are some examples of jobs that are prone to experiencing the third dimension of job burnout?', 'Third, job burnout is characterized by diminished personal accomplishment, which is the tendency to evaluate one’s work negatively by, for example, experiencing dissatisfaction with one’s job-related accomplishments or feeling as though one has categorically failed to influence others’ lives through one’s work.']

['Teacher: What are some characteristics of workers who are most commonly observed to experience job burnout?', 'Job strain appears to be one of the greatest risk factors leading to job burnout, which is most commonly observed in workers who are older (ages 55–64), unmarried, and whose jobs involve manual labor.']

['What other factors, aside from job strain, are associated with job burnout according to Ahola et al. in 2006?', 'Heavy alcohol consumption, physical inactivity, being overweight, and having a physical or lifetime mental disorder are also associated with job burnout (Ahola, et al., 2006).']

['What are some factors that are associated with job burnout in addition to heavy alcohol consumption, physical inactivity, being overweight, and having a physical or lifetime mental disorder?', 'In addition, depression often co-occurs with job burnout.']

['What did a large-scale study of over 3,000 Finnish employees report about the co-occurrence of depression and job burnout?', 'One large-scale study of over 3,000 Finnish employees reported that half of the participants with severe job burnout had some form of depressive disorder (Ahola et al., 2005).']

['What are some factors that can precipitate job burnout, according to Tatris et al. in 2001?', 'Job burnout is often precipitated by feelings of having invested considerable energy, effort, and time into one’s work while receiving little in return (e.g., little respect or support from others or low pay) (Tatris, Peeters, Le Blanc, Schreurs, & Schaufeli, 2001).']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example that highlights the concept of hassles in the context of the nursing profession?', 'As an illustration, consider Tyre, a nursing assistant who worked in a nursing home.']
["Teacher: What aspects of Tyre's job in the nursing home can be considered as hassles?", 'Tyre worked long hours for little pay in a difficult facility.']

["What impact did Tyre's supervisor have on his overall work experience in the nursing home?", "Tyre's supervisor was domineering, unpleasant, and unsupportive, as well as disrespectful of Tyre's personal time, frequently informing them at the last minute they must work several additional hours after their shift ended or report to work on weekends."]
["What effect did the lack of autonomy have on Tyre's overall work experience in the nursing home?", 'Tyre had very little autonomy at work.']

["Did the lack of autonomy contribute to Tyre's feeling of being constantly overwhelmed and stressed at work?", 'They had little input in day-to-day duties and how to perform them, and was not permitted to take breaks unless explicitly told by their supervisor.']

["Was Tyre's lack of recognition and appreciation a significant factor in their overall experience?", 'Tyre did not feel as though their hard work was appreciated, either by supervisory staff or by the residents of the home.']

["What impact did Tyre's feelings of being unappreciated have on their overall work experience in the nursing home?", 'Tyre was very unhappy over the low pay, and felt that many of the residents treated them disrespectfully.']
['what have researchers discovered about the long-term effects of daily hassles?', 'After several years,']
['Teacher: What did Tyre begin to feel towards their job after several years?', 'Tyre began to hate their job.']

["What was Tyre's attitude towards the residents after developing a hatred for their job?", 'Tyre dreaded going to work in the morning, and gradually developed a callous, hostile attitude toward many of the residents.']
["What impact did Tyre's negative attitude towards the residents have on their ability to help them?", 'Eventually, they began to feel they could no longer help the nursing home residents.']
["What was the final outcome of Tyre's negative attitude and increased absenteeism from work?", 'Tyre’s absenteeism from work increased, and one day they decided that they had had enough and quit.']
['What career did Tyre pursue after leaving their job in nursing?', 'Tyre now has a job in sales, vowing never to work in nursing again.']

['Teacher: How can our close relationships with friends and family contribute to stress?', 'Finally, our close relationships with friends and family—particularly the negative aspects of these relationships—can be a potent source of stress.']

['What are some examples of negative aspects in close relationships that can contribute to stress?', 'Negative aspects of close relationships can include conflicts such as disagreements or arguments, lack of emotional support or confiding, and lack of reciprocity.']
['Can you explain how conflicts in close relationships can contribute to stress?', 'All of these can be overwhelming, threatening to the relationship, and thus stressful.']
['What role does lack of emotional support or confiding play in contributing to stress in close relationships?', 'Such stressors can take a toll both emotionally and physically.']

['What does the longitudinal investigation of British civil servants suggest about the impact of negative interactions in close relationships on heart problems?', 'A longitudinal investigation of over 9,000 British civil servants found that those who at one point had reported the highest levels of negative interactions in their closest relationship were 34% more likely to experience serious heart problems (fatal or nonfatal heart attacks) over a 13–15 year period, compared to those who experienced the lowest levels of negative interaction (De Vogli, Chandola & Marmot, 2007).']
['Teacher: What topic will we be exploring in this section?', 'In this section, we will discuss stress and illness.']
['"there is a clear connection between chronic stress and the development of various illnesses."', 'As stress researcher Robert Sapolsky (1998) describes,']

['Teacher: What is the term used to describe the coordinated physiological reactions that occur during the stress response?', 'The stress response, as noted earlier, consists of a coordinated but complex system of physiological reactions that are called upon as needed.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a potentially dangerous or threatening situation that would trigger the stress response?', 'These reactions are beneficial at times because they prepare us to deal with potentially dangerous or threatening situations (for example, recall our old friend, the fearsome bear on the trail).']
['Teacher: Why is ongoing stress potentially detrimental to our health?', 'However, health is affected when physiological reactions are sustained, as can happen in response to ongoing stress.']

['Teacher: What are the potential consequences if the reactions that make up the stress response are chronic or frequently exceed normal ranges?', 'If the reactions that compose the stress response are chronic or if they frequently exceed normal ranges, they can lead to cumulative wear and tear on the body, in much the same way that running your air conditioner on full blast all summer will eventually cause wear and tear on it.']

['What are some potential consequences of chronic or frequently exceeding normal ranges for the reactions that make up the stress response?', 'For example, the high blood pressure that a person under considerable job strain experiences might eventually take a toll on their heart and set the stage for a heart attack or heart failure.']

["What is an example of how chronic stress or exceeding normal ranges for the reactions in the stress response can affect a person's immune system functioning?", 'Also, someone exposed to high levels of the stress hormone cortisol might become vulnerable to infection or disease because of weakened immune system functioning (McEwen, 1998).']

['Teacher: How would you define psychophysiological disorders?', 'Physical disorders or diseases whose symptoms are brought about or worsened by stress and emotional factors are called psychophysiological disorders.']

['Teacher: Can you give me an example of how stress and emotional factors can worsen the symptoms of psychophysiological disorders?', 'The physical symptoms of psychophysiological disorders are real and they can be produced or exacerbated by psychological factors (hence the psycho and physiological in psychophysiological).']

['Teacher: What are some examples of psychophysiological disorders that are commonly encountered according to Table 14.3 in the textbook?', 'A list of frequently encountered psychophysiological disorders is provided in Table 14.3.']

["Teacher: What was the purpose of Friedman and Booth-Kewley's review of 101 studies on the link between personality and illness?", 'Friedman and Booth-Kewley (1987) statistically reviewed 101 studies to examine the link between personality and illness.']

['Teacher: What were some of the personality characteristics that Friedman and Booth-Kewley proposed as being disease-prone?', 'They proposed the existence of disease-prone personality characteristics, including depression, anger/hostility, and anxiety.']

["Teacher: Can you provide an example of a study that supports Friedman and Booth-Kewley's findings on the link between depression and illness?", 'Indeed, a study of over 61,000 Norwegians identified depression as a risk factor for all major disease-related causes of death (Mykletun et al., 2007).']

['Teacher: Can you explain how neuroticism, a personality trait, is related to chronic health problems and mortality?', 'In addition, neuroticism—a personality trait that reflects how anxious, moody, and sad one is—has been identified as a risk factor for chronic health problems and mortality (Ploubidis & Grundy, 2009).']

['Teacher: What are the two kinds of psychophysiological disorders discussed in the passage that we will be focusing on?', 'Below, we discuss two kinds of psychophysiological disorders about which a great deal is known: cardiovascular disorders and asthma.']

['What are the major pathways through which stress and emotional factors can lead to illness and disease, as discussed in the passage?', 'First, however, it is necessary to turn our attention to a discussion of the immune system—one of the major pathways through which stress and emotional factors can lead to illness and disease.']
["Teacher: How would you describe the immune system's role in the body?", 'In a sense, the immune system is the body’s surveillance system.']

['Teacher: Can you provide some examples of the structures, cells, and mechanisms that make up the immune system and contribute to protecting the body?', 'It consists of a variety of structures, cells, and mechanisms that serve to protect the body from invading microorganisms that can harm or damage the body’s tissues and organs.']

['Teacher: How does the immune system keep us healthy and disease-free?', 'When the immune system is working as it should, it keeps us healthy and disease free by eliminating harmful bacteria, viruses, and other foreign substances that have entered the body (Everly & Lating, 2002).']
['Teacher: What is it called when the immune system does not function properly?', 'Sometimes, the immune system will function erroneously.']

["Why does the immune system sometimes mistakenly attack the body's own healthy cells?", 'For example, sometimes it can go awry by mistaking your body’s own healthy cells for invaders and repeatedly attacking them.']

["Teacher: What is the term used to describe the condition when the immune system mistakenly attacks the body's own healthy cells?", 'When this happens, the person is said to have an autoimmune disease, which can affect almost any part of the body.']
['What are some examples of autoimmune diseases that can affect different parts of the body?', 'How an autoimmune disease affects a person depends on what part of the body is targeted.']

['What are some symptoms and effects of rheumatoid arthritis, an autoimmune disease that affects the joints?', 'For instance, rheumatoid arthritis, an autoimmune disease that affects the joints, results in joint pain, stiffness, and loss of function.']

['What are some symptoms and effects of systemic lupus erythematosus, an autoimmune disease that affects the skin?', 'Systemic lupus erythematosus, an autoimmune disease that affects the skin, can result in rashes and swelling of the skin.']

["What are some symptoms and effects of Grave's disease, an autoimmune disease that affects the thyroid gland?", 'Grave’s disease, an autoimmune disease that affects the thyroid gland, can result in fatigue, weight gain, and muscle aches (National Institute of Arthritis and Musculoskeletal and Skin Diseases [NIAMS], 2012).']
['Teacher: Can you explain what happens when the immune system "breaks down" and is unable to do its job?', 'In addition, the immune system may sometimes break down and be unable to do its job.']

['What is the term used to describe the situation when the immune system is unable to do its job?', 'This situation is referred to as immunosuppression, the decreased effectiveness of the immune system.']
['What are some consequences of immunosuppression?', 'When people experience immunosuppression, they become susceptible to any number of infections, illness, and diseases.']

['What is one example of a disease that can occur as a consequence of immunosuppression?', 'For example, acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) is a serious and lethal disease that is caused by human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), which greatly weakens the immune system by infecting and destroying antibody-producing cells, thus rendering an untreated person vulnerable to any of a number of opportunistic infections (Powell, 1996).']

['Teacher: What has captivated researchers for over three decades regarding stress and negative emotional states?', 'The question of whether stress and negative emotional states can influence immune function has captivated researchers for over three decades, and discoveries made over that time have dramatically changed the face of health psychology (Kiecolt-Glaser, 2009).']

["Teacher: How has the field of health psychology been impacted by the discoveries made regarding stress and negative emotional states' influence on immune function?", 'Psychoneuroimmunology is the field that studies how psychological factors such as stress influence the immune system and immune functioning.']

['Teacher: What is the definition of psychoneuroimmunology and when was the term first coined?', 'The term psychoneuroimmunology was first coined in 1981, when it appeared as the title of a book that reviewed available evidence for associations between the brain, endocrine system, and immune system (Zacharie, 2009).']

['Teacher: How has the connection between the central nervous system and the immune system contributed to the development of the field of psychoneuroimmunology?', 'To a large extent, this field evolved from the discovery that there is a connection between the central nervous system and the immune system.']

['Teacher: What is one of the most compelling pieces of evidence for a connection between the brain and the immune system, as mentioned in the passage?', 'Some of the most compelling evidence for a connection between the brain and the immune system comes from studies in which researchers demonstrated that immune responses in animals could be classically conditioned (Everly & Lating, 2002).']

['What is one example of a study mentioned in the passage that demonstrates a connection between the brain and the immune system?', 'For example, Ader and Cohen (1975) paired flavored water (the conditioned stimulus) with the presentation of an immunosuppressive drug (the unconditioned stimulus), causing sickness (an unconditioned response).']

['What was the result of pairing flavored water with an immunosuppressive drug in the study mentioned in the passage?', 'Not surprisingly, rats exposed to this pairing developed a conditioned aversion to the flavored water.']

['What does the study mentioned in the passage indicate about the connection between the brain and the immune system?', 'However, the taste of the water itself later produced immunosuppression (a conditioned response), indicating that the immune system itself had been conditioned.']

['How have subsequent studies further demonstrated the connection between the brain and the immune system, as mentioned in the passage?', 'Many subsequent studies over the years have further demonstrated that immune responses can be classically conditioned in both animals and humans (Ader & Cohen, 2001).']

['What do subsequent studies suggest about the ability of psychological factors to affect immune responses?', 'Thus, if classical conditioning can alter immunity, other psychological factors should be capable of altering it as well.']

['Teacher: What are some examples of stressors that have been studied in relation to their effects on the immune system?', 'Hundreds of studies involving tens of thousands of participants have tested many kinds of brief and chronic stressors and their effects on the immune system (e.g., public speaking, medical school examinations, unemployment, marital discord, divorce, death of spouse, burnout and job strain, caring for a relative with Alzheimer’s disease, and exposure to the harsh climate of Antarctica).']

['What are some examples of stressors that have been shown to be associated with poor or weakened immune functioning?', 'It has been repeatedly demonstrated that many kinds of stressors are associated with poor or weakened immune functioning (Glaser & Kiecolt-Glaser, 2005; Kiecolt-Glaser, McGuire, Robles, & Glaser, 2002; Segerstrom & Miller, 2004).']

['Teacher: What is important to remember when evaluating these findings about stressors and immune function?', 'When evaluating these findings, it is important to remember that there is a tangible physiological connection between the brain and the immune system.']

['Teacher: Can you explain how the sympathetic nervous system is involved in the regulation of immune organs?', 'For example, the sympathetic nervous system innervates immune organs such as the thymus, bone marrow, spleen, and even lymph nodes (Maier, Watkins, & Fleshner, 1994).']

['Teacher: How does the activation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis during stress impact immune function?', 'Also, we noted earlier that stress hormones released during hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis activation can adversely impact immune function.']

['Teacher: What is the negative impact of stress hormones on immune function?', 'One way they do this is by inhibiting the production of lymphocytes, white blood cells that circulate in the body’s fluids that are important in the immune response (Everly & Lating, 2002).']

['Teacher: Can you explain how studies involving volunteers exposed to viruses demonstrate the link between stress and impaired immune function?', 'Some of the more dramatic examples demonstrating the link between stress and impaired immune function involve studies in which volunteers were exposed to viruses.']

['Teacher: What is the rationale behind conducting studies that involve exposing volunteers to viruses to investigate the link between stress and impaired immune function?', 'The rationale behind this research is that because stress weakens the immune system, people with high stress levels should be more likely to develop an illness compared to those under little stress.']

['Why would researchers use interviews to collect data on recent stressful experiences in a study investigating the link between stress and impaired immune function?', 'In one memorable experiment using this method, researchers interviewed 276 healthy volunteers about recent stressful experiences (Cohen et al., 1998).']

['What was the purpose of giving nasal drops containing the cold virus to the participants in the study?', 'Following the interview, these participants were given nasal drops containing the cold virus (in case you are wondering why anybody would ever want to participate in a study in which they are subjected to such treatment, the participants were paid $800 for their trouble).']

['Why did participants who reported experiencing chronic stressors for more than one month have a higher likelihood of developing colds compared to participants who reported no chronic stressors in the study?', 'When examined later, participants who reported experiencing chronic stressors for more than one month—especially enduring difficulties involving work or relationships—were considerably more likely to have developed colds than were participants who reported no chronic stressors (Figure 14.15).']
['Teacher: What was the purpose of giving older volunteers an influenza virus vaccination?', 'In another study, older volunteers were given an influenza virus vaccination.']

['Teacher: What was the impact of chronic stress on the antibody response of older volunteers following the influenza virus vaccination?', 'Compared to controls, those who were caring for a spouse with Alzheimer’s disease (and thus were under chronic stress) showed poorer antibody response following the vaccination (Kiecolt-Glaser, Glaser, Gravenstein, Malarkey, & Sheridan, 1996).']

["Teacher: How do stressors impact the immune system's ability to heal wounds according to Glaser and Kiecolt-Glaser's research in 2005?", 'Other studies have demonstrated that stress slows down wound healing by impairing immune responses important to wound repair (Glaser & Kiecolt-Glaser, 2005).']

['Teacher: What was the observed effect of stress on wound healing in the study where skin blisters were induced on the forearm?', 'In one study, for example, skin blisters were induced on the forearm.']

['What was the relationship between stress levels and immune protein production in subjects with induced skin blisters in the study by Glaser et al. (1999)?', 'Subjects who reported higher levels of stress produced lower levels of immune proteins necessary for wound healing (Glaser et al., 1999).']

['What is the analogy used to describe the relationship between stress and the immune system in the passage?', 'Stress, then, is not so much the sword that kills the knight, so to speak; rather, it’s the sword that breaks the knight’s shield, and your immune system is that shield.']
['Teacher: What are the two main components of the cardiovascular system?', 'The cardiovascular system is composed of the heart and blood circulation system.']

['What is the significance of studying cardiovascular disorders in relation to psychophysiological disorders?', 'For many years, disorders that involve the cardiovascular system—known as cardiovascular disorders—have been a major focal point in the study of psychophysiological disorders because of the cardiovascular system’s centrality in the stress response (Everly & Lating, 2002).']
['What are some examples of cardiovascular disorders that are studied in relation to psychophysiological disorders?', 'Heart disease is one such condition.']

['What are the current statistics on the prevalence of heart disease and its impact on mortality rates?', 'Each year, heart disease causes approximately one in three deaths in the United States, and it is the leading cause of death in the developed world (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention [CDC], 2011; Shapiro, 2005).']

['Teacher: Can you tell me one of the common symptoms experienced by individuals with heart disease?', 'The symptoms of heart disease vary somewhat depending on the specific kind of heart disease one has, but they generally involve angina—chest pains or discomfort that occur when the heart does not receive enough blood (Office on Women’s Health, 2009).']

['Teacher: How does angina, one of the common symptoms of heart disease, manifest itself in individuals?', 'The pain often feels like the chest is being pressed or squeezed; burning sensations in the chest and shortness of breath are also commonly reported.']

['What are some of the other areas where the pain and discomfort from angina can spread to?', 'Such pain and discomfort can spread to the arms, neck, jaws, stomach (as nausea), and back (American Heart Association [AHA], 2012a) (Figure 14.17).']
['Teacher: What is a major risk factor for heart disease that is characterized by high blood pressure?', 'A major risk factor for heart disease is hypertension, which is high blood pressure.']
['Teacher: How does hypertension contribute to an increased risk of heart disease?', 'Hypertension forces a person’s heart to pump harder, thus putting more physical strain on the heart.']

['What are some potential consequences of untreated hypertension?', 'If left unchecked, hypertension can lead to a heart attack, stroke, or heart failure; it can also lead to kidney failure and blindness.']

['Teacher: Why is hypertension sometimes referred to as the "silent killer"?', 'Hypertension is a serious cardiovascular disorder, and it is sometimes called the silent killer because it has no symptoms—one who has high blood pressure may not even be aware of it (AHA, 2012b).']
['Teacher: Can you provide me with some examples of the identified risk factors for cardiovascular disorders?', 'Many risk factors contributing to cardiovascular disorders have been identified.']

['Teacher: Can you elaborate on the social determinants that contribute to cardiovascular disorders?', 'These risk factors include social determinants such as aging, income, education, and employment status, as well as behavioral risk factors that include unhealthy diet, tobacco use, physical inactivity, and excessive alcohol consumption; obesity and diabetes are additional risk factors (World Health Organization [WHO], 2013).']

['Teacher: What has there been much greater recognition and awareness of in cardiovascular health over the past few decades?', 'Over the past few decades, there has been much greater recognition and awareness of the importance of stress and other psychological factors in cardiovascular health (Nusair, Al-dadah, & Kumar, 2012).']

['Teacher: What are some examples of stressors that have been linked to cardiovascular problems?', 'Indeed, exposure to stressors of many kinds has also been linked to cardiovascular problems; in the case of hypertension, some of these stressors include job strain (Trudel, Brisson, & Milot, 2010), natural disasters (Saito, Kim, Maekawa, Ikeda, & Yokoyama, 1997), marital conflict (Nealey-Moore, Smith, Uchino, Hawkins, & Olson-Cerny, 2007), and exposure to high traffic noise levels at one’s home (de Kluizenaar, Gansevoort, Miedema, & de Jong, 2007).']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how cardiovascular problems have been linked to perceived discrimination?', 'Perceived discrimination appears to be associated with hypertension among African Americans (Sims et al., 2012).']

['Teacher: How have laboratory-based stress tasks been shown to affect blood pressure?', 'In addition, laboratory-based stress tasks, such as performing mental arithmetic under time pressure, immersing one’s hand into ice water (known as the cold pressor test), mirror tracing, and public speaking have all been shown to elevate blood pressure (Phillips, 2011).']
['Teacher: How can research ideas and theories sometimes emerge?', 'Sometimes research ideas and theories emerge from seemingly trivial observations.']

['Teacher: What realization did cardiologist Meyer Friedman have while examining his waiting room furniture in the 1950s?', 'In the 1950s, cardiologist Meyer Friedman was looking over his waiting room furniture, which consisted of upholstered chairs with armrests.']
['Teacher: Why did cardiologist Meyer Friedman decide to have the chairs in his waiting room reupholstered?', 'Friedman decided to have these chairs reupholstered.']
