["Why were the front edges of the cushions and the front tips of the armrests of the chairs in Friedman's waiting room worn down in a unique manner?", 'When the man doing the reupholstering came to the office to do the work, he commented on how the chairs were worn in a unique manner—the front edges of the cushions were worn down, as were the front tips of the arm rests.']

["What hypothesis did Friedman and Rosenman develop based on the unique wear on the chairs in Friedman's waiting room?", 'It seemed like the cardiology patients were tapping or squeezing the front of the armrests, as well as literally sitting on the edge of their seats (Friedman & Rosenman, 1974).']

['Teacher: What did Friedman and his colleague, Ray Rosenman, come to understand about people who are prone to heart disease in relation to their thoughts, feelings, and actions?', 'After researching this matter, Friedman and his colleague, Ray Rosenman, came to understand that people who are prone to heart disease tend to think, feel, and act differently than those who are not.']

["What are some common characteristics of individuals who are prone to heart disease according to Friedman and Rosenman's research?", 'These individuals tend to be intensively driven workaholics who are preoccupied with deadlines and always seem to be in a rush.']

["What are the characteristics of people who exhibit Type B behavior pattern according to Friedman and Rosenman's research?", 'According to Friedman and Rosenman, these individuals exhibit Type A behavior pattern; those who are more relaxed and laid-back were characterized as Type B (Figure 14.18).']

['What did Friedman and Rosenman discover about the frequency of heart disease among Type A and Type B individuals in their study?', 'In a sample of Type As and Type Bs, Friedman and Rosenman were startled to discover that heart disease was over seven times more frequent among the Type As than the Type Bs (Friedman & Rosenman, 1959).']

['Teacher: What are the major components of the Type A pattern according to Friedman and Rosenman in 1974?', 'The major components of the Type A pattern include an aggressive and chronic struggle to achieve more and more in less and less time (Friedman & Rosenman, 1974).']

['What specific characteristics are associated with the Type A pattern according to Friedman and Rosenman in 1974?', 'Specific characteristics of the Type A pattern include an excessive competitive drive, chronic sense of time urgency, impatience, and hostility toward others (particularly those who get in the person’s way).']
['Teacher: Can you describe some characteristics or behaviors of Jeffrey that align with the Type A behavior pattern?', 'An example of a person who exhibits Type A behavior pattern is Jeffrey.']
["Teacher: What are some specific examples of Jeffrey's intense and driven behavior, even in his childhood?", 'Even as a child, Jeffrey was intense and driven.']

["Teacher: How did Jeffrey's intense and driven behavior manifest itself in his academic achievements and extracurricular activities?", 'He excelled at school, was captain of the swim team, and graduated with honors from an Ivy League college.']

["Teacher: How does Jeffrey's inability to relax and constant need to work impact his personal life and relationships?", 'Jeffrey never seems able to relax; he is always working on something, even on the weekends.']

["Teacher: How does Jeffrey's constant need to work and feeling of not having enough time impact his overall stress levels and well-being?", 'However, Jeffrey always seems to feel as though there are not enough hours in the day to accomplish all he feels he should.']

["What are some specific ways in which Jeffrey's constant need to work affects his work-life balance and personal time?", 'He volunteers to take on extra tasks at work and often brings his work home with him; he often goes to bed frustrated late at night because he feels that he has not done enough.']

["Can you explain how Jeffrey's quick temper and irritability towards coworkers who work slowly or don't meet his standards align with the Type A behavior pattern?", 'Jeffrey is quick tempered with his coworkers; he often becomes noticeably agitated when dealing with those coworkers he feels work too slowly or whose work does not meet his standards.']

["What is one specific example of how Jeffrey's quick temper and irritability towards interruptions align with the Type A behavior pattern?", 'He typically reacts with hostility when interrupted at work.']
["How does Jeffrey's lack of time spent with his family impact his marriage and relationships?", 'He has experienced problems in his marriage over his lack of time spent with family.']

["What impact does Jeffrey's impatience and aggressiveness towards other drivers have on his overall stress levels and well-being?", 'When caught in traffic during his commute to and from work, Jeffrey incessantly pounds on his horn and swears loudly at other drivers.']
["How does Jeffrey's Type A behavior pattern contribute to his increased risk of health issues such as heart attacks?", 'When Jeffrey was 52, he suffered his first heart attack.']

['Teacher: According to the passage, what did a majority of practicing cardiologists believe about Type A behavior pattern by the 1970s?', 'By the 1970s, a majority of practicing cardiologists believed that Type A behavior pattern was a significant risk factor for heart disease (Friedman, 1977).']

['What evidence did early longitudinal investigations provide regarding the link between Type A behavior pattern and the development of heart disease?', 'Indeed, a number of early longitudinal investigations demonstrated a link between Type A behavior pattern and later development of heart disease (Rosenman et al., 1975; Haynes, Feinleib, & Kannel, 1980).']

['Teacher: Can you provide any information on the results of the subsequent research that investigated the association between Type A and heart disease?', 'Subsequent research examining the association between Type A and heart disease, however, failed to replicate these earlier findings (Glassman, 2007; Myrtek, 2001).']

['What were the results of the subsequent research on the association between Type A and heart disease?', 'Because Type A theory did not pan out as well as they had hoped, researchers shifted their attention toward determining if any of the specific elements of Type A predict heart disease.']

['Teacher: What does extensive research suggest about the anger/hostility dimension of the Type A behavior pattern in relation to heart disease development?', 'Extensive research clearly suggests that the anger/hostility dimension of Type A behavior pattern may be one of the most important factors in the development of heart disease.']

['What was found regarding the relationship between suppressed hostility and the risk of heart disease in the Haynes et al. study mentioned?', 'This relationship was initially described in the Haynes et al. (1980) study mentioned above: Suppressed hostility was found to substantially elevate the risk of heart disease for both men and women.']

['Teacher: What was the purpose of the investigation that followed over 1,000 male medical students from 32 to 48 years?', 'Also, one investigation followed over 1,000 male medical students from 32 to 48 years.']

['Teacher: What were the findings of the investigation regarding the relationship between anger response and the risk of heart disease in the male medical students?', 'At the beginning of the study, these men completed a questionnaire assessing how they react to pressure; some indicated that they respond with high levels of anger, whereas others indicated that they respond with less anger.']

['What were the long-term health outcomes for male medical students who indicated high levels of anger in response to pressure?', 'Decades later, researchers found that those who earlier had indicated the highest levels of anger were over 6 times more likely than those who indicated less anger to have had a heart attack by age 55, and they were 3.5 times more likely to have experienced heart disease by the same age (Chang, Ford, Meoni, Wang, & Klag, 2002).']

['What conclusion can be drawn from the long-term health outcomes of male medical students who indicated high levels of anger in response to pressure?', 'From a health standpoint, it clearly does not pay to be an angry person.']

['Teacher: What did Chida and Steptoe conclude after reviewing and statistically summarizing 35 studies from 1983 to 2006 regarding anger and hostility?', 'After reviewing and statistically summarizing 35 studies from 1983 to 2006, Chida and Steptoe (2009) concluded that the bulk of the evidence suggests that anger and hostility constitute serious long-term risk factors for adverse cardiovascular outcomes among both healthy individuals and those already suffering from heart disease.']

['What are some potential reasons why angry and hostile moods might contribute to cardiovascular diseases?', 'One reason angry and hostile moods might contribute to cardiovascular diseases is that such moods can create social strain, mainly in the form of antagonistic social encounters with others.']

['What is the potential physiological mechanism through which anger and hostility contribute to cardiovascular diseases?', 'This strain could then lay the foundation for disease-promoting cardiovascular responses among hostile individuals (Vella, Kamarck, Flory, & Manuck, 2012).']
['What does the transactional model suggest about the relationship between hostility and social strain?', 'In this transactional model, hostility and social strain form a cycle (Figure 14.19).']

["Teacher: How would you describe Kaitlin's disposition and attitude towards others?", 'For example, suppose Kaitlin has a hostile disposition; she has a cynical, distrustful attitude toward others and often thinks that other people are out to get her.']

["What are some characteristics of Kaitlin's attitude towards others based on the passage?", 'She is very defensive around people, even those she has known for years, and she is always looking for signs that others are either disrespecting or belittling her.']

["What is an example of Kaitlin's defensive behavior towards others mentioned in the passage?", 'In the shower each morning before work, she often mentally rehearses what she would say to someone who said or did something that angered her, such as making a political statement that was counter to her own ideology.']

["What does Kaitlin's attitude towards others reveal about her mindset?", 'As Kaitlin goes through these mental rehearsals, she often grins and thinks about the retaliation on anyone who will irk her that day.']

['Teacher: How would you describe her behavior in social interactions?', 'Socially, she is confrontational and tends to use a harsh tone with people, which often leads to very disagreeable and sometimes argumentative social interactions.']

["Teacher: How does Kaitlin's behavior in social interactions affect her relationships with others?", 'As you might imagine, Kaitlin is not especially popular with others, including coworkers, neighbors, and even members of her own family.']

["Teacher: How does Kaitlin's confrontational behavior and harsh tone impact the people around her?", 'They either avoid her at all costs or snap back at her, which causes Kaitlin to become even more cynical and distrustful of others, making her disposition even more hostile.']

["Teacher: How does Kaitlin's hostility and anger potentially contribute to the development of cardiovascular problems?", 'Kaitlin’s hostility—through her own doing—has created an antagonistic environment that cyclically causes her to become even more hostile and angry, thereby potentially setting the stage for cardiovascular problems.']

['Teacher: What are some other negative emotional states that have been associated with heart disease, besides anger and hostility?', 'In addition to anger and hostility, a number of other negative emotional states have been linked with heart disease, including negative affectivity and depression (Suls & Bunde, 2005).']

['What are some examples of negative affectivity that have been associated with heart disease?', 'Negative affectivity is a tendency to experience distressed emotional states involving anger, contempt, disgust, guilt, fear, and nervousness (Watson, Clark, & Tellegen, 1988).']
['What is the relationship between negative affectivity and the development of hypertension and heart disease?', 'It has been linked with the development of both hypertension and heart disease.']

['What were the findings of the study tracking over 3,000 initially healthy participants regarding the relationship between negative affectivity and hypertension and heart disease?', 'For example, over 3,000 initially healthy participants in one study were tracked longitudinally, up to 22 years.']

['What were the outcomes of the study regarding the relationship between negative affectivity and hypertension among the initially healthy participants?', 'Those with higher levels of negative affectivity at the time the study began were substantially more likely to develop and be treated for hypertension during the ensuing years than were those with lower levels of negative affectivity (Jonas & Lando, 2000).']

['What were the results of the study regarding the relationship between negative affectivity and heart disease among the middle-aged civil servants in London?', 'In addition, a study of over 10,000 middle-aged London-based civil servants who were followed an average of 12.5 years revealed that those who earlier had scored in the upper third on a test of negative affectivity were 32% more likely to have experienced heart disease, heart attack, or angina over a period of years than were those who scored in the lowest third (Nabi, Kivimaki, De Vogli, Marmot, & Singh-Manoux, 2008).']

['What is the significance of the findings regarding the relationship between negative affectivity and heart disease among the middle-aged civil servants in London?', 'Hence, negative affectivity appears to be a potentially vital risk factor for the development of cardiovascular disorders.']

['Teacher: According to Glassman and Shapiro, what has been asserted by poets and folklore for centuries regarding the connection between moods and the heart?', 'For centuries, poets and folklore have asserted that there is a connection between moods and the heart (Glassman & Shapiro, 1998).']

['Teacher: Can you provide some examples of how the notion of a broken heart following a disappointing or depressing event has been portrayed in songs, films, and literature?', 'You are no doubt familiar with the notion of a broken heart following a disappointing or depressing event and have encountered that notion in songs, films, and literature.']

['Teacher: Who was one of the first researchers to establish a connection between depression and heart disease?', 'Perhaps the first to recognize the link between depression and heart disease was Benjamin Malzberg (1937), who found that the death rate among institutionalized patients with melancholia (an archaic term for depression) was six times higher than that of the population.']

['Who conducted a classic study in the late 1970s that found a nearly 50% increase in deaths from heart disease among patients diagnosed with manic-depressive disorder?', 'A classic study in the late 1970s looked at over 8,000 people diagnosed with manic-depressive disorder (now classified as bipolar disorder) in Denmark, finding a nearly 50% increase in deaths from heart disease among these patients compared with the general Danish population (Weeke, 1979).']

['What is the significance of the evidence accumulated in the early 1990s regarding depressed individuals and their risk for heart disease and cardiac death?', 'By the early 1990s, evidence began to accumulate showing that depressed individuals who were followed for long periods of time were at increased risk for heart disease and cardiac death (Glassman, 2007).']

['What did the investigation of over 700 Denmark residents reveal about the relationship between depression scores and the likelihood of experiencing a heart attack?', 'In one investigation of over 700 Denmark residents, those with the highest depression scores were 71% more likely to have experienced a heart attack than were those with lower depression scores (Barefoot & Schroll, 1996).']

['What does Figure 14.20 in the textbook illustrate regarding the risk of heart attacks for both men and women?', 'Figure 14.20 illustrates the gradation in risk of heart attacks for both men and women.']
['Teacher: What is now clear after more than two decades of research regarding depression and the heart?', 'After more than two decades of research, it is now clear that a relationship exists:']

['Teacher: What are some of the findings regarding the relationship between depression and the heart after more than two decades of research?', 'Patients with heart disease have more depression than the general population, and people with depression are more likely to eventually develop heart disease and experience higher mortality than those who do not have depression (Hare, Toukhsati, Johansson, & Jaarsma, 2013); the more severe the depression, the higher the risk (Glassman, 2007).']
['What are some of the consequences of depression on patients with heart disease?', 'Consider the following:']

['Teacher: What were the findings of the study regarding death rates from cardiovascular problems in depressed individuals?', 'In one study, death rates from cardiovascular problems was substantially higher in depressed people; depressed men were 50% more likely to have died from cardiovascular problems, and depressed women were 70% more likely (Ösby, Brandt, Correia, Ekbom, & Sparén, 2001).']

['What is the average increased risk of developing heart disease for individuals with elevated depressive symptoms compared to those with fewer symptoms, according to the statistical review of 10 longitudinal studies?', 'A statistical review of 10 longitudinal studies involving initially healthy individuals revealed that those with elevated depressive symptoms have, on average, a 64% greater risk of developing heart disease than do those with fewer symptoms (Wulsin & Singal, 2003).']

['What percentage increase in risk of fatal heart disease was found in registered nurses with more depressed symptoms compared to those with fewer symptoms in the study of over 63,000 registered nurses?', 'A study of over 63,000 registered nurses found that those with more depressed symptoms when the study began were 49% more likely to experience fatal heart disease over a 12-year period (Whang et al., 2009).']

['Teacher: What did the American Heart Association recommend several years ago in relation to depression and cardiovascular diseases?', 'The American Heart Association, fully aware of the established importance of depression in cardiovascular diseases, several years ago recommended routine depression screening for all heart disease patients (Lichtman et al., 2008).']

["Teacher: Can you explain the main difference between the American Heart Association's recommendations on depression and cardiovascular diseases several years ago compared to their recent recommendations?", 'Recently, they have recommended including depression as a risk factor for heart disease patients (AHA, 2014).']

['Teacher: What has a recent investigation done in relation to the connection between depression and heart problems in early life?', 'Although the exact mechanisms through which depression might produce heart problems have not been fully clarified, a recent investigation examining this connection in early life has shed some light.']

['What were some of the findings of the ongoing study of childhood depression in relation to heart problems?', 'In an ongoing study of childhood depression, adolescents who had been diagnosed with depression as children were more likely to be obese, smoke, and be physically inactive than were those who had not received this diagnosis (Rottenberg et al., 2014).']

['What are some potential reasons behind the increased likelihood of an unfavorable cardiovascular disease risk profile for individuals with early-life depression, according to the study?', 'One implication of this study is that depression, especially if it occurs early in life, may increase the likelihood of living an unhealthy lifestyle, thereby predisposing people to an unfavorable cardiovascular disease risk profile.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why it is important to recognize that depression is not the sole emotional factor linked to the heightened risk of heart disease?', 'It is important to point out that depression may be just one piece of the emotional puzzle in elevating the risk for heart disease, and that chronically experiencing several negative emotional states may be especially important.']

['What does the longitudinal investigation of Vietnam War veterans suggest about the relationship between depression, anxiety, hostility, and trait anger and the risk of heart disease?', 'A longitudinal investigation of Vietnam War veterans found that depression, anxiety, hostility, and trait anger each independently predicted the onset of heart disease (Boyle, Michalek, & Suarez, 2006).']

['How did the combined variable of negative psychological attributes predict heart disease compared to the individual variables?', 'However, when each of these negative psychological attributes was combined into a single variable, this new variable (which researchers called psychological risk factor) predicted heart disease more strongly than any of the individual variables.']

['What is the term researchers used to refer to the combination of negative psychological attributes in predicting heart disease?', 'Thus, rather than examining the predictive power of isolated psychological risk factors, it seems crucial for future researchers to examine the effects of combined and more general negative emotional and psychological traits in the development of cardiovascular illnesses.']

['Teacher: Can you explain in your own words what happens to the airways in the respiratory system when a person has asthma?', 'Asthma is a chronic and serious disease in which the airways of the respiratory system become obstructed, leading to great difficulty expelling air from the lungs.']

['What are the two main factors that contribute to the obstruction of airways in asthma?', 'The airway obstruction is caused by inflammation of the airways (leading to thickening of the airway walls) and a tightening of the muscles around them, resulting in a narrowing of the airways (Figure 14.21) (American Lung Association, 2010).']

['What are some common symptoms experienced by a person with asthma due to the obstruction of airways?', 'Because airways become obstructed, a person with asthma will sometimes have great difficulty breathing and will experience repeated episodes of wheezing, chest tightness, shortness of breath, and coughing, the latter occurring mostly during the morning and night (CDC, 2006).']

['Teacher: What does the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) report about the number of asthma-related deaths each year?', 'According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), around 4,000 people die each year from asthma-related causes, and asthma is a contributing factor to another 7,000 deaths each year (CDC, 2013a).']

['What is the prevalence of asthma among U.S. adults according to the CDC?', 'The CDC has revealed that asthma affects 18.7 million U.S. adults and is more common among people with lower income levels (CDC, 2013b).']

['Teacher: Could you explain why the increasing rates of asthma between 2000 and 2010 are a cause for concern according to the CDC?', 'Especially concerning is that asthma is on the rise, with rates of asthma increasing 157% between 2000 and 2010 (CDC, 2013b).']
['Teacher: What are asthma attacks characterized by?', 'Asthma attacks are acute episodes in which an asthma sufferer experiences the full range of symptoms.']

['Teacher: What are some common environmental factors that can trigger asthma exacerbation?', 'Asthma exacerbation is often triggered by environmental factors, such as air pollution, allergens (e.g., pollen, mold, and pet hairs), cigarette smoke, airway infections, cold air or a sudden change in temperature, and exercise (CDC, 2013b).']

['Teacher: What are some possible reasons for certain regions and neighborhoods having high rates of asthma and related diseases?', 'Certain regions and neighborhoods are known for having notably high rates of asthma and related diseases due to high rates of concentrated pollution and low air quality.']

['What are some examples of areas with high rates of asthma and related diseases due to concentrated pollution and low air quality?', 'For example, Long Beach, California and Bronx, New York contain "asthma alleys" due to the density of trucking, power plants, factories, sewage  works, or other agents of air pollution.']

['Teacher: What role do psychological factors appear to play in asthma, according to Wright, Rodriguez, and Cohen (1998)?', 'Psychological factors appear to play an important role in asthma (Wright, Rodriguez, & Cohen, 1998), although some believe that psychological factors serve as potential triggers in only a subset of asthma patients (Ritz, Steptoe, Bobb, Harris, & Edwards, 2006).']

['What evidence is there to support the claim that psychological factors can trigger asthma symptoms in certain individuals?', 'Many studies over the years have demonstrated that some people with asthma will experience asthma-like symptoms if they expect to experience such symptoms, such as when breathing an inert substance that they (falsely) believe will lead to airway obstruction (Sodergren & Hyland, 1999).']

['How do stress and emotions directly affect immune and respiratory functions in individuals with asthma?', 'As stress and emotions directly affect immune and respiratory functions, psychological factors likely serve as one of the most common triggers of asthma exacerbation (Trueba & Ritz, 2013).']

['Teacher: What are some examples of negative emotions that people with asthma tend to report and display?', 'People with asthma tend to report and display a high level of negative emotions such as anxiety, and asthma attacks have been linked to periods of high emotionality (Lehrer, Isenberg, & Hochron, 1993).']

['What are some examples of negative effects that high levels of emotional distress can have on people with asthma?', 'In addition, high levels of emotional distress during both laboratory tasks and daily life have been found to negatively affect airway function and can produce asthma-like symptoms in people with asthma (von Leupoldt, Ehnes, & Dahme, 2006).']

['What was the purpose of the investigation mentioned in the passage?', 'In one investigation, 20 adults with asthma wore preprogrammed wristwatches that signaled them to breathe into a portable device that measures airway function.']

['What were the results of the investigation mentioned in the passage regarding the association between negative emotions and asthma symptoms?', 'Results showed that higher levels of negative emotions and stress were associated with increased airway obstruction and self-reported asthma symptoms (Smyth, Soefer, Hurewitz, Kliment, & Stone, 1999).']

["What was the impact of the breakup on the 18-year-old man's asthma symptoms?", 'In addition, D’Amato, Liccardi, Cecchi, Pellegrino, & D’Amato (2010) described a case study of an 18-year-old man with asthma whose girlfriend had broken up with him, leaving him in a depressed state.']

["What can be inferred from the 18-year-old man's experience of his girlfriend breaking up with him and unfriending him on Facebook?", 'She had also unfriended him on Facebook, while friending other young males.']
["What was the young man's response to his girlfriend unfriending him on Facebook?", 'Eventually, the young man was able to “friend” her once again and could monitor her activity through Facebook.']

["What can be concluded about the young man's asthma symptoms when he would access his girlfriend's profile on Facebook?", 'Subsequently, he would experience asthma symptoms whenever he logged on and accessed her profile.']
["What was the outcome of the young man's decision to stop using Facebook?", 'When he later resigned not to use Facebook any longer, the asthma attacks stopped.']

['What was the main finding of the case study regarding the use of social media and asthma attacks?', 'This case suggests that the use of Facebook and other forms of social media may represent a new source of stress—it may be a triggering factor for asthma attacks, especially in depressed asthmatic individuals.']

['Teacher: What are some factors that have been associated with the development of asthma?', 'Exposure to stressful experiences, particularly those that involve parental or interpersonal conflicts, has been linked to the development of asthma throughout the lifespan.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a study that supports the association between stressful experiences and the development of asthma?', 'A longitudinal study of 145 children found that parenting difficulties during the first year of life increased the chances that the child developed asthma by 107% (Klinnert et al., 2001).']

['What were the findings of the longitudinal study on the association between parenting difficulties during the first year of life and the development of asthma?', 'In addition, a cross-sectional study of over 10,000 Finnish college students found that high rates of parent or personal conflicts (e.g., parental divorce, separation from spouse, or severe conflicts in other long-term relationships) increased the risk of asthma onset (Kilpeläinen, Koskenvuo, Helenius, & Terho, 2002).']

['What were the findings of the cross-sectional study on the association between high rates of parent or personal conflicts and the risk of asthma onset?', 'Further, a study of over 4,000 middle-aged men who were interviewed in the early 1990s and again a decade later found that breaking off an important life partnership (e.g., divorce or breaking off relationship from parents) increased the risk of developing asthma by 124% over the time of the study (Loerbroks, Apfelbacher, Thayer, Debling, & Stürmer, 2009).']
['Teacher: Can you define what a headache is?', 'A headache is a continuous pain anywhere in the head and neck region.']

['What are some possible causes of sinus headaches?', 'Inflammation of the sinuses caused by an infection or allergic reaction can cause sinus headaches, which are experienced as pain in the cheeks and forehead.']
['Teacher: How are migraine headaches believed to be caused?', 'Migraine headaches are a type of headache thought to be caused by blood vessel swelling and increased blood flow (McIntosh, 2013).']
['What are some common symptoms of migraines?', 'Migraines are characterized by severe pain on one or both sides of the head, an upset stomach, and disturbed vision.']
['What are some recommended treatments for migraines?', 'They are more frequently experienced by women than by men (American Academy of Neurology, 2014).']

['What are some of the characteristics of tension headaches?', 'Tension headaches are triggered by tightening/tensing of facial and neck muscles; they are the most commonly experienced kind of headache, accounting for about 42% of all headaches worldwide (Stovner et al., 2007).']

['What are some possible triggers for tension headaches?', 'In the United States, well over one-third of the population experiences tension headaches each year, and 2–3% of the population suffers from chronic tension headaches (Schwartz, Stewart, Simon, & Lipton, 1998).']

['Teacher: What are some factors that can contribute to tension headaches according to the textbook passage?', 'A number of factors can contribute to tension headaches, including sleep deprivation, skipping meals, eye strain, overexertion, muscular tension caused by poor posture, and stress (MedicineNet, 2013).']

['What is one way that stress contributes to tension headaches according to the passage?', 'Although there is uncertainty regarding the exact mechanisms through which stress can produce tension headaches, stress has been demonstrated to increase sensitivity to pain (Caceres & Burns, 1997; Logan et al., 2001).']

['How do tension headache sufferers differ from non-sufferers in terms of pain sensitivity and subjective stress levels?', 'In general, tension headache sufferers, compared to non-sufferers, have a lower threshold for and greater sensitivity to pain (Ukestad & Wittrock, 1996), and they report greater levels of subjective stress when faced with a stressor (Myers, Wittrock, & Foreman, 1998).']

['What is the possible mechanism through which stress increases pain sensitivity in tension headache sufferers, according to the passage?', 'Thus, stress may contribute to tension headaches by increasing pain sensitivity in already-sensitive pain pathways in tension headache sufferers (Cathcart, Petkov, & Pritchard, 2008).']

['Teacher: What can you tell me about the impact of chronic stress on our bodies and our health?', 'As we learned in the previous section, stress—especially if it is chronic—takes a toll on our bodies and can have enormously negative health implications.']

['Teacher: What are some examples of effective coping strategies to manage stress?', 'When we experience events in our lives that we appraise as stressful, it is essential that we use effective coping strategies to manage our stress.']
['Teacher: How can coping strategies help us deal with problems related to stress?', 'Coping refers to mental and behavioral efforts that we use to deal with problems relating to stress.']

['Teacher: Can you please explain the two fundamental kinds of coping distinguished by Lazarus and Folkman?', 'Lazarus and Folkman (1984) distinguished two fundamental kinds of coping: problem-focused coping and emotion-focused coping.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of problem-focused coping?', 'In problem-focused coping, one attempts to manage or alter the problem that is causing one to experience stress (i.e., the stressor).']

['Teacher: Can you explain how problem-focused coping strategies are similar to everyday problem-solving strategies?', 'Problem-focused coping strategies are similar to strategies used in everyday problem-solving: they typically involve identifying the problem, considering possible solutions, weighing the costs and benefits of these solutions, and then selecting an alternative (Lazarus & Folkman, 1984).']

['Teacher: How might Bradford apply problem-focused coping strategies to address his failing grade in statistics class?', 'As an example, suppose Bradford receives a midterm notice that he is failing statistics class.']

['Teacher: How might Bradford apply problem-focused coping strategies to address his failing grade in statistics class?', 'If Bradford adopts a problem-focused coping approach to managing his stress, he would be proactive in trying to alleviate the source of the stress.']

['Teacher: What are some specific problem-focused coping strategies that Bradford could use to address his failing grade in statistics class?', 'He might contact his professor to discuss what must be done to raise his grade, he might also decide to set aside two hours daily to study statistics assignments, and he may seek tutoring assistance.']

['Teacher: How does a problem-focused coping approach differ from an emotion-focused coping approach in terms of addressing stress?', 'A problem-focused approach to managing stress means we actively try to do things to address the problem.']
['Teacher: Can you explain what emotion-focused coping entails?', 'Emotion-focused coping, in contrast, consists of efforts to change or reduce the negative emotions associated with stress.']

['Teacher: Can you provide specific examples of emotion-focused coping strategies?', 'These efforts may include avoiding, minimizing, or distancing oneself from the problem, or positive comparisons with others (“I’m not as bad off as she is”), or seeking something positive in a negative event (“Now that I’ve been fired, I can sleep in for a few days”).']

['Teacher: How does reappraisal play a role in emotion-focused coping strategies?', 'In some cases, emotion-focused coping strategies involve reappraisal, whereby the stressor is construed differently (and somewhat self-deceptively) without changing its objective level of threat (Lazarus & Folkman, 1984).']

['Teacher: Can you provide another example of how reappraisal can be used as an emotion-focused coping strategy?', 'For example, a person sentenced to federal prison who thinks, “This will give me a great chance to network with others,” is using reappraisal.']

['What are some examples of emotion-focused coping strategies that Bradford could use to manage his midterm deficiency stress?', 'If Bradford adopted an emotion-focused approach to managing his midterm deficiency stress, he might watch a comedy movie, play video games, or spend hours on social media to take his mind off the situation.']

['What are the advantages and disadvantages of using emotion-focused coping strategies?', 'In a certain sense, emotion-focused coping can be thought of as treating the symptoms rather than the actual cause.']

['Teacher: What are the factors that influence whether someone is more likely to engage in problem-focused or emotion-focused coping strategies?', 'While many stressors elicit both kinds of coping strategies, problem-focused coping is more likely to occur when encountering stressors we perceive as controllable, while emotion-focused coping is more likely to predominate when faced with stressors that we believe we are powerless to change (Folkman &  Lazarus, 1980).']

['Teacher: Why is emotion-focused coping more likely to be used when faced with stressors that we believe we are powerless to change?', 'Clearly, emotion-focused coping is more effective in dealing with uncontrollable stressors.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why emotion-focused coping is more effective in dealing with uncontrollable stressors, using the example of the stress experienced when a loved one dies?', 'For example, the stress you experience when a loved one dies can be overwhelming.']

['Teacher: Why would problem-focused coping be less effective in dealing with the stress of losing a loved one?', 'You are simply powerless to change the situation as there is nothing you can do to bring this person back.']

['Why is emotion-focused coping considered the most helpful coping response in the grieving period after losing a loved one?', 'The most helpful coping response is emotion-focused coping aimed at minimizing the pain of the grieving period.']
['Teacher: How can we describe the level of control we have over most stressors we encounter?', 'Fortunately, most stressors we encounter can be modified and are, to varying degrees, controllable.']

['Teacher: Can you give me some examples of how individuals can modify and control stressors they encounter?', 'A person who cannot stand her job can quit and look for work elsewhere; a middle-aged divorcee can find another potential partner; the freshman who fails an exam can study harder next time, and a breast lump does not necessarily mean that one is fated to die of breast cancer.']

['Teacher: What is a fundamental aspect of human behavior related to control and stress?', 'The desire and ability to predict events, make decisions, and affect outcomes—that is, to enact control in our lives—is a basic tenet of human behavior (Everly & Lating, 2002).']

['Teacher: How does the desire and ability to predict events, make decisions, and affect outcomes relate to control and stress according to Everly & Lating (2002)?', 'Albert Bandura (1997) stated that “the intensity and chronicity of human stress is governed largely by perceived control over the demands of one’s life” (p. 262).']

["Teacher: According to Albert Bandura (1997), how does the level of perceived control over the demands of one's life influence the intensity and chronicity of human stress?", 'As cogently described in his statement, our reaction to potential stressors depends to a large extent on how much control we feel we have over such things.']

['Teacher: How does perceived control influence our reaction to potential stressors, according to the statement described by the student?', 'Perceived control is our beliefs about our personal capacity to exert influence over and shape outcomes, and it has major implications for our health and happiness (Infurna & Gerstorf, 2014).']

['Teacher: According to Infurna & Gerstorf (2014), what are the major implications of perceived control for our health and happiness?', 'Extensive research has demonstrated that perceptions of personal control are associated with a variety of favorable outcomes, such as better physical and mental health and greater psychological well-being (Diehl & Hay, 2010).']

['Teacher: According to Diehl & Hay (2010), how is greater personal control associated with reactivity to stressors in daily life?', 'Greater personal control is also associated with lower reactivity to stressors in daily life.']

['Teacher: According to Neupert, Almeida, & Charles (2007), what is the relationship between higher levels of perceived control and emotional and physical reactivity to interpersonal stressors?', 'For example, researchers in one investigation found that higher levels of perceived control at one point in time were later associated with lower emotional and physical reactivity to interpersonal stressors (Neupert, Almeida, & Charles, 2007).']

['Teacher: According to Ong, Bergeman, & Bisconti (2005), how does greater perceived control affect the stress and anxiety levels of older widows on a daily basis?', 'Further, a daily diary study with 34 older widows found that their stress and anxiety levels were significantly reduced on days during which the widows felt greater perceived control (Ong, Bergeman, & Bisconti, 2005).']

["Teacher: How does the perception of control influence an individual's management of their health and engagement in behaviors related to good health?", 'People who report higher levels of perceived control view their health as controllable, thereby making it more likely that they will better manage their health and engage in behaviors conducive to good health (Bandura, 2004).']

['What are some physical health problems that have been found to be less likely in individuals who perceive a higher level of control over their health?', 'Not surprisingly, greater perceived control has been linked to lower risk of physical health problems, including declines in physical functioning (Infurna, Gerstorf, Ram, Schupp, & Wagner, 2011), heart attacks (Rosengren et al., 2004), and both cardiovascular disease incidence (Stürmer, Hasselbach, & Amelang, 2006) and mortality from cardiac disease (Surtees et al., 2010).']

['What is one study that supports the relationship between perceived control and the development of heart disease?', 'In addition, longitudinal studies of British civil servants have found that those in low-status jobs (e.g., clerical and office support staff) in which the degree of control over the job is minimal are considerably more likely to develop heart disease than those with high-status jobs or considerable control over their jobs (Marmot, Bosma, Hemingway, & Stansfeld, 1997).']

['Teacher: Can you explain how the relationship between perceived control and health could help explain the connection between social class and health outcomes?', 'The link between perceived control and health may provide an explanation for the frequently observed relationship between social class and health outcomes (Kraus, Piff, Mendoza-Denton, Rheinschmidt, & Keltner, 2012).']

['How does the belief in personal control contribute to better health outcomes among more affluent individuals?', 'In general, research has found that more affluent individuals experience better health partly because they tend to believe that they can personally control and manage their reactions to life’s stressors (Johnson & Krueger, 2006).']

['What is one possible consequence of individuals of higher social class overestimating their level of control?', 'Perhaps buoyed by the perceived level of control, individuals of higher social class may be prone to overestimating the degree of influence they have over particular outcomes.']

['How can the belief of having more control influence the voting behavior of individuals from higher social classes?', 'For example, those of higher social class tend to believe that their votes have greater sway on election outcomes than do those of lower social class, which may explain higher rates of voting in more affluent communities (Krosnick, 1990).']

['What are some negative consequences of individuals from lower social classes underestimating their level of control?', 'Other research has found that a sense of perceived control can protect less affluent individuals from poorer health, depression, and reduced life-satisfaction—all of which tend to accompany lower social standing (Lachman & Weaver, 1998).']

['Teacher: According to Baumeister and Leary (1995), what is a powerful, pervasive, and fundamental human motive?', 'The need to form and maintain strong, stable relationships with others is a powerful, pervasive, and fundamental human motive (Baumeister & Leary, 1995).']

['Teacher: How does building strong interpersonal relationships with others help us in times of distress, sorrow, and fear?', 'Building strong interpersonal relationships with others helps us establish a network of close, caring individuals who can provide social support in times of distress, sorrow, and fear.']

['Teacher: What are some examples of individuals who can provide social support in times of distress, sorrow, and fear?', 'Social support can be thought of as the soothing impact of friends, family, and acquaintances (Baron & Kerr, 2003).']

['What are some forms of social support that individuals can provide?', 'Social support can take many forms, including advice, guidance, encouragement, acceptance, emotional comfort, and tangible assistance (such as financial help).']

['What are some examples of life stressors that individuals may face and that can be helped through social support?', 'Thus, other people can be very comforting to us when we are faced with a wide range of life stressors, and they can be extremely helpful in our efforts to manage these challenges.']
['What kind of challenges can social support help individuals manage?', 'Even in nonhuman animals, species mates can offer social support during times of stress.']

['What are some ways that animals provide social support to one another during times of stress?', 'For example, elephants seem to be able to sense when other elephants are stressed and will often comfort them with physical contact—such as a trunk touch—or an empathetic vocal response (Krumboltz, 2014).']

['Teacher: What triggered scientific interest in the importance of social support in the 1970s?', 'Scientific interest in the importance of social support first emerged in the 1970s when health researchers developed an interest in the health consequences of being socially integrated (Stroebe & Stroebe, 1996).']

['Teacher: What were the key factors that led to the emergence of interest in the importance of social support in the 1970s?', 'Interest was further fueled by longitudinal studies showing that social connectedness reduced mortality.']

['Teacher: What were the findings of the classic study that followed nearly 7,000 Alameda County residents over 9 years?', 'In one classic study, nearly 7,000 Alameda County, California, residents were followed over 9 years.']

['Teacher: What were the implications of the classic study in Alameda County regarding the association between social support and mortality?', 'Those who had previously indicated that they lacked social and community ties were more likely to die during the follow-up period than those with more extensive social networks.']

['What are the mortality risks for isolated men and women compared to those with the most social contacts according to the classic study in Alameda County?', 'Compared to those with the most social contacts, isolated men and women were, respectively, 2.3 and 2.8 times more likely to die.']

['What variables were controlled for in the classic study in Alameda County to ensure accurate findings regarding the association between social support and mortality?', 'These trends persisted even after controlling for a variety of health-related variables, such as smoking, alcohol consumption, self-reported health at the beginning of the study, and physical activity (Berkman & Syme, 1979).']

['Teacher: What is one of the well-documented psychosocial factors that has emerged as affecting health outcomes since the time of that study?', 'Since the time of that study, social support has emerged as one of the well-documented psychosocial factors affecting health outcomes (Uchino, 2009).']

["What does the statistical review of the 148 studies between 1982 and 2007 conclude about the impact of social relationships on individuals' likelihood of survival?", 'A statistical review of 148 studies conducted between 1982 and 2007 involving over 300,000 participants concluded that individuals with stronger social relationships have a 50% greater likelihood of survival compared to those with weak or insufficient social relationships (Holt-Lunstad, Smith, & Layton, 2010).']

['What are some well-known risk factors for mortality that the effect of social support observed in this study exceeded?', 'According to the researchers, the magnitude of the effect of social support observed in this study is comparable with quitting smoking and exceeded many well-known risk factors for mortality, such as obesity and physical inactivity (Figure 14.23).']

['Teacher: What is the connection between low levels of social support and mortality based on the findings of large-scale studies?', 'A number of large-scale studies have found that individuals with low levels of social support are at greater risk of mortality, especially from cardiovascular disorders (Brummett et al., 2001).']

['What are some examples of specific health outcomes that are influenced by levels of social support?', 'Further, higher levels of social supported have been linked to better survival rates following breast cancer (Falagas et al., 2007) and infectious diseases, especially HIV infection (Lee & Rotheram-Borus, 2001).']
['What are some examples of infectious diseases that are influenced by levels of social support?', 'In fact, a person with high levels of social support is less likely to contract a common cold.']

['What were the findings of the study regarding the risk of contracting a common cold based on the levels of social support?', 'In one study, 334 participants completed questionnaires assessing their sociability; these individuals were subsequently exposed to a virus that causes a common cold and monitored for several weeks to see who became ill.']

['What was the relationship between sociability and the risk of developing a common cold based on the study findings?', 'Results showed that increased sociability was linearly associated with a decreased probability of developing a cold (Cohen, Doyle, Turner, Alper, & Skoner, 2003).']
['Teacher: Who or what are often considered as a vital source of social support for many of us?', 'For many of us, friends are a vital source of social support.']

['Teacher: What are the potential negative consequences for students who experience drastic reductions in their social support?', 'Many students who leave home to attend and live at college experience drastic reductions in their social support, which makes them vulnerable to anxiety, depression, and loneliness.']

['Teacher: How can social media impact the social support of students who experience drastic reductions?', 'Social media can sometimes be useful in navigating these transitions (Raney & Troop Gordon, 2012) but might also cause increases in loneliness (Hunt, Marx, Lipson, & Young, 2018).']

['Teacher: What types of first-year programs can colleges implement to help students build new social networks?', 'For this reason, many colleges have designed first-year programs, such as peer mentoring (Raymond & Shepard, 2018), that can help students build new social networks.']
['What are other potential sources of social support for many individuals, besides friends?', 'For some people, our families—especially our parents—are a major source of social support.']

['Teacher: How does social support seem to affect the immune system, particularly among individuals facing stress?', 'Social support appears to work by boosting the immune system, especially among people who are experiencing stress (Uchino, Vaughn, Carlisle, & Birmingham, 2012).']

['How did spouses of cancer patients in a study show differences in immune functioning based on their levels of social support?', 'In a pioneering study, spouses of cancer patients who reported high levels of social support showed indications of better immune functioning on two out of three immune functioning measures, compared to spouses who were below the median on reported social support (Baron, Cutrona, Hicklin, Russell, & Lubaroff, 1990).']

['What are some other populations that have shown similar results in studies regarding the effects of social support on immune functioning?', 'Studies of other populations have produced similar results, including those of spousal caregivers of dementia sufferers, medical students, elderly adults, and cancer patients (Cohen & Herbert, 1996; Kiecolt-Glaser, McGuire, Robles, & Glaser, 2002).']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how social support can impact physical health during stressful situations?', 'In addition, social support has been shown to reduce blood pressure for people performing stressful tasks, such as giving a speech or performing mental arithmetic (Lepore, 1998).']

['Teacher: How does social support impact blood pressure for individuals performing stressful tasks, according to the study by Lepore in 1998?', 'In these kinds of studies, participants are usually asked to perform a stressful task either alone, with a stranger present (who may be either supportive or unsupportive), or with a friend present.']

['Teacher: Why do participants tested with a friend present generally exhibit lower blood pressure compared to those tested alone or with a stranger, as mentioned in the study by Fontana, Diegnan, Villeneuve, & Lepore in 1999?', 'Those tested with a friend present generally exhibit lower blood pressure than those tested alone or with a stranger (Fontana, Diegnan, Villeneuve, & Lepore, 1999).']

['Teacher: Why did female participants who received support from a male friend exhibit lower blood pressure during stressful mental arithmetic tasks, as found in the study by Phillips, Gallagher, & Carroll in 2009?', 'In one study, 112 female participants who performed stressful mental arithmetic exhibited lower blood pressure when they received support from a friend rather than a stranger, but only if the friend was a male (Phillips, Gallagher, & Carroll, 2009).']

['Teacher: Why might female participants feel less supported and more evaluated by other females, leading to lower blood pressure when receiving support from a male friend during stressful mental arithmetic tasks, according to the authors?', 'Although these findings are somewhat difficult to interpret, the authors mention that it is possible that females feel less supported and more evaluated by other females, particularly females whose opinions they value.']

['Teacher: Why are social support and favorable health outcomes connected?', 'Taken together, the findings above suggest one of the reasons social support is connected to favorable health outcomes is because it has several beneficial physiological effects in stressful situations.']

['Teacher: Can you explain some of the physiological effects of social support that contribute to favorable health outcomes in stressful situations?', 'However, it is also important to consider the possibility that social support may lead to better health behaviors, such as a healthy diet, exercising, smoking cessation, and cooperation with medical regimens (Uchino, 2009).']

['Teacher: What are some additional ways mentioned in Figure 14.24 that can help us manage stress?', 'Beyond having a sense of control and establishing social support networks, there are numerous other means by which we can manage stress (Figure 14.24).']
['What does Figure 14.24 mention as additional ways to manage stress?', 'A common technique people use to combat stress is exercise (Salmon, 2001).']

['What benefits can be derived from both long (aerobic) and short (anaerobic) duration exercises in terms of stress reduction?', 'It is well-established that exercise, both of long (aerobic) and short (anaerobic) duration, is beneficial for both physical and mental health (Everly & Lating, 2002).']

['What evidence supports the claim that physically fit individuals are more resistant to the adverse effects of stress and recover more quickly from stress?', 'There is considerable evidence that physically fit individuals are more resistant to the adverse effects of stress and recover more quickly from stress than less physically fit individuals (Cotton, 1990).']

['What were the findings of a study conducted on Swiss police officers and emergency service personnel regarding the relationship between physical fitness and stress reduction?', 'In a study of more than 500 Swiss police officers and emergency service personnel, increased physical fitness was associated with reduced stress, and regular exercise was reported to protect against stress-related health problems (Gerber, Kellman, Hartman, & Pühse, 2010).']

['Teacher: Why might exercise be considered beneficial in terms of stress reduction?', 'One reason exercise may be beneficial is because it might buffer some of the deleterious physiological mechanisms of stress.']

['What was the outcome of the study regarding the rats that exercised for six weeks?', 'One study found rats that exercised for six weeks showed a decrease in hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal responsiveness to mild stressors (Campeau et al., 2010).']

['What is one potential benefit of exercise for humans in terms of stress reduction?', 'In high-stress humans, exercise has been shown to prevent telomere shortening, which may explain the common observation of a youthful appearance among those who exercise regularly (Puterman et al., 2010).']

['What are some potential effects of exercise on the brain and memory in relation to stress reduction?', 'Further, exercise in later adulthood appears to minimize the detrimental effects of stress on the hippocampus and memory (Head, Singh, & Bugg, 2012).']

['What are some mental health benefits of exercise in relation to stress reduction?', 'Among cancer survivors, exercise has been shown to reduce anxiety (Speck, Courneya, Masse, Duval, & Schmitz, 2010) and depressive symptoms (Craft, VanIterson, Helenowski, Rademaker, & Courneya, 2012).']
['How would you summarize the overall effectiveness of exercise in terms of stress reduction?', 'Clearly, exercise is a highly effective tool for regulating stress.']

['Teacher: Who is the person credited with developing the relaxation response technique?', 'In the 1970s, Herbert Benson, a cardiologist, developed a stress reduction method called the relaxation response technique (Greenberg, 2006).']

['Teacher: Can you please explain what the four components of the relaxation response technique are?', 'The relaxation response technique combines relaxation with transcendental meditation, and consists of four components (Stein, 2001):']

['Teacher: How does the relaxation response approach contribute to stress reduction and treatment of high blood pressure?', 'Another technique to combat stress, biofeedback, was developed by Gary Schwartz at Harvard University in the early 1970s.']

['Teacher: How does the technique of biofeedback differ from the relaxation response approach in terms of providing feedback to individuals?', 'Biofeedback is a technique that uses electronic equipment to accurately measure a person’s neuromuscular and autonomic activity—feedback is provided in the form of visual or auditory signals.']

['Teacher: How does the assumption of the biofeedback approach align with the goals of the relaxation response approach in terms of stress reduction and treatment of high blood pressure?', 'The main assumption of this approach is that providing somebody biofeedback will enable the individual to develop strategies that help gain some level of voluntary control over what are normally involuntary bodily processes (Schwartz & Schwartz, 1995).']

['Teacher: How does the use of different bodily measures in biofeedback research align with the goals of the relaxation response approach in terms of stress reduction and treatment of high blood pressure?', 'A number of different bodily measures have been used in biofeedback research, including facial muscle movement, brain activity, and skin temperature, and it has been applied successfully with individuals experiencing tension headaches, high blood pressure, asthma, and phobias (Stein, 2001).']

["Teacher: What is the student's opinion about the study of stress and its effects?", 'Although the study of stress and how it affects us physically and psychologically is fascinating, it is—admittedly—somewhat of a grim topic.']

['Teacher: What topic is psychology interested in studying as a more positive alternative to the study of stress and its effects?', 'Psychology is also interested in the study of a more upbeat and encouraging approach to human affairs—the quest for happiness.']

["Teacher: According to America's founders, what right do its citizens possess in relation to happiness?", 'America’s founders declared that its citizens have an unalienable right to pursue happiness.']

["Teacher: That's correct. Now, can you explain why people emphasize different aspects of happiness when asked to define the term?", 'When asked to define the term, people emphasize different aspects of this elusive state.']
['Teacher: Why do people have different perspectives when defining happiness?', 'Indeed, happiness is somewhat ambiguous and can be defined from different perspectives (Martin, 2012).']

['What are some aspects of happiness that highly committed religious individuals emphasize?', 'Some people, especially those who are highly committed to their religious faith, view happiness in ways that emphasize virtuosity, reverence, and enlightened spirituality.']

['What aspects of happiness do individuals who prioritize contentment tend to emphasize?', 'Others see happiness as primarily contentment—the inner peace and joy that come from deep satisfaction with one’s surroundings, relationships with others, accomplishments, and oneself.']

['What are some aspects of happiness that individuals who prioritize pleasure tend to emphasize?', 'Still others view happiness mainly as pleasurable engagement with their personal environment—having a career and hobbies that are engaging, meaningful, rewarding, and exciting.']
['What are some aspects of happiness that individuals who prioritize personal growth tend to emphasize?', 'These differences, of course, are merely differences in emphasis.']

['What is the commonality among the different perspectives on happiness described in the passage?', 'Most people would probably agree that each of these views, in some respects, captures the essence of happiness.']

['Teacher: What are the three distinct elements of happiness that some psychologists have suggested?', 'Some psychologists have suggested that happiness consists of three distinct elements: the pleasant life, the good life, and the meaningful life, as shown in Figure 14.25 (Seligman, 2002; Seligman, Steen, Park, & Peterson, 2005).']
['What does the pleasant life element of happiness consist of?', 'The pleasant life is realized through the attainment of day-to-day pleasures that add fun, joy, and excitement to our lives.']

['What does the good life element of happiness consist of?', 'For example, evening walks along the beach and a fulfilling sex life can enhance our daily pleasure and contribute to the pleasant life.']

['What is the third element of happiness called and how can it be achieved?', 'The good life is achieved through identifying our unique skills and abilities and engaging these talents to enrich our lives; those who achieve the good life often find themselves absorbed in their work or their recreational pursuits.']

['What is the significance of the meaningful life element of happiness?', 'The meaningful life involves a deep sense of fulfillment that comes from using our talents in the service of the greater good: in ways that benefit the lives of others or that make the world a better place.']

['What are the three elements of happiness that people should orient their pursuits toward?', 'In general, the happiest people tend to be those who pursue the full life—they orient their pursuits toward all three elements (Seligman et al., 2005).']

["Teacher: How does Lyubomirsky's definition of happiness incorporate different elements?", 'For practical purposes, a precise definition of happiness might incorporate each of these elements: an enduring state of mind consisting of joy, contentment, and other positive emotions, plus the sense that one’s life has meaning and value (Lyubomirsky, 2001).']

["Teacher: According to Lyubomirsky's definition, what are the different elements that contribute to happiness?", 'The definition implies that happiness is a long-term state—what is often characterized as subjective well-being—rather than merely a transient positive mood we all experience from time to time.']
["What is included in Lyubomirsky's definition of an enduring state of happiness?", 'It is this enduring happiness that has captured the interests of psychologists and other social scientists.']
['Teacher: What has happened to the study of happiness in the last three decades?', 'The study of happiness has grown dramatically in the last three decades (Diener, 2013).']
['What is one of the most basic questions that happiness investigators routinely examine?', 'One of the most basic questions that happiness investigators routinely examine is this:']

['Teacher: How does the average person around the world tend to rate their level of happiness and emotions?', 'The average person in the world tends to be relatively happy and tends to indicate experiencing more positive feelings than negative feelings (Diener, Ng, Harter, & Arora, 2010).']

['What is the average score that people from more than 150 countries reported when evaluating their current lives on a scale from 0 to 10?', 'When asked to evaluate their current lives on a scale ranging from 0 to 10 (with 0 representing “worst possible life” and 10 representing “best possible life”), people in more than 150 countries surveyed from 2010–2012 reported an average score of 5.2.']

['What are the highest and lowest average scores reported by people in different regions of the world when evaluating their current lives on a scale from 0 to 10?', 'People who live in North America, Australia, and New Zealand reported the highest average score at 7.1, whereas those living Sub-Saharan Africa reported the lowest average score at 4.6 (Helliwell, Layard, & Sachs, 2013).']

['Teacher: Which countries are ranked as the top five happiest in the world according to Figure 14.26?', 'Worldwide, the five happiest countries are Denmark, Norway, Switzerland, the Netherlands, and Sweden; the United States is ranked 17th happiest (Figure 14.26) (Helliwell et al., 2013).']

['Teacher: According to the Gallup survey, what percentage of U.S. adults reported being "very happy"?', 'Several years ago, a Gallup survey of more than 1,000 U.S. adults found that 52% reported that they were “very happy.”']

['Teacher: Can you please share how many U.S. adults, as reported in the Gallup survey, indicated that they were "very satisfied" with their lives?', 'In addition, more than 8 in 10 indicated that they were “very satisfied” with their lives (Carroll, 2007).']

['Teacher: According to the recent poll you mentioned, what percentage of American adults reported being "very happy"?', 'However, a recent poll found that only 42% of American adults report being "very happy."']

['What are some of the groups that show the greatest declines in happiness, according to the recent poll you mentioned?', 'The groups that show the greatest declines in happiness are people of color, those who have not completed a college education, and those who politically identify as Democrats or independents (McCarthy, 2020).']

['What is the possible connection between challenging economic conditions and declines in happiness, based on the results of the recent poll you mentioned?', 'These results suggest that challenging economic conditions may be related to declines in happiness.']

["What can we infer about the relationship between individuals' financial situations and their level of happiness based on the results of the recent poll you mentioned?", "Of course, this interpretation implies that happiness is closely tied to one's finances."]
['Teacher: What has extensive research over the years examined?', 'Extensive research over the years has examined this question.']
['What is one of the findings connected to happiness in relation to age?', 'One finding is that age is related to happiness:']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a finding related to happiness in relation to gender?', 'Life satisfaction usually increases the older people get, but there do not appear to be gender differences in happiness (Diener, Suh, Lucas, & Smith, 1999).']

['Teacher: Can you elaborate on some of the key findings related to happiness that have been summarized in the passage?', 'Although it is important to point out that much of this work has been correlational, many of the key findings (some of which may surprise you) are summarized below.']

['Teacher: Can you identify any factors that are strongly associated with happiness, particularly in relation to family and social connections?', 'Family and other social relationships appear to be key factors correlated with happiness.']

['Teacher: According to the passage, which marital status is commonly associated with higher levels of happiness?', 'Studies show that married people report being happier than those who are single, divorced, or widowed (Diener et al., 1999).']

['Teacher: Can you provide any specific evidence from the passage that supports the claim that married individuals tend to be happier than those who are single, divorced, or widowed?', 'Happy individuals also report that their marriages are fulfilling (Lyubomirsky, King, & Diener, 2005).']

['Teacher: What is suggested to be the strongest predictor of happiness, according to some researchers?', 'In fact, some have suggested that satisfaction with marriage and family life is the strongest predictor of happiness (Myers, 2000).']

['What evidence does the passage provide to support the claim that happy people tend to have more friends and stronger social support networks compared to less happy people?', 'Happy people tend to have more friends, more high-quality social relationships, and stronger social support networks than less happy people (Lyubomirsky et al., 2005).']

['What is one specific type of social connection that happy people tend to have more of compared to less happy people?', 'Happy people also have a high frequency of contact with friends (Pinquart & Sörensen, 2000).']
['Teacher: According to extensive research, is there a connection between factors and happiness?', 'In general, extensive research suggests that the answer is yes, but with several caveats.']

["What is the relationship between a nation's per capita gross domestic product (GDP) and happiness levels according to the research?", 'While a nation’s per capita gross domestic product (GDP) is associated with happiness levels (Helliwell et al., 2013), changes in GDP (which is a less certain index of household income) bear little relationship to changes in happiness (Diener, Tay, & Oishi, 2013).']

["What is the general relationship between a nation's affluence and happiness levels according to the research?", 'On the whole, residents of affluent countries tend to be happier than residents of poor countries; within countries, wealthy individuals are happier than poor individuals, but the association is much weaker (Diener & Biswas-Diener, 2002).']

['What is the association between increases in income and happiness levels according to the research?', 'To the extent that it leads to increases in purchasing power, increases in income are associated with increases in happiness (Diener, Oishi, & Ryan, 2013).']
['What does the research suggest about the correlation between income and happiness within societies?', 'However, income within societies appears to correlate with happiness only up to a point.']

['What did Kahneman and Deaton find about the correlation between well-being and annual income in their study of U.S. residents?', 'In a study of over 450,000 U.S. residents surveyed by the Gallup Organization, Kahneman and Deaton (2010) found that well-being rises with annual income, but only up to $75,000.']

['What was the finding of the study conducted by Kahneman and Deaton regarding the well-being of people with incomes greater than $75,000?', 'The average increase in reported well-being for people with incomes greater than $75,000 was null.']

['What is the potential explanation for the null increase in reported well-being for people with incomes greater than $75,000 according to the research?', 'As implausible as these findings might seem—after all, higher incomes would enable people to indulge in Hawaiian vacations, prime seats as sporting events, expensive automobiles, and expansive new homes—higher incomes may impair people’s ability to savor and enjoy the small pleasures of life (Kahneman, 2011).']

["What is the potential impact of wealth on people's ability to savor and enjoy small pleasures in life, based on the research?", 'Indeed, researchers in one study found that participants exposed to a subliminal reminder of wealth spent less time savoring a chocolate candy bar and exhibited less enjoyment of this experience than did participants who were not reminded of wealth (Quoidbach, Dunn, Petrides, & Mikolajczak, 2010).']

['Teacher: What is one outcome that happy people are more likely to experience compared to those who are less happy in terms of education and employment?', 'Happy people, compared to those who are less happy, are more likely to graduate from college and secure more meaningful and engaging jobs.']

['What is another positive outcome that happy people are more likely to experience compared to those who are less happy, once they obtain a job?', 'Once they obtain a job, they are also more likely to succeed (Lyubomirsky et al., 2005).']

['What is one factor that shows a positive correlation with happiness based on the passage?', 'While education shows a positive (but weak) correlation with happiness, intelligence is not appreciably related to happiness (Diener et al., 1999).']
['Teacher: According to Hackney and Sanders in 2003, is the answer to the question generally positive or negative?', 'In general, the answer is yes (Hackney & Sanders, 2003).']

['Teacher: Can you explain how the relationship between religiosity and happiness can vary depending on societal circumstances?', 'However, the relationship between religiosity and happiness depends on societal circumstances.']

['Teacher: What are some factors that contribute to societies with difficult living conditions being more highly religious compared to societies with more favorable living conditions?', 'Nations and states with more difficult living conditions (e.g., widespread hunger and low life expectancy) tend to be more highly religious than societies with more favorable living conditions.']

['Teacher: How does the level of religiosity affect the well-being of individuals living in societies with difficult living conditions compared to societies with more favorable living conditions?', 'Among those who live in nations with difficult living conditions, religiosity is associated with greater well-being; in nations with more favorable living conditions, religious and nonreligious individuals report similar levels of well-being (Diener, Tay, & Myers, 2011).']

["Teacher: How can the living conditions of one's nation potentially affect factors connected to happiness?", 'Clearly the living conditions of one’s nation can influence factors related to happiness.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how the living conditions of a nation can influence factors connected to happiness based on the passage?', 'To the extent that people possess characteristics that are highly valued by their culture, they tend to be happier (Diener, 2012).']

['Teacher: According to the passage, what are some characteristics that are highly valued by cultures and can potentially influence factors connected to happiness?', 'For example, self-esteem is a stronger predictor of life satisfaction in individualistic cultures than in collectivistic cultures (Diener, Diener, & Diener, 1995), and extraverted people tend to be happier in extraverted cultures than in introverted cultures (Fulmer et al., 2010).']
['Teacher: Can you provide examples of some factors that exhibit some correlation to happiness?', 'So we’ve identified many factors that exhibit some correlation to happiness.']

['Teacher: Can you elaborate on the research findings regarding parenthood and physical attractiveness as potential factors contributing to happiness?', 'Researchers have studied both parenthood and physical attractiveness as potential contributors to happiness, but no link has been identified.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why the aggregate findings suggest that people who do not have children are generally happier than those who do, despite the belief that parenthood is central to a meaningful and fulfilling life?', 'Although people tend to believe that parenthood is central to a meaningful and fulﬁlling life, aggregate findings from a range of countries indicate that people who do not have children are generally happier than those who do (Hansen, 2012).']

['Teacher: According to the research, what do the aggregate findings suggest about the happiness of people who have children compared to those who do not?', 'And although one’s perceived level of attractiveness seems to predict happiness, a person’s objective physical attractiveness is only weakly correlated with their happiness (Diener, Wolsic, & Fujita, 1995).']
['Teacher: What is the important point that should be considered regarding happiness?', 'An important point should be considered regarding happiness.']

['Teacher: Why are people often poor at affective forecasting, according to Wilson and Gilbert (2003)?', 'People are often poor at affective forecasting: predicting the intensity and duration of their future emotions (Wilson & Gilbert, 2003).']
