['Teacher: What is an example of a study that supports the idea that people are often poor at affective forecasting?', 'In one study, nearly all newlywed spouses predicted their marital satisfaction would remain stable or improve over the following four years; despite this high level of initial optimism, their marital satisfaction actually declined during this period (Lavner, Karner, & Bradbury, 2013).']

['Teacher: Can you provide another example that demonstrates how people may be incorrect when estimating their long-term happiness in response to life events?', 'In addition, we are often incorrect when estimating how our long-term happiness would change for the better or worse in response to certain life events.']

['Teacher: What is a common misconception that people have regarding their long-term happiness when it comes to winning the lottery, being asked on a date by an attractive celebrity, or getting their dream job?', 'For example, it is easy for many of us to imagine how euphoric we would feel if we won the lottery, were asked on a date by an attractive celebrity, or were offered our dream job.']

['What was the reality for the long-suffering fans of the Chicago Cubs baseball team after they finally won another World Series in 2016?', 'It is also easy to understand how long-suffering fans of the Chicago Cubs baseball team, which had not won a World Series championship since 1908, thought they would feel permanently elated when their team finally won another World Series in 2016.']

['What is the reality for the long-suffering fans of the Chicago Cubs baseball team after they finally won another World Series in 2016?', 'Likewise, it is easy to predict that we would feel permanently miserable if we suffered a disabling accident or if a romantic relationship ended.']

['Teacher: What are some similarities to sensory adaptation that occur when people experience emotional reactions to life events?', 'However, something similar to sensory adaptation often occurs when people experience emotional reactions to life events.']

['How is the process of adapting to changing emotional circumstances similar to sensory adaptation?', 'In much the same way our senses adapt to changes in stimulation (e.g., our eyes adapting to bright light after walking out of the darkness of a movie theater into the bright afternoon sun), we eventually adapt to changing emotional circumstances in our lives (Brickman & Campbell, 1971; Helson, 1964).']

['How does our initial experience of the emotional impact of life events differ from our long-term emotional adaptation?', 'When an event that provokes positive or negative emotions occurs, at first we tend to experience its emotional impact at full intensity.']

['What can we compare the burst of pleasure that follows positive life events to?', 'We feel a burst of pleasure following such things as a marriage proposal, birth of a child, acceptance to law school, an inheritance, and the like; as you might imagine, lottery winners experience a surge of happiness after hitting the jackpot (Lutter, 2007).']
['What is the emotional reaction that follows negative life events similar to?', 'Likewise, we experience a surge of misery following widowhood, a divorce, or a layoff from work.']

['What happens to our emotional baseline levels in the long run after experiencing negative life events?', 'In the long run, however, we eventually adjust to the emotional new normal; the emotional impact of the event tends to erode, and we eventually revert to our original baseline happiness levels.']

['How does our long-term emotional adaptation to positive life events compare to our initial burst of pleasure?', 'Thus, what was at first a thrilling lottery windfall or World Series championship eventually loses its luster and becomes the status quo (Figure 14.27).']

['How do dramatic life events impact long-term happiness levels?', 'Indeed, dramatic life events have much less long-lasting impact on happiness than might be expected (Brickman, Coats, & Janoff-Bulman, 1978).']

["Teacher: What is the focus of the questions that have been raised concerning the extent to which important life events can permanently alter people's happiness set points?", 'Recently, some have raised questions concerning the extent to which important life events can permanently alter people’s happiness set points (Diener, Lucas, & Scollon, 2006).']

['Teacher: What does the evidence indicate about the reversion of happiness levels to their original positions in certain circumstances?', 'Evidence from a number of investigations suggests that, in some circumstances, happiness levels do not revert to their original positions.']

['Teacher: What are some life events that people typically do not fully adapt to in terms of their happiness levels?', 'For example, although people generally tend to adapt to marriage so that it no longer makes them happier or unhappier than before, they often do not fully adapt to unemployment or severe disabilities (Diener, 2012).']

['Teacher: How does Figure 14.28 demonstrate the concept of adaptation to different life events and its impact on life satisfaction scores?', 'Figure 14.28, which is based on longitudinal data from a sample of over 3,000 German respondents, shows life satisfaction scores several years before, during, and after various life events, and it illustrates how people adapt (or fail to adapt) to these events.']

['Teacher: How do German respondents typically experience happiness levels after getting married, according to the data from Figure 14.28?', 'German respondents did not get lasting emotional boosts from marriage; instead, they reported brief increases in happiness, followed by quick adaptation.']

['Teacher: How do widows and individuals who have been laid off typically experience changes in their happiness levels, according to the findings mentioned in the passage?', 'In contrast, widows and those who had been laid off experienced sizeable decreases in happiness that appeared to result in long-term changes in life satisfaction (Diener et al., 2006).']

['Teacher: What percentage of respondents in the study showed major changes in their happiness levels over time?', 'Further, longitudinal data from the same sample showed that happiness levels changed significantly over time for nearly a quarter of respondents, with 9% showing major changes (Fujita & Diener, 2005).']

['Teacher: How do people typically adapt to the experience of unemployment or severe disabilities in terms of their happiness levels, based on the information provided?\nStudent: People often do not fully adapt to unemployment or severe disabilities.', 'Thus, long-term happiness levels can and do change for some people.']

['Teacher: What do recent findings about happiness suggest in terms of real changes?', 'Some recent findings about happiness provide an optimistic picture, suggesting that real changes in happiness are possible.']

["Teacher: How can thoughtfully developed well-being interventions potentially impact a person's baseline levels of happiness?", 'For example, thoughtfully developed well-being interventions designed to augment people’s baseline levels of happiness may increase happiness in ways that are permanent and long-lasting, not just temporary.']

['Teacher: How might interventions targeting individual, organizational, and societal levels contribute to sustainable changes in happiness?', 'These changes in happiness may be targeted at individual, organizational, and societal levels (Diener et al., 2006).']

['How can writing down three good things that occurred each day potentially contribute to sustainable changes in happiness?', 'Researchers in one study found that a series of happiness interventions involving such exercises as writing down three good things that occurred each day led to increases in happiness that lasted over six months (Seligman et al., 2005).']

['Teacher: How can measuring happiness and well-being at the societal level assist policy makers?', 'Measuring happiness and well-being at the societal level over time may assist policy makers in determining if people are generally happy or miserable, as well as when and why they might feel the way they do.']

['What are the six key variables that studies have shown to relate strongly to average national happiness scores?', 'Studies show that average national happiness scores (over time and across countries) relate strongly to six key variables: per capita gross domestic product (GDP, which reflects a nation’s economic standard of living), social support, freedom to make important life choices, healthy life expectancy, freedom from perceived corruption in government and business, and generosity (Helliwell et al., 2013).']

['What is the significance of investigating why people are happy or unhappy for policymakers?', 'Investigating why people are happy or unhappy might help policymakers develop programs that increase happiness and well-being within a society (Diener et al., 2006).']

["What are some examples of contemporary political and social issues that policymakers should consider with people's happiness in mind?", 'Resolutions about contemporary political and social issues that are frequent topics of debate—such as poverty, taxation, affordable health care and housing, clean air and water, and income inequality—might be best considered with people’s happiness in mind.']

['Teacher: Who was the president of the American Psychological Association in 1998?', 'In 1998, Seligman (the same person who conducted the learned helplessness experiments mentioned earlier), who was then president of the American Psychological Association, urged psychologists to focus more on understanding how to build human strength and psychological well-being.']

['What was the name of the movement and field of research that Seligman helped establish?', 'In deliberately setting out to create a new direction and new orientation for psychology, Seligman helped establish a growing movement and field of research called positive psychology (Compton, 2005).']

['What is the main focus or goal of positive psychology?', 'In a very general sense, positive psychology can be thought of as the science of happiness; it is an area of study that seeks to identify and promote those qualities that lead to greater fulfillment in our lives.']

['What are some areas of focus in positive psychology that differentiate it from traditional psychology?', 'This field looks at people’s strengths and what helps individuals to lead happy, contented lives, and it moves away from focusing on people’s pathology, faults, and problems.']

['focuses on studying the positive aspects of human experiences, such as positive emotions, character strengths, and optimal functioning.', 'According to Seligman and Csikszentmihalyi (2000), positive psychology,']

['Teacher: What are some of the topics that positive psychologists study?', 'Some of the topics studied by positive psychologists include altruism and empathy, creativity, forgiveness and compassion, the importance of positive emotions, enhancement of immune system functioning, savoring the fleeting moments of life, and strengthening virtues as a way to increase authentic happiness (Compton, 2005).']

['What are some recent efforts in the field of positive psychology and how do they aim to extend its principles?', 'Recent efforts in the field of positive psychology have focused on extending its principles toward peace and well-being at the level of the global community.']

['What are the potential implications of applying positive psychology principles to promote global peace in a war-torn world?', 'In a war-torn world in which conflict, hatred, and distrust are common, such an extended “positive peace psychology” could have important implications for understanding how to overcome oppression and work toward global peace (Cohrs, Christie, White, & Das, 2013).']

['Teacher: What has extensive research over the last 10-15 years examined in relation to physical well-being, taking inspiration from positive psychology?', 'Taking a cue from positive psychology, extensive research over the last 10-15 years has examined the importance of positive psychological attributes in physical well-being.']

['What specific psychological attributes are linked with favorable health outcomes, according to the research mentioned in the passage?', 'Qualities that help promote psychological well-being (e.g., having meaning and purpose in life, a sense of autonomy, positive emotions, and satisfaction with life) are linked with a range of favorable health outcomes (especially improved cardiovascular health) mainly through their relationships with biological functions and health behaviors (such as diet, physical activity, and sleep quality) (Boehm & Kubzansky, 2012).']

['What does the term "positive affect" refer to, according to the passage?', 'The quality that has received attention is positive affect, which refers to pleasurable engagement with the environment, such as happiness, joy, enthusiasm, alertness, and excitement (Watson, Clark, & Tellegen, 1988).']

['What are some characteristics of positive affect, as mentioned in the passage?', 'The characteristics of positive affect, as with negative affect (discussed earlier), can be brief, long-lasting, or trait-like (Pressman & Cohen, 2005).']

['What are some of the associations of positive affect, according to the passage?', 'Independent of age, gender, and income, positive affect is associated with greater social connectedness, emotional and practical support, adaptive coping efforts, and lower depression; it is also associated with longevity and favorable physiological functioning (Steptoe, O’Donnell, Marmot, & Wardle, 2008).']
['Teacher: How does positive affect contribute to protecting against heart disease?', 'Positive affect also serves as a protective factor against heart disease.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a study that supports the link between positive affect and protection against heart disease?', 'In a 10-year study of Nova Scotians, the rate of heart disease was 22% lower for each one-point increase on the measure of positive affect, from 1 (no positive affect expressed) to 5 (extreme positive affect) (Davidson, Mostofsky, & Whang, 2010).']
['Teacher: Why is positive affect considered a protective factor against heart disease?', 'In terms of our health, the expression, “don’t worry, be happy” is helpful advice indeed.']

['Why is optimism considered a significant predictor of positive health outcomes?', 'There has also been much work suggesting that optimism—the general tendency to look on the bright side of things—is also a significant predictor of positive health outcomes.']

['Teacher: How would you describe the relationship between positive affect and optimism according to the study by Pressman & Cohen in 2005?', 'Although positive affect and optimism are related in some ways, they are not the same (Pressman & Cohen, 2005).']

['What is the difference between positive affect and optimism, according to the study by Pressman & Cohen in 2005?', 'Whereas positive affect is mostly concerned with positive feeling states, optimism has been regarded as a generalized tendency to expect that good things will happen (Chang, 2001).']

['How has optimism been conceptualized in the study by Peterson & Steen in 2002?', 'It has also been conceptualized as a tendency to view life’s stressors and difficulties as temporary and external to oneself (Peterson & Steen, 2002).']

['What are some of the positive outcomes or benefits that have been associated with optimism, according to the study by Rasmussen & Wallio in 2008?', 'Numerous studies over the years have consistently shown that optimism is linked to longevity, healthier behaviors, fewer postsurgical complications, better immune functioning among men with prostate cancer, and better treatment adherence (Rasmussen & Wallio, 2008).']

['What are some of the physical benefits associated with optimism, according to the study by Rasmussen, Scheier, & Greenhouse in 2009?', 'Further, optimistic people report fewer physical symptoms, less pain, better physical functioning, and are less likely to be rehospitalized following heart surgery (Rasmussen, Scheier, & Greenhouse, 2009).']

['Teacher: What is another factor that appears to be significant in cultivating a profound feeling of well-being?', 'Another factor that seems to be important in fostering a deep sense of well-being is the ability to derive flow from the things we do in life.']

['Teacher: How would you define flow in relation to the things we do in life?', 'Flow is described as a particular experience that is so engaging and engrossing that it becomes worth doing for its own sake (Csikszentmihalyi, 1997).']

['Teacher: Can you provide some examples of activities that can elicit a state of flow?', 'It is usually related to creative endeavors and leisure activities, but it can also be experienced by workers who like their jobs or students who love studying (Csikszentmihalyi, 1999).']
['Teacher: How does our recognition of the notion of flow contribute to experiencing a sense of well-being in our lives?', 'Many of us instantly recognize the notion of flow.']

['Teacher: How does the recognition of the notion of flow contribute to experiencing a sense of well-being in our lives? Can you provide any specific examples or explanations to support your answer?', 'In fact, the term derived from respondents’ spontaneous use of the term when asked to describe how it felt when what they were doing was going well.']

['Teacher: Can you elaborate on how losing oneself in an activity contributes to experiencing a sense of well-being?', 'When people experience flow, they become involved in an activity to the point where they feel they lose themselves in the activity.']

['What are some characteristics or experiences that people have when they are in a state of flow?', 'They effortlessly maintain their concentration and focus, they feel as though they have complete control of their actions, and time seems to pass more quickly than usual (Csikszentmihalyi, 1997).']

['What are some examples of challenging activities that can elicit a state of flow?', 'Flow is considered a pleasurable experience, and it typically occurs when people are engaged in challenging activities that require skills and knowledge they know they possess.']

['What is an example of an activity that is unlikely to elicit a state of flow according to the passage?', 'For example, people would be more likely report flow experiences in relation to their work or hobbies than in relation to eating.']

['What percentage of Americans and Europeans report having flow-like experiences regularly when asked the question, "Do you ever get involved in something so deeply that nothing else seems to matter, and you lose track of time?"?', 'When asked the question, “Do you ever get involved in something so deeply that nothing else seems to matter, and you lose track of time?” about 20% of Americans and Europeans report having these flow-like experiences regularly (Csikszentmihalyi, 1997).']

['Teacher: What does the notion of flow suggest about wealth and material possessions in relation to a happy and fulfilling life?', 'Although wealth and material possessions are nice to have, the notion of flow suggests that neither are prerequisites for a happy and fulfilling life.']

['What does the notion of flow prioritize over wealth and material possessions for a happy and fulfilling life?', 'Finding an activity that you are truly enthusiastic about, something so absorbing that doing it is reward itself (whether it be playing tennis, studying Arabic, writing children’s novels, or cooking lavish meals) is perhaps the real key.']

['What does Csikszentmihalyi suggest should be a top social and political priority based on the notion of flow?', 'According to Csikszentmihalyi (1999), creating conditions that make flow experiences possible should be a top social and political priority.']

['Teacher: What is the desired outcome of scientific research endeavors in an ideal world?', 'In an ideal world, scientific research endeavors should inform us on how to bring about a better world for all people.']

['Teacher: How does positive psychology contribute to our understanding of flow and genuine personal fulfillment?', 'The field of positive psychology promises to be instrumental in helping us understand what truly builds hope, optimism, happiness, healthy relationships, flow, and genuine personal fulfillment.']

['Teacher: How does the American Psychiatric Association define a psychological disorder?', "According to the American Psychiatric Association, a psychological disorder, or mental disorder, is “a syndrome characterized by clinically significant disturbance in an individual's cognition, emotion regulation, or behavior that reflects a dysfunction in the psychological, biological, or developmental processes underlying mental functioning."]

['What are the three main areas that a psychological disorder can impact according to the American Psychiatric Association?', 'Mental disorders are usually associated with significant distress in social, occupational, or other important activities” (2013).']
['What is psychopathology?', 'Psychopathology is the study of psychological disorders, including their symptoms, etiology (i.e., their causes), and treatment.']
['What does the term psychopathology encompass in the study of psychological disorders?', 'The term psychopathology can also refer to the manifestation of a psychological disorder.']

['What is the importance of consensus among mental health professionals when determining what constitutes abnormal thoughts, feelings, and behaviors?', 'Although consensus can be difficult, it is extremely important for mental health professionals to agree on what kinds of thoughts, feelings, and behaviors are truly abnormal in the sense that they genuinely indicate the presence of psychopathology.']

['What are some examples of patterns of behavior and inner experience that can be labeled as abnormal in the context of psychological disorders?', 'Certain patterns of behavior and inner experience can easily be labeled as abnormal and clearly signify some kind of psychological disturbance.']

['What are some examples of behaviors and inner experiences that most people would consider abnormal and indicative of a psychological disorder?', 'The person who washes their hands 40 times per day and the person who claims to hear the voices of demons exhibit behaviors and inner experiences that most would regard as abnormal: beliefs and behaviors that suggest the existence of a psychological disorder.']

['Why is it important for mental health professionals to differentiate between normal experiences and psychological disorders?', 'But, consider the nervousness a young man feels when talking to an attractive person or the loneliness and longing for home a first-year student experiences during her first semester of college—these feelings may not be regularly present, but they fall in the range of normal.']

['What factors do psychologists consider when distinguishing psychological disorders from situational, idiosyncratic, or unconventional experiences?', 'Psychologists work to distinguish psychological disorders from inner experiences and behaviors that are merely situational, idiosyncratic, or unconventional.']

['Teacher: Why are mental health issues sometimes viewed as less important than physical illnesses, leading to blame or stigma towards the individuals experiencing them?', 'Mental health issues are often incorrectly viewed as less important than physical illnesses, and sometimes people are blamed or otherwise stigmatized for their condition.']

['Teacher: Why is it incorrect to view mental health issues as less important than physical illnesses and blame or stigmatize individuals experiencing them?', 'People with mental illnesses did not choose or create their illness, and cannot simply manage it through positive thinking or other attitudinal changes.']

['Teacher: What factors should be considered when providing diagnosis, treatment, and support for individuals with mental illnesses?', 'Diagnosis, treatment, and support are all necessary, and all must be considered with respect and sensitivity to the extremely challenging nature of mental illness.']

['Teacher: Why is mental health critical to our ability to function in our relationships, education, and work?', 'While not everyone experiencing difficulty has a psychological disorder, mental health is critical to our ability to function in our relationships, education, and work.']

['What actions should individuals take if they are experiencing persistent feelings or experiences related to psychological disorders?', 'It is important that people talk with qualified professionals if they are having persistent feelings or experiences in line with the descriptions below; the discussion may or may not lead to a diagnosis, but as with physical illnesses, one has a better chance at success if they raise the issues with doctors or other experts.']

['Teacher: How would you describe the simplest way of conceptualizing psychological disorders?', 'Perhaps the simplest approach to conceptualizing psychological disorders is to label behaviors, thoughts, and inner experiences that are atypical, distressful, dysfunctional, and sometimes even dangerous, as signs of a disorder.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of an atypical behavior that might be considered a sign of a psychological disorder?', 'For example, if you ask a classmate for a date and you are rejected, you probably would feel a little dejected.']
['Teacher: Why would the feeling of being rejected after asking a classmate for a date be considered normal?', 'Such feelings would be normal.']

['Teacher: What are some examples of behaviors, thoughts, or inner experiences that might signify the presence of a psychological disorder?', 'If you felt extremely depressed—so much so that you lost interest in activities, had difficulty eating or sleeping, felt utterly worthless, and contemplated suicide—your feelings would be atypical, would deviate from the norm, and could signify the presence of a psychological disorder.']

['Teacher: Why is it important to consider more than just atypicality when determining if something is a psychological disorder?', 'Just because something is atypical, however, does not necessarily mean it is disordered.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the difference between an atypical characteristic and a psychological disorder?', 'For example, only about 4% of people in the United States have red hair, so red hair is considered an atypical characteristic (Figure 15.2), but it is not considered disordered, it’s just unusual.']

['Teacher: Can you provide another example of an atypical characteristic that is not considered disordered?', 'And it is less unusual in Scotland, where approximately 13% of the population has red hair (“DNA Project Aims,” 2012).']

['What can you say about the rates of certain psychological disorders in the population?', 'As you will learn, some disorders, although not exactly typical, are far from atypical, and the rates in which they appear in the population are surprisingly high.']

['Teacher: According to the passage, what does it suggest might be the case for a person who walks around a subway platform wearing a heavy winter coat in July while screaming obscenities at strangers?', 'Using this criterion, a person who walks around a subway platform wearing a heavy winter coat in July while screaming obscenities at strangers may be considered as exhibiting symptoms of a psychological disorder.']

["Teacher: What are the two criteria mentioned in the passage that suggest the person's behavior could be considered as symptoms of a psychological disorder?", 'Their actions and clothes violate socially accepted rules governing appropriate dress and behavior; these characteristics are atypical.']

['Teacher: What is the implication of violating cultural expectations when it comes to identifying a psychological disorder?', 'Violating cultural expectations is not, in and of itself, a satisfactory means of identifying the presence of a psychological disorder.']

['Teacher: Why is it important to consider cultural expectations when identifying a psychological disorder?', 'Since behavior varies from one culture to another, what may be expected and considered appropriate in one culture may not be viewed as such in other cultures.']

['Teacher: Can you provide another example of how cultural expectations can vary when it comes to identifying a psychological disorder?', 'For example, returning a stranger’s smile is expected in the United States because a pervasive social norm dictates that we reciprocate friendly gestures.']

["Teacher: How does violating cultural expectations in the United States regarding reciprocating friendly gestures impact the perception of an individual's social competence?", 'A person who refuses to acknowledge such gestures might be considered socially awkward—perhaps even disordered—for violating this expectation.']

['Teacher: Why is it important to recognize that cultural expectations regarding reciprocating friendly gestures are not universally shared?', 'However, such expectations are not universally shared.']

['How might failing to show reserve, restraint, and a concern for privacy around strangers be perceived in Japan?', 'Cultural expectations in Japan involve showing reserve, restraint, and a concern for maintaining privacy around strangers.']

['Teacher: How might a person from Japan perceive someone who openly smiles at them in a public setting?', 'Japanese people are generally unresponsive to smiles from strangers (Patterson et al., 2007).']
['Teacher: How does the expectation of eye contact vary across cultures when it comes to perceiving social competence?', 'Eye contact provides another example.']
['Teacher: How is eye contact perceived in cultures where it is not expected or valued?', 'In the United States and Europe, eye contact with others typically signifies honesty and attention.']

['Teacher: How might the perception of honesty and attention be affected in Latin-American, Asian, and African cultures where direct eye contact is considered rude, confrontational, and aggressive?', 'However, most Latin-American, Asian, and African cultures interpret direct eye contact as rude, confrontational, and aggressive (Pazain, 2010).']

['What is the potential impact of misinterpreting eye contact in different cultural contexts?', 'Thus, someone who makes eye contact with you could be considered appropriate and respectful or brazen and offensive, depending on your culture (Figure 15.3).']

['Teacher: How is the reporting of hallucinations seen in Western societies, and what happens to individuals who report such inner experiences?', 'Hallucinations (seeing or hearing things that are not physically present) in Western societies is a violation of cultural expectations, and a person who reports such inner experiences is readily labeled as psychologically disordered.']

['Teacher: How are hallucinations viewed in other cultures, and how are individuals who report such inner experiences perceived in those societies?', 'In other cultures, visions that, for example, pertain to future events may be regarded as normal experiences that are positively valued (Bourguignon, 1970).']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a cultural norm that has changed over time, similar to how the perception of hallucinations varies in different societies?', 'Finally, it is important to recognize that cultural norms change over time: what might be considered typical in a society at one time may no longer be viewed this way later, similar to how fashion trends from one era may elicit quizzical looks decades later—imagine how a headband, legwarmers, and the big hair of the 1980s would go over on your campus today.']

['Teacher: What has been the focus of many efforts in trying to understand psychological disorders?', 'Many efforts have been made to identify the specific dimensions of psychological disorders, yet none is entirely satisfactory.']

['Teacher: Why is it challenging to establish a universal definition of psychological disorder?', 'No universal definition of psychological disorder exists that can apply to all situations in which a disorder is thought to be present (Zachar & Kendler, 2007).']

['Teacher: According to Wakefield (1992), how did he define psychological disorder?', 'However, one of the more influential conceptualizations was proposed by Wakefield (1992), who defined psychological disorder as a harmful dysfunction.']

['Teacher: How does Wakefield define psychological disorder as a harmful dysfunction?', 'Wakefield argued that natural internal mechanisms—that is, psychological processes honed by evolution, such as cognition, perception, and learning—have important functions, such as enabling us to experience the world the way others do and to engage in rational thought, problem solving, and communication.']

["Teacher: According to Wakefield's definition, what is the role of natural internal mechanisms in psychological disorders?", 'For example, learning allows us to associate a fear with a potential danger in such a way that the intensity of fear is roughly equal to the degree of actual danger.']

["Teacher: According to Wakefield's definition of psychological disorder, what happens when an internal mechanism breaks down and can no longer perform its normal function?", 'Dysfunction occurs when an internal mechanism breaks down and can no longer perform its normal function.']

["Teacher: According to Wakefield's definition of psychological disorder, what additional criteria must be met for a dysfunction to be considered a disorder?", 'But, the presence of a dysfunction by itself does not determine a disorder.']

["Teacher: According to Wakefield's definition of psychological disorder, what must also be present for a dysfunction to be considered a disorder?", 'The dysfunction must be harmful in that it leads to negative consequences for the individual or for others, as judged by the standards of the individual’s culture.']

["According to Wakefield's definition of psychological disorder, what types of negative consequences can result from a dysfunction that is considered a disorder?", 'The harm may include significant internal anguish (e.g., high levels of anxiety or depression) or problems in day-to-day living (e.g., in one’s social or work life).']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example that helps explain the concept of Harmful Dysfunction?', 'To illustrate, Janet has an extreme fear of spiders.']

["Teacher: How does Janet's extreme fear of spiders demonstrate the concept of Harmful Dysfunction?", 'Janet’s fear might be considered a dysfunction in that it signals that the internal mechanism of learning is not working correctly (i.e., a faulty process prevents Janet from appropriately associating the magnitude of fear with the actual threat posed by spiders).']

["Teacher: What are some examples of the negative impact that Janet's extreme fear of spiders has on her daily life?", 'Janet’s fear of spiders has a significant negative influence on daily life: she avoids all situations in which she suspects spiders to be present (e.g., the basement or a friend’s home), and she quit her job last month because she saw a spider in the restroom at work and is now unemployed.']

["Teacher: According to the harmful dysfunction model, what elements need to be present for Janet's extreme fear of spiders to be considered a disorder?", 'According to the harmful dysfunction model, Janet’s condition would signify a disorder because (a) there is a dysfunction in an internal mechanism, and (b) the dysfunction has resulted in harmful consequences.']

['Teacher: How does the harmful dysfunction model view psychological disorders in relation to physical illnesses?', 'Similar to how the symptoms of physical illness reflect dysfunctions in biological processes, the symptoms of psychological disorders presumably reflect dysfunctions in mental processes.']

['Teacher: How does the harmful dysfunction model support contemporary neurobiological models of psychological disorders?', 'The internal mechanism component of this model is especially appealing because it implies that disorders may occur through a breakdown of biological functions that govern various psychological processes, thus supporting contemporary neurobiological models of psychological disorders (Fabrega, 2007).']

['Teacher: Who developed the formal definition of psychological disorder?', 'Many of the features of the harmful dysfunction model are incorporated in a formal definition of psychological disorder developed by the American Psychiatric Association (APA).']

["Teacher: Can you explain what the APA's formal definition of psychological disorder consists of?", 'According to the APA (2013), a psychological disorder is a condition that is said to consist of the following:']
['Teacher: According to the passage, what can be observed in individuals affected by the disturbances mentioned?', 'There are significant disturbances in thoughts, feelings, and behaviors.']

['What are some examples of disturbed behaviors mentioned in the passage?', 'A person must experience inner states (e.g., thoughts and/or feelings) and exhibit behaviors that are clearly disturbed—that is, unusual, but in a negative, self-defeating way.']

['What is the impact of disturbances on individuals around the person experiencing them, according to the passage?', 'Often, such disturbances are troubling to those around the individual who experiences them.']

['What are some examples of specific disturbances mentioned in the passage?', 'For example, an individual who is uncontrollably preoccupied by thoughts of germs spends hours each day bathing, has inner experiences, and displays behaviors that most would consider atypical and negative (disturbed) and that would likely be troubling to family members.']
['What are the potential causes of the disturbances mentioned in the passage?', 'The disturbances reflect some kind of biological, psychological, or developmental dysfunction.']

['What do the disturbed patterns of inner experiences and behaviors reflect, according to the passage?', 'Disturbed patterns of inner experiences and behaviors should reflect some flaw (dysfunction) in the internal biological, psychological, and developmental mechanisms that lead to normal, healthy psychological functioning.']

['What is an example of a specific disturbance mentioned in the passage that could be a sign of brain abnormalities?', 'For example, the hallucinations observed in schizophrenia could be a sign of brain abnormalities.']
['What is the outcome of the disturbances mentioned in the passage?', 'The disturbances lead to significant distress or disability in one’s life.']

["What are the criteria for considering an individual's inner experiences and behaviors as a psychological disorder, according to the passage?", 'A person’s inner experiences and behaviors are considered to reflect a psychological disorder if they cause the person considerable distress, or greatly impair their ability to function as a normal individual (often referred to as functional impairment, or occupational and social impairment).']

['What are some examples of functional impairment mentioned in the passage?', 'As an illustration, a person’s fear of social situations might be so distressing that it causes the person to avoid all social situations (e.g., preventing that person from being able to attend class or apply for a job).']

["What is one of the criteria mentioned in the passage for considering an individual's inner experiences and behaviors as a psychological disorder?", 'The disturbances do not reflect expected or culturally approved responses to certain events.']

['What is the requirement for disturbances in thoughts, feelings, and behaviors to be considered as a psychological disorder, according to the passage?', 'Disturbances in thoughts, feelings, and behaviors must be socially unacceptable responses to certain events that often happen in life.']

['Can you give an example of a situation where disturbances in thoughts, feelings, and behaviors would not be considered as a psychological disorder according to the passage?', 'For example, it is perfectly natural (and expected) that a person would experience great sadness and might wish to be left alone following the death of a close family member.']

['What is one of the criteria mentioned in the passage for disturbances in thoughts, feelings, and behaviors to be considered as a psychological disorder?', 'Because such reactions are in some ways culturally expected, the individual would not be assumed to signify a mental disorder.']

['Teacher: What do some believe about the essential criterion or set of criteria that can distinguish all cases of disorder from nondisorder?', 'Some believe that there is no essential criterion or set of criteria that can definitively distinguish all cases of disorder from nondisorder (Lilienfeld & Marino, 1999).']

['Teacher: Why do some believe that no essential criterion or set of criteria can definitively distinguish all cases of disorder from nondisorder?', 'In truth, no single approach to defining a psychological disorder is adequate by itself, nor is there universal agreement on where the boundary is between disordered and not disordered.']

['Teacher: What challenges arise when trying to establish a universal boundary between disordered and not disordered behavior?', 'From time to time we all experience anxiety, unwanted thoughts, and moments of sadness; our behavior at other times may not make much sense to ourselves or to others.']

['Teacher: How are inner experiences and behaviors considered disordered?', 'These inner experiences and behaviors can vary in their intensity, but are only considered disordered when they are highly disturbing to us and/or others, suggest a dysfunction in normal mental functioning, and are associated with significant distress or disability in social or occupational activities.']

['Teacher: What is a crucial initial step when it comes to studying psychological disorders?', 'A first step in the study of psychological disorders is carefully and systematically discerning significant signs and symptoms.']

['What is the significance of arriving at a proper diagnosis when studying psychological disorders?', 'Arriving at a proper diagnosis—that is, appropriately identifying and labeling a set of defined symptoms—is absolutely crucial.']

['What are the benefits of using a common language and proper communication when diagnosing psychological disorders?', 'This process enables professionals to use a common language with others in the field and aids in communication about the disorder with the patient, colleagues and the public.']
['Why is a proper diagnosis essential in guiding treatment for psychological disorders?', 'A proper diagnosis is an essential element to guide proper and successful treatment.']

['What is the purpose of classification systems in the study of psychological disorders?', 'For these reasons, classification systems that organize psychological disorders systematically are necessary.']

['Teacher: What is the name of the classification system that is commonly used by mental health professionals in the United States?', 'Although a number of classification systems have been developed over time, the one that is used by most mental health professionals in the United States is the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), published by the American Psychiatric Association (2013).']

['Teacher: Who is the publisher of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5)?', '(Note that the American Psychiatric Association differs from the American Psychological Association; both are abbreviated APA.)']

['Who developed the format that the first edition of the DSM used to classify psychological disorders?', 'The first edition of the DSM, published in 1952, classified psychological disorders according to a format developed by the U.S. Army during World War II (Clegg, 2012).']
['Teacher: What is the latest edition of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM)?', 'In the years since, the DSM has undergone numerous revisions and editions.']

['Teacher: What year was the DSM-5, the latest edition of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, published?', 'The most recent edition, published in 2013, is the DSM-5 (APA, 2013).']

['What are some examples of the categories of disorders included in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5)?', 'The DSM-5 includes many categories of disorders (e.g., anxiety disorders, depressive disorders, and dissociative disorders).']

['Teacher: What information does the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5) provide about each disorder?', 'Each disorder is described in detail, including an overview of the disorder (diagnostic features), specific symptoms required for diagnosis (diagnostic criteria), prevalence information (what percent of the population is thought to be afflicted with the disorder), and risk factors associated with the disorder.']

['What type of information does Figure 15.4 in the textbook provide about psychological disorders among U.S. adults?', 'Figure 15.4 shows lifetime prevalence rates—the percentage of people in a population who develop a disorder in their lifetime—of various psychological disorders among U.S. adults.']

['What are some examples of the psychological disorders included in Figure 15.4 in the textbook?', 'These data were based on a national sample of 9,282 U.S. residents (National Comorbidity Survey, 2007).']

['Teacher: According to the passage, what does the DSM-5 provide information about in relation to disorders?', 'The DSM-5 also provides information about comorbidity; the co-occurrence of two disorders.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of comorbidity mentioned in the DSM-5, where two disorders co-occur?', 'For example, the DSM-5 mentions that 41% of people with obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) also meet the diagnostic criteria for major depressive disorder (Figure 15.5).']

['Teacher: Can you explain why comorbidity is an important concept in understanding mental disorders?', 'Problematic substance use is highly comorbid with other mental illnesses; 6 out of 10 people who have a substance use disorder also suffer from another form of mental illness (National Institute on Drug Abuse [NIDA], 2007).']
['Teacher: How has the DSM evolved over the past fifty years?', 'The DSM has changed considerably in the half-century since it was originally published.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a significant change in the DSM over the years and explain its impact?', 'The first two editions of the DSM, for example, listed homosexuality as a disorder; however, in 1973, the APA voted to remove it from the manual (Silverstein, 2009).']

['Teacher: How did the DSM-III address the issue of homosexuality and what was the new diagnosis it introduced?', 'While the DSM-III did not list homosexuality as a disorder, it introduced a new diagnosis, ego-dystonic homosexuality, which emphasized same-sex arousal that the patient viewed as interfering with desired heterosexual relationships and causing distress for the individual.']

['Teacher: How did the removal of homosexuality as a disorder from the DSM-III impact the perception and understanding of homosexuality as a mental illness?', 'This new diagnosis was considered by many as a compromise to appease those who viewed homosexuality as a mental illness.']

['Teacher: What were some of the concerns raised by professionals regarding the introduction of the new diagnosis of ego-dystonic homosexuality in the DSM-III?', "Other professionals questioned how appropriate it was to have a separate diagnosis that described the content of an individual's distress."]
['Teacher: How did the removal of ego-dystonic homosexuality from the DSM-III-R address the concerns raised by professionals?', 'In 1986, the diagnosis was removed from the DSM-III-R (Herek, 2012).']

['Teacher: How did the increased detail and the growing number of diagnosable conditions in the DSM-III impact the field of mental health?', 'Additionally, beginning with the DSM-III in 1980, mental disorders have been described in much greater detail, and the number of diagnosable conditions has grown steadily, as has the size of the manual itself.']

['Teacher: How did the increased detail and number of diagnosable conditions in the DSM-III impact the field of mental health?', 'DSM-I included 106 diagnoses and was 130 total pages, whereas DSM-III included more than 2 times as many diagnoses (265) and was nearly seven times its size (886 total pages) (Mayes & Horowitz, 2005).']

['What is the difference in the number of disorders listed in the DSM-IV compared to the DSM-5, and what does this indicate about the evolution of the DSM over time?', 'Although DSM-5 is longer than DSM-IV, the volume includes only 237 disorders, a decrease from the 297 disorders that were listed in DSM-IV.']

['What are some of the changes made in the organization and naming of categories in the DSM-5 compared to previous editions, and what is the rationale behind these changes?', 'The latest edition, DSM-5, includes revisions in the organization and naming of categories and in the diagnostic criteria for various disorders (Regier, Kuhl, & Kupfer, 2012), while emphasizing careful consideration of the importance of gender and cultural difference in the expression of various symptoms (Fisher, 2010).']

['Teacher: What is one concern that some people have regarding the establishment of new diagnoses in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM)?', 'Some believe that establishing new diagnoses might overpathologize the human condition by turning common human problems into mental illnesses (The Associated Press, 2013).']

['Why do some people believe that establishing new diagnoses in the DSM might overpathologize the human condition?', 'Indeed, the finding that nearly half of all Americans will meet the criteria for a DSM disorder at some point in their life (Kessler et al., 2005) likely fuels much of this skepticism.']

['What is one reason why some people criticize the DSM-5 for loosening its diagnostic criteria?', 'The DSM-5 is also criticized on the grounds that its diagnostic criteria have been loosened, thereby threatening to “turn our current diagnostic inflation into diagnostic hyperinflation” (Frances, 2012, para. 22).']

['Why is the loosening of diagnostic criteria in the DSM-5 criticized with regards to major depressive disorder and normal bereavement?', 'For example, DSM-IV specified that the symptoms of major depressive disorder must not be attributable to normal bereavement (loss of a loved one).']

['What is one criticism regarding the removal of the bereavement exclusion in the DSM-5?', 'The DSM-5, however, has removed this bereavement exclusion, essentially meaning that grief and sadness after a loved one’s death can constitute major depressive disorder.']

['Teacher: What is the name of the second classification system widely recognized, in addition to the one mentioned earlier?', 'A second classification system, the International Classification of Diseases (ICD), is also widely recognized.']

['Teacher: Who developed the International Classification of Diseases (ICD) and when was it developed?', 'Published by the World Health Organization (WHO), the ICD was developed in Europe shortly after World War II and, like the DSM, has been revised several times.']

['What is the purpose of the International Classification of Diseases (ICD)?', 'The categories of psychological disorders in both the DSM and ICD are similar, as are the criteria for specific disorders; however, some differences exist.']

['What are some additional purposes of the International Classification of Diseases (ICD) other than clinical use?', 'Although the ICD is used for clinical purposes, this tool is also used to examine the general health of populations and to monitor the prevalence of diseases and other health problems internationally (WHO, 2013).']

['What is the current edition of the International Classification of Diseases (ICD) and why is a new edition being developed?', 'The ICD is in its 10th edition (ICD-10); however, efforts are now underway to develop a new edition (ICD-11) that, in conjunction with the changes in DSM-5, will help harmonize the two classification systems as much as possible (APA, 2013).']

['Teacher: According to the passage, which classification system is more frequently used for clinical diagnosis worldwide?', 'A study that compared the use of the two classification systems found that worldwide the ICD is more frequently used for clinical diagnosis, whereas the DSM is more valued for research (Mezzich, 2002).']

['Teacher: According to the passage, what is the classification system that is more valued for research?', 'Most research findings concerning the etiology and treatment of psychological disorders are based on criteria set forth in the DSM (Oltmanns & Castonguay, 2013).']

['Teacher: According to the passage, what are some features of the DSM classification system that make it more useful for research purposes?', 'The DSM also includes more explicit disorder criteria, along with an extensive and helpful explanatory text (Regier et al., 2012).']

['Teacher: According to the passage, what are some features of the ICD classification system that make it more frequently used for clinical diagnosis worldwide?', 'The DSM is the classification system of choice among U.S. mental health professionals, and this chapter is based on the DSM paradigm.']
['Teacher: What two things should we keep in mind while considering these outlined disorders?', 'As these disorders are outlined, please bear two things in mind.']
['What is the second thing we should keep in mind while considering these outlined disorders?', 'First, remember that psychological disorders represent extremes of inner experience and behavior.']

['What is the first thing we should keep in mind while considering these outlined disorders?', 'If, while reading about these disorders, you feel that these descriptions begin to personally characterize you, do not worry—this moment of enlightenment probably means nothing more than you have had a range of experiences and emotions.']

['What do these episodes of sadness, anxiety, and preoccupation with certain thoughts indicate about our inner experience and behavior?', 'Each of us experiences episodes of sadness, anxiety, and preoccupation with certain thoughts—times when we do not quite feel ourselves.']

['What does it mean for psychological disorders to represent extremes of inner experience and behavior?', 'These episodes should not be considered problematic unless the accompanying thoughts and behaviors become extreme and have a disruptive effect on one’s life.']

['What is the second important aspect to understand about people with psychological disorders?', 'Second, understand that people with psychological disorders are far more than just embodiments of their disorders.']

['What is the reason behind not using terms such as schizophrenics, depressives, or phobics to refer to people with psychological disorders?', 'We do not use terms such as schizophrenics, depressives, or phobics because they are labels that objectify people who have these conditions, thus promoting biased and disparaging assumptions about them.']

['What is the difference between thinking of a person as "having" a psychological disorder versus thinking of a person as "being" a psychological disorder?', 'It is important to remember that a psychological disorder is not what a person is; it is something that a person has—through no fault of their own.']

['What is the significance of comparing psychological disorders to physical conditions like cancer or diabetes?', 'As is the case with cancer or diabetes, those with psychological disorders suffer debilitating, often painful conditions that are not of their own choosing.']
['What should be our approach towards individuals with psychological disorders?', 'These individuals deserve to be viewed and treated with compassion, understanding, and dignity.']

['Teacher: How do scientists, mental health professionals, and cultural healers approach the understanding or explanation of the underlying mechanisms that contribute to the development of a psychological disorder?', 'Scientists, mental health professionals, and cultural healers may adopt different perspectives in attempting to understand or explain the underlying mechanisms that contribute to the development of a psychological disorder.']

['What are some examples of different perspectives that scientists, mental health professionals, and cultural healers may adopt when trying to understand or explain the underlying mechanisms of psychological disorders?', 'The specific perspective used in explaining a psychological disorder is extremely important.']

['What are some examples of specific perspectives that scientists, mental health professionals, and cultural healers use to explain psychological disorders?', 'Each perspective explains psychological disorders, their causes or etiology, and effective treatments from a different viewpoint.']

['How can considering different perspectives enhance our understanding of psychological disorders?', 'Different perspectives provide alternate ways for how to think about the nature of psychopathology.']

['Teacher: How have psychological disorders been historically perceived, before the development of scientific understanding?', 'For centuries, psychological disorders were viewed from a supernatural perspective: attributed to a force beyond scientific understanding.']

['What were some common explanations for psychological disorders from a supernatural perspective?', 'Those afflicted were thought to be practitioners of black magic or possessed by spirits (Figure 15.6) (Maher & Maher, 1985).']

['What kind of behaviors and symptoms were associated with psychological disorders from a supernatural perspective?', 'For example, convents throughout Europe in the 16th and 17th centuries reported hundreds of nuns falling into a state of frenzy in which the afflicted foamed at the mouth, screamed and convulsed, sexually propositioned priests, and confessed to having carnal relations with devils or Christ.']

['What were some of the explanations given for the behaviors and symptoms exhibited by the afflicted individuals in convents during the 16th and 17th centuries?', 'Although, today, these cases would suggest serious mental illness; at the time, these events were routinely explained as possession by devilish forces (Waller, 2009a).']

['What is an example of how psychological disorders were perceived as supernatural phenomena in New England during the witch panic of the late 17th century?', 'Similarly, grievous fits by young girls are believed to have precipitated the witch panic in New England late in the 17th century (Demos, 1983).']

['How were psychological disorders perceived as supernatural phenomena in modern-day Nigeria according to the passage?', 'Such beliefs in supernatural causes of mental illness are still held in some societies today; for example, beliefs that supernatural forces cause mental illness are common in some cultures in modern-day Nigeria (Aghukwa, 2012).']

['Teacher: How does the biological perspective explain the causes of psychological disorders?', 'The biological perspective views psychological disorders as linked to biological phenomena, such as genetic factors, chemical imbalances, and brain abnormalities; it has gained considerable attention and acceptance in recent decades (Wyatt & Midkiff, 2006).']

['Teacher: Can you provide some examples of biological phenomena that the biological perspective relates to psychological disorders?', 'Evidence from many sources indicates that most psychological disorders have a genetic component; in fact, there is little dispute that some disorders are largely due to genetic factors.']
['Teacher: What does the graph in Figure 15.8 show in relation to schizophrenia?', 'The graph in Figure 15.8 shows heritability estimates for schizophrenia.']

['Teacher: What have findings like these led many researchers to search for in relation to mental disorders?', 'Findings such as these have led many of today’s researchers to search for specific genes and genetic mutations that contribute to mental disorders.']

['What are some other areas of research that have been explored in relation to mental disorders besides genetics?', 'Also, sophisticated neural imaging technology in recent decades has revealed how abnormalities in brain structure and function might be directly involved in many disorders, and advances in our understanding of neurotransmitters and hormones have yielded insights into their possible connections.']

['What are some examples of recent advancements or techniques that have contributed to the biological perspective in the study of psychological disorders?', 'The biological perspective is currently thriving in the study of psychological disorders.']

['Teacher: Why is the psychosocial perspective significant in understanding psychological disorders, even with the advancements in understanding the biological basis?', 'Despite advances in understanding the biological basis of psychological disorders, the psychosocial perspective is still very important.']

['Teacher: How does the psychosocial perspective contribute to our understanding of psychological disorders?', 'This perspective emphasizes the importance of learning, stress, faulty and self-defeating thinking patterns, and environmental factors.']

['Teacher: How does the Diathesis-Stress Model integrate biological and psychosocial factors in understanding psychological disorders?', 'Perhaps the best way to think about psychological disorders, then, is to view them as originating from a combination of biological and psychological processes.']

['What does the Diathesis-Stress Model suggest about the causes of psychological disorders?', 'Many develop not from a single cause, but from a delicate fusion between partly biological and partly psychosocial factors.']

['Teacher: What does the diathesis-stress model integrate to predict the likelihood of a disorder?', 'The diathesis-stress model (Zuckerman, 1999) integrates biological and psychosocial factors to predict the likelihood of a disorder.']

['What does the diathesis-stress model suggest about the likelihood of developing a disorder when faced with adverse environmental or psychological events?', 'This diathesis-stress model suggests that people with an underlying predisposition for a disorder (i.e., a diathesis) are more likely than others to develop a disorder when faced with adverse environmental or psychological events (i.e., stress), such as childhood maltreatment, negative life events, trauma, and so on.']

['What types of factors does the diathesis-stress model integrate to predict the likelihood of a disorder?', 'A diathesis is not always a biological vulnerability to an illness; some diatheses may be psychological (e.g., a tendency to think about life events in a pessimistic, self-defeating way).']

['Teacher: What is the key assumption of the diathesis-stress model regarding the development of a disorder?', 'The key assumption of the diathesis-stress model is that both factors, diathesis and stress, are necessary in the development of a disorder.']

['Teacher: How does the relationship between the level of stress and the level of diathesis affect the development of a disorder according to the diathesis-stress model?', 'Different models explore the relationship between the two factors: the level of stress needed to produce the disorder is inversely proportional to the level of diathesis.']
['Teacher: What do you mean by "anxiety"?', 'Everybody experiences anxiety from time to time.']
['Teacher: Can you explain the important differences between anxiety and fear?', 'Although anxiety is closely related to fear, the two states possess important differences.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example to illustrate the difference between fear and anxiety?', 'Fear involves an instantaneous reaction to an imminent threat, whereas anxiety involves apprehension, avoidance, and cautiousness regarding a potential threat, danger, or other negative event (Craske, 1999).']
['Teacher: Why is anxiety considered important to our health, safety, and well-being?', 'While anxiety is unpleasant to most people, it is important to our health, safety, and well-being.']

['Teacher: How does anxiety motivate us to take actions that enable us to avert potential future problems?', 'Anxiety motivates us to take actions—such as preparing for exams, watching our weight, showing up to work on time—that enable us to avert potential future problems.']

["Teacher: Can you explain the negative consequences of excessive anxiety on a person's daily life and functioning?", 'Anxiety also motivates us to avoid certain things—such as running up debts and engaging in illegal activities—that could lead to future trouble.']

["Teacher: How does the magnitude of the potential threat relate to an individual's level and duration of anxiety?", 'Most individuals’ level and duration of anxiety approximates the magnitude of the potential threat they face.']

['What are some specific anxieties that the student in the example might be experiencing?', 'For example, suppose a student who came to the U.S. as a “Dreamer” (someone whose parents didn’t lawfully immigrate) is concerned about the possibility of being unable to continue in the university program or of losing access to academic financial aid, due to changes and litigation around the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program.']

['Teacher: How might the anxiety experienced by the student in the example affect their academic performance and overall well-being?', 'This person likely would experience anxiety of greater intensity and duration than would a 21-year-old junior who entered college as a birthright citizen.']

['What are some examples of anxiety disorders that could be characterized by excessive, persistent, and disproportionate anxiety?', 'Some people experience anxiety that is excessive, persistent, and greatly out of proportion to the actual threat; if one’s anxiety has a disruptive influence on one’s life, this is a strong indicator that the individual is experiencing an anxiety disorder.']

['Teacher: How are anxiety disorders characterized according to the textbook passage?', 'Anxiety disorders are characterized by excessive and persistent fear and anxiety, and by related disturbances in behavior (APA, 2013).']

['Teacher: What are the two main characteristics of anxiety disorders mentioned in the textbook passage?', 'Although anxiety is universally experienced, anxiety disorders cause considerable distress.']

['Teacher: According to the textbook passage, what is the prevalence of anxiety disorders in the U.S. population?', 'As a group, anxiety disorders are common: approximately 25%–30% of the U.S. population meets the criteria for at least one anxiety disorder during their lifetime (Kessler et al., 2005).']

['Teacher: What is the difference in prevalence of anxiety disorders between men and women, as mentioned in the textbook passage?', 'Also, these disorders appear to be much more common in women than they are in men; within a 12-month period, around 23% of women and 14% of men will experience at least one anxiety disorder (National Comorbidity Survey, 2007).']

['What are some of the common comorbidities associated with anxiety disorders, as mentioned in the textbook passage?', 'Anxiety disorders are the most frequently occurring class of mental disorders and are often comorbid with each other and with other mental disorders (Kessler, Ruscio, Shear, & Wittchen, 2009).']
["Teacher: That's correct! Now, could you please explain to me what a specific phobia is?", 'Phobia is a Greek word that means fear.']

['What are the main characteristics of a person diagnosed with a specific phobia?', 'A person diagnosed with a specific phobia (formerly known as simple phobia) experiences excessive, distressing, and persistent fear or anxiety about a specific object or situation (such as animals, enclosed spaces, elevators, or flying) (APA, 2013).']

['What are some examples of common specific phobias that people may experience?', 'Even though people realize their level of fear and anxiety in relation to the phobic stimulus is irrational, some people with a specific phobia may go to great lengths to avoid the phobic stimulus (the object or situation that triggers the fear and anxiety).']
["Can you provide some examples of how a specific phobia can disrupt a person's life?", 'Typically, the fear and anxiety a phobic stimulus elicits is disruptive to the person’s life.']

['What are some negative consequences a person with a phobia of flying might experience in terms of their personal life?', 'For example, a man with a phobia of flying might refuse to accept a job that requires frequent air travel, thus negatively affecting his career.']

['What are some negative consequences a person with a phobia of enclosed spaces might experience in terms of their personal life?', 'Clinicians who have worked with people who have specific phobias have encountered many kinds of phobias, some of which are shown in Table 15.1.']

['Teacher: What percentage of the United States population is estimated to experience a specific phobia at some point in their lifetime according to Kessler et al. in 2005?', 'Specific phobias are common; in the United States, around 12.5% of the population will meet the criteria for a specific phobia at some point in their lifetime (Kessler et al., 2005).']

['Teacher: Can you provide an estimate of the percentage of the United States population that may develop a specific phobia at some point in their lifetime, based on the findings of Kessler et al. in 2005?', 'One type of phobia, agoraphobia, is listed in the DSM-5 as a separate anxiety disorder.']

['Teacher: What does agoraphobia mean and how is it characterized according to the passage?', 'Agoraphobia, which literally means “fear of the marketplace,” is characterized by intense fear, anxiety, and avoidance of situations in which it might be difficult to escape or receive help if one experiences symptoms of a panic attack (a state of extreme anxiety that we will discuss shortly).']

['Teacher: According to the passage, what are some of the situations that individuals with agoraphobia may experience intense fear and anxiety in?', 'These situations include public transportation, open spaces (parking lots), enclosed spaces (stores), crowds, or being outside the home alone (APA, 2013).']

['Teacher: How many Americans are estimated to experience agoraphobia at some point in their lifetime, based on the findings of Kessler et al. in 2005?', 'About 1.4% of Americans experience agoraphobia during their lifetime (Kessler et al., 2005).']
['Teacher: What is the main topic or subject that many theories suggest develop through learning?', 'Many theories suggest that phobias develop through learning.']
['What did Rachman (1977) propose regarding the acquisition of phobias through learning?', 'Rachman (1977) proposed that phobias can be acquired through three major learning pathways.']
['What are the other two major learning pathways proposed by Rachman (1977) for the acquisition of phobias?', 'The first pathway is through classical conditioning.']

['What is the second major learning pathway proposed by Rachman (1977) for the acquisition of phobias?', 'As you may recall, classical conditioning is a form of learning in which a previously neutral stimulus is paired with an unconditioned stimulus (UCS) that reflexively elicits an unconditioned response (UCR), eliciting the same response through its association with the unconditioned stimulus.']

['What is the term used to refer to a response that is elicited by a conditioned stimulus after it has been associated with an unconditioned stimulus?', 'The response is called a conditioned response (CR).']

['What is an example of how a phobia can be acquired through classical conditioning?', 'For example, a child who has been bitten by a dog may come to fear dogs because of a past association with pain.']

['What is the term used to refer to the process in which a neutral stimulus becomes associated with a conditioned stimulus and elicits a conditioned response?', 'In this case, the dog bite is the UCS and the fear it elicits is the UCR.']

['What is the term used to refer to the process of a conditioned stimulus eliciting a conditioned response?', 'Because a dog was associated with the bite, any dog may come to serve as a conditioned stimulus, thereby eliciting fear; the fear the child experiences around dogs, then, becomes a CR.']
['Teacher: Can you explain what is meant by the term "vicarious learning" as mentioned in the passage?', 'The second pathway of phobia acquisition is through vicarious learning, such as modeling.']

['Teacher: Can you provide another example of vicarious learning mentioned in the passage, apart from the one involving the cousin and spiders?', 'For example, a child who observes their cousin react fearfully to spiders may later express the same fears, even though spiders have never presented any danger to them.']

['Teacher: How does vicarious learning contribute to the acquisition of phobias according to the passage?', 'This phenomenon has been observed in both humans and nonhuman primates (Olsson & Phelps, 2007).']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example from a different study that supports the idea of vicarious learning in the acquisition of phobias?', 'A study of laboratory-reared monkeys readily acquired a fear of snakes after observing wild-reared monkeys react fearfully to snakes (Mineka & Cook, 1993).']
['Teacher: How can phobias be acquired through verbal transmission or information?', 'The third pathway is through verbal transmission or information.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how someone might acquire a phobia through verbal transmission or information?', 'For example, a child whose parents, siblings, friends, and classmates constantly tell them how disgusting and dangerous snakes are may come to acquire a fear of snakes.']

['Teacher: What kind of things are people more likely to develop phobias of according to the passage?', 'Interestingly, people are more likely to develop phobias of things that do not represent much actual danger to themselves, such as animals and heights, and are less likely to develop phobias toward things that present legitimate danger in contemporary society, such as motorcycles and weapons (Öhman & Mineka, 2001).']

['Teacher: Why are people more likely to develop phobias towards things that do not represent much actual danger, according to the theory mentioned in the passage?', 'One theory suggests that the human brain is evolutionarily predisposed to more readily associate certain objects or situations with fear (Seligman, 1971).']

['What are some examples of stimuli that our ancestors may have associated with potential danger, according to the theory mentioned in the passage?', 'This theory argues that throughout our evolutionary history, our ancestors associated certain stimuli (e.g., snakes, spiders, heights, and thunder) with potential danger.']

['What are some examples of stimuli that our ancestors may have associated with less potential danger, according to the theory mentioned in the passage?', 'As time progressed, the mind has become adapted to more readily develop fears of these things than of others.']

['What does experimental evidence suggest about the development of conditioned fears towards fear-relevant stimuli compared to fear-irrelevant stimuli?', 'Experimental evidence has consistently demonstrated that conditioned fears develop more readily to fear-relevant stimuli (images of snakes and spiders) than to fear-irrelevant stimuli (images of flowers and berries) (Öhman & Mineka, 2001).']
['What has research shown about the development of conditioned fears towards fear-relevant stimuli in monkeys?', 'Such prepared learning has also been shown to occur in monkeys.']

['What were the results of the study where monkeys watched videos of model monkeys reacting fearfully to fear-relevant and fear-irrelevant stimuli?', 'In one study (Cook & Mineka, 1989), monkeys watched videotapes of model monkeys reacting fearfully to either fear-relevant stimuli (toy snakes or a toy crocodile) or fear-irrelevant stimuli (flowers or a toy rabbit).']

['What were the results of the study regarding the development of fears in observer monkeys towards fear-relevant and fear-irrelevant stimuli?', 'The observer monkeys developed fears of the fear-relevant stimuli but not the fear-irrelevant stimuli.']

['Teacher: How would you define social anxiety disorder?', 'Social anxiety disorder (formerly called social phobia) is characterized by extreme and persistent fear or anxiety and avoidance of social situations in which the person could potentially be evaluated negatively by others (APA, 2013).']

['Teacher: How is social anxiety disorder characterized and what behaviors are commonly associated with it?', 'As with specific phobias, social anxiety disorder is common in the United States; a little over 12% of all Americans experience social anxiety disorder during their lifetime (Kessler et al., 2005).']

['Teacher: What are some examples of behaviors or actions that individuals with social anxiety disorder may fear will lead to rejection or embarrassment?', 'The heart of the fear and anxiety in social anxiety disorder is the person’s concern that they may act in a humiliating or embarrassing way, such as appearing foolish, showing symptoms of anxiety (blushing), or doing or saying something that might lead to rejection (such as offending others).']

['What are some common social situations that individuals with social anxiety disorder may have difficulties in?', 'The kinds of social situations in which individuals with social anxiety disorder usually have problems include public speaking, having a conversation, meeting strangers, eating in restaurants, and, in some cases, using public restrooms.']

["What are some specific ways in which the fear, anxiety, and avoidance experienced in social anxiety disorder can significantly impact a person's life?", 'Although many people become anxious in social situations like public speaking, the fear, anxiety, and avoidance experienced in social anxiety disorder are highly distressing and lead to serious impairments in life.']

["What are some negative impacts of social anxiety disorder on a person's education, career, and overall quality of life?", 'Adults with this disorder are more likely to experience lower educational attainment and lower earnings (Katzelnick et al., 2001), perform more poorly at work and are more likely to be unemployed (Moitra, Beard, Weisberg, & Keller, 2011), and report greater dissatisfaction with their family lives, friends, leisure activities, and income (Stein & Kean, 2000).']
