['Teacher: According to the research, which type of event has a greater likelihood of triggering major depressive disorder - the breakup of a relationship initiated by the other person or the death of a loved one?', 'For example, people who experience the breakup of a relationship initiated by the other person develop major depressive disorder at a rate more than 2 times that of people who experience the death of a loved one (Kendler, Hettema, Butera, Gardner, & Prescott, 2003).']

["Teacher: How does exposure to traumatic stress during childhood affect an individual's risk of developing depression?", 'Likewise, individuals who are exposed to traumatic stress during childhood—such as separation from a parent, family turmoil, and maltreatment (physical or sexual abuse)—are at a heightened risk of developing depression at any point in their lives (Kessler, 1997).']

["What are some examples of traumatic stress during childhood that can increase an individual's risk of developing depression?", 'A recent review of 16 studies involving over 23,000 subjects concluded that those who experience childhood maltreatment are more than 2 times as likely to develop recurring and persistent depression (Nanni, Uher, & Danese, 2012).']

['Teacher: What is the outcome for most people who experience stressful life events or childhood adversities in relation to depression?', 'Of course, not everyone who experiences stressful life events or childhood adversities succumbs to depression—indeed, most do not.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the concept of a diathesis-stress interpretation of major depressive disorder in relation to the impact of stressful life events or childhood adversities on individuals?', 'Clearly, a diathesis-stress interpretation of major depressive disorder, in which certain predispositions or vulnerability factors influence one’s reaction to stress, would seem logical.']

['Teacher: What does the study by Caspi and others (2003) suggest about the role of a specific gene in major depressive disorder and its relationship to stressful life events or childhood adversities?', 'A study by Caspi and others (2003) suggests that an alteration in a specific gene that regulates serotonin (the 5-HTTLPR gene) might be one culprit.']

['Teacher: According to the study by Caspi and others (2003), how does the presence of the short versions of the 5-HTTLPR gene influence the likelihood of experiencing major depression in individuals who have several stressful life events?', 'These investigators found that people who experienced several stressful life events were significantly more likely to experience episodes of major depression if they carried one or two short versions of this gene than if they carried two long versions.']

['Teacher: How does the presence of the long versions of the 5-HTTLPR gene affect the likelihood of experiencing major depression in individuals who have several stressful life events?', 'Those who carried one or two short versions of the 5-HTTLPR gene were unlikely to experience an episode, however, if they had experienced few or no stressful life events.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a specific population that has been studied in relation to the diathesis-stress model and major depressive disorder?', 'Numerous studies have replicated these findings, including studies of people who experienced maltreatment during childhood (Goodman & Brand, 2009).']

['What were the findings of a recent investigation conducted in the United Kingdom (Brown & Harris, 2013) in relation to the diathesis-stress model and major depressive disorder?', 'In a recent investigation conducted in the United Kingdom (Brown & Harris, 2013), researchers found that childhood maltreatment before age 9 elevated the risk of chronic adult depression (a depression episode lasting for at least 12 months) among those individuals having one (LS) or two (SS) short versions of the 5-HTTLPR gene (Figure 15.18).']

['What are the implications for individuals with two long versions of the 5-HTTLPR gene in relation to childhood maltreatment and the risk of chronic depression?', 'Childhood maltreatment did not increase the risk for chronic depression for those have two long (LL) versions of this gene.']

['What is one potential mechanism through which stress may lead to depression, according to the passage?', 'Thus, genetic vulnerability may be one mechanism through which stress potentially leads to depression.']

['Teacher: What factors do cognitive theories of depression propose as triggers for depression?', 'Cognitive theories of depression take the view that depression is triggered by negative thoughts, interpretations, self-evaluations, and expectations (Joormann, 2009).']

['What are the two factors proposed by diathesis-stress models as triggers for depression?', 'These diathesis-stress models propose that depression is triggered by a “cognitive vulnerability” (negative and maladaptive thinking) and by precipitating stressful life events (Gotlib & Joormann, 2010).']

['Who developed one of the most well-known cognitive theories of depression?', 'Perhaps the most well-known cognitive theory of depression was developed in the 1960s by psychiatrist Aaron Beck, based on clinical observations and supported by research (Beck, 2008).']

["What is the main concept or idea behind Beck's cognitive theory of depression?", 'Beck theorized that depression-prone people possess depressive schemas, or mental predispositions to think about most things in a negative way (Beck, 1976).']

["What are some examples of themes found in depressive schemas according to Beck's cognitive theory of depression?", 'Depressive schemas contain themes of loss, failure, rejection, worthlessness, and inadequacy, and may develop early in childhood in response to adverse experiences, then remain dormant until they are activated by stressful or negative life events.']
["What is the role of depressive schemas in Beck's cognitive theory of depression?", 'Depressive schemas prompt dysfunctional and pessimistic thoughts about the self, the world, and the future.']

["What are cognitive biases according to Beck's cognitive theory of depression?", 'Beck believed that this dysfunctional style of thinking is maintained by cognitive biases, or errors in how we process information about ourselves, which lead us to focus on negative aspects of experiences, interpret things negatively, and block positive memories (Beck, 2008).']

["What is an example of a cognitive bias according to Beck's cognitive theory of depression?", 'A person whose depressive schema consists of a theme of rejection might be overly attentive to social cues of rejection (more likely to notice another’s frown), and they might interpret this cue as a sign of rejection and automatically remember past incidents of rejection.']

["How do longitudinal studies support Beck's theory of depression?", 'Longitudinal studies have supported Beck’s theory, in showing that a preexisting tendency to engage in this negative, self-defeating style of thinking—when combined with life stress—over time predicts the onset of depression (Dozois & Beck, 2008).']

["What is the purpose of cognitive therapies for depression according to Beck's cognitive theory?", 'Cognitive therapies for depression, aimed at changing a depressed person’s negative thinking, were developed as an expansion of this theory (Beck, 1976).']

['Teacher: According to the passage, what does the hopelessness theory postulate about a particular style of thinking and its relationship to depression?', 'Another cognitive theory of depression, hopelessness theory, postulates that a particular style of negative thinking leads to a sense of hopelessness, which then leads to depression (Abramson, Metalsky, & Alloy, 1989).']

['What is the relationship between a particular style of negative thinking and hopelessness, according to the hopelessness theory?', 'According to this theory, hopelessness is an expectation that unpleasant outcomes will occur or that desired outcomes will not occur, and there is nothing one can do to prevent such outcomes.']

['What are some important life realms in which negative life events can lead to feelings of hopelessness, based on the hopelessness theory?', 'A key assumption of this theory is that hopelessness stems from a tendency to perceive negative life events as having stable (“It’s never going to change”) and global (“It’s going to affect my whole life”) causes, in contrast to unstable (“It’s fixable”) and specific (“It applies only to this particular situation”) causes, especially if these negative life events occur in important life realms, such as relationships, academic achievement, and the like.']

["How might the hopelessness theory interpret the student's reaction to performing poorly on the law school admissions test?", 'Suppose a student who wishes to go to law school does poorly on an admissions test.']

['According to the hopelessness theory, how might the student interpret their poor performance on the law school admissions test, in relation to stable and global causes?', 'If the student infers negative life events as having stable and global causes, they may believe that their poor performance has a stable and global cause (“I lack intelligence, and it’s going to prevent me from ever finding a meaningful career”), as opposed to an unstable and specific cause (“I was sick the day of the exam, so my low score was a fluke”).']

['What is the primary cause of depression, according to the hopelessness theory?', 'Hopelessness theory predicts that people who exhibit this cognitive style in response to undesirable life events will view such events as having negative implications for their future and self-worth, thereby increasing the likelihood of hopelessness—the primary cause of depression (Abramson et al., 1989).']

['What did the study measuring the tendency to make negative inferences for bad life events in participants aim to test, in relation to hopelessness theory?', 'One study testing hopelessness theory measured the tendency to make negative inferences for bad life effects in participants who were experiencing uncontrollable stressors.']

['What were the findings of the study that measured the tendency to make negative inferences for bad life events in participants, in relation to the development of depression according to hopelessness theory?', 'Over the ensuing six months, those with scores reflecting high cognitive vulnerability were 7 times more likely to develop depression compared to those with lower scores (Kleim, Gonzalo, & Ehlers, 2011).']

['Teacher: What aspect do the cognitive theories of depression mainly focus on?', 'A third cognitive theory of depression focuses on how people’s thoughts about their distressed moods—depressed symptoms in particular—can increase the risk and duration of depression.']

['Teacher: Can you explain how the cognitive theory of depression that focuses on rumination helps to explain the higher rates of depression in women compared to men?', 'This theory, which focuses on rumination in the development of depression, was first described in the late 1980s to explain the higher rates of depression in women than in men (Nolen-Hoeksema, 1987).']

['Teacher: How does rumination, as described in the cognitive theory of depression, differ from actively addressing and distracting oneself from depressed symptoms?', 'Rumination is the repetitive and passive focus on the fact that one is depressed and dwelling on depressed symptoms, rather that distracting one’s self from the symptoms or attempting to address them in an active, problem-solving manner (Nolen-Hoeksema, 1991).']

['Teacher: According to the cognitive theory of depression, what is an example of a thought that someone experiencing rumination might have?', 'I’m never going to get my work done feeling this way” (Nolen-Hoeksema & Hilt, 2009, p. 393).']

['Teacher: How does the tendency of rumination contribute to the higher rates of depression in women compared to men, according to the cognitive theory of depression?', 'Women are more likely than men to ruminate when they are sad or depressed (Butler & Nolen-Hoeksema, 1994), and the tendency to ruminate is associated with increases in depression symptoms (Nolen-Hoeksema, Larson, & Grayson, 1999), heightened risk of major depressive episodes (Abela & Hankin, 2011), and chronicity of such episodes (Robinson & Alloy, 2003)']
['Teacher: What happens to the emotional pain for some individuals with mood disorders?', 'For some people with mood disorders, the extreme emotional pain they experience becomes unendurable.']

['Teacher: Why might some individuals with mood disorders consider suicide as a reasonable way out?', 'Overwhelmed by hopelessness, devastated by incapacitating feelings of worthlessness, and burdened with the inability to adequately cope with such feelings, they may consider suicide to be a reasonable way out.']

['Teacher: How does suicide relate to the combination of various factors going wrong simultaneously?', 'Suicide, defined by the CDC as “death caused by self-directed injurious behavior with any intent to die as the result of the behavior” (CDC, 2013a), in a sense represents an outcome of several things going wrong all at the same time (Crosby, Ortega, & Melanson, 2011).']

['Teacher: According to the passage, what are the three requirements for someone to consider suicide as a possible option?', 'Not only must the person be biologically or psychologically vulnerable, but they must also have the means to perform the suicidal act, and they must lack the necessary protective factors (e.g., social support from friends and family, religion, coping skills, and problem-solving skills) that provide comfort and enable one to cope during times of crisis or great psychological pain (Berman, 2009).']

['Teacher: Why is suicide not listed as a disorder in the DSM-5, but still related to mental disorders such as mood disorders?', 'Suicide is not listed as a disorder in the DSM-5; however, people with a mental disorder—especially a mood disorder—have the greatest risk for suicide.']

['Teacher: Can you provide a statistic that supports the statement that people with mood disorders are at the greatest risk for suicide?', 'Around 90% of those who die by suicide have a diagnosis of at least one mental disorder, with mood disorders being the most frequent (Fleischman, Bertolote, Belfer, & Beautrais, 2005).']

['Teacher: Why do you think there is a strong association between major depressive disorder and suicide?', 'In fact, the association between major depressive disorder and suicide is so strong that one of the criteria for the disorder is thoughts of suicide, as discussed above (APA, 2013).']

['Teacher: Why can suicide rates be challenging to interpret?', 'Suicide rates can be difficult to interpret because some deaths that appear to be accidental may in fact be acts of suicide (e.g., automobile crash).']

['What are some common examples of deaths that may initially appear accidental but could actually be acts of suicide?', 'Nevertheless, investigations into U.S. suicide rates have uncovered these facts:']

['Teacher: According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention [CDC], what was the ranking of suicide as a cause of death for all ages in 2010?', 'Suicide was the 10th leading cause of death for all ages in 2010 (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention [CDC], 2012).']
['Teacher: Can you tell me the number of suicides that occurred in the United States in 2010?', 'There were 38,364 suicides in 2010 in the United States—an average of 105 each day (CDC, 2012).']

['Teacher: What are the two most commonly used methods of suicide for males and females, according to the CDC?', 'Suicide among males is 4 times higher than among females and accounts for 79% of all suicides; firearms are the most commonly used method of suicide for males, whereas poisoning is the most commonly used method for females (CDC, 2012).']

['Teacher: Can you provide any reasons or factors that may contribute to the higher suicide rates among individuals aged 65 years and older during the period from 1991 to 2003?', 'From 1991 to 2003, suicide rates were consistently higher among those 65 years and older.']

['Teacher: Why have suicide rates been consistently higher among individuals aged 65 years and older since 2006?', 'Since 2001, however, suicide rates among those ages 25–64 have risen consistently, and, since 2006, suicide rates have been greater for those ages 65 and older (CDC, 2013b).']

['Teacher: What are some potential factors that may contribute to the increased suicide rates among middle-aged Americans since 2006?', 'This increase in suicide rates among middle-aged Americans has prompted concern in some quarters that baby boomers (individuals born between 1946–1964) who face economic worry and easy access to prescription medication may be particularly vulnerable to suicide (Parker-Pope, 2013).']

['Teacher: According to the CDC, which two groups have the highest rates of suicide within the United States?', 'The highest rates of suicide within the United States are among American Indians/Alaskan natives and Non-Hispanic White people (CDC, 2013b).']

['Teacher: Which region of the United States has consistently shown the highest rates of suicide according to the CDC?', 'Suicide rates vary across the United States, with the highest rates consistently found in the mountain states of the west (Alaska, Montana, Nevada, Wyoming, Colorado, and Idaho) (Berman, 2009).']

['Teacher: Can you explain the surprising finding that suicide rates actually peak during the springtime rather than during the holiday season or winter?', 'Contrary to popular belief, suicide rates peak during the springtime (April and May), not during the holiday season or winter.']
['Why do suicide rates peak during the springtime rather than during the holiday season or winter?', 'In fact, suicide rates are generally lowest during the winter months (Postolache et al., 2010).']

['Teacher: What is the group of individuals that exhibits an elevated risk of suicide, especially if they have substance use problems?', 'Suicidal risk is especially high among people with substance use problems.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of the specific substance use problem that puts individuals at a significantly higher risk for suicide compared to the general population?', 'Individuals with alcohol dependence are at 10 times greater risk for suicide than the general population (Wilcox, Conner, & Caine, 2004).']

['Teacher: Can you explain why individuals who have made a prior suicide attempt are at a higher risk for future suicidal behavior compared to the general population?', 'The risk of suicidal behavior is especially high among those who have made a prior suicide attempt.']

['Teacher: Can you provide any evidence or statistics to support the higher risk of future suicidal behavior among individuals who have made a prior suicide attempt compared to the general population?', 'Among those who attempt suicide, 16% make another attempt within a year and over 21% make another attempt within four years (Owens, Horrocks, & House, 2002).']

['Teacher: Can you explain how the presence of a lethal means, such as a firearm in the home, increases the risk of suicide for individuals who are already suicidal?', 'Suicidal individuals may be at high risk for terminating their life if they have a lethal means in which to act, such as a firearm in the home (Brent & Bridge, 2003).']

['Teacher: Can you provide any examples of precursors to suicidal behavior other than withdrawal from social relationships, feeling as though one is a burden to others, and engaging in reckless and risk-taking behaviors?', 'Withdrawal from social relationships, feeling as though one is a burden to others, and engaging in reckless and risk-taking behaviors may be precursors to suicidal behavior (Berman, 2009).']

['Teacher: Can you provide any examples of psychological factors that are associated with an increased risk of suicidal behavior, other than a sense of entrapment?\nStudent:', 'A sense of entrapment or feeling unable to escape one’s miserable feelings or external circumstances (e.g., an abusive relationship with no perceived way out) predicts suicidal behavior (O’Connor, Smyth, Ferguson, Ryan, & Williams, 2013).']

['Teacher: Can you explain how cyberbullying is associated with an increased risk of suicidal behavior among adolescents?', 'Tragically, reports of suicides among adolescents following instances of cyberbullying have emerged in recent years.']

['Teacher: Can you provide any other examples of how cyberbullying has been associated with an increased risk of suicidal behavior among adolescents, other than the case of Phoebe Prince?', 'In one widely-publicized case a few years ago, Phoebe Prince, a 15-year-old Massachusetts high school student, died by suicide following incessant harassment and taunting from her classmates via texting and Facebook (McCabe, 2010).']
['Teacher: How do suicides potentially impact others and spread?', 'Suicides can have a contagious effect on people.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how the risk of suicide can be heightened for individuals when someone they know, like a family member, dies by suicide?', 'For example, another’s suicide, especially that of a family member, heightens one’s risk of suicide (Agerbo, Nordentoft, & Mortensen, 2002).']

['Teacher: Can you explain how widely-publicized suicides might trigger additional suicides in some individuals?', 'Additionally, widely-publicized suicides tend to trigger additional suicides in some individuals.']

['Teacher: How can media coverage of suicide contribute to an increase in suicide rates in certain individuals?', 'One study examining suicide statistics in the United States from 1947–1967 found that the rates of suicide increased significantly for the first month after a report about suicide was printed on the front page of the New York Times (Phillips, 1974).']

['Teacher: Can you provide another example of how media coverage can influence suicide rates in specific populations?', 'Austrian researchers found a significant increase in the number of suicides by firearms in the three weeks following extensive reports in Austria’s largest newspaper of a celebrity suicide by gun (Etzersdorfer, Voracek, & Sonneck, 2004).']

['Teacher: Can you explain how media coverage of celebrity suicides can have a different impact on suicide rates compared to coverage of non-celebrity suicides?', 'A review of 42 studies concluded that media coverage of celebrity suicides is more than 14 times more likely to trigger copycat suicides than is coverage of non-celebrity suicides (Stack, 2000).']

['Teacher: Can you provide an explanation for why televised stories of suicides are less likely to prompt a surge in suicides compared to newspaper stories?', 'This review also demonstrated that the medium of coverage is important: televised stories are considerably less likely to prompt a surge in suicides than are newspaper stories.']

['Why is the potential impact of suicide notes on online social media less clear compared to other forms of media coverage?', 'Research suggests that a trend appears to be emerging whereby people use online social media to leave suicide notes, although it is not clear to what extent suicide notes on such media might induce subsequent suicides (Ruder, Hatch, Ampanozi, Thali, & Fischer, 2011).']

['Teacher: How might the presence of suicide notes on social media impact vulnerable individuals who come across them?', 'Nevertheless, it is reasonable to conjecture that suicide notes left by individuals on social media may influence the decisions of other vulnerable people who encounter them (Luxton, June, & Fairall, 2012).']
['Teacher: Can you explain how brain chemistry can be a contributing factor in suicide?', 'One possible contributing factor in suicide is brain chemistry.']

['Teacher: Can you provide some examples of disturbances in serotonin functioning that have been linked to suicidal behavior according to the contemporary neurological research mentioned?', 'Contemporary neurological research shows that disturbances in the functioning of serotonin are linked to suicidal behavior (Pompili et al., 2010).']

['Teacher: How do low levels of serotonin predict future suicide attempts and death by suicide, according to the research findings mentioned?', 'Low levels of serotonin predict future suicide attempts and death by suicide, and low levels have been observed post-mortem among suicide victims (Mann, 2003).']

['Teacher: What other mental health conditions are associated with serotonin dysfunction, as mentioned in the passage?', 'Serotonin dysfunction, as noted earlier, is also known to play an important role in depression; low levels of serotonin have also been linked to aggression and impulsivity (Stanley et al., 2000).']

['What are the potential implications of the combination of depression, aggression, and impulsivity in relation to suicide?', 'The combination of these three characteristics constitutes a potential formula for suicide—especially violent suicide.']

['What were the findings of the classic study conducted during the 1970s regarding patients with major depressive disorder and their serotonin levels in relation to suicide attempts?', 'A classic study conducted during the 1970s found that patients with major depressive disorder who had very low levels of serotonin attempted suicide more frequently and more violently than did patients with higher levels (Asberg, Thorén, Träskman, Bertilsson, & Ringberger, 1976; Mann, 2003).']

['Teacher: Why should suicidal thoughts, plans, and even off-hand remarks always be taken extremely seriously?', 'Suicidal thoughts, plans, and even off-hand remarks (“I might kill myself this afternoon”) should always be taken extremely seriously.']
['Why is it important to take suicidal thoughts, plans, and even off-hand remarks seriously?', 'People who contemplate terminating their life need immediate help.']

['What kind of help can people who contemplate terminating their life potentially receive from the provided website?', 'Below is a link to an excellent website that contains resources (including hotlines) for people who are struggling with suicidal ideation, have loved ones who may be suicidal, or who have lost loved ones to suicide: http://www.afsp.org.']

['What are some examples of the resources that the provided website contains?', 'You can also contact the 24-hour National Suicide Prevention Hotline by calling 1-800-273-8255 or texting HELLO to 741741 to access their Crisis Text Line.']

['Teacher: Can you provide a brief description of schizophrenia and its key features?', 'Schizophrenia is a psychological disorder that is characterized by major disturbances in thought, perception, emotion, and behavior.']

['Teacher: How would you describe the age range at which schizophrenia is typically first diagnosed?', 'About 1% of the population experiences schizophrenia in their lifetime, and usually the disorder is first diagnosed during early adulthood (early to mid-20s).']

['Teacher: What are some of the day-to-day activities that individuals with schizophrenia often find challenging?', 'Most people with schizophrenia experience significant difficulties in many day-to-day activities, such as holding a job, paying bills, caring for oneself (grooming and hygiene), and maintaining relationships with others.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the role of frequent hospitalizations in the management of schizophrenia?', 'Frequent hospitalizations are more often the rule rather than the exception with schizophrenia.']

['Teacher: What is the long-term outcome for individuals with schizophrenia, even with the best available treatments?', 'Even when they receive the best treatments available, many with schizophrenia will continue to experience serious social and occupational impairment throughout their lives.']

['Teacher: What is an important distinction to make between schizophrenia and dissociative identity disorder?', 'First, schizophrenia is not a condition involving a split personality; that is, schizophrenia is not the same thing as dissociative identity disorder (better known as multiple personality disorder).']

['Teacher: Can you explain the origin of the term "schizophrenia" and how it relates to the misconception of it involving a split personality?', 'These disorders are sometimes confused because the word schizophrenia first coined by the Swiss psychiatrist Eugen Bleuler in 1911, derives from Greek words that refer to a “splitting” (schizo) of psychic functions (phrene) (Green, 2001).']

['Teacher: Can you explain what is meant by a psychotic disorder and how it relates to schizophrenia?', 'Schizophrenia is considered a psychotic disorder, or one in which the person’s thoughts, perceptions, and behaviors are impaired to the point where they are not able to function normally in life.']

["Teacher: How does schizophrenia specifically impair an individual's thoughts, perceptions, and behaviors to the extent that they cannot function normally in life?", 'In informal terms, one who suffers from a psychotic disorder (that is, has a psychosis) is disconnected from the world in which most of us live.']

['Teacher: What are the main symptoms of schizophrenia according to the source?', 'The main symptoms of schizophrenia include hallucinations, delusions, disorganized thinking, disorganized or abnormal motor behavior, and negative symptoms (APA, 2013).']

['What is one of the main symptoms of schizophrenia that involves perceptual experiences occurring without external stimulation?', 'A hallucination is a perceptual experience that occurs in the absence of external stimulation.']

['Teacher: Could you provide an example of a common type of hallucination experienced by individuals with schizophrenia?', 'Auditory hallucinations (hearing voices) occur in roughly two-thirds of patients with schizophrenia and are by far the most common form of hallucination (Andreasen, 1987).']

['What are the other types of hallucinations that individuals with schizophrenia may experience, aside from auditory hallucinations?', 'The voices may be familiar or unfamiliar, they may have a conversation or argue, or the voices may provide a running commentary on the person’s behavior (Tsuang, Farone, & Green, 1999).']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a hallucination that involves perceiving something visually or olfactorily that is not actually present?', 'Delusions are beliefs that are contrary to reality and are firmly held even in the face of contradictory evidence.']

['Teacher: How would you differentiate between a delusion and a belief that some may consider odd?', 'Many of us hold beliefs that some would consider odd, but a delusion is easily identified because it is clearly absurd.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a less common hallucination that involves perceiving something olfactorily that is not actually present?', 'A person with schizophrenia may believe that their mother is plotting with the FBI to poison their coffee, or that their neighbor is an enemy spy who wants to kill them.']

['Teacher: How would you differentiate between a paranoid delusion and a delusion that involves perceiving an odor that is not actually present?', 'These kinds of delusions are known as paranoid delusions, which involve the (false) belief that other people or agencies are plotting to harm the person.']

['Teacher: How is grandiose delusion different from a belief that some may consider as having high self-esteem or confidence?', 'People with schizophrenia also may hold grandiose delusions, beliefs that one holds special power, unique knowledge, or is extremely important.']

['Teacher: How would you differentiate between someone with grandiose delusions and someone who simply has a strong sense of self-confidence or high self-esteem?', 'For example, the person who claims to be Jesus Christ, or who claims to have knowledge going back 5,000 years, or who claims to be a great philosopher is experiencing grandiose delusions.']

["Teacher: Can you provide an example of a hallucination that involves perceiving something regarding one's thoughts that is not actually happening?", 'Other delusions include the belief that one’s thoughts are being removed (thought withdrawal) or thoughts have been placed inside one’s head (thought insertion).']

["How would you differentiate between a somatic delusion and a belief that one's body is experiencing something unusual or abnormal but not extreme like cockroaches eating one's kidneys?", 'Another type of delusion is somatic delusion, which is the belief that something highly abnormal is happening to one’s body (e.g., that one’s kidneys are being eaten by cockroaches).']

['Teacher: What does disorganized thinking refer to, and how is it usually detected?', 'Disorganized thinking refers to disjointed and incoherent thought processes—usually detected by what a person says.']

["Teacher: How does disorganized thinking typically manifest in a person's speech?", 'The person might ramble, exhibit loose associations (jump from topic to topic), or talk in a way that is so disorganized and incomprehensible that it seems as though the person is randomly combining words.']

['Teacher: Can you give me an example of how disorganized thinking can be manifested through speech?', 'Disorganized thinking is also exhibited by blatantly illogical remarks (e.g., “Fenway Park is in Boston.']
['Teacher: How do visual hallucinations differ from olfactory hallucinations?', 'I live in Boston.']

["Teacher: How can a person's speech manifest disorganized thinking through tangentiality?", 'Therefore, I live at Fenway Park.”) and by tangentiality: responding to others’ statements or questions by remarks that are either barely related or unrelated to what was said or asked.']

["What is tangentiality and how can it be observed in a person's speech?", 'For example, if a person diagnosed with schizophrenia is asked if they are interested in receiving special job training, they might state that they once rode on a train somewhere.']

["What are some examples of tangentiality in a person's speech?", 'To a person with schizophrenia, the tangential (slightly related) connection between job training and riding a train are sufficient enough to cause such a response.']

['Teacher: What are two examples of less common hallucinations mentioned in the passage?', 'Disorganized or abnormal motor behavior refers to unusual behaviors and movements: becoming unusually active, exhibiting silly child-like behaviors (giggling and self-absorbed smiling), engaging in repeated and purposeless movements, or displaying odd facial expressions and gestures.']

['What are two examples of disorganized or abnormal motor behavior mentioned in the passage?', 'In some cases, the person will exhibit catatonic behaviors, which show decreased reactivity to the environment, such as posturing, in which the person maintains a rigid and bizarre posture for long periods of time, or catatonic stupor, a complete lack of movement and verbal behavior.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of negative symptoms as described in the passage?', 'Negative symptoms are those that reflect noticeable decreases and absences in certain behaviors, emotions, or drives (Green, 2001).']

['What are some examples of negative symptoms mentioned in the passage that reflect noticeable decreases and absences in certain behaviors, emotions, or drives?', 'A person who exhibits diminished emotional expression shows no emotion in their facial expressions, speech, or movements, even when such expressions are normal or expected.']

['What are some examples of positive symptoms that are less common compared to visual and olfactory hallucinations?', 'Avolition is characterized by a lack of motivation to engage in self-initiated and meaningful activity, including the most basic of tasks, such as bathing and grooming.']
['What is an example of a less common positive symptom that is mentioned in the passage?', 'Alogia refers to reduced speech output; in simple terms, patients do not say much.']

['What is an example of a less common negative symptom mentioned in the passage?', 'Another negative symptom is asociality, or social withdrawal and lack of interest in engaging in social interactions with others.']
['What is the definition of anhedonia as mentioned in the passage?', 'A final negative symptom, anhedonia, refers to an inability to experience pleasure.']

['What is the definition of avolition as mentioned in the passage?', 'One who exhibits anhedonia expresses little interest in what most people consider to be pleasurable activities, such as hobbies, recreation, or sexual activity.']
['Teacher: What does the evidence suggest about the genetic basis of schizophrenia?', 'There is considerable evidence suggesting that schizophrenia has a genetic basis.']

['Teacher: Can you explain how having a parent with schizophrenia increases the risk of developing schizophrenia?', 'The risk of developing schizophrenia is nearly 6 times greater if one has a parent with schizophrenia than if one does not (Goldstein, Buka, Seidman, & Tsuang, 2010).']

['Teacher: How does the risk of developing schizophrenia change as the genetic relatedness to family members diagnosed with schizophrenia increases?', 'Additionally, one’s risk of developing schizophrenia increases as genetic relatedness to family members diagnosed with schizophrenia increases (Gottesman, 2001).']

['Teacher: Why are conclusions based on family and twin studies regarding the role of genetics in schizophrenia subject to criticism?', 'When considering the role of genetics in schizophrenia, as in any disorder, conclusions based on family and twin studies are subject to criticism.']

['Teacher: What are some of the reasons why conclusions based on family and twin studies regarding the role of genetics in schizophrenia can be criticized?', 'This is because family members who are closely related (such as siblings) are more likely to share similar environments than are family members who are less closely related (such as cousins); further, identical twins may be more likely to be treated similarly by others than might fraternal twins.']

['Teacher: What implications does the presence of shared environments and experiences in family and twin studies have on the conclusions regarding the role of genetics in schizophrenia?', 'Thus, family and twin studies cannot completely rule out the possible effects of shared environments and experiences.']

['Teacher: How can adoption studies help address the potential limitations of family and twin studies when studying the role of genetics in schizophrenia?', 'Such problems can be corrected by using adoption studies, in which children are separated from their parents at an early age.']

["Teacher: What did Heston's adoption study on schizophrenia involve and for how long was it conducted?", 'One of the first adoption studies of schizophrenia conducted by Heston (1966) followed 97 adoptees, including 47 who were born to mothers with schizophrenia, over a 36-year period.']

['What does the research conducted by Heston on schizophrenia adoption studies suggest about the role of genetics in the development of schizophrenia?', 'Five of the 47 adoptees (11%) whose mothers had schizophrenia were later diagnosed with schizophrenia, compared to none of the 50 control adoptees.']

['What does the research conducted by Heston and other adoption studies suggest about the hereditary nature of schizophrenia?', 'Other adoption studies have consistently reported that for adoptees who are later diagnosed with schizophrenia, their biological relatives have a higher risk of schizophrenia than do adoptive relatives (Shih, Belmonte, & Zandi, 2004).']

['Teacher: What evidence do adoption studies provide about the contribution of genetic factors to schizophrenia?', 'Although adoption studies have supported the hypothesis that genetic factors contribute to schizophrenia, they have also demonstrated that the disorder most likely arises from a combination of genetic and environmental factors, rather than just genes themselves.']

['Teacher: What were the findings of the study conducted by Tienari et al. (2004) concerning rates of schizophrenia among adoptees?', 'For example, investigators in one study examined the rates of schizophrenia among 303 adoptees (Tienari et al., 2004).']

['Teacher: What were the rates of schizophrenia observed among the adoptees who had biological mothers with schizophrenia in the study conducted by Tienari et al. (2004)?', 'A total of 145 of the adoptees had biological mothers with schizophrenia; these adoptees constituted the high genetic risk group.']

['Teacher: What were the rates of schizophrenia observed among the adoptees who had biological mothers with no psychiatric history in the study conducted by Tienari et al. (2004)?', 'The other 158 adoptees had mothers with no psychiatric history; these adoptees composed the low genetic risk group.']

["Teacher: How did the researchers determine whether the adoptees' families were healthy or disturbed in the study conducted by Tienari et al. (2004)?", 'The researchers managed to determine whether the adoptees’ families were either healthy or disturbed.']

['Teacher: How did the researchers assess whether the adoptees were raised in a disturbed family environment in the study conducted by Tienari et al. (2004)?', 'For example, the adoptees were considered to be raised in a disturbed family environment if the family exhibited a lot of criticism, conflict, and a lack of problem-solving skills.']

['Teacher: What were the rates of schizophrenia observed among adoptees who had biological mothers with schizophrenia and were raised in a healthy environment in the study conducted by Tienari et al. (2004)?', 'The findings revealed that adoptees whose biological mothers had schizophrenia (high genetic risk) and who had been raised in a disturbed family environment were much more likely to develop schizophrenia or another psychotic disorder (36.8%) than were adoptees whose biological mothers had schizophrenia but who had been raised in a healthy environment (5.8%), or than adoptees with a low genetic risk who were raised in either a disturbed (5.3%) or healthy (4.8%) environment.']

['What conclusions can be drawn from the rates of schizophrenia observed among adoptees in the study conducted by Tienari et al. (2004)?', 'Because the adoptees who were at high genetic risk were likely to develop schizophrenia only if they were raised in a disturbed home environment, this study supports a diathesis-stress interpretation of schizophrenia—both genetic vulnerability and environmental stress are necessary for schizophrenia to develop, genes alone do not show the complete picture.']

['Teacher: What is the rationale behind identifying biological abnormalities in individuals with schizophrenia, considering its assumed genetic contribution?', 'If we accept that schizophrenia is at least partly genetic in origin, as it seems to be, it makes sense that the next step should be to identify biological abnormalities commonly found in people with the disorder.']

['What are some examples of neurobiological factors that have been found to be related to schizophrenia?', 'Perhaps not surprisingly, a number of neurobiological factors have indeed been found to be related to schizophrenia.']
['What role does dopamine play in relation to schizophrenia?', 'One such factor that has received considerable attention for many years is the neurotransmitter dopamine.']

['What are the two sets of findings that stimulated interest in the role of dopamine in schizophrenia?', 'Interest in the role of dopamine in schizophrenia was stimulated by two sets of findings: drugs that increase dopamine levels can produce schizophrenia-like symptoms, and medications that block dopamine activity reduce the symptoms (Howes & Kapur, 2009).']

['What does the dopamine hypothesis of schizophrenia propose?', 'The dopamine hypothesis of schizophrenia proposed that an overabundance of dopamine or too many dopamine receptors are responsible for the onset and maintenance of schizophrenia (Snyder, 1976).']

['What does more recent work suggest about the relationship between abnormalities in dopamine and symptoms of schizophrenia?', 'More recent work in this area suggests that abnormalities in dopamine vary by brain region and thus contribute to symptoms in unique ways.']

['What are some of the symptoms associated with an overabundance of dopamine in the limbic system?', 'In general, this research has suggested that an overabundance of dopamine in the limbic system may be responsible for some symptoms, such as hallucinations and delusions, whereas low levels of dopamine in the prefrontal cortex might be responsible primarily for the negative symptoms (avolition, alogia, asociality, and anhedonia) (Davis, Kahn, Ko, & Davidson, 1991).']

['What is the role of serotonin in relation to schizophrenia and how do newer antipsychotic medications target it?', 'In recent years, serotonin has received attention, and newer antipsychotic medications used to treat the disorder work by blocking serotonin receptors (Baumeister & Hawkins, 2004).']

['Teacher: What do brain imaging studies reveal about the ventricles in people with schizophrenia?', 'Brain imaging studies reveal that people with schizophrenia have enlarged ventricles, the cavities within the brain that contain cerebral spinal fluid (Green, 2001).']

['Teacher: Why is it significant that people with schizophrenia have enlarged ventricles?', 'This finding is important because larger than normal ventricles suggests that various brain regions are reduced in size, thus implying that schizophrenia is associated with a loss of brain tissue.']

['Teacher: How are the enlarged ventricles in people with schizophrenia related to the reduced size of various brain regions and the loss of brain tissue?', 'In addition, many people with schizophrenia display a reduction in gray matter (cell bodies of neurons) in the frontal lobes (Lawrie & Abukmeil, 1998), and many show less frontal lobe activity when performing cognitive tasks (Buchsbaum et al., 1990).']

['Teacher: How do the reduced size of various brain regions and the loss of brain tissue in people with schizophrenia relate to their cognitive functions?', 'The frontal lobes are important in a variety of complex cognitive functions, such as planning and executing behavior, attention, speech, movement, and problem solving.']

['What are some specific deficits in cognitive functions that people with schizophrenia may experience due to abnormalities in the frontal lobes?', 'Hence, abnormalities in this region provide merit in explaining why people with schizophrenia experience deficits in these of areas.']

['Teacher: What are some examples of environmental factors that could impact normal brain development?', 'A number of environmental factors that could impact normal brain development might be at fault.']

['Teacher: Can you provide more specific examples of environmental factors that have been linked to compromised brain development?', 'High rates of obstetric complications in the births of children who later developed schizophrenia have been reported (Cannon, Jones, & Murray, 2002).']

['Teacher: Can you explain how exposure to influenza during the first trimester of pregnancy is linked to an increased risk of developing schizophrenia?', 'In addition, people are at an increased risk for developing schizophrenia if their mother was exposed to influenza during the first trimester of pregnancy (Brown et al., 2004).']

['Teacher: Can you provide any examples of other maternal factors during pregnancy that have been associated with an increased risk of schizophrenia in offspring?', 'Research has also suggested that a person’s emotional stress during pregnancy may increase the risk of schizophrenia in offspring.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the findings of the study that reported an elevated risk of schizophrenia in offspring whose mothers experienced the death of a relative during the first trimester of pregnancy?', 'One study reported that the risk of schizophrenia is elevated substantially in offspring whose mothers experienced the death of a relative during the first trimester of pregnancy (Khashan et al., 2008).']
['Teacher: How does marijuana use relate to schizophrenia?', 'Another variable that is linked to schizophrenia is marijuana use.']

['Teacher: What are the limitations of investigations showing a correlation between marijuana use and schizophrenia in terms of causation?', 'Although a number of reports have shown that individuals with schizophrenia are more likely to use marijuana than are individuals without schizophrenia (Thornicroft, 1990), such investigations cannot determine if marijuana use leads to schizophrenia, or vice versa.']

['Teacher: Can you explain the findings of the longitudinal studies that suggest marijuana use as a risk factor for schizophrenia?', 'However, a number of longitudinal studies have suggested that marijuana use is, in fact, a risk factor for schizophrenia.']

['Teacher: What were the findings of the classic investigation involving Swedish military personnel in relation to marijuana use and the development of schizophrenia?', 'A classic investigation of over 45,000 Swedish military personnel who were followed up after 15 years found that those individuals who had reported using marijuana at least once by the time they were conscripted (drafted) into the military were more than 2 times as likely to develop schizophrenia during the ensuing 15 years than were those who reported never using marijuana; those who had indicated using marijuana 50 or more times were 6 times as likely to develop schizophrenia (Andréasson, Allbeck, Engström, & Rydberg, 1987).']

['What do the findings of the review of 35 longitudinal studies suggest about the relationship between marijuana use and the risk of schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders?', 'More recently, a review of 35 longitudinal studies found a substantially increased risk of schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders in people who had used marijuana, with the greatest risk in the most frequent users (Moore et al., 2007).']

['What did other research indicate about the age of onset of psychotic disorders in relation to marijuana use?', 'Other work has found that marijuana use is associated with an onset of psychotic disorders at an earlier age (Large, Sharma, Compton, Slade, & Nielssen, 2011).']

['What can be concluded about the relationship between marijuana use and the development of schizophrenia based on the available evidence and research?', 'Overall, the available evidence seems to indicate that marijuana use plays a causal role in the development of schizophrenia, although it is important to point out that marijuana use is not an essential or sufficient risk factor as not all people with schizophrenia have used marijuana and the majority of marijuana users do not develop schizophrenia (Casadio, Fernandes, Murray, & Di Forti, 2011).']

['What is one plausible explanation for the association between marijuana use and the development of schizophrenia?', 'One plausible interpretation of the data is that early marijuana use may disrupt normal brain development during important early maturation periods in adolescence (Trezza, Cuomo, & Vanderschuren, 2008).']

['What does the available evidence suggest about the role of marijuana use in the development of schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders?', 'Thus, early marijuana use may set the stage for the development of schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders, especially among individuals with an established vulnerability (Casadio et al., 2011).']

['Teacher: How have early detection and treatment of conditions like heart disease and cancer improved outcomes for those affected by these conditions?', 'Early detection and treatment of conditions such as heart disease and cancer have improved survival rates and quality of life for people who suffer from these conditions.']

['What are some of the prodromal symptoms that are used to identify individuals who may develop a psychotic disorder later on?', 'A new approach involves identifying people who show minor symptoms of psychosis, such as unusual thought content, paranoia, odd communication, delusions, problems at school or work, and a decline in social functioning—which are coined prodromal symptoms—and following these individuals over time to determine which of them develop a psychotic disorder and which factors best predict such a disorder.']

['What are some of the factors that can predict a greater likelihood of prodromal individuals developing a psychotic disorder?', 'A number of factors have been identified that predict a greater likelihood that prodromal individuals will develop a psychotic disorder: genetic risk (a family history of psychosis), recent deterioration in functioning, high levels of unusual thought content, high levels of suspicion or paranoia, poor social functioning, and a history of substance abuse (Fusar-Poli et al., 2013).']

['What are some of the challenges in accurately predicting which individuals are at greatest risk for developing schizophrenia?', 'Further research will enable a more accurate prediction of those at greatest risk for developing schizophrenia, and thus to whom early intervention efforts should be directed.']
['Teacher: How are dissociative disorders characterized?', 'Dissociative disorders are characterized by an individual becoming split off, or dissociated, from their core sense of self.']

['Teacher: Can you provide examples of disrupted memory and identity in individuals with dissociative disorders?', 'Memory and identity become disturbed; these disturbances have a psychological rather than physical cause.']

['Teacher: What are some specific examples of dissociative disorders listed in the DSM-5?', 'Dissociative disorders listed in the DSM-5 include dissociative amnesia, depersonalization/derealization disorder, and dissociative identity disorder.']
['Teacher: Can you explain what amnesia refers to?', 'Amnesia refers to the partial or total forgetting of some experience or event.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a situation that could trigger dissociative amnesia?', 'An individual with dissociative amnesia is unable to recall important personal information, usually following an extremely stressful or traumatic experience such as combat, natural disasters, or being the victim of violence.']
['Teacher: Why are the memory impairments in dissociative amnesia not caused by ordinary forgetting?', 'The memory impairments are not caused by ordinary forgetting.']

['Teacher: What are some additional symptoms that individuals with dissociative amnesia may experience, besides memory impairments?', 'Some individuals with dissociative amnesia will also experience dissociative fugue (from the word “to flee” in French), whereby they suddenly wander away from their home, experience confusion about their identity, and sometimes even adopt a new identity (Cardeña & Gleaves, 2006).']
['What is dissociative fugue and what are some of its symptoms?', 'Most fugue episodes last only a few hours or days, but some can last longer.']

['What is the prevalence of dissociative amnesia according to a study conducted in upstate New York?', 'One study of residents in communities in upstate New York reported that about 1.8% experienced dissociative amnesia in the previous year (Johnson, Cohen, Kasen, & Brook, 2006).']

['Teacher: What are some of the criticisms or doubts that have been raised about the validity of dissociative amnesia?', 'Some have questioned the validity of dissociative amnesia (Pope, Hudson, Bodkin, & Oliva, 1998); it has even been characterized as a “piece of psychiatric folklore devoid of convincing empirical support” (McNally, 2003, p. 275).']

['What evidence is there to support the claim that dissociative amnesia is lacking convincing empirical support?', 'Notably, scientific publications regarding dissociative amnesia rose during the 1980s and reached a peak in the mid-1990s, followed by an equally sharp decline by 2003; in fact, only 13 cases of individuals with dissociative amnesia worldwide could be found in the literature that same year (Pope, Barry, Bodkin, & Hudson, 2006).']

['What is the significance of the decline in scientific publications regarding dissociative amnesia after the mid-1990s?', 'Further, no description of individuals showing dissociative amnesia following a trauma exists in any fictional or nonfictional work prior to 1800 (Pope, Poliakoff, Parker, Boynes, & Hudson, 2006).']

['Teacher: What does the study of 82 individuals who enrolled for treatment at a psychiatric outpatient hospital suggest about the prevalence of dissociative amnesia in psychiatric populations?', 'However, a study of 82 individuals who enrolled for treatment at a psychiatric outpatient hospital found that nearly 10% met the criteria for dissociative amnesia, perhaps suggesting that the condition is underdiagnosed, especially in psychiatric populations (Foote, Smolin, Kaplan, Legatt, & Lipschitz, 2006).']

['Teacher: How would you describe depersonalization/derealization disorder in terms of its main characteristics?', 'Depersonalization/derealization disorder is characterized by recurring episodes of depersonalization, derealization, or both.']

['Teacher: Can you explain what is meant by the term "depersonalization" in the context of depersonalization/derealization disorder?', 'Depersonalization is defined as feelings of “unreality or detachment from, or unfamiliarity with, one’s whole self or from aspects of the self” (APA, 2013, p. 302).']

['Teacher: Can you explain what is meant by the term "derealization" in the context of depersonalization/derealization disorder?', 'Individuals who experience depersonalization might believe their thoughts and feelings are not their own; they may feel robotic as though they lack control over their movements and speech; they may experience a distorted sense of time and, in extreme cases, they may sense an “out-of-body” experience in which they see themselves from the vantage point of another person.']

['Teacher: How may individuals with depersonalization/derealization disorder experience derealization in relation to their surroundings?', 'Derealization is conceptualized as a sense of “unreality or detachment from, or unfamiliarity with, the world, be it individuals, inanimate objects, or all surroundings” (APA, 2013, p. 303).']

['Teacher: How do recurring episodes of depersonalization and derealization affect individuals with depersonalization/derealization disorder?', 'A person who experiences derealization might feel as though they are in a fog or a dream, or that the surrounding world is somehow artificial and unreal.']

["Teacher: How does depersonalization/derealization disorder affect individuals' perception of their own identity and reality?", 'Individuals with depersonalization/derealization disorder often have difficulty describing their symptoms and may think they are going crazy (APA, 2013).']

['Teacher: Can you tell me which dissociative disorder is the most well-known?', 'By far, the most well-known dissociative disorder is dissociative identity disorder (formerly called multiple personality disorder).']

['What is another name formerly used to refer to dissociative identity disorder?', 'People with dissociative identity disorder exhibit two or more separate personalities or identities, each well-defined and distinct from one another.']

['What are some common symptoms or experiences that individuals with dissociative identity disorder may have?', 'They also experience memory gaps for the time during which another identity is in charge (e.g., one might find unfamiliar items in their shopping bags or among their possessions), and in some cases may report hearing voices, such as a child’s voice or the sound of somebody crying (APA, 2013).']

['What is the prevalence rate of dissociative identity disorder among upstate New York residents according to the study mentioned?', 'The study of upstate New York residents mentioned above (Johnson et al., 2006) reported that 1.5% of their sample experienced symptoms consistent with dissociative identity disorder in the previous year.']
['Teacher: Why is dissociative identity disorder (DID) considered highly controversial?', 'Dissociative identity disorder (DID) is highly controversial.']

['Teacher: What is one reason why dissociative identity disorder (DID) is considered highly controversial?', 'Some believe that people fake symptoms to avoid the consequences of illegal actions (e.g., “I am not responsible for shoplifting because it was my other personality”).']

['Can you provide an example of how people might adopt the role of a person with different personalities to their advantage?', 'In fact, it has been demonstrated that people are generally skilled at adopting the role of a person with different personalities when they believe it might be advantageous to do so.']

["What is the significance of Kenneth Bianchi's case in relation to dissociative identity disorder (DID)?", 'As an example, Kenneth Bianchi was an infamous serial killer who, along with his cousin, murdered over a dozen girls and women around Los Angeles in the late 1970s.']
["What role did dissociative identity disorder (DID) play in Kenneth Bianchi's case as a serial killer?", 'Eventually, he and his cousin were apprehended.']

["What was Kenneth Bianchi's defense strategy during his trial for the murders he committed?", 'At Bianchi’s trial, he pled not guilty by reason of insanity, presenting himself as though he had DID and claiming that a different personality (“Steve Walker”) committed the murders.']

["What was the outcome of Kenneth Bianchi's defense strategy during his trial for the murders he committed?", 'When these claims were scrutinized, he admitted faking the symptoms and was found guilty (Schwartz, 1981).']
['Teacher: Why is DID considered controversial?', 'A second reason DID is controversial is because rates of the disorder suddenly skyrocketed in the 1980s.']

['Teacher: What was one significant finding regarding the number of cases of DID in the years leading up to 1986?', 'More cases of DID were identified during the five years prior to 1986 than in the preceding two centuries (Putnam, Guroff, Silberman, Barban, & Post, 1986).']

['Teacher: What are two possible factors that could have contributed to the sudden increase in the number of identified cases of DID in the years leading up to 1986?', 'Although this increase may be due to the development of more sophisticated diagnostic techniques, it is also possible that the popularization of DID—helped in part by Sybil, a popular 1970s book (and later film) about a woman with 16 different personalities—may have prompted clinicians to overdiagnose the disorder (Piper & Merskey, 2004).']

['Teacher: What recent suggestion has caused further doubt regarding the existence of multiple personalities or identities?', 'Casting further scrutiny on the existence of multiple personalities or identities is the recent suggestion that the story of Sybil was largely fabricated, and the idea for the book might have been exaggerated (Nathan, 2011).']

["Teacher: What is the student's opinion about the legitimacy and seriousness of Dissociative Identity Disorder (DID)?", 'Despite its controversial nature, DID is clearly a legitimate and serious disorder, and although some people may fake symptoms, others suffer their entire lives with it.']

['Teacher: Can you provide some evidence to support the claim that individuals with Dissociative Identity Disorder tend to have a history of childhood trauma?', 'People with this disorder tend to report a history of childhood trauma, some cases having been corroborated through medical or legal records (Cardeña & Gleaves, 2006).']

['Teacher: How do researchers Cardeña and Gleaves (2006) support the claim that individuals with Dissociative Identity Disorder have a history of childhood trauma?', 'Research by Ross et al. (1990) suggests that in one study about 95% of people with DID were physically and/or sexually abused as children.']

['Teacher: How does the student acknowledge the potential limitations of the reported history of childhood trauma in individuals with Dissociative Identity Disorder?', 'Of course, not all reports of childhood abuse can be expected to be valid or accurate.']

['Teacher: What does the student suggest about the relationship between traumatic experiences and the development of dissociative states in individuals with Dissociative Identity Disorder?', 'However, there is strong evidence that traumatic experiences can cause people to experience states of dissociation, suggesting that dissociative states—including the adoption of multiple personalities—may serve as a psychologically important coping mechanism for threat and danger (Dalenberg et al., 2012).']

['Teacher: Could you give me an example of one disorder that can be diagnosed in adulthood but also occurs during childhood?', 'Most of the disorders we have discussed so far are typically diagnosed in adulthood, although they can and sometimes do occur during childhood.']

['Teacher: Can you name one specific disorder from this group that is typically diagnosed early in childhood?', 'However, there are a group of conditions that, when present, are diagnosed early in childhood, often before the time a child enters school.']

['Teacher: Can you provide some examples of specific neurodevelopmental disorders listed in the DSM-5?', 'These conditions are listed in the DSM-5 as neurodevelopmental disorders, and they involve developmental problems in personal, social, academic, and intellectual functioning (APA, 2013).']

['Teacher: What are some examples of specific neurodevelopmental disorders listed in the DSM-5 that commonly persist from childhood into adulthood?', 'While they are often diagnosed in childhood, many people live with them throughout adulthood.']

['What are some challenges or difficulties that individuals with attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder and autism commonly face throughout adulthood?', 'In this section, we will discuss two such disorders: attention deficit/ hyperactivity disorder and autism.']
["Teacher: How would you describe Diego's level of activity throughout the day?", 'Diego is always active, from the time he wakes up in the morning until the time he goes to bed at night.']

['Teacher: Can you explain further what Diego\'s mother meant by "he came out the womb kicking and screaming"?', 'His mother reports that he came out the womb kicking and screaming, and he has not stopped moving since.']

["Teacher: How does Diego's behavior affect his interactions with authority figures and caregivers?", 'He has a sweet disposition, but always seems to be in trouble with his teachers, parents, and after-school program counselors.']

["Teacher: How does Diego's constant movement and tendency to accidentally break things affect his daily routines?", 'He seems to accidentally break things; he lost his jacket three times last winter, and he never seems to sit still.']

["Teacher: How does Diego's impulsiveness and inability to finish tasks impact his academic performance?", 'His teachers believe he is a smart child, but he never finishes anything he starts and is so impulsive that he does not seem to learn much in school.']
['Teacher: What is the reason you say that Diego likely has attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD)?', 'Diego likely has attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).']

['Teacher: Great! Can you please explain how the symptoms of attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) were described by Hans Hoffman in the 1920s?', 'The symptoms of this disorder were first described by Hans Hoffman in the 1920s.']

['What specific symptoms of attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) did Hans Hoffman observe in his son?', 'While taking care of his son while his wife was in the hospital giving birth to a second child, Hoffman noticed that the boy had trouble concentrating on his homework, had a short attention span, and had to repeatedly go over easy homework to learn the material (Jellinek & Herzog, 1999).']

['What are some common characteristics of hyperactive children who also display symptoms of attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD)?', 'Later, it was discovered that many hyperactive children—those who are fidgety, restless, socially disruptive, and have trouble with impulse control—also display short attention spans, problems with concentration, and distractibility.']

['What led to the realization that children with attention problems often exhibit signs of hyperactivity?', 'By the 1970s, it had become clear that many children who display attention problems often also exhibit signs of hyperactivity.']

['What changes were made in the DSM-III (published in 1980) in regards to attention deficit disorder with and without hyperactivity?', 'In recognition of such findings, the DSM-III (published in 1980) included a new disorder: attention deficit disorder with and without hyperactivity, now known as attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).']

['Teacher: According to the textbook, how would you describe a child with Attention Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)?', 'A child with ADHD shows a constant pattern of inattention and/or hyperactive and impulsive behavior that interferes with normal functioning (APA, 2013).']

['What are some of the signs of inattention in a child with ADHD, according to the textbook?', 'Some of the signs of inattention include great difficulty with and avoidance of tasks that require sustained attention (such as conversations or reading), failure to follow instructions (often resulting in failure to complete school work and other duties), disorganization (difficulty keeping things in order, poor time management, sloppy and messy work), lack of attention to detail, becoming easily distracted, and forgetfulness.']

['What are some of the signs of hyperactivity in a child with ADHD, according to the textbook?', 'Hyperactivity is characterized by excessive movement, and includes fidgeting or squirming, leaving one’s seat in situations when remaining seated is expected, having trouble sitting still (e.g., in a restaurant), running about and climbing on things, blurting out responses before another person’s question or statement has been completed, difficulty waiting one’s turn for something, and interrupting and intruding on others.']
['What are some of the signs of impulsivity in a child with ADHD, according to the textbook?', 'Frequently, the hyperactive child comes across as noisy and boisterous.']

['Teacher: What are some consequences of impulsivity in children with ADHD, according to the textbook?', 'The child’s behavior is hasty, impulsive, and seems to occur without much forethought; these characteristics may explain why adolescents and young adults diagnosed with ADHD receive more traffic tickets and have more automobile accidents than do others (Thompson, Molina, Pelham, & Gnagy, 2007).']

['Teacher: What percentage of children does ADHD occur in, according to Danielson et al in 2016?', 'ADHD occurs in about 8% of children (Danielson et al, 2016), and studies estimate that for about 60% of these people, ADHD continues into adulthood (Sibley et al 2016).']

['What are the possible factors that might contribute to the higher prevalence of ADHD in boys compared to girls, according to Barkley in 2006?', 'On the average, boys are 3 times more likely to have ADHD than are girls; however, such findings might reflect the greater propensity of boys to engage in aggressive and antisocial behavior and thus incur a greater likelihood of being referred to psychological clinics (Barkley, 2006).']
['What types of challenges do children with ADHD typically face in academic and social settings?', 'Children with ADHD face severe academic and social challenges.']

['What are some specific examples of academic challenges that children with ADHD may experience compared to their non-ADHD counterparts?', 'Compared to their non-ADHD counterparts, children with ADHD have lower grades and standardized test scores and higher rates of expulsion, grade retention, and dropping out (Loe & Feldman, 2007).']

['What are some specific examples of social challenges that children with ADHD may experience compared to their non-ADHD counterparts?', 'they also are less well-liked and more often rejected by their peers (Hoza et al., 2005).']

['Teacher: What evidence supports the claim that children with ADHD experience worse long-term outcomes compared to children without ADHD?', 'Children with ADHD face considerably worse long-term outcomes than do those children who do not have ADHD.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a specific study that highlights the negative long-term outcomes for adults diagnosed with ADHD?', 'Adults diagnosed with ADHD in childhood, but not treated for ADHD, have been reported to have poor outcomes in a wide range of areas of life, including social function, education, criminality, alcohol use, substance use, and occupational outcomes (Arnold et al, 2015).']

['Teacher: What were the outcomes reported in the investigation conducted by Klein et al. in relation to adults who had ADHD symptoms in the 1970s?', 'In one investigation, 135 adults who had been identified as having ADHD symptoms in the 1970s were contacted decades later and interviewed (Klein et al., 2012).']

['What were the findings or results of the investigation conducted by Klein et al. regarding the long-term outcomes of adults who had ADHD symptoms in the 1970s?', 'Compared to a control sample of 136 participants who had never been diagnosed with ADHD, those who were diagnosed as children:']

['Teacher: What are some negative outcomes associated with ADHD, according to the passage?', 'had worse educational attainment (more likely to have dropped out of high school and less likely to have earned a bachelor’s degree); had lower socioeconomic status; held less prestigious occupational positions; were more likely to be unemployed; made considerably less in salary; scored worse on a measure of occupational functioning (indicating, for example, lower job satisfaction, poorer work relationships, and more firings); scored worse on a measure of social functioning (indicating, for example, fewer friendships and less involvement in social activities); were more likely to be divorced; and were more likely to have non-alcohol-related substance abuse problems.']
['What are some negative outcomes associated with ADHD, according to the study conducted by Klein et al. in 2012?', '(Klein et al., 2012)']

['Teacher: What do longitudinal studies show about children diagnosed with ADHD and their risk for substance abuse problems?', 'Longitudinal studies also show that children diagnosed with ADHD are at higher risk for substance abuse problems.']

['What were some specific substance abuse problems that were predicted by childhood ADHD in the study mentioned?', 'One study reported that childhood ADHD predicted later drinking problems, daily smoking, and use of marijuana and other illicit drugs (Molina & Pelham, 2003).']

['What factors might increase the risk of substance abuse problems in children diagnosed with ADHD?', 'The risk of substance abuse problems appears to be even greater for those with ADHD who also exhibit antisocial tendencies (Marshal & Molina, 2006).']

['Teacher: How has the diagnosis, treatment, and general awareness of ADHD improved over the decades?', 'Diagnosis, treatment, and general awareness of ADHD has certainly improved in the decades since the people in the above studies were diagnosed.']

['Teacher: Can you provide some examples of the positive effects of treatment for ADHD that have been observed in more recent studies?', 'Studies that include more recent outcomes show positive effects of treatment as opposed to non-treatment (Harpin, 2013; Arnold 2015).']

['Teacher: What does the student suggest about the need for further research in the field of ADHD treatment and its impacts?', 'In most cases, the same studies indicate that more research and work needs to be undertaken to understand the most effect treatments and their impacts.']

['Teacher: How do family and twin studies contribute to our understanding of the causes of ADHD?', 'Family and twin studies indicate that genetics play a significant role in the development of ADHD.']

['What do family and twin studies reveal about the hereditary factor in ADHD?', 'Burt (2009), in a review of 26 studies, reported that the median rate of concordance for identical twins was .66 (one study reported a rate of .90), whereas the median concordance rate for fraternal twins was .20.']

['What do the concordance rates for identical twins, fraternal twins, and unrelated siblings suggest about the role of genetics and environment in ADHD?', 'This study also found that the median concordance rate for unrelated (adoptive) siblings was .09; although this number is small, it is greater than 0, thus suggesting that the environment may have at least some influence.']

['What do studies suggest about the heritability of inattention and hyperactivity in ADHD?', 'Another review of studies concluded that the heritability of inattention and hyperactivity were 71% and 73%, respectively (Nikolas & Burt, 2010).']

['Teacher: According to the passage, what specific genes are believed to play a role in the regulation of the neurotransmitter dopamine in ADHD?', 'The specific genes involved in ADHD are thought to include at least two that are important in the regulation of the neurotransmitter dopamine (Gizer, Ficks, & Waldman, 2009), suggesting that dopamine may be important in ADHD.']

['What are some medications commonly used in the treatment of ADHD and how do they affect dopamine activity?', 'Indeed, medications used in the treatment of ADHD, such as methylphenidate (Ritalin) and amphetamine with dextroamphetamine (Adderall), have stimulant qualities and elevate dopamine activity.']

['What evidence from the passage supports the theory that dopamine deficits may be a vital factor in the development of ADHD?', 'People with ADHD show less dopamine activity in key regions of the brain, especially those associated with motivation and reward (Volkow et al., 2009), which provides support to the theory that dopamine deficits may be a vital factor in the development this disorder (Swanson et al., 2007).']

['Teacher: What have brain imaging studies revealed about children with ADHD and their frontal lobes?', 'Brain imaging studies have shown that children with ADHD exhibit abnormalities in their frontal lobes, an area in which dopamine is in abundance.']

['What is the role of dopamine in the frontal lobes of children with ADHD, according to brain imaging studies?', 'Compared to children without ADHD, those with ADHD appear to have smaller frontal lobe volume, and they show less frontal lobe activation when performing mental tasks.']

['What impact does the smaller frontal lobe volume and less frontal lobe activation have on the behavior of children with ADHD?', 'Recall that one of the functions of the frontal lobes is to inhibit our behavior.']
