['How do the abnormalities in the frontal lobes contribute to the hyperactive and uncontrolled behavior of children with ADHD?', 'Thus, abnormalities in this region may go a long way toward explaining the hyperactive, uncontrolled behavior of ADHD.']

['Teacher: What did many people become aware of in the 1970s in relation to childhood behavior?', 'By the 1970s, many had become aware of the connection between nutritional factors and childhood behavior.']

['Teacher: What specific nutritional factors were believed to be connected to hyperactivity in children during the 1970s?', 'At the time, much of the public believed that hyperactivity was caused by sugar and food additives, such as artificial coloring and flavoring.']

['Teacher: Why was the hypothesis connecting sugar and food additives to hyperactivity in children appealing to many people in the 1970s?', 'Undoubtedly, part of the appeal of this hypothesis was that it provided a simple explanation of (and treatment for) behavioral problems in children.']

['Teacher: What did a statistical review of 16 studies conclude about the effect of sugar consumption on the behavioral and cognitive performance of children?', 'A statistical review of 16 studies, however, concluded that sugar consumption has no effect at all on the behavioral and cognitive performance of children (Wolraich, Wilson, & White, 1995).']

['Teacher: What is the effect of food additives on hyperactivity in children with ADHD?', 'Additionally, although food additives have been shown to increase hyperactivity in non-ADHD children, the effect is rather small (McCann et al., 2007).']

['Teacher: What is one factor that has been found to have a significant relationship with ADHD when exposed to during the prenatal period?', 'Numerous studies, however, have shown a significant relationship between exposure to nicotine in cigarette smoke during the prenatal period and ADHD (Linnet et al., 2003).']

['Teacher: What is the association between maternal smoking during pregnancy and the severity of symptoms in ADHD?', 'Maternal smoking during pregnancy is associated with the development of more severe symptoms of the disorder (Thakur et al., 2013).']
['Teacher: Have you ever wondered what factors contribute to the development of ADHD?', 'No.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why the family environment is not believed to play a significant role in the development of ADHD, based on the genetics studies we discussed?', 'Remember, the genetics studies discussed above suggested that the family environment does not seem to play much of a role in the development of this disorder; if it did, we would expect the concordance rates to be higher for fraternal twins and adoptive siblings than has been demonstrated.']

['Teacher: Based on what you just said, what does the evidence suggest about the factors that trigger ADHD?', 'All things considered, the evidence seems to point to the conclusion that ADHD is triggered more by genetic and neurological factors and less by social or environmental ones.']

['Teacher: What did psychiatrist Leo Kanner describe in his seminal paper published in 1943?', 'A seminal paper published in 1943 by psychiatrist Leo Kanner described an unusual neurodevelopmental condition he observed in a group of children.']

['What were the main characteristics of the neurodevelopmental condition that psychiatrist Leo Kanner described in his paper?', 'He called this condition early infantile autism, and it was characterized mainly by an inability to form close emotional ties with others, speech and language abnormalities, repetitive behaviors, and an intolerance of minor changes in the environment and in normal routines (Bregman, 2005).']

['What is the term used today to refer to the condition that psychiatrist Leo Kanner described in his paper?', 'What the DSM-5 refers to as autism spectrum disorder today, is a direct extension of Kanner’s work.']
['Teacher: What is considered to be the most misunderstood of the neurodevelopmental disorders?', 'Autism spectrum disorder is probably the most misunderstood of the neurodevelopmental disorders.']

['What are the three main areas in which children with autism spectrum disorder show signs of significant disturbances?', 'Children with this disorder show signs of significant disturbances in three main areas: (a) deficits in social interaction, (b) deficits in communication, and (c) repetitive patterns of behavior or interests.']

['What are some examples of deficits in social interaction that children with autism spectrum disorder may exhibit?', 'These disturbances appear early in life and cause serious impairments in functioning (APA, 2013).']

['What are some examples of deficits in communication that children with autism spectrum disorder may exhibit?', 'The child with autism spectrum disorder might exhibit deficits in social interaction by not initiating conversations with other children or turning their head away when spoken to.']

['What are some examples of repetitive patterns of behavior or interests that children with autism spectrum disorder may exhibit?', 'Typically, these children do not make eye contact with others and seem to prefer playing alone rather than with others.']

['What are some possible reasons for why children with autism spectrum disorder may exhibit repetitive patterns of behavior or interests?', 'In some cases, it is almost as though these individuals live in a personal and isolated social world others are simply not privy to or able to penetrate.']

['What are some examples of deficits in communication that children with autism spectrum disorder may exhibit?', 'Communication deficits can range from a complete lack of speech, to one word responses (e.g., saying “Yes” or “No” when replying to questions or statements that require additional elaboration), to echoed speech (e.g., parroting what another person says, either immediately or several hours or even days later), to difficulty maintaining a conversation because of an inability to reciprocate others’ comments.']

['What are some examples of nonverbal cues that children with autism spectrum disorder may have difficulty using and understanding?', 'These deficits can also include problems in using and understanding nonverbal cues (e.g., facial expressions, gestures, and postures) that facilitate normal communication.']

['Teacher: How can individuals with Autism Spectrum Disorder demonstrate repetitive patterns of behavior or interests?', 'Repetitive patterns of behavior or interests can be exhibited a number of ways.']

['Teacher: Can you provide some examples of stereotyped, repetitive movements that individuals with Autism Spectrum Disorder might engage in?', 'The child might engage in stereotyped, repetitive movements (rocking, head-banging, or repeatedly dropping an object and then picking it up), or they might show great distress at small changes in routine or the environment.']

['Teacher: Can you give me some examples of highly restricted and fixated interests that individuals with Autism Spectrum Disorder might have?', 'In some cases, the person with autism spectrum disorder might show highly restricted and fixated interests that appear to be abnormal in their intensity.']

['What are some potential challenges that individuals with Autism Spectrum Disorder may face due to their highly restricted and fixated interests?', 'For instance, the person might learn and memorize every detail about something even though doing so serves no apparent purpose.']

['What other challenges might individuals with Autism Spectrum Disorder face as a result of their highly restricted and fixated interests?', 'Importantly, autism spectrum disorder is not the same thing as intellectual disability, although these two conditions are often comorbid.']

['Can you explain the difference between Autism Spectrum Disorder and intellectual disability according to the DSM-5?', 'The DSM-5 specifies that the symptoms of autism spectrum disorder are not caused or explained by intellectual disability.']

['Teacher: What term is commonly used in everyday language to refer to autism spectrum disorder?', 'Autism spectrum disorder is referred to in everyday language as autism; in fact, the disorder was termed “autistic disorder” in earlier editions of the DSM, and its diagnostic criteria were much narrower than those of autism spectrum disorder.']

['What was the term used for autism spectrum disorder in earlier editions of the DSM?', 'The qualifier “spectrum” in autism spectrum disorder is used to indicate that individuals with the disorder can show a range, or spectrum, of symptoms that vary in their magnitude and severity: some severe, others less severe.']

['What was the previous diagnosis included in the DSM that was generally recognized as a less severe form of autistic disorder?', 'The previous edition of the DSM included a diagnosis of Asperger’s disorder, generally recognized as a less severe form of autistic disorder; individuals diagnosed with Asperger’s disorder were described as having average or high intelligence and a strong vocabulary, but exhibiting impairments in social interaction and social communication, such as talking only about their special interests (Wing, Gould, & Gillberg, 2011).']

["What is the reason why the DSM-5 no longer includes the diagnosis of Asperger's disorder?", 'However, because research has failed to demonstrate that Asperger’s disorder differs qualitatively from autistic disorder, the DSM-5 does not include it, which is prompting concerns among some parents that their children may no longer be eligible for special services (“Asperger’s Syndrome Dropped,” 2012).']

['What is one possible outcome for individuals with autism spectrum disorder who have better language and intellectual skills?', 'Some individuals with autism spectrum disorder, particularly those with better language and intellectual skills, can live and work independently as adults.']

['What factors contribute to most individuals with autism spectrum disorder not being able to live and work independently as adults?', 'However, most do not because the symptoms remain sufficient to cause serious impairment in many realms of life (APA, 2013).']

['Teacher: According to the Center for Disease Control and Prevention’s Autism and Developmental Disabilities Monitoring Network, what is the current estimate for the number of children with autism spectrum disorder in the United States?', 'Current estimates from the Center for Disease Control and Prevention’s Autism and Developmental Disabilities Monitoring Network indicate that 1 in 59 children in the United States has autism spectrum disorder; the disorder is 4 times more common among boys (1 in 38) than in girls (1 in 152) (Baio et al, 2018).']

["What is the current estimate for the number of children with autism spectrum disorder in the United States according to the Center for Disease Control and Prevention's Autism and Developmental Disabilities Monitoring Network?", 'Rates of autistic spectrum disorder have increased dramatically since the 1980s.']

['What examples can you provide to support the statement that rates of autistic spectrum disorder have increased dramatically since the 1980s?', 'For example, California saw an increase of 273% in reported cases from 1987 through 1998 (Byrd, 2002); between 2000 and 2008, the rate of autism diagnoses in the United States increased 78% (CDC, 2012).']

['What are some possible factors that could contribute to the increase in the prevalence of autism spectrum disorder?', 'Although it is difficult to interpret this increase, it is possible that the rise in prevalence is the result of the broadening of the diagnosis, increased efforts to identify cases in the community, and greater awareness and acceptance of the diagnosis.']

["Based on the student's response, what are some reasons for the increase in the prevalence of autism spectrum disorder?", 'In addition, mental health professionals are now more knowledgeable about autism spectrum disorder and are better equipped to make the diagnosis, even in subtle cases (Novella, 2008).']

['Teacher: What has been the outcome of the extensive research efforts conducted over the last two decades in terms of understanding the causes of autism spectrum disorder?', 'The exact causes of autism spectrum disorder remain unknown despite massive research efforts over the last two decades (Meek, Lemery-Chalfant, Jahromi, & Valiente, 2013).']

['What evidence suggests that genetics play a significant role in the development of autism spectrum disorder?', 'Autism appears to be strongly influenced by genetics, as identical twins show concordance rates of 60%–90%, whereas concordance rates for fraternal twins and siblings are 5%–10% (Autism Genome Project Consortium, 2007).']

['What other factors, aside from genetics, have been implicated in the development of autism spectrum disorder?', 'Many different genes and gene mutations have been implicated in autism (Meek et al., 2013).']

['Teacher: How do genes related to the formation of synaptic circuits contribute to the development of autism spectrum disorder?', 'Among the genes involved are those important in the formation of synaptic circuits that facilitate communication between different areas of the brain (Gauthier et al., 2011).']

['What are some examples of environmental factors that have been associated with an increased risk for autism spectrum disorder?', 'A number of environmental factors are also thought to be associated with increased risk for autism spectrum disorder, at least in part, because they contribute to new mutations.']

['What is the relationship between exposure to pollutants and an increased risk for autism spectrum disorder?', 'These factors include exposure to pollutants, such as plant emissions and mercury, urban versus rural residence, and vitamin D deficiency (Kinney, Barch, Chayka, Napoleon, & Munir, 2009).']

['Teacher: What publication in the late 1990s claimed a link between autism and the MMR vaccine?', 'In the late 1990s, a prestigious medical journal published an article purportedly showing that autism is triggered by the MMR (measles, mumps, and rubella) vaccine.']

['Teacher: What impact did the publication claiming a link between autism and the MMR vaccine have on public opinion and the discussion surrounding child vaccinations?', 'These findings were very controversial and drew a great deal of attention, sparking an international forum on whether children should be vaccinated.']

['Teacher: Why did the publication claiming a link between autism and the MMR vaccine receive a lot of attention and controversy?', 'In a shocking turn of events, some years later the article was retracted by the journal that had published it after evidence of fraud and unethical practices on the part of the lead researcher.']

['Why did the publication of the article claiming a link between autism and the MMR vaccine receive attention from the popular media?', 'Despite the retraction, the reporting in popular media led to concerns about a possible link between vaccines and autism persisting.']

['What were the consequences of the concerns about a possible link between vaccines and autism persisting?', 'A recent survey of parents, for example, found that roughly a third of respondents expressed such a concern (Kennedy, LaVail, Nowak, Basket, & Landry, 2011); and perhaps fearing that their children would develop autism, more than 10% of parents of young children refuse or delay vaccinations (Dempsey et al., 2011).']

['What is one response from parents of children with autism to scientists who refuted the vaccine-autism link?', 'Some parents of children with autism mounted a campaign against scientists who refuted the vaccine-autism link.']

['What role did well-known celebrities, such as actress Jenny McCarthy, play in the discussion surrounding the vaccine-autism link?', 'Even politicians and several well-known celebrities weighed in; for example, actress Jenny McCarthy (who believed that a vaccination caused her son’s autism) co-authored a book on the matter.']

['What does the scientific evidence say about the link between autism and vaccinations?', 'However, there is no scientific evidence that a link exists between autism and vaccinations (Hughes, 2007).']

['What were the findings of the recent study that compared the vaccination histories of children with autism spectrum disorder and control children?', 'Indeed, a recent study compared the vaccination histories of 256 children with autism spectrum disorder with that of 752 control children across three time periods during their first two years of life (birth to 3 months, birth to 7 months, and birth to 2 years) (DeStefano, Price, & Weintraub, 2013).']

['What did the recent study find when comparing the vaccination histories of children with autism spectrum disorder and control children?', 'At the time of the study, the children were between 6 and 13 years old, and their prior vaccination records were obtained.']

['What were the findings of the recent study regarding the relationship between the number of immunogens received through vaccinations and the risk of developing autism spectrum disorder?', 'Because vaccines contain immunogens (substances that fight infections), the investigators examined medical records to see how many immunogens children received to determine if those children who received more immunogens were at greater risk for developing autism spectrum disorder.']

['What did the results of the recent study show in regards to the relationship between the number of immunogens received through vaccinations and the risk of developing autism spectrum disorder?', 'The results of this study, a portion of which are shown in Figure 15.19, clearly demonstrate that the quantity of immunogens from vaccines received during the first two years of life were not at all related to the development of autism spectrum disorder.']

['What is the main conclusion drawn from the recent study regarding the relationship between vaccinations and autism spectrum disorders?', 'There is not a relationship between vaccinations and autism spectrum disorders.']

['Teacher: How has the proliferation of the Internet in the 1990s impacted parents when it comes to information about child vaccinations and autism spectrum disorder?', 'Since the proliferation of the Internet in the 1990s, parents have been constantly bombarded with online information that can become magnified and take on a life of its own.']

['What are some challenges that parents face when trying to differentiate between reliable and unreliable information about child vaccinations and autism spectrum disorder on the Internet?', 'The enormous volume of electronic information pertaining to autism spectrum disorder, combined with how difficult it can be to grasp complex scientific concepts, can make separating good research from bad challenging (Downs, 2008).']

['What is the controversy surrounding child vaccinations and autism spectrum disorder that the student mentioned?', 'Notably, the study that fueled the controversy reported that 8 out of 12 children—according to their parents—developed symptoms consistent with autism spectrum disorder shortly after receiving a vaccination.']

['What is the main issue with using the study that reported 8 out of 12 children developing symptoms after a vaccination to conclude that vaccines cause autism spectrum disorder?', 'To conclude that vaccines cause autism spectrum disorder on this basis, as many did, is clearly incorrect for a number of reasons, not the least of which is because correlation does not imply causation, as you’ve learned.']

['Teacher: What similarity can be drawn between the belief that diet causes ADHD in the 1970s and the belief that vaccinations cause autism spectrum disorder?', 'Additionally, as was the case with diet and ADHD in the 1970s, the notion that autism spectrum disorder is caused by vaccinations is appealing to some because it provides a simple explanation for this condition.']

['Teacher: Why do some people find the belief that vaccinations cause autism appealing in terms of providing a simple explanation for the disorder?', 'Like all disorders, however, there are no simple explanations for autism spectrum disorder.']

['Teacher: Why is it important to acknowledge that there are no simple explanations for autism spectrum disorder, despite the appeal of the belief that vaccinations cause it?', 'Although the research discussed above has shed some light on its causes, science is still a long way from complete understanding of the disorder.']

["Teacher: How would you define the concept of personality in relation to one's thoughts, feelings, actions, and interactions with the world?", 'The term personality refers loosely to one’s stable, consistent, and distinctive way of thinking about, feeling, acting, and relating to the world.']

['Teacher: Can you provide some key characteristics of personality disorders?', 'People with personality disorders exhibit a personality style that differs markedly from the expectations of their culture, is pervasive and inflexible, begins in adolescence or early adulthood, and causes distress or impairment (APA, 2013).']

['Teacher: How does the onset of personality disorders typically occur?', 'Generally, individuals with these disorders exhibit enduring personality styles that are extremely troubling and often create problems for them and those with whom they come into contact.']

["Teacher: Can you provide an example of how a maladaptive personality style can disrupt someone's ability to develop and maintain social relationships?", 'Their maladaptive personality styles frequently bring them into conflict with others, disrupt their ability to develop and maintain social relationships, and prevent them from accomplishing realistic life goals.']
['Teacher: What is the number of personality disorders recognized by the DSM-5?', 'The DSM-5 recognizes 10 personality disorders, organized into 3 different clusters.']
['Teacher: Can you name one personality disorder from Cluster A?', 'Cluster A disorders include paranoid personality disorder, schizoid personality disorder, and schizotypal personality disorder.']
['Teacher: How about Cluster B? Can you name one personality disorder from Cluster B?', 'People with these disorders display a personality style that is odd or eccentric.']

['Teacher: Great job! Now, can you name one personality disorder from Cluster C?', 'Cluster B disorders include antisocial personality disorder, histrionic personality disorder, narcissistic personality disorder, and borderline personality disorder.']

["Teacher: That's correct! Now, how would you describe the personality style of individuals with Cluster C personality disorders?", 'People with these disorders usually are impulsive, overly dramatic, highly emotional, and erratic.']

['Teacher: Can you briefly describe the characteristics of individuals with avoidant personality disorder?', 'Cluster C disorders include avoidant personality disorder, dependent personality disorder, and obsessive-compulsive personality disorder (which is not the same thing as obsessive-compulsive disorder).']
['Teacher: How would you differentiate between obsessive-compulsive personality disorder and obsessive-compulsive disorder?', 'People with these disorders often appear to be nervous and fearful.']
['What is the purpose of Table 15.2 in relation to the DSM-5 personality disorders?', 'Table 15.2 provides a description of each of the DSM-5 personality disorders:']

['Teacher: What percentage of the U.S. population is estimated to suffer from a personality disorder?', 'Slightly over 9% of the U.S. population suffers from a personality disorder, with avoidant and schizoid personality disorders the most frequent (Lezenweger, Lane, Loranger, & Kessler, 2007).']

['Teacher: Why are borderline personality disorder and antisocial personality disorder considered particularly problematic?', 'Two of these personality disorders, borderline personality disorder and antisocial personality disorder, are regarded by many as especially problematic.']

['Teacher: How was the term "borderline" originally used to describe patients with borderline personality disorder?', 'The “borderline” in borderline personality disorder was originally coined in the late 1930s in an effort to describe patients who appeared anxious, but were prone to brief psychotic experiences—that is, patients who were thought to be literally on the borderline between anxiety and psychosis (Freeman, Stone, Martin, & Reinecke, 2005).']

['Teacher: How did the term "borderline" initially describe patients with borderline personality disorder, according to the passage?', 'Today, borderline personality disorder has a completely different meaning.']

['Teacher: What are the main characteristics that define Borderline Personality Disorder according to the passage?', 'Borderline personality disorder is characterized chiefly by instability in interpersonal relationships, self-image, and mood, as well as marked impulsivity (APA, 2013).']

['Teacher: According to the passage, what are the behaviors that individuals with borderline personality disorder may exhibit in order to avoid abandonment or separation?', 'People with borderline personality disorder cannot tolerate the thought of being alone and will make frantic efforts (including making suicidal gestures and engaging in self-mutilation) to avoid abandonment or separation (whether real or imagined).']

['What is one example of how relationships can become intense and unstable for individuals with borderline personality disorder, according to the passage?', 'Their relationships are intense and unstable; for example, a romantic partner may be idealized early in a relationship, but then later vilified at the slightest sign they appear to no longer show interest.']

['What is an example of how individuals with borderline personality disorder may exhibit instability in self-image and personal choices, according to the passage?', 'These individuals have an unstable view of self and, thus, might suddenly display a shift in personal attitudes, interests, career plans, and choice of friends.']

['What are the potential consequences of the instability in self-image and personal choices for individuals with borderline personality disorder, as mentioned in the passage?', 'For example, a law school student may, despite having invested tens of thousands of dollars toward earning a law degree and despite having performed well in the program, consider dropping out and pursuing a career in another field.']

['What are some examples of impulsive and self-destructive behaviors that individuals with borderline personality disorder may engage in, as mentioned in the passage?', 'People with borderline personality disorder may be highly impulsive and may engage in reckless and self-destructive behaviors such as excessive gambling, spending money irresponsibly, substance abuse, engaging in unsafe sex, and reckless driving.']

['According to the passage, how do individuals with borderline personality disorder sometimes express their intense and inappropriate anger?', 'They sometimes show intense and inappropriate anger that they have difficulty controlling, and they can be moody, sarcastic, bitter, and verbally abusive.']

['Teacher: What is the estimated prevalence of borderline personality disorder in the U.S. population according to Lezenweger et al. (2007)?', 'The prevalence of borderline personality disorder in the U.S. population is estimated to be around 1.4% (Lezenweger et al., 2007), but the rates are higher among those who use mental health services; approximately 10% of mental health outpatients and 20% of psychiatric inpatients meet the criteria for diagnosis (APA, 2013).']

['What are the rates of borderline personality disorder among mental health outpatients and psychiatric inpatients?', 'Additionally, borderline personality disorder is comorbid with anxiety, mood, and substance use disorders (Lezenweger et al., 2007).']
['Teacher: What role do genetic factors play in the development of borderline personality disorder?', 'Genetic factors appear to be important in the development of borderline personality disorder.']

['Teacher: Can you explain how the high degree of heritability of core personality traits relates to the role of genetic factors in the development of borderline personality disorder?', 'For example, core personality traits that characterize this disorder, such as impulsivity and emotional instability, show a high degree of heritability (Livesley, 2008).']

['Teacher: How do the high rates of borderline personality disorder among relatives of individuals with the disorder support the role of genetic factors in its development?', 'Also, the rates of borderline personality disorder among relatives of people with this disorder have been found to be as high as 24.9% (White, Gunderson, Zanarani, & Hudson, 2003).']

['Teacher: How does the high prevalence of childhood physical, sexual, and/or emotional abuse among individuals with borderline personality disorder suggest the involvement of environmental factors in its development?', 'Individuals with borderline personality disorder report experiencing childhood physical, sexual, and/or emotional abuse at rates far greater than those observed in the general population (Afifi et al., 2010), indicating that environmental factors are also crucial.']

['Teacher: How do the findings regarding the high heritability of core personality traits and the prevalence of childhood abuse among individuals with borderline personality disorder suggest a possible interaction between genetic factors and environmental experiences in determining the disorder?', 'These findings would suggest that borderline personality disorder may be determined by an interaction between genetic factors and adverse environmental experiences.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how genetic factors and adverse environmental experiences interact to contribute to the development of borderline personality disorder?', 'Consistent with this hypothesis, one study found that the highest rates of borderline personality disorder were among individuals with a borderline temperament (characterized by high novelty seeking and high harm-avoidance) and those who experienced childhood abuse and/or neglect (Joyce et al., 2003).']

['Teacher: Can you explain the concept of a moral compass and its significance in the context of human behavior?', 'Most human beings live in accordance with a moral compass, a sense of right and wrong.']

['Teacher: How does the presence of a moral compass shape and influence human behavior in society?', 'Most individuals learn at a very young age that there are certain things that should not be done.']
['Teacher: What role does a moral compass play in preventing individuals from engaging in dishonest behaviors like lying or cheating?', 'We learn that we should not lie or cheat.']

['Teacher: How might the absence or weak development of a moral compass contribute to antisocial behaviors, such as theft or manipulation?', 'We are taught that it is wrong to take things that do not belong to us, and that it is wrong to exploit others for personal gain.']

['Teacher: How does the lack of a moral compass in individuals with antisocial personality disorder contribute to their tendency to engage in unethical behaviors, such as manipulation and exploitation of others?', 'People with antisocial personality disorder, however, do not seem to have a moral compass.']

['Teacher: How can the absence of a moral compass in individuals with antisocial personality disorder affect their interactions and relationships with others?', 'These individuals act as though they neither have a sense of nor care about right or wrong.']

['Teacher: How might the lack of a moral compass in individuals with antisocial personality disorder contribute to the harm they can cause to others and society?', 'Not surprisingly, these people represent a serious problem for others and for society in general.']

['Teacher: What characteristic of individuals with antisocial personality disorder is emphasized by the DSM-5?', 'According to the DSM-5, the individual with antisocial personality disorder shows no regard at all for other people’s rights or feelings.']

["Teacher: Can you provide some examples of how individuals with antisocial personality disorder exhibit a lack of regard for other people's rights or feelings?", 'This lack of regard is exhibited a number of ways and can include repeatedly performing illegal acts, lying to or conning others, impulsivity and recklessness, irritability and aggressiveness toward others, and failure to act in a responsible way (e.g., leaving debts unpaid) (APA, 2013).']

['Teacher: How does the lack of remorse in individuals with antisocial personality disorder contribute to their ability to hurt, manipulate, exploit, and abuse others without feeling guilty?', 'People with this disorder have no remorse over their misdeeds; these people will hurt, manipulate, exploit, and abuse others and not feel any guilt.']

['Teacher: How does the age requirement for diagnosis of antisocial personality disorder align with the emergence of signs of the disorder early in life?', 'Signs of this disorder can emerge early in life; however, a person must be at least 18 years old to be diagnosed with antisocial personality disorder.']

['Teacher: How do individuals with antisocial personality disorder generally perceive the world around them?', 'People with antisocial personality disorder seem to view the world as self-serving and unkind.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how individuals with antisocial personality disorder might justify using whatever means necessary to get by in life?', 'They seem to think that they should use whatever means necessary to get by in life.']

['Teacher: How does the perception of others as pawns affect the behavior of individuals with antisocial personality disorder?', 'They tend to view others not as living, thinking, feeling beings, but rather as pawns to be used or abused for a specific purpose.']

['Teacher: How does the presence of an over-inflated sense of self contribute to the behavior of individuals with antisocial personality disorder?', 'They often have an over-inflated sense of themselves and can appear extremely arrogant.']

['How does the display of superficial charm by individuals with antisocial personality disorder relate to their deceptive nature and manipulation of others?', 'They frequently display superficial charm; for example, without really meaning it they might say exactly what they think another person wants to hear.']
['What is one aspect of empathy that individuals with antisocial personality disorder lack?', 'They lack empathy: they are incapable of understanding the emotional point-of-view of others.']

['What are some typical behaviors exhibited by individuals with antisocial personality disorder?', 'People with this disorder may become involved in illegal enterprises, show cruelty toward others, leave their jobs with no plans to obtain another job, have multiple sexual partners, repeatedly get into fights with others, and show reckless disregard for themselves and others (e.g., repeated arrests for driving while intoxicated) (APA, 2013).']

['Teacher: What is the purpose of the alternative model for conceptualizing personality disorders based on the traits identified in the Five Factor Model of personality in the DSM-5?', 'The DSM-5 has included an alternative model for conceptualizing personality disorders based on the traits identified in the Five Factor Model of personality.']

['Teacher: How does the alternative model in the DSM-5 address the level of personality functioning in individuals with personality disorders?', 'This model addresses the level of personality functioning such as impairments in self (identity or self-direction) and interpersonal (empathy or intimacy) functioning.']

['Teacher: What are the predominant traits identified in individuals with antisocial personality disorder according to the DSM-5 alternative model?', 'In the case of antisocial personality disorder, the DSM-5 identifies the predominant traits of antagonism (such as disregard for others’ needs, manipulative or deceitful behavior) and disinhibition (characterized by impulsivity, irresponsibility, and risk-taking) (Harwood, Schade, Krueger, Wright, & Markon, 2012).']

['Teacher: How does the DSM-5 alternative model for antisocial personality disorder incorporate the traits of attention seeking and low anxiousness?', 'A psychopathology specifier is also included that emphasizes traits such as attention seeking and low anxiousness (lack of concern about negative consequences for risky or harmful behavior) (Crego & Widiger, 2014).']

['Teacher: What is the approximate prevalence of antisocial personality disorder in the population?', 'Antisocial personality disorder is observed in about 3.6% of the population; the disorder is much more common among men, with a 3 to 1 ratio of men to women, and it is more likely to occur in men who are younger, widowed, separated, divorced, of lower socioeconomic status, who live in urban areas, and who live in the western United States (Compton, Conway, Stinson, Colliver, & Grant, 2005).']

['What are some risk factors associated with antisocial personality disorder?', 'Compared to men with antisocial personality disorder, women with the disorder are more likely to have experienced emotional neglect and sexual abuse during childhood, and they are more likely to have had parents who abused substances and who engaged in antisocial behaviors themselves (Alegria et al., 2013).']

['Teacher: According to Table 15.3, what are some of the differences between the specific types of antisocial behaviors exhibited by men and women with antisocial personality disorder, as mentioned in the passage?', 'Family, twin, and adoption studies suggest that both genetic and environmental factors influence the development of antisocial personality disorder, as well as general antisocial behavior (criminality, violence, aggressiveness) (Baker, Bezdjian, & Raine, 2006).']

['Teacher: According to the passage, what are some personality and temperament dimensions that have a substantial genetic influence on antisocial personality disorder in both men and women?', 'Personality and temperament dimensions that are related to this disorder, including fearlessness, impulsive antisociality, and callousness, have a substantial genetic influence (Livesley & Jang, 2008).']

['Teacher: According to the passage, what does the research on adoption studies show about the development of antisocial behavior in individuals with antisocial personality disorder?', 'Adoption studies clearly demonstrate that the development of antisocial behavior is determined by the interaction of genetic factors and adverse environmental circumstances (Rhee & Waldman, 2002).']

['Teacher: How does the research on adoption studies in individuals with antisocial personality disorder show the impact of both genetic factors and environmental circumstances on the development of antisocial behavior?', 'For example, one investigation found that adoptees of biological parents with antisocial personality disorder were more likely to exhibit adolescent and adult antisocial behaviors if they were raised in adverse adoptive family environments (e.g., adoptive parents had marital problems, were divorced, used drugs, and had legal problems) than if they were raised in a more normal adoptive environment (Cadoret, Yates, Ed, Woodworth, & Stewart, 1995).']

['Teacher: How have researchers directed their attention to factors such as the community, the structure and functioning of the family, and peer groups in relation to the development of antisocial personality disorder?', 'Researchers who are interested in the importance of environment in the development of antisocial personality disorder have directed their attention to such factors as the community, the structure and functioning of the family, and peer groups.']

['What specific examples within the community, family structure, and peer groups have researchers found to influence the likelihood of engaging in antisocial behavior?', 'Each of these factors influences the likelihood of antisocial behavior.']

['How did the longitudinal investigation measure risk factors for violence among Seattle-area youth?', 'One longitudinal investigation of more than 800 Seattle-area youth measured risk factors for violence at 10, 14, 16, and 18 years of age (Herrenkohl et al., 2000).']

['What were some of the specific risk factors that were examined in relation to antisocial behavior among Seattle-area youth?', 'The risk factors examined included those involving the family, peers, and community.']

['What does Figure 15.20 in the textbook illustrate regarding the findings of the study on risk factors for antisocial behavior among Seattle-area youth?', 'A portion of the findings from this study are provided in Figure 15.20.']

['Teacher: According to Table 15.3, do men and women with antisocial personality disorder exhibit similar emotional experiences compared to the general population?', 'Those with antisocial tendencies do not seem to experience emotions the way most other people do.']

['Teacher: According to the passage, how do individuals with antisocial personality disorder typically respond to environmental cues that signal punishment, pain, or noxious stimulation?', 'These individuals fail to show fear in response to environment cues that signal punishment, pain, or noxious stimulation.']

['Teacher: According to Table 15.3, how do individuals with antisocial personality disorder differ from those without the disorder in terms of their skin conductance response to anticipated electric shock?', 'For instance, they show less skin conductance (sweatiness on hands) in anticipation of electric shock than do people without antisocial tendencies (Hare, 1965).']

['Teacher: What does skin conductance measure and why is it used in assessing autonomic nervous system functioning?', 'Skin conductance is controlled by the sympathetic nervous system and is used to assess autonomic nervous system functioning.']

['Teacher: Why is skin conductance an important measure in assessing autonomic nervous system functioning?', 'When the sympathetic nervous system is active, people become aroused and anxious, and sweat gland activity increases.']

['Teacher: According to Table 15.3, how do individuals with antisocial personality disorder differ from those without the disorder in terms of their levels of arousal or anxiety?', 'Thus, increased sweat gland activity, as assessed through skin conductance, is taken as a sign of arousal or anxiety.']

['Teacher: According to the passage, what characteristics may be associated with a lack of skin conductance in individuals with antisocial personality disorder?', 'For those with antisocial personality disorder, a lack of skin conductance may indicate the presence of characteristics such as emotional deficits and impulsivity that underlie the propensity for antisocial behavior and negative social relationships (Fung et al., 2005).']

['Teacher: How does Table 15.3 contribute to our understanding of the differences in specific types of antisocial behaviors exhibited by men and women with antisocial personality disorder?', 'Another example showing that those with antisocial personality disorder fail to respond to environmental cues comes from a recent study by Stuppy-Sullivan and Baskin-Sommers (2019).']

['Teacher: How does the study by Stuppy-Sullivan and Baskin-Sommers (2019) complement the information provided in Table 15.3 regarding the specific types of antisocial behaviors exhibited by individuals with antisocial personality disorder?', 'The researchers studied cognitive and reward factors associated with antisocial personality disorder dysfunction in 119 incarcerated males.']

['Teacher: How do the tasks administered to the incarcerated males in the study by Stuppy-Sullivan and Baskin-Sommers (2019) help us understand the cognitive and reward factors associated with antisocial personality disorder dysfunction?', 'Each subject was administered three tasks targeting different aspects of cognition and reward.']

['Teacher: What were the different aspects of cognition and reward targeted by the three tasks administered to the incarcerated males in the study by Stuppy-Sullivan and Baskin-Sommers (2019)?', 'High-magnitude rewards tended to impair perception in those with antisocial personality disorder, worsened executive function when they were consciously aware of the high rewards, and worsened inhibition when the tasks placed high demand on working memory.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why it is important for us to understand how many people experience mental illness and receive treatment?', 'Before we explore the various approaches to therapy used today, let’s begin our study of therapy by looking at how many people experience mental illness and how many receive treatment.']

["Teacher: That's a great statistic! Can you please share with the class how many adults in the United States received mental health treatment in 2017, based on the same source?", 'According to the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (2017), 18.9% of U.S. adults experienced mental illness in 2017.']

['What percentage of teens (ages 13-18) in the United States experienced mental illness in a given year according to the National Institute of Mental Health?', 'For teens (ages 13–18), the rate is similar to that of adults, and for children ages 8–15, current estimates suggest that approximately 13% experience mental illness in a given year (National Institute of Mental Health [NIMH], 2017).']

['Teacher: What percentage of adults received treatment for a mental health issue according to the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA) in 2017?', 'According to the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA), in 2017, 14.8% of adults received treatment for a mental health issue (NIMH, 2017).']

["What settings were included in the study's definition of treatment for mental health issues?", 'These percentages, shown in Figure 16.2, reflect the number of adults who received care in inpatient and outpatient settings and/or used prescription medication for psychological disorders.']
['Teacher: Who else besides adults can receive mental health services?', 'Children and adolescents also receive mental health services.']

['Teacher: According to the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES), what percentage of children with mental disorders have received treatment within the past year?', "The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) found that approximately half (50.6%) of children with mental disorders had received treatment for their disorder within the past year (NIMH, n.d.)."]

['Teacher: What did the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) find regarding the treatment rates of children with mental disorders within the past year?', 'However, there were some differences between treatment rates by category of disorder (Figure 16.3).']

['Teacher: According to Figure 16.3, which category of disorder had the lowest treatment rates for children in the past year?', 'For example, children with anxiety disorders were least likely to have received treatment in the past year, while children with ADHD or a conduct disorder were more likely to receive treatment.']

['Teacher: How does the history of mental health treatment from the past compare to our current understanding of mental illness?', 'Let’s take a look at the history of mental health treatment from the past (with some questionable approaches in light of modern understanding of mental illness) to where we are today.']
['Teacher: How have people with mental illness been treated throughout much of history?', 'For much of history, people with mental illness have been treated very poorly.']

['Teacher: What were some of the beliefs about the causes of mental illness in the past?', 'It was believed that mental illness was caused by demonic possession, witchcraft, or an angry god (Szasz, 1960).']
['Teacher: How were abnormal behaviors viewed and explained in medieval times?', 'For example, in medieval times, abnormal behaviors were viewed as a sign that a person was possessed by demons.']

['Teacher: Can you provide some examples of the treatment methods used during medieval times to release demons from individuals who were considered possessed?', 'If someone was considered to be possessed, there were several forms of treatment to release spirits from the individual.']

['What were some other treatment methods used during medieval times to release demons from individuals who were considered possessed?', 'The most common treatment was exorcism, often conducted by priests or other religious figures:']

['Teacher: Were there any physical interventions or rituals performed during exorcisms in medieval times to release demons from individuals who were considered possessed?', 'Incantations and prayers were said over the person’s body, and they may have been given some medicinal drinks.']

['What is trephining, and how was it used as a treatment method for mental illness during medieval times?', 'Another form of treatment for extreme cases of mental illness was trephining: A small hole was made in the afflicted individual’s skull to release spirits from the body.']
['What were some of the potential risks or dangers associated with the practice of trephining during medieval times?', 'Most people treated in this manner died.']

['What were some other practices besides exorcism and trephining that were used to treat people with psychological disorders during medieval times?', 'In addition to exorcism and trephining, other practices involved execution or imprisonment of people with psychological disorders.']
['What were the consequences of the treatment methods used in medieval times for individuals with mental illness?', 'Still others were left to be homeless beggars.']

['How did the treatment methods in medieval times contribute to the stigma and mistreatment of individuals with mental illness?', 'Generally speaking, most people who exhibited strange behaviors were greatly misunderstood and treated cruelly.']

['What were some of the prevailing beliefs in earlier history about the causes of mental illness?', 'The prevailing theory of psychopathology in earlier history was the idea that mental illness was the result of demonic possession by either an evil spirit or an evil god because early beliefs incorrectly attributed all unexplainable phenomena to deities deemed either good or evil.']

['Teacher: What was a common belief perpetuated by some religious organizations from the late 1400s to the late 1600s, regarding certain individuals?', 'From the late 1400s to the late 1600s, a common belief perpetuated by some religious organizations was that some people made pacts with the devil and committed horrible acts, such as eating babies (Blumberg, 2007).']

['What were some of the acts that these individuals were accused of committing, according to some religious organizations from the late 1400s to the late 1600s?', 'These people were considered to be witches and were tried and condemned by courts—they were often burned at the stake.']

['What was the estimated number of mentally ill people who were killed after being accused of witchcraft worldwide?', 'Worldwide, it is estimated that tens of thousands of mentally ill people were killed after being accused of being witches or under the influence of witchcraft (Hemphill, 1966)']

['Teacher: What was the common approach for dealing with individuals who were considered odd and unusual during the 18th century?', 'By the 18th century, people who were considered odd and unusual were placed in asylums (Figure 16.4).']

['What was the primary emphasis of placing individuals considered odd and unusual in asylums during the 18th century?', 'Asylums were the first institutions created for the specific purpose of housing people with psychological disorders, but the focus was ostracizing them from society rather than treating their disorders.']

['What were some of the inhumane conditions that individuals in asylums during the 18th century were subjected to?', 'Often these people were kept in windowless dungeons, beaten, chained to their beds, and had little to no contact with caregivers.']

['Teacher: Who was the physician that advocated for more humane treatment of individuals with mental illness in the late 1700s?', 'In the late 1700s, a French physician, Philippe Pinel, argued for more humane treatment of people with mental illness.']

['What did Philippe Pinel do for patients at La Salpêtrière in Paris in 1795?', 'He suggested that they be unchained and talked to, and that’s just what he did for patients at La Salpêtrière in Paris in 1795 (Figure 16.5).']

["Why did patients benefit from Philippe Pinel's more humane treatment at La Salpêtrière in Paris in 1795?", 'Patients benefited from this more humane treatment, and many were able to leave the hospital.']

['Teacher: Who was the prominent figure in the 19th century that spearheaded the reform efforts for mental health care in the United States?', 'In the 19th century, Dorothea Dix led reform efforts for mental health care in the United States (Figure 16.6).']

['Teacher: What did Dorothea Dix discover about the mental health care system for the mentally ill and poor in the 19th century?', 'She investigated how those who are mentally ill and poor were cared for, and she discovered an underfunded and unregulated system that perpetuated abuse of this population (Tiffany, 1891).']

['Teacher: What steps did Dorothea Dix take after discovering the underfunded and unregulated mental health care system for the mentally ill and poor in the 19th century?', 'Horrified by her findings, Dix began lobbying various state legislatures and the U.S. Congress for change (Tiffany, 1891).']

["Teacher: What was the outcome of Dorothea Dix's lobbying efforts for mental health care reform in the 19th century?", 'Her efforts led to the creation of the first mental asylums in the United States.']

['Teacher: What were the conditions like in a typical asylum despite the efforts of reformers?', 'Despite reformers’ efforts, however, a typical asylum was filthy, offered very little treatment, and often kept people for decades.']

['What treatment method was used at Willard Psychiatric Center in upstate New York?', 'At Willard Psychiatric Center in upstate New York, for example, one treatment was to submerge patients in cold baths for long periods of time.']

['What were some of the negative effects of the electroshock treatment administered at Willard Psychiatric Center?', 'Electroshock treatment was also used, and the way the treatment was administered often broke patients’ backs; in 1943, doctors at Willard administered 1,443 shock treatments (Willard Psychiatric Center, 2009).']

['What are some of the ways that electroshock treatment has changed since its use at Willard Psychiatric Center?', '(Electroshock is now called electroconvulsive treatment, and the therapy is still used, but with safeguards and under anesthesia.']

['What are some of the safeguards and modifications that have been implemented in the modern use of electroconvulsive treatment?', 'A brief application of electric stimulus is used to produce a generalized seizure.']
['What is the main point of controversy surrounding the modern use of electroconvulsive treatment?', 'Controversy continues over its effectiveness versus the side effects.)']

['What are some of the side effects that have caused controversy regarding the modern use of electroconvulsive treatment?', 'Many of the wards and rooms were so cold that a glass of water would be frozen by morning (Willard Psychiatric Center, 2009).']
['What is significant about the closing of Willard Psychiatric Center in 1995?', 'Willard’s doors were not closed until 1995.']

['What are some examples of the deplorable conditions that persisted in psychiatric institutions well into the 20th century?', 'Conditions like these remained commonplace until well into the 20th century.']

['Teacher: Can you tell me when antipsychotic medications were introduced and when they gained popularity?', 'Starting in 1954 and gaining popularity in the 1960s, antipsychotic medications were introduced.']

['What were some of the benefits of antipsychotic medications in treating psychological disorders?', 'These proved a tremendous help in controlling the symptoms of certain psychological disorders, such as psychosis.']

['Teacher: What were some of the symptoms of psychosis that antipsychotic medications helped to control?', 'Psychosis was a common diagnosis of individuals in mental hospitals, and it was often evidenced by symptoms like hallucinations and delusions, indicating a loss of contact with reality.']

['What was the purpose of the Mental Retardation Facilities and Community Mental Health Centers Construction Act passed in 1963?', 'Then in 1963, Congress passed and John F. Kennedy signed the Mental Retardation Facilities and Community Mental Health Centers Construction Act, which provided federal support and funding for community mental health centers (National Institutes of Health, 2013).']

['What was the significance of the Mental Retardation Facilities and Community Mental Health Centers Construction Act in the United States?', 'This legislation changed how mental health services were delivered in the United States.']

['What was the impact of the Mental Retardation Facilities and Community Mental Health Centers Construction Act on the delivery of mental health services in the United States?', 'It started the process of deinstitutionalization, the closing of large asylums, by providing for people to stay in their communities and be treated locally.']
['What was the purpose of deinstitutionalization in the United States?', 'In 1955, there were 558,239 severely mentally ill patients institutionalized at public hospitals (Torrey, 1997).']

['What was the impact of deinstitutionalization on the number of hospitalized individuals with severe mental illness in the United States from 1955 to 1994?', 'By 1994, by percentage of the population, there were 92% fewer hospitalized individuals (Torrey, 1997).']
['Teacher: What do we have across the nation today in terms of mental health centers?', 'Today, there are community mental health centers across the nation.']

['Teacher: Can you tell me more about the location and purpose of community mental health centers?', 'They are located in neighborhoods near the homes of clients, and they provide large numbers of people with mental health services of various kinds and for many kinds of problems.']

['Teacher: What was one of the challenges that arose as a result of deinstitutionalization and the establishment of community mental health centers?', 'Unfortunately, part of what occurred with deinstitutionalization was that those released from institutions were supposed to go to newly created centers, but the system was not set up effectively.']

['Teacher: How did the challenges of underfunding and inadequate training contribute to the effectiveness of community mental health centers during the time of deinstitutionalization?', 'Centers were underfunded, staff was not trained to handle severe illnesses such as schizophrenia, there was high staff burnout, and no provision was made for the other services people needed, such as housing, food, and job training.']

['Teacher: What were some of the consequences that arose for individuals released under deinstitutionalization when community mental health centers lacked essential support services?', 'Without these supports, those people released under deinstitutionalization often ended up homeless.']

['Teacher: How does the lack of essential support services in community mental health centers contribute to the issue of homelessness among individuals who were released under deinstitutionalization?', 'Even today, a large portion of the homeless population is considered to be mentally ill (Figure 16.7).']

['Teacher: What percentage of homeless adults living in shelters are reported to have mental illness?', 'Statistics show that 26% of homeless adults living in shelters experience mental illness (U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development [HUD], 2011).']

['Teacher: What are some significant concerns regarding mental health issues and the corrections system?', 'Mental health issues are also significant concerns regarding those involved in the corrections system.']

['Teacher: Excellent. Can you provide any additional statistics or data that support the significant concerns regarding mental health issues and the corrections system?', 'According to a 2006 special report by the Bureau of Justice Statistics (BJS), approximately 705,600 adults with mental health issues were incarcerated in the state prison system, and another 78,800 were incarcerated in the federal prison system.']
['Why is it important to have accurate statistics and data regarding the number of incarcerated individuals with mental health issues?', 'A further 479,000 were in local jails.']

['What is the significance of having accurate statistics and data regarding the representation of people with mental illnesses in probation and parole populations?', 'According to the study, “people with mental illnesses are overrepresented in probation and parole populations at estimated rates ranging from two to four times the general population” (Prins & Draper, 2009, p. 23).']

['What is one impact of the increasing burden faced by the correctional system in managing people with mental health issues?', 'The correctional system faces increasing burdens in managing and supporting people with mental health issues (Torrey et al., 2014).']

['What are some long-term effects that can be triggered or exacerbated by the incarceration experience for individuals with mental health issues?', 'The incarceration experience itself exacerbates existing issues, triggers disturbances, or leads to long term effects such as PTSD, depression, or other disorders.']

['What are some of the specific physical or emotional traumas that individuals with mental health issues may experience while incarcerated?', 'While incarcerated, people are often subjected to or witness violence or sexual assault, face isolation from family, and endure other physical or emotional traumas (Edgemon & Clay-Warner, 2019).']

['Teacher: What is the current trend in mental health treatment, replacing asylums?', 'Today, instead of asylums, there are psychiatric hospitals run by state governments and local community hospitals focused on short-term care.']

['Teacher: What is the average length of stay in the psychiatric hospitals and community hospitals focused on mental health treatment today?', 'In all types of hospitals, the emphasis is on short-term stays, with the average length of stay being less than two weeks and often only several days.']

['Teacher: Why is the average length of stay in psychiatric hospitals and community hospitals focused on mental health treatment today usually less than two weeks?', 'This is partly due to the very high cost of psychiatric hospitalization, which can be about $800 to $1000 per night (Stensland, Watson, & Grazier, 2012).']

['Teacher: What is one factor that contributes to the average length of stay in psychiatric hospitals and community hospitals being less than two weeks?', 'Therefore, insurance coverage often limits the length of time a person can be hospitalized for treatment.']

['Teacher: What is one of the main criteria for individuals to be hospitalized for mental health treatment today?', 'Usually individuals are hospitalized only if they are an imminent threat to themselves or others.']
['Teacher: What is the general pattern of mental health treatment for individuals with mental illnesses?', 'Most people who have mental illnesses are not hospitalized.']

['Teacher: What are some common symptoms or signs that might indicate the need for psychological treatment for individuals with mental illnesses?', 'If someone is feeling very depressed, complains of hearing voices, or feels anxious all the time, they might seek psychological treatment.']
['Teacher: Who are some of the individuals who might refer someone for psychological treatment?', 'A friend, spouse, or parent might refer someone for treatment.']

['Teacher: What is the usual first step for an individual seeking psychological treatment for a mental illness?', 'The individual might go see their primary care physician first and then be referred to a mental health practitioner.']

["Teacher: Why might some individuals seek mental health treatment specifically if they are involved with the state's child protective services?", 'Some people seek treatment because they are involved with the state’s child protective services—that is, their children have been removed from their care due to abuse or neglect.']

['Teacher: What types of treatments might be available for parents who are referred to psychiatric or substance abuse facilities as part of their involvement with child protective services?', 'The parents might be referred to psychiatric or substance abuse facilities and the children would likely receive treatment for trauma.']

['What is the ultimate goal of treatment for parents referred to psychiatric or substance abuse facilities as part of their involvement with child protective services?', 'If the parents are interested in and capable of becoming better parents, the goal of treatment might be family reunification.']

['What are the potential outcomes for children whose parents are unable to change and refuse to enter treatment?', 'For other children whose parents are unable to change—for example, the parent or parents who are heavily addicted to drugs and refuse to enter treatment—the goal of therapy might be to help the children adjust to foster care and/or adoption (Figure 16.8).']
['Teacher: Why do some individuals seek therapy in relation to the criminal justice system?', 'Some people seek therapy because the criminal justice system referred them or required them to go.']

['Teacher: Can you provide me with another example of how the criminal justice system may require individuals to seek therapy?', 'For some individuals, for example, attending weekly counseling sessions might be a condition of parole.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why attending therapy sessions as a condition of parole may be considered seeking therapy involuntarily?', 'If an individual is mandated to attend therapy, they are seeking services involuntarily.']
['Teacher: What are some potential benefits and challenges of seeking therapy involuntarily?', 'Involuntary treatment refers to therapy that is not the individual’s choice.']
['Teacher: What are some potential benefits and challenges of individuals voluntarily seeking therapy?', 'Other individuals might voluntarily seek treatment.']
['Teacher: What are some reasons why individuals might choose to voluntarily seek therapy?', 'Voluntary treatment means the person chooses to attend therapy to obtain relief from symptoms.']
['Teacher: Where are some of the places where psychological treatment can take place?', 'Psychological treatment can occur in a variety of places.']

['Teacher: Can you provide some examples of community mental health centers that offer psychological treatment?', 'An individual might go to a community mental health center or a practitioner in private or community practice.']

['Teacher: What are some professionals who can provide psychological treatment for children in a school setting?', 'A child might see a school counselor, school psychologist, or school social worker.']
['Teacher: Where are some of the settings where psychological treatment can be provided for incarcerated individuals?', 'An incarcerated person might receive group therapy in prison.']

['Teacher: What are some factors that can determine the type of treatment provider an individual may receive and the licensing requirements they must meet?', 'There are many different types of treatment providers, and licensing requirements vary from state to state.']

['Teacher: What are some additional professions, besides psychologists and psychiatrists, that provide counseling and therapy services?', 'Besides psychologists and psychiatrists, there are clinical social workers, marriage and family therapists, and trained religious personnel who also perform counseling and therapy.']

['Teacher: What are some of the funding sources that pay for mental health treatment today?', 'A range of funding sources pay for mental health treatment: health insurance, government, and private pay.']

['Teacher: How has the coverage for mental health services changed over time, especially for those with health insurance?', 'In the past, even when people had health insurance, the coverage would not always pay for mental health services.']

['Teacher: What was the impact of the Mental Health Parity and Addiction Equity Act of 2008 on the coverage for mental health services for individuals with health insurance?', 'This changed with the Mental Health Parity and Addiction Equity Act of 2008, which requires group health plans and insurers to make sure there is parity of mental health services (U.S. Department of Labor, n.d.).']

['What are some specific examples of the changes brought about by the Mental Health Parity and Addiction Equity Act of 2008 in terms of coverage for mental health services?', 'This means that co-pays, total number of visits, and deductibles for mental health and substance use treatment need to be equal to and cannot be more restrictive or harsher than those for physical illnesses and medical/surgical problems.']

['Teacher: What challenges might individuals face when trying to access mental health treatment in rural areas and low-income urban areas?', 'Finding treatment sources is also not always easy: there may be limited options, especially in rural areas and low-income urban areas; waiting lists; poor quality of care available for indigent patients; and financial obstacles such as co-pays, deductibles, and time off from work.']

['What are some challenges specific to rural areas in terms of accessing mental health treatment?', 'Over 85% of the l,669 federally designated mental health professional shortage areas are rural; often primary care physicians and law enforcement are the first-line mental health providers (Ivey, Scheffler, & Zazzali, 1998), although they do not have the specialized training of a mental health professional, who often would be better equipped to provide care.']

['What are some challenges specific to low-income urban areas in terms of accessing mental health treatment?', 'Availability, accessibility, and acceptability (the stigma attached to mental illness) are all problems in rural areas.']

['Teacher: What is the percentage of individuals with symptoms in low-income urban areas who do not receive any mental health care?', 'Approximately two-thirds of those with symptoms receive no care at all (U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, 2005; Wagenfeld, Murray, Mohatt, & DeBruiynb, 1994).']

['What specific initiative did the U.S. Department of Agriculture announce at the end of 2013 to address the challenges of accessing mental health treatment in rural areas?', 'At the end of 2013, the U.S. Department of Agriculture announced an investment of $50 million to help improve access and treatment for mental health problems as part of the Obama administration’s effort to strengthen rural communities.']

["Teacher: What is one of the primary objectives of therapy regarding a person's destructive patterns and difficult situations?", 'One of the goals of therapy is to help a person stop repeating and reenacting destructive patterns and to start looking for better solutions to difficult situations.']

['Teacher: Can you explain how therapy helps a person in stopping the repetition of destructive patterns and finding better solutions to difficult situations?', 'This goal is reflected in the following poem:']
['Teacher: What are the two types of therapy mentioned in the passage?', 'Two types of therapy are psychotherapy and biomedical therapy.']

['Teacher: How are psychotherapy and biomedical therapy beneficial for individuals with mental health issues?', 'Both types of treatment help people with mental health issues, such as depression, anxiety, and schizophrenia.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a method used in psychotherapy to help individuals overcome personal problems or achieve personal growth?', 'Psychotherapy is a psychological treatment that employs various methods to help someone overcome personal problems, or to attain personal growth.']

['Teacher: What is the term used to describe the evolved form of psychotherapy mentioned in the passage?', 'In modern practice, it has evolved into what is known as psychodynamic therapy, which will be discussed later.']
['Teacher: How does biomedical therapy differ from psychotherapy in terms of treatment methods?', 'Biomedical therapy involves medication and/or medical procedures to treat psychological disorders.']

['Teacher: What is the purpose of exploring the various psychotherapeutic orientations outlined in Table 16.1?', 'First, we will explore the various psychotherapeutic orientations outlined in Table 16.1 (many of these orientations were discussed in the Introduction chapter).']

['Teacher: Who is credited with developing psychoanalysis and what significant role did it play in the field of psychotherapy?', 'Psychoanalysis was developed by Sigmund Freud and was the first form of psychotherapy.']

['Teacher: Why was psychoanalysis considered the dominant therapeutic technique in the early 20th century?', 'It was the dominant therapeutic technique in the early 20th century, but it has since waned significantly in popularity.']

['What are some of the criticisms of psychoanalysis that have led to its decline in popularity?', 'Freud believed most of our psychological problems are the result of repressed impulses and trauma experienced in childhood, and he believed psychoanalysis would help uncover long-buried feelings.']

['What are some of the techniques used in psychoanalysis, such as free association and dream analysis?', 'In a psychoanalyst’s office, you might see a patient lying on a couch speaking of dreams or childhood memories, and the therapist using various Freudian methods such as free association and dream analysis (Figure 16.9).']
['What happens during the process of free association in psychoanalysis?', 'In free association, the patient relaxes and then says whatever comes to mind at the moment.']

["What is the purpose of the therapist's role in free association during psychoanalysis?", 'However, Freud felt that the ego would at times try to block, or repress, unacceptable urges or painful conflicts during free association.']

['What is the significance of resistance in the process of psychoanalysis and how does it impact the therapy?', 'Consequently, a patient would demonstrate resistance to recalling these thoughts or situations.']
['What is the goal or purpose of dream analysis in psychoanalysis?', 'In dream analysis, a therapist interprets the underlying meaning of dreams.']
['Teacher: What is the typical duration of psychoanalysis as a therapy approach?', 'Psychoanalysis is a therapy approach that typically takes years.']
['Teacher: Why does it typically take years for psychoanalysis to be completed as a therapy approach?', 'Over the course of time, the patient reveals a great deal about himself to the therapist.']

['Why do patients develop strong feelings for their therapists during psychoanalysis?', 'Freud suggested that during this patient-therapist relationship, the patient comes to develop strong feelings for the therapist—maybe positive feelings, maybe negative feelings.']

['What is the concept of transference according to Freud in the context of psychoanalysis?', 'Freud called this transference: the patient transfers all the positive or negative emotions associated with the patient’s other relationships to the psychoanalyst.']
['What might happen if Crystal transfers positive feelings from another relationship to her psychoanalyst?', 'For example, Crystal is seeing a psychoanalyst.']

['Why might Crystal seeing her therapist as a father figure during the years of therapy be an example of transference according to Freud?', 'During the years of therapy, she comes to see her therapist as a father figure.']

['What might be the underlying reason for Crystal transferring her feelings about her father onto her therapist?', 'She transfers her feelings about her father onto her therapist, perhaps in an effort to gain the love and attention she did not receive from her own father.']

["Teacher: How has Freud's psychoanalytical perspective been expanded upon?", 'Today, Freud’s psychoanalytical perspective has been expanded upon by the developments of subsequent theories and methodologies: the psychodynamic perspective.']

["Teacher: What is the primary difference between Freud's original psychoanalytical approach and the psychodynamic perspective?", 'This approach to therapy remains centered on the role of people’s internal drives and forces, but treatment is less intensive than Freud’s original model.']

['Teacher: Why is play therapy often used with children instead of traditional talk therapy?', 'Play therapy is often used with children since they are not likely to sit on a couch and recall their dreams or engage in traditional talk therapy.']

["What is the goal of play therapy in terms of client's psychosocial difficulties and growth?", 'This technique uses a therapeutic process of play to “help clients prevent or resolve psychosocial difficulties and achieve optimal growth” (O’Connor, 2000, p. 7).']

['What are some examples of tools or materials commonly used in play therapy?', 'The idea is that children play out their hopes, fantasies, and traumas while using dolls, stuffed animals, and sandbox figurines (Figure 16.10).']
["How can play therapy contribute to a therapist's diagnostic process?", 'Play therapy can also be used to help a therapist make a diagnosis.']

["What insights can a therapist gain by observing a child's interactions with toys during play therapy?", 'The therapist observes how the child interacts with toys (e.g., dolls, animals, and home settings) in an effort to understand the roots of the child’s disturbed behavior.']
['What is the difference between nondirective and directive play therapy?', 'Play therapy can be nondirective or directive.']

['What is the role of the therapist in nondirective play therapy?', 'In nondirective play therapy, children are encouraged to work through their problems by playing freely while the therapist observes (LeBlanc & Ritchie, 2001).']

['What is the purpose of providing structure and guidance in directive play therapy?', 'In directive play therapy, the therapist provides more structure and guidance in the play session by suggesting topics, asking questions, and even playing with the child (Harter, 1977).']
