['Teacher: What approach is used in psychoanalysis to help patients explore their past and uncover repressed feelings?', 'In psychoanalysis, therapists help their patients look into their past to uncover repressed feelings.']

['What is the primary focus of behavior therapy in helping clients?', 'In behavior therapy, a therapist employs principles of learning to help clients change undesirable behaviors—rather than digging deeply into one’s unconscious.']

['What is the main principle behind behavior therapy in helping clients with dysfunctional behaviors?', 'Therapists with this orientation believe that dysfunctional behaviors, like phobias and bedwetting, can be changed by teaching clients new, more constructive behaviors.']
['What are the two types of conditioning techniques that behavior therapy uses to change behavior?', 'Behavior therapy employs both classical and operant conditioning techniques to change behavior.']
['Teacher: Can you explain how classical conditioning techniques are used in behavior therapy?', 'One type of behavior therapy utilizes classical conditioning techniques.']

['Teacher: How do therapists who utilize classical conditioning techniques in behavior therapy view dysfunctional behaviors?', 'Therapists using these techniques believe that dysfunctional behaviors are conditioned responses.']

['What is the goal of therapists who use classical conditioning techniques in behavior therapy?', 'Applying the conditioning principles developed by Ivan Pavlov, these therapists seek to recondition their clients and thus change their behavior.']
['What techniques might therapists using classical conditioning in behavior therapy employ to help Emmie overcome her bedwetting?', 'Emmie is eight years old, and frequently wets her bed at night.']

['How might therapists using classical conditioning techniques in behavior therapy help Emmie overcome her bedwetting?', 'She’s been invited to several sleepovers, but she won’t go because of her problem.']

["What would be the purpose of using a liquid-sensitive bed pad and alarm as part of the therapy for Emmie's bedwetting?", 'Using a type of conditioning therapy, Emmie begins to sleep on a liquid-sensitive bed pad that is hooked to an alarm.']
['What is the purpose of the alarm waking up Emmie when moisture touches the liquid-sensitive bed pad?', 'When moisture touches the pad, it sets off the alarm, waking up Emmie.']

["How does the association between urinary relaxation and waking up stop Emmie's bedwetting?", 'When this process is repeated enough times, Emmie develops an association between urinary relaxation and waking up, and this stops the bedwetting.']

['What is the significance of Emmie being able to go three weeks without wetting her bed and looking forward to her first sleepover?', 'Emmie has now gone three weeks without wetting her bed and is looking forward to her first sleepover this weekend.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how counterconditioning works in behavior therapy?', 'One commonly used classical conditioning therapeutic technique is counterconditioning: a client learns a new response to a stimulus that has previously elicited an undesirable behavior.']
['What are two examples of counterconditioning techniques used in behavior therapy?', 'Two counterconditioning techniques are aversive conditioning and exposure therapy.']
['What does exposure therapy aim to accomplish in behavior therapy?', 'Aversive conditioning uses an unpleasant stimulus to stop an undesirable behavior.']
['What is the primary goal of aversive conditioning in behavior therapy?', 'Therapists apply this technique to eliminate addictive behaviors, such as  smoking, nail biting, and drinking.']

['What are some examples of addictive behaviors that can be targeted with aversive conditioning in behavior therapy?', 'In aversion therapy, clients will typically engage in a specific behavior (such as nail biting) and at the same time are exposed to something unpleasant, such as a mild electric shock or a bad taste.']

['How can exposure therapy be effective in helping individuals overcome phobias and anxieties?', 'After repeated associations between the unpleasant stimulus and the behavior, the client can learn to stop the unwanted behavior.']

['Teacher: Can you provide some examples of the effectiveness of aversion therapy in treating alcoholism?', 'Aversion therapy has been used effectively for years in the treatment of alcoholism (Davidson, 1974; Elkins, 1991; Streeton & Whelan, 2001).']
['What is one example of a chemically based substance used in aversion therapy for treating alcoholism?', 'One common way this occurs is through a chemically based substance known as Antabuse.']

['What are some of the side effects that occur when a person takes Antabuse and consumes alcohol?', 'When a person takes Antabuse and then consumes alcohol, uncomfortable side effects result including nausea, vomiting, increased heart rate, heart palpitations, severe headache, and shortness of breath.']

['What is the purpose of repeatedly pairing Antabuse with alcohol in aversion therapy for treating alcoholism?', 'Antabuse is repeatedly paired with alcohol until the client associates alcohol with unpleasant feelings, which decreases the client’s desire to consume alcohol.']

['What is the benefit of creating a conditioned aversion to alcohol in the treatment of alcoholism using Antabuse?', 'Antabuse creates a conditioned aversion to alcohol because it replaces the original pleasure response with an unpleasant one.']

['Teacher: What is the main objective of a therapist in exposure therapy?', 'In exposure therapy, a therapist seeks to treat clients’ fears or anxiety by presenting them with the object or situation that causes their problem, with the idea that they will eventually get used to it.']
['Teacher: How does a therapist facilitate exposure therapy?', 'This can be done via reality, imagination, or virtual reality.']

['Teacher: Who is credited with first reporting exposure therapy in 1924 and is often referred to as the mother of behavior therapy?', 'Exposure therapy was first reported in 1924 by Mary Cover Jones, who is considered the mother of behavior therapy.']
["What was the outcome of Mary Cover Jones' work with Peter in exposure therapy?", 'Jones worked with a boy named Peter who was afraid of rabbits.']

["What approach did Mary Cover Jones use to replace Peter's fear of rabbits with a conditioned response of relaxation?", 'Her goal was to replace Peter’s fear of rabbits with a conditioned response of relaxation, which is a response that is incompatible with fear (Figure 16.11).']

['How did Mary Cover Jones gradually expose Peter to the rabbit while he was eating his afternoon snack?', 'Jones began by placing a caged rabbit on the other side of a room with Peter while he ate his afternoon snack.']

['What was the purpose of gradually moving the rabbit closer to Peter while he was eating his snack in exposure therapy?', 'Over the course of several days, Jones moved the rabbit closer and closer to where Peter was seated with his snack.']

["What was the timeline for Peter's progress in exposure therapy with the rabbit?", 'After two months of being exposed to the rabbit while relaxing with his snack, Peter was able to hold the rabbit and pet it while eating (Jones, 1924).']

["Teacher: Who refined Mary Cover Jones's techniques and gave us systematic desensitization?", 'Thirty years later, Joseph Wolpe (1958) refined Jones’s techniques, giving us systematic desensitization.']

['What is the purpose of creating a hierarchy of anxiety in the systematic desensitization technique?', 'Using this method, a person creates a hierarchy of anxiety, ranging from the least-anxiety-producing stimulus to the feared object.']

['What is the role of relaxation techniques in the systematic desensitization process?', 'These activities are paired with relaxation techniques, which are taught to the client beforehand and used during the graduated exposures.']
['What is the underlying principle behind the use of relaxation techniques in systematic desensitization?', 'The idea is that a person cannot be nervous and relaxed at the same time.']

['What is the main goal of systematic desensitization?', 'Therefore, if they can learn to relax when they are facing environmental stimuli that make them nervous or fearful, they can eventually eliminate the unwanted fear response.']
['What does Figure 16.12 in the textbook illustrate?', '(Figure 16.12).']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example of someone experiencing a specific fear or phobia?', 'For example, Jayden is terrified of elevators.']

['Teacher: Why do you think Jayden is afraid of elevators even though nothing bad has ever happened to him on one?', 'Nothing bad has ever happened to him on an elevator, but he’s so afraid of elevators that he will always take the stairs.']

["Teacher: How do you think Jayden's fear of elevators is currently affecting his daily life?", 'That wasn’t a problem when Jayden worked on the second floor of an office building, but now he has a new job—on the 29th floor of a skyscraper in downtown Los Angeles.']

['Teacher: What type of therapy do you think the behavior therapist might use to help Jayden overcome his fear of elevators?', 'Jayden knows he can’t climb 29 flights of stairs in order to get to work each day, so he decided to see a behavior therapist for help.']

["What is the purpose of constructing a hierarchy of elevator-related situations in behavior therapy for Jayden's fear of elevators?", 'The therapist asks Jayden to first construct a hierarchy of elevator-related situations that elicit fear and anxiety.']

["What is the process or goal of using the hierarchy of elevator-related situations in behavior therapy for Jayden's fear of elevators?", 'They range from situations of mild anxiety such as being nervous around the other people in the elevator, to the fear of getting an arm caught in the door, to panic-provoking situations such as getting trapped or the cable snapping.']
["What do you think the therapist's goal is in using progressive relaxation with Jayden in behavior therapy?", 'Next, the therapist uses progressive relaxation.']

['What is the purpose or goal of teaching Jayden progressive relaxation in behavior therapy for his fear of elevators?', 'They teach Jayden how to relax each of his muscle groups so that he achieves a drowsy, relaxed, and comfortable state of mind.']

["What does the therapist ask Jayden to do once he's in a drowsy, relaxed, and comfortable state of mind in behavior therapy?", 'Once he’s in this state, the therapist asks Jayden to imagine a mildly anxiety-provoking situation.']

['What does the therapist ask Jayden to do once he imagines a mildly anxiety-provoking situation in behavior therapy?', 'Jayden is standing in front of the elevator thinking about pressing the call button.']
['Teacher: What does Jayden do if this scenario causes him anxiety?', 'If this scenario causes Jayden anxiety, he lifts his finger.']
['Teacher: What does the therapist instruct Jayden to do after he lifts his finger?', 'The therapist would then tell Jayden to forget the scene and return to his relaxed state.']

['Teacher: How does behavior therapy aim to help Jayden reduce his anxiety in response to the scenario?', 'They repeat this scenario over and over until Jayden can imagine himself pressing the call button without anxiety.']

['What techniques are used in behavior therapy to help Jayden become desensitized to each situation on his hierarchy?', 'Over time the therapist and Jayden use progressive relaxation and imagination to proceed through all of the situations on Jayden’s hierarchy until he becomes desensitized to each one.']

['What is the purpose of Jayden and the therapist practicing what he previously envisioned in therapy?', 'After this, Jayden and the therapist begin to practice what he only previously envisioned in therapy, gradually going from pressing the button to actually riding an elevator.']

['What is the ultimate goal of behavior therapy in this scenario?', 'The goal is that Jayden will soon be able to take the elevator all the way up to the 29th floor of his office without feeling any anxiety.']

['Teacher: What alternative approach might a therapist use when it is not possible to re-create anxiety-producing situations in behavior therapy?', 'Sometimes, it’s too impractical, expensive, or embarrassing to re-create anxiety- producing situations, so a therapist might employ virtual reality exposure therapy by using a simulation to help conquer fears.']

['How does virtual reality exposure therapy help in treating anxiety disorders?', 'Virtual reality exposure therapy has been used effectively to treat numerous anxiety disorders such as the fear of public speaking, claustrophobia (fear of enclosed spaces), aviophobia (fear of flying), and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), a trauma and stressor-related disorder (Gerardi, Cukor, Difede, Rizzo, & Rothbaum, 2010).']
['Teacher: What can you tell me about the use of operant conditioning in behavior therapies?', 'Some behavior therapies employ operant conditioning.']
["Teacher: That's correct! Can you provide an example of how operant conditioning is used in behavior therapies?", 'Recall what you learned about operant conditioning:']
['Teacher: Excellent! Can you provide an example of how reinforcement is used in behavior therapies to encourage desired behaviors?', 'We have a tendency to repeat behaviors that are reinforced.']
['What happens to behaviors that are no longer reinforced in behavior therapies?', 'They become extinguished.']

['Teacher: How can the principles of operant conditioning be applied in behavior therapies to help people with psychological problems?', 'These principles, defined by Skinner as operant conditioning, can be applied to help people with a wide range of psychological problems.']
['Teacher: What is one popular operant conditioning intervention called in behavior therapy?', 'One popular operant conditioning intervention is called the token economy.']

['Teacher: Can you explain how the token economy works in behavior therapy and what individuals are reinforced with?', 'This involves a controlled setting where individuals are reinforced for desirable behaviors with tokens, such as a poker chip, that can be exchanged for items or privileges.']

['Teacher: How does the use of a token economy benefit individuals in psychiatric hospitals in terms of cooperation and activity levels?', 'Token economies are often used in psychiatric hospitals to increase patient cooperation and activity levels.']

['How can the use of a token economy system encourage patients in psychiatric hospitals to engage in positive behaviors?', 'Patients are rewarded with tokens when they engage in positive behaviors (e.g., making their beds, brushing their teeth, coming to the cafeteria on time, and socializing with other patients).']

['What are some examples of the privileges or rewards that patients in psychiatric hospitals can exchange their tokens for in a token economy system?', 'They can later exchange the tokens for extra TV time, private rooms, visits to the canteen, and so on (Dickerson, Tenhula, & Green-Paden, 2005).']
['Teacher: What is the main focus of cognitive therapy?', 'Cognitive therapy is a form of psychotherapy that focuses on how a person’s thoughts lead to feelings of distress.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why cognitive therapy emphasizes the connection between thoughts, feelings, and behaviors?', 'The idea behind cognitive therapy is that how you think determines how you feel and act.']

['Teacher: How do cognitive therapists help their clients alleviate distress in cognitive therapy?', 'Cognitive therapists help their clients change dysfunctional thoughts in order to relieve distress.']
['Teacher: What role does cognitive distortion play in cognitive therapy?', 'They help a client see how they misinterpret a situation (cognitive distortion).']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example of overgeneralization in cognitive therapy?', 'For example, a client may overgeneralize.']

['Teacher: How would a cognitive therapist address the overgeneralization in this example to help the client alleviate distress?', 'Because a person failed one test in Psychology 101, they feel stupid and worthless.']
['Teacher: What would a cognitive therapist do to address these thoughts and help their client alleviate distress?', 'These thoughts then cause their mood to worsen.']

['Teacher: How would a cognitive therapist help their client recognize and challenge the thoughts that are blown out of proportion?', 'Therapists also help clients recognize when they blow things out of proportion.']

['How would a cognitive therapist help Ray challenge and reframe his thought about failing the entire course and flunking out of college?', 'Because Ray failed his Psychology 101 test, he has concluded that he’s going to fail the entire course and probably flunk out of college altogether.']

['What strategies or techniques might a cognitive therapist use to help Ray challenge and reframe his thought about failing the entire course and flunking out of college?', 'These errors in thinking have contributed to Ray’s feelings of distress.']

['How can a cognitive therapist help Ray challenge and reframe his thought about failing the entire course and flunking out of college?', 'His therapist will help him challenge these irrational beliefs, focus on their illogical basis, and correct them with more logical and rational thoughts and beliefs.']
['Teacher: Who is the psychiatrist that developed cognitive therapy in the 1960s?', 'Cognitive therapy was developed by psychiatrist Aaron Beck in the 1960s.']

["Who was Aaron Beck's initial focus on when he developed cognitive therapy in the 1960s?", 'His initial focus was on depression and how a client’s self-defeating attitude served to maintain a depression despite positive factors in her life (Beck, Rush, Shaw, & Emery, 1979) (Figure 16.13).']

['What are some techniques that a cognitive therapist can use to help a client recognize and challenge dysfunctional ideas?', 'Through questioning, a cognitive therapist can help a client recognize dysfunctional ideas, challenge catastrophizing thoughts about themselves and their situations, and find a more positive way to view things (Beck, 2011).']

['Teacher: What is the main focus of cognitive-behavioral therapists compared to other forms of psychotherapy?', 'Cognitive-behavioral therapists focus much more on present issues than on a patient’s childhood or past, as in other forms of psychotherapy.']

['What are some characteristics of rational emotive therapy (RET) and who founded it?', 'One of the first forms of cognitive-behavioral therapy was rational emotive therapy (RET), which was founded by Albert Ellis and grew out of his dislike of Freudian psychoanalysis (Daniel, n.d.).']

["Who were some other influential behaviorists that influenced Albert Ellis's therapeutic approach?", 'Behaviorists such as Joseph Wolpe also influenced Ellis’s therapeutic approach (National Association of Cognitive-Behavioral Therapists, 2009).']

['Teacher: How does cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) assist clients in understanding the relationship between their thoughts and behavior?', 'Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) helps clients examine how their thoughts affect their behavior.']

['What are some specific techniques or strategies used in cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) to address cognitive distortions and self-defeating behaviors?', 'It aims to change cognitive distortions and self-defeating behaviors.']
['What is the main goal of cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT)?', 'In essence, this approach is designed to change the way people think as well as how they act.']

['What is the difference between cognitive therapy and cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) in terms of their approach to helping individuals change their thinking patterns?', 'It is similar to cognitive therapy in that CBT attempts to make individuals aware of their irrational and negative thoughts and helps people replace them with new, more positive ways of thinking.']

['How does cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) distinguish itself from behavior therapies in terms of its approach to helping individuals change their thinking patterns?', 'It is also similar to behavior therapies in that CBT teaches people how to practice and engage in more positive and healthy approaches to daily situations.']

['What are some examples of psychological disorders that have been shown to be effectively treated by cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT)?', 'In total, hundreds of studies have shown the effectiveness of cognitive-behavioral therapy in the treatment of numerous psychological disorders such as depression, PTSD, anxiety disorders, eating disorders, bipolar disorder, and substance abuse (Beck Institute for Cognitive Behavior Therapy, n.d.).']

['How has cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) been found to be effective in decreasing levels of hopelessness and suicidal thoughts in previously suicidal teenagers?', 'For example, CBT has been found to be effective in decreasing levels of hopelessness and suicidal thoughts in previously suicidal teenagers (Alavi, Sharifi, Ghanizadeh, & Dehbozorgi, 2013).']

['What are some populations in which cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) has been found to be effective in reducing symptoms of PTSD?', 'Cognitive-behavioral therapy has also been effective in reducing PTSD in specific populations, such as transit workers (Lowinger & Rombom, 2012).']

['Teacher: How does cognitive-behavioral therapy aim to address cognitive distortions and self-defeating behaviors?', 'Cognitive-behavioral therapy aims to change cognitive distortions and self-defeating behaviors using techniques like the ABC model.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how the ABC model is applied in cognitive-behavioral therapy to address cognitive distortions and self-defeating behaviors?', 'With this model, there is an Action (sometimes called an activating event), the Belief about the event, and the Consequences of this belief.']

['Teacher: How might the ABC model be used in cognitive-behavioral therapy to address cognitive distortions and self-defeating behaviors in the scenario involving Jon and Joe at a party?', 'Let’s say Jon and Joe both go to a party.']

['Teacher: What would be the possible activating event (Action) in this scenario involving Jon and Joe at the party?', 'Jon and Joe each have met an interesting person at the party and spend a few hours chatting with them.']

["What might be the beliefs of Jon and Joe about the refusal to exchange phone numbers with the person they've been talking to at the end of the party?", "At the end of the party, Jon and Joe ask to exchange phone numbers with the person they've been talking to, and the request is refused."]

["What could be the possible consequences of Jon and Joe's belief about the refusal to exchange phone numbers with the person they've been talking to?", 'Both Jon and Joe are surprised, as they thought things were going well.']
["What technique or intervention could be used in cognitive-behavioral therapy to challenge Jon's negative self-beliefs?", 'Let’s say Jon tells himself he is a loser, or is ugly, or “has no game.”']

["Teacher: How might a therapist use cognitive restructuring to challenge Jon's negative self-beliefs in cognitive-behavioral therapy?", 'Jon then gets depressed and decides not to go to another party, which starts a cycle that keeps him depressed.']

["What is the possible cognitive restructuring technique that a therapist might use to challenge Jon's negative self-beliefs in cognitive-behavioral therapy and break the cycle of depression?", 'Joe tells himself that he had bad breath, goes out and buys a new toothbrush, goes to another party, and meets someone new.']

["Teacher: How do Jon's beliefs about what happened affect his state of mind, and what is the result of these beliefs?", 'Jon’s belief about what happened results in a consequence of further depression, whereas Joe’s belief does not.']
['What is the consequence of Jon internalizing the attribution or reason for the rebuffs?', 'Jon is internalizing the attribution or reason for the rebuffs, which triggers his depression.']

["What is the difference between Jon and Joe's thinking patterns regarding the cause of the rebuffs?", 'On the other hand, Joe is externalizing the cause, so his thinking does not contribute to feelings of depression.']

['What does cognitive-behavioral therapy focus on when examining thoughts and cognitive distortions?', 'Cognitive-behavioral therapy examines specific maladaptive and automatic thoughts and cognitive distortions.']

['What are some examples of cognitive distortions that Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy examines?', 'Some examples of cognitive distortions are all-or-nothing thinking, overgeneralization, and jumping to conclusions.']

['What is an example of all-or-nothing thinking that Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy examines?', 'In overgeneralization, someone takes a small situation and makes it huge—for example, instead of saying, “This particular person was not interested in me,” the man says, “I am ugly, a loser, and no one is ever going to be interested in me.”']

['Teacher: Can you explain what cognitive distortion refers to in the context of cognitive-behavioral therapy?', 'All or nothing thinking, which is a common type of cognitive distortion for people suffering from depression, reflects extremes.']

['Teacher: How does the cognitive distortion of all or nothing thinking manifest itself in the thoughts and beliefs of individuals suffering from depression?', 'In other words, everything is black or white.']

["Teacher: How does the cognitive distortion of all or nothing thinking impact Jon's thoughts and beliefs about dating and relationships?", 'After being turned down for a date, Jon begins to think, “No woman will ever go out with me.']
["Teacher: Based on Jon's thoughts and beliefs, what kind of cognitive distortion is he experiencing in terms of his dating and relationships?", 'I’m going to be alone forever.”']
["How does the cognitive distortion of catastrophizing affect Jon's emotions and feelings about his future?", 'He begins to feel anxious and sad as he contemplates his future.']

['Teacher: What is the third kind of distortion in cognitive-behavioral therapy that involves assuming negative thoughts or reactions from others without any evidence?', 'The third kind of distortion involves jumping to conclusions—assuming that people are thinking negatively about you or reacting negatively to you, even though there is no evidence.']
['Teacher: Can you provide an example of jumping to conclusions in the context of Savannah and Hillaire?', 'Consider the example of Savannah and Hillaire, who recently met at a party.']
["Teacher: How might jumping to conclusions distort Savannah's thoughts or reactions about Hillaire in this situation?", 'They have a lot in common, and Savannah thinks they could become friends.']

['Teacher: What could be a possible negative thought or reaction that Savannah might assume about Hillaire after calling her for coffee, due to jumping to conclusions?', 'She calls Hillaire to invite her for coffee.']

['Teacher: What negative thought or reaction might Savannah assume about Hillaire after leaving her a message and not receiving a response, due to jumping to conclusions?', 'Since Hillaire doesn’t answer, Savannah leaves her a message.']

["Teacher: How might jumping to conclusions affect Savannah's feelings or reactions towards Hillaire after not receiving a response to the message?", 'Several days go by and Savannah never hears back from her potential new friend.']

["What kind of distortion is the student describing when they suggest possible reasons for Hillaire not responding to Savannah's message?", 'Maybe Hillaire never received the message because she lost her phone or she is too busy to return the phone call.']

["What impact does jumping to conclusions have on Savannah's beliefs about Hillaire not responding to her message?", 'But if Savannah believes that Hillaire didn’t like Savannah or didn’t want to be her friend, she is demonstrating the cognitive distortion of jumping to conclusions.']
['Teacher: "Can you share with us what the client said about his cognitive-behavioral therapy?"', 'One client said this about his cognitive-behavioral therapy:']
['Teacher: What is the main focus of humanistic psychology in relation to helping individuals?', 'Humanistic psychology focuses on helping people achieve their potential.']

["Teacher: That's correct! In humanistic therapy, what are the specific techniques used to help individuals achieve self-awareness and acceptance?", 'So it makes sense that the goal of humanistic therapy is to help people become more self-aware and accepting of themselves.']

['What specific techniques are used in humanistic therapy to help individuals achieve self-awareness and acceptance?', 'In contrast to psychoanalysis, humanistic therapists focus on conscious rather than unconscious thoughts.']

["What are the key differences between humanistic therapy and psychoanalysis in terms of their focus on thoughts and patient's timeline?", 'They also emphasize the patient’s present and future, as opposed to exploring the patient’s past.']

['Teacher: Can you tell me the name of the therapeutic orientation developed by psychologist Carl Rogers?', 'Psychologist Carl Rogers developed a therapeutic orientation known as Rogerian, or client-centered therapy.']
['What is another name for Rogerian therapy, as coined by psychologist Carl Rogers?', 'Note the change from patients to clients.']

['Why did Carl Rogers prefer to use the term "clients" instead of "patients" in his therapy approach?', 'Rogers (1951) felt that the term patient suggested the person seeking help was sick and looking for a cure.']

['What term did Carl Rogers use to describe his therapy approach?', 'Since this is a form of nondirective therapy, a therapeutic approach in which the therapist does not give advice or provide interpretations but helps the person to identify conflicts and understand feelings, Rogers (1951) emphasized the importance of the person taking control of his own life to overcome life’s challenges.']
['Teacher: What technique does the therapist use in client-centered therapy?', 'In client-centered therapy, the therapist uses the technique of active listening.']
['Teacher: How does the therapist demonstrate active listening in client-centered therapy?', 'In active listening, the therapist acknowledges, restates, and clarifies what the client expresses.']

['Teacher: Can you explain what Rogers meant by unconditional positive regard in client-centered therapy?', 'Therapists also practice what Rogers called unconditional positive regard, which involves not judging clients and simply accepting them for who they are.']

['Teacher: How are genuineness, empathy, and acceptance demonstrated by therapists in client-centered therapy according to Rogers?', 'Rogers (1951) also felt that therapists should demonstrate genuineness, empathy, and acceptance toward their clients because this helps people become more accepting of themselves, which results in personal growth.']
['Teacher: What is the significance of these questions for individuals contemplating therapy?', 'For anyone considering therapy, these are important questions.']

['Teacher: Can you please explain what the three factors are that the American Psychological Association states are important for successful treatment?', 'According to the American Psychological Association, three factors work together to produce successful treatment.']

['Teacher: How does evidence-based treatment contribute to successful therapy according to the American Psychological Association?', 'The first is the use of evidence-based treatment that is deemed appropriate for your particular issue.']

['Teacher: Can you elaborate on how the therapeutic alliance is important for successful therapy, as identified by the American Psychological Association?', 'The second important factor is the clinical expertise of the psychologist or therapist.']
['What are the three factors identified by the American Psychological Association for successful treatment?', 'The third factor is your own characteristics, values, preferences, and culture.']

['How does psychotherapy help individuals in improving their situation?', 'Many people begin psychotherapy feeling like their problem will never be resolved; however, psychotherapy helps people see that they can do things to make their situation better.']
['What are some common issues that psychotherapy can help individuals address?', 'Psychotherapy can help reduce a person’s anxiety, depression, and maladaptive behaviors.']

['What are some specific benefits of psychotherapy mentioned in the passage?', 'Through psychotherapy, individuals can learn to engage in healthy behaviors designed to help them better express emotions, improve relationships, think more positively, and perform more effectively at work or school.']
['Teacher: Could you provide some examples of the studies that have examined the effectiveness of psychotherapy?', 'Many studies have explored the effectiveness of psychotherapy.']

['Teacher: Can you describe any specific findings from the large-scale study that examined the effectiveness of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) in treating different psychological disorders?', 'For example, one large-scale study that examined 16 meta-analyses of CBT reported that it was equally effective or more effective than other therapies in treating PTSD, generalized anxiety disorder, depression, and social phobia (Butlera, Chapmanb, Formanc, & Becka, 2006).']

['What were the specific findings from the study regarding the effectiveness of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) in treating depression compared to prescription medication and a placebo rate?', 'Another study found that CBT was as effective at treating depression (43% success rate) as prescription medication (50% success rate) compared to the placebo rate of 25% (DeRubeis et al., 2005).']

['What were the findings from the meta-analysis regarding the effectiveness of psychodynamic therapy compared to Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) in treating psychological issues?', 'Another meta-analysis found that psychodynamic therapy was also as effective at treating these types of psychological issues as CBT (Shedler, 2010).']

['What do studies suggest about the effectiveness of different psychotherapeutic approaches compared to one another?', 'However, no studies have found one psychotherapeutic approach more effective than another (Abbass, Kisely, & Kroenke, 2006; Chorpita et al., 2011), nor have they shown any relationship between a client’s treatment outcome and the level of the clinician’s training or experience (Wampold, 2007).']

['What is one critical factor that determines the success of psychotherapy regardless of the type of treatment chosen?', 'Regardless of which type of psychotherapy an individual chooses, one critical factor that determines the success of treatment is the person’s relationship with the psychologist or therapist.']

['Teacher: What are some examples of biologically based treatments or psychotropic medications that can be prescribed to treat mental disorders?', 'Individuals can be prescribed biologically based treatments or psychotropic medications that are used to treat mental disorders.']

['Teacher: Can you provide some specific examples of biologically based treatments or psychotropic medications that are commonly prescribed for mental disorders?', 'While these are often used in combination with psychotherapy, they also are taken by individuals not in therapy.']
['Teacher: How does the use of biologically based treatments or psychotropic medications relate to biomedical therapy for mental disorders?', 'This is known as biomedical therapy.']

['What is the role of psychotropic medications in biomedical therapy for mental disorders?', 'Medications used to treat psychological disorders are called psychotropic medications and are prescribed by medical doctors, including psychiatrists.']

['What are some examples of psychotropic medications commonly used in biomedical therapy for mental disorders?', 'In Louisiana and New Mexico, psychologists are able to prescribe some types of these medications (American Psychological Association, 2014).']
['Teacher: Can you elaborate on the different types and classes of medications used in biomedical therapies?', 'Different types and classes of medications are prescribed for different disorders.']

["Teacher: That's correct! Can you provide some examples of medications that are commonly used as mood stabilizers in bipolar disorder treatment?", 'An individual with depression might be given an antidepressant, an individual with bipolar disorder might be given a mood stabilizer, and an individual with schizophrenia might be given an antipsychotic.']

['What is the purpose of giving antidepressants, mood stabilizers, and antipsychotics to individuals with psychological disorders?', 'These medications treat the symptoms of a psychological disorder by altering the levels or effects of neurotransmitters.']

['What are some examples of mood stabilizers and antipsychotics commonly used in the treatment of psychological disorders?', 'For example, each type of antidepressant affects a different neurotransmitter, such as SSRI (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor) antidepressants that increase the level of the neurotransmitter serotonin, and SNRI (serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor) antidepressants that increase the levels of both serotonin and norepinephrine.']

['What are some common side effects of mood stabilizers and antipsychotics used in the treatment of psychological disorders?', 'They can help people feel better so that they can function on a daily basis, but they do not cure the disorder.']
['What is the purpose of prescribing psychotropic medications for a short period of time?', 'Some people may only need to take a psychotropic medication for a short period of time.']

['What factors might determine whether a person needs to take psychotropic medication for a short period of time or a long time?', 'Others with severe disorders like bipolar disorder or schizophrenia may need to take psychotropic medication for a long time.']

['Teacher: How are psychotropic medications typically used in combination with psychotherapy for the treatment of disorders?', 'Psychotropic medications are a popular treatment option for many types of disorders, and research suggests that they are most effective when combined with psychotherapy.']

['Teacher: Can you explain why research suggests that psychotropic medications are most effective when combined with psychotherapy?', 'This is especially true for the most common mental disorders, such as depressive and anxiety disorders (Cuijpers et al, 2014).']

['Teacher: What are some important considerations individuals should keep in mind when considering adding medication as a treatment option for mental disorders?', 'When considering adding medication as a treatment option, individuals should know that some psychotropic medications have very concerning side effects.']

['Teacher: What can individuals find in Table 16.2 regarding psychotropic medications and their potential side effects?', 'Table 16.2 shows the commonly prescribed types of medications, how they are used, and some of the potential side effects that may occur.']

['Teacher: Can you tell me about the treatment that is occasionally used in biomedical therapies and was previously referred to as electroshock therapy?', 'Another biologically based treatment that continues to be used, although infrequently, is electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) (formerly known by its unscientific name as electroshock therapy).']

['Teacher: What is another name for electroconvulsive therapy (ECT), which is occasionally used as a treatment in biomedical therapies?', 'It involves using an electrical current to induce seizures to help alleviate the effects of severe depression.']

['What is the purpose of using electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) in the treatment of severe depression?', 'The exact mechanism is unknown, although it does help alleviate symptoms for people with severe depression who have not responded to traditional drug therapy (Pagnin, de Queiroz, Pini, & Cassano, 2004).']
['What percentage of people treated with electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) typically show improvement?', 'About 85% of people treated with ECT improve (Reti, n.d.).']

['What factor has led to electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) being implemented as a last resort?', 'However, the memory loss associated with repeated administrations has led to it being implemented as a last resort (Donahue, 2000; Prudic, Peyser, & Sackeim, 2000).']

['What is transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) and when is it typically used in the treatment of depression?', 'A more recent alternative is transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS), a procedure approved by the FDA in 2008 that uses magnetic fields to stimulate nerve cells in the brain to improve depression symptoms; it is used when other treatments have not worked (Mayo Clinic, 2012).']

['Teacher: What is the purpose of conducting an intake when a person seeks treatment?', 'Once a person seeks treatment, whether voluntarily or involuntarily, they have an intake done to assess their clinical needs.']
['Teacher: What does the intake process involve for a therapist during their first meeting with a client?', 'An intake is the therapist’s first meeting with the client.']

['Teacher: What are some specific pieces of information that the therapist gathers during the intake process?', 'The therapist gathers specific information to address the client’s immediate needs, such as the presenting problem, the client’s support system, and insurance status.']

['Teacher: What are some important topics that the therapist discusses with the client during the first meeting regarding the treatment process?', 'The therapist informs the client about confidentiality, fees, and what to expect in treatment.']

["What factors can influence a therapist's decision to disclose confidential information to a third party?", 'Confidentiality means the therapist cannot disclose confidential communications to any third party unless mandated or permitted by law to do so.']

['What are some examples of treatment goals that a therapist and client may discuss during the intake process?', 'During the intake, the therapist and client will work together to discuss treatment goals.']
['What are some factors that may be taken into consideration when formulating a treatment plan?', 'Then a treatment plan will be formulated, usually with specific measurable objectives.']

["What are some common treatment modalities that may be included in a therapist's treatment plan?", 'Also, the therapist and client will discuss how treatment success will be measured and the estimated length of treatment.']

["What are the most common types of therapy modalities included in a therapist's treatment plan?", 'There are several different modalities of treatment (Figure 16.14): Individual therapy, family therapy, couples therapy, and group therapy are the most common.']

['Teacher: What is the typical duration of a session in individual therapy?', 'In individual therapy, also known as individual psychotherapy or individual counseling, the client and clinician meet one-on-one (usually from 45 minutes to 1 hour).']

['What are some common frequencies of individual therapy sessions?', 'These meetings typically occur weekly or every other week, and sessions are conducted in a confidential and caring environment (Figure 16.15).']

['What are some goals that clients may set for themselves in individual therapy?', 'The clinician will work with clients to help them explore their feelings, work through life challenges, identify aspects of themselves and their lives that they wish to change, and set goals to help them work towards these changes.']

['What factors might determine the length of time a client attends individual therapy sessions?', 'A client might see a clinician for only a few sessions, or the client may attend individual therapy sessions for a year or longer.']

['What are some potential reasons why a client might attend individual therapy sessions for a longer period of time?', 'The amount of time spent in therapy depends on the needs of the client as well as her personal goals.']

['Teacher: What is the purpose of a clinician meeting together with several clients with similar problems in group therapy?', 'In group therapy, a clinician meets together with several clients with similar problems (Figure 16.16).']

['Teacher: Why is it particularly important to match clients for age and problems when children are placed in group therapy?', 'When children are placed in group therapy, it is particularly important to match clients for age and problems.']

['Teacher: What are some of the benefits of group therapy in terms of reducing shame and isolation for clients?', 'One benefit of group therapy is that it can help decrease a client’s shame and isolation about a problem while offering needed support, both from the therapist and other members of the group (American Psychological Association, 2014).']

['Teacher: How can group therapy help a nine-year-old sexual abuse victim who may feel embarrassed and ashamed?', 'A nine-year-old sexual abuse victim, for example, may feel very embarrassed and ashamed.']

['Teacher: How can the experience of being in a group with other sexually abused boys in group therapy help the nine-year-old sexual abuse victim feel more supported and understood?', 'If he is placed in a group with other sexually abused boys, he will realize that he is not alone.']

['What kind of group therapy would be suitable for a child struggling with poor social skills?', 'A child struggling with poor social skills would likely benefit from a group with a specific curriculum to foster special skills.']

['What are the potential benefits of group therapy for a woman suffering from post-partum depression?', 'A woman suffering from post-partum depression could feel less guilty and more supported by being in a group with similar women.']
['Teacher: What are some specific limitations of group therapy mentioned in the textbook passage?', 'Group therapy also has some specific limitations.']

['Teacher: What are some reasons why members of a group therapy session might be afraid to speak openly?', 'Members of the group may be afraid to speak in front of other people because sharing secrets and problems with complete strangers can be stressful and overwhelming.']
['What are some possible consequences of personality clashes and arguments among group members in a group therapy session?', 'There may be personality clashes and arguments among group members.']

['What are some potential negative effects of confidentiality breaches in a group therapy session?', 'There could also be concerns about confidentiality: Someone from the group might share what another participant said to people outside of the group.']

['Teacher: What is one advantage of members confronting each other about their patterns in group therapy?', 'Another benefit of group therapy is that members can confront each other about their patterns.']

['What is an example of a specific type of problem for which group therapy is recommended?', 'For those with some types of problems, such as sexual abusers, group therapy is the recommended treatment.']
['What are some of the benefits of group therapy for sexual abusers?', 'Group treatment for this population is considered to have several benefits:']
['Teacher: Can you please explain what groups that have a strong educational component are called?', 'Groups that have a strong educational component are called psycho-educational groups.']

['What are some examples of topics that a psycho-educational group for children whose parents have cancer might discuss?', 'For example, a group for children whose parents have cancer might discuss in depth what cancer is, types of treatment for cancer, and the side effects of treatments, such as hair loss.']
['What are some advantages of conducting group therapy sessions for children in a school setting?', 'Often, group therapy sessions with children take place in school.']

['What are some benefits of conducting group therapy sessions in a school setting as opposed to other settings?', 'They are led by a school counselor, a school psychologist, or a school social worker.']

['What are some examples of topics that a psycho-educational group for children in a school setting might focus on?', 'Groups might focus on test anxiety, social isolation, self-esteem, bullying, or school failure (Shechtman, 2002).']

['What is the overall effectiveness of group therapy with children facing various challenges, regardless of the setting?', 'Whether the group is held in school or in a clinician’s office, group therapy has been found to be effective with children facing numerous kinds of challenges (Shechtman, 2002).']

["Teacher: What is the purpose or benefit of the entire group reflecting on an individual's problem or difficulties during a group therapy session?", 'During a group session, the entire group could reflect on an individual’s problem or difficulties, and others might disclose what they have done in that situation.']

["Teacher: Why is it important for the focus of the group therapy session to be on everyone's participation and benefit rather than solely on one individual?", 'When a clinician is facilitating a group, the focus is always on making sure that everyone benefits and participates in the group and that no one person is the focus of the entire session.']

['Why is the organization and structure of a group therapy session important for its success?', 'Groups can be organized in various ways: some have an overarching theme or purpose, some are time-limited, some have open membership that allows people to come and go, and some are closed.']
['What are the advantages and disadvantages of structured and unstructured group therapy sessions?', 'Some groups are structured with planned activities and goals, while others are unstructured:']

['Teacher: What are some advantages of structured group therapy sessions compared to unstructured ones?', 'There is no specific plan, and group members themselves decide how the group will spend its time and on what goals it will focus.']

['What are some disadvantages of unstructured group therapy sessions compared to structured ones?', 'This can become a complex and emotionally charged process, but it is also an opportunity for personal growth (Page & Berkow, 1994).']
['Teacher: What is the main purpose of couples therapy?', 'Couples therapy involves two people in an intimate relationship who are having difficulties and are trying to resolve them (Figure 16.17).']
['What types of relationships can benefit from couples therapy?', 'The couple may be dating, partnered, engaged, or married.']

['Teacher: What is the primary therapeutic orientation used in couples counseling?', 'The primary therapeutic orientation used in couples counseling is cognitive-behavioral therapy (Rathus & Sanderson, 1999).']
['Teacher: What are some of the reasons why couples may seek couples therapy?', 'Couples meet with a therapist to discuss conflicts and/or aspects of their relationship that they want to change.']

['Teacher: How does the therapist assist the couple in understanding the impact of their individual backgrounds, beliefs, and actions on their relationship?', 'The therapist helps them see how their individual backgrounds, beliefs, and actions are affecting their relationship.']

['How can the therapist help the couple implement strategies for a healthier and happier relationship?', 'Often, a therapist tries to help the couple resolve these problems, as well as implement strategies that will lead to a healthier and happier relationship, such as how to listen, how to argue, and how to express feelings.']

['What is one potential outcome for a couple after working with a therapist in couples therapy?', 'However, sometimes, after working with a therapist, a couple will realize that they are too incompatible and will decide to separate.']

['What are the two main reasons why couples may seek couples therapy?', 'Some couples seek therapy to work out their problems, while others attend therapy to determine whether staying together is the best solution.']

['What are some of the challenges that therapists might face when counseling couples in a high-conflict and volatile relationship?', 'Counseling couples in a high-conflict and volatile relationship can be difficult.']

['What analogy do Peter Pearson and Ellyn Bader use to describe the experience of a therapist in couples therapy for high-conflict and volatile relationships?', 'In fact, psychologists Peter Pearson and Ellyn Bader, who founded the Couples Institute in Palo Alto, California, have compared the experience of the clinician in couples’ therapy to be like “piloting a helicopter in a hurricane” (Weil, 2012, para. 7).']
['Teacher: What is family therapy and what does it consist of?', 'Family therapy is a special form of group therapy, consisting of one or more families.']
['What are some of the theoretical orientations in family therapy?', 'Although there are many theoretical orientations in family therapy, one of the most predominant is the systems approach.']

['What is the main perspective or belief in the systems approach to family therapy?', 'The family is viewed as an organized system, and each individual within the family is a contributing member who creates and maintains processes within the system that shape behavior (Minuchin, 1985).']
['What role does each member of the family play in the systems approach to family therapy?', 'Each member of the family influences and is influenced by the others.']
['What is the goal of the systems approach to family therapy?', 'The goal of this approach is to enhance the growth of each family member as well as that of the family as a whole.']

['Teacher: What are some of the consequences that can arise from dysfunctional patterns of communication between family members?', 'Often, dysfunctional patterns of communication that develop between family members can lead to conflict.']

['Teacher: Why might a family with dysfunctional patterns of communication choose to attend therapy together instead of individually?', 'A family with this dynamic might wish to attend therapy together rather than individually.']

['Teacher: What potential benefits can arise from attending family therapy together when one member of the family has problems affecting everyone?', 'In many cases, one member of the family has problems that detrimentally affect everyone.']

['Teacher: What are some potential ways in which family therapy can help address the problems that are affecting all members of the family?', 'For example, a mother’s depression, teen daughter’s eating disorder, or father’s alcohol dependence could affect all members of the family.']

['What are some specific goals that a therapist might have when working with a family in family therapy to address the problems affecting all members?', 'The therapist would work with all members of the family to help them cope with the issue, and to encourage resolution and growth in the case of the individual family member with the problem.']

['Teacher: Who typically participates in family therapy?', 'With family therapy, the nuclear family (i.e., parents and children) or the nuclear family plus whoever lives in the household (e.g., grandparent) come into treatment.']
['What is the purpose of including additional family members, such as grandparents, in family therapy sessions?', 'Family therapists work with the whole family unit to heal the family.']
['What are some examples of the different types of family therapy?', 'There are several different types of family therapy.']

['What is the focus of structural family therapy and what aspects of the family are examined and discussed by the therapist?', 'In structural family therapy, the therapist examines and discusses the boundaries and structure of the family: who makes the rules, who sleeps in the bed with whom, how decisions are made, and what are the boundaries within the family.']

['In what ways can structural family therapy help address issues in which parents do not work together to make rules or undermine each other?', 'In some families, the parents do not work together to make rules, or one parent may undermine the other, leading the children to act out.']
['How does structural family therapy help parents in resolving issues and improving communication?', 'The therapist helps them resolve these issues and learn to communicate more effectively.']

['Teacher: What is the main objective of strategic family therapy?', 'In strategic family therapy, the goal is to address specific problems within the family that can be dealt with in a relatively short amount of time.']

['What is the role of the therapist in strategic family therapy?', 'Typically, the therapist would guide what happens in the therapy session and design a detailed approach to resolving each member’s problem (Madanes, 1991).']
['Teacher: How is addiction commonly perceived in terms of its nature and duration?', 'Addiction is often viewed as a chronic disease (Figure 16.18).']

['What factors contribute to a person becoming driven to use drugs and/or alcohol?', 'The choice to use a substance is initially voluntary; however, because chronic substance use can permanently alter the neural structure in the prefrontal cortex, an area of the brain associated with decision-making and judgment, a person becomes driven to use drugs and/or alcohol (Muñoz-Cuevas, Athilingam, Piscopo, & Wilbrecht, 2013).']
['Why do relapse rates tend to be high for individuals with substance-related and addictive disorders?', 'This helps explain why relapse rates tend to be high.']

['Teacher: What percentage of individuals with substance-related and addictive disorders typically experience relapse?', 'About 40%–60% of individuals relapse, which means they return to abusing drugs and/or alcohol after a period of improvement (National Institute on Drug Abuse [NIDA], 2008).']

['Teacher: What is the main objective of substance-related treatment for individuals struggling with addiction?', 'The goal of substance-related treatment is to help a person with an addiction stop compulsive drug-seeking behaviors (NIDA, 2012).']

['What is the reasoning behind the need for long-term treatment for individuals with substance addiction?', 'This means a person with addiction will need long-term treatment, similar to a person battling a chronic physical disease such as hypertension or diabetes.']
['Teacher: What are some common components of substance-related treatment?', 'Treatment usually includes behavioral therapy and/or medication, depending on the individual (NIDA, 2012).']

['Teacher: Can you provide some examples of specialized therapies that have been developed for specific types of substance-related disorders?', 'Specialized therapies have also been developed for specific types of substance-related disorders, including alcohol, cocaine, and opioids (McGovern & Carroll, 2003).']

['What is one benefit of substance-related treatment compared to incarceration or not treating individuals with addictions?', 'Substance-related treatment is considered much more cost-effective than incarceration or not treating those with addictions (NIDA, 2012) (Figure 16.19).']
['Teacher: What is it that makes substance-related treatment much more effective?', 'Specific factors make substance-related treatment much more effective.']
['What other specific factors contribute to the effectiveness of substance-related treatment?', 'One factor is duration of treatment.']

['Teacher: Can you give an example of a recommended duration for substance-related treatment to achieve a positive outcome?', 'Generally, a person with addict needs to be in treatment for at least three months to achieve a positive outcome (Simpson, 1981; Simpson, Joe, & Bracy, 1982; NIDA, 2012).']

['Why is it important for a person with addiction to undergo treatment for at least three months?', 'This is due to the psychological, physiological, behavioral, and social aspects of abuse (Simpson, 1981; Simpson et al., 1982; NIDA, 2012).']

['How does behavior therapy in substance-related treatment contribute to helping a person with addiction?', 'While in treatment, a person with addiction might receive behavior therapy, which can help motivate the person with addiction to participate in the treatment program and teach strategies for dealing with cravings and how to prevent relapse.']

['What are some other aspects that treatment for a person with addiction should address besides the drug addiction?', 'Also, treatment needs to be holistic and address multiple needs, not just the drug addiction.']

['What are some factors that a holistic treatment for a person with addiction should address?', 'This means that treatment will address factors such as communication, stress management, relationship issues, parenting, vocational concerns, and legal concerns (McGovern & Carroll, 2003; NIDA, 2012).']

['Teacher: What is the most widespread treatment modality for substance-related disorders?', 'While individual therapy is used in the treatment of substance-related disorders, group therapy is the most widespread treatment modality (Weiss, Jaffee, de Menil, & Cogley, 2004).']

['Teacher: What is the rationale behind using group therapy for addiction treatment?', 'The rationale behind using group therapy for addiction treatment is that people with addiction are much more likely to maintain sobriety in a group format.']

['Teacher: What are some of the possible rewarding and therapeutic benefits of group therapy for addiction treatment?', 'It has been suggested that this is due to the rewarding and therapeutic benefits of the group, such as support, affiliation, identification, and even confrontation (Center for Substance Abuse Treatment, 2005).']

['What are some important factors to consider when treating substance-related disorders in teenagers?', 'For teenagers, the whole family often needs to participate in treatment to address issues such as family dynamics, communication, and relapse prevention.']
['Teacher: Why is family involvement considered vital in the treatment of teen drug addiction?', 'Family involvement in teen drug addiction is vital.']

['Teacher: What does research suggest about the correlation between parental involvement and reduction in substance use by teenagers?', 'Research suggests that greater parental involvement is correlated with a greater reduction in use by teen substance abusers.']

['What are some potential benefits of mothers participating in treatment for teen substance abuse?', 'Also, mothers who participated in treatment displayed better mental health and greater warmth toward their children (Bertrand et al., 2013).']

['What does the research suggest about the comparative effectiveness of individual therapy and group therapy for treating substance-related disorders?', 'However, neither individual nor group therapy has been found to be more effective (Weiss et al., 2004).']

['What is the primary focus of treatment for substance-related disorders?', 'Regardless of the type of treatment service, the primary focus is on abstinence or at the very least a significant reduction in use (McGovern & Carroll, 2003).']

['Teacher: What are some common medications used in the treatment of addiction to detox a person safely after an overdose and manage withdrawal symptoms?', 'Treatment also usually involves medications to detox a person with addiction safely after an overdose, to prevent seizures and agitation that often occur in detox, to prevent reuse of the drug, and to manage withdrawal symptoms.']
['Teacher: Why is it common for treatment of addiction to involve the use of medications?', 'Getting off drugs often involves the use of drugs—some of which can be just as addictive.']
['Teacher: Why is detox considered difficult and dangerous?', 'Detox can be difficult and dangerous.']

["Teacher: What is commonly found in addition to a person's addiction to drugs and/or alcohol?", 'Frequently, a person with an addiction to drugs and/or alcohol has an additional psychological disorder.']
['What does it mean when we say a person has comorbid disorders?', 'Saying a person has comorbid disorders means the individual has two or more diagnoses.']

['What are some examples of psychiatric diagnoses that can co-occur with a substance-related diagnosis in individuals with comorbid disorders?', 'This can often be a substance-related diagnosis and another psychiatric diagnosis, such as depression, bipolar disorder, or schizophrenia.']

['What challenges do individuals with comorbid disorders, such as depression, bipolar disorder, or schizophrenia combined with substance-related diagnosis, often face?', 'These individuals fall into the category of mentally ill and chemically addicted (MICA)—their problems are often chronic and expensive to treat, with limited success.']

['What is the correlation between illicit drug use or prescription drug misuse and mood or anxiety disorders in comparison to the overall population?', 'Compared with the overall population, people who use illicit drugs or misuse prescription drugs are twice as likely to have a mood or anxiety disorder.']

['Why do people with debilitating symptoms of a psychiatric disorder sometimes self-medicate and misuse substances?', 'Drug use can cause symptoms of mood and anxiety disorders and the reverse is also true—people with debilitating symptoms of a psychiatric disorder may self-medicate and misuse substances.']

['Teacher: What is believed to be the most effective approach in treating comorbid disorders?', 'In cases of comorbidity, the best treatment is thought to address both (or multiple) disorders simultaneously (NIDA, 2012).']

['Teacher: Can you explain why behavior therapies are used to treat comorbid disorders?', 'Behavior therapies are used to treat comorbid conditions, and in many cases, psychotropic medications are used along with psychotherapy.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of a psychotropic medication that might be used to treat comorbid disorders?', 'For example, evidence suggests that bupropion (trade names: Wellbutrin and Zyban), approved for treating depression and nicotine dependence, might also help reduce craving and use of the drug methamphetamine (NIDA, 2011).']

['Teacher: What is the importance of conducting further research on the effectiveness of psychotropic medications for treating comorbid disorders?', 'However, more research is needed to better understand how these medications work—particularly when combined in patients with comorbidities.']

["Teacher: How does the sociocultural perspective approach an individual's behaviors and symptoms?", 'The sociocultural perspective looks at you, your behaviors, and your symptoms in the context of your culture and background.']

["Teacher: How might José's cultural background and traditional family upbringing contribute to his behaviors and symptoms according to the sociocultural perspective?", 'For example, José is an 18-year-old Hispanic male from a traditional family.']

["Teacher: How might the sociocultural perspective explain the influence of José's Hispanic and traditional family background on his experience of depression?", 'José comes to treatment because of depression.']

["Teacher: How might the sociocultural perspective explain the potential impact of José's cultural background and traditional family values on his experience of depression and his apprehension about coming out as gay to his family?", 'During the intake session, he reveals that he is gay and is nervous about telling his family.']

["How might the sociocultural perspective explain the influence of José's religious background and its teachings on his apprehension about coming out as gay to his family?", 'He also discloses that he is concerned because his religious background has taught him that being gay is wrong.']

['Teacher: What does it mean for mental health professionals to develop cultural competence?', 'Mental health professionals must develop cultural competence (Figure 16.20), which means they must understand and address issues of race, culture, and ethnicity.']

['Teacher: What are some of the key aspects for mental health professionals to consider when developing cultural competence?', 'They must also develop strategies to effectively address the needs of various populations for which Eurocentric therapies have limited application (Sue, 2004).']

['Teacher: How can a mental health professional address the needs of populations that Eurocentric therapies may not be well-suited for?', 'For example, a counselor whose treatment focuses on individual decision making may be ineffective at helping a Chinese client with a collectivist approach to problem solving (Sue, 2004).']

['Teacher: What are the objectives of multicultural counseling and therapy in terms of the helping role and process?', 'Multicultural counseling and therapy aims to offer both a helping role and process that uses modalities and defines goals consistent with the life experiences and cultural values of clients.']

['What are the main components of multicultural counseling and therapy?', 'It strives to recognize client identities to include individual, group, and universal dimensions, advocate the use of universal and culture-specific strategies and roles in the healing process, and balances the importance of individualism and collectivism in the assessment, diagnosis, and treatment of client and client systems (Sue, 2001).']

['Teacher: What is the name of the therapeutic perspective that integrates the impact of cultural and social norms, starting at the beginning of treatment?', 'This therapeutic perspective integrates the impact of cultural and social norms, starting at the beginning of treatment.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how therapists using this therapeutic perspective integrate cultural patterns into treatment approaches?', 'Therapists who use this perspective work with clients to obtain and integrate information about their cultural patterns into a unique treatment approach based on their particular situation (Stewart, Simmons, & Habibpour, 2012).']

['Teacher: What are some examples of treatment modalities that can be utilized within the sociocultural therapy approach?', 'Sociocultural therapy can include individual, group, family, and couples treatment modalities.']

['Teacher: Why do ethnic minorities tend to utilize mental health services less frequently than White, middle-class Americans?', 'Statistically, ethnic minorities tend to utilize mental health services less frequently than White, middle-class Americans (Alegría et al., 2008; Richman, Kohn-Wood, & Williams, 2007).']

['Teacher: What are some potential reasons for the lower utilization of mental health services among ethnic minorities compared to White, middle-class Americans?', 'Perhaps the reason has to do with access and availability of mental health services.']

['Do ethnic minorities and individuals of low socioeconomic status (SES) face specific barriers to accessing mental health services?', 'Ethnic minorities and individuals of low socioeconomic status (SES) report that barriers to services include lack of insurance, transportation, and time (Thomas & Snowden, 2002).']

['What are some of the specific barriers that ethnic minorities and individuals of low socioeconomic status (SES) face when trying to access mental health services?', 'However, researchers have found that even when income levels and insurance variables are taken into account, ethnic minorities are far less likely to seek out and utilize mental health services.']

['What are some possible explanations for the continued disparities in mental health service utilization among ethnic minorities, even when access is comparable across different racial and ethnic groups?', 'And when access to mental health services is comparable across ethnic and racial groups, differences in service utilization remain (Richman et al., 2007).']

['Teacher: What did the study find about the prevalence rates of anorexia among different races?', 'In a study involving thousands of women, it was found that the prevalence rate of anorexia was similar across different races, but that bulimia nervosa was more prevalent among Hispanic and African American women when compared with non-Hispanic']
['What did the study find about the prevalence rates of bulimia nervosa among different races?', 'White people (Marques et al., 2011).']

['Why do Hispanic and African American women with eating disorders tend to seek and engage in treatment less than White women?', 'Although they have similar or higher rates of eating disorders, Hispanic and African American women with these disorders tend to seek and engage in treatment far less than White women.']

['What are some factors that may contribute to the lower rates of seeking and engaging in treatment among Hispanic and African American women with eating disorders compared to White women?', 'These findings suggest ethnic disparities in access to care, as well as clinical and referral practices that may prevent Hispanic and African American women from receiving care, which could include lack of bilingual treatment, stigma, fear of not being understood, family privacy, and lack of education about eating disorders.']
['Teacher: What factors can contribute to the imbalance in accessing mental health services?', 'Perceptions and attitudes toward mental health services may also contribute to this imbalance.']

["Teacher: Can you provide examples of the complex reasons why people may not seek treatment for mental health issues according to the study at King's College, London?", 'A recent study at King’s College, London, found many complex reasons why people do not seek treatment: self-sufficiency and not seeing the need for help, not seeing therapy as effective, concerns about confidentiality, and the many effects of stigma and shame (Clement et al., 2014).']

['Teacher: Can you provide any other examples of barriers to treatment for mental health issues that have been identified in research studies?', 'And in another study, African Americans exhibiting depression were less willing to seek treatment due to fear of possible psychiatric hospitalization as well as fear of the treatment itself (Sussman, Robins, & Earls, 1987).']

['Teacher: Can you provide any examples of how cultural beliefs and practices can act as barriers to seeking mental health treatment?', 'Instead of mental health treatment, many African Americans prefer to be self-reliant or use spiritual practices (Snowden, 2001; Belgrave & Allison, 2010).']

['Teacher: How does the Black church play a role in addressing mental health issues within the African American community?', 'For example, it has been found that the Black church plays a significant role as an alternative to mental health services by providing prevention and treatment-type programs designed to enhance the psychological and physical well-being of its members (Blank, Mahmood, Fox, & Guterbock, 2002).']

['Teacher: What are some reasons why people belonging to ethnic groups might be less likely to seek services for a mental illness?', 'Additionally, people belonging to ethnic groups that already report concerns about prejudice and discrimination are less likely to seek services for a mental illness because they view it as an additional stigma (Gary, 2005; Townes, Cunningham, & Chavez-Korell, 2009; Scott, McCoy, Munson, Snowden, & McMillen, 2011).']

['Why might people belonging to ethnic groups view seeking services for a mental illness as an additional stigma?', 'For example, in one recent study of 462 older Korean Americans (over the age of 60) many participants reported suffering from depressive symptoms.']

['Teacher: Why did many older Korean Americans view depression as a sign of personal weakness and having a mentally ill family member as bringing shame to the family?', 'However, 71% indicated they thought depression was a sign of personal weakness, and 14% reported that having a mentally ill family member would bring shame to the family (Jang, Chiriboga, & Okazaki, 2009).']
['Teacher: What is considered as a further barrier to treatment?', 'Language differences are a further barrier to treatment.']

['Teacher: Can you provide an example of how language differences can act as a barrier to treatment?', 'In the previous study on Korean Americans’ attitudes toward mental health services, it was found that there were no Korean-speaking mental health professionals where the study was conducted (Orlando and Tampa, Florida) (Jang et al., 2009).']

['Teacher: How can therapists and psychologists address the barrier of language differences to provide effective treatment to individuals from ethnically diverse backgrounds?', 'Because of the growing number of people from ethnically diverse backgrounds, there is a need for therapists and psychologists to develop knowledge and skills to become culturally competent (Ahmed, Wilson, Henriksen, & Jones, 2011).']

['Teacher: How can therapists and psychologists develop cultural competence to address the barrier of language differences in providing effective treatment to individuals from ethnically diverse backgrounds?', 'Those providing therapy must approach the process from the context of the unique culture of each client (Sue & Sue, 2007).']
Average
